description:
A16 is a really solid Italian restaurant in the Marina. I came here for dinner and was seated at the chef's counter (always the best seat in the house and it's a treat to see the chefs prepare pizza and the entrees in a wood fired oven).

The meal included the heirloom cucumber salad, half order of the pasta special that night (perfectly cooked carbonara with truffle), the chicken meatballs with beans and garlic on the side and strawberry panna cotta for dessert.  I really wanted to try a pizza but, alas, I was already stuffed by the end of the meatballs.  

It's really good food but it's not the best Italian I've had in SF (the pork and veal meatballs at Zero zero are better and I would go to Cotogna or SPQR for pasta).  Service was so-so but the ambiance definitely exuded the Marina vibe.  With tax and tip, this ended up being $115.  Overall, I think four stars is about right and I would recommend this place if you are craving Italian food and are in the neighborhood.
author: Andrew S.

description:
This restaurant has really gone down hill since the days of Nate Appleman as head chef of this restaurant.....I flew in from LA and took my wife here for dinner. It had been several years since I had been....The place was packed and the ambience was the same. However the bar area greeted you with an unclean odor....

We sat in the very rear of the restaurant and ordered a Roma style Pizza, Squid Ink pasta, and the chicken meatballs. and apple salad. 

The apple salad came out first and that was simple and good....

The Roma style pizza was next and the dough and crust had the same great flavor I always remembered, however the anchovy paste on the pizza was over the top salty.......

Next came the meatballs and cannelloni beans......The meatballs were basic....similar to what you would get in a prepackaged container at Trader Joes.....the Cannelini beans were smashed.....(I thought they would come out whole) and poorly executed.

When we tried the squid ink Pasta it was undercooked and had no flavor....we had to return it......we thought we woudl re-order something else but the service was so slow we just decided to leave...my wife left the restaurant hungry.

The service was extremely unattentive and unprofessional lacking in any formalities you would expect from a restaurant of this caliber.......

A16 you broke my heart, you used to be one of my favorites....but you have fallen, a far cry from your glory days.......it's sad to see
author: Justin C.

description:
The ambience of this place is solid and the staff is both personable and knowledgeable but this is the worst meal I have eaten at a restaurant in years. 

I ordered the squid ink pasta and paid nearly $30 for a dish that lacked protein and featured poorly cooked tomatoes and garlic slices. It was a lazy attempt at a dish that should have excited- I feel like I could recreate this meal easily after spending less than $8 on ingredients at the grocery store after work on a random Tuesday. I also ordered the salad to start which was drenched in dressing and underwhelming at best.

To say the least I've had better quality food ANYWHERE else and I've had finer Italian cuisine at Olive Garden. 

I'd recommend the wine here and that's about it.
author: PK E.

description:
Between how long they've been around and how well regarded they've consistently been, it's not exactly shocking to see how many reviews A16 has accumulated over the years.  Which, in turn, largely explains their popularity and why it's historically been so tough to get a table here.  That is, until as of late it seems; after seeing available reservations pop up more and more often on OpenTable, it was like a sign that the time had finally come to check this place out!  However belated it might be...

Although the restaurant looked rather dark when we first stepped inside, I really enjoyed the vibe of the space.  Yes, it's loud, but I liked the dim and cozy vibe, as well as how you can sit at the counter and watch the open kitchen at work (the back patio space looked really nice, as well).  Most importantly though, the menu looked terrific - lots of starters, pastas, pizzas, and meats/entrees to choose from, alongside the "Black Truffle & Grana Padano Festival" specials they had going on as well.

-- BURRATA with Olive Oil, Sea Salt, and Crostini...$18
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a16-san-francisco-4?select=VOSywV-8zhNTY0D3YthrSQ)
Burrata is a must for me whenever I see it and, fortunately, this didn't disappoint - the cheese was flavorful, stringy, and not very watery.  Also,  while a couple of the crostinis were borderline burnt, they complemented the burrata and olive oil very well!

-- ZUCCA with Summer Squash, Pancetta, Crema di Cipolla, and Pecorino...$20
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a16-san-francisco-4?select=VjkGIjBvA4kVfeXAw-Eufw)
I had heard the pizzas at A16 were quite good and I can certainly see why!  The pancetta (there was so much), crema, squash, and cheese created this delicious mix of flavors.  What's more, the crust was terrific - slightly thick and just a touch salty.  Yum!

-- CASSARECCIA - Ragu Bianco, White Wine, Grana Padano...$26 (full order)
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a16-san-francisco-4?select=4qFdq2Ajex_DKft0M4Bw6g)
My least favorite dish of the night.  On the plus side, the pasta was well-cooked and the grana padano was tasty.  On the other, the sauce wasn't very good and the meat in the ragu had a weird/gritty taste and texture to it.

-- CAPUNTI - Preserved Egg Yolk, Summer Squash, Grana Padano, Black Umbrian Summer Truffle...$24
(https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a16-san-francisco-4?select=Yv5z1pNQwkSAqJz6eLZsJg)
I was pretty hopeful for this dish (it was our one pick from their festival specials), but sadly, it didn't stand out.  The noodles were perfect, and I liked the truffles, but the sauce didn't pack much of a punch otherwise.  Not bad, just not super memorable.

Beyond the food, service here was pretty solid.  Our server wasn't over the top friendly, but she and the rest of the staff were still pretty nice and accommodating.  I just wonder the food was like when Nate Appleman was here; his views on SF diners aside, his time was when A16 seemed to get more notoriety.  Our food certainly wasn't awful, but it'd be fair to say I was hoping for more.

Given how good the pizza and burrata were, I wouldn't mind coming back for those two, especially to sit in the back patio area on a date.  However, with so many great alternatives out there now, I'd be hard pressed to round up from THREE AND A HALF STARS.
author: Mike L.

description: Really good Italian food and a really hot vibe. Restaurant was packed on a Thursday nite. We had a great meal pasta was delicious wine extremely good. Hip and cool place for a group or for two. I'd definitely check this one out. A little off the beaten path but worth the trip.
author: John W.

description:
Decent pizza and other Italian food, but not really anything special enough to justify the price.

My friends and I got a nice little table in their back courtyard, which was a fun setting as it had a spacious feel without actually being exposed to the outdoors.  Getting our food did take a little while though, so you may be sacrificing service somewhat by sitting out here.

I had the white pizza with prosciutto and mushrooms, and added arugula.  The crust had a good quality and the ingredients themselves were all fresh, but the overall flavor felt a bit flat.  Adding some spice helped, and I ended up requesting lemons to give the pizza a bit of acid.  It was pretty enjoyable with these additions, but not really enough of a treat to justify the price.  

You'll probably enjoy your meal here and it's a pretty nice setting if you're looking for something more upscale, but I'd personally prefer to check out some of the legit Italian places in North Beach that can offer better quality in a more casual environment.
author: Neal C.

description: This is a popular restaurant. Although it was crowded the service was reasonable. We did not find the food to our liking. The prosciutto dish was ok. However the mushroom pizza was small with much less mushroom than depicted on some of the pictures. The crust was too chewy. Finally the squid ink tonnarelli was small despite us ordering the large portion. The meal was relatively very expensive for what we were served.
author: Meng L.

description: No reason that A16 deserves 3.5 stars. The food, ambience, and wine list are exactly what you want from a neighborhood gem. If I was to be critical I'd love for them to have cocktails but hey, can't have it all. Grab a bar seat in the back and watch the kitchen staff work their magic. Won't disappoint!
author: Gianna D.

description:
This restaurant is very busy, which means it's very good, right?
Well, not really. The food was very salty, very greasy, the pasta dish tasted like canned corn beef hash mixed in with the pasta.
Desserts were dry. Pork chop was 50% fat.
Avoid A16. It's not worth it!
author: Christina P.

description:
The wood-fired oven aroma permeates out to the sidewalk.  Love that.  

Pasta, pizza, burrata.  Be sure to order all 3.  Pasta al dente, thin pizza crust to perfection, & the burrata is gold standard.   

Bustling, warm vibe, open kitchen.  I've come in on weeknights and on weekends, & honestly every night is busy, but weekend nights are off the hook busy.  Reservations are a must, & even w one you might opt to stay seated at the bar instead of waiting for your table to come up.  It's happened.

Not ideal if you're looking for quiet & private, but there are tables that are more intimate than others.  For instance, the tiny back patio is perfect for romance.  

If you want to watch the kitchen action, you can opt to sit at the chef's counter instead of a table, where you'll have a full view.  Regardless of which area or room you're in, service is always excellent.  

A16 also prides itself on their extensive wine list.  Because...wine & pasta.

The only downer is how busy it gets, & thus the sometimes excruciatingly long wait.  But, champagne problems.

Always a great meal.

4 & 1/2 stars
author: Veronica M.

description:
One of my favorite Italian places in the Marina. I've been on 2-3 Wednesday or Thursday nights without a reservation and have been able to get right in each time. 

The servers are amazing, knowledgable, and know everything about the wine list you could possibly want to ask. 

My favorite things to get here are the pasta, burrata, and any of the pizzas. Fun fact, they do not cut the pizza here, but give your own pair of scissors to cut your own! Love this. Sounds gimmicky, but I find it super fun every time. 

Every pizza I've tried is great, my favorite being the mushroom/prosciutto pizza. The burrata is also perfectly oily and salty... they also give you a very good sized portion for the price (which is a major plus in my opinion!) 

A16 has been in business for over 20 years, so you know you can't go wrong with most dishes! If you're in the neighborhood and craving Italian food you will not be steered dining wrong here.
author: Liz S.

description: This place is WAY OVERRATED! The service was awful - short staffed, overworked, grumpy front desk and food servers. They are just way too busy to give a crap about providing good service. I have no idea why this place is so busy to begin with. I suppose the pizza is alright and perhaps the drink selection. Otherwise, for quality food and great dining - not the place. There are SO many other places in the Marina to go - A16 just has a trendy name and nice outdoor facade. Otherwise, the experience of dining here is nothing special. Avoid it if you can.
author: Ellie W.

description:
We got to sit at the back of the restaurant with some sunlight and green wall. A restaurant with good ambience.

We ordered the funghi pizza with pancetta added. I liked the texture of the pizza dough which had a nice chew to it. The server also brought us some chilli oil to spice things up. 

The squid ink pasta was a little disappointment. I was expecting it to be more tomato-ly but it was more olive base so it was a bit too acidic for my liking. Also I saw in old yelp photos that they did have squid in the pasta but the current versions only came with anchovies.
author: Ava A.

description:
About 10 years ago this we THE restaurant in SF. Sadly as you can see from the reviews, it's gone downhill. 

We live around the corner and hadn't returned to A16 since a subpar meal in 2012. Sadly our visit last night left us in a bad place and we probably won't return unless it's pizza from their stand at Off The Grid. 

We eat very early so we can be home to put our daughter to bed at 7:30pm. 5:30pm reservation, we walked in the door at 5:28pm and the host told us "since we aren't open yet, you can sit at the bar."  Ok, no problem. 

Server was kind at first but then totally forgot about our table. We shared a bottle of wine and I had to pour the entire bottle for ourselves during the duration of the meal. Rookie move from a service side. 

Beet salad was great. Pizza, incredible. But then came the pasta. Totally raw, crunchy. I couldn't believe it. My maiden name is Vetrano, I've spent a decent amount of time in Italy, I'm aware of "al dente". The was raw, under cooked pasta...at an Italian restaurant. 

We called them over and a 24 y/o "manager" came by with a wrinkled, untucked shirt plus rugby knit scarf...suggesting we get another pasta that isn't cooked al dente. Give me a break. 

Sad experience overall. The last piece of feedback: take down the Walgreens Christmas lights that are poorly wrapped around every object in the dinning room and never, ever play the Pandora Pearl Jam station during service. 

What happened to the place?
author: Alison C.

description:
it's been a few years since i've come back to A16, and it's still pretty stinking delicious! came to celebrate one year with boi on a friday night - made the reservation about 3-4 weeks in advance to secure a 7 pm table for 2. we arrived on time for the ressie and were seated immediately. the restaurant was poppin' though - just like i remembered it to always be. the restaurant is beer & wine only with a rather large list of all your italian faves, but we opted for beer and their wine-based cocktails, which were yummy and beautifully presented.  

service was fast, friendly and attentive enough. hard to cover a crowded, bustling room of eager diners, but our lady handled it well.  we perused the menu and made the following selections - burrata (add proscuitto for $6), two pizzas - sausage and funghi, and a side of cauliflower (i would skip this next time). we ended with the chocolate budino, served with olive oil and sea salt, which was a delight.  everything was yummy, and my overly picky dining companion agreed - he said it was his fave pizza in sf, dethroning his previous favorite - montesacro (he later said that it's been so long that he doesnt quite remember why he liked it so much.. rolls eyes**) 

$115 for the above post tax and tip. not bad at all! would return :)
author: Christina L.

description: A16, a highway in Italy, likes this shop name very much and tastes good.I like prosclutto、pork
author: Mizu S.

description: Not great, food was pretty standard. The pizza we ordered required lots of chilli oil to spice things up. Squid ink pasta was overwhelmed by the tomato. Burrata was the best dish by far, and it's burrata.
author: Zhen Y.

description:
The portions are tiny and cost is expensive. The pastas have two prices reflecting small / large portions. I ordered large ink squid pasta, with olives, no meat $27 - the portion was dinky.  I'm not a big eater, and had to confirm with the wait staff that I received the a large.  The pasta was good, cooked al dente.  

The bill came and there was an additional 4% surcharge to cover SF employee health care. That is an employer tax, it should not be charged to customers. It's part of the cost of doing business in SF.
author: E F.

description:
Great upscale italian restaurant in the Marina - definitely the nicest italian restaurant on Chestnut St. It can get super crowded on the weekends, but they take reservations (highly recommend unless you're okay waiting at the bar). The restaurant itself is pretty small/close quarters, but I think it gives it a lively/fun vibe. 
Pizza is thin-crust, neopolitan-style and delicious (and it's served with scissors to cut your own slices!) - you can't go wrong! 
Overall, a great neighborhood staple when you're not feeling the ~trendy/communal table~ experience at Delarosa, but still want some amazing pizza.
author: Catherine S.

description: Meh. This restaurant was ok but there was TONS of confusion. I ordered an arugula salad with stone fruit (to me that's peaches or anything we with a damn stone seed inside) they come back with an arugula salad with Pear! Last time I checked there are No stones in pears. I then ordered a heirloom tomato salad but it included a Burrata (im lacrosse intorlant) so I was confused again. Then I ordered a pork meatballs which were under pasta section so I assumed it was a pasta with meatballs...  nope no pasta.
author: Pau Y Monica C.

description: A16 is one of the best Italian restaurants in San Francisco. I just spent my last birthday at A16, reserving a table with Open table, that made the reservation really easy. The location is in the center of one of the most nice neighborhoods in SF with a lot of bars and attractions for a pre or post dinner time. A16 has elegant interiors and atmosphere. Me and my party had a warm welcome service and even if the restaurant was packed the service was fast and courteous. The food was fenomenal, from the appetizers (we ordered the salumi board and the burrata) to the pizzas and the seconds (we tried the salmon and the steak). They have a very furnished list of wines for all palates and prices. For sure a place that I recommend for every occasion.
author: Sara C.

description: Can't fault the food.. burrata was very good. Romana pizza was spicy with more than enough anchovies and olives. Service was attentive, maybe a little over bearing but...i almost wanted to give this 3* stars. We didn't enjoy the meal. The restaurant is very very noisy, a little cramped, the menu is a little odd. Can't put my finger in precisely why we didn't enjoy it.. But we didn't
author: Ed C.

description: I knows this place has been in the Marina forever and even though the space and service is great, the food is pretty basic. I wanted so badly to like it enough to come back but left feeling like I spent a lot of money for an average meal. Alas, glad I tried it but probably won't be coming back.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
3.5 stars. Been wanting to try this for a while. It's been a popular restaurant in SF for years now. Decided to walk in early one weekday night. They were able to accommodate us in the front dining room. Good, but before returning, I would try SPQR or another place in the Marina.

Service: Very friendly. 

Atmosphere: Less upscale than I expected. The front dining room at least is pretty casual. All high top tables.

Food: 
- Maccaronaro: The ragu was delicious. Really savory and meaty. The pasta was a little too chewy.
- Funghi pizza: Delicious! The crust was so perfect. It was crispy, fluffy and chewy all at once. Also, the presentation was awesome. The pizza came whole with a pair of scissors to cut individual slices off of.
- Romana pizza: Very tomato heavy, a good briny taste from the olives and anchovies, a little too salty.
author: Amanda C.

description: I tried this pizza at Fort Mason Off The Grid in SF, it was delicious!!! Thin crust and it was crispy and flaky on the outer crust, slightly burnt in the best kind of way! Everyone kept coming up to me asking me what I was eating and where I can find it lol it was truly savory. The sauce did not taste like jar marinara, it tasted more like homemade with fresh ingredients. It had fresh basil and various meats with onion, DEFINITELY worth a try.
author: Alejandra A.

description: A friend of a friend suggested that we come here as we were going to be near the Golden Gate bridge. We lucked out and got seated quickly during a crowded dinner service as another group didn't show for their reservation. Limited menu with mainly pizzas and a few other non-pizza dishes. Menus were hard to read under the dim dining room lights. The menus were trying too hard by having all of the names and  most of the key ingredients listed only in Italian. I'm a vegetarian and it's annoying to have to Google the ingredients in order to figure out if you can eat that dish. It took too much effort to decipher the menu. I was also surprised that they were not willing to make any substitutions on their dishes...replacing a white sauce for a tomato sauce on a pizza. So, I ended up frustrated and ordered a standard, safe Margherita pizza instead of trying something new. Our group was also out of luck trying to get a substitute/common replacement when ordering coffee with our  desserts. Seems as if this restaurant is a bit too pretentious for me. Lots of other Italian restaurants to choose from.
author: Ajay P.

description: Ordered a small cup of pork meatballs at the Presidio Picnic. The meatballs were soft and tender, and I was blown away by the marinara and cheese. The prohibitive $13 per cup stops me from getting this again, but it will be well spent for experiencing the taste once.
author: Yen Ting L.

description:
I really, really want to love this place.  The service is superb, 5 stars across the board.  And I am a picky-ass person who notices service.  But....

The front desk was very pleasant, and didn't give us any attitude for being walk-ins (from cultivar, another ehhh).  They only had front bar section available, which was perfect for us....or so we thought.  Noise level was horrendous - the music blared to the point we were screaming at each other, and the staff themselves even commented on it as they were trying to describe the food.  And I'm usually the one defending high noise levels.

The big thing's always the food, and we were not impressed.  Again, there's the 'you cut with cool scissors' pizza, both of which was bland and just ok.  The starters - carrot salad and beet salad, were both pretty good.  Dessert - the chocolate mousse tart was not a hit.

Overall....ehhhhh, but we're not around the Marina for food usually, maybe it's the best it's got to offer.
author: Lola K P.

description:
Pizza is awesome- neopolitan style so a basic crust with a thin bottom showcasing the toppings. Got the funghi and the margharita with pancetta. Both were excellent! Pair that with an app and carafe of wine and you're set!!

Also they serve the pizza with scissors which is ingenious! No more straggly cutting and ruining the cheese and form of the pizza with a knife!
author: Alison L.

description:
I've been here at least 10 times in the past year. It is ALWAYS consistent. Service is flawless. Food is always good. Even great. Adventurous and thoughtful menu. Oh, and you can cut your pizza with scissors. 

Wine list is top notch. Make a reservation. Order a bottle. Stay awhile.
author: Nichole W.

description:
Best pizza in San Fran.  
Great wine list and nice atmosphere
The
Pizza is thin and perfect! I prefer my pizza simple
Dipped in a bit of the spicy oil. 
Appointment were all very good 
Located in a cute area.
author: Kim A.

description:
A16 was yet another restaurant in San Francisco that I wanted to visit for years, but only recently got around to. Reservations weren't too difficult to get booking a few weeks in advance for a Sunday lunch, but they DID fill up quickly after the fact.

THE OVERVIEW.
- Honestly, kind of snooty service. Is this just a nice-place thing in San Francisco now? If so, I hate it
- The restaurant is quite long (rather than wide), and the noise level is off the charts. Being seated in the little greenhouse area mildly helps, but it's very tight quarters
+ The food is absolutely INCREDIBLE here. We dined on delicious marinated olives, trippa napoletana, beet salads, and other tasty antipasti, as well as an order of their meatballs (amazing!). 
~ The bill was a bit high for 3 people, so I can't imagine frequenting this place, but the food was well worth it

The snooty service bothered me the most, especially as I was taking my dad out to lunch. You'd think maybe the servers would be a bit respectful towards their elders, but it felt like my father was a burden to them when it came to ordering, not wanting to really give him the time of day.

Is it just me, or are trendy places in the city kind of treating customers more like cattle and less like humans? I don't know. I'm still a little bitter... The food is the one thing that kept me at 3 stars for this place.
author: Claire S.

description: A16 is a cute little spot in the Marine that I wouldn't have found hadn't it been for Yelp. I love to feast, and the food here is made to order. It may take some time to leave the kitchen, but once it does ... mmmm mmmm mmmm!!!! I always order a bottle of wine for the table whenever I go here with friends. I have yet to be disappointed!!!
author: Ali R.

description:
One word to describe this place and it is delicious. I always start with the shishito peppers which are cooked in lemon and fried breadcrumbs. Then the burrata with sea salt and olive oil is awesome and definitely worth trying. My friend ordered the funghi and the margharita with pancetta pizza and it looked awesome.  For dinner I had the mcfarland springs trout which was cooked to perfection.

I highly recommend this place as the service is great, food is delicious, and it has a great vibe.
author: Robert V.

description: Recommend sitting at the chef's counter. We were treated to a birdseye view of the speedy yet precise artistry of Chef Larry as he prepared and garnished each dish with care and efficiency. We were told he had been there for only a few weeks, but he owned that brick oven and workspace like a boss! Our pizzas were out of this world, and the wine list was extensive but not overwhelming. The burrata was salty yet balanced perfection. We could not have enjoyed our experience at A16 more.
author: Lisa T.

description:
I recommend this place for their homemade pastas. The pizzas are good, but their pastas shine. 

The lemon saffron sauce on the seafood pasta was divine. I would go back just for that pasta. 

Pizzas are thin and good, but a lot of places can do that. 

The wine list is excellent with a lot of rarer Italian regions represented. There were some California wines on the list too. 

Parking in the area is awful, but you probably already knew that. 

The place is loud, so this is not the place for intimate discussions.
author: michelle l.

description:
I would say the food is solidly okay, which isn't great for the price. The price of most menu items is up there, and comparatively I've had better for a similar price. The food portions also aren't huge. 

I had the maccaronara, which was good but didn't blow my mind. It was also my birthday so they nicely gave me a birthday dessert! It was kind of like fancy cookies haha. 

I'd definitely say the environment is fancy and the place has older/wealthier clientele. Everyone there had wine by the bottle, and my friends and I were the youngest ones there. Not somewhere I necessarily see as a young restaurant or even great for families.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
A16 is a great restaurant with a fun ambiance! Perfect spot for date night or a night out with friends! If you want a nice, fun place to go to, but not over the top fancy, then this is the place for you! Plus they have a great bar. I haven't tried the pastas, but I hear they are great. I tried the prosciutto and mushroom pizza, and it was absolutely to die for. It is a white sauce pizza and the mushrooms and prosciutto just go so nicely together. If you want a side or a starter, I recommend the caesar salad. It is a more nuanced caesar, but fantastic. 
Overall, this is a really fun place that is absolutely worth the try. I am definitely coming back, plus Chestnut street in general is very fun, so you can walk down the street afterwards.
author: Abbie S.

description:
This was a birthday celebration and it was chosen for its long-standing reputation as one of the dining gems on Chestnut St. in the Marina.  It may have been great once, but it is a disappointment on multiple counts.
Fairly noisy place and some of the staff are downright unfriendly, including our waiter, Omar, who wasn't much interested in answering our questions about the menu.  More discouraging was the most important factor -- the food itself.  Both pizzas and pastas are good, but portions are small and prices are noticeably high.  A single glass of basic wine starts at around $12 and goes up from there.  This place may have been a destination at one time, but it is fairly average now with a high price tag.
author: John S.

description: Amazing pizza and wine selection! Amazing service and they are happy to help with wine selections because there are SO many! We had the best bottle of wine, coolest pizza eating experience, and amazing chocolate mousse dessert! We will be back
author: Cristina R.

description: We came here on a Christmas day in a small group of 3 and it's not difficult to guess that it was super booked. The pre-set menu/chef's tasting seemed popular (which has to be booked in advance). We got seated at the tall chairs overlooking the chef's preparing the dishes. The service was good and we got help in picking the right wine. We had burrata to start with which was pretty standard. They did serve us additional crostini on request. The pasta with cauliflower and zucca pizza we picked sounded like some new combinations that might be interesting. However, I was let down by the lack of flavor in both the pizza and the pasta. It just had lot of oil/butter. On the other hand, the seafood being prepared by the chefs looked promising. Being left with the limited menu and choices, we could not get the best out of this restaurant.
author: Tejashree M.

description:
I saw A16 on "Check, Please! Bay Area" about 4 years ago and it has been on my list of restaurants to try ever since. We finally decided to try it last night, and it did not disappoint! 

We arrived a few minutes late for our 8:00 p.m. reservation on a Friday night, without incident. I wanted to change our reservation the day of to an earlier time so we could squeeze in the Madea Halloween movie, and I was surprised to find that it was not an option for us - A16 was all booked up on Open Table by then. 

We started with the burrata and acqua pazza, which were excellent choices! We were told we got the last acqua pazza, which was delicious--served in a spicy tomato based broth with all of the seafoods--I would call it a "must-have."  The burrata may be the best I've had to date, largely because (i) it was served at the perfect temperature (room) (ii) with a very high-quality olive oil and a hint of saltiness... yum!  We ordered extra bread so we could sop up every last drop of broth and olive oil, sooooo goood! 

We shared the bavette steak, medium rare, served with cannellini beans, and the pesto bucatini for entrees. Both were delicious. The bucatini was cooked perfectly al dente and the almond pesto was likewise perfectly satisfying. The steak was cooked exactly medium rare and served in a sweet but yummy plum sauce. 

We were so stuffed from those two courses we skipped dessert. Some final notes: Beer and wine only. Dark and loud. Your typical Marina crowd. Service is seamless and efficient. Prices are typical for the area. Not great for parking. 

We were just very pleased.
author: Sunny S.

description: Extremely loud. Three of us ordered the lamb chop which was so gristly we needed sharper knives (but still could not cut through the gristle). Others ordered pasta and the portion was so small it looked like an appetizer.  Service was pleasant but slow. The worst dining experience I've had in years. I won't go back - and do not recommend.
author: Michelle B.

description:
My wife and I used to love coming here when we lived in the City a few years ago, and we were excited to return for a date night. Unfortunately, it seems that something changed in the interim - the food was blander than what we had grown accustomed to in our new hood in Southern Marin (which is not known for its good food). 

We ordered the trout, a pasta dish, and a couple appetizers, none of which were very appetizing. Over all pretty disappointing.
author: Adam M.

description: We had the most amazing experience dining here on Tuesday evening.   From the person who booked our reservation- Helen to the hostess, Di and our server- we celebrated an occasion that surpassed our expectation with a request that was met above and beyond.  This place rocks and we can't thank you enough for your thoughtfulness and your delicious food.
author: Valerie I.

description:
This receives a two for a variety of reasons. Cutting to the chase with the food - very overpriced and bland. The Gem Salad was $15 for some lettuce on a plate. Literally about 6 pieces of lettuce, and light dressing. I've eaten salads all over the world my friends (NY, Paris, LA, SF, Dallas, etc), this should've been priced at $7 for what you get. The meatball soup was pretty good, very fresh in the sense it's a light broth and very minimalistic. Overall I would say just okay, it's saving grace being it seems healthy. The Maccaronara was $16 for a small portion, and it wasn't good at all. Neither the noodle nor the sauce. My boyfriend's lemon gnocchi was bland as well. 

Other issues include how loud the restaurant was and the service. 

It's very very loud inside. We asked to be moved due to the noise. The original waitress we had because of our first table wasn't very accommodating when we asked to move one table over so that we could sit side by side to hear each other. The hostess then came and moved us to the atrium. The new waitress we had in the atrium was great but a little slow on service. The original waitress delivered our food at one point and still had an attitude. I didn't appreciate her irritation when I placed an order for some more wine since I hadn't seen our atrium waitress in a while. 

The wine was pretty good, and perhaps I could see myself stopping in for a glass in the future. But I definitely won't be eating here again.
author: Rachel P.

description:
I had such a great dinner here. Kind of last minute, made a reservation on OpenTable at 7:30PM, for a 9PM spot. The servers were knowledgeable and personable. We got a pasta dish and a pizza dish to share, UM the pizza is served with SCISSORS. Such a fun, authentic touch. 

Also, the wine bottle the server recommended was so good, BRAVO all around.
author: Rachel T.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city and one that I recommend to out of towners. It's consistently good. They have a phenomenal wine list. Everything I've had on the menu is excellent. Their burrata and crostini appetizer is terrific. I love their pizzas and their pastas.
author: Rachel F.

description:
After around 8 visits, I won't be going  
back.  Our experiences have been wildly inconsistent in terms of food, service, and ambiance.  We've had good (never great) meals, and really bland ones.   Portion sizes are tiny relative to price.   The wine list is excellent but expensive.  Service can be excruciatingly slow, and on busy nights sloppy, forgetful, and brusque.  Any time it is busy it is deafeningly loud - to the level of being unable to carry in a conversation.  Last night we were seated a full half hour after our reservation with little apology.  On the positive side, when we've gone there very early (6pm) it's been calm and not as loud - but still with inattentive service.
author: c n.

description:
Had reservations for a large group and was accommodated immediately during the busy dinner rush. 

The staff was incredibly knowledgeable and answered all of our questions from food allergy concerns down to specific questions about wines. 

Ordered almost everything off the menu with our group and all of us were incredibly satisfied. The general consensus was that the Pizza Arrabbiata was off the charts. It was easily our favorite pie of the night. Burrata was very good as well and the sampler appetizer was a huge hit as well. 

I would highly recommend checking this spot out for a great local eat!
author: Ken A.

description:
Several weeks ago we stopped in A16 to see if we would like to return for dinner at a later date. We were greeted by a wonderful woman
who explained the story behind the name. Wish we had got her name.
Tall brunette. We went back some weeks later for dinner and it was not the same great experience. We were put in the obligatory back room. Rather than change we thought is would be quieter than the main area.
It was boring and lacked atmosphere. More important was the food. My pasta with Bolognese had very little if any bolognese. My husband had
the cod which he said was adequate. When dining at A16, which you should, ask to be seated in the main dining area and stick with their pizzas. They look delicious!  We will give them a second chance. But they need to step their game on their pasta dishes.
author: Sally N.

description: Having spoken with the manager, it was an off night and we're giving it another try. She was quite apologetic, and understand mistakes happen. We will update upon the next go.
author: Brett Y.

description: Hugely disappointing family dinner tonight. We've been coming here for 10 years, even did a large party for Christmas Eve 2017. Our server was a sad, mopey, depressive man who dragged his heels and rolled his eyes at us every time he came to the table. The service was so slow, for a party of 4 it took us 2 hours to get 1 salad and 1 pizza. Getting drinks ordered was a chore. Overall, a shitty experience celebrating our cousins 10 year anniversary. We waited 30 mins for the check. Had to beg to leave.
author: Giselle B.

description: When you come here you are really paying for the ambiance the food is great but portions are small if you are trying to do family style. For wine they have an amazing selection. I recommend trying to get a seat in the back patio area.
author: Ranna K.

description: Where's the gluten free pizza ? Wish you could find a way to whip up some of these pizzas. Limited choices on menu otherwise.
author: Kris T.

description: Mediocre pizza for an absurd price. Paid $27 for a margherita pizza with a mound of cold arugula that was dumped on top, that took about 25 minutes to cook.
author: Ben H.

description:
A16 is an absolute favorite! From the stellar service from front to back, to the delicious food & wine and great people watching, we always enjoy. 

Typically we sit at the wine bar, and soak up as much knowledge from the awesome bartender as we can about what we're drinking. My husband is a big beer drinker and enjoys the unusual picks that end up on their list. 

It's worth the trip if you don't live in the Marina: come have a great evening and meal!
author: Kristen B.

description:
I tried A16's pizza booth over at Off The Grid: Fort Mason.  I'm just happy to see that OTGFM finally has a another pizza vendor since Casey's Pizza left two years ago.

On Fort Mason's opening night, their menu had five pizzas along with their house Meatballs and Cannolis for dessert (http://bit.ly/1MfAeO0).  Since Lent is still going on and OTG is on a Friday, I was only limited to their vegetarian pizzas.  Luckily, I went with fellow yelper, Elena N. and we were able to split their Funghi pizza.

Funghi -- http://bit.ly/1TXBZry
White mushrooms, kale, fior de latte, truffled pecorino. garlic, chili
The pizza was good.  The crust had a good chew, but it had a little bit of a burned taste.  It did have a good amount of mushrooms and cheese though.  This was actually my first time have kale on pizza and thought it gave it a bitter taste.  I probably would try this again another time.

So far, I like A16, but I can only give them 3 stars for now since the pizza I had didn't totally blow me away.  I think I might want to try their other pizzas which might be better tasting than their Funghi, and also try their braised pork meatballs which sounded amazing when they described it to me.  So as soon as Lent is over so I can try their meatballs and meat pizzas, I'll update this review with hopefully better results.
author: Rodney H.

description: Always love going to A16. Great food, always. I've never been disappointed. Loud and chatty environment. Everyone enjoying good food and good company.
author: L M.

description:
This review is only for the pizza as we didn't try anything else.  Normally we are gluttons that try and eat our way through an entire menu but we were so overstuffed from a weekend of pigging out that all we could manage was 2 pizzas.  

However the pizzas were the best Neapolitan pizzas I've tried so far in the Bay Area so now I understand the critical acclaim.  Yes they are a little bit pricey for what they are, but who can argue when they taste so good?

We had the Funghi and the Margherita.  I feel like you can always tell how good a place is by the classic Margherita.  You can't hide anything when all you have is the dough, the sauce, the cheese and some basil.  I'm happy to say the sauce was tangy, the cheese was milky/creamy deliciousness, but the star of the show was the smokey, crunchy yet chewy, perfection that is the crust.  The hardest component to get right but boy did they get it right.

The Funghi was equally delicious but had a completely different flavor profile.  Boy were they generous with the mushrooms.  The thing was absolutely smothered.

Service was good and friendly and the decor is the San Francisco chic you are likely accustomed to.

The one main gripe I would have is that the amount of mozzarella was a bit stingy.  Maybe that's deliberate to keep a certain balance and let the sauce or toppings shine, but I definitely wanted more cheese.

Would definitely recommend this to anyone seeking their Neapolitan fix!
author: Tarek S.

description:
This review is for their food stall at Off the Grid: Fort Mason only.

This was my first stop at OtG: FM last Friday, March 4th around 6:30pm. I met up Rodney H who suggested we share a pizza. Since I'm still off red meat, and he can't eat meat on Fridays, we got the Funghi: wild mushrooms, kale, fior di latte, truffled pecorino, garlic, chili ($13). The crust was soft with a nice chew, but I didn't find the slice very flavorful. For a slice without tomato sauce, I wanted it to taste creamier. I felt the slice was kinda dry. There were plenty of mushrooms, but not much truffle flavor.

Since OtG is a food buffet for me, I only had a slice. The pizzas are served on a cardboard round. When I asked about getting a Pizza box, I found out they were a $1. Not wanting to pay a dollar for a box, I asked Rodney if he really wanted to take home the pizza. He ended up just finishing it instead.

Good crust, but I wanted more flavor from the slice. Not sure how the pizzas are in house, but the Funghi from their food stall left me wanting a little more.
author: Elena N.

description:
We are San Francisco locals and have lived here for 10 years. We hadn't gone to A16 for sometime because the last time we were there found it to be mediocre and the staff not too friendly. We had guests visiting from out of town and were happy to bring them to a great Italian spot. First off, the hostess was extremely rude. I figured she was having a bad day, but our waitress was also extremely rude and downright nasty. She literally said, "Are you ready to order or not?" I mean, seriously. The environment was so loud you had to shout across the table, and the food was mediocre at best. They do an amazing job of hype with a cookbook and publicity, but this place is NOT good. Seriously, for much better food, keep looking. If it was at least friendly, I would say well, it was a fun environment. However, with food like that, drop that attitude. Honey, I've eaten pizza in Naples, Italy. And yours is not very good. And, don't treat locals like tourists. We will not be back. Ever.
By the way, if you are visiting and looking for a better spot, there are many much better Italian places in the city. Zero Zero, Delfina, Flour & Water, Delpopolo, etc. Keep looking!
author: Alex L.

description:
Took the family here on a recommendation from two friends and one family member who was in attendance. Granted, neither he or the friends who recommended the place had eaten at the restaurant in over four years so a lot can change in that time. 
The service: we had a reservation, we waited considerably longer than I would typically brush off as no big deal. It was a special occasion so it made it a bit more uncomfortable.
The two hostesses were not polite when we checked in and inquired about our table. They brushed us off and moved on the other people in line waiting to check on their tables. 
When we were finally seated, we realized our server was working two sections. Our tables and the bar overlooking the chefs. I felt for her. She was nice and she was doing her best but we got overlooked a lot. Our drinks took a very long time to arrive. And we had to flag someone down. We were ready to order our meals and finally had to flag someone down for that as well. 
Everyone at our table was understanding of her situation but we were also hungry. They shouldn't have sat so many tables in her section at the same time if they knew they had a lot of reservations, they should have staggered the walk ins better. The people at the table next to us mentioned they'd also been seated for some time and were feeling ignored. 
The food was okay, the pizza Marguerita was the only item we all enjoyed. There were four of us, we ordered four dishes. All four dishes came at different times. Maybe she thought we all wanted to pick at a dish like a four course meal? 
 One of the dishes was made as a pizza instead of a Pasta. It was very loud in there so I get how she heard mushroom pizza instead of pasta. It was really crappy to have to wait even longer than we already had to have the dish made again. The pasta wound up being very flavorless.
Overall, no one was happy with the food or the service.
author: Cheech G.

description: Good spot for a group and while I really love the ambiance and the wine list, food is pretty average. I have had the burrata, the gem salad, margherita pizza, funghi pizza, salsiccia pizza, and macconara pasta. Though I loved all of the ingredients and concepts, when it came together it wasn't all that great, especially for the pricing given the portions.
author: Shabnam E.

description:
SALT - you had better like it if you are going to dine here. Everything is over-salted. We stared with the burrata with sea salt, the whole sea of salt!

I ordered the salmon with summer beans and a side of summer squash.  The beans were over salted and when I sent them back and was told that a new batch would be prepared. The dish was retuned with refrigerator cold beans and a now cold piece of fish. The summer squash was inedible it was so salty.  My date was in full agreement on all of my assessments, so it wasn't just me!  His pizza margherita was good, not exceptional.  The wine by the glass pour is stingy for what they charge, especially since they are $$$ rated (dinner mains over $30.00)

Let's not forget the biscotti - or should I say they'd best be forgotten.  What happened to the second bake (as in twice baked). They were soft, chewy and fairly tasteless.  Not the hard crunchy cookies one anticipates when ordering. 

No wonder you can easily get a reservation here.
author: Hank B.

description:
if you are walking in for a table, I would highly recommend you show the number of people you want a table for in writing and the "owner" see it clearly as she very conveniently would deny it.

The so-called "owner" should focus on getting her reviews in order and drop the condescending tone.
author: Kartik K.

description: I was blown away by how delicious this restaurant was. I'd go back in a heartbeat. All of the dishes were so beautifully presented, and you could taste how fresh the ingredients were. We look forward to going back and ordering two rounds of the prosciutto pallet lol.
author: C K.

description: Love this place.  The food was excellent and the ambiance was great.  Art on the walls was so good too!  We all enjoyed several different dishes and shared so I got to try a lot of things I normally would not have.  Terrific service
author: Kellie B.

description: Our friends made reservations for this place. Very nice find on the NW side of SF. Great place for thin crust pizza and fresh pasta. Great wine list too. Would return next time I'm in town.
author: Thuan D.

description: My sister and I have been coming to A-16 for years. We always get the bianca pizza - it's one of the best pizzas in the city. Great service here, too!
author: Beth T.

description: The service was horrible. They nickel and dime you for everything and the pizza was just ok. Not going back.
author: renee g.

description:
OK, why not five stars?

The deserts rock.  

Maybe the hit-and-miss service? Its a four, but it would not drag down a perfect pizza.

Maybe the fact they are a member of the "The True Neapolitan Pizza Association" and yet its the worst pizza I have ever tried from a member restaurant?  I have tried at least six.  The good news is that despite all this, the pizza is at least as good as any pizza served by a non-member in the USA.  So you guys, you can eat here.  I give you permission.  It is just that I was expecting that much more.
author: Juan J.

description: Delicious, intimate. Mushroom pizza was on point and our waiter, a lovely italian man, was very helpful and insightful.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Lots of cool features to this restaurant: open kitchen, counter dining in front of the open kitchen, cozy bar in front with marble top, sky lights, and the covered patio (where we sat). All of these lend to the experience that will cost you...but if you appreciate unique and creative dishes then this place is for you. 

The first dish was disappointing but the rest was amazing. 

Cencioni (oval-shaped flat disc pasta) Lemony-sage flavor. Pasta was far from al dente - I was really chewing hard! They need to reexamine price. $17 but portion was $12-14 worth. 

Roasted chicken pollette (chicken meatballs)....amazing! Served with a caponata of beautiful flavors coming from golden raisins, pine nuts, and eggplant. 

Salmon- perfectly pan-fried. Flavors came from tangy cucumber spices and seaweed. It was probably a 4oz portion so fill up on the potatoes, which is one of the sides you will have a choice of. 

Sides- faro salad (gotta get it!); potatoes (gotta have more of that!)

Wine- yikes! Small pours. I was sad that $15 was spent on about 6 sips. 

Service - perfect!
author: Lance A.

description: I have loved this restaurant for 10years.  Shelley always hires a fantastic staff that matches the fantastic food!
author: John C.

description: Very good food but had arranged for an outside table but when we got there one was not reserved ...had to re-ask and wait but they comped us a dessert so all is good...if not for this oversight would have been 4 STARS.
author: Nick T.

description:
Unfortunately, A16 was not worth the drive to San Francisco. 
We were greeted by smiling maitre'ds but from then on the service was horrible, rolling eyes at salt request, throwing plates on the table with no explanation, and a combination of impersonal and lack of enthusiasm from the wait staff. 
Everyone is crowded in with tables too close together. 
Food portions and creativity was sub par. Our pasta was chewy and lacked flavor. (need to boil the water before putting the fresh pasta in).
The burrata appetizer was accompanied with 3 thin slices of bread and did not look appetizing. 
I will not return to A16.
author: Jane K.

description:
The service is deplorable at this organization. Leadership, get involved, shadow your waiters, figure it out.
Pasta is great, but my goodness- service is as simple as it gets.
I was hesitant to come back, and now I remember why. I rarely write reviews but I felt inclined to share a candid customer experience, because service is the easiest thing to fix. Hire right.
author: Jaclyn K.

description:
Stick with the pizza, the pizza is amazeballs! Seriously though, this is some of the best pizza I've ever had. Wonderfully chewy crust that's just slightly burnt, and a range of masterfully paired toppings. And how fun is it to cut your pizza with scissors?! I've had several different pizzas, and they all take me to my happy place.

My only regret is when I decided to be adventurous and try an entree other than pizza, the paccheri pasta (the waitress schooled me on the pronunciation - it's a hard c, not a ch, for those who want to impress their date). The lemon was so overpowering I couldn't finish it and it was very al dente (to be fair, I was warned). Luckily, I was able to have a slice of someone else's pizza and all was right with the world again.

Note that unlike their Oakland location which has a fabulous cocktail program, the SF location is beer and wine only. So class it up with a glass of wine and try to snag a seat by the back garden area.

Pro tip - They don't take phone orders, but you can order for take out and wait at the bar.
author: Cristina S.

description: Good food, good service. Pizzas are thin crust and delicious. However, the wait is long (they told us 15 minutes and we had to wait for 45 minutes). It is very loud and very hard to hear each other. Overall, still recommend this modern Italian restaurant in Marina!
author: Merve A.

description: Two carafes of delightful northern Italian wine, a delicious burrata appetizer, a wholly underwhelming hollow spaghetti pasta dish and an exceptional saffron flat noodle with muscles: $180 dinner for 3
author: jacob m.

description: Not crazy about this place.  Noise is louder than moderate.  Food was so so and pricey.  They do take reservations.   I gave the featured wine for the night only 3* on Vivino.  The meatballs were good, but the side order of pinto beans was different than what I would get at a Southern sideboard.  Would not go back.
author: Wade S.

description: We arrived pretty early in the evening and were seated quite quickly at a high table, not in main dining room. Ordered Pizza and a few other dishes. Have to say, not impressed. Bland, over priced and just does not live up to the reputation. So many other good restaurants in the area. would not advise.
author: Carlita P.

description:
This is a great, non-tourist, casual but upscale southern Italian eatery.  We visited on a recent weekend stay in the city by the Bay at the suggestion of a local. It's off the beaten path for the tourist crowd, but easy enough to find by either bus (how we arrived) or Lyft (how we returned) from our hotel at Union Square.  

I think the food was very good, but--Hipster foodies will likely roll their eyes at this--I found the place a little pretentious.  For example, my wife had some squid ink seafood pasta. Very good, but the squid ink served only to blacken the pasta without really adding anything but a few bucks to the price.  And the wine list outstrips the menu by at least 500+ items.

I enjoyed our visit, and others who appreciate wine and new twists on food will probably love it.
author: David R.

description: Came here with my boyfriend on a Friday night and it was a great date night spot! A16 made me almost feel like I was back in Manhattan with its trendy vibes and young bustling crowd. We loved the ambiance and the food was amazing too! We got the funghi pizza, calamarata, and casareccia pasta. For dessert we got a chocolate tart and I forget the name of mine but it was a yogurt with berries and was delicious. Not to mention the service and staff were wonderful and very hospitable. Will definitely return!
author: Skylar H.

description: This restaurant is just ok. Nothing seemingly terrible. The menu is very limited besides pizza and wine. The ambiance is very nice. The food is coated in olive oil regardless of what you get. My pasta was very dry tasting and somewhat flavorless. The menu seems to lack an explanation of what the food is especially the dessert menu. Overall not great but if you can find something you like then definitely stop by.
author: Rachel A.

description: Just awful. Have been to this place many times over the years but not in about a year. This time walked in and wondered why it was empty. Then the food arrived. The salad was literally just lettuce with oil and vinegar. Pizza was terrible - and that is hard to do. Same with Pasta. What happened to this place?
author: Michael P.

description:
We had eaten there years ago when it first opened and felt that the food didn't live up to the hype. We decided to give it another try and brought our son with us to celebrate his graduation from kindergarten. We made reservations and they stuck us way in the back 'garden' room which was so hot it felt like a greenhouse. As we were being seated we saw another party ask to get moved into the main room - so we asked for the same but to sit at the counter so our boy could enjoy seeing the cooks and pizza ovens. They told us no - the counter was reserved for "walk-ins" and that we couldn't move into the main room either. WTF?!! We had RESERVATIONS!!
Service from that point on wasn't any better and the food was meh. My husband had a pizza - the dough was undercooked and super chewy (i confirmed). My son had a pasta which was one of the specials with truffles and the entire dish was so bland we could've gotten by with pasta, butter, parm. 
Salad was boring and I had the trout which was overcooked. We also ordered the side of snap peas that were overcooked/soggy and the mint flavor definitely didn't transport me to any part of Italy.
For the finale - I ordered a glass of white wine for $15 and the pour was close to a tasting - barely a 1/3rd of the glass size.
We will never return - I'm so surprised they've survived this long.
author: DeeLite W.

description:
Had a great experience here tonight. They get busy so definitely make sure to make a reservation a few days to a week in advance depending on the night. 

Service was very good. Our waiter was attentive and polite. Starters came out quickly. Burrata was superb, felt like we were back in Italy. Waiter recommended the apple salad which was also tasty- light and features lots of fennel which I am a fan of. My friend and I shared a margarita pizza and added prosciutto. It was really great. Doughy yet crunchy crust, flavorful sauce, gooey cheese and perfectly salty prosciutto. They also let you cut your own pizza with scissors which is a fun touch. 

As for the location, it's a fun atmosphere that seems to always be brimming with people. Long and narrow with a pretty outdoor area in the very back. We were seated at the bar which was quite nice and allowed for easy conversation despite being seated next to the person that you're with. The open kitchen offered a fun peak into the inter workings of the kitchen while you dine. 

Will definitely be back again for some authentic Italian food in the marina!
author: Alyssa C.

description: The quality and quantity of food is bad for the amount of money spent here. Disappointed and never coming back.
author: Prasanna N.

description: Alright here's the scoop on this restaurant. We went  here for my friends birthday party and it was fun being with our group drinking wine and enjoying some appetizers. The setting was perfect, the ambiance was nice and surprisingly it's a lot bigger than expected. It looks so tiny from the outside but when you walk in the good spots are in the back. Our waiter was awesome and he was so patient. big kudos to him. I'll try adding his name on here once I figure it out. So the reason they got 4 stars was because of the dish 3 of us ordered and unfortunately had to send it back. We ordered the Maccaronara which I guess is their most popular dish according to the waiter but it wasn't great at all. We all tasted it as a hard noodle that needed to be cooked longer. It kind of almost felt like the it was cooked half way. But after sending back I ordered their Beet Salad.... which was amazing! Oh my god. Everything was just perfect and surprisingly fulfilling. I did want to try their pizza but   I guess next time with a bigger appetite, I hope to make it happen. Definitely will be back.
author: Hector C.

description:
Disappointing Overall.

A16 was very busy but can't understand why.

Dishes are hit and miss at best and doesn't warrant the service with attitude. 

Positives:
Salumi Appetizer - Very well done, includes terrine which was refreshly different and the pickled veggies were delicious.
Pasta - Macasomething - perfectly al dente, seasoned well, and homemade/fresh (Pasta Marinara with a fancy name - thicker noodle) - poorly proportioned - comes like an appetizer size.


Negatives:
Restaurant space is very long, but extremely cramped. During our 2 hour dinner, I was bumped/hit 3 times as the waiters were scrambling around.

Bathrooms are insufficient for the size and poorly located. 2 Bathrooms each restricted to 1 mens and 1 womens. Had to constantly wait up against a wall while the ENTIRE restaurant patrons squeeze through to walk to main dining area.

Squid appetizer - way too salty, the cook added olives that were so salty that it ruined the dish.

Pork Chop - More fat than meat, under seasoned, underwhelming.

Pizza - Ordered the spicy pancetta pizza - came out tasting good and very spicy due to chili oil. So much chili oil the middle of the pizza was a soggy, oily mess, and way too salty due to the pancetta which was BLACK (aka burnt). Pizza crust was good.

Squid Ink Dish - Was listed as top 25 item for 7x7 things to eat before you die....I will pass. Underseasoned, seafood was mediocre, and tiny proportion. Go to Old Skool and get the Uni/Squid Ink dish - that is Amazing.

Service - Asked for sparking water in the middle of dinner. Was given to carafes and no additional cups (we had 4 cups with regular water). We asked for additional cups for the sparkling water. Waitress gives us the cups and started taking the regular water cups away. My wife said, I will keep my water glass. The waitress' response is "I am only doing what you asked". She was very curt and rude as she was scrambling around acting like she doesn't have time to provide us with the proper service. 

The food highlights does not compensate for bad service and overall bad experience.
author: Joseph L.

description: After our meal we were told by the staff on the way out stick with the pizza and share.  We had non pizza entree items average, nothing exceptional.  This restaurant is very busy and very noisy and tight seating.  If we do return we'll go for the pizza
author: Bill W.

description:
This is one of my dad's favorite spots. Whenever he would go out, he'd always bring me something back. So when I was in town to visit, I wasn't surprised when he wanted to come here for lunch on his birthday. 

From the entrance, it looks very small, but the place is actually a pretty decent size, and there's tons of seating in the back. 

It's a beautiful, cozy, and initiate spot- perfect for a date! I'm sure it's pretty romantic at night. 
We ordered:
-Burrata 5/5
-Trippa Napoletana 5/5
- Half order of the pork meatballs 4/5
-Squid ink pasta 5/5

Everything was absolutely delicious! I wanted to eat more- but was literally SO full. 
The service was outstanding- very friendly, helpful, and attentive. 
I would definitely recommend this spot. Come in for an excellent meal and a bottle of wine and enjoy!
author: Lainey L.

description: Dinner at A16 last night.  Great food (five stars)  Excellent service (ditto). Interesting wine list (same).  But gevalt!, the noise (minus two).  Crowded room, all hard surfaces, excited diners.  Conversation impossible.   Ears still ringing.
author: Bruce C.

description: Exceptionally authentic Italian pizza. If you want a true taste of Italy, go to A16. Even the look and feel reminded me of places I frequented in Venice.
author: Steve A.

description: My sister, niece and her friend, and I ate at A16 on Sunday April 29th. They had no problem accommodating us which was appreciated.  However, the service was poorly lacking, unfriendly and a bit condescending. Three of us had the steak. Mine was served medium rare even though I wanted medium and the server did not come by to check on us to my recollection. Each of our steaks contained a healthy serving of gristle, making it difficult to cut - I was shaking the table. I did see a previous review that thought her pork was overly salted; I felt the same about the steak. Two of the sides came out after we were served our steak, not with our meal.  We were never offered bread (are we supposed to ask?) The steaks were 38.00 per person and totally not worth it. I will say the fava beans and potatoes were good and well seasoned. I've been to the A16 in Rockridge and my experience was much better.
author: Mary M.

description:
I was really looking forward to a dinner at A16 with my boyfriend - we made reservations for Friday night, which is when we decided to celebrate Valentines this year.

We ordered:
- Burrata to share
- Margherita Pizza to share
- I ordered the pumpkin gnocchi, my partner ordered the maccaronara
- We asked the waiter to recommend a good wine, as neither my partner or I am experienced with Italian wine.  He suggested a reasonably priced, delicious bottle.  It was the most delicious thing of the evening.

The burrata was good, though it had an interesting texture I haven't ever experienced with Burrata before.  It was.....chewy in places?  But it was decent in general.

The pizza was horrible.  First, they bring it out with scissors.  Yes, scissors.  I get it - scissors are the "traditional italian cutting tool" for pizza from forever ago or whatever.  Awesome.  Welcome to 2017 where knives are commonplace.  Oh, and btw, for a restaurant of this caliber, i have expectations the kitchen will cut the pizza for me, and not leave it to me to make a total mess out of the pie by attempting to creation fashion out of pizza with scissors.

That aside, the pizza was SOUR.  Not sour, like tomato sauce sour.  It was SOUR.  As it it had been dipped in lemon juice prior to serving.  We sent it back, with no replacement.

The pumpkin Gnocchi was absolutely flavorless.  And the dish was the size of a small candy bowl.  After having to return the gross (and messy) pizza, I was hungry.  Not only was I disappointed with portion sizes, but I had to send this dish back too as it just didn't taste good at all.

My partner's Maccaronara was equally "disgusting."  It just had a very off flavor and I didn't blame him for not wanting it.

The staff handled it all very well, and very professionally.  They offered to bring additional food items and even offered to comp the whole check.  We opted NOT to try any more dishes, as at this point with 4 disappointing dishes we figure this restaurant isn't for us.  We definitely paid for our bottle of wine (it was delicious!) and quietly left the scene.

We probably will never return.  Looks like we missed the boat on A16 serving great italian food.
author: Michael D.

description: The wine selection is impeccable! We had two glasses of delicious Italian red. The wait staff was also very accommodating. Moved us when we requested a quieter table. That being said, the gem salad was a bit bland. The meatball soup was very savory! The gnocchi was a bit dry and outside of the lemon didn't have much oomph. The ambience is great and location is wonderful.
author: John A.

description: Very poor service before you even arrive, with an attitude to boot!  We called, they said come in, it's a 45 minute wait. We arrived within 10 minutes and were turned away. The hostess was an absolute ^]%]'s!!!  We heard great things about A16, but now we'll never know!
author: Brad M.

description: Went here on a Sunday for lunch before a show. Upon arrival at 11:45, it was completely empty, so I took a seat at the bar and enjoyed a glass of a lovely Italian white the bartender recommended. People trickled in, then my friend arrived and we were seated. Our service started well, and we shared the luscious burrata with nice, fruity EVOO. My friend had the bean soup while I had the gemelli pasta with a citrusy herb pesto. The texture of the pasta was great, but there was uneven salty and not salty bites. After we had been served, our waiter basically never returned. I flagged down another sever to ask for the wine list to order another glass to share, but no one returned nor made eye contact until after we were done, so we skipped the wine and paid. It's a pleasant atmosphere, the food and wine are interesting and basically fine, but for the price I expect better service. If this was on a slow day, I would not want to experience the service when things get busy.
author: Nancy E.

description:
Ok, stay with me on this review.. i promise you'll be entertained and well advised:

We headed to A16 last night becuase it was 10 years ago when we met for dinner [@A16]. We thought it would be fun to relive the 'scene of the crime'.. 

Wine bar:
I have to say, the bartender was on his game and knew what he was pouring. It was a pleasure in that he allowed me to taste almost anything. I had a lovely glass of 'sarno 1860'. a dry white from Italy. Anyway, onto dinner...

We were seated and give a menu with our names printed in the top with 'Happy Anniversary'. I gotta tell you.. this is pretty fab folks.. really.

Appetizers:
I ordered polenta, Sandra ordered a salad. Salad was fine yet after i tasted the polenta i noticed it was spicy.. like chili spicy.. i'm like WTH? so i looked at the menu.. weird, nothing on it explained there were slices of chili minced into the polenta = deal breaker. Ok, do I enjoy heat, yes. Do I like salsa, yes. Do I like pepper, yes.. yet NOT in my polenta.. and simply LIST it on the menu.

I explained to the the server (Emily) and she brought me a bean soup. Thank you Emily ;-)

Main courses:
I ordered the roasted chicken with broccolini. Sandra ordered the salmon. Salmon was fine. After a bite of chicken I noticed there was way too much salt. I took another bite, same thing. It was as if the chef was having a field day with salt.. and anyone in the culinary field understands what heavy salting equates to.. right? Anyway, Itried the broccolini. It was prepared fine yet they added grapes and something else essentially making it taste like something other than broccolini.. kinda like eating some sort of bland generic legume. 

Jacob, the manager must have noticed something was not right and came over inquiring about the food. I explained the huge amount of salt, the spicy polenta and tasteless broccolini.. Jacob was great, he said, 'can i please have the chef see your chicken?" Of course, i obliged. Jacob returned saying the chef, agreed with my sodium assessment ;-)

Emily brought over desserts; rice pudding and the chocolate budini tart. I took a bite into the art.. WOW! that salt from the chicken somehow made its was to the dessert. Ok, to be fair, the tart is suppose to contain sea salt in the recipe.. just not the equivalent to a salt shaker...

Rice pudding had a hardened caramel coating akin to creme brule. It was ok, just nothing to write home about.

Jacob came over after and I explained to him that the over use of salt, the polenta, the broccolini, the tart with more excessive salt.. was disappointing. I kindly explained A-16 needs to step up its game to compete with so many places in SF currently.. Jacob explained he was so appreciative of our feedback becuase the only was for them to get better is by hearing from customers.

Lastly:
Meal was gratis. I actually, said to Emily, that is not necessary, yet she said, 'no, it's quite alright'.

A-16 staff/management receives high marks for being professional... yet A-16 falters with respect to food preparation and clarity in communicating the menu.

With that said, would you return given our experience?
author: sam l.

description: Perfect cozy neighborhood Italian ristorante serving fab food and WOW let's talk about the rocking attentive Staff too! The pizza is amazing and my pork entree with the roasted summer squash was deeeelicious! Praise goes to Satya our fab Roman waiter and to Maria who both made our visit very special.
author: Judi B.

description:
I had been looking forward to dinner at A16 for a long time and was very disappointed in the visit. Not so much in the food, but in the general attitude of the staff.  Although we had a reservation for dinner, the two women at the front desk were very unfriendly on our arrival, had us wait for at least 20 minutes for a table and were totally uninterested in making us comfortable.  Then when we were finally seated, our waiter Omar, was also unfriendly and moderately rude.  He threw down the menu on the table, and when the food arrived slapped down the plates on our table.
The food was reasonably good, but the portions were small.
Perhaps a popular restaurant like this can get away with this level of service, but I am not anxious to return.  I frequently dine out in San
Francisco and have been living here for over 30 years, and have not encountered unpleasant service  of this type.
author: Bernard R.

description: A-16 is a restaurant far past its prime resting on laurels earned long long ago. We are still trying to expiate the overwhelming taste of salt from  the one desert that has always been the signature here, the bundino. We had also ordered two different pastas and they were over-seasoned as well.  The kitchen is simply careless and there is no excuse for that. I have lived in the Bay Area long enough to know that restaurants like this do not deserve a second chance.
author: Steven A.

description: Great experience overall. We got Burrata (exceeded all expectations), apple salad, bucatini, and the baked candele lunghe with braised lamb. All four were exceptional. Servers were attentive and kind. We were sat a little closer to another group than I had hoped (one side is a long booth that runs the length of several tables). However, I was surprised at how little sound carried in the space. Ultimately our tables couldn't hear each other's conversations and I felt very comfortable despite my initial concerns. The decor is warm and decently romantic. It turned out to be a great date spot for my wife and I before heading to a show at the Orpheum.
author: Joel T.

description: Came here on a recommendation. Service was excellent. Pizza was very good. Burrata was also very good although crostini were too crispy for my taste. The bread was nice although I'm sure it would have been excellent warm. As others said, it's pricey.
author: Ashley H.

description:
I gave up tonight.  Been there 6-7 times and sit at the bar and often wait for service.  Tonight after 4-5 minutes I turned and looked at the hostess and she said how are you?  I responded, "invisible".  Two or 3 minutes later he left the bar, and never came my way (there's only 10 seats).  She was sweet and offered to go get him, I walked: no complaining, no scene.
If you're a regular, or he lowers himself, he will go on and on about his wine knowledge.  It's a shame because the pizza is very good.
author: George S.

description:
Dishes like the burrata and maccaronara pasta proved reasonably satisfying, yet hardly mindblowing. All in all, simply decent Italian fare. I will say that, unlike some reviews here, service was the strong point for me: attentive, on point, and friendly.

Maybe the ambience and atmosphere is what people go for here in the Marina, but if you're looking for substance, you might not be in the right neighborhood, let alone the right restaurant.
author: Vincent L.

description: Cozy place for a glass of wine- all Italian,  Did not try the food.  Sat at the wine bar and was guided to a selection that would be close to my standard Viognier or Chardonnay.  Good conversation with the bartender and other guests at the bar.  I'm gluten free so the food is not something I can have, pity. Will go back for a nightcap.
author: Diane A.

description: The burrata for appetizer was amazing but a bit too much salt on the bread that accompanies it. My wife took the paccheri pasta (pasta with lamb) and it was very good. However for me I was a bit disappointed from my Ragu pasta (maccaronara) the I took, the tomato sauce tasted like it came straight from a rusty can . The place is very nice and very cool ambience .
author: Fadi A.

description:
If you're looking for a charming spot to have dinner and people-watch at the same time, this is the spot. The entire place was entirely packed by 8pm with the crowd you'd expect from the Marina. I had the Salsiccia pizza, Maccaronara pasta, Roasted Delicata Squash, and Brussel Sprouts. 

Make a reservation if you want to skip an hour wait. I had a reservation but there was still a bit of a wait. Just enough time to start a drink before the meal. The bartender helped paired me off with a very satisfying glass of medium-bodied red.
author: Yad L.

description:
A16 has long been a favorite, especially at lunch, but must say that dinner last night was far from pleasurable. Came especially for the white truffle specials and ordered three of them.
All were disappointing: the pizza was like a flatbread with a little bit of cheese with a minuscule amount of truffle shaved on it (for $78!!!!) The two pastas--one was very pasty, the second we had to return for lack of salt and the remake had too much salt, almost  couldn't eat it.
Not a fun evening with a major check!

May be awhile before we go back---it was a Sunday night, maybe the second string kitchen staff was at work.
author: Hans G.

description:
I have lived In Naples and I know what  a true Neapolitan pizza looks like.The pizza I had last nite wasn't much different from any other American pizza you'd have In another average American restaurant. I wish I would have taken a pic of that pizza because it was super small, expensive and crispy as f....., for any true Neapolitan pizza lover this is the last place you wanna come to have a Neapolitan pizza. Service was great and our server was Italian and super welcoming a super nice guy.
Definitely not coming back to this place you can get better Neapolitan pizzas in sf.
author: Lindsay P.

description: Absolutely delicious food! We ordered the burger and it was to die for. We waited for a long time to get a table as the place is small but was worth the wait / the manager was very nice and gave us a free appetizer due to the long wait. It's expensive but worth it! Loved it! U can tell the ingredients are fresh!
author: Barbara T.

description:
Went here with friends on a referral. Although we got there 10 minutes before they closed for lunch they accommodated us. Pizza was very tasty, although the homemade pasta and sauce was way over priced for the child size portion they said was entree size. Best part of meal, red wine and bread.
Won't return.
author: Judy K.

description:
