description: Have been treated very poorly by the blonde hostess and the bartender the last two times that I came to the restaurant. Food and wine is still good but not good enough for the hostess to be so rude.
author: B D.

description: The pasta dishes are really small, definitely not worth the 25$! I am a small person and don't eat a lot, but I left the restaurant still hungry... The pasta lacked seasoning, it was cold, just meh... My husband had pizza, which was also cold... At least he had a decent portion and wasn't hungry after a 100$ dinner... I came to A16 with really high expectations and it was such a disappointment -it was awful... Don't spend your money here folks!
author: Yasine K.

description:
This review is long over due! I came here a while back with my brother. We sat at the bar and had a simple pizza and pork appetizer. The wine was recommended by the bartender and really hit the spot.  

The would have been no chance of us getting a table without reservation, so I recommend going on to open table or something similar. The bar is large, but there are plenty of people hovering to take your spot when you're through.

Overall, good experience. The bartender was lovely and the atmosphere was fun and lively!
author: JoBeth B.

description:
1) Amazing wine list and super knowledgeable and communicative sommelier. Served us the best sparkling wine either of us have ever had.
2) Killer authentic ingredients...many house made.
3) Beautifully combined dishes.....very, very well done.
4) Best server (Laura) I have had in any restaurant anywhere in a good while
5) Stunningly low tab, given the quality of the experience.

This almost didn't happen, though.  The hostess is horrid.  Walking in from the street, the place seems airport runway loud, chaotic, low ceilings, narrow....and very, very busy.  The hostess was the opposite of welcoming.....my wife (we had just gotten married a few hours earlier) was panicking.  The barman slipped us two Bellavista glasses and I convinced her to give it a chance.

The hostess' "revenge" was to seat us in Siberia....the faux back garden separated from the action by glass walls and way back by the fire exit.  High ceilings, wide room, peaceful.....awesome.  We had one of the best meals we have ever had in The City.....and we laughed to each other as the hostess glared at us on the way out.

Ironically, Michael Bauer (SF Chronicle food writer) had the exact same experience with a hostess in today's paper at a different restaurant.  I am a restaurant guy and have an intimate understanding of the insane amount of work and investment it takes to open and keep a place running.  To have the experience blown at the door is defeating.  It takes a bullet proof diner to shrug off that kind of "welcome" and persevere.  Luckily.....I am that guy.

We almost went back for lunch today....but we were still full!  I would go back in a heartbeat......probably dressed in polyester to get shipped off to Siberia again.  I would definitely try to ruin the hostess' night somehow.....the way she tries to wreck eveyone else's.  Ignore her and have a great, great meal at a great, great price.
author: Michael J.

description:
The food was good (not great) but what really made this an unpleasant experience was our server, Daniel.  He was inattentive, condescending and, to top it off, he refused to pick up our checks or leave our table until he had all six pens he dropped off accounted for.  It was, by far, one of the most awkward moments I've ever experienced at dinner.  

It is a lovely venue but if you're looking for affordable, delicious food and friendly service this isn't the place to go.
author: Allyson F.

description:
Amazing pizza in an authentic Italian style with unique toppings, as well as an impressive wine list and eclectic cocktail menu.

Food: I split two pizzas with my boyfriend, and that was definitely enough to keep us full! Both were thin-crusted and a bit "soupy" in the middle, reminiscent of the pizza I had in Italy. The scissors they provide to cut the pizza are a fun novelty, and easy to use.

1) Vongole pizza. This one took a while to tackle since the clams are still in their shells, but it was by far my favorite. Well-balanced and not "fishy" or gritty at all. 
2) Salsiccia fennel sausage pizza. Really savory and hearty with little sauce, great if you like earthy flavors like roast meat and vegetables. 

We also ordered a couple of aperitif cocktails, both of which were delicious and complex! 

Service: Excellent! Servers were easy to find, and vigilant about keeping water glasses full. 

Ambiance: An upscale, average-sized place with low lighting. Great for dates, but I wouldn't recommend it for groups much bigger than 4-6. 

Price: On the pricey side for pizza, but this isn't your late-night Domino's.
author: L H.

description: Me and my boyfriend went there on ouranniversary and it was terrible never going back. It was a 20 min wait to get seated, the waiter was taking forever to get to us, not to mention our food took a long time and I had hair in my pasta. I decided to order a pizza instead and it was watery. The topping to the pizza fell off and the bread was burned. I do not recommend coming to this place. Unfortunately, you can get better food and service at Olive Garden.
author: Jaela R.

description:
A-16 always hits a home-run.  This is one of my favorite all-around restaurants in SF, and one of my top 2 or 3 pizzas in the city (or anywhere for that matter).  A-16 is almost always busy in the evenings, and does a nice lunch business certain days of the week, so plan ahead.

I have never had a bad experience here.  Most frequently I order pizzas, but I move around the menu as well.  There is some rotation of items based on seasons, but there always seems to be their 'maccaronara' pasta which is essentially a very thick and tasty noodle. I have also tried gnocchi and squid ink tonnarelli when they appear on the menu, and they are both wonderful dishes.  Starters- the burrata is almost always on the menu and a winner.  I've also had a wonderful tuna conserva dish and a pepper dish which was a special.  Everything is delicious.

All of the pizzas are great- their crust is exceptional. They execute the 'thin' neopolitan style to perfection- with a nice light char on the bottom, not too chewy nor too crispy.  My personal favorite is pomodorro pizza with cherry tomatoes and ricotta cheese (no sauce).  The margarita is wonderful as well, and the fungi is another personal favorite of mine.  You will definitely wind up having random A-16 pizza cravings after your first experience which will inevitably draw you back for more.

FInally, the desserts- try the chocolate budino.  It is a great chocolate cake with a savory touch of sea salt and olive oil which will make your mouth water.  I have tried other items which rotate on and off the menu, and they were all excellent, but this one is 'always' ordered at my table when I visit.

In summary, A-16 is always superb, as evidenced by the very busy and energetic crowds piling into the place and clogging the doorway at the bar waiting for a seat.  So may call it a scene, but scenes don't last long in SF unless the food works, and A-16 has been around too long to still live off of 'social status'. Make a reservation 1 week ahead for a 'premium' time or shoot for day-of after 9pm.  Be prepared to wait if you just pop in, but who knows, maybe you will get lucky.  A-16 most favorably compares to Flour+Water- and there are a lot of similarities between the two.  I take A-16 for pizzas and F+W for pastas, but both execute everything on the menu in a superior, no-lose manner.  Please enjoy A-16- I always do....
author: Andy S.

description:
The restaurant itself is nice. There is a cool little seating area in the back that is great for larger parties. And the waiters are polite and helpful. But I was disappointed in the food...

My party shared some appetizers like the bread and cheese with honey which were okay. We ordered some pasta dishes which were also just okay. The pasta was undercooked and needed seasoning. I rarely eat salty foods and never need to season anything when I go to restaurants so I found that surprising. For the main course I had the short rib plate. It costed $36 for the plate. When they served it to me I was shocked to see that it wasn't any bigger than any of the appetizers. This was a joke I literally finished it in 3 bites. It was tiny and extremely over priced. It did taste good but who cares how it tastes when u can't even get full off it! For $36 they could at least given a normal portion of food.
author: Guerito L.

description:
Very dissappointing experience here on Feb 15 (caveat - it was a holiday weekend). It had been a few years since I've been, but nothing went right and food was extremely bland. I never rant about restaurants but thought I would share since this place was packed as ever. Maybe people just like the bar scene and atmosphere?

Both pasta dishes - a bucatini with crab and a squid ink tonnarelli - were overcooked and flavorless. The waitress suggested there may have been a problem with the water and pasta cooking process. The sweetbreads were really good. The liberty duck was mediocre. Very surprised. I've been there at least half a dozen times and it was always good. Maybe the regular kitchen crew was off for the holiday.
author: Joe A.

description:
3.5 stars. 

Obviously a lot of care and refinement goes into an establishment like A16 to give itself a voice in the culinary world of San Francisco, being one of the most popular restaurants to get a coveted table. 

Every dish is designed with care and deliberation but somehow didn't make it to my favorite list of my restaurants to return to.

Ambience -- classy, trendy, but a bit too loud for my taste.

burrata with olive oil, sea salt, crostini -- great starter. how could one go wrong with burrata at a place like this?

I liked the pastas that I had here but didn't love them (speaking relatively to Flour & Water, as an example). The style tends to be like traditional Italian style in Italy: the sauce & other ingredients are only there to enhance the taste of the pasta itself. This works in Italy because the ingredients are bursting with flavor given how amazing the produce are in Italy. But it just didn't happen here. I had the Squid Ink Cavatelli with oven roasted cherry tomatoes, sicilian tuna heart, upland cress, fried breadcrumbs. It was pretty good, but I didn't love the tuna heart - it was a bit too mushy for my taste and the fried breadcrumbs, usually a great addition for puttanesca sauce, just didn't add that much here. One needs the spiciness and acidity in the sauce to cut through some of taste of the breadcrumb, here the cherry tomatos were not enough to counter the additional carb/grease brought on by the breadcrumb. My friend had the special pasta and I would have to give the similar opinion on that one as well.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
We went here to try it out based on a recommendation. Upon arrival, my wife asked the waitress what kind of bread was served with the meal. The waitress seemed to be taken aback with the question and gave us a look like it was a stupid question. Considering we were about to order burrata and the bread was available upon request, we wanted to know if it would be something that would go well with it. She finally ended up telling us but the rest of the evening, she made us feel like we were an inconvenience and she just wanted us to leave. 

We ended up ordering a large plate to share and the burrata. While the burrata was very good, the plate that showed up for us to share was absolutely tiny. It literally looked like a half order and both of us were shocked with the size. Especially since we looked around and saw others eating much larger plates. We waited for the bill after splitting the tiny dish assuming that the bill would show it as a half order in error but no, $25 for a tiny plate to share. Absolutely atrocious. With no drinks and just water, our meal came to $55 for something that would barely feed one. Absolutely atrocious pricing and the waitress kept giving us a hurry up and leave vibe.

Not impressed at all.
author: Mike J.

description:
Overpriced, deafeningly noisy and for the most part INEDIBLE food.
Aside from that the waitress was nice and the service prompt at weekday lunch
The Marguerita Pizza was good too. Delicate fresh tomato sauce on a great thin Italian crust. It was the only redeeming item on the menu
The Anchovey Pizza was too salty to eat.
Potato Pizza was a tasteless thick mass of cheese hiding thin potato slices blanketing the crust which was literally unfindable.
The salad was green leaves of lettuce covered with shards of cheese with no perceptible dressing. That and the soup were not finished.
The stuffed artichoke had a mass of gloppy garlicky sour lemony bread crumbs completely masking whatever flavor the artichoke ever had, floating in a an olive oily watery sauce.
There was too much noise for any conversation mostly from Pacific Heights matrons out for lunch and who could not have cared less for the food, as it were.
Not one of our six are planning ever to come back.
author: Arthur E. L.

description:
I rarely write reviews but we had such an underwhelming experience last night and mainly due to one person.  My wife and I arrived at 6:30 for our 6:30 reservation and the hostess told us we would be seated shortly and so we moved aside to wait.  While waiting I decided to ask if the Chef's counter was available and the hostess gave me a nasty snarl of a look and then said "No, we are fully booked at the counter."  The response was fine but the look she shot at me is what inspired the saying "if looks could kill."  Hey, I understand you are stressed, the restaurant is busy but I am the customer not the enemy and not sure what warranted that look.

Now another couple comes in and we are still waiting, they check in with the hostess and are seated immediately.  Ahhh, what just happened?  My wife and I look at each other in disbelief.  Why would they be seated before us?  Seems she did not like my question about the Chef's counter and now we suffer the consequences.

After 15 minutes we are seated and the rest of the evening goes fairly well as our server was fantastic and quite helpful with the wine list.  The menu felt a bit limited with 4 pasta dishes and 3 main courses, however they are well executed and that is what is most important.

Overall, the hostess ruined the evening with her unwelcoming attitude.  Isn't the role of the hostess to be pleasant and welcoming?  Apparently not last evening.  Crossing A16 off our list due to her unpleasantness.
author: Brendan C.

description: I love this place, and make a point to eat there when I'm visiting San Francisco.  The Romana pizza changed my concept of pizza when I first tried it in 2009 - it had no cheese! - but with olives and calabrian chiles it was unbelievably good.  I've been back numerous times since, and enjoy the wine list, the burrata, and have made several of their bruschettas at home with the A16 cookbook, which have been massive hits with guests.
author: Jon L.

description:
I am visiting San Francisco and was struggling to find a last minute reservation on Monday night.  A local friend recommended A16 for their pizza, which is really the prominent menu category offering a large assortment of options.  Outside of pizza, I only tried some of the antipasta (marinated olives were excellent) and a couple sides.  The inside is surprisingly large and rather loud.  The volume levels aren't disruptive, but its worth mentioning - if you are looking for a quiet/romantic Italian place, this isn't the spot.  

Overall, the food was very good, as was the service.
author: Christine R.

description:
Pros: service, atmosphere, price , appetizers and the pizza shears!! 

Cons: waited for a while for our table with reservations. Next time hoping to score a more delicious pizza! 

I really enjoyed A16. Highlights are the service and the appetizers. Our waitress was super friendly and great at providing suggestions. We ordered a water melon salad appetizer which was light and delicious...I would order this again. 

The coolest part about A16 is that you are given a pair of metal sheers to cut and slice your pizza with....it doesn't come pre-sliced. Though this was strange at first, it turned to be a fun and cool way to make it a memorable experience...the shears are pretty nifty and are good at ripping slices apart. 

We ordered the Fungi pizza and the Romana pizza. Fungi was okay but a bit overly done with the mushrooms (as I guess is to be expected). The romana pizza was good and had a nice smoky crust which I enjoyed, but a bit blander and less salty than expected (olives, anchovies, etc) I ordered without the chiles, so maybe that had something to do with the seemingly missing kick of flavor.
author: Ronnie S.

description:
Back home in Chicago I'd caught a special on Food Network about Nate Appleman and heard mention about this restaurant and the possibility of bumping into him while working here.  I bookmarked the restaurant and thought when the time came round for my next trip to the City, I'd stop by for a taste of the fine South Italian cooking they are known for.  (Later I would learn this Food network special is very outdated, as Nate is now working in NYC)  

Fast forward to the other evening and soon after my sis picked me up from the airport we were on the way over.  A Thursday night and while some had previously told me reservations are a must, we popped our heads in to see if a table for two would be possible.  Street parking could not be found.  Two and half blocks down the street we found a parking structure which cost $3 per hour and we were back on route.  We were offered a petite table for two or a chance to sit at the chef's table.  Heck yeah, watch delectable fare prepared and make our choices on dinner from what we see, rather than what we read off a menu.  Fo'sho.  Our waiter was forgettable and offered little to no personality within the short exchanges.  The hostess however was bright and full of smile, her warm welcome made us feel that we made the best choice for our dinner destination.  Our dinner menu consisted of:

Braised artichokes with burrata and toasted pistachio.  (Starter)
(Pizza) Salsiccia - fennel sausage, spring onions, mozzarella, tomato, grana, garlic, chilies, olive oil
(Pasta) Maccaronara with ragu napoletana and house-made ricotta salata 

Both the chef and pizza maker were before us.  We watched as fresh ingredients were applied to cause and then pie sent into the wood fired oven.  It's a lot to take in sitting there.  First time I realized why people on Food shows smile so much when sitting near to the chef during a dinner presentation.  Large pieces of meat, finely cared for, added to tasty ingredients and then cooked to perfection by the mindful watch of the skilled chef.   Sister had said she would hate to be the chef, cooking while so many watched and took photos.  I had a smile ear to ear, looking down on this beautiful cut of pork shoulder.  

Back to our meal.  The pasta was tasty and not too much.  Pizza pie was excellent.  We had a few slices to go and I can report that they heated up well.  Even cold, the flavors of the sauce with the fennel sausage and garlic just equaled yum.  

Due to a minor infraction with our waiter, we were about to leave without finding out whether they offered desserts.  We felt that since we weren't alike other tables ordering up wines, we were forgotten.  Which we were.  On the walk out, the hostess with the mostest was too eager to not allow us to leave without trying at least  one.  With the helpful assistance of the manager Nathan, we were introduced to a signature dessert, the Chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil and a pleasantly paired glass of moscato.  I like sweet wines and have had moscato before, but never such a fine one.  The dessert was a perfect finisher.  Sweet, then salty, than a crunchy sweet once again.  

Had thought about inquiring about a bottle, but due to a bleeding parking meter had to make it back to the car.  Maybe I'll stop back and grab a bottle or I've already bookmarked it for future visits for next time.

My only complaints; no booze.  Only wines.  I would love if you guys had at least one top shelf bourbon maybe? Basil Hayden.  Also, bathrooms are only for one!  I stood in a line three men deep and joked with others, "if that guy is dropping a deuce, this wait would be obnoxious."  For a Thursday night and over a thousand reviews; they are busy.  

It's best to say something to management if you feel slighted.  We almost missed out on a completely satisfying experience, which dinner, dessert and company were.  Thank you A 16 for the time.
author: Jacob J.

description:
A close friend recommended A16 when I asked for a Valentine's Day location.  Being my first Valentine's Day dinner with my new wife, I wanted it to be extra nice.  The evening started off poorly when we were required to wait an additional 40 minutes past our reservation time for our table and it was quite crowded.  Oh well, we bought cocktails and made the best of it.

It was a prix fix dinner with I think 4 courses each and my wife and I each ordered 4 different dishes so we'd get to sample more.  Sadly only 1 of the 8 different dishes was good and one of the dishes, the sweetbread (and I know this is a polarizing dish) was absolutely inedible.  The rabbit pasta dish was dried out and over cooked and so was the fish.  Even the dessert was terrible.  The staff were nice but they were so under staffed and overbooked; the restaurant took the occasion to make a money printing machine - overbook the restaurant, understaff and churn out the same 12 dishes all night without attention to quality.  

It was such a disappointment as my wife and I don't' live in the Marina or an expensive SF neighborhood and live on a budget; this dinner was an extravagance.  I can't imagine that a restaurant in this location could make it this long (I think they've been in business more than 10 years) without having great food and service so either the overall quality has slipped or they just really screwed up this evening.
author: Ryan A.

description:
So disappointed. 
Food didn't meet my expectation at all and it was over priced.  
I'll never go there again.
I don't know why this restaurant is on Michelin Guide.
author: Sawyoon Z.

description:
It takes a bit to get me walking, but once my wheels are in motion, there's no stopping me. Walked with my date all the way from the Mission District to the Marina, where this spot is found in.

It's been about 4 months since now, but the main reason I remember this place (let alone any place) is a good one: they serve decent octopus. We ordered their braised octopus with roasted garlic and ceci beans, and the portions were nearly right on in tenderness. Also recall a seared sole with slices of orange, but the rest is vague at this point...

A tad pricey. Still, I wanted to give thumbs up to a lovely, pizza-less dining experience, whose pleasant and informative fine dining waiters made our trek by foot completely worth it.
author: Garett T.

description:
"OH! It's suppose to be undercooked"  I don't recall al dente pasta - but whatever floats your boat. Yeah the pizzas were amazing. If it was purely a pizza joint it would be five stars. 

Wine and drink pairing was pleasant.
author: Janno L.

description:
Was not that impressed food good but not stellar and service was extremely slow and boarder line rude  

1). Check in was kind about as kind and personal as I would expect at Apple bees. Snippy and kind of rude. However intend to ignore the front of the houses interaction.  

2) from order to table it took almost one hour and 15 min. They did comp two glasses of wine but considering the 36$ per plate I expect them to be on point

3) The food is good but not outstanding  again 36$ steak should at least arrive in 30 min and not cold. 

Mist of been an off night but still full price.
author: David C.

description:
Just dined here and had pretty lousy service.
Ordered a salad, pizza, and an entree. It took while to get our pizza and entree but the salad didn't even show up. When the waitress gave us our food she said the salad would come shortly. Shouldn't the salad come before the entrees?

Sadly it didn't come within 5 minutes and I asked to cancel the salad if it hasn't been made. It was cancelled without an acknowledgment or even an apology!
author: Marc Y.

description:
Have tried to get in a few times in the past, but have always been too busy. So tonite we were thrilled that they had a table for us. Excited to see what the fuss was. 
First came the smoked trout appetizer salad. Trout tasted like canned salmon. Mixed with fingerling potatoes in dill cream sauce. Small portion. Not much flavor, but rich and heavy. Felt there should have been some cucumbers or green of some sort to cut it. Really pricey at $19. 

My husband ordered sausage pizza for the main course. Outstanding. Great sausage. Nice crust and cheese mixture. $20. Reasonable for upscale restaurant pizza. 

I ordered black ink clam pasta (one of my favorite dishes). Really, how can it go wrong. Dish had about 5 or 6 of the smallest clams I've ever seen. Primary taste was salt and a strange herbal after taste. Noodles were hard and really under cooked. I rarely return anything as my husband gets really embarrassed and Im not that discriminate when I'm hungry. But yeah. I just couldn't swallow anymore after the 3 bite. 

So, I send the dish back and ask if they could give me something they recommended. I didn't care what it was. Just wanted to give the restaurant a fair chance to represent themselves. The dish I get in place is hard pasta again, except its white and not black, covered in a tomato sauce that taste exactly like the canned chef boy r dee pastas except cooked really really long. Like if u scooped tomato paste from the can. That consistency and taste. expect the canned sauce is better. Pricy at $22 with absolutely no protein of any sort. 
My husband gives me the eye because he would be mortified if I returned a second dish. 
So I eat, but it doesn't get better. Almost drier by the bite. 
I wonder...doesn't the staff or managers eat this stuff. They have to know. 
Maybe, their good chef is out for the evening and we just hit a bad nite. 
Im glad we did stop in because now we won't wonder what the crowd is all about. 
Atmosphere is upscale, elegant, intimate, but with all the great restaurants in the area, we won't be back.
author: choi t.

description:
I had really high expectations for A16 and my impressions after my first visit are mixed, I went on a Friday night with a reservation for 9:00 pm the place is buzzing with people and the ambiance is really nice. Expect to wait 30-40 min to actually get seated, people who manage the seats are also not very helpful and you can see people leaving disappointed with reservations because they waited too long. We ended up seating at the bar instead of a table.

We ordered wine and a sausage pizza, there's a good selection of wines from both California and Italy and there should be a glass of wine that fits mostly everybody. The pizza was ok it was well cook and came fast but the mix of ingredients was not to our liking, on a scale from 1-10 it was a 5. Service can also be greatly improved.
author: Angel J.

description:
OPEN CALL TO ALL TRENDY PLACES IN SF: Please check your cookbook again what "al dente" really means.  I grew up in Europe and spent a lot of time in Italy and I promise you, it does NOT mean half-cooked noodles!

Went there with 2 friends on a Sat at 6 pm -- and the place was almost packed.  When we left at 7:30, the line was through the bar to outside, so we were lucky -- but I think this place is overrated.  Service was very good, food very good to experimental, and rather on the pricey side, but hey, its the Marina...
author: Peter D.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and have been here a few times. They have this thing known as 'meatball monday' which is pretty popular. The food is alright...and the wine selection is pretty eclectic Italian. I had an Italian wine I wanted to bring and try out....until I found out the corkage fee was $30?! I mean....come on. Just put a sign in the window that says ' leave your wine at home'. Lived here all my life and never seen a $30 corkage fee for a neighborhood restaurant. The wine aside....the 1/2 order of pasta and 3 meatballs were average at best, but the bill was over $50. Their wine list is not bad....but it's overpriced. Even a friend of mine who works in the wine wholesale business thought the policy was mindless and greedy. I always say "If you're going to try and screw the neighborhood....you are going to lose your local following." Take it for what it's worth. And let's not forget the bartender who projects an attitude that he's doing you a favor by serving you. All in all a forgetful dinner...and my last at A16.

ciao
author: norman c.

description:
A16 is a quaint little Italian Restaurant located in the Marina neighborhood.  On the outside, it is non-descript... Trendy, quant, & cozy. The atmosphere is a sophisticated blend of old world Italian blended with the new age vibe of hipsters. The wine list is top notch and the food is superb. True to form for the southern Italian cuisine, they opt out of providing balsamic vinegar with bread, so don't even bother to ask for it. The pizzas were served piping hot and piled with fresh cheese. Instead of slicing the pizza for you, they bring out a pair of scissors for you to cut your slices as you wish. To finish off the meal, I ordered a vanilla latte. I do have to say, this was the highlight of my meal. It was perfect, and comes with a piece of homemade toffee to dip in the latte. It was divine and the perfect end to a wonderful dinner.

All in all it was a lovely experience!
author: Natalie W.

description:
Come on A16, how could you serve such a horrible prix-fixe dinner for New Year's Eve?  We spent $400 before tip, and the meal was terrible tip to tail.   

We've been huge A16 fans.  Went there every Friday night for years, then stopped when we had a baby.  We haven't been in a couple of years, but thought of course it would be a great experience, since it always had been.

Such a huge disappointment.  We won't go back.

The last horrible prix-fixe meal we had was Valentine's Day at Des Amis in 2014.  They went out of business within a year.... Wonder if this is the fate for A16.
author: heather h.

description: The food lives up to the feel of the restaurant, which is traditional, yet trendy and has good energy.
author: Karen L.

description: We haven't been more than twice... It's been a long time since we've been back. (Telling) I remember it being just ok.. Not astounding while not bad... :)
author: Kirk M.

description: Good food and nice atmosphere. My friends and I went here last night for dinner and we got the squid ink pasta, funghi pizza, and the bianca pizza. Although the pasta was good, I was disappointed with it. I've had squid ink pasta numerous times in both Italy and Japan and they always come in squid ink. This pasta was dyed with squid ink and just tossed in olive oil. It also only came with slivers of dungeness crab, which was sweet and tasted amazing, but disappointing for the price point. My friend's funghi pizza and bianca pizza were both good but nothing better than anything I've had before. The restaurant has an up-scale atmosphere so dress a little dressier and it is much larger than it looks on the outside!
author: Hana K.

description:
I have been here a few times and the food and service is constantly great. For starters- you should absolutely have the burrata- it's amazing and we also had the octopus- also great. 

For dinner we shared the sausage pizza and the fungi pizza. I would recommend the sausage- maybe not the mushroom. 

For dessert- we charged the peach crostata- amazing and the almond pound cake- it was good- could have been better. 

But always a great place to dine with great service.
author: Lauren L.

description: I was so looking forward to eating here as I heard it was great. The atmosphere is lovely, the service is great but the food is subpar. Not bad, just not amazing. It was really hot too with both ovens open in the dining area. Don't order the squid ink past- one of the worst versions I've had
author: Analeise T.

description: As good as it gets for Pizza - most people think "pizza is pizza" but A16 convinced me otherwise. The topping combos are unique and pair excellent with their wine selection. The crust is perfectly cooked on every pizza I've ever gotten here. They switch their menu quite often and I'm always impressed with the new selection of appetizers, new antipasti dishes, and pizza extras. They focus on only southern Italian wines which I didn't know much about before but one of their  wine sommelier took the time to give us the whole run down. He paired our entire meal with different wines which made everything taste just that much better! Very impressed with this restaurant and will definitely be back soon!
author: Dylan O.

description:
Service was great, I'll say right off the bat. The food wasn't terribly mind blowing on my end but my dates food was very tasty. We ordered the prosciutto as an appetizer, which was fine, just a pile of meat and some apple slices, not much to say about that. The entree I ordered was the squid ink pasta, which I had to send back because it wasn't cooked through enough and was very dry/bland, I think it was supposed to be al dente, but didn't quite get there. The waitress was very accommodating and swapped it out for a pizza (i figured that was a safe bet) which was tasty but nothing extraordinary. My date ordered the halibut with a side of brussel sprouts both of which were excellent and flavorful, made me wish I had just ordered that. It also gets VERY loud inside once it started to fill up, I could barely hear my date across the table talking at a normal speaking level.

Overall I think this place just tries to be shishi for the sake of being so. All the menu items are every fancy specialty store term and ingredient without any kind of context, the prices are on the high end and the food wasn't bad but wasn't terribly memorable either. The ambience is really cute and charming, the waitstaff were very attentive and friendly but I doubt I'll be returning.
author: Jp M.

description: I came here with 3 friends last night after receiving a gift card from my boss. 2 of my friends ordered the squid ink pasta, which we all agreed was pretty bland. I ordered the Funghi pizza, which was pretty good. Very fresh ingredients and the arugula and ricotta kept it light. My other friend ordered the Biana pizza, which I liked the most. All in all the food was good, but it's San Francisco so I can almost always say I've had better.
author: Allison D.

description: I really like the pizza here. I have only had the pizza so I can't speak for the rest of the menu. I have only gone to the bar so I can only comment on the barstaff. Both times I was very pleased with the staff. Knowledgeable and courteous. Well done
author: Valerie R.

description: Have been twice now and enjoyed both meals here. The other night I had the prosciutto and fruit to start. Delicious, but the fruit component was just a few fine slices of persimmons... I was imagining more sweetness with the salt. For my entree I had the squid ink pasta with sea urchin. Also tasty, though I found the portion a tad light. Fortunately my dining companions over ordered, so I stole bites of everyone else's meal to fill me up. Service was excellent, my water glass was always filled to the brim and our waiter was on point the entire evening.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
A 16 gives a stellar food and service experience - one of the best in the Bay Area which is a big bold statement. Also, it's vegetarian friendly - my wife commented that it was a great balance and selection along with the meat and seafood dishes.

We had the arugula salad with fruit (baked grapes) and o-m-goodness, it was outstandingly tasty. And right off the bat, a simple and amazing appy set the tone for the rest of the meal.

As a half dish (a little small IMHO) was the pasta special with shaved crusted roe. This in itself was one of the most sublime and best pasta I've ever tasted. The texture and right balance of basil herb sauce and seafood was unexpectedly knock-your-socks-off good.

A 16's pizzas are just outstanding - we opted for the funghi / mushroom thin crust pizza and it surpassed our expectations as well. Coming from NYC and east coast roots, I have to say that the best SF pizzas can go toe-to-toe with any pizza from Manhattan or Brooklyn. 

The wine menu is incredible (and can be very very pricey). Absolutely the bill can run away from you if you're ordering wine, it's their specialty and no Bay-area restaurant can match their Italian selections. But if you want to go there for amazing food and maybe a glass or a tasty beer (Dogfish Head IPA with Syrah Must is the bomb!), a five star meal can be had for moderate price. 

Another aspect that makes A 16 stand out from other restaurants is their incredible service. Ignore the pooh-poohers and haters, go with terrific company and have yourselves a sublime dining experience.
author: Dante G.

description:
Positive:  Very good sausage pizza.  Stick with the pizza and you will be okay.

Negatives:  Wife order squid ink pasta with clams.  Very weird, strong taste of some herb.  Fortunately waitresses took it back with no argument.  Wife asked waitress to bring a pasta that she thinks is good.  The Maccaronara showed.  It was edible, but reminded me of the canned spagetti I ate many decades ago.

Special that night was trout salad.  Not good.

Restaurant is pricey with 3 of the 4 items pretty bad.  Vastly overrated.
author: steven t.

description:
3.5 stars but rounding down since the service was so so and I didn't love a lot of the dishes.

We made reservations for a party of 6 on a Saturday night, and the restaurant was packed when we arrived at 7:00pm, which was expected. However, our table wasn't ready when we arrived, which wasn't expected! We had to wait for 10-15 minutes, which was pretty annoying. When we were finally seated, we ordered:

-Burrata w/Olive Oil, Sea Salt, Crostini ($12, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a-16-san-francisco?select=tDuBmXLL5PPINF_d2pn43A#tDuBmXLL5PPINF_d2pn43A): Pretty good, but not amazing. I didn't like the crostini they served with it, and preferred eating the burrata with the complimentary bread.
-Braised Octopus w/Fingerling Potatoes, Green Olives, Celery, Frisee, Roasted Garlic ($16, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a-16-san-francisco?select=tDuBmXLL5PPINF_d2pn43A#pTDlMh-bE6Y3nu6g6KPKqQ): Just ok. There were too many components in the salad and the braised octopus got lost amidst all the other flavors. Skip!
-Salsiccia (Mozzarella, Fennel Sausage, Roasted Broccoli Rabe, Grana Padano, Garlic, Chiles, Olive Oil, $19 + $2 for Arugula, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a-16-san-francisco?select=tDuBmXLL5PPINF_d2pn43A#hIT0FiURSlu8NgknP9sEpw): Too salty. I didn't like the combination of ingredients, and wouldn't order this again.
-Bianca (Mozzarella, Grana Padano, Green Olives, Basil, Chiles, Garlic, Olive Oil, $17 + $2 for Arugula, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a-16-san-francisco?select=tDuBmXLL5PPINF_d2pn43A#hIT0FiURSlu8NgknP9sEpw): Yum! I liked how the flavors of the different cheeses worked together. Recommended!
-Squid Ink Tonnarelli w/Fort Bragg Sea Urchin, Cherry Tomatoes, Fennel, Fried Bread Crumbs ($22, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a-16-san-francisco?select=tDuBmXLL5PPINF_d2pn43A#sb4C5-Sk_Ml6AJ8ZHunZBQ): Yum! The bottom of the uni got a little cooked from the hot pasta, but I liked the contrast of the briny uni and sweet squid ink tonnarelli. Recommended!
-Maccaronara w/Ragu Napoletana, House-Made Ricotta Salata ($18): Just ok.. I had high expectations for this dish, which was on the 2011 7x7 Big Eat list. The maccaronara had a nice chewiness, but the ragu was on the bland side. Skip!
-Nettle and Ricotta Gnocchi w/Hen of the Woods Mushrooms, Green Garlic, Olio Nuovo, Grana Padano ($21, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a-16-san-francisco?select=tDuBmXLL5PPINF_d2pn43A#p9ri4c7piZFC6vj450S-3g): Just ok, but I've never been a huge fan of gnocchi so if you really like gnocchi, you may like this.
-Roasted Anson Mills Polenta ($7, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a-16-san-francisco?select=tDuBmXLL5PPINF_d2pn43A#weD_Cd-tJ-5Mq88zkdAWoA): Eh, very bland/tasteless. I didn't like their version of polenta at all, and would not pay $7 for it again. Skip!
-Chocolate Budino Tart w/Sea Salt, Extra Virgin Olive Oil ($9, http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/a-16-san-francisco?select=tDuBmXLL5PPINF_d2pn43A#zDryzlyXBirG7xT4hNtMqQ): Yum! The chocolate was nice and dark, and went really well with the sea salt and olive oil. I can see why everyone raves about this dessert. Recommended!

This was my second time to A16, although a few dishes were pretty good, there wasn't anything that I'm in a hurry to come back for. I feel like A16 is a solid restaurant to go to for a good meal, but not somewhere you necessarily rave about. It's also really loud in the restaurant, so this isn't a good place to have an intimate conversation. Our server also seemed stretched thin, and it was hard to grab her if we needed something. Parking in this area is usually pretty tough to find, but A16 is towards the outskirts of the Marina, so there should be street parking nearby that is available.
author: Amy D.

description:
Great meal , average service. Unfortunately Too hot in the place to enjoy the food 
Hire a new AC guy !!
author: Kevin T.

description:
Outstanding! Not being familiar with Southern Italian food or wine, this was an adventure for us all. Our server, Shawn, made an excellent wine recommendation to start us off. The 2008 Terrefora Taurasi (red) was earthy with a smooth finish. It went very well with the Burrata, Salami and Olives we had as starters.

For our second course, we went with the Sausage Pizza - we added pancetta and arugula. Again, the next wine selection (2009 Taurasi) was perfect. The Pizza was so good - a perfect crust that was just crispy enough yet still chewy. And we had the fun of cutting it ourselves with pizza scissors! 

Our main courses (2 had the steak, 1 the tomato pasta, 1 the short rib pasta) were perfectly cooked and tasty. There was so much food, the side dishes almost went to waste. But a second bottle of 2009 Taurasi helped!

Dessert - paired as suggested in the menu - was divine. We shared the Cannoli, the lemon cheese cake and the Chocolate Budino. Divine!

Would definitely hit this one again in SF - excellent service and great ambience.
author: Dawn A.

description: Fantastic food and service. The Burrata (made in house) appetizer was incredible and along with the unique fresh persimmon salad, a full meal. Even the salt tastes extra delicious here!
author: Cynthia S.

description:
From the appetizers all the way to the canoli this was an excellent choice. I sat at the bar with my girlfriend and Stephen our wine connoisseur guided us through the meal with 7 pairings.

The wine selection is unique and extensive, all from southern Italy.

Highlights of the meal includes the clam pizza, the calamari, and the home made pasta.

Go here if you like wine and a great food experience
author: Sean A.

description:
If food were the only thing to write about I would have easily walked out of the restaurant so happy. However my ordering wine experience was so horrible that it almost literally left a bad taste in my mouth. 

I was at the bar celebrating a birthday and wanted to order carafe of wine. I was trying to decide between two so I asked the server if i could have a little taste to help me decide. The server told me they don't do tasted and based on her description I should be able to choose. I almost walked out. It was clear we were going to order wine and a taste would of just been good service. 

I ended up enjoying my meal, but I don't know when I will be back or if I will ever recommend this restaurant to a friend. 

Sad the wine order experience was so bad. Good service just isn't the same anymore.
author: Madison O.

description:
Located in the yuppie Marina district, I was surprised that we could get a table at this restaurant during prime time without reservation. So, upon hearing so much about this restaurant, particularly in rave reviews of the pizzas and pastas, I thought it'd be amazing. It turns out, the appetizers were great, specifically the tripe. The sauce was creamy and full of depth in the trippa that I had expected the pastas to come out the same (full of flavor, creamy sauce, etc.). The pastas were quite the opposite, as the sauce was watery and disappointing. The texture of the pasta was firm, but nearly anything to write home about. Perhaps, A16 had an off night about the pastas. I really wanted to like this restaurant, but could only see the goodness in the trippa. Below is a rundown of what we had.

Prosciutto
Zuppa
Trippa
Squid ink tonnarelli
Mezzemaniche
Steak
Chocolate Budino Tart
Meyer Lemon Tart
author: Jay C.

description:
Positives: I came here with my mom from out of town (NYC and Cleveland). We sat in the back in front of the pizza counter. We loved the yellow flowers and open skylights of the restaurant. The food was delicious. We had the sweet greens salad and the other one with the egg on it and it was so good! The dressing was amazing. We got the ricotta pizza and the bucatini for entrees. Both good but not best I ever ate. Dessert we had biscotti with cappuccinos. 4 star food

Negatives: our server was a young man who was not very attentive. I asked for a Cabernet recommendation since their wine menu is like a book! He ended up giving me a blend which was good but not what I preferred. Also after dinner our plates were cleared and we had to wait 10 minutes before he came and asked us if we wanted dessert. Overall the service was a 1 star.
author: Tiffany A.

description:
Great place for a dinner with friends! The service was excellent. 

Peppers, burrata and several different kinds of their pizza. All great! Pretty nice wine selection and a few good craft beers.

Desert was gelato... Also delicious. Would definitely come back.
author: Brett H.

description:
They called me a week before Valentine's Day to confirm my Saturday (day before V Day) reservation and also spring it on me that the only option is a prix fixe menu at $85 a head. This is stated no where on the website or anywhere else (I just double checked).

At this point, it's way too late to get a reservation anywhere else, which I'm sure A16 would realize if they cared about customer service at all. There are two possible reasons for this -- either they don't care enough about customer service to even post their plans to have a prix fixe menu or they know a week out from Valentine's Day, customers with reservations will have no choice but to pay the OUTRAGEOUS $85 per head for a place known for pizza and main courses that normally range between $15-20.
author: Evan K.

description:
I cannot speak for the food itself since we didn't get that far, but in my opinion, it's usually not the food you remember. It's the overall experience and this was a very, very poor one. I made a reservation at A16 days out for my boyfriend and I who were in town for the Super Bowl. A friend of mine had recommended this place, so we made the trek from where we were staying to check it out. We were running 10 minutes late for our reservation so I called to let the restaurant know. The gentleman who answered said it was no problem and that they'd have something for us right when we arrived. When we got there, we were seated at a bar for dinner. I politely asked the hostess who sat us, who claims she was the manager, if there was a table since we had a reservation and she said they didn't have any tables. I again told her I had a reservation and she says "yes and you guys were late and we are still accommodating you." Wow.

I usually give people the benefit of the doubt, but she could have cared less about the situation and was unprofessional and rude. I explained to her how far out I booked the reservation, that we were in from out of town and really looking forward to dining with them and she says "well you'll still have the same experience." Umm wrong answer sweetheart. We decided to leave and on our way out I walked up to her and told her I was really disappointed in the way she handled the situation and she didn't even know what to say. And if she really was the manager, I suggest the owner think twice about the representation in the front of the house. I will never go back or recommend this place. It's a trendy "you're lucky to even be here" kind of atmosphere and mentality, based on how we were treated. I've worked in the hospitality industry and this could have easily been avoided. What a shame.
author: Jenna Q.

description:
Other than the wine sommelier who paired a great wine for dinner this place really let me down!! Pasta was so bland, salty and was nothing what I expected!! My fiancé got the spicy pasta dish that came with a fistful of undercooked pasta (al dente is one thing this was not) that tasted like Tabasco with noodles!! Awful!!! 

Have no idea where the good reviews are coming from but if you want real homemade Italian this is not for you!!
author: Damian D.

description:
For my 100th review, took my eating buddy here to specifically to try the Margherita since we are both thin crust pizza junkies who are big fans of this pizza at Delfina. 
We made reservations at 6:30pm and by the time we got to the restaurant with traffic, the place was already packed. It was really cool to see how the restaurant ambiance changes as afternoon shifts to evening. The natural white light that pours through from the sliding glass doors and skylights gradually changes to softer yellows, kudos for the designer of this restaurant. 
Onto the food. Eating buddy really knows how to order, and she requested that they put sausage on only half the pizza, so we could get a taste of it with and without toppings, very smart!

We ordered the following dishes:
Octopus salad with potato and olives
Bucatini pasta
Pig head pasta
Margherita pizza with half fennel sausage
Signature chocolate budino tart with sea salt & extra virgin olive oil

The margherita here was very solid. In my humble opinion it stacked up very well against Delfina (not an easy task), the only difference being the sauce was a little bit saltier and the crust was just a tad more heavy. At that point, it's just a matter of personal preference.

The octopus salad was a nice starter, balancing the lighter thin sliced seafood with tiny potatoes. The bucatini pasta is their signature pasta that was good enough to overcome eating buddy's aversion to thick pastas. It was a small sized but hearty tasting portion perfect for sharing. I also enjoyed the pig head pasta which was unique, with flakes of meat that almost reminded me of a more savory version of cooked tuna. By the time we got to dessert, the signature chocolate budino tart was a great cap to the whole meal. 

Needed a short walk around Chestnut after the meal to get the juices flowing but overall it a great time at one of the cutest restaurants in the Marina.
author: Mark Y.

description: Good food and wine, but pretentious D Bags.  I had eaten there several times over the years.  One Wednesday, I went in just after it opened for lunch.  As far as I could tell, the place was empty, and the somm and bartender were hanging out.  I asked if I could order a pizza to go, and they refused!.  Now I could see if they were at capacity and struggling to serve seated diners.  But the place was totally empty.  I had certainly ordered pizza before at A16 and taken the leftovers home in a full size pizza box.  Stupid people with stupid policies.
author: Steve S.

description:
A16 is simply the best Pizza I have ever had outside of Italy. The produces are extraordinary and with everything begin done in house you can taste the freshness in every bite. The pizza is SIMPLY fantastic, emphasizing on SIMPLY as that is what makes for amazing Italian food. 
Simply love this place and have been loving it for years!!
author: Bouba C.

description: The food was excellent. But, our waiter was testy. Ruined our evening. We talked to other people who said they've gotten the same treatment. I don't care how good the pizza is. I wouldn't go back and risk having to put up with shoddy treatment from a pissy waiter. Sorry, A16. Have a talk with your staff.
author: Sally R.

description:
Made a reservation and were promptly seated at 6:30 on Wednesday. The place is much bigger that it looks from the outside and also has a covered patio which looked lovely.

We are vegetarians ordered a half carafe of an Italian wine that our server recommended, and three dishes: the lemon zest ricotta gnocchi with green garlic and morel mushrooms, the bucatini with walnut pesto, and the funghi pizza.

The short version? Ignore the pasta and just go with the pizza

The longer version:
After we had placed our order, we overheard a group nearby complain among themselves about the bucatini dish they had ordered; they sent the dish back saying that it was "too al dente" and "they were excellent chefs and so they knew the difference". Immediately, tucked in our corner, we started judging and ridiculing these people who clearly didn't know what al dente was and who basically were demanding limp pasta. But then, our dish came. And there were crunchy parts-- like literally uncooked parts, especially at the ends of the noodles. And we discussed in hushed tones our options-- stop eating and have the dish cleared? Finish it and spit out the tough noodle sections? Or... send it back? But if we sent it back did we want it replaced? What if they overcook it to compensate? As you can imagine, this was quite the dinner conversation/ dilemma. Eventually we decided yes, it would be sent back, and yes, we would want it replaced. And everyone in the restaurant was gracious about it even though we felt bad and couldn't quite meet their eyes the rest of the time we were there. And frankly, even when cooked right, the flavors of the dish didn't impress us, and we wished we had ordered something else. The gnocchi was a similar story-- fine, but not amazing, though cooked perfectly.

Then the pizza came out, in it's full glory with the cutting scissors and all. Covered in mushrooms with a delicious smoky cheese and accompanied by chili oil, we were in love with it from the first bite. The crust had the perfect chew. The chili oil had a nice kick. The mushrooms were plentiful and fantastic.

The verdict: Perhaps yes we'd be back to eat pizza, and pizza alone. However, the pasta game in SF is strong and this place, at least for their vegetarian options, didn't make the cut.
author: T K.

description:
We ordered:

2 pizzas (one funghi, one sausage with egg)
Then the table split a salad, the gnocchi, and the pork loin
One chocolate Budino to split (I could have eaten the whole thing - this was amazing)
2 orders of fingerling potatoes (another error, the one order that came with the pork would have been enough)

I went with 3 friends (we spilt all of the above). Here's a tip, if you go with 4 people only order ONE pizza as an app.  (our table ordered 2, and that was a mistake b/c we were full when the other food arrived).  

For me the pizza was awesome, but that dessert was INCREDIBLE, it was a chocolate wafer crust filled with ganache and topped with chocolate gelato and - here's where it gets interesting - a generous sprinkling of olive oil and salt.
author: Amy W.

description:
Good pizza, nice crowd, nicer service and welcoming premises in the middle of enchanting Chestnut Street. 

Recommended!!
author: R P.

description: A16 is a go-to for a great meal. If you love pizza, meatballs, and wine, this is your spot! PS order all of those things!
author: anonymous a.

description: Out of the world food with unique food options.  Designer salads, great pasta and pizza from the southern italy in most authentic taste.  I was traveling from out of town so finding this gem was a blessing in disguise.  I am sending this message to all my SF friends so they all can enjoy this wonderful cusine, loving staff and extra cute menu of spectacular foods !! Loved it. Be back sooon !!
author: Sam W.

description:
Finally came here for dinner. Ambience--dimly lit, loud but not unbearable.  Food was overrated---pizza was meh (not crispy), one of the pastas way too salty, the pork shoulder dry and flavorless.  I recall this place had amazing reviews when it opened several years ago.  Seems like quality must have gone down.  Details below.

Appetizers were the only thing I enjoyed. Burrata-- creamy silky, delicious. But the sea salt was unevenly distributed. Kale salad was bright and flavorful.

Then things went downhill.

We ordered two pastas;
Macconara: sauce was way too SALTY.  That's the only flavor I could taste. 
Bucatini: a bit bland. Pasta was a bit too al dente.  Overall, dissapointed with their pastas. Vega in Bernal Heights has better homemade pasta.

Margherita pizza: just okay. Was soggy. Nothing to write home about. Seemed like a waste of calories/ space in my stomach. Pizzeria Delfina has much better pizza that isn't soggy.

Pork shoulder entree: bland,dry, zero flavor. Did the chef taste this at all? We ordered cauliflower as a side-- a hint of lemon but way too SALTY! (5a5 has Brussel sprouts seasoned with Meyer lemon that, flavor-wise, blow this out of the water).

Mocha gelato: pretty good. Hard to screw up.

Not a memorable meal. Would I come back?  No. There are far better places to eat in sf.
author: Caroline I.

description:
I don't venture into the Marina as often as i should. I was really glad to be able to dine at A16 after a last minute reservation on a busy Friday night. We were only given a 15 minute estimated wait! Amazing.

The starters are a blur. My only recollection is deeming the octopus and fingerling potato salad a winner. Sweet octopus and lightly dressed potatoes kept this appetizer refreshing. I practiced my table manners until the pizza's started to arrive to our table. Then i just threw my napkin aside and suddenly went on a carbo load. I kid you not, i inhaled 6 slices. I love authentic neapolitan pizza! A16 nails it with simple, fresh ingredients and a fluffy crispy crust.

Funghi: You better love mushrooms on top of mushrooms. They were piled up high and certainly meaty little mushrooms. 
Salsiccia: My favorite of the night! Not greasy but full of flavor from the sausage.
Margherita: Just fresh cheese and tomato sauce. I had to eat two, just to make sure ;)
author: Samantha L.

description:
Gave it a 3rd star ONLY because the Italian white wine our server chose based on our palate was good .. after she had to interpret what they all were.  

I lived in southern Italy and Sicily for 4 years so maybe I'm too picky??

If this is what "Italian" has become, don't tell the Italians.  It's the last place I would go for pizza and pasta.  Over-priced, crowded and very noisy.

We had the secondi plate .. so maybe that was the problem.  Roast chicken was actual chicken meatballs, the thick juicy pork chop was half fat, and I wish the waitress would have asked how I wanted my salmon.  I like it medium rare -- but barely heated raw is not what I expected.  Side dish of cannellini beans was ok - but why would you put bread crumb topping on them.  Roasted squash was initially ok .. but when I couldn't identify what the herb was .. it started tasting very metallic.  

I would not recommend this restaurant for dinner.  Maybe it's better for lunch?
author: Dorothy J.

description:
Before I say anything else, their service is TOP NOTCH. My buddy and I never felt unattended.

We ordered a barrata, margherita pizza, squid ink pasta, and maccaronara. The barata was excellent, the pizza needed a little more cheese and basil, and the pastas were a little undercooked but fresh.

All in all, it was a good experience.
author: Nick J.

description: Was recommended by a cousin who lives in LA and told us it was worth making reservations in advance.   We came from Philadelphia and were really psyched to try this place.  The food was great, the chefs behind the glass were pleasant and engaging, but our waiter was a total jerk. He made us feel inadequate when we asked questions about the menu, never asked us how we liked our meal,( the busboy did and the chef did), and he was no where to be found when we needed water desperately from the spicy chili sauce.   The chefs brought us water and even smiled that we asked them and not the waiter.  I will tell you as a frequent restaurant goer, I have never been treated like that anywhere. The meal was pricey and we would not have minded but the haute,snobbish attitude from the waiter destroyed our experience. Would not recommend this place at all.
author: Carole B.

description: Came here with Meetup group SF Foodies. I rarely eat at a nicer restaurant in the Marina, so I was happy to try this. Got the salsiccia pizza. It was decent. There was a special menu for Sunday dinner. Got the sirloin steak and string bean pesto pizza. These dishes were okay. The bruschetta was one piece. Got strawberry souffle, blackberry pie, and chocolate dessert. Those were good. Paid $32 with tax and tip each for four people. The food was okay, but not amazing.
author: Denise C.

description:
I came back, almost a year and a half later from my first heavenly experience and although it was still good - it wasn't the A16 I experienced that night.

Obviously every place is different each day and I'll say that the prosciutto was still amazing and the noodles were still well done. I got the pizza this time which was also very good.

I'm not sure why, but it didn't have that magical feeling I had the first time. Which only means I'm human.
author: Julia P.

description: It is always a pleasure, as an out of town visitor, to think of a dining establishment as something you wished was located in your own neighborhood.  I have been going here since Day 1, and for me, may be the best authentic expression of Naples cooking.  The wine list excels with choices from Southern Italy, and pair well with the courses.  Five stars all the way.  Be sure to dive deep.
author: Richard B.

description: We had a reservation and were seated promptly. The place was a little crowded and loud. The Insalta Pantesca and Norma pizza was awesome! We also had the fungi pizza but weren't a fan of it. The deserts were good especially the chocolate bread pudding. Overall, the food was good however the service was terrible.
author: Dipali P.

description:
A16 is popular for so many reasons: it's sophisticated. Unpretentious. Fun.

It's also super busy. On a Sunday night, every seat in the house was occupied, so MAKE a reservation.

The kitchen did an amazing job of turning out our dishes fast and hot. I usually prefer the food not to come out all at once, but we were hungry so on to the food we go! 

The special app of the night was a bruschetta with pureed fava bean on a thick cut rustic bread with a thinly shaved pecorino cheese on top. Is it worth $4/piece? I would say it's a delicious starter, with hints of lemon and mint, but it could be priced lower.

The roasted calamari with agretti, Sicilian cucunci, basil and orange agrumato was pretty in presentation and wonderful in the mouth. I loved the freshness of the calamari.

Our Funghi pizza had generous roasted mushrooms, smoked mozzarella, grana, garlic, oregano and olive oil.  The peppery arugula that topped this pizza lends an interesting note to the smoky mozz.  It was absolutely tasty, though the crust was not crisp enough to our liking.

I've been in a pasta mood lately and the squid ink tonnarelli didn't disappoint.  It had Manila clams cooked in white wine, capers and garlic. A little heavy handed on the salt, but the pasta was al dente. It's also not stated on the menu, but this dish had a little kick to it from the red pepper flakes.

The polenta had a slightly crispy outer layer and moist interior.  A nice side dish to our meal. 

Even though we were close to being full, we couldn't pass up on dessert: a chocolate budino tart with sea salt and olive oil.  I've noticed the sea salt/olive oil theme popping up in a lot of dessert menus in SF, rightfully so, since the flavors really work together: the olive oil adds another dimension taste-wise and the salt brings out the chocolate flavors.  A16's version is fantastic, a chocolate pudding sitting atop a tart -- the crust is slightly crumbly and the pudding itself hints of bittersweet chocolate.

Service was efficient and unobstrusive, perfect for 3 ladies who just want to catch up on gossip!

A16 still has room for improvements, but having a reliable restaurant in the Marina that features Southern Italian cuisine, well, that's another reason why they're so popular.
author: Janice C.

description:
Went to A 16 on a Valentine's date with him. And to popular belief, yes, its true this is a place to be for any one who want an intimate setting. On nice nights, the patio is highly suggested.

We ordered the margherita pizza with mushrooms and it was very saucy and warm. The dough was tasty but not dough-y at all. The server cut out pizza with shears, something that we had never seen before. 

We will definitely keep this place in mind to try the other pizza topping flavors as its not the most inexpensive pizza pie in town, hehe.
author: C M.

description:
Been here a few times and usually have a decent experience; however last Friday the service, wine, and food, respectively, was quite off. 

Without going into full detail, we were offered various wines for some sort of wine festival that was going on, but were never offered a tasting nor was the first glass slightly poured so one person could check to see if it was acceptable. Definitely a a wine bar faux pas. All 3 glasses got filled up and as it turned out, both carafes we ordered were not to our liking. Not so much that we were going to send it back, but it certainly didn't enhance our food experience. 

Our server was not very interested in attending to our table, which was fine because we wanted a quiet dinner, but my meal was a simple pasta with tomato sauce that tasted acidic and not much better than a frozen dinner would have been. Since he never came back to the table, I didn't bother to send it back and he didn't seem to care that my plate was barely touched and I did not wrap it up.

The ambiance is chic but cramped and it is one of the more nicer places on Chestnut; however for the price, I would expect a higher standard.
author: Derwood A.

description:
Damn..... The Bruschetta is worth it alone! This place knocks it out of the marina with their house made ricotta cheese on this rustic thick cut bread and perfectly sweet baby tomatoes! 
We tried one of their two house made pasta's, out of this world! Then a white pizza that had the best roasted peppers...period! 
I love it when people get it, this place gets it!
author: Brook M.

description:
This place is delicious! 

Pros: the pasta is very fresh with a great menu with many options! The pizza and wine are amazing too! The atmosphere was very relaxed and nice for a Saturday night dinner.

Cons: none

Tips: get in early it gets busy!
author: Kyle L.

description:
A16: an adapted Italian sonnet

A16, how do I love thee? Let me count the ways.
I love thee for your macaronara 
Your pole bean salad, your prosciutto de parma.
I've had too much of your Sagrantino
For your wine list strikes out the Great Bambino
Oh, the things you do when you knead your dough 
Those things, they belong on HBO.
I've spent more nights than I can count
You've dwindled to pieces my bank account
So before I depart you on Chestnut Street
I'll order one more glass - something sweet.
Then walk off into the night, my heart a-flutter
With lingering tastes of bread and butter
A16 you have me, I'm a sucker.
author: Nancy Y.

description:
Food was great, hostess on the other hand, made us contemplate staying through dinner. I came here with a group of 6 for dinner and was told by the hostess we would need to wait(our original res was for 4) which was fine with us. We gave her our mobile line and went bar hopping. We got a notification from open table that we were ready to be seated and headed in to be greeted by the same unpleasant hostess scolding "I've been calling you for 45 minutes; your table is ready". We were offended but had dinner anyways. 


Overall food was wonderful but the "front of house" staff member needs a serious attitude adjustment. You're in hospitality- pick another profession if you want to be moody.

Also, it seems I am not the first person to have had a nasty encounter with the blonde hostess. A16, you've got a staffing issue.
author: Virginia P.

description: We love A16 and try to go whenever we're in the city! It was our first time for lunch. We were celebrating my son's birthday and decided to get several dishes to share - they were all AMAZING!!! For our appetizer we selected the Burrata then moved on to the Mussels and Squid Ink Pasta with Clams followed by the Funghi Pizza. All of this delicious food was paired with a perfect Marisa Cuomo Costa d' Amalfi! The wait staff were all friendly and engaging, specifically Sean & Reuben. Highly recommend to anyone who enjoys authentic, well made food along with an extensive wine list.
author: Cynthia A.

description:
It was a very disappointing experience! This was not my first time, here but it is my last!
This restaurant is a highly regarded busy place and it is difficult to get a reservation.
Evening started great with a parking spot in front. Early reso @ 5:30 so it was not busy, which was also a plus. 

Waiter was training someone and initially was very available. The Italian wine list was a challenge, but the sommelier was there to help make a suggestion. I was with a friend and we only wanted a half carafe. We asked for a taste, before we made our decision, and he ignored my question until I pressed on and asked again! He finally acquiesced, need I say, reluctantly......Really?

We had to flag down the waiter to order a 3 course meal that we shared. 
Within 5 mins. The appetizer shows up at the table, brought by a "runner". No wine yet. I mention to my friend, I hate when the food comes before the wine, so that the runner would hear me and help. She walked back to the open kitchen line and stands there? Eventually, the sommelier sees the situation and asks the "runner" to bring the wine? Upon her return to our table, she acted as if  it was her idea to help us out, as she mentions this to us as she serves our wine?.........Really? She was instructed to do so, disingenuous?

Food was so disappointing!  Calamari appetizer with creamy polenta lacked any real flavor. The polenta was more like a sauce, not taste or texture,and just yellow. If blindfolded, you would not know what you are eating. Pork spiedini was 2 skewers with 3, 1 inch squares pieces of meat over arugula for $32. We were sharing, so basically we each had 3 bite sized pieces of pork! It was dry and over cooked and had to ask for extra sauce to combat the dryness! Even the prickly pear sorbet was mediocre. It was overly sweet, and with no discernible flavor.
 
We are both gluten free, so it was difficult to find much we could eat. They were very smug that this is an "old school Italian place" and there were no gluten free options. I guess they are busy enough to leave out a faction of gluten intolerant people, that is their choice, I get that!

I will never go back again. I think it is not worth the price and hype! I imagine it's the pasta and pizza that carries this place, but this limitation makes it another over priced, over rated SF establishment that I would say BEWARE!
author: Judy C.

description:
Items Selected:
Semolina Bread with Olive Oil
Wild Nettle Ricotta Gnocchi - Pioppini Mushroom, Garlic, Mushroom Brodo, Herbs, Caciocavallo
Trippa Napoletana - Onions, Tomato, Chiles, White Wine, Breadcrumbs
Margherita - Tomato, Mozzarella, Grana Padano, Basil, Olive Oil
Wood Fired Dry Peach Crostata - Buttermilk Sorbet
Chocolate Budino Tart - Sea Salt, Extra Virgin Olive Oil

Owned by the same team behind Michelin starred SPQR and located steps from the Presidio a late night bite at A16 with an old friend was set to cap Saturday night but with my pal suddenly called out of town on business I was instead left to fly solo - an early arrival due to a meal shorter than expected at Nico leaving me standing amidst a crowd of walk-ins as incompetent hostesses struggled to keep tabs on a growing 'list.'  Originally offered a seat at the Chef's counter only to have the suggestion soon rescinded it was not until nearly thirty-five minutes later that I was informed that the bar was 'first come, first serve, full service' and having watched seats come and go along with another long-delayed duo it would be ten minutes more before we each procured a seat - my new friends suddenly a silver lining allowing for me to over-order and share.  Still jostled from behind as more potential patrons packed the front foyer it was from the bartender that plates would soon be ordered and although substantial delays persisted to the point of being gifted a complimentary plate of creamy gnocchi I have to say the food universally justified the hassles.  Conceptually based in the cuisine of Campania it was with warm semolina bread and clean, fruity olive oil that the meal got started and with aforementioned gnocchi understatedly herbal and aromatic it was with course two that flavors began to 'pop' - the tender tripe fully embracing a sauce of acid and wine prior to a reference standard Margherita whose springy crust bubbled up in pecan wood char with just enough aged cheese to enliven hand-crushed tomatoes and fresh-pulled mozz.  Again finding myself solo as bar-mates turned elsewhere for more drinks it was simply illogical to me to eschew dessert and after debating a seasonal favorite against a 10-year classic the only right answer was "both" - the wood-oven singed puff pastry lovely and light while the dark chocolate budino proved every bit deserving of its status on many "Best of the Bay" lists - a light kiss of salt serving to enliven the fruitiness of the oil and accentuate the subtle sweetness of an otherwise intense finale.
author: Michael U.

description: Quite the popular family place. They serve Excellent thin pizza that's far more interesting than usual: Olives and anchovies was my favorite, served with a scissors! Terrific crunchy bread offered with olive oil and a special balsamic vinegar for dipping. Nice, but I wouldn't sit across from the open kitchen next time...too noisy and busy.
author: Lynn S.

description:
I took a girl out to a date here without really researching it besides the menu, and it seemed fine.

Then she hit me with the dreaded question, "Do you want to order two things and split them tapas style?" In my mind, I was thinking NOOOOOOO, but I had to be the gentleman, so I agreed.

I did not know what burrata was when I walked in and now I wish I had never known.

But then again, that's only half of our shared meal.

I got the margherita pizza and it was alright. I've had plenty of better ones delivered to me at 3am here, but it wasn't anything spectacular. Plus, she took like 3 slices compared to the one dab of burrata I ate.

Needless to say, do not take a girl on a date, agree to split meals, and then have no idea what the hell she actually ordered.

Service was good though and they were very attentive.
author: Max M.

description: I'm shocked that A 16 only has 3.5 stars, it's one of my favorite restaurants in the city! I love the food, atmosphere, and friendly staff. I recently had a celebration dinner with a close friend and we loved everything as usual! The fish was definitely my favorite dish of the night. We also had a side of zucchini with garlic olive oil which was phenomenal and pizza (always a favorite). Dinners at A16 are saved for special occasions and trust me they are worth it. It's a lovely restaurant! I hope to return soon :)
author: Rachel S.

description: The trout over endives and black olives was an excellent combination. They don't have northern Italian wine but suggested a central white, verdicio which went well with the fish. Also there is no Limoncello or grappa for apéritif but overall it is a nice place for any Italian dinner.
author: Lauren K.

description: Really enjoyed my last experience at A16. Their wine list rocks and the food was delicious. I thought the burrata was some of the best I've tried (and I've had a few, even in Italy). Service was attentive. Room was stuffy and too warm--my biggest complaint.
author: Sandy G.

description: This review involves the incompetent and indifferent staff of this restaurant.  About a week ago, I made an in person reservation for 7 PM this evening and requested a specific table which table was noted on their system since I had requested the same table several times before.  I was called twice to confirm the reservation before today and they confirmed the requested table.  It was a special occasion for my wife's birthday.  This evening, about 1/2 hour before my reservation time, I was called and informed that a party that reserved the same table for 5 PM had arrived late and were seated at the table and thus I would be seated at another table .  When I asked why the late arriving party was not given another table, I was given a lame excuse and an indifferent response.   A-16 is no longer on my list of favorite restaurants and they will have to do without my recommendations to friends and visitors,  and my dining again at this restaurant.   My wife and I dined elsewhere and A-16 lost about $200.00 that I paid elsewhere  for dinner this evening.
author: Joseph N.

description: This place is a real gem, great selection of beer and Italian wine, and the food is spot on. We had the panna pizza and ceppo pasta--both were delicious. The service, provided by Hardwick, was sensational. Keep doing what you're doing A16
author: Aaron W.

description:
In short: great food, good service, and good ambiance. 

We have come here on many occasions. The wait staff have consistently been nice and just the right amount of attentive. The hosts on occasion have come across a little snobby. We most often order the wood oven pizzas which have been consistently great. Overall we highly recommend this restaurant and only wish they would return the cannolis and the olive oil chocolate cake to the desert menu.
author: Fardad H.

description: This place is so overrated. It's ok but there are many better upscale pizza places in SF.
author: Maria D.

description:
Greeting- yes
Vibe- hobbit hideaway
Prices- average
parking- street
Service- good

Food
Beet salad $10 was good
Gnocchi nettle was very good $20
Meatballs were very good. Available only on Monday's $22
Budino tart $8.50 was too salty

WIGB? Yes
author: Hungry K.

description:
