Try the rabbit; it's deboned and cooked well. Great for beginners and experts alike. I don't have too much rabbit experience (maybe guilt drives that decision) but I'm happy I chanced it here because this was the best one I've had. (Poor lil' guy.) The Erbette chard with pine nuts side was ok.

On to pizza. A16: You need to fine tune your Napoli pizzas. I was all hyped about the pizza with the oven, etc. but was disappointed that the bread/crust wasn't the least bit crispy; rather it was soggy. Though I did appreciate the top notch ingredients that were used, including a wonderful spicy oil that would even make Amido in Pai happy!

The Albacore tuna conserva app was so/so at best. And the salad, the fact that I even forgot what type it was leads me to believe that it was nothing special.

We were originally seated between two tables of loud loud men. Upon complaining, we were promptly moved to a much better table. I was quite appreciative about this, especially because it was a busy night.

Thanks A16!
author: Brian J.

description:
A16 is still a 5 star place and one of my favorite SF spots!

Tried some new dishes tonight and they were wonderful. Some of the best items were off of the fall harvest menu (which isn't always around) but my faves off the main menu are the pumpkin gnocchi, burrata starter and arugula salad. Also delicious was the chocolate tart for dessert!

Yummmmmm
author: Rachel R.

description:
We had a reservation and were seated only 15 minutes late (Is this good?) The wine list was very good, I tried to channel my energies towards wine happiness and ignore the aggressive posturing of our waiting neighbors insisting on being seated next. By the time we were seated I felt harassed and out of sorts.

The food was adequate and the staff friendly, I was not delighted when a third person inserted themselves into the adjacent table of two. I started to wonder if a16 is rite of passage dining establishment for newly minted adults.

I prefer Delfina, but the pizza scissors are delightful I will give you that.
author: Erin G.

description:
Did I really eat that?  

Everything I read said to eat the pork here and, featured amongst last night's specials was pork belly, which I now know is a slab-o'-fat.  I'm game, as the funghi pizza was excellent, but here's the rub:  it really is a slice of lard.  Melt in your mouth lard, but lard none-the-less.  The crispy outer-ring was delicious.  The teensiest bit of pork attached to that belly fat was good too, but then I had to wrap my head around the fact that I was eating one tablespoon fat for every 1/4 teaspoon meat.   Hey though, I took one for the team and it was sort of really good.  I didn't think about the grotesqueness factor until this morning when my arteries started screaming "breathe, dammit, breathe!".  So, I won't be doing that again.

Flatbread funghi pizza - 5 stars
Nurse Michael's inky pasta - 5 stars
Espresso Gelato - 5 stars and only $3 per scoop!
Pork Belly:
- Outerparts - 5 stars
- Inner parts - 1 star

Nice, happening SF vibe.  Excellent service.  

These are apparently the same folks that brought us SPQR (where the food was excellent even if I had no idea what I was eating).  There's a similar thing going on here, though the food seemed somewhat more accessible.  All of it good, but no more pork belly for me like, ever.
author: Tracey A.

description:
This is my favorite restaurant in the marina district. It defines amazing and shows you what kind of flavor potential is possible. 

Your first clue that this place rocks should be the mob of well dressed people at the door waiting for the food. A mob of people will wait for just about any food if they are hungry, but a crowd that large in an area that overflowth with good food? It means they are waiting for something special.

Special is a good word to describe here. Everything tasted special. We tried a side of potatoes, two pastas and a pizza. There simply was not a weak dish. This pizza was perfect, extremely thin crust with the perfect amount of sauce and ingredients. The pasta's were had phenomenal flavor that just left you craving more. The potatoes were cooked to just a shade short of crispy and had a perfect balance of crispiness to texture. 

Basically, A16 food was a showcase of the potential of flavor combinations. It is just insane how much unique amazing flavor they got out of a simply caprese pizza or the pasta dishes. I describe them with justice, but GO! Try it! Its is incredible. 

The ambiance is great. It was cozy enough that my gf and I could have a nice couply conversation while not feeling like we were isolated, as you sat close enough to other tables to exchange looks of pure dining satisfaction with your neighbors. 

The wait staff was top notch and was helpful and informative about all our questions. Could not have been more helpful.I was just completely blown away by all aspects of this place.
author: Tom O.

description:
So disappointed I couldn't give this place a better review. I had really been looking forward to trying this place. It's listed on the Bib Gourmand Guide and I've heard such good feedback from friends. 

The ambiance is great, what looks like a small space from the front really opens up in the back. What they lack in width they make up with depth. Modern look with views into an open kitchen and a cool spot for a date, if you don't mind a little hustle, bustle and common noise. 

The food is where A16 fell short for me. It started off strong as I shared the tonnarelli as an appetizer. The pasta noodles really surprised me, I loved the flavor and the texture, also the crab was delicious and not over powering. After the pasta appetizer, we had two pizzas the Funghi and the Margherita. The Margherita was pretty standard, great flavor and loved the crust. The Funghi is what I was really excited to try. I added prosciutto to the Funghi, and even with the addition it still did not reach my expectations.  Sometimes too much of a good thing turns bad, and that is what happened with this pizza. I found myself overwhelmed by the flavor of the mushrooms, and underwhelmed by all the other ingredients. The mushrooms were so salty it just overpowered everything. Moreover I paid $4 extra for prosciutto but did not feel as though I was getting $4 worth of prosciutto, save your money. To top it off, this place gives you shears to cut your pizza, which I for the life of me could not understand. 

The takeaway comes down to this: for a reasonably priced Margherita pizza this place hits the spot. With the dressed up pizzas like the Funghi, A16 misses the mark pretty badly. But, they make it up with excellent pasta. Finally, don't leave it up to me to cut my pizza. And, if you do, at least give me the proper tool, I don't know anyone that cuts their pizza with shears.
author: Alex L.

description: For Christmas last year we got a gift certificate to this place from some lovely out of state family who knows we like our food. Took us awhile to finally make use of it as we did not go until August 13, but frankly it was worth the wait. We had read some of the more recent reviews a few of which were rather negative and seemed mostly to pertain to service issues rather than the food itself. We had no such issues. The staff was friendly and courteous and there was not a moment we were not attended to. For what it's worth we were there during lunch so perhaps that makes a difference compared with dinner service. Just the same they were great and the food was superb. We had olives, the burrata, braised pork meatballs and the melon salad. All of which were delightful. Everything was perfectly prepared and had beautifully balanced flavors. The melon salad was my favorite. There was such an array of texture and flavor...fresh, salty, sweet, crunchy, light...a must try in my humble opinion. Overall we were really pleased with every aspect of our visit and would definitely go again!
author: H. B.

description:
Everything about this place works:  cool ivy facade....bustling vibe inside says: people like to eat here....a very well heeled crowd.....attentive/professional staff....amazing food.....stellar wine list.  

a16 feels like a hip, but neighborhood favorite in the west village.
author: Fred A.

description: I'm not a fan of the Marina but I wanted to try this place. I really liked the margarita pizza. It was slightly  too wet and difficult to eat but very tasty.
author: illy m.

description:
I usually have dinner here and it's very good. But the other day I had lunch and it was good, but I felt like the menu was limited. I had to get pizza because I didn't feel like a full entre (b/c it was lunch) and I wasn't in the mood for a salad. I feel like the chefs are so talented here that they could broaden their horizons with this menu. P.s. I also tweeted them that I was coming and they didn't even bother to acknowledge. Boo! 

Good for dinner, kind of limited for lunch unless you want pizza.
author: Tracy P.

description:
Ambiance - 5
Wine - 5
Service - 5
Food - 2
Price/value for food alone - 1

Because I rate food over anything else, it comes out to be a 2.  I have been there 2 times prior: once 9 years ago, once 5 years ago and always felt it was a 2.  I decided to go back recently with a group of friends to give it another shot, and yep, it's still a two for the same reasons.  I had their famed chicken meatballs which was a measly portion and dry.  At the table, others ordered the pork chop (I can make one much better with chops from Marina Meats and jerk rub) and the gnocchi - really really bland.  Waste of calories really.  Anyhoo...I won't be forgetting and I won't be going back.
author: Deal G.

description: I loved this place. Great atmosphere, incredible service ... the beet and mozzarella salad was amazing and I want to re-create, plus the corn and fig. Yum. The pizzas were all outstanding and everything tastes so fresh. I wish we had this restaurant in South Florida!!
author: Niki C.

description: This review is for Hardwick.  From the get go, this wait person was caring and sincerely interested in my questions, and made me feel cared for.  It was my birthday, and so I especially appreciated the positive approach.  She was really genuine, not something in great supply in fancy restaurants these days.
author: Ellen M.

description:
I am generously giving A16 3 stars. Here's the deal...parents are in town for the weekend and want to have a good Italian meal before they head home. A16 has a reservation...I think, 'gee, what a great place'. Before I begin, just want to state that I'm not mad...just disappointed.

Our waiter was Conroy. He was informative, but also arrogant about things. Any time you would ask him to explain stuff, he would give a deep breath/sigh and, in an annoyed state, would respond to the question. My old man recognized a particular winery and asked about that wine and the waiter responded 'Well, did you want a Rosé?...If not, then don't look at the Rosé, look at the reds'. Later, they didn't fire all of the entrees at the same time, so my pizza came out and before I was able to eat it, it was snatched away from me. I then had to wait another 20 min. No apology. Just a quick snag of my pizza and off he went.

When it was time to leave, we asked three (3) times for the leftovers. My mom finally walked up to him at the host station and he shoved the leftover box into her gut and said 'HERE...I wasn't going to walk it back to you'. 

Listen, this place isn't hurting for business, so perhaps they don't give a damn about the one local customer they piss off. I mentioned something to the manager, who was nice and offered to buy my a drink, but in situations like this, I'm not looking for a freebie...I just want them to treat the customers right. I was looking for a good meal and got pretty rude service in return. Their meatballs were fantastic and the wine recommendation was good...aside from that, I see no need to return here.
author: Erik B.

description:
My husband and I are New Yorkers who are working in SF for four months. The other night, since we had three out of town guests, we asked our neighbor, who is a wine dealer, to recommend a restaurant that would be good for five people. He said A16 was terrific, so off we went with high expectations. 

Yes, the place offers excellent wine choices--my Pinot Noir was delicious, and reasonably priced. But the list of what's wrong with the place is long. First, it's ridiculously noisy and crowded. The tables are crammed together so that you can barely get into your seat; I'm a slim woman, but I couldn't get comfortable because my chair kept bumping into a guy seated behind me. Our table was located under a sun-roof window that could be cranked open and shut by a pole. When open, it blew so much cold air on us that our menus had to be held down by our water glasses. When we asked for it to be closed, we were hot. 

The service was truly unacceptable. My husband and I arrived early, and were seated at our table to wait for our three friends. It took us several minutes to get a waiter's attention so we could order drinks while we waited. Later, when we were all seated, the service was inattentive. When the meals arrived, I discovered I had no fork. Alas, getting a waiter's attention to remedy this was a challenge. 

I ordered a simple salad and a white cheese pizza. The salad was good, but the pizza? At this point, I've had a lot of SF pizza, and this one was mediocre at best. My friend's chicken was so undercooked she spurned it. Another friend, trying to order a steak, asked for mustard on the side. The waiter said, "We don't have any mustard." Why? Because the restaurant is Italian. Please! My caramel salted ice cream was so bland it was like iced milk--not nearly as good as what you can get at a supermarket. My friend said his ice cream had a coat of ice on it, indicating it had been scooped earlier and then placed in the refrigerator. Not a good move.

This is an unpleasant restaurant experience. The staff is nice enough, but everyone is so harried they can't help but offer terrible service. 

We all agreed that we would never go back.
author: Laurie F.

description:
Been going on and off to A16 for years --- and this place is still hitting it on all cylinders. 

Came in on Tuesday October 29th, 2013 around 8:45 PM --- and got the only remaining seat in the entire place --- a single bar stool in the front. 

I ordered the Margherita Pizza with tomato, mozzarella, grana padano, basil, and olive oil for $15 adding Prosciutto Di Parma for $4 to make it $19 overall plus a Peroni. The pizza took awhile however it came out hot --- and quite tasty along with generous portions of Prosciutto di Parma on it. The pizza was so large, I had to bring half home for the next day!

A16 is one of the few places to serve a "VPN Americas" certified pizza and it does not disappoint. After eating at Una Pizza Napoletana earlier in the week, I felt this place had a superior Margherita Pizza.
author: Brian D.

description:
I have never been less than very pleased with a meal here.  This is my go-to spot for a nice dinner in the Marina, and for good reason: a constantly rotating, broad and deep menu, great preparation and nice atmosphere.  Bonus: noise level below 130 dB (unlike many local spots).  

If you're looking to go out in the Marina for a great meal of pizza, pasta or meat paired with a nice wine AND want to avoid a complete scene, this is your spot.  Just be sure to make a reservation, or prepare to grab a drink around the block while you wait for a table to open up.
author: Scott N.

description:
Hard to get a reservation but so worth the wait.  Love the atmosphere in this cozy Italian place away from the Marina crowed.  We were seated right on time even though the place was packed and so many places end up planning poorly and you could end up waiting even with a reservation.  

We tried one of the Italian wines which was great.  For starters we got the burrata with crostinni, which was so fresh and tender yet, something was missing from this dish in presentation and taste, maybe some basil or sun dried tomatoes would have been a nice touch to bring some balance to the dish. 

Next we had the rabbit, kale and fungi pizza.  All the dishes were excellent, the rabbit was tender, stuffed with a little stuffing and celery in a broth.  Couldn't get enough.  The kale was nice as well.  The pizza was perfectly baked, great balance and toppings.  

Finished off with espresso, no room for dessert although they looked good.

The service was friendly, attentive and professional.  

Looking forward to eating here again.
author: Inga W.

description:
I have been to A16 twice. The first time, it was "meh" and the food was not that great. The only thing I loved was the wine and the burratta. Service was OK. 

2nd visit was last night and it was absolutely horrendous. Our server finally came over after sitting there for a good 10 min. Asked us, "Do you want to order anything?" Um yeah, how about drinks?? Brought our drinks & app. Never came back to check on us. We flagged down the Manager who took our dinner orders. 

I had the gnocchi which was so bland, in a chicken broth, with little squares of butternut squash. Ate half of it. 

My friend had the pork shoulder which was basically rare and polenta which was so bland. Ate about 2 bites of it. 

Server NEVER came back to check on us. We saw him and asked him for the check. We told him my friend didn't like her dish and he thankfully removed from the check. 

Overall, A16 is 
-overhyped
-overpriced
-bland food
-horrible service

ONLY go here if you like crappy service and bland food. Will NEVER return!!!
author: Heather M.

description:
I have been to A 16 twice in the past week.  The first time we went, I kid you not, we had such a warm hello from all the employees that saw us.  Our server  knew the  menu well and was pleasant.  Sadly,  we went back expecting the same kind of service and welcome a few days later, 
and did not get it.  The server knocked over a half drank glass of wine and it broke on the floor showering my friends' leg with wine.  The server said she was sorry and brought a half pour of the same wine.  I asked why a small pour and she said that was how much was in the glass when she knocked it over.  I said that she should have gave us a full pour and she should not "nickel and dimed' us.  One thing I would say is the manager came over and said sorry and gave us a much better pour and brought a free desert.  Good save.
author: Bryan M.

description: So I was in the restaurant for a weird occurrence, the staff of A16 preparing dishes from SQPR for a special Sunday lunch.  Of course they're tied by Shelly Lindgren and this came to be a North and South Italy mashup. Chicken Liver mousse with carrot puree, Herb torta with greens in dill sauce, gnocchi with lamb ragu, passion fruit panna cotta with coconut, and a ton of wine would create a 4 hour lunch. Needless to say I wanted to do nothing the rest of the day. This meal made me realize I had been missing out hitting A16 (and to some extent SPQR since Nate Appleman left) all these years. Im always looking for a good Italian place since there's so few of them in the south bay. I guess I'll have to continue to trek to SF for my quality Italian fixes.
author: Kim N.

description: This is the place to go! If you love wine, service that blows your mind away then look no further. I love these guys and everything they stand for. Stop reading and get down there now!!! "I'm from the UK been here 3 times in the last week"
author: Iain W.

description:
Felt lucky that we got a booking here, despite the weird time of 5:30.

After eating here, I'm not so sure.

The place was full and vibey and pumping in the restaurant area near the marina on chestnut. Nice solid wooden, non table clothed tables in the modern style. Good varied clientele from families to youngish couples.

Large, long room with a bar taking up the entire side of one of the walls.

We get given one of the two man tables for 4 people. Yup, place is already full but the booking wasn't equivocal, it did say 4.


The starters were high quality, mostly low effort foods; salumi platter, prosciutto tasting, burratta ( this years mozzarella, what's best years wonder cheese, yak?). The one effortful one was the goat belly, unfortunately under seasoned, but helped by pickled cauliflower.

And then the average just started rolling: a pleasant duck fettuccine, an ok ink noodle calamari, a quite decent chicken meatball. What hurt was a ridiculously bland, uninspired, badly thought out butternut and gnocchi combo. The gnocchi were uninteresting, and combined in a broth???? with pieces of undercooked butternut. And this cost money?? It can and has been done better. But this was ridiculous.

Usually when going out we rate the maims 1st, 2nd and do forth. But my missus summed it up well when she said of the mains, why bother....


What saves it from being 2 stars is a few things. The look of the pizzas. We didn't try  any and that is a regret I will carry till my dying day as I'm unlikely to come back.  They were thin, attractive and were served with their own scissors. And people were finishing them, happily.

The starters, while simple, were fresh and great quality. The wines were interesting with a great selection by the glass. And finally the service was wonderful, especially the girl with the dragon tattoo.
author: Pantera W.

description:
Amazing Customer Service!!!!
Great food!
Best date my wife and I have had this year.
Thanks A 16
author: Brian O.

description: Upon arrival, they greeted me and I felt like a VIP. They made me feel very special and welcomed. The restaurant is small and the ambiance is great. They only use the freshest ingredients in their food too. I wish I lived closer, I would come back more frequently.
author: Kristin Y.

description:
This review was written after dining at A16 Rockridge; not SF.  But I'd avoid 'Special' dinners here, too!

CAVEAT:  We've had very good meals at A16 with their regular pizzas and pastas; but, when they do a 'special' menu -- as they did for New Years Eve -- run for the hills, because the meal will be on the dark side of execrable.  We learned too late; there's still time for you! 

To wit:

The first -- and, at least for one dish, the best -- course, ANTIPASTI, was either an albacore crudo (good, if hardly exceptional) or water buffalo veal polpettini (virtually inedible, but for the saving grace of some nicely-brothed, baby lentils underneath).  The polpettini were dry, overcooked, unspiced, and almost entirely lacking in flavor; I don't think we've ever had any 'Italian' dish taste so bland.

 So, we were off to an iffy start, but still undaunted.

Unfortunately, the second course, PASTA, was the beginning of the deluge of poorly conceived, prepared, and presented dishes.  The first, a crab crespelle -- not a pasta; think crunchy, tiny, crab flautas on a bed of oil-infused mashed potatoes -- sounded great and, indeed, the little flautas were fine.  But they sat on an oil-permeated, almost tasteless bed of mashed potatoes -- that, for some reason, were not just tepid, but soupy and cold.  A disastrous combo -- but if you ate the flautas quickly, the cold, oily potatoes could do only minimal damage to them.

The second pasta was a pasta: a single, large raviolo served with an egg inside.  We've had the Michael Chiarello version at Bodega, and it's absolutely superb: it comprises a very large raviolo, served piping hot, and when punctured by a fork, exudes a beautiful stream of bright, yellow egg yolk.  Here, tho, A16 over-cooked the raviolo -- such that the egg yolk had largely congealed.  And to add insult to their own injury, they then served the dish only luke warm.

The third course, the ENTREE, was a black cod or beef tenderloin choice.  The cod was OK, on a basic level but, strangely, lacked any seasoning, even tho it was touted as having a savory seafood brodo.  (Brodo? About the same as broth bought off the shelf at Trader Joes; tho somewhat less flavorful.)  It was served warm, the plate was cold.  Huh?

But, while the cod was at least edible, the beef tenderloin was horrible -- twice!  The first time, the plate was cold, and the beef, itself, was no warmer than room temperature.  I asked them to heat it and -- 10 minutes later -- was presented with what looked to be a different plate, with different cuts.  But, this time, the meat was gray, overcooked, dry, and -- essentially -- all from an end piece.  It looked thoroughly unappetizing -- but proved worse.

Resting on a bed of winter root vegetables, the beef proved inedible: about the worst I've tasted in my life.  Really.  The consistency was almost mealy.  And the bone marrow bread crumb garni only made a terrible dish worse -- since it tasted like small, sand granules.  (Cf.  Lark Creek's hot, savory, juicy Pot Roast with winter vegetables.)

The root vegetables were somewhat better -- but only because they had no flavor whatsoever.  And, to top it off, this version, tho slightly warmer than the first, was still served not much above room temperature. 

 After two bites, I conceded defeat, and pushed the plate far away.

Strangely -- or perhaps not -- our server never asked how that -- or any other -- dish tasted.  That, I found peculiar -- it was as if she knew just how bad the food she was serving had to be.  

We almost passed on dessert, figuring we could still get out alive, but -- hungry for something worthwhile -- were tempted by the rosemary + chocolate panna cotta.  Seemed like a fun concept of mixed flavors, but A16 took it precisely in the wrong direction: instead of lightly spicing the chocolate with rosemary, they basically served a rosemary panna cotta with chocolate flavoring.  The rosemary overpowered the palate -- and the many rosemary needles inevitably got stuck in one's teeth.  The cookies aside were stale -- as if purchased from a day-old bakery.

Our server was friendly, but the service overall was scattered and inattentive -- as the cold dishes (and lack of interest in how we 'liked' our meals) reflected.  Perhaps she had too many tables.

So, with relatively empty -- and thoroughly unsatisfied -- stomachs, and nearly $300 lighter in our pockets, we fled A16 for the safety of home, and some edible New Years Eve snacking.  

Enjoy the regular menu at A16 -- but by all means AVOID ALL 'SPECIAL' MENUS AT A16.  Even were if free, this would have been a terrible experience.

Silver lining?  The dinner was so abominable, we laughed [at] ourselves all the way home; we had to squeeze some lemonade out of the A16 lemon!  

(Two stars, because the regular menu is -- has to be -- much better; but no stars for last night.  Inexcusably atrocious!  And they probably have no clue how bad they were -- last night, at least
author: Susanne F.

description: New Years Eve in one of my favourite restaurants in San Francisco and i was extremely happy to manage to get a reservation for myself and friends on this night. They say at the end of a year "out with the old and in with the new." Well, that is what could be said about the food as well. They need to throw out all of the food from New Years Eve, as it tasted worse than old leftovers from thanksgiving; actually that is what they may have served. The food was truly disgusting. The soup to start was so small i had really focus to find it in front of me. Once i found it i then discovered it had no taste. I might as well have eaten the table cloth. For the second course I had the lobster pasta and what a workout that was trying to chew the lobster! It was clearly not fresh and was over cooked. Upon trying the beef for my third dish,  I discovered why they did not have salt on the table--they had used the restaurant's entire supply to season the beef. This leads me to dessert. I have a very sweet tooth and was excited to have a dish I would enjoy. But no, it was bland and tasteless. I also have to mention one of my friends had the lamb dish and it was actually inedible. We all tried it and it was actually sickening.  For a restaurant i absolutely love and the amazing food they normally provide, last night was a huge let down and is the reason I will never eat there again. The food was probably worth about 25% of what we actually paid. The atmosphere and service were much below the normal high standards as well. The restaurant did however take advantage of the occasion to provide a severely sub standard service for a premium price.
author: Andrew S.

description:
We were looking for a place to have a cozy/pizza wine and a little romantic dinner in the city, just us dressed up nice. 

We were so happy when we found this place, lovely with a fun atmosphere for us. Romantic and fun with a great wine list!

 - a bit on the haughty scale because casual jeans/button up shirt will make you stand out as the help (a patron asked my BF to move the chairs to a table for them)....we laughed at the silly people!
author: Tinydyno R.

description:
Wow, wow, wow... I think I found Heaven. 

I can't believe it took me so long to check this place out. It looks small from the outside, but the restaurant goes pretty far back and is fairly big. Service was great and our server was very knowledgeable. 

The food was the best I've tasted in... I can't remember when. I came here with a friend, and we started with the burrata appetizer, which was so good. The bread was a perfect dose of salty, and I think the cheese had honey or something drizzled on it. We also shared the octopus salad. I've seriously never had octopus that delicious before. It melted in my mouth like butter! For our entree, we had the chicken meatballs, which was equally delicious. Did you all know they have Meatball Mondays??? For dessert, we ordered the peach melba. BEST DECISION EVER. Ugh... so good. Do yourself a favor and order it... please. I felt like Giada with her uncomfortable sexual moaning after each bite. Even the wine was delicious! I wish I remember the names of them. 

We didn't plan on spending so much money for a random Thursday dinner, but we didn't care, because it was so worth it! Worth every penny! 10 stars!
author: Michelle W.

description:
A fantastic Italian restaurant that's surprisingly not that expensive. I came here with a friend for dinner on a Friday night. The wait was about an hour (normal for NY, so I didn't mind), and a glass of wine helped make it seem even shorter.

When we sat down, we went a little overboard and ordered way too much food for 2 people: the olives, the burrata, the butternut squash bruschetta, the lamb sugo pasta and the broccoli rabe and sausage pizza, and oh, the "bread upon request" too (hour wait + glasses of wine = big appetites?). And it was all great. Well, actually, 2 of the dishes were fantastic: the bruschetta (so flavorful) and the lamb sugo (the freshest pasta and most amazing lamb).

We skipped dessert because we were too full, but A16 is definitely on my list for next time I'm in SF.
author: Katie C.

description:
How can somewhere with some of the best wine I've ever swished down my throat, have also the most tasteless food I've ever had to force down that same throat? And if you aren't in a party, don't order a pizza because they won't cut it for you . I am still pondering this deeply, like why would you not cut a pizza if you have pizza on your menu?

BACK TO THAT WINE...oooh it's good. Get the Rose, out of this world!
author: Lauren V.

description:
Everyone on yelp will tell you to get the buratta, but it's pretty okay. Not stellar. If I did it over I'd probably stick to the bread basket. All the pasta was tasty, although if you're going to get the small portion, be aware that it's pretty small. My friend was still hungry and got a taco from TBell after our meal... and she's about 5'2", 105 pounds... so yeah, pretty small pasta portions. 

The atmosphere was nice, not too noisy, but still lively. I enjoyed watching the cooks toss the pizza dough and fire entrees behind the counter.

The food was less rustic Italian than I was hoping for. Probably wouldn't come back because there's so much else in San Fran that I'm sure would have me dying to return.
author: Meg S.

description: This place has good food. However, they will screw you with wait time. You come in with 1 hour wait, do not believe them. It will be 2 hours+. Make sure you ask them over and over again about the wait time before you sign up. We waited over 2 hours after a promised 1 hour wait and we're not going to be sat until 3 hours later.
author: Steph D.

description: I wanted to like this place, as we spend a lot of time in the Marina.  But it was a major disappointment. I had the polpitte (meatballs) and my husband had the calamari pasta.  The pasta was horrible and meatballs were just OK.  The arugula salad we both had was fine.  I had to send my wine back and get another variety, as it was not a smooth Pinot Grigio, as I was led to believe.  Pours were very small.
author: Diane G.

description:
We will not be going back.  Our waiter and server were both so rude that it ruined the meal.  The waiter was snarky, condescending and constantly rolling her eyes.  As an example, when delivering one of our dishes, I pulled a long black hair out of the cheese that was melted on top (none in our party had long black hair).  Our waiter watched this happen.  Rather than apologizing or taking the food back, she shrugged her shoulders and said "oh well" and walked away.

This is the third time we have gone to A16.  We keep going back because the food is good.  But this is the third time we have had horrible service, and there are so many better alternatives in the immediate area that we will not return.
author: clay c.

description:
I have been to this restaurant over 10 times since their opening.  Unfortunately since then they have slipped a lot in both food quality and service.  The food used to be universally tasty but now the macconara (sp?) is almost flavorless and the meat dishes are poor cuts and not properly prepared.  This is true of their other dishes as well.

I would particularly caution any diners with food allergies or restrictions as the management and kitchen seem unable to control for that despite assurances to the contrary.  On more than one occasion has my dish been cross-contaminated with nuts, oil or other detritus from completely unrelated dishes.  In other words, whatever the menu lists as the ingredients may or may not be in your dish.  This is sort of like playing Russian roulette with food so be careful.  My hope is that they can at least keep contaminants that are not clean out of the food but there would be no reason to believe that.

Michael Bauer is correct when he indicates that this restaurant has lost its focus.  it is unfortunate but the good news is that there are other much better Italian spots in the Marina including Parma and DeLaRossa.
 
Good luck if you eat here...
author: D G.

description: Ate here with the family on our first night on vacation in the city and it was a great experience.  The food was excellent and the service was good.  A bit crowded in the dining room in the back, but that is to be expected for SF.  Highly recommend (and we are picky)!
author: Kim V.

description:
I had Christmas Eve dinner here. All day I went restaurant hoping so I was pretty full when I came here.  My friend and I had ordered all apps and we had a few glasses of wine.  Everything was pretty decent.  Good ingredients, good fare.  Nothing too over the top though, except the tripe.  The tripe was the most tender tripe i had in my life.  It was so flavorful too.  Five stars for the tripe!  

Its a place where a lot of industry people eat.  It was interesting to observe the vibe in rest, especially at the bar.  would come back but not on my list.
author: A K.

description: Great pizza, great wines...although it's a bit of a meat-market sometimes.
author: Kevin F.

description: I've been meaning to write a very thorough review of this place. But first, the scenario...there is this banker who I just met that highly revered this place as an italian restaurant. Supposedly A 16 is in reference to a freeway or a road in Italy...ok...how is the food then? In a word, like they found it on the road and served it. That sounds mean, but here is the thing. We were a private party in the back and there were 12 to 14 people...all were lawyers, bankers, CEOs and then there is us...just a bunch of working joes who got the opportunity to see how the 'other half lives'. It's with this back drop that the appetizers were cold, the plates of food do not look like traditional Italian. I know because my family name is from Scafati so these plates of food look like a fusion of new age western concepts and there is nothing traditional about it. I was disappointed in the plating and the cold food. What I did like was their wine menu and my wife and I had a field day with the most expensive champagne and French wine. I think this restaurant is not authentic italian...it's more for the yuppie technocrats who plagued San Fran in the last 10 years and really don't know anything about food. Out of all the places we ate, we actually drank ALOT more than we ate here simply because it just wasn't appealing. A 16 is just about as Italian as Mario and Luigi from the Super Mario Bros.
author: Matt R.

description:
My favorite place to eat in San Francisco. 

The burratta cheese starter is simply phenomenal. I've never been so googly-eyed over cheese in my life. This deliciously creamy cheese is amazing. 

The pizza here is very savory.  I love the fresh ingredients and how they blend together with the thin crust.  Definitely a favorite.  

MAKE RESERVATIONS if you want any chance of eating here. Preferably a day or two in advance.  The food is great and everyone knows it, plan ahead.  

The location is also great.  Chestnut street is adorable and has lots to offer. 

Even though yelp claims the dress to be "casual", I suggest dressing up if you don't want to look out of place.
author: Michaela S.

description:
We were really looking forward to eating here, but were disappointed by the service and the food was meh.

Service:
As others have echoed, we arrived early for our reservation and were seated 15-20min afterwards. They seemed very busy so this place must be popular.

Our waiter was initially punctual, when we asked what was good, he listed 1/2 the menu in one long breath. He then disappeared for about 10-15 min. We placed our order based on his recommendations and asked for bread and water. Neither came until we flagged down another waiter that was passing through.

When the food was delivered and he asked us how it was before we had even taken a bite, we didn't see him again until we flagged him down for a to-go box.

Food: 
We ate almost 2 baskets of bread before the food came out, and had to stop ourselves from finishing the basket even though we noted that the bread olive oil combination was lack luster.

Pumpkin Gnocchi: typically a big gnocchi and pumpkin fans, we debated getting this as a full meal or as an appetizer. We ultimately decided to get it as an appetizer and actually said "wow I'm glad I didn't get this as my dish, it is not what i was expecting." 

 ******We were I ordered the steak medium rare and it was juicy and wonderful. 
The squash side dish reminded me the taste of a swimming pool. Weird I know, but basically it was not appetizing at all.

My friend ordered the pork with polenta on the side. 
*****We decided the polenta was good, but the pork was too dry. He admits that maybe he didn't know what to expect from the pork, so maybe it was a bad choice- although recommended by our absent waiter. 

We stopped eating and decided to finish the bread rather than the pork and squash dishes. We had to flag down the waiter for a to-go box since our dishes were still full of food, if he HAD been around to check up on us, he wouldn't have guessed that we were finished with the meal. As we walked home we wondered why we even had the to-go box since the food was not something we looked forward to trying again.

I can't remember the last time I ate somewhere where the food was so meh, that I verbally noted it was disappointing for several dishes in one meal. On top of it the service was sub-par. There were way too many tables in that space and the staff seemed to be overworked. I noticed that there were a lot of people on their cell phones at the end of the night. I assumed they were as bored as us waiting for their food, bills or credit cards to be returned. 

I wont return unless I find a guaranteed combination of items that I will actually enjoy.
author: Jessica H.

description:
We will never be back.  We had a reservation and some people in our party were running late.  This was a huge personal occassion for us and we wanted it to be somewhere special so we had picked A16.  Well, the hostess and the manager were snooty, snobby, rude, full of themselves.

We ended up at Bistro Aix where the servers were friendly and the atmosphere was relaxed and happy.

STAY AWAY from this place!
author: Sailing A.

description:
I've resisted reviewing this place.  I didn't love it.  But because it came so highly recommended I thought perhaps it was my fault.  I did something wrong.  Like maybe my expectations were just too high.  

From the outside it looks like a place I'd love.  Small, simplistic, dark...We started with a cocktail each.  There are only three to choose from-so thats 66% of the cocktail list tried by yours truely.  We sent one back, it was disgusting and tasted like watered down coke.  You know me, to send back something with alcohol served to me in a pretty glass...its got to be bad! The waiter just casually took it from my hand, and placed it on the tray of another waiter headiing back to the kitchen and asked us for our dinner orders.  He was apparently not too broken up over our disappointment. 

The wine list is spectacular if you really know Italian wines.  Im guessing.  I don't so I could be wrong.  But this menu was long, with a lot of Italian region headings of all places i'd like to visit or at least be able to pronounce.  I said, "I like brunellos, in fact give me a big Italian red"  He said I'll pick something for you and he was spot on! 

The buratta cheese was gooey and delivered.  The marinated olives good but kind of mushy.  And the ragu entree was delish.  I mean its ragu....

So all in all a good night, good company...and good food.  But I do believe people have a tendency to oversell this place.  And in a city like San Francisco it just isn't as special as I'd hoped.
author: Kierstan G.

description:
Mediocre in every sense. Overpriced and overhyped. Too many other places are better. Would never return.

Bad burrata (is anything more criminal?). Decent wine. Nice decor. Pizza decent.
author: George B.

description:
We came here with a few out of town guests. The food was good (4.5 stars). For appetizers, we had bruschetta, olives, and pork belly. For main courses, we split the margerita pizza and the grano pasta and a side of corn. The main dishes were really delicious. 

The sommelier was really nice and helpful but the rest of the staff was really inattentive and borderline rude. The hostess promised to seat us in an hour and then was incredibly rude when we inquired about how long it would be after an hour and a half. Our waitress ignored us for most of the evening and we kept having to flag her down. 

Good food, terrible service.
author: Jillian P.

description: It's somewhat of a relief that the food here is so mediocre; otherwise we'd have to endure the outrageous acoustics in order to enjoy a great meal. Which is to say, we did not have a great meal. The wine list is magnificent and the pizza crust is wonderful; the rest, poorly executed. Our servers was very sweet but overworked. Apparently the owners were/are devotees of the Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market, but it does not show in the food. My fiance is a former chef and I am an experienced home cook- we know food. If you want great pasta, go to Locanda in the Mission, at least it was great the last time we went, which was perhaps over a year ago. Everything we had at A16 was a bummer. I'm a pig, and I did not finish my food. The flavors of our pizza topping weren't balanced, the sauce on both of our pastas were lacking in depth and finesse, and our tripe was clearly cooked too fast (it has to have a loooooong and slowwwww cook to break down the fibers). If you want a place with good lighting, horrendous acoustics, great wine, and mediocre food, this is your place. It is not ours
author: Simcha K.

description: Great food, service and also the perfect place to take someone you don't want to converse with because of the sound level of the restaurant.   All kidding aside, the staff is friendly, attentive and top notch, the food is expressive of Italy especially the pizzas, the grilled salmon, the melon salad and the desserts fantastic such as the chocolate budino and pistachio torte.   A16, this restaurant would be 5 stars if it was quieter.   It's amazing how your wait staff can even communicate with the customers.   They must have noise cancelling ears.   : )
author: Bill F.

description: To our great delight we were able to get two seats at A-16 at the bar in front of the open kitchen without reservations. It is treats like this that make a vacation even more special. From the minute we sat down until we rolled out two hours later we were in food and drink heaven. The sommelier was delightful and we agreed on a bottle of wine that was perfect for the food we were ordering. Everything was delicious but the high point of the evening was watching the chef work non stop cooking food for a fully booked restaurant without missing a beat. Cannot recommend this place enough! But make reservations as I think we just lucked out to get to eat there with them.
author: Meridith M.

description:
A dinner for 3 and $163 later...

I'm far less than impressed. I get that this is an Italian place but if they can't cook meat entrees well -- don't include them on the menu. The pork chop was so-so and the lamb was over cooked. Service was slow too. Only saving grace was the house made peach ice cream (perfect for the one at our table who couldn't have dairy) that they brought us to make up for the entrees. 

Overall, I would never return or recommend this to anyone.
author: TM M.

description:
Why the low ratings? 

I dined here early on a Sunday night (5 pm, right when they opened) and enjoyed the experience. I had the buratta and crostini appetizer to start. No problem here. Then  I had the Salsiccia pizza to share. Most italian pizzerias have this kind of pizza and A16's was super yummy. (Way better  than the way Delarosa does it). The reason for this is because of their dough - super thin and light yet fluffy once you hit the crust. Yum yum. 

Service was top  notch and props to the ladies who kept having to refill our water glasses. Post beach = dehydrated. :)
author: Joy A.

description:
I have been to A-16 many times. It is dependable, a good first date spot with a variety of prices on both wine and menu items. However, the motivation to write a five star review is because things weren't perfect, but the way things were handled made my evening exceptional. 

1. On Sosh, we had read that there was a beer tasting menu- prix fixed inclusive beer pairings with food. When we got there, we found out that this was a misprint and they hadn't actually approved the messaging. But the concern our server had was so genuine. She went to a manager to check in it, she was apologetic and just so nice about it. She even brought us a complimentary beer taste. Very classy. It took the disappointment out of having to refocus on a new experience. 

2. At the end of my meal, for whatever reason, I got sick. I really rarely get sick. Our server (will add her lovely name later!) was so sweet, she brought me ginger ale and the manager came over to chat with me. She discussed that food poisoning usually takes some time. What she said made sense and I was happy to pay our bill, just had wanted to let someone know. (Was it the chili oil? Was it...) Ultimately, I just think my body didn't agree with something, or some combination.  On the way out, she handed me a gift certificate. She didn't have to, but again, it was very classy and left me feeling really great about the whole night. And a gift certificate was much better than taking something off our check. 

Thanks A-16 for a great night. I will be back soon. I love you guys!
author: Danielle V.

description:
The service was excellent.  The food was kind of a mixed bag.

We enjoyed the squid starter, which was stuffed with rice/risotto and raisins (they may have been cranberries or currants...I can't quite remember).  I didn't think the seafood and dried fruit would pair well, but was happy to be proven wrong.  We also shared a tomato and ricotta appetizer, which was simple, but very good.  (At least, I'm pretty sure the cheese was ricotta.  I could have sworn the menu had said the cheese was supposed to be burrata, but it definitely was not burrata.)

The pizza (margherita) and pasta (maccaronara) were disappointing.  The pizza was a bit bland, and the crust was soggy.  It was drizzled with a LOT of olive oil.  So much, that "drizzled" kind of seems like too light of a word.  The pasta was doughy.  We also ordered the sweet corn, which was served on the cob.  (The menu did not indicate this.)  It was delicious, rubbed with black pepper and olive oil, but not really worth the $8.  (We received three small cobettes, which equaled about one full ear.)

I also thought it was weird that they don't let you taste any of the wines.  I really don't want to pay $15+ for a glass of wine I might not like.  They do, however, offer half-glasses, for approximately half the price of a full glass.  I've been to other restaurants where a half-glass is closer to 2/3 the price of a full glass.

Would I go back?  Probably.  Would I go out of my way to do so? Definitely not.
author: D E.

description: Service, food and atmosphere were underwhelming.  Had a reservation but got seated in bar area as our table in the restaurant was still occupied by prior group (30 minutes after reservation time!).  No ambiance as it feels like sitting in a hallway.  It took 15-20 minutes to get wine ordered, food service was better.  The food was just okay, appetizers didn't taste good, main courses lacked flavor aside from pizzas.  Experience was similar to previous visit, I will not visit again as SF has lots of better places!
author: Marc L.

description:
A pleasant surprise awaited us after a bitter defeat in a beer pong fundraiser.  We strolled into this place with no reservations, and they seated us a a counter table right in front of the wood oven stove.  I know some people don't want to have all that distraction, but it was pretty cool to see the staff operated the stove with ruthless efficiency.

We ordered two pizzas (a mistake by us, but we both had leftovers for a nice Sunday lunch), roasted corn (completely awesome), and a dessert.  

My friend went off the grid with her pizza, per the chef, and got the Widowmaker via the Capriciosa.  This menu item is simply leaving it to the pizzaiolo (pizza maker) to decide what your pizza will be.  The widow maker had just the right combo of meat, and the server was gracious enough to give my friend two 1/2 glasses of wine to go with it.

The real hit of the meal was the dessert.  A Chocolate bodino tart with extra virgin olive oil and sea salt.  Generally, you'd think this was too many different flavors to go well, but you would be very, very wrong. Very.

So, here is to not planning, and going to a top notch restaurant when it first opens up on a Saturday.
author: Will A.

description: Lunch with some crochety oldsters who get together regularly and share dishes -- Four of the five patrons had some form of the burrito with tomatoes, eggplant and gorgonzola breadcrumbs -- excellent -- a squiggle of great olive oil over all if it, too.  We had some nice desserts, can't quite remember the pastry with mango and berry - fantastic.  We had one person with serious food concerns, and her issues were resolved by separating parts of one dish so that she could choose whether to have all parts or not.  Bingo -- she was happy.  We'll be back.  My latte was divine, too!  Most of us live in the East Bay; so, we'll try the location on College Ave in Oakland.
author: Sharon H.

description: My favorite restaurant in the Marina, easy. Love the squid ink pasta, any of the pizzas and I wish I could remember the delicious red wine we had the last time we dined there. My fiancé doesn't eat cheese so I get to eat all the burrata myself. :) Sit in the back at the bar area overseeing the kitchen. The chefs are friendly and will answer questions if you have them.
author: Liz S.

description:
Liked the restaurant and service was good. Interesting menu, needs to add a gluten free pizza to the mix . I had a pasta dish and it was very good. It is a loud restaurant, so it is not a romantic quiet date spot, but with 4 people at the table we could have fun and be loud. Everyone enjoyed their meal, with the best meal s being the steak or the pork chop. good job A16!
Only draw back no cocktails, but a bottle of good red solved the issue.......
author: John C.

description:
A16 had a chance to woo us as new diners who had purchased a Gilt City dinner for their Meatball Monday deal.  I understand that Gilt didn't make our reservation as they should have, which definitely sucked for an already packed restaurant.  I do appreciate the hostess finding us a table in a reasonable amount of time.  But Mister B and I felt like second class because we had essentially a prix fixe.  We like food, and probably would have ordered an additional dish from the main menu, had we been offered one.  Bummer, they lost some cashola and a chance to impress us.  I really would have liked to see what was on their regular menu.

The burrata was decent but a little chewy (not as good as the burrata at Westwood pop-up on Valencia) and served with somewhat salty bread which did not really complement it very well; however I enjoyed the arugula salad with stone fruit and almonds.  Next up was the fregola with peas, tarragon, and lemon olive oil and the famed meatballs - alone they were lacking in something like acid or salt, but went relatively well together.  Dessert was ok but we did not finish it - nothing to write home about - the chocolate budino with olive oil and sea salt.  

Service was perfunctory but I did not feel like I was welcome there at all, and as if they were trying to get another table in before too late.  

Needless to say we will not be revisiting.
author: Aimee B.

description: Really great dining experience.   We sat at the chef's counter with my kids.  Food was great.  The pork was not my favorite but still very good.  Pizzas, sides and deserts were excellent!
author: Paul F.

description:
(See pics)

It's not easy to get reservations on the weekends but we came here around 5pm and were to get a table before lots of people showing up in no time. It's a great place after the local wine tasting as we all needed some pizza to absorb all that alcohol that's mostly experimental.

The Burrata with olive oil was soft and tender, and with hard toast it was a perfect compliment and contrast. Quite a note to get it again.

The Margherita pizza was really, really hot and delicious with lots of light oil dripping. It's so thin and soft that I had to fold it when savoring.

The Funghi (roasted mushrooms with smoked mozzarella and arugula) was fantastic especially with the authentic chili oil that was super hot.

The wine server was very nice and let us try a few different wines as my date chatted up with him since he's a frequent patron. They had quite a few great Italian wines. The Pigalva I tried was very complimentary to the food.

Just the chili oil is a place to dream of and come back again!
author: T L.

description:
A16 is a beautiful restaurant, especially during the holidays. For a more casual experience I would recommend sitting in the back at the chef's table where you can watch the kitchen in action.  Or if al fresco is your thing, you'll find the back patio romantic and well heated.  

The pizza is stellar, but the gnocchi is cooked to perfection and by far my favorite.
author: Rachel G.

description:
It's no Pizzeria Mozza, but it's pretty good. 

I had the Buccatini. It was dressed with olive oil and tomatoes and... i forget what it's called but basically something like dried fish roe. Yes, okay, sounds weird. BUT, amazing. It acts like how grated cheese adds that right amount of saltiness, except you get a tiny bit of brine too. Loved it! Though, I did splash olive oil all over my placemat... like a kid.

Also the burrata app is worth mentioning and trying. It was creamy and delicious. High quality.

I found the pizza just alright. But, then again, I compare all fancy pizzas to Mario Batali's at Mozza... so, a little hard to live up to that.

The service was good. Solid 4 stars.
author: Hannah K.

description:
My girlfriend gave me a surprise dinner here over the weekend. I really really liked this place. A perfect Marina district restaurant. The restaurant is a power scene with tons of 1 percenters and investment banking frat boys. Ha! I kid...

We ordered a lot of food on our visit. We first started with the Burratta cheese, which was okay, I think the Cotogna Burratta was substantially better. We ordered a Siccia pizza (too lazy to look up the actual name) with an egg, pizza was DAMN good, light crust, flavorful toppings. I had the squid pasta with Sea urchin which was fantastic. My girlfriend had the chicken sausage which was surprisingly very good and not boring like most chicken dishes. Though I would avoid the side order of polenta and go with another side dish. Lastly the dessert was a chocolate cake, which was nice. 

We brought our own wine, however, given the reputation of this restaurant for having great wine selection, we went with a recommended southern Italian wine that had a rhone varietal similarity. Great wine at a fairly decent cost. 

Overall A16 was pretty damn good, I would come back for the pizza and pasta alone. However, I think SPQR muscles A16 in terms of pasta by just a hair
author: Justin L.

description:
Tried this place when my sister was in town because it is always crowded, even on a Monday night, which is when we went. We had to change our reservation time a couple times and the hosts were very gracious about it - kudos. The service was good, nothing to complain about, and the decor/atmosphere was gorgeous. 

The food, unfortunately, just did not live up to the hype. Yes, the burrata was delicious, but the meatball starter was VERY small and underwhelming as the sauce tasted like it was made specifically for a pizza. For entrees, I had the mushroom gnocchi - I hate to say it, but I've had better gnocchi out of the microwave. It was incredibly bland and the mushrooms were so hard I couldn't cut them with my fork. My boyfriend had the halibut and was equally underwhelmed. Our friend had the steak, which was really good.

My sister enjoyed her artichoke pizza, but unfortunately didn't get through much of it before we found a hair baked into the cheese. The waitstaff was horrified and very accommodating (the manager came over to apologize), but other than taking the pizza off the check, no other restitution was made. I may be wrong, but I would expect more out of such a pricey restaurant. 

Overall, with so many other amazing, original places to go in this city, I'm sure I won't be going back.
author: Catie F.

description: Rude, rude, rude! We were celebrating and made a reservation, but the maitre d' tried to put us at a table that was about 2 inches from several children who were crying or watching movies on their iPads. (Who takes a bunch of little kids to a fancy restaurant anyway?) When I asked for another table, he said: "Well, I've already seated all the other tables so you'll just have to wait." First, what a rude thing to say! Second, that was a lie because there were open tables, but those were tables for 4 and heaven forbid they put 2 people at a 4-top and lose all that money. After walking back to the front door, he said we would have to wait another 20 minutes. Um, no, I had a reservation and was there on time. I should not be forced to sit next to a group of loud kids when I want to have a nice and EXPENSIVE celebratory dinner. It is not unreasonable to request the same dining experience as the people who are sitting elsewhere and paying the same amount. So, we left and went to Spaghetti Bros, which honestly has much better food and far better service than A16. I won't go back to A16 ever again.
author: Jamon B.

description:
A very knowledgeable wine aficionado told me that dining at A16 is like dining in a candy store (of wines). I tried 8+ wine samplings here alongside their pizza, pastas, and starters and I agree! 
Fun for large groups of wine aficionados!
author: Laura F.

description:
Solid choice for dinner, especially if you live in the Marina. Can't go wrong. Great service. Great wine. 

This is a good place for dates, business dinners, and just for a good time with a friend or friends.
author: Kennie B.

description:
What would bring a group of gym-going, health conscious gay men out of their natural habitat and into the heterosexual stronghold of the Marina?  A16.

Food = 4.5:  The burrata appetizer is a heavenly pillowy cloud of cheesy luvin'.  The mushroom pizza is filled with all kinds of fungi that rivals the Whole Foods produce aisle.  But the pork chop.....oh the bone-in hearty-cut pork chop with a stripe of fat along the top.....DROOOOOOL!  If you like Italian wines, A16 will give you too many choices.  So, I suggest you get the help of the of the three (yes, three) sommeliers! 

Service = 4.5:  Chic and charming waitstaff were on top of their game on this particular Saturday night.   A16 was super packed but there was nothing off about service.  

Atmosphere = 4.0:  The place set in a long and somewhat narrow space, which was decorated with a modern aesthetic.  Tables were spaced together a little too closely.  Problematic for a bigger person but not us.  (See gay man reference, above)
author: Eddie L.

description:
I had a Blackboard Eats coupon and made a reservation for a Monday evening. The interior was dimly lit and there was more seating as you walk in straight into the restaurant and I was surprised at how large the restaurant actually is. I was seated right away at the Chef's Counter and I thought it was such a cool experience to get to see the chefs cooking right in front of me.

To start, I ordered the Acorn Squash Bruschetta with Ricotta and Fried Sage. I got to watch the chef pull the mashed squash out of the brick oven and make my bruschetta right in front of me. I figured it would be a couple small pieces of toast but what I got was one big slice of toast that I had to eat with a fork and knife. It was SO GOOD and I really want to try and replicate it at home.

For my entree I really wanted to try a unique pasta dish. There were about 5 pasta choices and I debated between the gnocchi and the fish roe pasta. I asked the waiter what he recommended and he said that he didn't really like the fish roe pasta and instead suggested either the Maccaronara (a classic) or the new Nettle Gnocchi with Butternut Squash. I went with the entree size gnocchi and I was surprised at the small portion. The taste was good but the gnocchi with the nettle scent and flavor got a little boring and nauseating after a while. I still finished the whole dish but I won't get that dish again. Still, I appreciated the quality of the food and really noticed the tenderness of the gnocchi.

For dessert I had a scoop of the the Fig Marsala gelato per the server's recommendation. It was the perfect way to end the meal with and my gelato was actually on the house! I left feeling satisfied and not too full. The price is reasonable for the quality of food, service, and ambiance of the restaurant. I also love that they take reservations because I despise waiting in line for a table.

The staff were extremely nice and helpful and they really made a good impression on me. I would come here again just because of the service.
author: Bommy C.

description:
Arrived late on a Sunday and found it busy. 
I am a wine professional so was excited to try here. 
We were seated at a 2 top quickly but waited a bit for attention. 
Waitress was not rude but far from personable I asked for a reisling btg and was told they only had one. Was not given a discription of the wine other than a place of origin and a beer for my date. 
Ordered a burata which came quickly 
The food runner asked about drinks and we told him we were waiting 
The drinks never showed up. 
After we had finished our app someone approached our table and asked about our drinks 
We told her they had never shown up and told her to just give us our check. NOTE
At no time after after our order did we ever have contact with our waitress!!
They charged us for the cheese !!
I know we ate it but come on!
I would hv at minimum comped it and apologized profusely at my place.
author: Kent B.

description: A truly mediocre food at high prices. If all dishes were about $10 cheaper I'd give it 3 stars but mediocre food + high prices + slow service= 2 stars
author: Lo F.

description:
This is a very enjoyable place. We had terrific service, and just enjoyed the ambiance quite a lot. 

The food: I guess I wouldn't come here expecting to have a gourmet, knock your socks off meal. The pizza is quite good, in the Neapolitan style and freshly made with a chewy crust. Somehow it didn't make the eyes roll back in the head, but sure, I'd eat pizza here often if I could. 

Really, my favorite thing may have been the arugula salad, with fruit and almonds. That was was wonderful. 

The clams in the tomato broth: pretty good. The broth kind of overwhelmed the clams so I probably would not order this again, but it would fit the bill if you're in the mood for a tomato-clam concoction.

SF black cod - nice. Some might find this a plain fish but they cooked it just right, and it went well with the grilled vegetables and chard we had on the side.

The chocolate mousse dessert is something to get. We didn't care so much for the slightly burned cookie or whatever it was underneath, but the mouse was delicious.

We had a Sicilian wine that the sommelier recommended, and it was a good choice. It went well with the whole meal. I guess considering how much restaurants mark up wine it was not a bad deal at $75, but it struck me as a little overpriced for this wine. And yet, as far as I could tell, it was one of the less expensive bottles on the menu. It would be tempting to come again prepared to shell out more money on something more unusual since they have quite an interesting wine list focused on Southern Italian wines. 

In fact, next time it's arugula salad, pizza, and the big bucks toward the wine.
author: Mister K.

description:
Sooooo I'm not one to write reviews. I'm usually upset if the service is sub par or satisfied if its great but last Friday was a different story. 

After reading the previous reviews I was ready for a rude waitress and decent food. Let me tell you not only was the food on point our server was world class. Iris was attentive, sweet, and one of the best servers I have had. The experience that she gave us was absolutely phenomenal. 

I had the Funghi Pizza which was cooked perfectly and my gf had the Lamb Pasta that was also great. 

We will be back and definitely recommending to our friends.
author: Kassim A.

description:
I was here with my family during our trip to San Francisco and A 16 was a great experience.

The restaurant was within walking distance from the apartment that we were renting for the weekend, so we strolled on over one night to sample the Italian fare.

The restaurant was packed, but luckily we had reservations so the wait was not a problem. The place had a nice atmosphere. Good decor and lighting, a bit crowded and noisy but nothing unexpected for getting a good meal on a Friday night.

Everything we ordered I loved. For starters: the burrata (an Italian cheese) with olive oil, sea salt and crostini along with the Prosciutto tasting. This was a great pairing. The creamy richness of the cheese played amazingly well with the saltiness of the prosciutto.

For entrees I was going to go strictly pizza because I saw a few being eaten around me and they looked incredible, but before arriving I read about one of their signature pasta dishes that was supposedly a must-eat in San Fran; the Maccaronara with ragu napoletano and house-made ricotta salata.

So as a compromise we ordered the pasta along with two pizzas and just ate everything family style. What amazing flavors! The pasta was definitely a good choice, out-of-this-world good. Both pizzas were cooked perfectly, melted cheese, simple/clean ingredients, great sauce with a thin, crunchy crust.

They also had a spicy, house-made crushed red pepper sauce that I applied liberally to my pizza. It was super hot, but I'm a fan of heat with my pie so I dug it.

Overall, A 16 was an awesome dining experience, living up to my expectations of a fine San Francisco eatery.
author: Jacob C.

description:
I can see why food critics in SF are skipping this on their go-to lists.

Put simply, A-16 has seen better days. They are apparently on edge from the vacant dining room which used to never be in the not so distant past. 

Service with an attitude. Burned charcoal pizza crust isn't my idea of a delicious meal. I also tried to order a pasta dish from the menu and have them swap the noodle with a spaghetti noodle that was on the menu (and even offered to pay more if necessary.) The server refused. We escalated to the cook, and he refused. We will never go back.
author: M E.

description:
I had dinner with family at A16 recently and was impressed. I loved the interior of the restaurant and appreciated the friendly service. 

I tried the margherita pizza which was very tasty and easily fed 3 people, and the Scialatielli squash pasta, which had a more delicate flavor. I recommend the pizza. 

Also recommend a reservation.
author: Christy D.

description:
I wish I'd liked A16 more.  It's always so crowded (we've tried to go there spur of the moment a couple of times and there is never even room at the bar) and it's expensive enough that you would think the food would be incredible.  That just hasn't been my experience, though.  My husband and I met some friends there a few weeks ago for a friend's birthday and I had high hopes, but in the end the food really wasn't exceptional.  The burrata was good but not really interesting or different.  It was just burrata.  Same thing with the gnocci.  It was fine but not something to write home about.  I tried some of my husband's margherita pizza and it was good.  The crust was one of the better ones I've had lately - thin and crispy- and the flavor of the tomato sauce was a little sweet.  I wished I had ordered that instead of the gnocci.  

The service was fine.  Our waiter recommended a wine that I really liked and it ended up being the high point of the dinner for me.  The ambiance at A16 is nice, even though the restaurant is really crowded.  I wish I had liked my food more.  Next time, if there is a next time, I'll order pizza.
author: Kate D.

description:
There are a lot of Italian restaurants everywhere but this one left an impression.  I love the pastas and rabbit dish.  Everything was flavorful and went well with the wine recommendation from the sommelier who provided us with tastings.  

How did the name of the dessert escape my mine?, maybe because it was that tasty!

The open kitchen is a nice place to sit by to enjoy the warmth of the pizza oven and the chefs' activities.  Even though the restaurant is narrow, we felt comfortable sitting at the table.
author: Kali F.

description:
I'd been wanting to try this place for a while, but I left pretty disappointed. The ambience and decor is beautiful, and the food is okay, but the tiny portions are way out of line with the prices. I had a "large" pumpkin gnocchi which was tasty-yet-tiny and my friend had the "large" meatball special (4 instead of 3). When she asked for a side of spaghetti instead of one of the other sides offered, they charged her an extra $10 for literally a fistful of noodles. She mentioned the other night that she's still a little ashamed she paid $30 for a mediocre spaghetti and meatballs.

Unfortunately it was also our waitress' first day - she may have been genuine Italiana, but it took 30 minutes to get our drinks and the bread came after our entrees arrived despite multiple requests. Obviously not completely her fault since it was her first day, but certainly didn't help the experience.

Next time I'll stick to pizza, but even then, I'd rather go to Delarosa's.
author: Victoria L.

description: Neat place. Seems popular to the locals. Great place to stop for a glass of wine and a snack. Dinner is good. (Cannot say that much about it as we were a party of 20 or so with a prearranged menu.) nothing was bad! Next time my husband and I go we will split a bottle of wine and a pizza!!! Wonderful pizza!
author: Bryna G.

description:
So close to five stars for the food, wine & atmosphere! - but couldn't give that last star because the customer service was less than mediocre. 

While I thoroughly enjoyed the Bianca pizza and Italian vino, I couldn't get past how rude two of the hostesses were when we walked in. 

They stood there and would not make eye contact or say they will be right with us and I was standing right in front of their podium. Finally I had to say, "Excuse me can you please help us?" Maybe I expect too much because my grandparents own a restaurant and value good service, but they were not warm, friendly, or inviting.

I live in the Marina and do not like the "snobby, stuck-up" reputation it gets but it is instances like that which justify it. 

Front door service aside, the food is to die for. Sit at the chef's table if you want to watch this divine cuisine be created :)
author: Jaclynn F.

description:
Well...it was bound to happen that I'd have to write a negative review about someplace.  i really avoid it, following the old adage of if you don't have something nice to say....blah, blah, blah.  But...when we drop as much money as we did last night for the meal and experience we had, I earnestly feel something should be said.  So...here goes.

To the guy that answered the phone when I called to make a reservation.  You were awesome.  friendly, inviting, told us no worries that we'd been out cycling all day and that attire was not an issue.  You were coolsville.

To the bartender.  Here's the deal.  I'm sorry you're hectic.  I'm sorry you have a lot of people that want your attention.  But in all honestly, I don't give a shit.  When I walk up to the bar, your job is to be accommodating and straightforward. If we're about to drop close to $40 on a carafe of wine...guess what...I'm going to ask for a splash of potential selections so I know if we like it.  If you have a policy of not doing that, then just say so...I may not be thrilled by that policy but I'm a big boy in big boy pants and I'll live.  IF however, you agree to do this and you don't have a policy against it, then you better fucking do it with a smile on your face and goodness in your heart, not the "oh my God...I can't believe you're inconveniencing me in this way" attitude you oozed on my wife and I after I had the audacity to ask you to taste 2 different wines.  Don't like your job?  I'm sorry but its not my problem.  Don't like being in a service industry, I don't blame you...I wouldn't want to either but guess what? I'm not holding a gun to your head you snide hipster asshat.  The three things that kept me from launching over the bar and punching you in the head after you slammed close the wine list, slammed shut the wine cooler, rolled your eyes at my wife, and slapped the wine glass on the bar like you'd just done me a life long favor were: a) I was with my wife, b) we were with our kids, and c) I'd be arrested.  So...get over your self because someday, someone will come in and ask for the same basic help without kids, or a wife/husband, or a care about an arrest record and will punch your smarmy face into next week.

To the chef.  Yeah...I know its easy to get deceived about Italian food.  Is it good...is it just pasta...etc.  But I lived in Italy for over a year and feel pretty qualified to say the following.  If you're gonna serve a $21 bowl of pasta (maccaronara ragu napoletana), make it taste like something more authentic than Chef Boyardee Beefaroni.  Seriously.  

So there it is.  I know I sound like the turd in the A16 punch bowl.  I've read the Yelp reviews and remain pretty confident in my foodie status and the fact that a bunch of loyal subjects not willing to say that the emperor has no clothes, doesn't make him any better dressed.
author: dave c.

description: Food was average with small portions. Service was sub par.
author: Mike G.

description:
Came here based on a rec from a former SFer. It is one of my favorite Italian places. I had the gnochhi with hen broth and my friend got the pasta with broccoli rabe and pancetta. We also split the bruschetta and the burrata. All delicious. 

Also: you should make a rec here too. The neighborhood was a nice walk to the water. Kind of an unsuspecting location for what it was on the inside--a very warm and casual chic place.
author: Taraneh D.

description: I remembered the pork chop to be absolutely delicious here.  I love the atmosphere and the location is not bad.
author: Sarah S.

description:
packed, dimly lit, lively, good energy, beautiful fire brick oven. Dare I say sexy?

Starters:
Burrata with olive oil & sea salt - I know everyone *always* loves the Burrata regardless of the restaurant, so you can't go wrong. But I'm serious, this was different in a GREAT way. Please taste.

Local manila clams in a garlic sauce w/ grilled bread - clams were small, garlic sauce /bread very tasty. 

Funghi Pizza - very good if you enjoy mushrooms. They werent really baked in, kinda of just laying over the top fresh. Pizza crust was a bit undercooked and "bready". Keep in mind this has absolutely no sauce, so it was a bit dry for my personal taste. Though the smoked mozz was a great compliment.

Maccaronara with ragu - Homemade pasta, excellent sauce. Must taste!


Overall, I would come back to try a different pizza and taste that Burrata again! The main dishes around me on other tables looked pretty good too.
author: Jessica A.

description:
We first saw that it's affiliated with SPQR and thought "oh no...."

However, because we probably tempered expectations, it turned out quite good!  I liked the pizza.  But honestly, pizza is pizza...The rest of the meal was tasty, just not something I'd come back to as there are so many other options.  

But if you like Italian food with a twist of American, then this is probably a place you should try.  

Wine list was good.
author: Carrie-C N.

description: I used to love a-16 it was one of my favorite places to have a quiet dinner with friends.
