Now its overrun by the "marina elite" that push and shove their way into the door to get to the hostess, thinking they are better than everyone else.  The reservations are never on time, the service takes forever and the food just isn't what it used to be.  My hesitance to ever go back is more the clientele than the restaurant, its just a fact that places in SF are continuously ruined by crappy homogenous people that act inappropriately. I brought my mom and she said "who are these people and why did you bring me here" Good question Mom.
author: jessica b.

description:
I made a reservation for Thursday night with no problem. I wanted to make sure we'd get in here because I've been wanting to try it for a few years.

Salsiccia pizza: YUM! I'm totally sold. 

Squid ink cavatelli: the pasta was a little dense but maybe that was personal preference. I would have liked a bit more calamari in there.
Gnocchi: light and fluffy like they should be but I was a little disappointed in the sauce. It just didn't have very much flavor.  

Pizza + 2 full portions of pasta was enough for 2!

And the WINE... they have a huge wine list! Goretti Perugia 2006 from Umbria was a great choice though ;)
author: Sara P.

description:
I'm puzzled at A16's overall Yelp rating. This place should be a solid 4 (if not higher - I tend to be more harsh on my ratings than others)! Yes, you need a reservation. No, you can't just walk in. It's a popular spot. But the food is great.

Our group started with the burrata and a special - Monterrey sardines finished with raisins, pine nuts and a few other things I don't remember. I was a little wary of them at first but, let me tell you, they were out of this world! So amazingly flavorful. 

For main courses, two folks at the table got pizzas, two got pastas, and I got the Mackerel and clams with sour Seville orange, fennel, and radicchio. The flavors were intense and so fantastic. The slightly bitter grilled radicchio, the sour orange, and the salty fish all balanced each other well. 

My only complaint: my side of chard and the chocolate cake the table shared for dessert were both too salty! But, I tend to prefer very minimal salt.

Others seem to have commented about the service but we had no problem with it. Our server was extremely knowledgeable and had all kinds of food and wine suggestions (although I did have some beef with how many times she used "lovely' and "beautiful" to describe various food dishes...but that's a personal thing). We were in the back room and it seemed like someone was always popping their head in to see how we were doing.
author: Sydney L.

description: The food is great, the room is great, the service was appalling. Bartenders were lovely and a waitress who wasn't ours was also lovely but our waitress was clearly miserable and quite rude. Very disappointing as it really ruined what could have easily been a five star experience.
author: Sarah M.

description:
This place has amazing food but so do a lot of places in SF. 
Went to dinner with friends I hadn't seen in a long time two weeks ago and the hostess at the front was completely rude and gave me a horrible attitude. I showed up on time and they were running late. I saw two couples walk in right before me which she sat right away in the back part which is more quiet and where you are put when you have reservations. Both people did not have their whole party there but we're sat anyways and I was left standing there. I finally asked to be seated in which she sat me in the front loud area and I asked to be moved to the back since I made reservations and she came over to my table and with a raised voice and said we give away your table after 15 minutes so this is where you are going to sit or else I'm giving it away. What? Even though two other incomplete parties had come in before me and got sat in the back. That was just the beginning... I could go on. Our server, bless him how nice he was but left our table at one point and didn't return for 20 minutes. By that time the last food we order he had completely forgotten and no one was hungry anymore but we didn't want to be rude so we waited. It clearly hadn't even been started yet bc it took another 15 minutes to get it out to us. Just a disaster! I usually love this place but had such a bad experience a couple weeks ago I don't know that I will go back or recommend.
author: Dorthy S.

description:
Ate here late on a Sunday night and it was surprisingly busy (a good sign, IMO). Starter of heirloom melon with lardo was delicious, one of the best dishes I've had this year. We had the pasta with ragu and lemon, not a mind-blower. Pizza with salsiccia and peppers was very good. 

The real closer for me was dessert. My date had chocolate tart with olive oil and salt, I had the panna cotta. Dessert ran late so the kitchen gave us a little taste of mango ice cream. All three were exceptional.
author: Eva R.

description: Very poor service, Gnocchi was inedible. Server consulted with management, who tasted it and apparently thought it was "spot on". Very concerning taste level. I am no food snob, but do not think that gnocchi should taste like plastic. Not only did they end up charging me for it even though my entire party couldn't swallow it, but management told us that we were wrong for thinking it didn't taste right. The food here is mostly great...and when 1 dish isn't, its really okay as long as someone acknowledges it. There is no need to be so defensive, I wish they cared more about customer service. I used to love this place and frequent it for dinner but unfortunately after this treatment will never be coming back.
author: Chelsea L.

description:
Seating at the bar and got very great service.  
 
I had order glass of wine, pasta, salad and coffee.  Food was tasted great but serving size is very small and total bill was just under $100 dollar. (Pricey.)

5* for service
4* for food
2* food and wine serving size.

Overall 3* with a high tap price....
author: Chris A.

description:
Such a swanky li'l place! My friend is a photographer and she took pictures all around the restaurant because it was so hip and pretty!

So we came here because my friend had memories of a nice restaurant that was in the area but the name of which she couldn't remember. We finally came across it. There was a 45-minute wait but we got those pager thingies, so we walked around the neighborhood (OK, fine. We're pigs, so we ate some buffalo wings a block down) until our seats were ready. We were lucky (?) enough to sit right where the action was. The whole time we watched the cooks make pizzas and toast them in the wood fired ovens, something I think alone deserves the restaurant one star.

The menu was quite exotic, which I enjoy since I always like to try the weirdest dish. I chose the octopus ravioli with squid ink. It was kind of a hauty-tauty dish because the portion was so small, and I think the ravioli was more noodle than octopus. My friend's margarita pizza wasn't too bad though. The dessert menu looked quite tempting but we only had gelato.

Service was pretty good. The servers are all young and good-looking. Can't go wrong there.
author: Kym M.

description: A16 is a must visit in SF.  It gets really busy, and the parking is terrible, but if you can time it right, it's a really nice experience.  I was there early without a reservation.  I liked the decor.  It felt like I was at my rich friend's gourmet kitchen.  I don't have a rich friend with a gourmet kitchen, but if I did, I imagine it would feel like this.  The kitchen staff was butchering some pig right behind the counter seats, which was really awesome.  The service was fast and friendly.  The wine selection is very good, too!  Like a said, a must visit in SF!
author: Les T.

description:
Stepping into A 16 this place was more  than what was suggested from the slender front lining Chestnut street. The restaurant is a long narrow building that was moving and shaking at 7:30 on a Thursday night. I liked the energy of the restaurant at least until a group of 6 of the most stereotypical Marina girls I have ever seen in my life sat at the table next to mine at the end of the meal. A gentle reminder of where I was. Nevertheless, the dinner at A 16 was great. For two people, we split an appetizer (braised artichoke), a pizza (gotta go classic, gotta go margherita), a half pasta (paccheri), and a side (chard). Their treatment of the veggies were amazing. The braised artichoke was a great texture and a perfect savory dish. As the chard hit the table I noticed an absolutely amazing smell and the dish tasted to match. The pasta was the least exciting dish of the night, on the hard side of al dente, to the point that my dining companion found it a little too tough, I just thought that the gentle lemon and asparagus flavor paired in comparison to what else they were accomplishing at this place. 

But I came for the pizza. I've tried many of the "best" pizza places in the city and find that A 16 beats out or holds up to any one I've been to. The crust is very thin, which tends to make the toppings a little harder to stay on, don't go crazy with overloading your pizza with the extra toppings, the menu is created with purpose and focus. The margherita pizza was lightly adorned with mozzarella, grana padano, olive oil, basil, and tomato sauce. And that sauce, the tomato sauce was absolutely fantastic at a just sweet enough spot that marks truly exceptional pizza. In my opinion, great sauce makes a pizza, an they definitely have a great tomato sauce here. The chili oil that accompanied the pizza was a nice touch as well, it brought heat (a lot of it if you wanted) in a more smooth way that topping it with chili flakes. 

A place worth checking out. The amount of food (appetizer, half pasta, pizza, side) was absolutely sufficient for two people. No room for dessert so if you wanted to indulge in something sweet might want to pass on something.
author: Stephen S.

description: Hats off to chef And the staff. From start to finish a great meal. Real pizza (coming from a north east person). Fantastic service, great wine list, and everything I ate was amazing. Roast chicken is a simple thing but when done right it is a thing of beauty and this was. My husband and I have a new date spot.
author: paulina k.

description: Burrata is amazing. Great beer selection. We sat at the bar and enjoyed a great Friday night meal. No wait at 10 pm
author: Kate B.

description: The pizza was great but the pasta (squid ink) was very lack luster.  It was very busy so it's obviously very popular but we probably won't be visiting again any time soon.
author: Lanae S.

description:
Wow!

Food: The food here has to be some of the best in the city.  As someone who has had pizza at ZeroZero, Flour and Water, Cafe Deluxe, Beretta and Cafe Baonecci pizza, I can say this may be the best pizza in town, certainly it rivals any of its high-end competition well.  Had squid ink pasta as well.  A bit chewy and fishy tasting (I like fish but it has sea urchin in it and it was a bit much for my taste), I wouldn't order it again but all in all the food was great. Burrata was perfect, though the toastini it was served with made it hard to enjoy the delicate texture and near scraped my mouth.  Normal bread would be fine.  they also offered for dipping some of the best olive oil I've ever had.

Atmosphere:  Some of the snazziest decor and one of the largest dining rooms in a nice SF restaurant, but the PEOPLE...the worst part of this experience was having to look at the Marina crowd.  Older men, younger women, plastic surgery, pink ballcap worn indoors, concealer on men, fake tans, tight polos...if you've been to the Marina, you know the deal.

Service:  Our waitress was nice, peppy and on it.  As soon as I'd notice my water glass running low (the spicy pepper pizza topping is no joke!), she would already be refilling it.  she made great suggestions and conversation and most of all, was always nearby, despite the restaurant being full of patrons.

Price: A16 is not cheap, but we made out pretty well.  four of us ate, each had a single alcoholic drink, split 2 appetizers and 3 entrees and the total was $42 per person, including tax and tip.

I'll be back for a special occasion or to show off one of San Francisco's finer dining establishments to an out-of towner.

(make reservations or you won't get in)
author: Lauren J.

description: I use to thoroughly enjoy A16 in the past. I went here with my family in Jan 2014 and felt ripped off. We raved about A16 to our out of town family members but it wasn't great. Service was poor; it was like they forgot us in the back patio room. Food was mediocre and portions were small. We ordered plain spaghetti for our kids and the portion was so small for my 8 year old, we had to ask for more and paid a lot for plain pasta. Maybe it came out to 1 measured cup of pasta. All these things I am mentioning were not what I had experienced years ago. The quality and standard has gone down. $300+ dollars short for 4 adults and 2 kids and unsatisfied.
author: Cat R.

description:
This is one of those restaurants where you know you are going to have wait at least an additional 15-20 minutes after your reservation time to be seated.  The last time we went in I think we waited about 40 mins, because of some oversight.  However, the hostess felt so bad that she (without being prompted) brought over a glass of Prosecco for all of us, and made sure to bring us some olives and a salad to share as soon as we were seated.  Wow, nice.

I love this place.  It is romantic enough for a special date, and fun enough for a last minute casual meal and a nice place to bring friends or family from out of town.

The pastas, apps (espesh the mozzarella burrata app and the tuna app), and PIZZA are so good and they have plenty of wines to choose from.

Despite always having to wait longer than promised, you never have to twist my arm to come back.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Delicious! Came to A 16 on a double date with friends one Friday night. I had seen Chef Applebaum on The Next Iron Chef and was anxious to try his cuisine. The bar area was packed and a great place to wait for a table and people watch. Even without a reservation, we only had to wait 30 minutes or so for a table.

My favorite part of the meal, by far, was the homemade mozzarella.  It was incredible, and a great way to start the evening.  Next, the pizzas.  My husband and I both had pizza.  Unfortunately, his came complete with burnt redwood chips from the oven.  Thankfully, our server remedied that with a new pizza quickly.  

I would definitely come here again.  The food and service was great, and the atmosphere is such that you want to spend time there.  Check it out.
author: Lacey H.

description:
I really like their mushroom pizza. Good wine, pricey though.

My one grief with this place is it is SO freaking loud!
/And they do not do take out. So I can't eat that Delicious pizza in the quiet privacy of my house ;)/
author: Maggie R.

description:
Yum, yum yum. If burrata were a religion, I'd practice at A 16. Their burrata and fresh prosciutto plate are to die for. Pizza here is also wonderful, and made in a brick oven. I have to say as well, anything squid ink infused is always agreeable to my palate. They have a squid ink cavatelli pasta dish that I just adore! 
It's fun to sit at the "back bar" and watch the food being prepped and cooked. Be sure to pair your meal with a fab bottle of vino right off their extensive wine list.
author: Meredith M.

description:
Delish!
I had the English and snap pea salad and pasta paccheri with asparagus passato, lemon and pecorino. I tasted my fellow diner's romana pizza and it was amazing. 
I don't recall the bottle of wine we had, but their list is beyond extensive and the wine we had was phenomenal. Lastly, the service was impeccable and their house sparkling water was a lovely surprise. So refreshing and tasty.
author: Nicole O.

description:
By far the best, most authentic, true to the original Napoli style Margherita Pizza in Northern California!!!  

Forget the pedigree of the chef/owner, the trendiness of the place, the yuppieness of the neighborhood, and the crappiness of the parking, and any service or atmosphere issues you may experience, if I was a quadriplegic I would drag myself with my tongue across broken glass and excrement to get to this place to have what others may call a limp, soggy, or just slightly above average pizza.  

The people that complain about the pizza here aren't wrong, as they are entitled to their opinions and preferences about their favorite pizza which are usually based on some New York style crispier thin crust memories with trying too hard foodie toppings and themes, their just ignorant, have never been to Naples, don't care what true Neapolitan is, or just stupid.

I love pizza and have spent the night in Naples just to experience the real deal from its birthplace.  No museums or sight seeing that day, just the best damn pizza in the world!  It's all about the Margherita and Marinara, and everything else is pretty much an over complicated away from center departure from what pizza is supposed to be. 

Yes there are other things on the menu, and yes there are other aspects of eating out other than the food which tends to drop 5 star food to 3 & 4 star restaurant ratings, unless I get into a fist fight or get food poisoning, ratings should only be about the food.  Taco trucks have some of the best food in the world but would only warrant a 2 or maybe 3 star rating if you figure everything else into the equation.

Pizza Margherita... A16... close your eyes, and your back in Naples sans air fair!
author: Michael G.

description: Went for lunch on Saturday. Ordered the buffula, and a margarita and zucca pizza. Absolutely fabulous. The service was outstanding, our waitress spoke intelligently about the wines we tried and the whole space is absolutely beautiful.
author: Brynley W.

description: My husband and I absolutely love A16. A perfect night is sitting at the bar, sharing a pasta and pizza and a carafe of Italian wines. We went hear to celebrate our engagement and continue to go back for special occasions and spontaneous date nights.
author: J G.

description: This place is way overhyped. The pizza is average but way overpriced. In fact, overpriced is a theme with this place. The food is in no way bad but there are so many places within four blocks that have so much better bang for your buck. Nothing on the menu really stands out and the protein entrees I have tried are underwhelming. If you go I'd recommend the mushroom pizza but it is still a good notch below the likes of delfina or any of the other upper echelon pizza spots in the city.
author: Andrew J.

description:
5 stars for Service (Nico was great) and atmosphere. 3 solid stars for food.

A glass of Prosecco and a Bellini to get the meal going. 

We started with the Mozzarella Burrata and Minestra Maritata (spicy pork meatball soup). Both were delicious. 
Second, Sunchoke and Escarole Salad and La Quercia tasting (Americano, Berkshire and Speck Prosciutto). Sunchoke salad was an unexpected great dish (prob my favorite of the night). Prosciuttos were really good. The Speck stood out to me the most. 
Third, we went for the one special of the evening which was a Pizza (ricotta cheese, ancho crusted crispy greens). This was my least favorite of the night. Not bc the pizza was bad (crust is delicious) the toppings (crispy greens) are not really my thing. I did enjoy the chile oil they served on the side for the pizza. I'm totally bummed though bc I was really excited for their pizza. Should have went with the Margarita. Next time. 
Fourth course, Pumpkin Ricotta Gnocchi and Roasted Chanterreles. Both good. Only criticism is that I didn't taste any pumpkin in the gnocchi. RL said he tasted it barley. A little more would have been nice. 
Dessert, their signature Chocolate Budino Tart with Sea Salt and Olive Oil and the stand out dish of the night Farro Custard with Bitter Chocolate and Orange Yogurt Sorbet. This Farro Custard was such an odd idea so I just had to try it. I love farro and this custard was amazing. The crispy bruleed top and the chunks of whole farro was just a great combination and a great end to the meal. 

Restaurant was packed (8pm on Saturday) but thanks to our OT resie we walked right it. We sat in the waaaaayyy back of the restaurant. Doesn't look like it but this place is quite big. Table was kind of tight but we made it work. Again, Service was great. Thank you Nico. 

Great dining experience. Will be back next trip to SF. Margarita pizza for sure and fingers crossed that the Farro Custard will still be on the menu.
author: Ciara G.

description:
Took four business partners to dinner.  We sampled a variety of appetizers and the classic margherita pizza.  All were exceptional.  My main was the porchetta and it is a heavenly, crispy piece of pork belly.  The green strawberries added an amazing element of tart/sour.  All wine selections were spot on.
It's quite busy, somewhat cramped and not the place for a quiet, romantic night.  But it is perfect for a hustling, lively dinner spot.
author: Jason G.

description:
Trippa Napoletana was fine, but can't compete with Incanto's version.

The margherita was pretty tasty, all the elements worked together, with a good ratio of cheese, sauce and basil.

However, the squid ink pasta was pretty bland, and the pork ragu pasta was way undercooked. We told the server but were too full to have it replaced.

Course pacing was way off, especially for a 9pm seating. I think we waited more than half an hour to get our pizza after the tripe. Inexcusable.

Go to SPQR for pasta.
author: Derrick V.

description: Do not eat here. I sat at the bar, and watched in horror as the girl working the wood fire used the same pair of tongs (without any cleaning!) to handle raw chicken, raw salmon, and cooked steak, stir cooked rice, and plate up vegetables that were ready to eat!  Other staff were cross contaminating containers of food too. I didn't see anyone wash their hands or use gloves, even once. Salmonella anyone?  I reported it to the manager, but overall standards of food safety seem below par here. Yuck!  I hope the Health Dept. pays them a visit.
author: Sara P.

description:
Well, it's more of a 3.5* than 3*, but Yelp doesn't let me do that, so consider this as a High 3 * :)

- Ambience: Good. I really liked the small room at the end of the restaurant. We might have got the table there because I was just wearing a T-shirt and everyone else was doing a formal Sunday dinner, but no complain!
Also, they have an interesting picture with all different kind of Pasta items close to their bathroom, and in the men's room they have a picture of 1982 Italian soccer team (I was there on the day of Finals of 2014 world cup, so maybe it was a temp photo).

- Food: Decent. They have a nice oven to cook the Pizza, so the pizaa was pretty good. I got the Funghi Pizza which doesn't have any meat, so no comment on the  quality of meat over there. BTW, they bring a scissor for you to cut the pizza. Which was different!

We also tried few of their sides, the sweet corn is a half a corn cob grilled and cut in pieces for $6 (if %500 margin if they get their corn from Safeway!). Also the squash was too oily and salty. The desert was pretty good though.
author: Ali F.

description:
There are only a handful of restaurants that I will repeatedly come back to without getting bored of the menu-- and A16 is one of them. Serving potentially the best burrata in all of San Francisco (not to mention their delicious and authentic Italian pizzas), A16 is the perfect venue for a upscale weekend meal that doesn't break the bank. Unless you indulge in copious amounts of wine...which you should. 

Yes, it's always crowded-- but just make a reservation a couple days in advance and I've never had a problem. If you're a walk in, you get the added bonus of bar seats which are also awesome because you get to watch  behind the scenes as the open ovens work their magic.
author: Dena G.

description:
You can get discouraged by all of the douchey restaurants on Chestnut in the Marina, but A16 is a great alternative.  We had an 8pm reservation on a Sunday and really enjoyed our meal.  

Burrata - I don't think I've ever not enjoyed burrata with olive oil salt and bread, this was no exception.

Lentil soup - Very brothy, very delicious with some nice greens (kale?)

Short ribs - Extremely tender, soft pieces of fat holding it together with a nice sauce.  With each entree you get to choose a side and we had the roasted potatoes with picked onion.  Maybe a touch underdone, but still good. 

Margherita Pizza - We added pancetta and an egg.  I was once told "If you're in a restaurant with a wood burning pizza oven, order a pizza."  This was great but I wish they hadn't cut my round pizza into square pieces.  You always end up with that triangle slice that is just crust and that square cut from the middle that is floppy and impossible to eat with your hands.  

Wine list - Great wine list.  May be unmanageable for some, but the waitress was extremely knowledgeable and if you require extra help, a super nice sommelier is there to make the perfect recommendation.  

Not crazy about how close the tables are, especially when you have someone annoying next to you, but at least you'll have the opportunity to easily eavesdrop on someone else's date.
author: Peter M.

description:
I had avoided coming to A16. I really had. I had heard lots of great reviews from friends but figured it'd be the restaurant equivalent of being a Bar None patron: a sure sign that I was a Marina-phile.

I walked down to A16 from the comforts of my home and true to every pre-conceived notion I had A16 was an explosion of attractive and seemingly well-to-do 25-35 year olds. 

So, onto the food. Hate to admit it: damn, it was good. 

We'll start with the appetizers. I had the burratta ($11) and crostini which was fantastic. I had never tried burratta.  Burrata is a fresh Italian cheese, made from mozzarella and cream. The outer shell is solid mozzarella while the inside contains both mozzarella and cream, which is all short for a damn good appetizer. 

Our 2nd appetizer was the 14 month aged San Daniele prosciutto ($14). Again, very good. Though to be honest - the La Quercia tasting: Americano, Berkshire and speck prosciutto * looked * phenomenal.

For an appetizer I had the Margherita pizza (tomato, mozzarella, grana padano, basil, olive oil). At $14 it was large enough for two people to share.

What surprised me most about A16 was that sweet spot between quality food and value. For what I consider a medium-priced restaurant the quality of the food was high for what is a welcoming and not overly complicated menu. 

The service was fantastic. The servers were very knowledgeable and friendly. 

As far as the ambiance, A16 is definitely busy but I would say it's a good place for a date if you like a bustling restaurant that is sleek and modern. For the extra romance points - the small patio in the back is nice if it isn't foggy out. 

There is no doubt I'd go back to A16. 

A16 is a winner in my book.
author: Carlos A.

description: Amazing. Everything I ate, I loved. We got a bunch of different plates and two pizzas. My favorite was the squid ink pasta. Can't wait to go back.
author: Valerie M.

description:
I don't often find myself in this part of town but now I know where to come and eat. 

I brought my folks here for my graduation dinner. We were seated promptly, the staff and service was stellar, which I have come to expect from all fine SF dining institutions. Unfortunately their menu changes regularly and when I booked the reservation there were a plethora of vegetarian entree options. When we arrived this was not the case. They managed to hold the beef on the sugo but I feel like they screwed the pooch a little by not offering a non-pizza veggie option. But I digress. 

The two salads went over well with the family, as did the wine. I had the Funghi pizza and man, oh man, it was probably one of the best mushroom-topped things I have ever munched on that didn't involved giggle fits thirty minutes later. We also split the hen gnocchi, which was neon green and not very noteworthy, although the shredded hen was most excellent. 

For desert some goat, cow, and goat-cow cheese along with raw honey and pickled cherries (which taste like they sound- gross) and a few cups of blue bottle french pressed at the table. 

All in all it was grand.
author: Jordan P.

description:
We had a reservation for 2 at 7pm but didn't get seated until 7:45pm. However the BF had mentioned that it was my birthday on opentable, so in addition to the many "happy birthday"s by hostess, various waiters, staff, we were handed 2 glasses of prosecco while we waited.
Unfortunately that was the highlight of the night. Once we were seated, we had a very overwhelmed-appearing waitress, and the food was below expectations.
We had the burrata appetizer, salsiccia pizza, maccaronara pasta (the least fave of the night). We then sprung for the orange blossom honey panna cotta for dessert which had a candle- this was delish, and when we got the bill found that dessert was on the house for my birthday.

A16 made me feel very special for my birthday, but I probably won't return anytime soon.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I've heard so many great things about A16 that I was excited to have the opportunity to finally check out the restaurant this past weekend.

I was not terribly impressed with anything about A16.   The service and wine list were OK - nothing great.  The menu was stale and unimaginative.  We had arugala/strawberry salad, the pea bruschetta, the Salsiccia (sp?) pizza and the budino cake.  Wasn't very hungry - just wanted to try a few dishes to get a sense of the place.  Nothing was exceptional.  Nothing was even remarkable.   $130 for a few glasses of average sparkling & Italian wine and average to sub-average food was a rip-off.

A16 was a dissappointment.   Zuppa, Cupola, Zero Zero and Beretta are all far superior in my opinion.   After hearing all the hype about this place - it was really a huge letdown...

Finally, what kind of italian restaurant doesn't have Peroni on the beer menu - strike 4...
author: Ron K.

description:
rating: 3.5

Solid food. Great salad with arugala. pizza was tasty just a bit over sauced. Nice rose wine. Pear dessert was pretty good, ice cream was better. Great service.

if going on a weekend parking is a b*tch. give yourself 15 minutes b4 your reservation to find a spot.
author: Nicole W.

description: Such a disappointment. Does not deserve it's hyped-up reputation. The walk-in tables are crammed into an unlit corner making for a very unenjoyable ambience. The hostess is unfriendly, the waiter is unfriendly, and busboys bus the tables like you are at TGIFridays. The food leaves much to be desired. Salmon tartare had absolutely no flavor. The 'fava bean' appetizer was actually burnt snap peas. Do not call something fava beans and then serve snap peas. The pasta with eggplant was gooey, also with no flavor. The farro contorno did not taste remotely Italian. I would never return.
author: Anna A.

description:
I can't believe it has taken me so long to finally have a meal at A 16.  Been to SPQR and loved it, so what was I waiting for?  Cow Hollow is rarely a destination for me, but between a BBE code and a show at the Palace of Fine Arts, I finally caved to temptation.

We had no problem getting at table at 6pm without a reservation (on a Sunday).  The space is lovely, quieter than usual (at least the section we were in had cork walls and floors!) and the staff is very attentive. It is almost too dimly lit: I needed to face the overhead light to read my menu.

Tonights feast:

Crostini with butternut squash, fried sage and ricotta with pumpkin oil on the most amazing bread ever.  One slice but satisfying.

Arugula salad with fuyu persimmons, nuts and picorino.  Very light and flavorful.

Hubby had the pork chop--which was HUGE.  Prepared perfectly to medium rare like he like it.  Side choice was a white bean puree- very rich.

I had the squid ink linguine.  I ordered the small--I should have ordered the large, it was so good!

The good news, is there was still room for desert.  We had the AMAZING orange blossom honey panna cotta with cooked plums.  OMG--seriously the best textured p.c. I have ever had.  Pause and gasp good.

I will find an excuse to go back to Cow Hollow--just so we can eat there again.  

Prices similar to Nopa, SPQR, LaCiccia.  Not crazy expensive--especially if you don't drink.
author: Monika S.

description:
My Favorite Restaurant in the city!  

The burrata appetizer is by far my favorite! So amazing how they add the sea salt to the soft cheese.

Also, their pizzas are so amazing.  I love the Margherita.  For pastas, my favorite is the Maccaronara with ragu napoletana.  

Great atmosphere every day of the week.  Make sure you have reservations - booking a couple weeks in advance for large parties.  My friend and I sat at the chefs table - perfect experience!
author: Cate A.

description:
I went for V-Day for their prix fixe menu. $95 for 5 courses and $70 wine pairings. Our table for our 9pm reservation wouldn't be ready until about 9:45 (they never apologized) so we sat at a high table next to the bar because we were starving. They seemed understaffed because everything was incredibly slow. We were seated for 10 minutes before my boyfriend got his vegetarian menu that I had talked with them about on multiple occasions before the dinner. And it took over 15 minutes to place a food/drink order. Everyone was really nice at least. 

The food was ok. Had it been a $50 meal, I probably would give it 4 stars. We sent one pasta dish back because it was very undercooked. Nothing else actually sticks out. The chocolate dessert was awful and dry but the cheesecake was amazing. Everything else was mediocre. Since we ended up in the bar, we saw people ordering pizza off the non-prix fixe menu and that actually looked really good. I'd go back to try the pizza but wouldn't go back for anything else. 

For a $200 meal, there were many, many better ones to be had in the city.
author: Daniel T.

description: Excellent food and service.  I've been to their store in Tokyo as well and bother are outstanding.
author: Eric P.

description:
Really disappointed to read the negative reviews here. I was here in the spring, and they served us the top pizza and pasta of our lives. The service was as fine as I can recall.  The wine was not to be missed. We were rushed as there was a flight to catch, and we still enjoyed a full tasting menu efficiently and effectively, considering our time constraints. 

We ate at some top chef restaurants while in SF, and yes, we enjoyed it here much more! No problem with wait since we had reservations, and our table was just fine!

I just returned from NY, and yes, the pizza here is still near the top in a class of its own. It's the one place that I look forward to returning to when I next visit SF which warrants a five star review in my books! 

San Franciscans must really be spoiled is all I have to say! And the area was beautiful but as pricey as we expected. I guess we are used to that coming from Vancouver? Needless to say, I have already re-booked for my next trip there.
author: B C.

description:
Around 5 PM on a Sat night during the president's day weekend, which coincided with Chinese New Year and Valentine's Day weekend, we decided to grab a quick romantic meal without our newborn.  Since it's difficult to get out of the house now, I wanted this dinner to be special more so than ever!  Since we live in the south bay, eating in the city was a treat.

We walked around the Marina district and found this place by accident.  I noticed that there was a crowd waiting outside, which indicated that this restaurant must be at least somewhat good.  The posted menu was impressive.  Italian food hasn't impressed me much, because I have found it easier than other European cuisine to be cooked at home.  A16 served southern Italian cuisine but was unique and fresh.

The one horrible thing was the wait in the beginning.  We were told that the wait was an hour.  This was at around 6 PM.  We walked around and returned and had to wait another 20 mins or so.  The restaurant was busy and bubbled with younger crowd.  It reminded us of a restaurant in NY late at night.  

The restaurant was worth the wait.  We ordered immediately since we've been staring at the menu for awhile.  Service was great!  Our waitress recommended an Italian white, which I wanted and went along great with my meal. The wine was crisp, floral, and light in alcohol (my request).  

The appetizers were served fast, which was great since we were starving. They beat the bread basket, which I couldn' believe!  I started off with the escarole salad with watermelon radishes, egg, anchovies, breadcrumbs and black pepper.  I'm not sure if the watermelon radishes were type of radish, but they were pickled perfectly.  I loved the anchovie dressing with the breadcrumbs (gave the dish crunch).  It gave the dish a Caesar salad feel without being the mundane Caesar salad.

My main entree was the squid ink cavatelli with house-made baccala, cherry tomatoes, green olives and chiles.  The pasta was chewy.  The baccala (salted cod) was delicious!  It was firm and flavorful... reminded me of crab meat.  

We shared a pumpkin panna cotta with hazelnut cake.  It was light and not horribly sweet.  The richness of the french-pressed decaf coffee balanced out the sweetness well.

I wanted to stay and enjoy the night longer even though it was crowded.  The food was delicious, and I enjoyed watching the cooks run around in the open kitchen.  I would highly recommend this restaurant for those who have the time to wait or make reservation.
author: Kaela H.

description:
Had the Burrata, Panzanella Estiva, & Roasted Eggplant for appetizers, all VERY good. 

For dinner we had the Bianca pizza (hold the basil which they didn't hold..) & the Pomodoro pizza add Prosciutto. The Bianca was kind of weird, even though it came recommended and it's also surprisingly spicy. The Pomodoro was great. 

Unfortunately I can't find the name of the bottle of American red we had, but it was alright...legitimately it tastes like jolly ranchers. I would ask for the sommelier to try a good Italian.

I would definitely go back for a second experience. My friend lives in the Marina and says this is his go-to spot.
author: Chloé M.

description:
A16 is simply sublime.  I try to get there every time I visit San Francisco and have always been delighted with the meals there.

The menu is excellent, the wine list is extensive and reasonably priced.  The atmosphere is that of a cozy neighborhood restaurant and its clear there are a lot of 'regulars' from the Marina district who eat there on a regular basis.

I have never been to A16 when it hasn't been packed so expect a wait (even for a seat at the bar) if you don't have a reservation.

Definitely try the Burrata that served with lightly grilled bread, locally sourced olive oil and sea salt.  It's OUTSTANDING!
author: Bob B.

description:
I rarely get the pleasure of introducing my foodie girlfriend to a hot spot she hasn't tried, so this hopping scene in the Marina was a long overdue destination for us.  Luckily for my credibility, the meal and the milieu was perfect start to finish.

I knew long before walking through the front door that I'd make haste for the burrata, as it was at A16 that I first tried this ambrosial creation four years ago.  It was better than I remembered, served simply with olive oil, sea salt and plain crostini, proving that you don't need lots of ingredients to make a dish memorable...provided those you do have are par excellence.

Our salad was magnificent, an orchestral blend of arugula, frisee, medjool dates, almonds and shaved pecorino with a light, tangy lemon olive oil dressing.   

Arriving on the heels of our salad was the salsiccia pizza, an auspicious combination of fennel sausage, gypsy peppers and several fresh, flavorful cheeses.  I was primed to love the pizza after spending several minutes staring into the belly of the wood-burning brick oven which is visible from nearly every seat in the dining room. 

To complement the pizza we got a half-order of homemade ricotta gnocchi with guinea hen sugo - rustic Italian comfort food which our server likened to chicken pot pie.  The tender hen spent hours being cooked rotisserie-style, producing a subtly smoky essence and a hearty flavor.

The A16 vibe is vastly different in the rear dining room where we sat (enthusiastic but mellow crowd, elegant decor) than in the frenetic, fashionista scene near the front.  Our server was a real value-add, pleasant, cheerful, and helpful without being pushy.   We had an 8pm Saturday night reservation, which the charming hostess helpfully turned into a 7:45pm seating.  Go early, stay late, there's a lot to love about this place.
author: Derek W.

description: Short and sweet, not that good.I will not be going back. I can't believe they charge the prices they do, for the food they serve. Our waiter tried to dissuade me from ordering the wine I selected. He was very condescending. Get over yourself! I work in the wine industry, in Napa Valley, been working there for over 15 years.  I think I can step up to the plate, when ordering wine.
author: Ann H.

description:
I've been having a tough time lately with the more well-known restaurants in the city. Not sure what it is.

First, the wait. I had a reservation for 2 at 7 pm the other night. Because of rush hour traffic, I called ahead to let the restaurant staff know that we may be 5-10 minutes late. I called at 6:30 pm -- no answer. I called again at 6:40 -- still no answer. 6:45. 6:55. No answer. We ended up arriving about 5 minutes late, and next thing we knew we were told we'd have to wait until 7:45 for our table. And even then, we ended up with a seat at the counter.

As for the food, it was good -- definitely the best part of the evening -- although not mind-blowing. We had the beet salad, the entree portion of the maccaronara, and the margherita pizza. The pasta was unique, thick and al dente, almost like a stir-fried udon. As advertised, the pizza was terrific. I've been to Starbelly and Beretta both within the past couple months, and I thought the pizza here was still better. Saucier, if you like that sort of thing.

The ambiance is nice. Warm lighting, nice buzz to the place, friendly service. But not sure if I'd go back.
author: Albert L.

description:
This is a really great semi casual date place!  Very comfortable cool ambiance.
Came here cause I heard that their pizza and wine selection is great!

DInner:
-Bruschetta with butternut squash, ricotta and mint (yum! Cant go wrong with bruschetta!)

-Prosciutto tasting: la quercia berkshire and speck - Great variety of prosciutto!  Nice display.  A great starter. 

- Funghi Pizza - mushrooms, smoked mozzarella, grana padano, garlic, oregano, dandelion greens, olive oil  - OMG I love mushroom pizza.  Simply the best! Thin crust with generous amount of cheese and mushrooms. Just the way I like it!

We wanted to ordered the Maccaronara with ragu napoletana and house-made ricotta salata (7x7 recommendation) but they were out!  No more late night reservations here.
Need to come back to try this dish!  I heard great things. 

Warning: its in the Marina.  Parking is an issue.  So arrive early :)
author: Ying F.

description:
As recommended, I needed to 'carb-load' before running the SF Half Marathon. Now I could have gone to the 'Pasta Feed' downtown and had a decent meal. But, no.....I was in the city and I wanted to make the evening special. 

I was referred here by a friend in LA. I was also told that there would be no better gnocchi than what I would be served at A 16. 

So I arrived in my little black dress and shiny dangly earrings... a very sophisticated diner who was going to run to her death in the morning. We started with some mozzarella burrata topped with olive oil, served with crostini bread. Such a simple dish yet, utterly brilliant in flavor and texture. 

I wasn't sure what to drink so I took the server's suggestion....she recommended the perfect wine based on my tastes. 

Then, the gnocchi arrived. 

As a seasoned yelper I don't even know where to begin to describe this dish. How do you find the words? These perfect little mounds of starchy ricotta-based goodness were delicately placed in a shallow dish along with tomatoes, garlic, basil....the acidity of the tomatoes provide the perfect contrast to the creamy savory gnocchi. 

I once again I stand firm on my opinion that the best dishes are those that are simple, and made with the best ingredients. A 16 exemplifies this idea. 

Best Italian meal I've EVER. HAD. End of discussion.
author: Monica N.

description:
A16 is back to hitting on all cylinders.  Great service.  An up-tempo venue.  And of course really good food.

I started with a terrine of rabbit and duck that came with plums and blackberry honey.  The grainy terrine was perfectly complemented by the stone fruit and honey.  

A well-sized half order of fregula with corn, fava beans and mascarpone was lovely.  Not too much cheese.  Perfect, sweet corn in abundance.  And likewise the favas.

Finally, a berkshire pork chop with peach mostarda and toasted hazelnuts.  The large rim of fat around the chop sealed the meat so that it remained very moist.  The mostarda was wonderful and could have stood on its own as a not too sweet desert.

All in all a great meal.
author: David D.

description:
Since posting my 11/2/12 review I was contacted by A16 management with another apology, and a gift certificate.  Thank you A16 for your gracious effort to change our perception.  I look forward to enjoying your restaurant in a new light.

Side note:  The seating options at A16 include a wonderful 'wine bar' (equipped for dining also) that seemed to offer lively, attentive interaction with their staff.  I suspect this is the best vantage point for enjoying A16 most.
author: Devin V.

description: Can't say enough how much we enjoyed our meal here! First, we loved the atmosphere. Very casual and friendly. The wait staff were so accommodating and fun. They did a really great job in working with us on wine selection. We ordered a lot of starters and entrees and the flavors were fantastic. We especially loved the bruschetta with the egg on top. My entree was the pasta with goat (can't remember the name) and it was so different but the pasta was perfectly cooked and the meat was tender and full of flavor. Desserts were also a hit, especially the lemon tart. Looking forward to the chance to go back.
author: Lynn L.

description: The food was spectacular and the wait staff attentive.  The one piece of advice I'd pass along is to share one of the pizzas.  They're more than enough for two if you're having (sharing) an appetizer.  Worth planning ahead to get a reservation.
author: Tom V.

description:
LOVED IT...again!!
We enjoyed lunch for (2) on Saturday before going to Fort Mason exhibit.  We enjoyed the burrata, bruschetta with octopus, mussels and olives.  Had sparkling water to drink. The check was under $50!! exceptional food --the service was a bit taxed and the lovely (brunette) General Manager (did not get her name) was running food and keeping everyone happy.  She was so delightful!  The food is amazing, just love it.  Definitely  will be back!!!
author: Mia B.

description: A rather particular friend recommended this and I thought it was great. Creative salad (corn with figs, pancetta and crew); lovely grilled chicken livers very tasty dessert.  But the main memory was the velvety texture of the pizza crust.  With great toppings, it was fabulous. Can't wait to go back.
author: Peter E.

description:
A great dining experience, everything was good but none of the food was stand-out. Favorite dish was baratta app. Macaronara and the squid ink pastas were both very good, although neither of us would order again. Italian sausage pizza was spot on, but again nothing to write home about.

For a little extra charge you can get smaller portions of many pasta dishes, which is great for our indecisive appetites.

Extra points for great service, amazing atmosphere and complimentary gelato for the special lady's birthday :)
author: Kent S.

description: Went to this Restaurant for our first Valentine's Day (just married) (pre-set menu) and it was awful. You'd think with a pre-set menu the food would be easier to prepare, nope! I could list everything that tasted awful, but I'll leave that to a manager if I ever get a response....The service was horrible. She wasn't rude, but seemed not to care. We barely ate our meals and it was obvious, but no one asked, cared or noticed. I emailed the business with no reply. I specifically stated in the email that I wanted to resolve this before I posted on Yelp. I guess no one cares. We live in Cow Hollow and frequent this area and will not be coming back. It was the worst meal we have had in all of SF and our total bill was close to $300. I'm hoping someone gets back to me this time. If not, it's obvious that all this business cares about is the $$$. I'll keep all you Yelpers posted!
author: Jessica L.

description:
I still love A 16, but our second visit made clear to me that this place excels most with their pizza. 

We ordered the sausage pizza again (couldn't help ourselves!) and it was as amazing as the first time. For pasta, the marconara was still on the menu and remembering how bland it was the first time, we steered clear of it. Instead we tried the gnocchi. It was delicious - a 1000x better than the marconara. That said, I think in the future we'll probably order two pizzas and skip the pasta dish altogether. Comparatively, the pasta is simply not as exciting or delicious -- if I were rating A16 and had only tried the pasta then they'd probably get 3 instead of 4 stars. Moral of the story, A16 is amazing, because their service is excellent, the atmosphere is warm and welcoming, and their pizza is phenomenal.
author: Kimya P.

description: I would give A16 5 stars on their burrata appetizer alone, which is divine. I also love their pizza which is simple, clean, and true to its Neapolitan roots. Their wine selection is fabulous and isn't widely overpriced like many other restaurants. They have a great variety and something to please even the most discerning palate. The homemade pastas and cannelloni beans are also excellent.
author: Frances O.

description:
Loved everything we ordered!  The pizzas were 2nd only to ones I've had in Italy!  The small charming space is quintessential urban fine (but not uptight) dining.  The menu is obviously created with a lot of care to highlight fresh, seasonal ingredients.  The squid ink and sea urchin pasta is sooo tastey and almost minimalist in how it allows the ingredients to really speak for themselves.

We let the sommelier pair our wines throughout dinner and she did a wonderful job as well.  It added a fun dimension to dinner too.  Looking forward to coming back!  Just make sure to make reservations plenty in advance, A16 is popular for  a reason!
author: KL A.

description:
We had a great time dining at A16. The food was delicious, and given that it was Saturday night, the place was packed! (reservations recommended)

Since my knowledge of Italian wines is lacking, I asked the waitress for a suggestion. She recommended a "bold" and "spicy" wine that lacked both boldness and spice (and was too chilled for my taste). Everything about the dinner was terrific except for the wine, which was just so-so. A16 has a spectacular wine list, so I'm disappointed in myself for choosing a sub-par wine and don't blame A16 for my poor selection.

On the other hand, dinner was delicious and I'm eager to go back -- this time after doing some vino research upfront!
author: Peter C.

description:
Freakin' A - A16 knows how to cook up some damn good Italian food!!
(so good I've brought back freakin' A, used constantly in college and still makes no sense.)

The only reason I've brought the review down to 4 stars is because of technical issues - food is definitely a very solid 5. 

Referred to Yelp reviews before the old college roommate and I headed over to A16 for our customary catch-up dinners so every single dish was a guaranteed delish!!

Appetizer: 
-Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini: As good as the reviews say! I think I read a review that said they stop the process before it becomes full mozzarella so it's a bit softer and tastes amazing with the olive oil and the crostinis. Every table around ours had this and after reading reviews I went especially to Walgreens to get some lactaid in preparation (is that gross to share? I'm Asian what can I say??). Definitely worth a try or two!

Pizza:
-Funghi - roasted mushrooms, smoked mozzarella, grana padano, garlic, oregano, wild arugula: Delicious!! I saw a few reviews that said the mushrooms weren't good but I found them perfectly cooked, not mushy with perfect texture and the chile oil on the table added just a bit of heat. The other pizzas on the menu seemed good as well - some with just tomato sauce, some with just cheese and one with both. Although the roomie said it was a bit dry I was completely happy just gobbling up the mushroomy goodness!

Pasta (ordered half orders to share since everything just looked too damn good!):
-Maccaronara with tomato ragu and house-made ricotta salata: on the 7x7 list. Now usually I appreciate a bit of meat or at least seafood in my pastas but in this case, it would only ruin the appreciation for a great sauce and amazing pasta. The pasta tasted like it was just made (who knows?) and had a perfect al dente texture that really carried the flavor of the ragu. Loved it loved it, very subtly delicious!

-Squid ink tonnarelli with octopus, Manila clams, black olives, chiles and garlic: I am a sucker for squid ink pasta ever since I tried it in Boston and this one by A16 definitely did not disappoint. Again, great texture in the pasta, amazing flavor and a generous helping of octopus and clams as well. Winner dish for sure!

We decided to skip out on the entrees considering the reviews for them were mediocre at best and focused mainly on the pasta, pizza and wine that A16 is known for. The bulk of the bill was the carafe of Cab that we ordered which was AMAZING in flavor and complemented our mushroom pizza very well.

All in all a raving good meal and it helped that everyone around us was raving over their food as well. The minus star happened at the end when we had one pizza slice left (a lot considering it's 1/4 the pizza!!) which was taken away to be boxed to-go yet we did not get back at the end of the meal. =( I'm extremely sad just thinking about how I could be eating for lunch today to re-live yesterday's delicious dinner. 

I know I know, longass review but all these dishes were perfect and if you follow this advice (reaffirmed by Yelpers!) I can guarantee a great dinner experience!!
author: Christina L.

description:
Still trendy, cool and nice space.  Great service, staff seems to be into the food.  Last visit a few years ago and flavors and service were great.

Why 2 stars then?  It seems the chef has been breathing too many sycophantic fumes.
Quantities are arrogantly small - an octopus appetizer which as basically a small salad with a few small pieces of very well prepared octopus for $14.
The mushroom pizza: piping hot, but doughy-chewy as in the dough isn't cooked through under the cheese.  With a good wood oven (and the hype), I expect that texture contrast of crust to cheese to ingredients.  And the flavors, while fresh, had no spark.
The wine: interesting varietals, lovingly and overly described, just didn't deliver.

If you are 20-something and wanna be at a cool place on Chestnut, go here.  For pizza, go to Galena.  If you don't need to be quite this hip, skip it.
author: Neal S.

description:
Exceptional dining experience that kept me smiling the whole way through. 4.5 stars 

Cost to worth it rating: 3 

Eve award: best margherita pizza, best grilled corn 

Highlights: 
- Wine: Italian gems all around. From sparkling to lighter whites to light to medium bodies reds, there's something outstanding for everyone. Takes some to wow me and I was thrilled with all that was poured. 
- Margarita pizza: the best I've had. Delicate, fresh, crushed tomato sauce, mozzarella, and a few leaves of basil. Charred chewy crust to round it all off makes it my favorite. 
- Corn: mini slices of corn on the cob expertly seasoned with cracked black pepper and sea salt. Sweetness, pepperiness, and saltiness comprise a stellar trio. 
- Pasta: fresh al dente with ripe tomatoes being the center of the dish making up the sauce. Ricotta bits mixed in vary the texture and flavor a bit, 
- Prosciutto tasting: 3 different kinds served in piles on a wooden paddle. Americano was standard, Berkshire was more substantial and salty, and speck was smokey. 
- Layout: longer than I expected--like a supermodel's legs. From the front it looks like it'd fit only a few tables, but it tricks you when you get inside the door being roomier than expected. 
- Service: our waitress Amanda was the best. Warm personality with fantastic wine suggestions based on our individual tastes. 
- Almond cake: cross between angel and pound with a noticeable almond flavor. 
- Chocolate tart: hard crunchy almost cookie crust like base topped with a clump of chocolate mousse laced with olive oil and sea salt. Be still my savory-loving yet sweet heart. 
- Ambiance: cafe style casual yet impeccably put together 

Midlights: 
- Sausage: on the pizza tasted more ground beef like than superior Italianed flavored sausage meat 

Lowlights: 
- Soundtrack: didn't quite fit the mood for me. Led Zepplin and the Who weren't what I was feeling at this top notch Italian spot. 

Had this place on my to try list for several tests and thrilled with the outcome. We'll be back for sure.
author: Eve K.

description:
A16 is good.  Not great.  Not worth an hour wait or braving crowds of blonde hair dye (not that I object to blonde hair dye).  But it's very much a scene.  A scene that annoys me in the same way that Mission hipsters annoy me... 

That aside... the waitstaff is wonderful and responsive.  The menu is creative but not always on hit.  The pizzas are delicious (but not the leftovers).  The lambneck pasta sounded promising but wasn't that exciting.  The semifreddo was beautiful but unremarkable.  Meh.

All in all, as the reviews say, a solid place and an excellent wine list.  Wonderful, professional staff.
author: Melanie K.

description: Not impressed. None of the dishes we got were that great. The pizza especially was sloppy and horrible. The waitresses all seemed a little bitchy to me, but hey you're in the Marina...
author: Cindy C.

description:
The pizza here is legit.  I would put it in the top 3 pizzas I've had in SF.  We ordered the margherita pizza with pancetta.  Every component of the pizza was perfect.  The crust was nice and chewy.  The cheese was of very high quality.  The sauce was perfect. They also serve it with the "house special chili oil," which pretty much was a fancy name for the chili oil they have at Chinese restaurants. Surprisingly it went real well with the pizza.  We also ordered the maccaronara ricotta salata and damn, that was delicious as well.  The noodles were like thick, doughy strands of spaghetti and the sauce went perfect with the dish.  We also ordered the braised octopus appetizer and this was a major dissapointment.  It literally came with half a tentacle. 

My only gripe about A16 is their lack of protein on the pizzas and pastas.  I had to get a taco down the street after I finished dinner.
author: Grant L.

description:
Even though this place was packed on a Monday night, our group of 3 was seated within 15 minutes. We sat at the counter, facing the pizza oven, and loved watching the chefs do their thing.

We took the recommendations of the awesome sous chef, Andy, and were treated with an amazing meal. Squash, broccoli, short ribs, pizza, and the budino tart (and delicious pinot noir to boot).

We all agreed we will definitely be back!
author: K A.

description:
This place never fails. 

Yes, it may be on the pricey side, so don't go if that's not what you're looking for. Bring good friends and you will be sure to have an enjoyable time. Heck, even go by yourself the food will definitely deliver. The service is great and the atmosphere is great as well. 

Good food, good friends, good time. Every time.
author: Kendra S.

description: A16 is a mecca for foodie deliciousness.. The steak is perfect and the zuppa di zucca, a zucchini soup, is also amazing and unique. A lover of braised octopus, I've had it more tender, so i'd support a subtle shift in preparation, but otherwise, service fantastic, wine list fantastic and setting idyllic as it comes.
author: Rachel S.

description:
OK, this is one of my favorite restaurants in town.  Yeah, it's in the Marina, but I can contently deal with that issue once I walk through the the front door.  The dining area has an open kitchen so you can watch all of the talent going throughout your dinner.  One of my favorite parts about this place is the service.  

A 16 has some amazing Italian wine, so ask your server to pair each course.  You can order by carafe or 1/2 carafe vs by bottle if you are into trying a different wine with different courses.  Everything on the menu is delicious, so try it all.  Do make sure you order the homemade buratta and a pizza of your choice. 

Bon Appetite!
author: Conrad N.

description: I had the STEAK for lunch ($22). While it was really friggin' tasty - I was still hungry. I winded up going to Super Duper Burgers for a mini burger for "dessert". Pretty sad.
author: Carolyn N.

description: Wonderful place tucked in the marina. Pizza was great! Fresh salad with peaches. Must try the octopus appetizer. Extensive wine list. Busy on weekend nights.
author: Pratima M.

description:
Amazing food, awesome service.  The food here has a lot of flavor.  Most dishes are bold and intense in flavor (vs delicate), which is how I like it.  If u can, sit at the counter and watch the chefs prepare the food.  It's a great experience. 

1. Loved the squash salad with buratta.

2. I know it sounds gross, but the tripe was excellent. I don't know what was in the sauce, but it was delicious. So rich in flavor.  Would've been a great sauce for pasta or dipping with bread. 

3.  The side of white corn on the cob was great.  Who would've thought to grill corn in a wood fire oven?  Then, they drizzle it with some olive oil and salt. Very simple but tasty. 

4.  The squid ink pasta was one of the best I've ever had. They use a good amount of lemon juice, which gives it a lot of flavor.  I heard they make the squid ink pasta on site, whereas a lot of other restaurants apparently buy the pasta. 

5.  The bucatini with heirloom tomatoes was fantastic. We went Labor Day weekend, so tomatoes were in season. It was such a simple dish, but so rich in flavor. 

6.  The chocolate budino tart was pretty good, but I personally preferred the peach crostada with raspberry sorbet. It was cool to see a dessert cooked in a wood fire oven. Peaches were in season, so they tasted great. And the raspberry sorbet was very flavorful. 

I'm from LA. I would definitely come back here next time I'm in sf. I heard they are expanding to other cities, so I hope LA is next on the list!
author: S. H.

description:
Definitely have been here many times, but what prompts me to write this review was my most recent experience this past wkend. My first choice for dining anywhere generally is sushi. Italian is delicious, but just try not to make a habit of it. 
So in the past, I have always liked A16 conveniently for its location in my old hood. So the whole yuppie-Marina vibe is partly what gravitates me here. I know, this may sway others from coming here for that reason alone... maybe that's a good thing, the negative star is for a painfully long wait for a table. 
Back to the gist of my review... I can not rave enough about the wine that Aiden, our bartender suggested to me that night. Gravello... OMG it was amazing!
Arrugala salad was delicious and exactly what I wanted. 
We sat at the bar, and this guy sitting next to me (who i later found out is a corporate chef for several restaurants through out the country) ... He gave us some great tips on other phenomenal Italian restaurants to try. I have to keep reminding myself that I don't have to order just pasta or pizza to eat Italian food. I plan to be more open to trying Italian from now on. You can't live in the city and not be a foodie!
author: Myra M.

description:
Drive on down to A-16 for a reasonable taste of the south of Italy.

With A-16, chef/owner Liza Shaw can save you the cost of airfare to Italy, as she delivers a fair rendition of food from Puglia and Campania right in The Marina.  With a few exceptions, dishes including fresh pasta, house-butchered and house-cured meats, and authentic Neapolitan pizza shine.

On a recent visit the burrata with olive oil, sea salt, and crostini displayed its characteristic creamy goodness.  An unusual appetizer of whole fava beans (with beans still in the pod) roasted in the wood-burning oven combined smoky, salty, and spicy flavors into a winner.  

Slightly disappointing, the crust of the pizza Romana was nicely singed on the edges, but the center was soggy and limp, indicating an oven temperature control problem. The squid ink tonnarelli with Manila clams, capers, white wine and garlic was bland and  underwhelming.

A well-chosen wine list with ample selections by the bottle and by the glass complements the rustic menu.  Including unique selections from Italy as well as California, the list highlights smaller, less well-known producers and non-standard grape varietals over the standard blockbusters.  Excellent wine knowledge allows the staff to steer diners to wines that accentuate the food without breaking the bank.

As a standard in The City for nearly six years, A-16 is obviously on the right road.  However, like any country road in Italy there are a few bumps.
author: CJ G.

description:
Needing reservations for a Monday night?  A sign of a good restaurant.

The restaurant is kind of dark, but I love how intimate it is even though it's really busy.  I was told by my friend that this place is usually busy every night of the week.

Fungi pizza with egg-  I was surprised that you can add an egg to the pizza.  I LOVED it!  Definitely something to try if you like runny eggs.  
Braised goat in a tomato like stew- Loved this too.  Tender meat and not very gamey.
We had the the polenta on the side and it was nicely seared on each side.
The BEST part . .DESSERT!!!
Chocolate tart with olive oil and coarse salt.  I was blown away.  We had it with a side of coffee gelato and it was amazing.  I love sweet and salty.
I was skeptical of the olive oil, but you couldn't really tell there was any on it.

A lil on the pricey side, but definitely worth it.
author: Lee D.

description:
Lousy service. @Managing: Considering weeding out the unfriendly staffers so you'll stop receiving these more than a one-off reviews describing bad experiences with service.

The food was decent. I'd try somewhere else.
author: Matthew C.

description:
Two stars because of the rude hostesses. Yes, for a very small, crowded and quite loud restaurant there were 4 hostesses running around the front of the restaurant. One, with a plaid flannel shirt and glasses, kept dogging in and out of my party of 4 people without even one "excuse me". I thought for a while she was a patron. We waited quite sometime up against the front door even though we had a reservation. Then, miss plaid shirt escorted us back to the wrong table then escorted us back to the front door area. No one kept us informed.   I told miss plaid that the place was very disorganized. Instead of apologizing, she gets all mouthy and defensive so I told her her to shut up. She kept on mouthing. Finally, one of the other 3 hostesses took us to the correct table. My son called over the manager to complain and the manager did nothing but defend miss plaid and actually scold me for telling the girl to shut up.  Really, I guess I should have politely told her to her to simply stop talking. The manager was defensive and told me that the hostesses were "very organized". However, they forgot to tell her that they sent us to the wrong table. So much for their organizational skills. 

As the restaurant later slowed down, the blond and miss plaid were taking photos of one another on their cell phones.  Later, a group of about 6 people came in and the blond was talking to a friend and her daughter at the bar and completely ignored the group until she finished chatting. 

Two stars as the pasta was fresh and our waitress was nice and attentive.  I have read a few other comments about the hostesses so I know it is not just me. The one with the long blond hair has an attitude as well.  Either the owner doesn't know, is related to them or simply doesn't care. I have been to their other restaurant on Filmore had had a much better, and more professional, experience.
author: Donna C.

description: Truly horrific service. Four servers split duties for the four of us - sounds great, right? But part of our order was forgotten and had to be requested twice again; servers gave the wrong items to each of us; a simple request for ice took 15 mins; we had to request silverware at every course.  Food was decent but presented terribly. Our vegetarian friends could order only sides, which came in meager bowls and plates and  with no attempt to make things look appetizing. Ugh.
author: Charles D.

description:
San Francisco doesn't know excellent pizza, and will never be the wiser so long as it's transplant inhabitants perpetuate the conviction that there is never any reason to visit the outside. (Not complaining- I'd prefer they remain over in the fog).

In your face, A16. Pizzziolo & Boot and Shoe school you.
author: jen e.

description:
You know, I gotta say, I was really underwhelmed by this place. 

Menu is pretty standard upscale Italian-American fusion.
Atmosphere is meh - the front half of the place feels a little like a renovated basement.
The piquillo peppers had an almost fishy taste - no indication on the menu that this was intended. My mom makes them better.
The topping to crust ratio was super off on the pizzas, and the funghi pizza (the waiter's recommendation when we told him this was our first time at the restaurant) would really only be good if you were obsessed with mushrooms. A standard run-of-the-mill mushroom eater like myself will feel OD'd on mushrooms after one or two bites.
It was also petty of them to charge us $1 for the side of tomato sauce we asked for to help give the pizza a little more flavor.

Overall, I really don't get the hype. Seems like the kind of place that was interesting when it first opened but didn't keep up with the SF level of innovation we've all grown accustomed to.
author: Joanne S.

description: Had a late night dinner at A 16 after Delarosa told us it was a 45 minute wait...after 9 pm on a Thursday!  (I still can't get used to all the late night diners in the city ;)  So glad we walked 2 more blocks, because dining at A 16 was excellent.  Nice ambience, great service, and QUIET so we could chat.  Oh yeah, the food was great, too.  We shared the burrata and crostini and the roasted firelli peppers.  Loved the burrata, but I'm not sure I would order the peppers again.  They were OK.  Shared a margherita pizza, and we loved the pizza scisors.  The explanation about why a pizza shouldn't be cut made so much sense!  (Look it up or better yet go to A16!)  Loved it!
author: Kim K.

description: The service is pretty bad and they get arrogant about not seating you unless your whole party is there. The food is hit/ miss - it's either great or terrible. The pizzas and soups are safe bets.
author: Jane D.

description: Great local restaurant. Amazing pastas and off the charts bruschetta. The Sicilian pizza was the best pizza I've ever had in SF. The wine list has great range of Italian selection. A must for work or pleasure.
author: Rob M.

description:
What took me so long!? I've been thinking about trying this place for months. Now I finally have and I can't stop raving. It's become one of my favorite San Francisco restaurants and that only happens less then once a year. 

I love recommending A16 for first dates, old dates, family visiting and a standard regular spot with girl/boy friends. The ambiance is inviting and fresh. My favorite spot to sit is at the end of the food bar watching the small plates Cook. It is an art and a talent to be able to pull off what they do in the kitchen. I am also, now inspired to have a wood burning stove built into my kitchen (a massive one). That will happen when I actually own a home instead of paying a mortgage on my rent in SF. That's besides the point... All you need to know is watching the cooks while waiting and eating your meal is inspiring! Better then staying home watching Top Chief.

Most areas in the dinning look romantic. The front is bar seating and seems a bit crowded for the space. But for a wonderful meal and comfortable seating, sit in the dinning area inside or out. :)

Cheers!
author: Dee C.

description: Recently my wife and I had one of the worse meals we have ever experienced. The meal went downhill after being served a beet salad that was so heavily salted it was inedible. We did not ask to have it replaced but just commented on it. This lead to the manager getting involved who quickly asked us to leave. She claimed we had created problems when we came in when all we had done was make the mistake of walking in and asking whether they could seat us. We were told yes and were promptly seated. Simple and fast. The person who seated us was not the manager and did not support the managers claims but she was unwilling to even discuss it. In a town with so many other choices I encourage you to find more amiable places to enjoy a meal with friends. Life is short.
author: Gary G.

description: I used to live across the street fro A16. Best Italian food around. I was a fortunate man. Now that I've moved away to the wilds of Marin, I make a point of returning to the old 'hood, just so I can get a taste of my old haunt. Keep up the good work!
author: Jeff W.

description: We are traveling and needed a bite late on our last night in town. We arrived 30 minutes before they closed. The staff was very pleasant and accommodating. The atmosphere is very pleasant and the wine list is impressive. Our food was great and reasonably priced. We would recommend to our friends.
author: Howard Z.

description: A16 was our first stop on our honeymoon in San Francisco!  We absolutely loved it.  Be sure to make reservations on Open Table, bc it only seats 75-ish ppl.  The restaurant brought us complimentary sparkling wine for our occasion, which was so yummy.  We started with the burrata for an appetizer (per Yelp reviews), and it was SO yummy.  Order it, no questions!  For drinks, I had the lager beer, and my husband had two other beers,, Calicraft and The Brewery, I think.  The second one mentioned was awesome!  It was a tangy, citrus-like brew.  Loved!  I didn't drink the other one, and I think I may have the names wrong anyway.  For dinner, I decided to do two appetizer servings of pasta, which was awesome if you like to try new things.  I got the maccaronara and the...one that is listed directly underneath if on the menu!  I think ricci, or something... but it has lemon, asparagus, and some other things.  They were both good, but I think I was expecting more.  Of the two, the maccaronara was better, more traditional if you're not adventurous.  My husband's dish though was insane.  He got the funghi pizza with prosciutto added on top of it.  It was sinful.  So yummy.  Mushroom lovers --- get it.  I think if I could order all over again, I would have got the Panna pizza.  I think pizza is going to be the best on the menu.  We had the popular chocolate dessert for our final order.  It was great, bc even though it was chocolate overkill --- they have huge pieces of sea salt on the plate to give you extra oomph.  It is worth trying if you're wanting the experience.  Service was awesome.  Our waitress Hardwick was fantastic, and she totally went out of her way the entire night.  The restaurant has a cool vibe too.  We highly recommend this restaurant to all.
author: Marisol O.

description: I think if I did not have such high hopes, A16 would receive 3.5 stars... The food was average (average for SF standards). Both dishes (fish and chicken) were overcooked. The waitress could not pronounce even the grapes on the wine list and her description of the wines amounted to generalizing the grape. This was the biggest disappoint; coming from a place that prides itself on wine (which yes, the list was interesting and something to admire).  Our reservation was not ready until 25 minutes after, but the hostess was very nice and accommodating.
author: JP A.

description:
There were two things I was impressed with:

1. The attentive service
2. The wine list . 

We shared a couple of pizzas and they were pretty tasty, not crazy about their desserts but definitely will go back to explore that wine list further
author: Mrs. Bauman M.

description: Octopus and clam appetizers great. Sirloin steak and sole entrees fantastic. Extensive wine list and our pinot was spot on. Waitress knowledgable and unobtrusively attentive. Seated at appointed time.
author: Ichor B.

description:
This review is for the awesome "Mock tail" the bartender made me to help me disguise an early pregnancy at a work dinner.  

A few months ago, I had a work dinner and was newly pregnant but not ready to tell my coworkers.  I arrived early and spoke with the bartender about my predicament (need to look like I'm drinking but not actually be drinking). This was made more difficult by the beer/wine only options...He made me a drink that they have on the menu which is made with Vermouth (I think).  It was not only VERY delicious, but it looked like a drink, anyone could have ordered it and my cover was not blown.

Additionally, the bartender slyly made his way to the dining room to see where we were sitting, spoke with our server to advise her of our scheme and the night went off without a hitch.

Thank you Mr. Bartender for the awesome mock-tail and your super slick skills!!! It's the little things in life and it made this situation I was very anxious about A-OK!  You rule!

The food is also awesome and other reviews speak to that. Nothing tops their pizza oven...Order your own- you won't want to share once it arrives.
author: Melissa I.

description: I have been here 6 times so it is time for me to write a review.  To start I have been here 6 times with 6 fun tables, so that is a "gimme".  I have sat in the front, middle and back and the ambiance is a different but the food is consistent every time.
