I had made pasta the night before so I had the duck for an entre, crisp and rare, perfect.  You cannot go wrong with the starters so order up but the surprise was veggie pizza mmm mmm good and the surprise was we ordered the funghi pizza and added prosciutto (smokey) .  A16 gets an A+
author: Toby N.

description:
The restaurant looks small from the outside, but the dining area stretches far back.  the room in the very back is cute and more quiet.

We came as a group of 5 and ordered a variety of things:  pork chops, sea bass, steak. we ordered burrata; i agree the mozzarella is amazing, but really nothing to rant and rave about.

I cant really brag about the food; thought it was mediocre, but the SERVICE is excellent!!  we ordered 2 porkchops, they took our order, came back and said they only had 1 left so they surprised us with a free pizza!  

The waitress was very knowledgeable and made good recommendations.  

it was a busy night so we waited almost 30 minutes to get seated and we had reservations.
author: R M.

description:
Pizzas' Great  so is the atmosphere. Fun place to sit down, and order a few pies with friends. Make sure to order there burrata cheese, and  Prosciutto appetizers. 


I would stick with ordering Pizza, and appetizers when going again. That's where A16 really shines.
author: Mark J.

description:
The Food is excellent here. I wish I could say the same for the service but, I think is was mostly to do with it being a Saturday night and a insanely packed house. Five stars for the following dishes:

- Burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini 
- Prosciutto sampler 
- Salsiccia Pizza- fennel sausage, spring onions, mozzarella, tomato,     
  grana, garlic, onions, chilies, olive oil 
- Maccaronara with ragu napoletano and house-made ricotta salata 
- Squid ink tonnarelli with sea urchin, calabrian chilies, fennel and 
  tomato
- Braised Beef ribs
- Chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil 

The wine list can be a little overwhelming if you are not familiar with your regional Italian wines but, ask the manager or Sommelier and they are sure to pick some good ones for you.
author: Marco M.

description:
GREAT food.. HORRIBLE service.. 

one of those places where the wait staff acts like they are doing you a favor by waiting on you

WAKE UP A-16.. hit the reset button with your staff--please tell them to get off of their high horse
author: A R.

description:
Very pricey and very disappointing.
I love anchovies on my pizza and thought a place like this would do it well. NO. Overly salty and otherwise flavorless... like wat you call this a gourmet pizza?
There are plenty of excellent Italian places in the city so I don't see a need to ever go back there again.
author: becca w.

description:
This is the type of restaurant you would probably only go once. It's not as special as I expected it to be. Came here for dinner with four people, even with a reservation, the wait was a bit long. The decor is nice, tables are pretty close together, and the noise level overpowers your dining experience. 

The pastas were alright, had the maccaronara, which is #42 on the 7x7 Big Eat List 2012, I found it to be good, but too salty. The Salsiccia, funghi, and margherita were flavorful, but not my favorite in the city. I enjoyed the flourless chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil, burrata, and the wines the most. Good food and great location, but not up to the hype.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
A place that prides themselves on wood fired pizzas, yet has no beers on tap?!?! Fail. 

Besides that, we had a good meal here. We started with the Mozzarella Burrata, olives and the San Daniele Prosciutto. These were all nice starts, but the cheese really stood out with its buttery goodness. We sat right across from the oven and saw these great pizzas coming out and had to have them. Margherita - tomato, mozzarella, grana padano, basil, olive oil for her and Salsiccia - fennel sausage, rapini, red onions, mozzarella, grana padano, garlic, chiles, olive oil for me. They were both quite good and the crust was perfect. But, I definitely needed the tomato sauce on mine. The rest of the menu looked really good, but that was all we had.
author: Dan G.

description: Had the risotto with black squid ink.  Great.
author: Tess A.

description:
A big disappointment for us at A16 yesterday. We stopped in for lunch before heading to the beach. We were greeted very warmly and professionally by the hostess who seated us promptly but it was downhill from there. Two of us ordered a glass of wine which cost $15 each and could not have been more than 3.5 oz each. There were 5 of us and our lunch orders were 3 pizzas, mussels, and lastly soup and salad. When the food did arrive (it took a while ) the toast that comes with the mussels was placed on the table so badly burned it was black. We asked for a replacement which we received but no removal of the burnt toast and no apology. One if the pizzas had ingredients in it that we're not listed on the menu. Two of the pizzas has sauce added to them one of which was sloppily poured on top after the pizza was baked. Clearly an afterthought. Al of the pizza toppings were very unevenly distributed on the pies too. The salad never came but was on the bill. The server removed the charge with a half-hearted apology. 
The pizzas were tasty but not worth the price or aggravation. It also took a long time to pay which didn't help matters. 
We has been to A16 a few years back and had a very good experience but after this visit, it's off our list for dining in the marina district.
author: Maria F.

description: I had a fantastic meal here with a group of six people for a birthday.  The restaurant was a total stickler on their "no outside cake" policy, which was ridiculous -- they wanted to charge us $8/slice for a cake someone had bought from Tartine, so we skipped all dessert and went home to munch instead.  They would have at least sold coffee and bourbon if they'd been more chill about that.  **But** we had some really solid Italian food, and enjoyed several bottles of excellent wine recommended to us by their sommelier.  Price is about what you would expect for higher end Italian in SF.  So, not a regular spot to go to, but a nice one.
author: Tasha D.

description:
We love this restaurant. I had the Fergula, which was light and delicate with a outstanding flavor. My husband's daughter had the margherita pizza, which was really delicious. My husband had the Lucky Dog Ranch beef culotte with braised romano beans and rucola, which he said was wonderful. He also tried my Fergula, and he couldn't stop sampling it! Our server recommended the Trimpilin 2007 Sangiovese which we really enjoyed - a really nice wine that complimented both of our dishes.

Note - If you use Open Table, be sure to reserve in advance. They are hard to get into.
author: Robyn W.

description:
The food was good, although I've never really had bad food at an Italian restaurant. For 3, we ordered the following to share: 

- Arugula salad with medjool dates, almonds and pecorino monte poro
- Squid ink tonnarelli with sea urchin, calabrian chilies, fennel and tomato
- Pork meatballs braised in tomato with basil and grana padano
- Margherita pizza - tomato, mozzarella, grana padano, basil, olive oil 
- Burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini / prosciutto di parma

Everything we had was good. I would say this is a good place to stop by if you're in the mood for Italian, but I'm not sure there was anything particularly outstanding about it. I like that you can order a smaller version of most plates to share.
author: Leily P.

description:
I am no fan of George Bush (Sr and Jr), but am a fan of his favorite movies) Godfather I and II. 

A 16? same scenario, I am not a fan, but am a huge of it's sister restaurant SPQR. 

I don't think it's a particularly bad restaurant, but I personally do not believe it lives up to it's hype and tends to let me down. There a few dishes that I think are exceptional which include the beet salad and the pizza. However is this enough to spend hours on opentable trying to score a table for four and drop my hard earned money on? 



I think not.
author: Rene C.

description:
3.5 stars for solid Italian food. Many of the pizzas were unremarkable. but I'll bump it up for good service and a chic interior dining space. My table ordered:

-Burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini, added prosciutto di parma for $4 more: So simple, yet one of my favorite dishes of the meal. The burrata was so creamy and FRESH and made a wonderful compliment to the saltiness of the prosciutto and the crisp crostini.

-Squid ink tonnarelli with sea urchin, calabrian chilies, fennel and tomato: while some may be turned off by eating black pasta, i really liked this squid ink pasta and loved the earthy, rustic taste that the squid ink added to a dish.  The sea urchin imparted a distinctive creaminess to the pasta.

-Pork meatballs braised in tomato with basil and grana padano: mmm, the meatballs were really tender and flavorful.

-Margherita pizza- tomato, mozzarella, grana padano, basil, olive oil: nothing special 

-Salsiccia - fennel sausage, gypsy peppers, mozzarella, ricotta, grana, garlic, chilies, olive oil : nothing special 

-Funghi - mushrooms, smoked mozzarella, grana, garlic, oregano, dandelion greens: nothing special 
 
-Bianca - mozzarella, grana padano, chiles, garlic, green olives, basil, olive oil: my favorite pizza of the night and the only one i thought was unique. I thought the Bianca pizza went well with the other heavier dishes we had. 

-Chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil: we ordered several desserts, but this is really the only one that stood out for me.  I loved the combination of chocolate + sea salt + olive oil. It reminded me of Sam's Sundae at Bi-Rite, but in a ice cream pie form.
author: Monelle A.

description:
fold, bite, swallow. the margherita pizza was incredible, slightly odd to me that you literally cut your own pizza with scissors...but hey it works. simple, fresh and comes out in 2 minutes, loooved it.

Maccaronara pasta - we shared this, but damn I could have eaten the whole dish myself. Perfect al dente bite, pork ragu is simple but crazy rich in flavor.

Sirloin steak - a bit overcooked, not the most memorable. Stick with the pizza/pastas.

Extensive wine list, try to get a table at the bar and watch the chefs, otherwise the tables can get really tight.
author: Angela L.

description: My boyfriend took me to A16 for our anniversary.  I am still dreaming about the pizza we ordered and the chile oil we dipped it in.  Loved our waitress, the experience, and the food.
author: Jessica K.

description:
This is a great trendy place to take out of town guests or go with friends. Overall, my visits to A16 have been pretty satisfying. The atmosphere is great but the experience varies depending on the waiter and what you order. 

FOOD: My favorites are the CARROTS (seriously order these, they are so good), burrata cheese app, and the macaronnara. The macaronnara is to die for! It's spicy and the pasta is fluffy and yummy. My least favorite is the gnocchi and gnocchi is one of my favorite italian dishes.

You definitely need a reservation or you can expect to have a long wait...the location is good because it's on Chestnut and you can park on the street.
author: Jenna Q.

description: The three stars are for the service, otherwise I would give them a one star. I ordered the Liberty Duck breast with farro and carrots.  The server was kind enough to sub kale for the farro.  However, the duck breast was so salty it was inedible.  I was at a business meeting and did not want to send it back, so I moved it around on the plate.  The carrots and kale were good.  To the chef: back off on the salt.
author: WK C.

description:
A+ service! Traveling on business can be tough and I'm not always sure where to setup client meals. The atmosphere was nice/casual, but the service was formal and perfectly timed. At first, I wanted to eat everything on the menu, then settled for the fennel sausage pizza and salad. It was delicious!

Q: During the lunch hour I peered over the open kitchen divider and saw a woman making little chocolate pieces with what might have been hazelnut inside. Are they on the dessert menu?
author: Lisa C.

description:
I came here with my family and everything we tried was superb.

We tried the ricotta, pea and mint bruschetta (outstanding) and the sunchokes with burrata. Both were great, though I'd recommend getting the burrata on it's own rather than with the sunchokes. 

For the main courses, we ordered the Fregula pasta and the Margherita and Bianca pizzas. If you're in doubt, I recommending ordering more pizza than pasta. Pizza is all about great crust & simple but high quality & delicious toppings and A16 nails it. The pasta was good too, though.

Definitely save room for dessert. The chocolate budino tart was the perfect mix of salty & sweet but I loved the the blueberry hazelnut cake even more. The creme fraiche & almond streusel were perfect complements. 

All in all, great place. Just make sure you make your reservation on time because if you don't, someone else may try to poach it. (Seriously, this happened in front of my very eyes).
author: Shreya O.

description: A16 was at the 2013 SF Street Food Festival today. The prichittus was $3 and it was a let down. The dough and the filling both lacked the wow factor.
author: D B.

description: Great food and lovely service, but the day I have to sit next to THREE 9 year old children at the chef's table/bar because their parents do not want to sit with them is the day I decide not to return. Why do we have to be exposed to "Free-Range Children" on a Saturday night??  If I wanted to go to Chuck E Cheese, would have made reservations there. C'mon people!
author: G C.

description: Wonderful service - very knowledgeable staff in regards to the entrees and wine selections. Food is fantastic, and not always your typical Italian fare. Try something new...you will not be disappointed.
author: Trang H.

description:
I see a lot of mixed reviews about this place.. but everything we ordered was great, and the service was good too! I think it definitely earned every single one of the stars I'm giving.

Squid ink cavatelli was AWESOME, and the pasta was cooked perfectly where it was nice and firm. It's rare to find squid ink dishes, and I definitely enjoyed it. The lamb was VERY flavorful.. in fact, I think that was the highlight of the meal. Pizza margherita with prosciutto was excellent as well. I also never had a prosciutto tasting -- a board with 3 different kinds of prosciutto -- I thought prosciutto was all the same!

Surprise - they actually have a sommelier, so be sure to ask for a wine recommendation.

I don't care what the other reviewers said; I liked the food here so much that I'm definitely making a return trip here!
author: Kazu O.

description: What a great find.  My server, Raymond, was beyond fantastic--attentive but not overbearingly so, and a great conversationalist for those who want to chat at the bar.  I had the tripe and a pizza to go, both of which were good, although I think the tripe may have been slightly under-seasoned.  The wine list kept me there all afternoon; they have incredible options both by the glass and by the bottle.  Truly one of the best wine lists I've ever seen.  The place was practically empty, though, which was fine for me to sit and read at the bar, but not very exciting for those looking for lively atmosphere.
author: Brooke J.

description:
Second visit, just as good.  Flying solo, was able to score the last seat in the back at the chef's bar-area.  Had the romana pizza, a couple glasses of wine, and the chard side.  Then I finished it off with the mejool date cake -- that was some cake!

A16 scores high marks all around -- hard to find something not to like.  If I lived in SF this would be a regular spot for me.
author: Jon M.

description:
So I hate to state myself the Italian culinary snob.  But having grown up around Italians and tasting many a "Nona's" home cooked meals, as well as having a culinary tour of Italy on various occasions....this Italian is not as my friend Yoda would say.

I went all out with my courses as one always should with Italian.  I got three starters including the Frisee salad, Albacore tuna and Trippa.  The Frisee was decent with a good blend of flavors.  The Albacore was overcooked taking away any flavor one would expect when biting and the trippa was well cooked however in a sauce that resembled something out of a can.

Moving on I then got the Margherita.  These pizzas are way overrated.  How hard is it to cook a timeless staple of a pizza?!  Sauce was ok, crust was burnt and center was doughy.  Don't think I've actually ever had pizza made this way.

I then ordered the pork shoulder which was just greasy and not cooked thoroughly.  Ended the meal with their Cioccolate something something with a scoop of gelatto.  Not bad but oh wait!  Let's drizzle the bastard with gobs of olive oil.  Don't get me wrong, this is a great blend of flavors but DON'T overdo it!  

Service was ok.  Our waitress had the "hipster" syndrome where excitement or personality are prohibited in ones personality however the gentleman who I believe is the up and coming wine connoisseur of A16 made a decent bottle suggestion and was very friendly. 

END RESULTS?  MY GIRLFRIEND AND I THROWING UP IN THE MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT.

I won't be coming back other than for a glass of wine.  Apprende cucinare cibo italiano per favore
author: Carlos S.

description:
Starting with a 30 minutes wait is never good, but I didn't want to knock off any points for that.

But unfortunately, A16 wasn't able to redeem itself with the food... the Pizza's were good, but not as nearly as good as the neighbor Delarosa.
The Uni pasta was interesting, but nothing to run back to.

For the price and praise, expected way more
author: Assaf B.

description:
Still not sure why this place is so wildly popular.  Marina folk need to venture outside their neighborhood more often.

The pizza is doughy, pricey, and average at best. 

Our prepubescent server had the personality of cardboard and the experience of a 12 year old sweat shop worker.  If I remember correctly, he gave us the wrong dishes TWICE and didn't apologize ONCE.
author: Scott G.

description:
I was expecting a little more from this restaurant since the chef is a James Beard award winner.

The broccoli inside the paccheri pasta was extremely mushy and ruined the dish.  It was also a bit too salty for us.  In addition, we had a pizza that was not memorable.
author: Jessica P.

description: Italian food can be found just about everywhere in the City or in any city for that matter.. However, I was pleasantly surprised by A16. The food brought nostalgic feelings of being in Italy when I was a kid. Ordered: bruschetta, mussels, halibut, squid ink pasta with braised squid, broccoli, mushroom (Funghi) pizza, margherita pizza. Fantastic food!
author: Eladio S.

description:
Today I start my quest of the 7x7 2010 Big Eat San Francisco: 100 Things to Try Before You Die list. A list that consists of restaurants all located in SF. For an East Bay guy this is not going to be easy since I mostly eat in the East Bay, but to quote JFK we do it "not because they are easy, but because they are hard." 

After taking our kids to Bay Area Discovery Museum in Sausalito we decided to cross the bridge and headed out to the Marina in SF for dinner. My wife thought it was cool, but I was excited because this was a perfect opportunity to try out a restaurant from the 7x7 list. First stop A16 and their Maccaronara with ricotta salata. (Technically I already tried the Pulled-pork sandwich at Roadside BBQ located in San Rafael, not SF but the same restaurant so that's checked off as well.) 

So on to the review. 

Immediately after we were seated we order the Maccaronara with ragu napoletana and house-made ricotta salata (7x7 recommendation) and the Margherita pizza for the kids. The Maccaronara was definitely delicious and I absolutely recommend it if you are planning to eat here at A16. But personally this wouldn't be on my list if I was making my own 100 Things to Try Before You Die list. It's just not something I would crave for or go out of my way to have. 

What I am a bigger fan of is the restaurant itself. A16 was very nice, cozy and elegant. The people were very nice and their staff was very attentive. Only negative for me is that this place is not kid friendly. I certainly would love to come back and dine here again, maybe when the kids are older. 

Overall outcome 3 1/2 stars, but I'm willing to nudge it up to 4 stars for the nice staff and great setting.
author: Mel B.

description: Nice atmosphere, solid service and on point Neapolitan pizza. I'm a sucker for the VPN certified list. Check.
author: J L.

description:
Not sure what all the hype is about.

First of all, the food was not memorable. What was memorable? The service. We were two couples without reservations but they squeezed us in before the rush. That was the only positive part of our experience. It then consisted of us being told by our server that the manager asked for us to hurry up and leave because there was a long wait. WTF? That MIGHT be appropriate in the rare circumstance that our party of four was sitting there well past the bill arrival with empty glasses and plates...but this wasn't the case. We had at least half a bottle of wine (with wine still in our glasses!) AND food on the table! Honestly, I don't even think we were there more than an hour at that point. To make matters worse, when we asked our server to have said manager speak to us personally about his request, she returned without him and told us he was too busy.

With service like that, I will NEVER return.
author: Jasmyn M.

description: went for my birthday and the staff and management were great as was the food.  will definitely be back next time in SF.  Try one of their fresh pastas, pizzas also super tasty.
author: Michael B.

description:
Pizza was great.  The gnocchi was divine.

They made us wait for over 30 minutes after our reservation time before we could sit down, but they gave us free champagne as apology.  The champagne was good.  All was forgiven!
author: Niniane W.

description:
Visited from San Diego for the weekend to catch up with a friend and waltzed in with no reservations nor expectations on a friend's recommendation. We shrugged at the 45 minute wait upon observation of wine bar to the immediate right upon entry...only to be whisked away 10 minutes later by the fantastic hostess who was able to grab my CC I had placed at the bar and take our drinks to the kitchen counter. 

Seats at the kitchen counter were a bit different than typical table seating but it worked. It was fun to watch the pies get assembled and tossed into the brick oven. Wine selection was legit ranging from Napa Valley to Italy to Argentina. We went with the bruschetta (spicy garbanzo beans was a different twist but it worked) along the arugula salad before attacking the Salsiccia pizza. Everything placed before us was fantastic. 

Waiter service was fantastic and he was kind enough to pretend I had a clue about the wine list. 

Yes, the bill is a tad high but it is par for the course for the type of restaurant and neighborhood so no complaints here.
author: Manfred M.

description: Some of the best service we have had in some time from a "higher end" SF restaurant. My wife, daughter and I went there at a whim.  We were not even that hungry but we could not stop eating the delicious dishes that we ordered (pizza, pasta, a nice arugula salad). From the time we walked in to the time we left, we were taken care of by a great team of professionals.  1) Sitting at the bar waiting for a table the bar tender recommended a perfect wine that met my description of what my wife and I prefered. 2) we were greeted by the host who took our glasses of wine and my daughter's Shirley Temple and showed us to a great table where we could watch our food being made (my daughter just loved it). 3) the cooks were friendly and greeted us and one even struck up a conversation with my little girl (they discovered that they were both fans of Dr Who). 4) the waiter(s), hosts and cooks all worked together seamlessly in a beautiful concert, helping eachother keep the busy flow of orders moving efficiently (it was beautiful to watch). 5) on our way out, we were met by no less than 4 different staff (most did not even take care of us that evening) that thanked us for coming. Amazing!  We all felt special, like we were honored guests. Will definitely be back.
author: Dave C.

description:
My husband and I had a dinner at A16 recently with out friends who were visiting from Saint Louis. We heard so much about it so we decided to try it out.
The atmosphere of the place is great. I thought for a second that it is much smaller than it really is (there is bigger dining room towards the back and even a patio.  We spent some time waiting for our table at the bar and had some yummie drinks. 
For dinner we ordered a few appetizers: octopus (good), burrata (amazing) and Salumi (really good).  I would recommend burrata to everyone. It is really fresh, milky and delicious.  
For dinner I had gnocchi and that is why I give this restaurant 3 stars.  Gnocchi itself had a great texture and they looked like they were home-made but the sauce (even though made out of great selection of mushrooms) was really bland.  No flavor at all. I was very disappointed and I am hoping I was there on an off night because other yelpers seemed to love it.  My husband had a funghi pasta which was delicious.

Our service was great.  The waitress was very attentive.  Wine selection was extensive. I love Italian wines and they had quite the selection. Little on the pricey side.
author: Ad F.

description:
Sis and I have been on a food adventure the past two weeks. Multiple continents and countries were involved. Inspired by Above & Beyond's weekly radio show Trance Around The World (TATW), I'm calling this Eat Around The World (EATW). Acronym works nicely. 

Episodes:

EATW #1: Seafood (Valparaiso, Chile)
EATW #2: Panaderias (Santiago, Chile)
EATW #3: Cow (Bueno Aires, Argentina)
EATW #4: Parillas (Puerto Iguazu, Argentina)
EATW #5: Thai (Pacific Heights, San Francisco http://goo.gl/E5Pko)

There was Chilean and Argentinian wine too. Lots of it. But I'll save that for DATW (you can figure out what the D stands for). Anyway, tonight was the final episode (for now):

EATW #6: Italian (Marina, San Francisco)

We walked in stuffed from all the above, but managed to find room for another excellent meal. "Track list":

- Albacore tuna with dried favas and croccantini. Tuna and fava was good if oily, bread was great alone as well as topped with the above.

- Marinara pizza. Great sauce and loved the thin crust. No need to mess around with cheese or a bunch of distracting toppings.

- Squid ink pasta. Excellent, intense, confident flavor. Small is plenty for two. 

- Halibut with sunchokes on the side. Halibut was very good, sunchokes blew my mind A & B style. Taste and look like a potato, but actually a root vegetable. Never mind all that, just make sure you get some.

- Strawberry sorbet. One of the best I've ever had.

Overall a strong four. Most of the food was excellent and priced about right. Service was friendly and knowledgeable. Space is warmly designed, love the pizza oven. Atmosphere is alive and buzzing, little too big and noisy for intimate conversation. I can't imagine this place not being full. Was a nice reminder you can travel halfway around the world and have some incredible food, yet know that you'll come home to some of the very best. 

P.S. Think we've got one more episode on the way. EATW #7 is likely coming this weekend down on the peninsula. Our grandparents will be the "guest mix". Knowing the source, it will probably be the best episode yet.
author: Jason B.

description:
Addictively excellent place -- delicious mostly Southern Italian fare, with a fantastic wine list with a particular emphasis on the wines of the Campania region near Naples.

Everything we had was excellent -- the arugula salad, the hallucinogenically great burrata, the prosciutto/speck sampler, and the salsiccia pizza.  The pizza was fantastic, with an amazing array of flavors -- the only thing that kept my review from 5 stars was that the pizza might have been slightly underdone in the center -- a little soggy in the middle.  (That might keep the pizza from being as good as, say, Pizzeria Mozza in LA.)

Then, of course, the wine -- had a glass of a crisp Falanghina to start, and then shared an outstanding bottle of Aglianico with the pizza.  Intense wine that Aglianico -- so acidic when it was opened I felt like my teeth were going to melt.  But the sommelier decanted it, and after a bit of time, it softened into a perfect wine with the salsiccia.  Still a wine with muchos huevos grandes, but still somehow in balance.  Great wine.

Anyway, great place -- go.  If I weren't headed back home to LA, I'd go back there again tomorrow!
author: Seth S.

description:
when SPQR wasn't available we hitched a ride over to A 16... 

rustic feel restaurant, totally segregated feel b/t bar, restaurant and its narrowness.  the bathroom assuredly was on the other side of the wall.  

i was in the mood for something hearty.  i saw that they offered squid ink pasta with UNI! it's rare that I see this specialty on the menu these days, but i am obsessed with uni and love it especially in my pasta.  i knew that this was "the one".  sadly, my only criticism was that there was not enough uni.  maybe 2 pieces max.  such a tease.  the pasta was dressed in olive oil well and seasoned nicely.  but nobody can expect to be satisfied with minimal.

pizza was good too... better definitely in NYC, but i can appreciate the usage of fresh ingredients, evident when you inhale them by the slice.  

definitely a long wait ... and everybody waiting and overcrowding the bar.  would i come back here??  the wait is a bit of a turn off..perhaps if we can score res early in advance, i wouldn't mind. otherwise, i think i'll be in the mood for something else.
author: Brittany H.

description: I've been here two times already and both experiences were just ok. The service the second time was great and my friends and I sat at the counter in front of the oven but the food left me wanting for more. I got squid ink pasta both times as this particular pasta has gotten publicity from magazines proclaiming it as one of the top pastas in the city. Both times, I was sort of disappointed. I like the fresh pasta but the braised squid was too chewy and was not tender enough. One of my friends on the second visit complained that her short rib entree was too salty. They do make a good arugula salad though but that is not enough to redeem the restaurant in my eyes.
author: Kai C.

description:
Hmmmm....I was pretty unimpressed with this place. I was starving by the time I got here and everything SHOULD have tasted amazing, gaging by how hungry I was. Instead the pizza was decent and the pasta too salty.  And the fava bean stuff, which they served later on in the meal was very unappetizing. It tasted like gritz gone bad. 

Overall, the meal was nothing I would ever rave over. If I wasn't in such a hurry to leave, I would have tried the dessert and maybe a star could have been added, but alas no chocolate mousse or tiramusu - leaves a weak three stars, mostly because I don't think price and quality of food matched up.
author: Jessica T.

description:
If you like a restaurant in which disinterested waitresses serve small portions of overpriced,  average Italian food, this is your place.

This is heaven for the Marina trust fund and yuppie set.  Style trumps substance in a room that is so hot, you will literally sweat.   

They don't even give you bread.  Very disappointing.
author: Lewis F.

description:
A 16 definitely impressed.  Although did you think it was hard enough just to get a reservation?  Just you wait, young sir, to be sat anywhere close to right away when you get there (even on a weekday). Their wine menu is excellent, but I came here for the pizza!  Don't expect to get a cheap glass (carafe or bottle) at A16, shit's classy here.

We tried the crostini and burrata to start.  Not that you can really go wrong with toasted bread, cheese and cream but it was an excellent little foreplay to the cheese orgasm that would later ensue.  I got the Quattro Formaggi pizza (mozzarella, ricotta, grana, smoked mozzarella, garlic, oregano and wild arugula) and added prosciutto di parma...and was VERY pleased with my decision.  Highly recommended add the prosciutto.  Friends got the fregula and the maccaronara and I think the fregula was the pick between the two.

I'd love to come back here with a few more dolla dolla billz to splurge on some great wine!
author: Kelli P.

description: I love this restaurant. I think they use mostly local organic ingredients and their wine selection is amazing.
author: Lien N.

description:
It was Halloween and we treated ourselves to a nice dinner at A16 before hitting the party scenes.

We had 8:30 resos and we were seated promptly in the back of the dining room. This place is packed, noisy, but happening. It reminds me of a busy restaurant in Manhattan. Sophisticated-looking people, friendly service, and a good wine list.

Natasha and I split the Funghi pizza and the pumpkin and ricotta gnocchi. The pizza reminded me of Rome, authentic thin-crust, and very flavorable. The cheese blended well with the plentiful mushrooms. The crust was crunchy, chewy, baked to perfection. I think it is my favorite pizza in the North Bay.

The gnocchi is out of this world. It is the best gnocchi I have ever had. I love the side greens and the texture of the gnocchi. I need to go to Quince and try theirs - they are supposedly better.

Once again, I was not impressed by the dessert menu. Almond this, sorbet that . . nothing stood out. Hence, minus one star.

Service was attentive, the atmosphere is cool and modern, and they provided unlimited supply of filtered cold water in glass carafes. Nice.

Pizza, gnocchi, and bottle of Umbria wine = $70 (not bad!)

I would consider A16 as one of my top 10 restaurants in SF without a doubt.
author: Betty N.

description:
This place (and SPQR) are very meh.  I don't know why I'm always so disappointed with the food each time I go (and I've been multiple times), but I never think it's that good.  

I'll keep going back and trying again though.  Hundreds of yelpers can't be wrong...right??
author: Cat L.

description: A 16 is a restaurant we always hit when in SF. Great service, food and wine selections. The Mozzarella with olive oil is absurd, they bring it in fresh from a local farm. Make a reservation or you might not get a table!
author: Andy B.

description:
I came here for dinner with the family (5 people) on Labor Day and surprisingly we were seated right away! We shared several dishes that ranged form excellent to Okay. bruschetta

Firstly, the bruschetta had very fresh tomatoes and a nice garlic olive oil. The prosciutto taster mixed US ham with european and was Okay. The standout entree was actually their special; the meatballs! They were delicious. 

Their pizzas did not wow me, I think Delarosa down the street makes tastier pies. 

Generally, everyone was happy with their meal.
author: katrina w.

description:
On a recent visit to A16, I tasted just about everything on the menu, had god knows how much wine (all expertly chosen by Shelly) and left feeling extremely happy. It was a very, very good night.

The Mozzarella burrata was unbelievable. They procure it from some small place in Southern California. I've never tasted anything like it in my life.

This fabulous experience, all told, cost me $90. I know because I recently found the crumpled receipt. I went with three other people, who each paid $90 as well. While I wouldn't jump on the chance to pay that much again, and think that it is quite possible to return to A16 without spending that amount, I do believe it was worth it for the experience I had.

I do, however, have this nagging feeling that my experience was made in large part better by the fact that my friend is friends with Shelly. I guess only a return trip will hold the answer.
author: Miriam W.

description:
This place is way overrated and I really don't understand why it's always so busy. 

The service is mediocre.
The food is mediocre. 
The ambiance is mediocre (well except for maybe the back room but we didn't get to sit there.)

Here's what we ordered and what I thought about the dish:
smoked salmon with gold beets appetizer - pretty good
arugula salad with nectarines - not so good
funghi pizza - way too many mushrooms and the crust/dough was like eating naan bread which I don't mind but not what I was expecting for an Italian pizza
pork scallopine entree - umm it looked more like tonkatsu (japanese) than a scallopine. i was disappointed
and side of roast corn on the cob - good but on the salty side

Now onto the service (or lack of):
When delivering our appetizers, one of the waiters accidentally spilled my glass of water -- ice and water splashed over my side of the table. LUCKILY no water got inside my bag but still...I expected an immediate apology but instead it took about 5 min before she uttered the words. Our other waitress was more sincere and asked if I needed another napkin etc. 
I don't think it helped that our table was literally sandwiched btwn two small aisles for bus boys and waiters to move around. I was also hoping that they would MAYBE comp us for some dessert or a drink but nothing. As the meal went on, our main waitress seemed to pay less attention to us. I had to flag her down a few times for things to get boxed up and to get our bill. 

I was also quite annoyed with the water boy. He literally had 5 pitchers of water in his hands and would refill my glass like he was a water fountain. Umm, I don't appreciate the waterfall show -- there's no need to have water dripping on my plate and my fork and my bread. Either aim correctly or focus on just carrying one water pitcher at a time.

I really don't feel the need to come back again.
author: Helen Y.

description:
(This review is so long because I have lots to say.  If you want the short version, here it is.  Go to A16 and order the Burrata Appetizer, mushroom pizza and quit being a wimpy, seafood-fearing-pants on fire and get the squid-ink calamari pasta).


I've held a 3 year grudge against A 16, and I'm so glad I gave it another chance.  My first trip I split the Marghertia pizza with a friend.  Not memorable and certainly not adventurous.  I thought the restaurant was loud, overhyped and sceney (all three descriptors do not go hand-in-hand with Italian food).  I thought Michael Bauer needed to boot this place off his Top 100.  I also tend to exaggerate and speak in extremes.  

When making a reservation here (recommended) I would suggest requesting the back dining room.  The waiting area kind of spills into the front tables and I noticed those patrons had people hovering over them, staring at their food while waiting for a table.  

The wine list is diverse and expansive.  Our server was helpful in selecting a medium-bodied red and deciphering the pastas (it's one of the few menus where every single pasta had to be explained to me; I didn't recognize any of the names).  We decided to split a pizza and a pasta, since that's what A 16 is known for and seemed like a safe bet.  

We started with the Burrata, which is a must-have.  I hear that the burrata disappears from the menu from time to time, but may be available upon request.  The Italian cheese is drizzled with olive oil and served with crostini.  I could eat this for breakfast, lunch and dinner.  Request more crostini when the 4 they give you are gone!

Now on to the main course.  We decided to go with the famed Funghi Pizza and the Tonnarelli with calamari.  Let me tell you, I'm so glad I had an adventurous dining companion.  The Tonnarelli with calamari may be intimidating to some, as it's a squid-ink pasta which is dark and murky (between that and the red wine, we were convinced we'd leave A 16 with black teeth).  Seriously though....order it.  It's garlicy and basily.  And seafoody, but not too intense.  The tonnarelli is homemade at the restaurant the al dente texture is amazing.  PLUS, they add some aged tomatoes into the dish which give it an incredible pop of flavor.  If you don't fear seafood, you need to get this dish.  Just do it.  

I know mushroom pizza might not sound exciting, but this was totally unique.  The mushrooms are all different sizes and nothing like you see on that Mr. Pizza Man pizza you order at 2 am when you're having a bad day and eating your feelings.  Flavors include oregano and garlic with smoked mozzarella.  No sauce.  Also, there's a little jar of spicy oil to dabble on the pizza.  DABBLE and dribble, do NOT dump this sauce on your food because mother of mercy, it is spicy.

If I hadn't just gifted the birthday boy a dozen red velvet cupcakes from Noe Valley Bakery, we probably would have ordered dessert!

This is a great place for a fancy date if you want to be out amongst the people.  Just don't expect it to be all drippy candles and violin music, this place is jammin'.  Lovely times all around
author: Kerry D.

description: Great place! Hard to get a table but once you do, enjoy the great facilities and awesome menu. One of the best dinner spots in the marina.
author: Spencer R.

description:
Have been here twice - wouldn't have gone back a second time if I didn't enjoy the food.  Service is spotty - the place is always packed tightly and servers seem to be running around frantically.  If you can, try to snag a seat in front of the pizza oven, it's fun to watch the pizzas being made and food being prepared.  

The pizza is just delectable - I've had the funghi and the ricotta with squash.  Both were delicious.  In case your server doesn't bring it, ask for the chili sauce - very spicy but nice to dip your pizza crust in.  Their arugula salads are tasty.  The second time I came here, I also tried the coffee with cookies which totally hit the spot.  Two entrees with coffee, dessert for two people - under 40 bucks?  Totally down.
author: Jessica T.

description: The food at A16 is a slam dunk but the service SUCKS! And I mean it when I say that. I have heard this from myself, my good friends and coworkers. Seriously cannot believe how many people agree with me when I say that A16 has terrible service. Went for a birthday dinner and they forgot our order entirely- didn't even apologize OR remove anything from our bill. They offered to "throw in" salads after we had already eaten salads. Another time they didn't have my reservation saved, claimed we never made one. They do not acknowledge you when you walk in the door, are notorious for taking forever to get you the check, and the staff isn't even knowledgeable about the food. I keep going back chalking these instances up to "maybe it was just one time..." but time and time again I'm dissapointed. Step up the service game A16- otherwise I'll continue to save my pizza craving and head to Delarosa.
author: Ashley S.

description:
You disappointed me A-16.  Don't get me wrong, your starters are fantastic but your main courses were not that impressive.  As I was sitting there enjoying my Burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini as well as the Prosciutto tasting: La Quercia Berkshire prosciutto and prosciutto di Parma, I was thinking to myself.... Wow, if this is what the starters are like then I am SUPER excited for the main course. 

The main course showed up and I was sorely disappointed.  For the price I was expecting more from you.  (Big Sigh). My husband pretty much ate the rest of the meal as I forlornly watched my fellow patrons enjoying the appetizers I had just eaten.  

Will I return? Well, you do have the best Burrata I have ever tasted so yes but I will not make the mistake of ordering a main course. More appetizers for me in the future.
author: Kylie L.

description: Having read the reviews, I was ready for a mixed bag, but we were pleasantly surprised by the whole experience. We had a huge group dinner. It was delicious, the service was unobtrusive and the meat meat meat was divine! Good for a date.
author: Betty G.

description: This place always has a line. But it's so worth it. We just sat at the bar, had 2 bottles of wine (they have a wonderful beer list.) the Napoleon pizza was cooked to perfection. Thin crust, and amazing red sauce. I can't wait to go back and eat there. By the way, it's the perfect place to bring your parents- or go for a date
author: Alexandra W.

description:
Went here on a date and it was pretty fantastic.  Everyone was super friendly, the waitstaff and hostess were extremely attentive, and there was a really nice atmosphere.  The food there was fantastic - I'm allergic to wheat but I couldn't stop myself from trying the pasta sauces, it was all really yummy!  The salad was delicious too. 

PS - There is also this pastry chef there who is cute as hell...
author: Emma H.

description: Visiting from out of state. This spot was recommended by a local and I'm so glad we went. Great space, excellent service and the food  was awesome. Arugula salad with peaches and the funghi pizza were super. Loved it so much we booked a table for our last night in town.
author: Lorraine D.

description:
A beautiful space, with dark wood and leather everywhere. Our server was friendly and quirky, but forgot one of our starters and lagged on the water refills.

The food was seriously mediocre. Our mussels starter was underwhelming. The cured pork and tomato broth overwhelmed the poor little shellfish, which were a bit gritty and not particularly fresh. No bread was offered with the mussels, and no decent spoon for scooping them out.

The pizzas are famous, but for barely any reason. The crust was baked off perfectly, but lacked any flavor. There was not enough gluten development and maybe even some non-yeast leavening, so the mouthfeel was more yielding than chewy. The crust's flavor was completely empty.

The funghi pizza had plenty of pricey mushrooms, and good texture, but it was a bit simple. A bit of a one-trick pony.

I ordered the tasting pizza, the "do whatever you want" to me, the adventurous diner. Our reservations were early, before the place got really buzzing. So the kitchen had plenty of time to experiment and showoff their, say, cured meats or, say, seasonal veg. No, instead I got four cheeses and rocket. The tired, boring default pizza that is served in every London pizza chain. The cheeses lost each other, the pizza needed seasoning and much more rocket.

Authentic Italian pizza does not necessarily require a tomato sauce, but I do not care. Plenty about A16's pizza is completely inauthentic, so why stop at the tomatoes?  I ended up using the chili oil like a tomato sauce if I squinted my eyes.

Dessert was a fresh torte, a layered thing of booze soaked cake and chestnut custard. It was topped with an annoyingly sweet marshmallow layer, which was probably a nod to toasted brulee.

The sticky wine paired with the dessert was crisp and perfect, by far the best part of the meal. Our by -the- carafe cab was drinkable, but very simple for the price.

A16 is really, really overrated. As other reviews mention, Delfina blows it out of the water.
author: Ben G.

description: Excellent food. Extremely noisy at night. Don't go if you intend to have a conversation.
author: Sramana M.

description:
Just are here last night with a party of 4. The wait was ridiculous at 1 1/2 hours but it was worth it.

Got the margherita pizza, meatballs (meatball Monday), and a couple sides.

Food was fresh, well cooked and came out at the right time. Will definitely be going back next time I'll need to get there earlier to avoid the long line
author: Andrew W.

description:
Went to A16 for the first time last night after hearing (and reading) many good things. There were four of us with very specific tastebuds (and allergies) and let's just say we were all accommodated perfectly. The mozzarella burrata to start was insane(!) and so was the prosciuotto sampler platter. Apparently the octopus salad was divine. I'd been told to order a pizza so my friend and I shared the simple margherita --- very, very good. The cheese was perfectly warm and clumped on top. We also ordered a side dish, cannellini beans... SO darned good.

Service was great, we were seated promptly, lah dee dah. 5 stars for shiz, I'm definitely going back.
author: Meredith R.

description: My wife and i went with friends for dinner on the 19th... we all shared several things. We got two pizzas (both with fennel sausage) and we loved them!! Have a little bit of spice kick to them. We also got the pasta dish with duck. Wasn't what we were expecting, it was like a ground up duck.. not sliced. The homemade pasta was good, but overall that dish was a little bland. Service, overall was pretty good. They messed up an order but recovered quickly. Had a great wine selection, but we also wish they sold liquor. Overall, we would go back for the pizza!
author: Cory W.

description: We are new to San Francisco....And have wanted to try out as many restaurants as possible.  A16 was one of those restaurants.  It was OK.  The noise level is to a point when the restaurant is full, you need a megaphone to talk to your table mate.  The seating is disappointing along one side of the restaurant.  Think the bar by the kitchen is by far the best place to sit!  The watermelon salad was wonderful!  The pasta was mediocre to say the least.  The pizza (Margarita) was dripping in cheese and the crust was almost non-existent.  The tripe was excellent!  Definitely mixed reviews..
author: Linda A.

description:
Came in during a busy lunch hour, got lucky and didn't have to wait for a table. 

Service was incredibly slow, I rarely saw the server. I ordered the G-wine, bruschetta, and the Scarola pizza. The food is good, but the pizza crust was a little burnt. The server also told me that the tomato sauce they use was canned. Ergh for the price on the menu you'd think it would be made fresh or if it's not in season overnight tomatoes from some where!
author: Julie S.

description:
I'm a fan, not a die hard fan, but a fan.

We sat at the bar for a casual dinner.  The bartender was really great - his wine recommendations were right on (pretty extensive Italian wine menu.  If you're not familiar, it can be daunting)

- Burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini = YUM  I'm a burrata fan, and love the way they serve it.
- Pizza with mushrooms = YUM Awesome assortment of mushrooms and fantastic crust.

Yes, it's crowded.  It's a trendy Marina spot.  Go on a weekday if you don't like crowds.
author: brandie y.

description:
I've found that sometimes quality is the most important factor to success, and sometimes hype is more important. I think A-16 is a case of the latter. The restaurant is definitely a happening place. Why? That's yet to be determined.

It's a tiny (some may call it cozy) little place with a really active wine bar (with good reason, several nice selections). The wait was 1.5 hours, which may have been acceptable for a meal that brings tears to your eyes, but definitely not what we got. We ordered two pizzas and the ricotta gnocchi. Everything was edible, but not good. The gnocchi was spongy and in a weird clear broth flavored with mushrooms. Service was fine, which might be special at this kind of trendy restaurant in this part of town.

It seems like people have told each other that this is the place to go ... probably so they didn't feel cheated by going there themselves.
author: Akash K.

description:
Time for an update...I had guests in from out of town and took them to A16 for dinner. We were led through the dining room to a great table on the enclosed patio (quick tip - if you want a quieter dining experience definitely request a table on the patio) 

We decided to order a bunch of apps, pizza and pasta and were definitely pleased with our decision. The burrata is always a must order and was typical creamy goodness. The salumi plate had some interesting options (hello beef tongue!) and went well with the cheese.  

Next up - pasta. Ricotta gnocchi with braised Watson Farms lamb and Jimmy Nardello peppers was divine though the star of the evening was the Bucatini with Sicilian almond and dried san marzano pesto, mint and pecorino. The bucatini was a perfect al dente and while the was the first non-green pesto for me it definitely won't be the last.

We moved on to two pizzas and wanted to keep it simple - one Margherita and one Margherita with added arugula. The classic Margherita continues to be one of my favorite pizzas in SF though the Margherita with arugula suffered from too much arugula! We ended up picking off a good portion of it and it made the pizza more manageable. 

Service was top notch - we were greeted with smiles by the hostesses (who sat us as soon as we walked in even though our party was incomplete) and treated great by the entire floor staff. A16 might get overlooked with all the new restaurant openings in the city but it remains one of my all time favorites and a must visit for the Italian food lover.
author: phil h.

description: Used to be wonderful but sucks now.  Extremely rude staff all around.  Pasta still is good but  I was served a salad with rancid nuts then told the chef claims it is supposed to be served that way.  ???  Sad it has fallen so much.  Go somewhere new that actually cares about being a decent dining experience.
author: JD L.

description:
A16 is a great italian restaurant.  efficient use of interior space with generous materials, though it can get loud with hard surfaces.

educated servers listen and comply with all requests.  they know the menu very well; trust them.  service is brisk and intuitive.  not sure how it works at the "Chef's Table" around the prep area, as we had a table against the wall.

ask for a table outside on the patio, where it might be less noisy and better lit.

burrata is the best i've ever had, and i've had a lot of burrata.  all the appetizers, as noted in other reviews, are well-executed and worth a try in lieu of a larger entree choice, if you can't decide.

the Romana pizza is very tasty, if a bit spicy.  the crust is fresh and slightly charred in contrast to the near-gooey toppings and fresh herbs.  this is not Delfina's, but what is, really?

entree portions can be ordered full or half-size.  get the half-size if you  fill up on the appetizers and pizza, but be sure to at least try the perfectly-textured pastas that are firm, yet light and melt-in-your-mouth.  we had the gnocchi and the maccaronara which were both fantastic.  to my chagrin, i was compelled to order a second plate of maccoronara.

our favorite part of the meal was sampling the deep selection of italian wines by the glass.  don't overlook the whites, as these are not the usual pinot grigio, and can hold up to the heartiest of dishes.  ask for a pairing of red or white with any dish and you will be rewarded.

can't wait to return and try everything else.
author: Mishel F.

description:
I'd heard rave reviews of A16; Italians tell me it's the only REAL Italian food in San Francisco.  I enjoyed the food at A16 - a 3.5 star experience, but as Stephen G. mentions, it was the service that put it over the top for me.

My friend and I arrived at A16 45 minutes early for our 9 p.m. reservation -way, way early.  But we figured we might as well see if we could get in a bit early; she had a table up front near the bar area of the restaurant but we'd probably have to wait for our real reservation time for a table in the dining area.  We decided to wait for a real table in the back of the restaurant.  The hostess was incredibly nice and actually checked to see if there was availability (rather than just flippantly looking through her reservations for the evening).  The bar area was a bit crowded so we went around the corner for a glass of wine.

When we returned a few minutes later for our 9 p.m. reservation, the place was still packed.  We were seated immediately and were promptly waited on by a server.  My friend and I don't particularly know Italian wines, so the server brought over the sommelier.  We gave the sommelier a price range and a desired flavor, and he found something perfect for us (without any sort of upsell).  

We ordered the pizza of the day (ricotta cheese and arugula) as an appetizer; I got the gnocchi with pancetta for an entree while my friend had the beef short ribs (with a side of butternut squash which was highly recommended by the server).  I really enjoyed the pizza - very tasty considering the simplicity of the ingredients.  I liked my gnocchi but it fell a bit flat for me; perhaps I was expecting the pancetta to give the gnocchi more of its flavor but it was a bit bland for my taste.  My friend really enjoyed the beef short ribs, so I think I may have to go with one of the meatier entrees the next time around.

And, yes, there will definitely be a next time.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Took a trip to San Fran for our anniversary.  Had read the GQ article of the best pizza list and A-16 was on the map for a while.  I know that sounds cheesy but being from Phoenix and having one of the best pizza places I've ever been to (crazy right, but true) in Pizzeria Bianco I have been on a quest to find something that can compare.  Been to several places in NYC that couldn't sweep the floor in Biancos shop.  That is until I had the romano at A-16 in San Fran.  

Never having anchovies on a pizza before the wife and I almost ordered something else but I stuck to my guns and thank God I did.  It's been a long long time since we were here but the memory is still fresh.  This was the most perfectly balanced pizza I have ever tasted.  From the crust, to the sauce, to the ingredients.  Just blew my mind.  

I remember walking out and telling my wife the saddest part about it wasnt that it was gone but is that we dont live near A -16 to be able to follow it up with frequent visits.  I'm still sad when I think about that pizza.  I know the first and last thing I will eat on my next visit to one of my favorite cities.
author: Jack N.

description:
Best part of the meal - the burrata appetizer - amaaazing.  Intensely rich, flavorful cheese.

The much-hyped pizza was a bit overcooked to my tastes -- crust was a little burnt.  They've got nothin' on Delfina or Gialina's.  

We had the salsiccia pizza and the Romana were ok but not remarkable, Romana a bit salty for my tastes (I really like anchovies, but this sauce was still a bit too salty for me).  

Side note:  we had reservations for 9pm on a Friday night, and waited almost an hour to get seated.  They were nice about it, brought out some cheap Prosecco while we waited, as well as some olives, but just FYI in case you are starving, just b/c you have reservations doesn't mean you'll get seated anytime soon, and the bar is packed like sardines.

Would I go again to brave the crowd and the wait?  For that, I'd rather eat at another of the city's delicious pizzerias.
author: Annie M.

description: Nice vibe, great service. Fab pizza, pasta and salads.
author: Vicki L.

description:
There are two things you need to know about this place.

First don't bother coming here on a busy night like a Friday or Saturday without reservations.  The wait is really long.  See that "Make a Reservation" section above.  Use it.

Second order whatever dessert comes with pine nut gelato/ice cream.  You don't like carrot cake..who cares..order it so you can get the pine nut gelato.  I tried to order the pine nut gelato by itself but it wasn't one of the options when you order the homemade gelato and sorbetto.

*My review is based on the pine nut gelato/ice cream only.
author: Rachel R.

description:
We came back to A 16 after a year.This place is always good.
Simple food with great flavors. Burrata is always good, clams, peppers,pasta to die for.
For main we had halibut and short ribs with few sides...Great
Only thing that we didn't care for are the desserts.
Best service I got in long time.
Mayra was great, she made our fun evening even better.
Thanks
author: Roko a.

description: More than 3 years after my first (poor) experience at A 16, I was willing to give this cute restaurant another chance. Unfortunately, it was a disappointment again. Yes, the food is great (for the most part) and the wine selection impressive. But it does not justify the high prices nor the poor service. In one word: overrated.
author: Cecile P.

description:
The place is hip and trendy--stilleto hang out for sure ...ok so now the pizza...The pizza was Chewy (not krispy, not soggy, CHEWY) is that a good thing? Why Yes it was--it was different. The taste however was just OK to me. 

-Pizza portions are generous
-Pizza tastes OK (not bad but not special)
-Pizza Chewiness or Taste is not great enough for me to want to go back there, rather I'd go there just because there is a bar, wine and decent food and a cool crowd, dim lighting and has candles. 
-I ordered the Napolotena and it was saucy, chewy but not really to my liking, but with the bottle of Zin, it was good 
-Oh Parking is difficult (but whoever said Parking was easy in the Marina)


OK so overall rating three stars...
author: Q A.

description:
The scene: blue haired Marina crowd, speckled with suburbanites.  

Our reservations were set for 10pm on Saturday night, got there at 10:15pm and the table wasn't ready.  

Tick tock.  We waited for 30 minutes and the table was still occupied, btw, the bar was slammed too.  Crazy.  I was thinking, this place better be damn good.  Anyway we settled in some chairs by the chalkboard and ordered some great pinot from the Lompoc Valley.  

Another 15 mins rolled by and we were pretty hungry and pissed.  

The manager, who had the look of a sexy secretary, came by to explain that they are trying to hint to the guests leisurely dining to hurry the hell up.  We appreciated the update and her galliant effort.  Henceforth, she will be known as SS.

We finally got seated and decided to pick up a bottle of the pinot.  It was a bargain at $62.  

The bread and EVOO satiated us till the food got to the table.  Their EVOO was out of the ordinary, a strong aftertaste and almost salty, we found the olives were pressed when they were young.  Different.  The SS sent over some olives too.  

Between the four of us we ordered:
*Marinara - tomato, oregano, garlic, olive oil pizza
*Gramigna nera with octopus, borlotti beans, tomato, garlic and basil
*Maccaronara with tomato ragu and house-made ricotta salata 
*Watson Farms lamb mixed roast with fennel, carrots and herbs
*Romaine and chicory salad with lemon and olive oil

All entrees come with a free side of your choosing, we chose the romaine salad.  Everything was seasoned well and was not heavy like typical Italian fare.  The pasta was al dente just how I like it.  The lamb entree was pretty small, two small pieces, plus sausage.  

We had room for dessert.  Dessert ROCKED.  And it was comped by the SS.  

*Raspberry crostata di marmellata with figs, pistachios, and ricotta-loved the figs and the crostata was a flaky pie-like pastry.  Fantastic.  
*Honey semifreddo with cornmeal croccante and blueberries-they are not bashful with fruits here, this dessert reminded me of being on a farm.

We charmed her into getting us a round of dessert wine too.  SS you're our hero!

The whole meal was just $75/couple.  If you don't like deafening noise, just get the back room-we had it all to ourselves by the end of the night.
author: Cynthia C.

description: 3rd time here ... Order the Margherita pizza, So good! Dont forget to ask for the chilli oil
author: Marcos M.

description: This review is solely for the customer service on the phone. I just had a very disappointing interaction... I had a rather long break today so I decided to treat myself to a nice dessert before heading back to work. After a little research on the internets, I decided that A 16's budino sounded worth the 45 minute bus trip each way since I could read my book on the way there and back. However, I decided a little caution was necessary as I would have hated to get there and for them to not have any... I called and spoke with the hostess who confirmed it was on their menu (she didn't know what I was talking about at first but maybe she was new as I would assume any hostess has to be familiar with the menu). She put me on hold after I asked her to check if they *currently* had any. I'm sure the pastry chef had other things to do besides getting on the phone to speak with me- and I would not have asked her to do so- but she was the one to pick up the phone after I was on hold for a short time. Well regardless of whether or not this is in her job description, she was very rude about it. She asked how many I needed and obviously my answer of just one was not enough for her to become nicer. She hung up before I could even thank her. I decided not to bother going even though it sounds delicious. I don't want to patronize a restaurant where customer service is this bad and my food would made by someone so mean.
author: A-S R.

description:
Originally on our way to Delarosa for their crispy yummy pizza and sides, and got side tracked by walking by A 16 and its famed reputation from our friends.  I should of yelped it before walking in to see it was indeed not that special after all.  

Needless to say we had a decent dinner service, but for 80 bucks, for pizza and two salads and one beer, NO WAY.  On top of that we had a very cold waitress that seemed to take our decisions personally and had no personality what so ever.  I don't expect a song and dance, but act like you like life, just a little....

The pizza, disappointing.  Not as good as Beretta, or not even close to Delfina pizzeria.  Very disappointing pizza...My pickled beet salad(love beets!), was decent, but not popping with flavors.  Ok, enough, for the price point, this was not worth it.  Maybe the other dishes are great, but I will forever skip this place on my way to delarosa when I am out and about in the Marina and want a decent crispy pizza.  

I will happily get drunk off of wine, in the cold, while waiting for a coveted seat at Delfina pizzeria or Beretta(cocktails are killer here) rather than come back.

Oh, one very good note, stop off at Susie's cakes for a cupcake of heaven.  The red velvet was so good, next time I should get the slice of red velvet cake, it looked like paradise on roids.  YUM.
author: Jenice A.

description: We had a nice dinner at A16 with friends on a Friday night. The service was excellent and the wine was amazing. We split a pizza to start, which was the highlight of the night. My three companions each had different pastas, which were also quite excellent. Unfortunately, the pork chop I ordered, while ample in size, was overcooked, tough, and dry. I would go back for the pizza, however.
author: Evel K.

description:
the food was good, the wine was better and the service was excellent...but i guess i just wasn't that impressed with this place, especially after hearing and reading all the hype. their pizza was definitely tasty but i've had better. 

also the place seems to attract a lot of hipsters which is semi annoying. not their fault of course...i blame the area.
author: Mayra S.

description:
I don't get what all the hype is about, A 16 was just ok. We had a blackboard eats coupon so we thought we'd give it a shot. With reservations, we didn't have to wait too long for a table. The burrata appetizer and meyer lemon panna cotta are must haves- definitely exceptional. Other things we had that were just ok included:

- beet salad
- pizza- eh, delfina is better, especially for $18
- lamp chops
- squid ink pasta
- gnocchi
- chocolate budino tart

Wine list is a little pricey, ambiance is nice but really loud. We decided to take the first table available which was closer to the bar rather than the back dining room. Not sure if it was as loud back there, but I barely could hear my friends sitting across the table. Who knows...I probably won't be going back to find out.
author: Inna L.

description:
My 2 star rating is a curmudgeon's compromise. Barbara brought me here for special dinner date. 

Marina neighborhood parking is a hassle. Circle a 10 square block area 8 times and MAYBE you'll squeeze your little car into a spot that was just vacated 30 seconds before.  If you're a suburbanite with a Big SUV, forget about it.  Park your big vehicle over in the Presidio Letterman Lucas complex and walk the seven streets to A16.

The restaurant was packed. Literally, it was shoulder to shoulder. Be prepared for the noise, I'm going to repeat this many times "THE NOISE LEVEL WAS DEAFENING." After screaming our names to the host, we were escorted to a table just past the open kitchen to the rear of the narrow alley-like room. 

Barbara sat at the banquette I got the chair on the crowded bump-alley. The back of my chair got slammed once every 5 minutes by waiter or other guests squeezing past me.  We sat within 18 inches of our neighbors on both sides. I like to meet cute young women, I just don't want them nearly sitting on my lap during an expensive dinner.  

Barbara liked watching the chefs at work in the open kitchen. I would liked to have talked with her, but the noise level prevented it. 

We ate really delicious food. We spent an hour in the place. I had to skip dessert to get out of the place. I yelled to the waiter, " Forget dessert, IT'S TOO FxxxxxG LOUD IN HERE!" He was offended. Too bad since I had to pay for the sonic abuse. 

My advice to A16 owners: Take out 50% of the tables & chairs, then maybe I'll return for the food.  But, probably not.  This place is about the scene, the crowd, and all the big $$ that they squander here. 

The dining experience here is NOT my idea of fun.
author: Tom S.

description:
in Dec. of 2006 My boyfriend took me there for my birthday. He made reservations 3weeks ago, yet they seated us 55 mins after our reservation time of 8pm. The mozzarrella appetizer had no taste. Which turned out to be a blessing compared to the recommended pasta which had a salty flavor, making it impossible to finish. We tried the pork that everyone has raved about. It was good, but not worth the endless praise. The chocolate dessert tasted stale to me but the anaise sauce was very good. After waiting 20 mins. for our credit card, we left our table in order to sign our bill. We do not understand the hype and hope others will ignore A16 so it can be replaced with a better restaurant.

Pros: pretty environment

Cons: reserv. irrelevant, sub par food, bad service
author: Madhuri K.

description:
"as everything is unspectacular"

Nice space - but a bit on the loud side. 

food was mediocre. No attention to detail - the pizza was okay but didn't make my mouth sing.  

meh.
author: slow c.

description: Pizza crust shouldn't be this doughy and chewy. It's strange...they have the right oven, the ends are properly charred, but there's absolutely no leavening going on. It's less a pizza pie and more a pizza puck. Heavy and dense and not worth eating twice.
author: Scott S.

description:
I had dinner her last night.  It was a bit of a celebration of family.....My sister, her husband and his sister were all present.  We shared everything and it was all delicious.

I especially enjoyed the two pizzas we ordered (white with olives, peppers) and a special meat pizza my brother-in-law knew about from the A16 cookbook.  The chicken meatballs were also outstanding.  Additionally, we had a cauliflower pasta dish that I didn't care for. and a fantastic selection of salumi and cheese.
author: Katharine A.

description: Service was decent, even though we had to wait 20 minutes for our table, the restaurant itself was nice but my god my dinner was the worst entree I have ever ordered anywhere.  I still dry heave thinking about the pork chop that I had placed in front of me.  It had to have had at lease 3 inches of straight fat around it.   Once i was done sawing off the fat that took up 3/4 of my plate I took a bite and refused to eat any more of it.  It was just gross.  My sweet husband took my plate and traded me for his dish.  He's a meat and potatoes kind of guy and even he said the pork chop was gross.  I can't go back and I don't think I could ever order another pork chop at a restaurant because of this one.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
My fiance and I went here last night for our 5-year anniversary and had a wonderful time...

When we arrived, they seated us within 5 minutes...they were not as attentive as I would have liked, but oh well. We were sat in the back main dining room, which has a great, lively atmosphere. Since we brought our own wine, I can't elaborate on the wine selections, but I assume they're pretty stellar. 

We'd heard about the Burrata from several friends and ordered that as our appetizer....AMAZING!! It literally melts in your mouth, so good. We also ordered the Funghi pizza, which was so flavorful & delicious...put a little of the hot sauce they provide on it to kick it up! The dough is really delicious....I'm sure any pizza would be great here. Next up, we had the Pumpkin Gnocchi which was so buttery and silky - only drawback is that I wish it had more pungent flavors. We also ordered the Squid Ink pasta with clams - I didn't love the texture and I'm not a huge fan of clams - I wouldn't order this one again. To finish our meal, we got the Vanilla Hazelnut and Salted Caramel gelatos - truly incredible, you have to try these! And they're home-made...yum!

Overall, I loved our experience there, our waiter was attentive and we'll definitely go back!
author: Keira A.

description: Excellent service but with all of the other options in San Francisco I would probably not bother coming back.
author: Adam M.

description:
Slow service. Long wait inbetween each course.

Very, very loud place. Good food, good wine but it's a long wait just to get a table.

Restaurant decor nice, will try the book.
author: John G.

description:
Really great place with good food, good service and a great bar. Their pizza is really good (but not as great as Delfina's, alas).

You do need a reservation in advance, or be prepared to eat at the super small bar or in the front window (which is just weird). 

I went here with my BF for dinner the other day, and we had a great time. The beer we ordered was one of the best beers I've EVER had- creamy and so tasty! I drank it so can't really remember the name ( :-) ) but it was Italian (I think) and started with an M. It's a MUST have when dining here.  

The pizza was good too- we ordered a chef's choice and got a 4 cheese extra cheesy pizza, and I'm not so much of a cheese fan, but it was good.
author: Jennifer K.

description:
The most important thing I can say about this place, is try the chocolate salt tart. But beware: the mix of salty and sweet is dangerously addictive.
The pasta here is wonderful, although a little pricey. This is where I come on special nights with the boyfriend, birthdays and such. The atmosphere is verryyy cozy, you're basically sitting on top of the people eating next to you, so that is something to consider if you don't like cramped places. I would recommend getting a seat in the outdoor patio on a warm night.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Downgrading to 2 stars.  I hesitantly revisited this place, and my hesitations were confirmed:

-Uninspiring menu choices (no seafood options for secondi, and it took my party of 4 a good 20 minutes of head scratching before we all settled on "meh" choices, and we all skipped dessert even though we weren't full)
-Uninspiring food (the pizza was soggy and chewy, the "fresh" porcini mushrooms were gelatinous and goopy, the beef coulotte was ok but nothing special)

I'm washing my hands of this one (even though they serve Merry Edwards Sauvignon Blanc) :(
author: Priscilla T.

description:
The Hubs and I were visiting the area and had an early dinner reservation for a recent Tuesday evening.  He had eaten here once before and thought it was really good (hence the return visit).

Other reviewers mention the tables being very close together.  Those along the wall opposite the open kitchen are.  This is a small restaurant, although I did see tables farther back that appeared to be stand-alone with more space.  We were seated at a table along the wall, which turned out to be fine despite being sandwiched between two tables of kids and their parents.  Fortunately everyone was well-behaved (I wish I could say as much for the kids where I live so kudos to SF parents - you must be doing something right!).

The restaurant info above lists A16 as 'full bar'.  Maybe that means something different in wine country, but to me that means they have liquor as well as wine and beer.  They don't.  I asked.  So if you like to peruse a menu with a nice martini in hand - forget it!  They do have a nice selection of wine, however.

So a bottle of wine and the burrata starter (with olive oil, sea salt and crostini) were ordered while we perused the rest of the menu.  Everything sounded good and I decided on the Escarole Salad (with nectarines, olives, walnuts and ricotta salata) and the Roasted Chicken Meatballs (with cherry tomato and fennel agrodolce).  Hubs ordered the Roasted Calamari Panzanella (with cherry tomatoes, Sicilian cucunci, fennel and herbs) and the Maccaronara (with ragu napoletana and house-made ricotta salata).

The burrata itself was quite good but I think it was a bit too liberally sprinkled with the salt.  That would have been OK if the crostini had been plain, but it was oiled, salted and way too hard.  Overall, it was just too salty for my taste when everything was eaten together, so I ate the cheese by itself (rather decadent, I thought).

Then the salads came.  The Hubs' calamari salad looked good, but I didn't taste it so can't comment on that.  My escarole salad missed the mark somewhere.  It had great potential.  I think the nectarine and olive combo was brilliant, but either the greens weren't dried well and watered down the dressing or the dressing was just too bland to start with.  Somewhere along the way, the acid component was missed.  Too bad.  A little lemon juice or white wine vinegar would have taken this salad where it needed to be.  As it was, it was almost flavorless.

Then we received the entrees.  The Hubs' pasta looked pretty good.  It must have been since he ate it all without offering me a bite.  The chicken meatballs I ordered were very flavorful but waaaay too salty.  The only thing that helped was the tomato/fennel agrodolce which countered the saltiness somewhat.  My dish also came with a choice of sides so I had the Roasted Carrots and Turnips (with leeks, mint, lemon and chiles).  Pretty much all I got was roasted carrots.  There was hardly any turnip and I couldn't even detect any of the other ingredients.  Now I like roasted carrots, but I could have had this at home (actually mine are better).
