Overall, I was pretty disappointed with the experience.  The food wasn't that great and the service was efficient, but not particularly friendly.  To be honest, I doubt I'd go there again.  There are too many really good places to eat in SF.
author: Diane T.

description: This restaurant was highly recommended to me so naturally, I was looking forward to coming here and even agreed to take a 9 p.m. reservation (the earliest they could accommodate my husband and I).  While the service was very attentive and the server was extremely articulate, knowledgable and quite  lovely, she simply could not overcompensate for the extraordinarily  MEDIOCRE tasting food.  The  ridiculously small serving of chard (side dish- $7.00) and its presentation was laughable (sadly) and the tuna bread salad combination with fava beans for  $14 was borderline unpalatable.   Fortunately, our pizza was edible.  Overall, as a first time patron to this restaurant, I will not recommend it or return.  Oh well! Their loss!
author: Michelle L.

description:
This was probably the one last place on Chestnut St that I haven't been to. Maybe it is because it is always packed with seemingly pretentious people crowding the front bar. 
The other night, I finally made the visit as my date picked the place. 
I arrived a bit early, and was greeted by the gracious maitre de Diana. She was able to seat me right away. 

I love fennel and was glad to see several dishes on the menu with fennel. We of course had the pizza as well. 

Unfortunately, our waitress had a bit of an attitude..but it could have been that we parked our table way too long :-(

I have learned not to judge the book by it's cover and look forward to checking it out again.
author: Mimi T.

description: Wow, wow, wow, wow, wow - - - - there i got more wows in. We had a variety of appies and pizzas. We splurged on wine and let the owner pick two bottles for us. winner. winner. wonderful staff! dont pass up the deserts either. have fun! We'll be back!
author: C T.

description:
San Francisco dining at it's best.

Take a stroll down Chestnut and settle into A16, you're going to find the rabbit hole that Alice wish she had fallen into.

This enchanting restaurant comes across as small, but opens up beautifully in the back revealing a refined space with dark tones that ease you into your seat.

Upon arrival, you are tangled in the aroma drifting from the rustic pizza oven and the chatter that only soothing wines draws out of us.

The menu highlights fresh pasta, Neapolitan pizza and house cured meats. Your eyes will water from happiness.

My buddy and I decided to split the: 

Salsiccia Pizza - fennel sausage, roasted spring onions, mozzarella, grana, garlic, chiles, olive oil

Squid ink tonnarelli with Manila clams, capers, white wine and garlic

We started with the roasted calamari that had a strong balance of texture with a crunchy drizzle of crumbs that enveloped the softness of the calamari. Placed upon sea greens, the dish led us into the pizza wonderfully.

The sausage had a kick. Spicy and illuminating heat, it was a decadent bite when paired with the soft dough it lived on. The garlic, mozzarella and roasted spring onions atop the pizza  perfected the pie. Pizza was born to speak like this.

The squid ink tonnarelli was the true highlight of the evening. Coated in a white wine and garlic reduction, with sliced capers, the flavor profile was distinguished and sharp. A strong portion of manila clams played with the dish, and offered a visually stunning piece.

That was a food line up that could rival the best in SF.

***
For dessert, house made gelato and the carrot cake with pinenut gelato and candied fennel adorned our table.

The cinnamon crunch gelato was superb. Sweet and intoxicating while the warm carrot cake brought back a highlight reel of being a kid again. Needless to say, we ended the meal having worn down our forks.

***
A16 is an incredible show of the craft of cooking. This was how food was meant to be constructed. Meticulous, colorful and inviting. 

Job well done.
author: Mike K.

description: Who in their right mind would not rate this a 5 star. The best buratta and octopus salad I have ever had, and I'm a restaurant gm. The pizza was perfect and lacked nothing.  The excellent waitress (Monica) gave us great suggestions and even sent us out a third dessert. Got to try the pavlova though. Great wine, great service, great food.
author: Brian R.

description:
A16 is about the wine. The wine menu rivals any other restaurant in NorCal -- and that's just a fact. The food compliments the wine well. I'm a personal fan of their all meat sampler. 

A16 is notorious in the Marina for being the spot to take your beautiful wife/girlfriend. If your date is merely mediocre looking, I wouldn't recommend A16. The dude next to you will seriously put you to shame with his impressive arm candy.
author: Forrest S.

description:
The wine list alone is worth the trip.  Our sommelier made an excellent recommendation for an Italian sangrantino from Montefalco.  She was also just really great at what she did--she insisted on decanting the wine, and spent a lot of time discussing the wine.  

The mozzarella burrata was outstanding, and we just loved the pizza.  

It's a little crowded and noisy, but who cares?  It's worth it!
author: Dave L.

description:
Over the top satisfied by this place!!  Make resos though because the place was slammed.  Every table full.  It's a small, intimate venue and we sat at the back at the chef's counter.  Even though we weren't at a table, I enjoyed the experience.  The burrata cheese app was somehow to die for..perfect amount of salt and olive oil drizzled over the top with yummy crostini.  Prosciutto was great quality..salsiccia pizza was exquisite and the porcini rubbed steak (even though I am not a huge mushroom fan) was to die for.  All in all delicious, fabulous food, good service considering how packed it was and not badly priced.  About $160-ish for 3 people.  Didn't care for the dessert menu though..a little too much on the fancy side for me.

Yum!
author: Rissa R.

description: Love this place. A little bigger than its SPQR counterpart and can get a little noisy, but all I mainly care about is food and service and I can't complain on any of these points! Clean, simple dishes with basic and minimal ingredients but with lots of flavour.
author: E B.

description: Went with a date for lunch and was given a larger table for four which is always a nice surprise. However, the repast was somewhat uneven and unpredictable and it was VERY loud. The RN74 in Seattle is a far better venue and the food much improved over this original location.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Food = average, perhaps not great for the prices, we expected more quality!
Service = okay, attentive enough
Drinks = okay, nice wine list, full bar, etc
Ambience, well-lit, but good for romantic dates, etc.
Kitchen is wide open, which is a rarity

Overall..it was okay for an Italian place, but it seemed to be too superficial...maybe it's the neighborhood....

Not sure it's worth a second trip.
author: Fannie S.

description:
We had a great experience here.  The owner checked on several times as we breezed through courses of mozzarella, salumi, pizza and braised short ribs.  The mozzarella and short ribs great, but not as great as the dessert- "Chocolate budino tart with sea salt and olive oil"!  

Great wine list!

I like the feeling I get from the cozy interior and personal service.  thumbs up!
author: jennifer j.

description:
The hostess had the most awesome hair ever (feathers intertwined), and she was gorgeous. I'm jealous, not gonna lie. 

I came here w/ a friend to use my BBE coupon. Lunch was a GREAT deal with that coupon. I think we both walked out paying about $20-25 each for 2 appetizers? small plates?, 1 pizza, and 1 shared dessert. Ok possibly, 30, I really don't remember for sure, but it wasn't more than 30. I don't think I could afford to eat here without the coupon though. 

They were super chill about us being late for our reservation b/c Marina/Cow's Hollow is ridiculous to get to by public transportation, though the restaurant wasn't packed in any way. 

I honestly liked their pizza cold better than I liked it warm. We got the mushroom pizza. No I'm not going to look up and use the accurate name. Tired yo. We got meatballs and er. the salumi platter. Salumi platter was quite tasty. We had to ask for bread. I don't know if that's standard. Used the tasty bread to wipe up the tasty meatball sauce. 

Dessert was like a crazy smore, hazelnut tiramisu. It was tasty. 

I was amused to see a copy of Washoku, a Japanese home cooking cookbook in the kitchen. 

Design, decor of the restaurant is great. I've had better service but I also look like an unemployed college student, not that that's really an excuse for poor service. Did I mention that the hostess if gorgeous?
author: Andrea L.

description:
Every time I walked by and saw that this place is still busy after all these years I thought that I should try it again. I ate there years ago and was dramatically underwhelmed. 

A girlfriend suggested it for dinner last week and I was happy to give this place another chance but I continue to not understand why people love it so much. The waiter was rude and the food was mediocre (except the arugula salad which was delicious.)
author: Deb J.

description:
It's always easy to find a hyped restaurant with prices to match.  It's seldom possible to find one with delicious, high-quality menu items that justify the prices.  A 16 was worth every dollar, dime, and cent!  For two of us, with two glasses of wine, two starters, one pasta, one main, and two desserts it rounded up to $150 including tax + 20% tip.  

First, it's an Italian restaurant but it does not bore you with stereotypical foods everyone expects to find at an Italian restaurant.  There were so many things I had never heard of but with flavors and ingredients I love.

The staff listened to our tastes in wine and suggested two we'd never heard of, both of which BLEW US AWAY!  I wish I remembered their names.  But the important thing is A 16 is a restaurant you can trust the staff to read your tastes and make recommendations for you.

The food was great.  The starter of Burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini almost made me pass out it was so rich and scrumptious. I was surprised that I enjoyed the domestic Iowa Berkshire Prosciutto more than the di Parma.  Chestnut cavatelli with ragu bianco, chanterelles, dandelion greens and pecorino was an AMAZING winter pasta dish.  Each bite of the roasted half chicken from the thigh to the breast to the leg to the wing MELTED in our mouths.  Then, the desserts were such a surprise.  Panna cota with a jelly-like rosewater layer, roasted pistachios, and pomegranate!!!  Chocolate tart with bundino (saying its like a pudding doesn't do it justice) with the darkest, deepest flavor with sea salt.  It was an amazing experience.

It's a narrow, long restaurant.  The wall seats can be low, with straight up backs that I find a bit uncomfortable to sit in.  BUT, the chef's bar was great--especially if you can get on the corner like we did.  It gives great views of the entire restaurant and the kitchen.

Please try it out.
author: Kaku A.

description: This place is great; strange hours of operation but memorable tasty dishes and a pleasant European atmosphere. I love the way they make their squash/zucchini side dish :)
author: V L.

description: I have ordered the maccaronara 8 out of the 10 times I've gone here and the 2 times I didn't, I regretted it. They serve it with a THICK pasta so although the portion may look small, it's filling (get the large, not the small, the small is a joke). The sauce is a simple tomato sauce with the most incredible flavor, cooked with pork but then taken out at the end and shaved ricotta salata. It's all you need here! I can't speak on many of the other dishes, pizzas are pretty good, swordfish was good, not amazing, didn't care for the squid ink pasta. Just get the maccaronara!
author: Carly K.

description:
Impressive!

If i had to pick one word to sum up my experience here - that would have to be it!

The food was amazing... i don't think we could've made a wrong choice... and the wine list is sooooo extensive! Now usually I'd be pretty intimidated by a wine list like this, but the staff and sommeliers were so helpful in helping us choose a wine for our meal! They even let us do some tasters before deciding on purchasing a bottle! ...just to make sure we were happy! 

We sat along the bar that surround the wood burning ovens and the creative chefs! It was a phenomenal experience... I will be back.
author: Anita K.

description:
I love going here and sitting at a bar.  Its like watching top chef live, and usually no wait on weekdays. Great ambiance, good pasta and amazing mozzarella. I loved their squid ink pasta with uni. They can actually stay away from bread crumb to make it less heavy and more about ingredients. Pizza is better at Delarosa one block east. 

So is this the best italian food? i don't think so. but with great ambiance and bonus points for being in the best neighborhood in the SF.
author: Mika G.

description: My favorite is the mushroom (funghi) pizza.  They used to serve it with arugula on top but now you have to ask for it and they charge extra for it.  I still need the arugula on top though.  I also sprinkle their house-made hot chili infused oil which is uniquely tasty.  I pair my pizza with Terredora di Paolo Lacryma Christi del Vesuvio or Luigi Giusti Rubbjano.  This is my favorite meal.  ;D
author: Theresa L.

description: Such great food- will not disappoint. We loved our very knowledgeable waitress and sommelier was outstanding. Our wait for our table was a little long even with a reservation but the restaurant manager brought a complimentary appetizer over right away. The pizza was delicious and the salads were great.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Great dining experience, from the beginning, when we found the restaurant in the middle of a busy block of Chestnut Street.  It was lit up, in the holiday spirit, and looked like a tiny gem surrounded by bigger and bolder shops&eateries.  However, when we walked in, we discovered that A16 was much bigger than advertised.  In fact, it was the longest and narrowest restaurant we'd ever been in.  It just keeps going and going and going.  And it's got a magical draw to it.  The deeper you get inside, the more it grows on you.  Great ambience and energy.  It feels like the place to be, and for us, it really was.

Sara was our server, and she could not have been more professional, helpful and pleasant.  We asked about the starters, the pizzas, the pastas and the wines.  We told her we had to be out by 7:30 because we had tickets for the Smuin Ballet.  And she took care of everything from there.

We started with the burrata, that silky sweet cheese made from mozzarella and cream.  Could not have been more pleasing.  And then the crispy pork belly.  Also excellent.  We shared the Bianca pizza, with fennel sausage.  Fabulous thin crust, more mozzarella, along with padano--the semi-aged Italian hard cheese.

I was only slightly disappointed with my entree, which was the maccaronara napoletana.  The pasta was cooked perfectly, al dente.  And the sauce was hearty and flavorful.  The only thing missing was meat.  Chunks of meat.  But whatever meat there was originally was fully absorbed into the sauce.  A very minor complaint.  

I'd go back to A16 in a heartbeat.  In fact, I will.  For lunch, next week.
author: Ruben G.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco! I always order the fish and it is phenomenal! My boyfriend gets the pasta which is homemade and it is delicious. If you are in town definitely try it out!
author: Kaila L.

description:
I can honestly say that I've never been to this part of The City before.  Amazing what they can fit into a neat 7x7 square.

Anyway, among all of the places that were recommended, this one is probably my least favorite.  This isn't to say that it was especially bad, but it seemed quite unremarkable.  I definitely can see how this can become a neighborhood favorite if you happen to live near here, but for people in other neighborhoods (or nearby suburbs, like us), probably not.

If you do head here, remember to ask for bread.  It's free, but you have to ask).
author: Jason T.

description:
Here's a brief summary of our dinner here:

8:00 
Arrive, squirm my way to the hostess to put my name on the "half-hour" wait list.

9:00
Finally get seated in the back.  It's very posh, everyone is very quaft and the pizza oven is firing constantly.  We are in a good mood, happy to finally have seats.  We decline drinks, but order 2 pizzas and a lamb ravioli appetizer, which is delicious. But it's also $10 for 5 normal sized ravioli in a ridiculously large bowl.  Do you want to emphasize how little food you're feeding me? 

10:00
Wow.  Where the hell are our pizzas? That couple next to us has come, eaten, paid, and left.  We have completely vandalized our paper tablecloth with drawings of food that we shall never have.

10:30
Pizza and apologies arrive. Pizza crust is great - comparable to Pizzaria Delfina's, but the flavors are... subdued.  Just like the service.  

11:00 
Get the hell out of the Marina.

I gave em the tough customer act, which I NEVER use.  I was a waitress once, I know it sucks.  But honestly.  We'd been sitting there staring at them for 20 minutes and no one even filled our water glasses.  They offered free dessert, which I thought was actually better than the pizzas. I add a star to what would have been a very unhappy review.

I can't tell if I was actually underwhelmed by the pizzas or it was just the aftertaste of being hangry for over an hour and a half. I'd say they do a pretty decent job on the food, but I doubt I'll be going back.
author: Mari C.

description: Wow what a great menu food and wine list. ...ok yes staff were great too.!!Especially Shelly who treated us like royalty
author: Kerry K.

description: Such a cute restaurant in the Marina! The fam and I had such a great dinner tonight. Our server was lovely, the wine was divine, and the food was splendid. The clams sautéed in a tomato sauce and burrata were our favorite apps. The truffle pizza was good, but nothing phenomenal. The Lucky Dog short ribs were a delicious entree. Lastly, the wet cheesecake stole the show at the end of our feast (an excellent recommendation by our waitress). Overall, a wonderful dining experience and a solid kickoff to my holiday. Thanks A16! :)
author: Monique G.

description:
High expectations can lead to dissatisfaction.

A friend of mine and I were looking for a place to have dinner.. She was buying, so I should've just been a good sport and agreed to that Cheesecake Factory she likes so much in Union Square with a gorgeous view of the square. However, my inner voice that chants "NO FRANCHISES" with a fervor won the battle that night at some point during my monologue re: the willingness to try new things and often, as a result, finding hidden gems. Since I was craving for gnocchi (those who know me hear this a lot from me), we worked down the list for an Italian bib gourmand willing to seat us at 9pm that had gnocchi on their menu..

Maybe that was my first mistake. Not everyone makes good gnocchi. I would know. We decided on A16, which fit both important categories - a Bib Gourmand AND (at the time) a decently rated Yelp stop. 

The place was completely packed (on a weeknight) and yet they managed to find us a spot (although getting to our seats required quite the effort).. I was so impressed by the crowd that my expectations were heightened. 

We had:
* CALAMARI - 4/5 - I thought that the way they prepared the calamari was interesting.. it wasn't breaded, and it tasted very fresh and had an interestingly delicious combination of spices/seasoning.
* GNOCCHI - 2/5 - Slightly tough (even elastic) and salty. Much as I LOVE gnocchi, I just couldn't eat it.
* LAMB RAVIOLI - 3.5/5 - This was what my friend ordered - a good dish that we ended up sharing because of my terrible gnocchi.
* CHOCOLATE TART w/SEA SALT - 3.5/5 - Decent to good, but not memorable.

We also had a bottle of Pinot Grigio and, initially, a Lambrusco to drink with dessert at the end of the meal... I will add that the service was so great and our server was SO wonderful and attentive that when he saw our expressions, he replaced the Lambrusco with a bottle of Moscato d'Asti, my classic choice of dessert wine (grape juice, really).

With the Michelin Bib Gourmand status, I could've just gone at a bad time and ordered the wrong dishes - or maybe what granted them the status to begin with was Nate Appleman, who I just found out has moved to New York to open Pulino's. We may decide to go back to A16 and give it another shot after we've worked down the list of other Michelin starred and Bib Gourmand restaurants we've wanted to visit..................... but by then, without Nate Appleman, they probably would have altogether lost their MBG status.
author: Asha S.

description:
My boyfriend and I trekked over here via BART and Muni bus all the way from the East Bay and it was well worth the haul! 

The atmosphere: We had 9:30 reservations, and they were pretty good about seating us within 5 minutes of our reservation. They gave us a great table meant to seat four, which was nicely tucked away out of the way of the busy hustle & bustle. It was a very busy night - the Saturday before Valentine's Day, though the hostess told us they're usually that busy every weekend. We didn't feel rushed or pressured to order at all, despite the large crowd. The atmosphere is great - it was a pretty cold night so I appreciate the warmth, both temperature wise and vibe wise inside of A16. 

The food: We ordered the clams as an appetizer, which were in a really outstanding sauce and served with a large piece of toasted bread for dipping. We didn't realize when we ordered though that the type of clams were very small, so we ended up with this huge plate of tiny clams. They were good, but sort of an overwhelming portion size that took a lot of effort to eat. I would've preferred a smaller amount of larger clams, but that's our fault for not knowing what type of clams they were on the menu. 

My boyfriend ordered the gnocchi pasta dish and it was melt in your mouth good. I ordered the short rib with polenta on the side. The short rib itself was very tender, and the wine sauce was delicious. However the polenta that was served on the side was served way too hot and not that interesting. The biggest "complaint" I have about this place is that the meals are very one-dimensional. It seems like pizza is their specialty, being a northern Italian restaurant, so when I go back (because we will be back) I'll likely try a pizza. 

Finally, we were able to eat here for about $60 total, including an appetizer and two entrees. We had drinks elsewhere before, and needed to watch the time so we could catch the BART back to the East bay so skipped dessert and coffee, so that cut down on costs. We've both had some terrible meals for $60, so considering how great this place was I think that was a bargain. 

Overall we both had a wonderful experience - , this is a cute neighborhood to be in, decent amount night life and good restaurants and a young-ish (somewhat yuppie to older at times) crowd. The vibe at the restaurant seemed older at first when we were waiting for our table near the bar, but once we were seated in the back where the tables were the crowd was pretty mixed. 

Definitely worth a try, great with a date, though there was a table of "bros" dining together so good for a group of guy/girl friends, too!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
We're here for pizza, nothing else. OK, perhaps a glass of vino too. This place was jumping... I mean packed! I made a reservation a month in advance for a dinner table. 
The pizza was good, not great. It was a bit too artsy for me. The pancetta was basically cubed pork fat, not Italian bacon, there's a difference. It made for a strange topping. Homemade ingredients are on all the pizzas. Sausage, cheese, house cured soppressata, all very good. I would give it another shot if nearby.
Not my favorite place, but far better that the pizza most of us Americans eat every week and think is good. 6/10
author: Matt T.

description:
Before I came to A16, I had no idea what burrata was, nor maccaronara.  
Now, I know that they are DELICIOUS!!
Burrata - creamy yummy mozzarella goodness.
Maccaronara - chewy yummy pasta goodness.

Go to A16, order these two dishes, and you'll leave a very satisfied customer.
author: Cindy W.

description:
So I've been here 5 or 6 times but decided not to write a review until after my experience this past Saturday night. All of my past experiences have been great, but this one topped them all. 

I was here with a party of four and everyone loved their food. The appetizers we ordered were the Burrata with olive oil, Trippa napoletana, and Grilled sardines. For the past 26 years I have hated sardines but because my mom tried the tripe for me, I tried out the sardines and they were amazing. They did not have that overly salty taste that sardines usually have and I could have eaten a whole plate of them. The 2 pasta dishes (one being the squid ink and sea urchin), the rabbit, and the sole were all prepared to perfection. 

We had reservations at 5pm (when they open on Saturdays) since that was the only time available when I booked that week of and the restaurant was packed. The vibe is a lot of fun and the open kitchen adds to the experience since one can see the food being prepared and watch the hot plates walk by. Overall I am a big fan of this restaurant and have never been disappointed.
author: Fabrizio R.

description:
3 towards 3.5 stars, but not quite 4 stars.

This place is pretty pricey for what it is. 

Wine: House white wine, pinot grigio
Appetizers: Burrata and Fresh Proscuitto
Entrees: Quattro Formaggi Pizza, Maccaronara pasta
Dessert: Gelato

Let's start with the apps. Well, proscuitto is, proscuitto. You can't really screw it up. It  tasted fresh, and it was on the drier side which I didn't mind at all. Didn't leave grease stains which is a plus! The burrata was pretty delectable, although I would like my cheeses to be a bit more saltier, but it was melt in your mouth goodness. 

Entree wise, the pizza was a little bit too soggy for my liking. I mean, when I picked it up, the thing fell apart. The dough was freshly made and it tasted better than the Pizza Hut, that's for sure! It was just a-ok. For the Maccaronara pasta, you could tell that it was handmade. It was perfectly cooked (al dente!) but for some reason (and my friend agreed with me on this) those noodles reminded me too much of udon noodles. I felt like I should be eating it with fishballs in a hot soup. So, yes, the pasta was well made, but it was in a basic red sauce which was too simple and plain for me to go "wow! That was amazing!"

For dessert, we all just had two scoops of gelato: pistachio and almond. Both were good and creamy, but of course, it's not the same as the gelato in Italy, but I won't knock it. It was delicious and i would eat the whole quart like the fatty that I am if presented with it.

The service was very slow and I hate having to wait for the bill to arrive when you're ready to bolt outta there. But for a Monday night, it was very busy and our waitress looked like she had to cover a large area. Maybe next time it'll improve. 

The 3 of us split everything...tax and  tip = $44/person
author: Victoria B.

description: A16 was up to its usual tricks this past weekend, i.e., it was jam-packed and loud.  But per usual, everything was worth it:  the pizza was incredible, the wine could not have been better (and was reasonably priced), and the pasta (a lamb ragu) was incredible.  A16 is always a great experience, and has only gotten better with age.
author: Ty D.

description:
Living so close to delfina, it's been awhile since I've been here.  Last week was the first time I've since Nate abandoned SF.  
 
The meatballs were over seasoned, way too much salt.  The pasta was okay not great. Where I was truely disappointed was in the pizza.

The crust used to be near perfect, slightly crunchy exterior with a soft smooth chewy interior.  No more.  It no longer soft or smooth.  Requiring more chewing effort.  

I use to place it slightly ahead of Delfina, but no longer.
Delfina now #1 in SF.
author: David L.

description:
Cute restaurant that is - Overrated and overpriced. Not impressed :-( 

I wanted to try A16 because it is always packed, so I thought it must be pretty good, but I was disappointed. We ordered the calamari for appetizer and I thought it was pretty good - maybe it was the best thing we got but it was a small portion. I also had the Carciofi (artichoke) pizza and the Orecchiette. The pizza was good, not great and the pasta was mediocre and didn't really have much taste to it - it was also a pretty small portion considering we ordered the "large" size. I feel like the menu is fancily worded & high priced and then when the food comes out it doesn't compare. 

The service was not great - basically inattentive, it was a Friday night so it was busy but I think they should be used to that. We had to ask for bread and water refills ourselves. 

OH and throw in the minor food poisoning that my boyfriend got (!!) and I would've rather been eating at someplace like the macaroni grill...seriously.
author: Selena G.

description:
I couldn't decide between 4 and 5 stars, but decided to go with 5.... i've been to this place hundred times now since i live in the hood and its always a fun place to go.... 

The reason i was thinking to give them 4 stars is because some things on their menu are not that great... For example, the pork chop has so much fat in it, that the actual meat on it is like 15% of the plate... Not worth the price they charge for it...  Some other items i thought were pretty average as well.... 

However, those are just few on their menu... Everything else i had is sooooo good and delicious!  Their pasta and pizzas are to die for!  And burrata is just out of this world!

So overall, its a great restaurant that has some ok things on their menu in addition to  some incredible ones!

I will keep going to this place when i want some delicious italian and don't feel like going to the north beach.  They also have a fun atmosphere and a lively bar to wait for your table.  If you dont have a resi you can wait as a walk-in anywhere from 60 min. to 15 min.
author: Anna S.

description:
A16 certainly met my expectations and surpassed some of them. Starters included the burrata and prosciutto plates. The burrata was exquisite as was the prosciutto, the latter featuring a prosciutto di Parma and a US homegrown variety from Iowa. The Iowan took the blue ribbon, though both were excellent. 

We split the macaronnara for the pre-main course and the house-made pasta was second to none to say the least. It was perfectly cooked and the sauce was magnificent in all aspects.

Entrees included the gnocchi, the pork, and the rabbit they featured as a special. All three amply satisfied, though the gnocchi particularly stood out. Their consistency was that of soft little potato pillows, light and not overly-filling. 

For dessert we had the lemon panna cota, the chocolate budino, and both flavors of gelato. Out of those three the gelatos stole the show. The featured flavors were burnt caramel and pistachio with the former being my favorite. My only complaint with regards to the food was that the budino was over-salted. Salt can do amazing things for a dessert, but you've definitely got to keep it in check. 

Our server (I wish I could remember her name to give her proper credit) was knowledgable, unobtrusive, and overall more than competent. Her wine suggestions helped to round this dining experience out to be near perfect.
author: Lucas S.

description:
I ate about it...

Don't you dare leave SF without tasting the Burrata- the bar is the perfect start to a great evening with a glass of wine, or if the sun is out and you are lucky enough to snag a seat in exclusive back patio, then you are lucky enough.  You'll crave this place time and time again.
author: Kristina I.

description: Second time to eat here and the food was as good as I remember. However our server was absent the majority of the time. Nowhere to be seen. Party of 3, early reservations, (a good idea for busy Friday night!) but still were neglected.
author: Annie M.

description:
Maybe it was because I hadn't had an adult meal in over a month. Maybe it was because the restaurant was bustling, and I do mean bustling, on a Monday night. Maybe it was the wine, or perhaps the appetizers, but something about this place really resonated with me. I haven't dined in the city much in the last six months due to the little one and I may have never found this place but I'm glad I did. 

Great dinner at the counter with a fabulous girlfriend, the head chef is a friend of hers so yes, we were treated very well. The food was fantastic and the wine perfectly chilled. Oh, and the chocolate torte with olive oil and sea salt was TO DIE for. I'm a big dessert person and this was pure bliss. 

I don't know if I'll be back for sometime, this is NOT a kid friendly place, only because I'm guessing it's packed with PYTs all the time, not a bad thing, especially when all you need is an escape, even for a few hours. 

Yes, yes, yes!!! Do try please!!!
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
Totally not the pomp and circumstance I had built my preconceived notions for!

Make a reservation, elbow your way through hangry (that's hungry + angry FYI) crowd at the front, and chill in the low key kitchen/dining room in the back.  

Of course we opted for a portion of the macaronara con whatever is on that eat before you die- pretty much glorified spaghetti and sauce in my opinion, but that's ok! the pizza salsiccia was phenomenal, and let's talk about the chocolate budino tart for a moment.

OMFG.

I may or may not have used that teenaged, overused acronym upon first taste of this heavenly bliss (did i mention i typically HATE chocolate?) 

Something about the combo of moussed chocolate, crunch chocolate sable crust drizzled in olive oil and coarse sea salt will drive your tastebuds to nirvana.

We found the wine list to be very reasonable considering 1) SF 2) A 16 is one of the most widely recognized SF restaurants 3)Italian wines are typically not that low priced...

I'm so glad we finally opted to try this trend magnet- I'm already a full recruiting other member convert.
author: Gabrielle J.

description:
I came here to celebrate my birthday in October, was greeted by the hostess, only had to wait a couple minutes, was seated at a nice two top table, the server greeted us promptly and was very very nice, the funghi pizza is to die for!! It is so delicious and my friend and I could not get enough of it (also I thought it was pretty cool that we got to cut our own pizza with scissors ^.^) next my friend had some pasta with seafood that I tried and it was delicious! But I liked my dish better, I don't quite remember what it was called, but I do remember it was green pasta, and let me tell you it was so freaking good. Please let me know if anyone knows of the dish I am talking about! I must eat it again!! And lastly for dessert, I believe we had the pear sorbetto which came with a birthday candle, and although I was pretty full, my friend and I finished that pear sorbetto super quick. The light, sweet, tart flavors to that sorbetto were divine. Next time I'm in San Francisco I will surely stop by again.
****heads up: it can get pretty loud in the restaurant, it was difficult to hear my friend speak, but I liked the feel of it, the buzz of a restaurant (@9:30pm) just tells you how good they're doing!
author: Astrid C.

description: Their food is fantastic. However they are pricey and even though the waiters were very friendly, the service was little slow. Overall very cool spot though. It can be little loud depending on where you are sitting, in case you'd like to have a private or a deep conversation:)
author: Onnik Y.

description: Buzzing is the word and the food was stellar. Went here for late dinner. Was seated within 7-10 minutes of reservation. People who did not have reservations had a 45- to a 1 hour wait. Ordered some bread for table. Wonderful Sour Dough with Olive oil and the side. Split two salads between the four of us the Panzanella and Arugula salad, Delicious, Ordered two pizza's, the Salsiccia and Treviso. De vine, Finished up with the Pork Chop. Filling and Tender. Tried the home made cookies, Apple Bread Pudding and Chocolate Tart. Outstanding with Coffee and Espresso. Service was exceptional. Will go back.
author: J G.

description:
So apparently the one of the chefs here got the James Beard award for up and coming chef...  Maybe it was his night off or maybe it's because I see A12 as an upscale pizza 'n pasta place.  I know, I know, gasp.

I appreciate the thin crust and sauce of their pizza and their pasta was a little too al dente for me.  

The service was great.  She was very knowledgeable about the wine and food they had.  Sadly not common but should be the norm.

I do like that they can accommodate larger groups if you make reservations but overall, I don't get what the wait is for.  Sorry.
author: Gina K.

description:
This was our second dining experience at A16.  We started with the heirloom salad special which was very fresh.  For entrees we had the meatballs and halibut - both were excellent, incredibly flavorful, cooked perfectly and well presented.

Our server was friendly and made excellent wine pairing recommendations.

Great atmosphere, service and food.  Always consistent.  Highly recommend.
author: Amy B.

description: A16 has obviously been Yelped a bizillion times, so what is there to add? The Pizza and burrata are the obvious "go to's", but I've never been impressed by the other plates. Five years ago they were one of the best pizza spots in the bay, but now that the pizza craze has caught on there's many other newcomers to the scene who also put out some great pies. Parking in the Marina is always a pain too, so why the 4 stars? It's solid pizza and the wine list doesn't suck.
author: Mitchell M.

description:
Prologue: this place was recommended to me by an Italian (Napolitan) guy who has a cafè in North Beach. He was a pizzaiolo himself back in Naples and he told me that his favourite pizza in the city was A16's.  Doesn't it sound like a reliable advice? 

Tonight, after the theatre, I have dragged two Italian friends to this restaurant and guess what? we all ordered pizza. Not only, in fact. I also shared an appetizer, namely grilled calamari with lemongrass and spicy peppers, that we all found divine!  But let's go back to the pizza... After my pizza margherita with Parma ham (exactly like in Delfina last week)  I'm sorry to say that ... I'm so confused! Starting from today, I officially cannot distinguish any longer which is my favourite margherita pizza in SF: Tony's, Delfina or A16? A16's and Delfina's are very very similar, but there is some grated parmigiano on A16's, a typical Napolitan final touch (not so commonly used elsewhere, even in Italy) which contributes to enrich the already excellent taste. Really hard to pick one anyway ... fortunately I don't have to :-)

The desserts are also seriously worth to be mentioned: my bunet pudding with cinnamon and cocoa, topped with freshly made whipped cream and accompanied by delicious liquor soaked cherries was a glorious way of ending the meal!  The best dessert I have got since my dinner at La Ciccia. The rhubarb cake with green almond ice-cream chosen by my fellow diners was also memorable.

Adding a good refreshing Hoogarden beer, you get a reasonable 38$ (without tip) in total and everything was nothing less than excellent, including the service.  I'm truly sorry that a place capable of delivering such a great food has an average of only 3.5 stars ... Lack of flavour? here? Based on what I could sample this (first) time, sorry, but I can hardly believe it.
author: Andrea L.

description:
This place has a following and with good reason. The food is phenomenal and the crowd is buzzing. The downside is there really is no place to wait. We had reservations and even with those we had to wait ~40 minutes. 

But if the stars were just for the quality of food it would be 5 stars without a doubt. Outstanding pizzas and pastas. Their extensive wine menu is pretty impressive as well.

For me this is more a spot to go on special occasions but if you can afford it on the regular its a real treat. Either way give it a go!
author: Nelson C.

description: Burratta and pizza are a must! One of my favorite Italian food spots in SF.
author: Ryan L.

description:
I rarely head to the Marina but I had family visiting in town and they picked this spot and I'm glad I ventured over there. This restaurant looks deceivingly small and is larger than you'd expect but they do pack the tables close together. We were fortune enough to sit in the covered atrium in the back. It was well lit and warm and was sprinkled with beautiful orchids that created a summer ambiance (even though it was freezing out on the street!)

The pizzas were great, the cavatalli pasta was delicious and the almond cake dessert was amazing. Would definitely go back!

Leave the kids at home for this place. The table behind us had a litter of brats and one of them broke a glass and cut his hand. Little bastard, this isn't burger king use your manners!
author: Tyler J.

description:
The food was below average.  The service was almost as bad.  I ordered the fish and mussels with red broth dish. My date actually asked if I wanted some of her food when she saw how small it was. It was $24 and had about 5 pieces of overcooked white cod and other fish.  The broth had no taste.  There were about 6 mussels.  The appetizer was mediocre and small.  We had bruschetta and there was one piece of bread. When I asked about wine, the hostess kept turning me to the page of wines at $85 a bottle and higher even though I just wanted a simple pinot.  It must be a great location because the prices here do not justify the food at all.  Go to Nob Hill Cafe for much better food and prices.

By the way, i have eaten here several times and it has never been a 5 star place.
author: Z A.

description:
I don't find myself in the marina very often, but I took my chance (and time) heading over there for my love of pizza. 

As usual, the wait was long. I didn't expect much since it was a Saturday night, but at least they will call you on your cell when your table is ready. I think I waited over an hour. 

I hear the other food at the restaurant is tasty and some of the appetizers are hit and miss. I mainly just needed to try the pizza. Service was more or less fast though it was strangely difficult to get some of their complementary bread.

The margherita pizza looked A+, but it lacked flavor. This seriously was some of the most flavorless pizza I've ever eaten. Not really sure why because it definitely looked top notch and claimed to use high end ingredients. I won't be going back since it's just too damn far away from where I live. Flour and Water still is my favorite restaurant in town for pizza like this.
author: rob k.

description: We stumbled upon this place from a friend's recommendation. We were able to be seated around 5p with a group of 6 girl after we ran the marathon Sunday. The wine list was extensive and very eclectic. I had the special which was clams. They were perfectly seasoned and had a spicy kick to them. The other girls had the soup and it was delicious. I would recommend this place and would like to come back to try the pizza.
author: Irissa N.

description: Food is good. A bit high but that's to be expected in San Francisco. Pizza was a bit too much crust for me, say 50%. I bit too trendy atmosphere for me. People are nice and food is good. It's a fine place, just not my thing.
author: R M.

description:
One of those SF eateries that's been on my list for days.
Meaning to go, meaning to go, meaning to go.
Make a res many weeks ahead.
Excited to go, excited to go, excited to go.

At last,
I Go!
And...

eehh...

Apparently, according to A16 lovers who I've given said mediocre review to, I 'should have ordered the pizza', but I persist that I ordered (mainly) based off of yelp reviews. I don't feel like had I of ordered the pizza I'd be giving this place 4+ stars. Oh, waitress-distant/distracted too. All my love to yelp/yelpers but the burrata- pretty flavorless and the chocolate dessert, I mean they didn't screw up this blase' chocolate desert, just not noteworthy.  

In closing, unfortuneatly, not on my 'must hit again' list' though wouldn't say I disliked it necessarily...just didn't live up to the hype...
author: Ash E.

description:
I understand why this might be worthy of a three star review. It's tough to get in without planning ahead and service isn't the best in the world. However, it happens to be one of my go-to restaurants when guests come in town. It seems to capture the essence of my neighborhood (this may or may not be seen as a positive aspect for the anti-Marina crowd) and you really can't beat a pizza and a glass of wine, perhaps my favorite culinary combination.

Coming from NYC, I had been spoiled with some really fantastic pizza places (dreaming of Keste Pizza in West Village at the moment) and while I have not had a chance yet to try out the other notable San Francisco establishments (Pizzaria Delfina, Flour + Water, Tony's Pizza Napoletana) I am pretty satisfied with the quality pizza that is produced at A16. Being a purist when it comes pizza, I typically go for the Margarita which is a perfect ratio of cheese to sauce. It is also fun to get the "trust your pizzola" aka mystery pizza which turns out to be a good deal usually coming in at $15. I haven't had a bad one yet.

I have yet to try any entrees as I am stuck on the typical combination of splitting an appetizer (typically of the calamari variety - they change up the preparation methods frequently - but it is always delicious) and then splitting a pizza. This is perfect for 2 people - perhaps supplemented by a salad if you want a little extra.

If you are looking for a quiet, romantic, impressive dinner, I'm not sure this would be the place as the service could be spotty and you may end up at the pizza counter (this happened to me last time even though I had a reservation). As long as you have a bit of patience, and are not annoyed with a typical influx of people waiting around the bar and hostess area either to get a seat or just as their final destination - A16 is a great local pick. Prices aren't terrible and food quality is good. Wine list is great and they are typically helpful with the wine selection if you need some help deciding.

Just make sure to plan ahead and make some reservations - it won't guarantee you a seat right away but it will at least guarantee you a seat!
author: Katie S.

description: After hearing from family and friends about this place, I was expecting to be wowed. I wouldn't give it a 5 stars, but it was pretty good. I was with a  group of six and we got a good variety of dishes to share. The pizza was good, but not stellar. All the other dishes were excellently executed. The service was attentive.I kind of like how the restaurant has two very distinctly different looking dinning areas. It was nice use of the space. I was sort of expecting more from the menu than what we saw. This place gets a lot of buzz, but I would definitely drop by on my next trip to SF to be a good judge of the rest of their menu.
author: Josie V.

description: Been twice. Great food and ambiance. Waitress was attentive, and also a little stoney, which was pretty entertaining.
author: Brendan D.

description:
I had a very nice experience here.  We came on a Monday night, we got in right away with our reservation and the service was good.  As soon as we sat down, we were told that there was a change to the menu and the cod was to be replaced with swordfish.  Well, since swordfish is better than cod (what?...it is), I ordered that...and it was SO good!  The sauce that came on top was some sort of capery green goop and it was wonderful!  My date said his meatballs were good too.

The wine we ordered was great.  We ordered, "Walnut cake with crema fresca panna cotta and rosemary caramel" for dessert.  It was awesome.  I was very pleased with my experience and would definitely go back.
author: PrincessPeac H.

description:
Jenn C. and I dined here last week on our visit to SF. The place was bumpin' on a Sunday night but we sat in the back room where it is definitely quieter than the front. The room looked like an extension of the main restaurant so we had an issue with temperature as it was a little chilly. When they turned on the heat it got quite hot. 

We split the burrata, escarole salad which was a light take on the classic caesar salad, the cappriciosa of the day, two half sized portions of pasta - buccatini with walnut pesto & the infamous maccaronara - oh hell yes! and 2 desserts that were good to OK. Great meal. One complaint was the bread that came with the oh so creamy burrata was hard and dry. 

Ok, so the pizza was very good, but I have to say it's not the best I've had. Perhaps you can call me one of those NY pizza snobs who likes her pizzas done certain ways. The crust was perfectly charred underneath, had some chew but I found it kind of bland. The toppings that night were fresh and worked well. My favorites were definitely the pastas. Comfort food, the kind that makes you rub your belly and go "mmmmm". I wish they weren't so stingy with their portions. Their "half" portions are more like 4 small fork fulls. I'd give the food 3.5 stars but since the place is fun and lively and our overall experience was pleasant I'll bump it up to 4. 

Perhaps I'll give SF pizza another try next year with Delfina..
author: Lizz K.

description:
The BEST Restaurant - Hands Down

There is nothing more to say but this is one of the best restaurants in San Francisco.
I have eaten at. The food, atmosphere, and service are top notch.

Just go and you will find out why!
author: David Q.

description:
One of the worst experiences I have ever had at a restaurant!  Everything went well for the first half an hour, ordered some drinks, came on time, no issues.  About an hour after we finished drinks, we were still waiting for food.  It didn't strike us as a problem until people around us were all getting food even though they had sat down more than half an hour after us.  We flagged down the waiter and he said he would check on it.  It took another 20 minutes, and 2 different managers before we got any food.  On top of that, the waiter never returned until almost the end of the meal, and claimed that the food was late because he didn't put in the order until after we finished appetizers (impossible because that was almost 1.5 hours before the food came).

When the food finally came, it was very good except for one dish (only reason for the 2nd star).  That one dish was so bad, I can't believe they try to sell it.  The dish had 7 noodles, all under-cooked and overly salted, and they tried to sell it for $11, unbelievable.

On top of all that, the manager only took $30 off the bill, there is no way that makes up for the terrible experience I had there, would never go back under any circumstances!

In summary, good food, atrocious service, don't ever go there, it's overrated, expensive, and the portions are small.  Good pizza though (but there are other places with just as good of pizza for a lot less money if that's all you want).
author: Philip G.

description: Good and fun place.  Atmosphere is super nice.  Pizza was good, not great...should have been cooked longer for the crust to come to life.  Pasta was great!  Only complaint was that it all tasted the same, which is not a bad thing.  Fish was great too.  Solid restaurant and great atmosphere!
author: Jordan S.

description:
Great wine list. Pretty good service.
Love their pastas and pizza.
I've had a lotta farm eggs on pizzas, but when the yolk is sitting on a puddle of raw egg white...that runs down to the edge of the crust, that's gross!  I like my egg runny, not the white to be raw. But they remade it and it was better...
Short rib entree was so tender that you could eat it with a spoon!
Overall, I always enjoy the food here..and always too full to eat dessert. One day I'll learn to save room for dessert!
author: Melissa F.

description:
My friend practically flies up to visit me just so she can eat at A16. So every time she books her ticket, I immediately make a reservation for A16. 

We've been there 5+ times so I feel it's fair to write a review now. I'll be honest, I don't like everything we've ordered here. For example, the squid ink tonnarelli is not my thing (the taste, texture, and way it looks).

But there are so many things that I do enjoy here that it definitely deserves 5 stars. There are a few things that we ALWAYS order here - the house-cured salumi or prosciutto tasting, trippa napoletana, maccaronara with ragu napoletana, and the pizza margherita (depending on how many people we have). 

I don't tend to deviate from the well known dishes that we usually enjoy so it's always been a positive experience. Also, we never come without a reservation (which is usually made at least a month in advance). 

We only come to the Marina to eat at A16 and to get cupcakes at That Takes the Cake since parking is always a challenge. But then again, it usually is in the city.
author: Connie W.

description: Hands down, best Margherita pizza in San Francisco. I've been here about 5 times now and I can't help but get that pizza (among other things) every single time. Not only is the food always a hit, but the service is amazing. Attentive, quick, knowledgeable... whenever we ask for a wine suggestion we get tastings and they're spot on. And each time I've been here the place has been packed to the gills but we've never sat waiting for any attention, the bill, etc... I love this place.
author: Doogie D.

description:
Seems like there are a lot of A16 fans out there.  Went to the restaurant for dinner last night with a 10 PM reservation on a Tuesday night and it was packed.  Standing room only, full bar of people waiting for a table -packed.

Why you ask?  I'm not quite sure.  I found the restaurant good but not great.  Had a beat salad appetizer and black cod with pistachio main course.  Wine list was impressive with a particularly good, mid-priced American and Italian selection.

Atmosphere was very pleasant.  There's a back room that could be useful for anyone wanting to come as a group.

In summary, a nice place to have some good food with a great glass of California wine.
author: David A.

description: A16 just never disappoints! I've been coming here for years - date nights w/ the hubs, ladies nights, etc. Always good - always great service - fabulous wine - knowledgeable staff. I'm not much into writing Yelp reviews - but I felt after the millionth time dining here, I need to finally do it!
author: Jennifer M.

description: Excellent restaurant where you can choose two kind of portions, no long waiting, delicious cuisine with a French and Spanish and Italian twist.
author: Belgian D.

description:
Always crowded, yet not pretentious, A16 is the best of what SF dining has to offer.  A constantly changing, seasonal menu makes the most of fresh ingredients at their best.  Generally rustic in nature, A16 never disappoints even the most sophisticated of palates.

In addition, the waitstaff is amazingly knowledgeable (semi-unusual in the Marina) and can speak to the broad wine list in great detail.  

Sadly, the same cannot be said about the barstaff which are often far too overwhelmed by the large number of people crowded around the tiny entrance.  Word to the wise, always make a reservation, check in with the hostess when you arrive, and see if she can call your cell when your table is ready.  This will cut down on the crowded bar area while also not forcing you endure the painful experience of waiting for a drink at the bar.  Fortunately, there are a great number of local bars (see Mamacita's on Chesnut) where you can get a drink until your table is ready.
author: Adam M.

description: I went here a few nights ago and had the most AMAZING meal!!!! Everything was delicious, especially the bruschetta... the house made ricotta was sooooo yummy! The pizzas were even better and I really liked the restaurant's ambiance and how the kitchen is open. I'd say the bruschetta is a must and if you want to try something a little different, get the squid pasta- it has a unique flavor but I thought it was super good and definitely worth getting again!
author: Genevieve E.

description:
It's warm and inviting inside and the staff is very friendly and welcoming. Good pizza (excellent the next morning for breakfast) - the crust has a good chew and is just just blistered enough to be addicting. Love the burrata, although the bread that came with it was a little TOO dried out and crispy, like it was hard to bite into. The pastas also are available in half portions, which is great when theres only two of you and you want to try a pizza and two pastas - we had the bucatini with walnut pesto, which was nice and creamy and nutty, and the famed maccaronara with ricotta salata - the ragu was savory and rich and clung nicely to the homemade, perfectly chewy pasta.

We did the Cappriciosa, which is kind of like Dealer's Choice for pizza - basically you just trust the pizzaiolo to make your pizza and you can't make any specifications. Since I really have no food aversions I thought this was a fun idea and we ended up with a great pizza - smoked moz, regular mozz, grana padano, roasted garlic,  chiles, pancetta, and treviso. 

Speaking of, the chili oil is pretty spicy, so use sparingly!
author: Jenn C.

description:
How does this place only have an average of 3.5 stars?! This place is a gem! Been here two times now and intend to go back many many more.
A few tips before you go:
1) MAKE A RESERVATION. seriously. and make it at least 3 weeks in advance.
2) Get a pizza. Get the Salsiccia if you like meat. Get the Pomodoro otherwise.
3) If you like Riesling or Gewürztraminer (so in other words, if you are a female and drink only sweet white wine), try the Bonny Doon 'Ca' del Solo Vineyard' Muscat 2008. You will not be disappointed! If you are adverse to fruity white wines (the rest of the male population), the wine selection at A16 is superb. You will have plenty to choose from. 
4) The Ricotta gnocchi is fabulous. If you're not too hungry, this is the perfect option.
5) Meat lovers, get the roasted beef coulotte.

The place is romantic - bring a date. Wait staff is excellent. And I shouldn't forget to mention how close this place is to your favorite marina bars. You can slide on by Tipsy Pig whenever you're done.
author: Alisa A.

description:
We met some friends who were visiting from Canada at the restaurant. I did not check the Yelp reviews until less than an hour before we arrived. I noticed that there was quite a wide range of star ratings which always makes me suspicious. Unfortunately, my worst fears were realized.

We were pretty disappointed with just about everything. It didn't help that parents with small child sat right across from us who allowed their kid to pretty much trash the table and surrounding area with baby food and Cheerios. Since this is a neighborhood restaurant, it was pretty common to see small children around.

The food was honestly marginal at best. The pizza was uninspiring, lacking of any depth or character. We ordered the Mozzarella Burrata and while better than the pizza, I have had much better. The best part of the evening were drinks at the wine bar where the 2 bartenders were very nice and talkative. I will say that the waitress did not rush us through the meal which was very nice but probably held up the reservation list.

By the time we left, the place was a mob scene. I literally couldn't exit the restaurant there were that many people in the reception area. I had to say excuse me 3 times to get people to move so we could walk out. This is not the place you want to be in case of a fire or earthquake....

I want to rate this as a single star but will toss out a 2 star rating because one of the bartenders was a Sharks Fan.
author: Steve D.

description:
Did not know that A16 was part of the SPQR family, but I see how they resemble each other.....not.  One's as open and bright while the other is dim and more intimate.  Either way, both seem to suit my palate.  It wasn't until an article revealed that A16 was getting a particular batch of Good Family Beef when my friends and I decided to take full advantage of it.  Good solid beef for something other than steak, gotta try it.  (if you're looking for it now, sorry to disappoint.  They only had a limited batch and it was over 6 months ago. )

We got to sit at the corner by the kitchen where we could see the chef throwing the braised short ribs into that 950 degree oven like a hot cake and tossing it around like it was nothing.  Then with a few pizza twirls going into the oven, it's truly amazing seeing what they're doing and being so close to that raging heat.  Also noticed they dressed almost everything in a generous amount of olive oil.  *inspiration time* Watching the kitchen just gives you that much more appreciation for the time and effort that goes into your meal.  

So aside from the ribs, we had a bunch of the following:
-Meatballs - comes in 5 with side of char and pickled onions.  Meatballs were a bit disappointing since I recently had Original Joes in North Beach and it tasted better.
-Braised Good Family Short Ribs over kale - so damn good and tender with the jus sauce being perfectly dressed.
-Margarita pizza - good with a thin crust except for a little bit of floppy from the sauce, but the sauce is pretty on point.  Not a fan of the tough mozzarella though.  I prefer more of a creamy softer kind.
-Roasted Polenta - good with the beef but kinda saltier than hoped
-Mashed beans - great flavor and nicely mild to go with the beef, but TOO damn thick.  Like Adolf L. says, its like the 2nd bite is a WHAM across the face.
-Squid Ink Pasta with Uni and cherry tomatoes - pretty good, but nothing extraordinary.  The sauce may have been too overpowering on the uni but the pasta was al dente and had a nice texture.  Cherry tomatoes on the other hand may have been roasted and didn't quite go well with the rest in my opinion. 


Overall, neat place, great view of the kitchen if you get seated there, but food has a bunch of hit or misses.
author: Vincent K.

description:
4th time's a charm?  Nope.  The epitome of the type of eatery where the reputation precedes it's main business: food!  I've been here 3 times two years ago, and I was always thinking to myself "why does everyone think this is such a great italian place? the pasta is mushy, flavorless, and the menu is not enticing at all."  But I kept going like a trooper mainly because a friend of mine lived in the Marina.  After all I must be nuts, we did sit next to Nancy Pelosi last time so it MUST be good right?

Fast forward to last month, a few friends visiting from out of town so I went against my gut and went to this highly rated place.  Once again disappointed.  The ONLY thing good there is the burrata (sp?) cheese.  The menu is very limited, and you'd think that would mean that everything was a 10/10.  Not even close.  Even the waiters believe their own hype on how good the food is and they talk it up like it truly is amazing. 

I had the black ink pasta...zero flavor, overcooked, and boring.  My fiance got the pizza, and that actually was good...but not good enough to propel this place into the stratosphere of highly reputable Italian in the bay area.   Prosciutto  app was just that.  Two other pasta mains and nobody was blown away.  Tried 3 deserts, obviously not memorable because I don't even know what they were.

Insane reservation list to boot. Go to Berretta, Antica Trattoria, or Stella Alpina Osteria (burlingame) for quality, authenticity, and favorable meals.
author: A A.

description:
Friend and I went here this weekend and started off by being disappointed by the corkage fee of $30 - ouch!  And the way the waiter announced it (literally) - was just kind of rude.  Oh well - that's fine I guess since we brought a nice bottle of Cab.  The rest of the meal was similarly disappointing - ugh!  The waiter was never to be found (had to ask for him twice), the food took quite a long time to arrive and once it did - was quite unimpressive (all around).  The pizza was soggy and flimsy, the salad wasn't quite dressed enough and the sole amazingly tasteless except when dipped in the overly salty sauce on the side.

First time and last time for me.

At least the wine we brought was damn good- yay!  :-)
author: Stu S.

description:
A 16 is a perenial favorite. While they have much more adventurous fare, I typically settle in for a custom margherita pizza and let the bar somm's do their thing.

And their thing rocks.

The bartenders at this long-time Marina fave are knowledgable about their wine. And they have a very nice list that changes often. 

Want a stinky, funky and totally pleasing red from Ischina? Come here.

Want to know what/where Ischina is? Come here.

Want to be satisfied beyong belief by a tasting flight and a hunk of spectacular authentic pizza (or maybe a squid ink pasta or the subtle, but specatucular meatballs if you're adventurous)? Come here.

There are plenty of reasons to visit A 16, why shouldn't you visit? Because I want an empty spot at the bar tomorrow night to delve even deeper into their spectacular Italian list.

If you want to test this gem out, drop by for a spectacular lunch (not open Mon/Tue for lunch, fyi).
author: Bo S.

description:
I really wanted to love this place. A16 has been a SF media darling, has a cookbook that was named cookbook of the year, had a chef that nabbed the national James Beard Foundation award for Rising Star Chef and was also a Food and Wine magazine Rising Star Chef. It seemed like the trappings of an amazing dinner, right? 

Wrong. 

That same chef with all those accolades left the helm this past summer. Did this have something to do with our less than perfect experience? Who knows, but that's the reason I'm going with.

We started with the famed mozzarella burrata with olive oil and sea salt. The mozzarella was out of this world; the crostini it was served with however, was burnt to a crisp. So much so, that upon first bite, the burned taste overpowered the delicate flavor of the sublime mozzarella. We asked our server if we could have non burned crostini because the burned flavor was taking away from the cheese and she told us sure, but just so we know, all of the bread is cooked uniformly. Um, ok, then why is the couple beside us munching on perfectly golden crostini with their mozzarella? 

The salumi sampler of americano, berkshire and speck prosciutto was also a porky treat and the calamari with butter beans was an unexpected combination that went well together and was perfectly cooked. 

My squid ink cavatelli with house-made baccala, cherry tomatoes, green olives and chiles was a disappointment. I appreciated the layered flavors and the pasta was cooked perfectly al dente, but the finish was so spicy that it took away from the delicate flavors. I like spicy, in fact, I crave spicy, but it seemed to me that there was a heavy hand with the use chiles in this dish. 

Food aside, the atmosphere was a disappointment. The seats were so jam packed, it was like we were on a double date with the couple beside us who were quite obviously on their first date. It was a painful evening of conversation that we had to endure. We opted to skip dessert and leave just to escape the confined quarters of the first date. 

Would I try A16 again? Probably not.
author: Lee H.

description:
Packed when we arrived, I usually take it as a good sign. 45 minute wait since we didn't have a reservation, which was pretty good considering. We ended up with the 5 of us at a table for 4, which was the only possibility since their front non-reservation tables are for 4, so my buddy was constantly bumped into from behind by the wait staff and other diners, but in their defense, there was nothing that could be done.

The appetizer sliced meats (Salami, Prosciutto) were nothing to write home about.

However, the meal itself was excellent. 2 of us had these cannelloni type tubes with meat inside, I am blanking if it was veal or lamb, but it was excellent.

The rest of the guys had pizzas and were pretty good.

Service was good.
author: Jordan C.

description:
Being a fan of all things Italian, this one was a no-brainer for me.  I found out about it (all the way in Atlanta) as my co-worker is the brother of the Manager of A16.  With my dad's 65th birthday on the horizon, I knew this was the spot for such a foodie family.

We did our best to try every dish on the menu, and we almost succeeded.  5 people and not a common dish among us, we passed the plates around and devoured every scrumptious bite.  

The wait was a little long, but only because the bar area is very tight and not a lot of room to wait around.  We passed the time with excellent wines and were seated very soon after.  Our service was impeccable, between our server and the manager.  The staff is quite eager to please and they accomplish that easily.
author: Lindy F.

description:
The food was good as was the service and the atmosphere. My only real difficulty was the portions. I saw a lot of huge dishes coming out of the kitchen so when the waitress asked if I'd like a small pasta order I said yes thinking it would be maybe half the size of what I was seeing. 
Result: I got five pieces of ravioli. 
If I were doing a tasting menu and this was meant to be one of several courses I can understand the portion but at a table where everyone is ordering main courses why did she suggest this option? Luckily everyone else had so much food they just shared with me.
author: Stacey C.

description:
Pizza and pasta done right. I went here with my sis and two friends of mine. My sister and I each got our own appetizer sized pastas and then split a pizza and an entree. This was too much food and we ended up taking home half the pizza. We would have been fine with just the pastas and the pizza OR the entree. 

The Salsiccia pizza (fennel sausage, roasted peppers, red onions, mozzarella, grana padano, garlic, chiles) was good as well as the calamari and squid ink pasta. The pumpkin gnocchi I ordered was disappointing. It didn't taste like pumpkin at all and lacked any real flavor. I was also not that impressed by the cod and scallops we ordered as the entree.  

Overall it was a good place for dinner on a Saturday night. Prob not worth the hype but still a solid place.
author: Debbie C.

description:
I have heard so many great things about this place and was definitely disappointed after eating here two nights ago. I really wanted to try the Bucatini, but our server talked me onto getting the special with calamari an ink sauce. I wish I would have been warned that it would smell like sea world and have a very strong "fishy" taste. I should have known though since it was ink and also the last day of the special. Never order seafood on a Monday.

We also had a pizza and the meatball appetizer, which were ok, nothing spectacular. The pizza was kind of runny and the meatballs reminded me of canned  spaghetti O's. I'm sure there are good dishes here, but obviously I didn't order the right things and won't be returning on any future trips to San Fran.
author: Lauren R.

description:
Major bummer, especially since I love SPQR. Perhaps A16 has lost its charm since Nate Appleman's departure? Maybe we ordered the wrong stuff? I don't know what the problem was, but I can only describe my meal as utterly disappointing. 

I liked the mozzarella burrata, though my dining companions had problems with the crostini, which were rock hard. (I like crispy crostini and even I have to admit they were close to breaking my teeth.) My friend's pumpkin gnocchi was probably the best dish at the table - tender and flavorful. However, my bucatini with anchovy-walnut-lemon pesto was dry and too heavy on the garlic, and my friend's ragu was salt overload. We shared the walnut cake for dessert, and that was good, but our sugar high was ruined when the bill came and we saw that the wine the waiter "strongly recommended" was a $60 bottle. Mea culpa for not verifying the price, but we were told a bottle would be more economical than three glasses...and I wasn't planning on ordering a $20 glass of wine.

Anyway, this was truly disappointing. I've wanted to go to A16 for years, and it fell so short of my expectations, I'm not sure I'll go back.
author: Beth T.

description:
Came in from another state and dined with a friend who lives in SF on 5/30/13.  She had heard good things and wanted to go.  I should have listened to the reviewers and found somewhere else.  

First the positives:
-Ambiance....we dined on the patio and that was nice if a little bit noisy, but still acceptable.  
-The wine list is extensive if that matters to you.  
-The buratta was delicious and the side of cannellini beans was very good, but that's where the deliciousness ended.

Now the negatives:
-The waitress was unfriendly and so stiff it was actually uncomfortable to converse with her and she had an attitude that conveyed she thought she was above us.....news flash--you're the one waiting on us......
-The wine we ordered was just fine but we ordered without the help of the waitress because she wasn't interested in actually helping, and looked at us as though she was bored with/or above the whole thing-it was hard to tell which it was.  
-You have to request bread or you don't get any-we didn't, so we didn't
-The halibut, which both of us ordered was dry, overcooked and inadequately seasoned.  I would have killed for some salt, but apparently they think they perfectly season everything so salt on the table is nowhere to be found.....nor was the waitress

Then to add insult to injury, I discovered on my credit card bill they double charged me for the tip.  I've called the manager, but as expected...no return call yet.  I made the mistake of leaving a message saying I was calling about a billing issue, so I doubt I'll ever hear back.

Summary:
Food is not that good (how do you overcook halibut?), the service was horrendous and the place is way over-hyped.  They don't deserve the buzz they get.  There are so many other places to go, I would never return here.
author: Vickie S.

description: The food here was fantastic.  Started with the bruschetta, which was good, but is not traditional bruschetta.  Next grazed on the Blanco pizza, which is one of the best pizza's I've ever had.  Finally, enjoyed the squid in the black ink pasta.  Everything was fantastic, washed down with an "approachable" bottle of wine, as per our waiter.  Not exactly sure what that means, but good nonetheless.
author: S I.

description:
One word: romantic. This spot is great to bring a date. For the appetizer we ordered the calamari. For the entree we got the Salsiccia pizza with gypsy mushrooms, italian sausage, and pancetta. The pizza was top notch. Overall, it was a great experience and I would highly recommend bringing a significant other here. 

Although don't be like the guy who was sitting next to us. I quote him, "What kind of drink should i get? its our first date and i wanna impress her but i dont wanna break the bank" -Random guy to the waitress and his date

P.S. the hot sauce is extremely hot. Use judiciously.
author: Brian W.

description:
Came back to A16 after reading Andrea L's review. I felt inspired to go back. Not disappointed with the pizza. Still as good as I recalled. 

The hostess sat us at the casual area - a step above the bar with high tables lining a narrow space. My only complaint was the NOISE. It was unbearable. It was a wind tunnel affect. The noise bouncing from the two chatty girlfriends and the booming sound from the three drunk men gave us the worst headache. We couldn't eat my pizza fast enough! Got the check & darted out. Once we were on Chestnut street, calmness and the crisp air brought us back to tranquility. 
Go for the food but beware that certain nights it might be so loud that your dining experience might be muddled.
author: Veritas V.

description: This place is really nice inside. We sat at the bar/chef table which was actually really cozy. The warmth from the two open ovens kept us nice and toasty. Plus the cooks themselves were fun to watch pound dough. Service was good and attentive. Food was decent, but not out of this world and certainly not worth the price. Over all the experience was nice.
author: Geoffrey H.

description:
We ate here last Friday, arriving about 15 mins late (parking is not easy near here and there is no valet) and then had to wait another 20-25 minutes to be seated. Can't complain when you come late, but hate to be seated 40 mins after your res time.

Anyway, we felt that service was good throughout the night. Everyone was friendly, answered questions, drinks and dishes came at the right time, etc.

I think I had always heard good things about this place, but after checking the reviews earlier that day, I was having my doubts. I'd say it was a solid 3-star, maybe 3.5-star due to the good service, experience.

We ordered the pizza with housemade sausage to start and were able to finish that between 2 people. It was pretty good, but the pizza at other places like Zero Zero, Flour and Water, Farina, etc, is all much better. Then I had the pasta that is supposedly their specialty - the Maccaronarra with ragu. This was okay. The sauce was simple, but good, but I agree with many other reviews, the pasta was seriously under-cooked.  I cook a lot myself and can respect an al dente pasta but this definitely has more than a bit. I didn't send it back, wasn't worth it, plus you always start to question -- is this how it's supposed to be?? but it definitely wasn't my preference. My husband had the pork chop with a side of asparagus, which I always warn him about getting as he raves about the pork chop at Marlowe and is always disappointed when he gets it elsewhere.

We were celebrating my husband's birthday and they brought out a little sorbet with a candle which was a nice gesture. Overall, it wasn't a bad meal, but the food definitely wasn't good enough to bring us back again.

When we were walking out, the hostess wished my husband a happy birthday which was really nice of her to make the connection.
author: Lauren M.

description:
My wife and I just spent $195 on a nice dinner that included a $60 bottle of wine and tip. The food and wait staff were great but I walked away doubting that I will ever return.
