In the middle of out meal, the waitress accidentally spilled an entire tray of drinks on my back. She was mortified and apologized profusely. The manager saw this and even came over to help clean up. Once we had  ordered dessert, he finally showed up and apologized. He gave me his card, said he would take care of the dry cleaning bill and told us that he had comped our dessert (woo-hoo, a $3 gelato). In all fairness, he also sent over a plate of cookies that we did not order (we were charged but credited for this item on the bill).

I wasn't looking for anything to be comped.  But if you're going to comp something, wow, how cheap can you get?

Let me compare this to a dinner we had a few days ago. I ordered a Chili Crusted Ribeye. It was different but I didn't really care for it. My wife's filet was great, as was everything else. The waiter asked us how we liked the meal. I told him everything was great except I would never order that item again. Not that the quality wasn't good, I just didn't like it. The waiter brought the bill later and told us he comped my $39 steak because they want all their customers to be totally satisfied.

Take a wild guess which one I'll make a point to go back to?
author: G C.

description:
Pretty damn good. Too busy (make a reservation)!

Reasonable pricing for somewhere pretty fancy-feeling.
author: Spencer H.

description:
Finally dropped by for a meal here and was pleasantly surprised after reading the negative reviews about it here on Yelp. 

Have walked by many times and was put off by how crowded it seemed because it' always seemed jammed with people standing around the wine bar at the entrance, but the restaurant is actually a very large (deep) with an open kitchen at the rear and dining tables all the way from the front to the rear. People w/reservations are seated in the rear at normal height tables.  "Walk-ins" are seated at high bar tables in the middle and at the counter facing the kitchen at the rear.

Made a last minute reservation for a 530 seating. Got there a little early and ordered a carafe of 2006 Turley Old Vine Zin  (a very nice wine) at the bar until we were seated.  Got very crowded at the entrance with people waiting for the dining area to be opened. There was a little confusion about whether they would add the wine to our dinner tab (rather than have to pay in advance) and deliver the glasses and carafe to our table when seated, but both happened when requested. 

Sat at the rear in the reserved dining area, which seems the nicest place to eat. The tables for 2 are a bit small and all of the tables are pretty close together. The wait staff and busboys are in constant motion between the tables and service was very good.  The service station for dining in the rear is only a few steps away from most tables and our waiter paid close attention to all of his tables as he breezed by between all of them. Only had to ask for water once and got it by just raising my glass to get the attention of the busboy to brought over a small carafe of H20. Never got any bread that others have said was very good.  It wasn't offered, didn't ask for it and didn't notice that it was missing.  So, I guess it didn't matter. 

There is a very limited selection of entrees (4?) which seemed a bit too pricey in the mid to hi $20's, but there's a broad selection of starters, pizzas and pasta with prices in the $teens. Had grilled sardines and a rabbit terrine (pate) with an spicy fennel sausage pizza along w/the wine and a honey gelato and a lemon mint sorbet for dinner which was all very good for $90 including tip.  Not bad considering the wine was about 1/3 the total cost. 

Reservations recommended.  The walk in tables and counter seats are quickly taken, so arrive early or be prepared to wait if you don't have a reservation and maybe even if you do.  Seemed odd that there were empty tables in the rear even though there were people still waiting for tables, but most of the empty tables were for parties of 4 (not 2), which may be why they were empty.  In any case, it's definitely worth the effort to try get in for a meal.
author: Martin C.

description:
It took us months to get a reservation, but we finally made it into A16 and we were so glad we did!  Although a bit crowded because the place is limited in space, it's a great place for a casual, Italian dinner.  The bar is also really fun & there's a great selection of wines.  The bartendars were kind enough to give me 4 small pours until I found a wine that I liked.  

We started with the burrata based on all on the Yelp reviews.  What can I say?  Yelpers are never wrong.  Amazing!  And yes, you will need more crostini but they gladly give it to you.  My boyfriend and I also split the pumpkin gnoochi & bucatini (also a Yelp favorite) pasta dishes, as well as the pork chop, which was HUGE!  The pasta was by far my favorite....so good, but the pork was good too.  We'll definitely be back.

I highly recommend taking a cab, bus or walking...not a lot of parking in the neighborhood.
author: Kim D.

description: Dinner at A16 was delicious, I loved the squid ink and sea urchin pasta- the half portion was very filling.  We also had the artichoke appetizer, it was full of flavor, presentation was not gorgeous but it sure tasted good.  We tried the famous pizza and it was incredibly spicy- maybe it's just the Romana that is so hot, there was also no visible cheese on the pizza, perhaps a bit healthier than the norm.  We were lucky enough to get seated in the back room, it has a romantic ambience, the ivy growing down the walls is beautiful.  The staff is likable and service was great, we'll definitely be back!
author: Liz Y.

description:
I don't do trendy. But I may do here more frequently. 

I was able to eat here before the chef, Nate Appleman left for New York. We had a tough time choosing a wine, and the one that was recommended was pricey, and good, but not worth the price tag. I wonder what it would retail for, maybe half what the restaurant charges, but that's how it goes. 

We started with the Burrata, and it was nice, but was more like egg white than anything else. It is supposedly something they are famous for, but left us more disappointed. The salt and olive oil made it better than it would have been served naked. 

We had the Margherita pizza and that was good, but not as good as others I've had. I liked the chili sauce they serve ... it's not dried flakes, but more like chili sauce you would find at an Asian restaurant. Different, but better than plain old flakes. 

The Maccaronara Pasta which every body raves about was just like Ragu, and nothing special. We should have ordered the larger portion, because the regular size is just enough to feed a child ... and a child that ate just before going to dinner. 

The desserts were hit and miss. My Almond Semifreddo was the clear winner over the Chocolate and Olive Oil Torte. It was easy to point that out and rub it in a bit. 

I am not sure how A 16 fares now that Nate Appleman has left, but I am willing to give it more tries. 

I really wanted to try the Salumi plate, but didn't because I would be the only one eating it. Subsequent visits, I was alone, and didn't want that much to eat.
author: Michael M.

description:
I heard about this place while dining at another establishment and was soooooooooo glad to get the tip. Oh my. We called from the table where we were eating lunch and got a 10pm reservation for that night (a Saturday night & I eat late so didn't mind the time) so my luck at finding good eats while vacationing seemed to be continuing... (knock on wood!)

We got there a bit before our reservation and yes, we had to wait even past 10:00pm to get seated. The place was packed (once again, it was a Saturday) and the bar was filled, but hey, it was prime people watching time with all the San Franfrisky-ians enjoy themselves. :)

We weren't starvin marvins and the menu looked good so all I had was...

APPETIZERS:
The mozzarella buratta crostini with olive oil is hands down THE best mozzarella appetizer I have ever had! Good lord! It was creamy and just the right amount for 2 people to get a taste and not fill up too much on the stuff. Any more and I probably would have felt sick! Highly recommended for an appetizer if you're there!

MAINS:
I can't remember what my friend but I had the chicken meatballs because it was different and when I asked our server how they were, she replied, "well we took them off the menu and got so many complaints that we put it back on!" I was sold. If the locals were beeyotching so much that meant they had to be good...and damn were they! Wow! I dreamed of these things for a long time after and told everyone about them, so suffice it to say, if you're there and they're still on the menu, get 'em. If not, ask anyway. They may make them for you...? They were just the right amount of flavor in a perfect tomato sauce...and just the right amount of crispiness (yes, crispiness!) on the bottom. I devoured them and look forward to indulging in them again.

Next time I'm back I'll try the pizzas that everyone's written about, but until then, the mozzarella and chicken meatballs will live on in my dreams as two of the best flavor I've had in a long while!!! :)
author: Dina L.

description:
Recently dined here with three friends. We had booked a table on Open Table for a 5pm reservation. It was either 5pm or 9pm, so of course we took the early one. Located in the Marina area, this place was great.  It's a pretty spacious place and the staff was very welcoming.  Each of ordered an appetizer. I ordered the mozzarella burrata as well as another reviewer. Caution: the crostini was realllly hard! I took one bite and thought my tooth would crack. The cheese was gooey and absolutely yummy. If you order, careful of the overly hard crostini, stick with the table bread. The table bread is sooooo good and soft. 

I had the gnocchi for dinner and was delicious. It was light and not cooked in a thick sauce. It comes with a little broth, some corn and a handful of spicy meatballs. They were really good. We were all stuffed , so we didn't get to try dessert.

Two of my friends had pizza and the crust of it was great. Sort of reminded me of naan.  

Reading other reviews: skip calling to make a reservation, go to OpenTable.com.  They call to confirm and email as well.  There is various parking on the street, but we took cab from Union Square for about $10.
author: Theresa N.

description:
I have been to A16 a couple of times with my boyfriend and this is a great Italian restaurant in the Marina with a warm atmosphere and decor. It' was packed with people when we there, both times on Saturdays, so I recommend making a reservation. 

The Funghi pizza with an egg is very tasty and is enough for two, especially with a starter and a salad. We brought our own wine, but A16 has a good wine list. 

Waiters are friendly, but the last time we went our waiter was kind of slow. 

Great place for a date or with friends.
author: Anna S.

description:
I went to A 16 for the first time about 2 weeks ago with some friends and overall I was a bit disappointed.

We ended up having 3 different waitresses throughout the meal so it was kinda hard to keep up with who exactly was helping us.  I never knew if I should be flagging down blondie with the wrist tattoos or the gal who had a hippie resemblance to Kerri Russell circa her "Felicity" days. What a great show that was. But I digress...

The mozzarella burrata was delicious, but I'm not sure if that was due to the way they prepared it (olive oil and sea salt on crostini) or the fact that it was mozzarella burrata; which is one bad ass cheese all on it's own.

The Funghi pizza was majorly disappointing.  I usually really enjoy a white pizza but this had little to no flavor and was *super* dry.  It was like eating mushrooms placed on dry naan bread.  Not good.  I ended up asking for a side of marinara sauce just to dip my crust in (it took so long for one of my 3 waitresses to bring it to the table all I had left was crust).

With so many great restaurants surrounding A 16, it wouldn't be my first choice to return to.
author: Tricia N.

description:
I just got back from an excellent dinner here. My brother was in town for a few hours and we had to catch an early dinner. I booked a 5:30 res on Open Table Sunday with no problem. We were sat in the back area along the wall. 

We split the margarita pizza to start with. We were both starving so having the pizza come about 5-6 minutes after we ordered was a treat. The crust was nice and chewy. It was a bit oversauced which made fork and knife the best option. I really enjoyed the chili oil on top instead of the usual parm and crushed red. I'd say this pizza was on par or maybe slightly topped by Delfina. 

For dinner, we both ordered the shortribs. I'm a little upset about this since there were several other options I would have like to try (roasted chicken, squid ink pasta, etc.). The shortribs were braised to perfection but a tad bit too fatty. I had a side of polenta which went well with the broth from the meat.

I'd love to come back here at night and check out the crowd. A16 is definitely worth a visit. If you don't want to wait for a res, book an early dinner and then bounce around Chestnut street for the evening.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
I love the vibe of this place. Fresh mozzarella is delicious and the pizza is (of course) tasty! I defiantly always recommend this place!
Reservations are a must, and make them well in advance. This place is small and really popular, it's not unusual for them to sell out and not even have a wait-list.
author: Monica A.

description:
We came here to celebrate my cousin's engagement...it was a nice, sophisticated atmosphere, and extremely busy. Lucky for us, we made reservations ahead of time so be sure to do that! I brought a cake for our celebration and the waitress told me they charge a cake handling fee of $4 per person. CAKE HANDLING FEE? You've got be kidding me...with a party of 5, it would've been $20 to serve my cake? Very unnecessary so that was a damper on part of our dining experience since we decided not to have the cake there.

Otherwise, the food was great and the service was wonderful as well. Food is a bit on the pricey side but the pizzas were decently priced. I started with the side of romaine and chicory salad which was very light and refreshing. Then, we all shared a margherita and carciofi pizza. Both were yummy! Beware of the carciofi...it's a bit on the spicy side.

I may give this place another try and see what their entrees have to offer but if you're in the city and want pizza at a nice restaurant in the Chestnut area...go for it.
author: Sunny B.

description: I was here with friends recently on a busy Saturday night and we were all happy with our food and the service.  We were late for our reservation (which I hate!!) but they were kind enough to seat us promptly anyway and our waitress was excellent.  We shared a mozzerrella burrata starter and a salumi platter and both were delicious.  My husband got the pork chop, I had the gnocchi which was made in-house, was beautiful and had a nice spicy kick to it.  I even ate some peas which I usually loathe, but these were prepared perfectly, not at all mushy.  Our friends had the squid ink pasta and the orichette, which I tasted and it was al dente and yummy.  Our dinner was reasonably priced and we all agreed we would go back.
author: Jocelyn R.

description: Best pizza crust I have found after many tries. Almost like Napoli. Salad at lunch was a bit stingy but the pizza made up for it. Italian wine list is mostly southern, which with a few exceptions are not Italy's best wines. They are expensive in relation to that fact. Nice ambience.
author: ronald d.

description:
First of all, kudos for staying open late!! You can go in for dinner till as late as 11pm!!  

The staff were friendly and nice. We asked for suggestions on what to order and were given some great tasting food. Started with house-cured salumi plate, it was delicious!

We basically got a dish from each section on the menu, 1 starter, 1 pizza, 1 pasta, 1 entree and 1 side dish. Everything came out at the right time too. They even helped with picking wine by the glass to go with our food. 

I love all the food here with the exception of the pizza crust.  The whole experience is great, casual, friendly, so this is a place to come back to.
author: Florence W.

description: I had read a lot of great things about A16 as I was planning a trip to San Francisco so I decided I definitely had to try it. My boyfriend and I went with another couple.  The only reservation we could get was at 5:30, but it was made last minute so we didn't mind. We arrived as they were opening and the place packed up fast! After a quick drink at the bar, we were seated. Our waitress was very attentive and the food was good... not the best I've ever had, but pretty good. I was more impressed with the atmosphere. The place was completely full and had great energy. I would definitely come back based on that alone. Overall, a fine experience!
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Pros:
-Great service - our server was very helpful in making decisions, was super friendly and they quickly threw together a new small pizza for me when they squished our leftovers.
-Good beer and wine list.
-Their pastas are cooked perfectly with the right amount of saucing and protein.
-Chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil was delicious and a perfect balance of not too sweet and a tiny bit salty.

Eh:
-A lively atmosphere, and a fun spot, but it was hard to block out our neighbors and both sets of them also started joining in on our conversations.  It was one of those restaurants where you sit closer to the table next to you than the person in front of you.
-Their pork shoulder was average, but nothing special.

Cons:
-They are somehow able to make their pizza with a very chewy and somewhat burnt crust (but I like that) and also a soggy middle. Ours also had way too much prosciutto, you couldn't taste anything else.
-Their cookies and biscottis were stale.

I would choose Piccino, La Ciccia or Gialina (on a good night) over A16 for pizza and just stick to A16's pastas.
author: Nina S.

description: Came across this little spot on a Saturday. Not their busiest day due to the location but the vibe was still great! The bartender was friendly and the bruschetta was amazing! Will definitely try this place during the week for happy hour!
author: Janice A.

description: Excellent food, lots of care in what they make.  A little on the expensive side, but I suppose that is to be expected in the Marina, right?  We had wood fired pizza, burrata (YUM), wild greens salad and squid-ink pasta.  They were all excellent dishes.  The service was maybe a little formal.  If the service had been a little more welcoming, I would give them the full five stars.  We also had to wait a while for water refills.  But otherwise, they're putting out excellent food, which is what matters in the end.
author: Virginia W.

description: I'm Italian and grew up eating beautiful, home-cooked Italian meals.  Nothing quite compares to home cooked Italian food, so whenever someone says "Let's go out for Italian food!" my first reaction is, "Uh...  I'd rather not."   But when A16 came up as a dinner option this past year, I couldn't resist any longer.  I'd read the reviews, heard about it for years from friends and colleagues, and on a recent trip to Tokyo saw that their outpost there was just as packed as the original back in SF, so I had to finally give it a try.  Boy, am I glad I did.  We had an exquisit meal at A16.  The burrata was out of this world.  The fresh pasta and pizza were spot on.  The wine was perfect.  The service, outstanding.  If you haven't been to A16, make your reservation now.  A mouthwatering meal awaits.
author: Tom F.

description:
I was excited to try the pizzas at this place since the chef has been featured on many food programs and the place was nominated for the 2010 James Beard Foundation award for outstanding wine service! Expect long waits, but at least they take walk-ins. 

We ordered burrata in olive oil and crostini for starters, which was good. For pizza, we ordered the Funghi (roasted mushrooms, smoked mozzarella, grana, garlic, oregano, wild arugula, olive oil) and Bianca (Bianca - mozzarella, grana, green olives, basil, chiles, garlic, olive oil). We wanted some red tomato sauce on the side (which they charged $1.00 for!), which when added to the Bianca, made it especially tasty. Nothing over the top, hence giving it a 3-star. I'm of course comparing it to the pizza Bianca from Mario Batali's Pizzeria Mozza in Los Angeles (the crust is AHH-MAAZING!).
author: Chinmayi B.

description:
I had such a mind blowing experience here that I felt I HAD to yelp my first restaurant in a long time.  

RANT: I was shocked to see it had a relatively low review on here.  Then I read the comments. "Bad reservation system" "underwhelming service" etc.  If this is what you're using to describe good food then I feel bad for you , son.  If service is what makes you give 5s, head to Houstons or something and stay away from the cream of the crop places like this.

I went here and had half the menu, no joking.  Below are my favorites:

Appetizers:
- Burrata -  Unbelievably good.  Good bread, good EVOO, good pepper.
- Beet Salad - I don't even like beets all that much (though sometimes crave them).  They had many different kinds with a very light sauce and some ricotta.  All the ingredients were high caliber.
- Salumi - Awesome.  
- Beef tongue also amazing, I don't know what sauce it was lightly dipped in, some sort of red wine I'm sure.

Entrees:
- Nettle gnocchi  - Delicious is the best word.
- Roast Chicken - best chicken I've ever had in my life.  No exaggerating.
- Pork Chop - Best pork chop I've ever had in my life.  No idea what kind of apples they used but it was orgasmic. 

Desert:
- Crostata was great.

The place was very busy (it was a saturday night) but we got our food quickly, had great recommendations by Niko (sp?) on both food and wine.

Will definitely go again next time I'm in town.
author: Kevin P.

description:
This place came highly recommended and it met most of my expectations.

The service was pretty good for being a packed house on a Saturday night.  My boyfriend and I went "balls to the wall" and likely ate enough to feed a small village.  Mind you there was only two of us but we managed to devour:
1. Burrata (delicious!  every meal should start with cheese)
2. Arugula salad (persimmons in a salad?...didn't think it would work but it totally did)
3. Treviso Pizza (prosciutto and bitter greens; unfortunately, pizza was a little too wet for our liking, hence the one star deduction)
4. Squid ink pasta with uni (heaven on a plate) 
5. Maccaronara with ragu (pasta was delicious but the sauce was way too acidic, minus half start)
6. Apple bread pudding (yum!  not too sweet and the gelato a la mode was double yum!)

Overall, a very good meal.  A little pricey for the portion sizes so had to deduct another half start.  Definitely going back.
author: Chanthi L.

description:
There's not much that can go wrong with a 6 pm weekday reservation. 

Seated on time. Served promptly. Little mingling in the front room with the Marina crowd.

I mostly loved my meal, which was cobbled together from several appetizers including a well-made margherita  pizza, a side of white beans (served, sadly, a little on the cool side), and duck meat balls (which, alas, suffered slightly from the always-possible scourge of duck meat: dryness).  The star of the meal was the sublime and delicious burrata - a trendy cheese to be sure, but here salted to perfection, creamy, milky and smooth, the way the gods of cheese intended burrata to be.

The pizza was very good, more Rome than Naples, though I would have appreciated a little more toast on it. It was about 30 seconds underdone - that extra time in the oven would have taken it from good to perfect. 

For dessert we opted for the crespelle (crepes) filled with ricotta and bitter chocolate. It wasn't quite texturally fulfilling - not enough contrast in bite, though the flavor was good and the bitterness of the chocolate cut through the sweetness of the cheese and buckwheat crepes.

Service was outstanding - attentive, helpful, thoughtful. 

Go early. Choose weeknights. And be prepared to wade through the throngs of humanity crowding the bar on your way out.
author: Lindley E.

description: Our party arrived for our reservation and were told that there was a 20-minute backup. We had to stand against a wall (no place to sit) in a cramped area for 40 minutes, as we watched newly arrived groups arrive and be seated. Some had no reservations. No one offered us a drink from the bar (which we couldn't approach as it was blocked with people) or anything. One woman then apologized and said our table was being cleared. We then watched as another party was given that very same table. The woman came back and apologized and said it'd be another 15 or so minutes. We can forgive incompetence, but it appeared as though some members of the staff were just seating their friends and people that they seemed to prefer over us. We never were seated, so I can't review the food. The place was extremely loud and stuffy. Water leak in the sink in the dirty women's bathroom. Never again! We've eaten many times at A16 in Rockridge and had a much better experience. In this case, we left and went to Mezes Greek Kitchen and Wine Bar a few doors down and were warmly welcomed by the staff and enjoyed a nice meal there. Forget this place and go to others in the neighborhood.
author: Jennifer V.

description: I came here with friends a week ago and I really enjoyed the steak!  My friend had the squid ink linguine and was not a fan.  Wine and dessert were really good.  Good atmosphere!  Downside, Only One bathroom for men and women.
author: Samantha J.

description:
It was ok!
Too crowded, accordingly very slow service.
author: Nazli K.

description:
Tried to go here for a late lunch on July 4th - they were unfortunately closed, even though all the other restaurants on Chestnut Street were open and very busy. Sad. Apparently they have something called Meatball Monday which we missed out on because of that.

We tried again on Tuesday around 7pm and had to wait over 30 minutes for a table which we don't typically do but since we'd heard good things, we waited. We gave them our cell # and they called to tell us when a table was ready. It was very full (the restaurant isn't huge to start with). Most of the patrons were young and trendy with a few families - our table neighbors were speaking French and some people were wearing jeans and sandals so there was a good mix of people even though the atmosphere was sort of 'posh'. The hostesses were both very nice.

Our server, Emily was super nice and helpful. We started with their special of the day which was a gnocchi dish with spinach. I think it just came in an appetizer size which we shared along with a bowl of their meatball soup (had to try the meatballs SOMEhow! ;) -- both were excellent. The gnocchi was tender and the soup broth was light and very flavorful.

I ordered their Fregula as my entree (there are 2 size options - $10 or $18 - I ordered the smaller one since we got some apps and I was definitely full) which had big English peas and marscapone - amazing flavor. The texture of the little fregula pastas was lovely, too.

The other entree we order was the Halibut with eggplant, squid and summer squash. The halibut was so flavorful - good texture - and the vegetables and squid were the perfect companion to the fish. The squid wasn't too chewy either which is the usual complaint.

We got a carafe of Grillo wine which is likened to a Chardonnay. It was really good and oaky and went well with both of our entrees. 

As a side to the halibut we ordered the Roasted Sunchokes with capers, chiles and onions. Delicious! Definitely recommend getting these.

For dessert we got the Peach Crostata with Honey Gelato which was light and lovely and not too sweet, though the crust to fruit ratio was a little off for my taste - slightly on the bready side. 

All around a really nice experience - a very flavorful and artful meal. More expensive than we would typically go for but worth it.
author: Natalie M.

description:
I've been to this restaurant several times. Loved the pasta. Especially Maccaronara and Squid ink Cavatelli. The menu is very authentic. Grate combination of flavors.
Vine pairing suggestion from the waiter was spot on. Would totally recommend it for those who like good Italian food.
author: Alex P.

description: Excellent food and interesting wine list, but service is consistently slow.  It's hard to get out even at lunch in under 2 hours and dinner can take longer.
author: P S.

description: A very new foodie, I am always thrilled to try something new.  This place was interesting and trendy.  I loved the burrata.  I got the small portion of pasta, it kept me from overeating.  I wish bread was brought without my asking.  I also didn't realize the  filtered water was not free.  Had a great time.  A leisurely meal with my brother and fellow foodie.  I wished I had room for dessert - they sounded delicious.  I would have appreciated some tastings or wine suggestions without asking.  Overall, good food, good time.  Even kids were enjoying their food - not always possible in places like this.  Looked like a regular eating place for the families that were there.
author: Doc D.

description:
Squid ink tonnarelli with Manila clams and Baby octopus starter, definitely noteworthy!

Didn't appreciate the fact that we had to wait for an hour and a half for the table, but a quick advice to everyone in the same situation-- Bin 38 is right down that block and is much less crowded! Enjoy your wait time there ;o)
author: Irina T.

description:
I went here with 3 other friends around 7pm during weekday.  It was SUPER LOUD.  Had to scream to talk to my friends at the same table.  Food took long time to be served, and everything we ordered tasted just ok.  Nothing special. 

Here is what we ordered.  

Tuna dish with artichoke (Starter)  ---- Disappointed.  We hardly found tuna in this dish, and bread pieces in the dish was way too hard. 

Sardine dish (Starter) ----- THIS WAS OK.  Nothing special.  Bread under neath was so hard again! 

They both were bit too heavy for starters.

Calamari PIzza ----  IT WAS JUST OK.  Bit too spicy.  I rather go to Pizzeria Delfina. 

Squid Ink Pasta ----  Wow dead bugs are on the plate!  Oh no they are the squid ink pasta!  They didn't taste much of squid ink.  Very sad. 

Gnocchi with mushrooms --- I only had one bite, but it tasted good.  Bit too soft.  I don't know if I wanted to finish entire plate by myself though.

Overall, the food was just alright, and this place is way too loud for dinner.  I've had better.  Ttherefore, I won't go back again.   I give this place 2 stars for clean water glasses.  

How's that now? I am still not giving this place more than 2 stars!
author: moshi m.

description:
Food was decent, but not memorable.  Even with a reservation, they made us wait about 15 minutes when I could see available tables. Make sure they sit you in the main dining room and not cramped into the add on room in the back where they seated us. Additionally, it would be nice if they didn't squeeze our party of three at a two top.
All the reviews I read prior to going here raved about the pizzas, again, unmemorable.
author: Alycia S.

description: It's always a pain to get a table here, and you can get some serious attitude even if the place is half-empty. I love the food though, their pizzas are second to none. All of them. I love cutting my pie with pizza shears, and the chili oil is the best thing I have ever had on a pizza. Their wine list is great, and the Bartenders definitely know how to recommend wine based on what you're in the mood for. The only reason why I can't give them 5-Stars is because they will almost never allow you to get a pizza to go, and if they do then they make it seem like it's such a big deal. I went over there when they had nobody in the bar area and barely any patrons inside, and the Hostess responded to me with "we are committed and cannot take any to-go orders tonight." She then said that I could sit at the bar and eat it there, which is bs. Just say that you don't do to-go orders yo. My take is their food is outstanding, and the service is very much like that of a hipster coffee shop.
author: Rory K.

description:
Delicious! Great pizza, great pasta, great atmosphere. We shared everything.  Make sure you make a reservation.  We brought our own wine after spending the day in Napa.  Corking fee is $30.  When we called to find out they told us $30 for 3 bottles. When we got the bill they asked for $30 A BOTTLE.  We explained that we called and asked ahead of time and they took the 2 additional bottle charges off. 

Everything was fresh and hot and I will definitely go back (if i can get a reservation).  It's expensive so save it for a nice occasion.
author: A S.

description:
One might like to think that with all the hype this restaurant gets it couldn't really be all that....THINK AGAIN!  Great service - fabulous food - terrific ambiance.  Loud but...oh well.  

The food?  Perfect!
author: Gen d.

description:
Over the past 5 years I have grown to not just like but love this place.
Always the freshest produce,and teh seasonal entrees are stellar!
I had the sqiud ink pasta with manila clams, WOW, the fungi pizza was out of this world
Try it with a egg on top!
Can not wait until I dine again!
author: Curtis H.

description:
We went on whim as there was an open reservation the night of onopentable. It was a little late, but the place still had a lot of energy.

We started with the Burrata and it was. As two Italians we are very picky about our Burrata and this did not disapoint. It was a perfect blend with the creamyness of the cheese and the saltyness of the crostini. 

Then for pizza we did the trust your pizzaiolo, and we were very happy with the results. Sausage, garlic, peppers, with chili oil. What a combo. 

We also got the arugula salad which was very fresh.

I will be back again for sure.
author: Drew F.

description:
not impressed. If you want better soda, go to a 7-11.

If you want better pizza, see Delfina or Pizza Orgasmica. If you want better service - go anywhere.

It is all decent but never 'good' or 'great'. Keep moving down the street - you will find better.
author: Jon C.

description:
You're all crazy.

This place is magical.

Barreled into San Francisco, hungry (as per usual) but more than a little overwhelmed by my dining choices. I'm only here two nights and will NOT waste a meal on something mediocre. I was also craving gnocchi.

Oh glorious gnocchi gods, thank you.

I somehow found a parking spot (thanks to the parking gods too) and walked up to a crazy packed restaurant. Oh, shit. No worries, they have a seat for me right at the chef's counter! Thanks restaurant gods! 

I just spent the past 2 hours watching a small, talented, VERY good-looking group of cooks do their thang like a fat guy watches strippers at 11 am off a freeway exit. NO SHAME. 

I met a friendly older couple from NYC who were seated next to me. They were a course ahead, and gave me a fabulous preview of my meal. After half a glass of some fantastic Campanian white wine recommended by the server, I ordered the friarelli peppers with anchovies for a starter, at their recommendation. I thought it was very good, if a tad salty (anchovies are new for me). 

The gnocchi has been discussed here before. All I will say is, GET THE FULL ORDER. I got the half order, then tried unsuccessfully to make googly eyes at the hot, tattooed cook who was responsible for this fluffy potato heaven, hoping he would sneak me some more. No dice. I had to settle for sopping up the broth with my bread. 

Two glasses of wine later, I agreed to a bitter almond semifreddo with cornflour cake and apricots and nectarines. This was, hands down, one of the most incredible things I have ever eaten, ever. EVER.  Whoever you are, pastry chef, I will find you and marry you. I'm pretty sure you're a chick, but I'd be willing to fudge some things if I could have that dessert on a regular basis. 

I should probably run around San Francisco twice tomorrow.
author: Hillary N.

description:
I really want to like this place because the food is pretty decent but unfortunately the service is so terrible I have to give it 2 stars.

I went to A16 a couple of days ago, to celebrate a friends birthday. I'd tried calling to get reservations but they were booked, they assured me they reserve half of their restaurant for walk-ins, so if I got there early enough it wouldn't be too long of a wait.

We stopped in at 6:50 on Saturday and were told the wait would be an hour, which I thought was high, but it was still early so we put down our name and had a drink somewhere else.

When we came back at 7:50 they told us it would be about 10 minutes, again, totally fine. However, we were not seated unti 8:40, almost 2 hours after we were told we'd have a seat. I get that it's hard to predict when people will leave but it still was excessive. I later learned they only  reserve about 1/3 of the restaurant for walk-ins, information which would have been nice to know before we came.

I was willing to give up on the long wait and enjoy the dinner but then our server came. I'm not sure if he was having a bad night or something, but he was just terrible. When I asked how big the appetizer sized pasta was, he said 'it's appetizer sized' - which can be very different from restaurant to restaurant, hence the reason I asked. Things continued to go downhill from there, we received our food before our drinks, we couldn't seem to get water refilled and our waiter never seemed to appear again until he gave us the check, before we were done eating.

I honestly don't know if I will return here, it's been a long time since I had service that terrible.
author: Erica D.

description:
Incredible all around food and wine experience in SF!

A 16 was responsible for saving us from a horrible experience at a bar/restaurant across the street and I am indebted to them for that. We had been completely ignored by this other "establishment" but upon walking into A 16 we felt welcomed right away. 

We sat down at the bar to have a glass of wine (the wine list is impressive and regionally specific) before being seated for our reservation. 

Our dinner was really good and we felt like we were on a piazza in Florence with the rustic style of food and the fresh pizzas that were made in front of us. The sommelier recommended a carafe of wine that really fit the meal well and was a great departure to wines that you find in most other Italian restaurants.
author: Jeff D.

description:
Lots of hype...totally deserved!

Bit of a scene in there with some classic marina clowns at their finest...the old cheese dick beside us was dining with what appeared to be his granddaughter - wearing quite the revealing dress!  It's all worth it once the incredible food arrives.

Fantastic!  5 stars all the way.
author: m m.

description: Don't be Trimplin - this is one of the best restaurants in the city! You'd be a POE if you cannot appreciate their amazing wine list, food and service. Do yourself a favor and go in, not just a meal but an experience! This is what dining out in San Francisco is all about so go and Le Pich Yo Self!
author: Mageebeme M.

description:
I ate here 2 weeks ago, and I am still dreaming of the cherry tomatoes on the Pomodoro pizza.  Imagine biting into the juiciest, sweetest, most tender tomato in the world and then multiply that by a million.  They made the pizza at A16 one of the best I've ever had.

Just so I don't sound like a nutcase obsessed with tomatoes, I'll gush about the desserts, as well.  My friend dining with me, a pastry chef from another SF restaurant, wanted to go all out and order a slew of desserts to gorge on.  We first got the raspberry crostata, served warm with a big scoop of ricotta gelato.  We then moved on to the chocolate tart with sea salt and olive oil.  This could be the most unusual desserts I've had, and I loved every bite.  The layers of sweet chocolate, coarse salt, and smooth oil will drive your taste buds crazy!

If you walk by A16 and it seems crowded, go on in and put your name down anyway.  The restaurant seems deceivingly small from the street (it's narrow but really long) and they have tons of tables in there, so the wait time is minimal.  If you do happen to wait more than 15 or 20 minutes, the hostess will take your phone number and call you when a table is ready, so you're free to walk to one of the Chestnut Street bars and have a drink while you wait.

Sometimes trendy restaurants are such a let down, but this one did NOT disappoint.  If only all dining experiences could be this good... Grazie mille, A16!
author: Christy L.

description:
The best way to describe this place is HIT OR MISS.

Don't go here expecting an intimate date night. This is a rowdy, crowded little joint with more of a bar atmosphere. And sadly, the service is exactly what you would get in a very crowded bar. We went on a Thursday and sat for 20 minutes before flagging down a server to put in a drink order.

The calamari appetiser was fantastic. The flavors were light and delicious. I order calamari all the time, from every type of establishment, and this was the BEST squid I have EVER had. The preparation was excellent, but I was really impressed with the quality of the actual seafood. It was top notch.

My friend ordered the gnocchi with braised lamb - which was fantastic by the way. I, sadly, ordered the beef culotte with lemon and salsa verde. The meat *looked* beautiful, but the flavor wasnt there at all. This cut is very lean, which I typically love...but my steak had no seasoning or juices. It was also a really tough piece of meat. The garnishes hardly present, and I would have liked a little more salsa verde to spice up this disappointing entree.

Corn on the cob was fantastic, but I can't fathom paying $6 for something I can make on the grill at home in 10 minutes for 79 cents.

I had the almond cake for dessert, with sage semi-freddo. First off, there was nothing SEMI about this FREDDO. Secondly, I'm really a fan of desserts that arent too decadent, rich, and sweet. I really thought the sage flavors would meet my needs for a toned down dessert, but instead it tasted like someone tossed thanksgiving stuffing on top of my cake. The sweet and savory combo didn't work at all, and I found it almost nauseating. The roasted nectarines were also incredibly sour tasting.

Over all, I can't imagine paying these prices for such bad service and mediocre food. It was a real turnoff, and we were flagging down waitstaff again when we wanted to leave. I will say, that when the staff helped us, they were polite and knowledgeable. I just wish they were more attentive or less overworked. 

I would try it again for lunch or on a slow night. At least I know what NOT to order.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
GQ recently named A16 one of the finer Pizza joints in the US.  
I know why.
Fresh ingredients, crisp yet chewy crust, and a melody of balanced flavors to send your taste buds singing in glee. 

Typical birthday festivities always include dinner.  
This year, rather than going on a seafood conquest or to a $$$$ steak house, I opted for something different.   Something in the city, something both of us would love, something simple, something fresh, something Italian. 
I traveled to the Marina in search of a relaxing birthday dinner.  A16 might of been a little busy and noisy, but it provided me exactly what I wanted.  Tucked in the back, we were seated beneath the stream of light radiating from the big glass window. As we enjoyed dinner in the cozy dining area, we were lucky enough to overlook the outdoor courtyard. The noise didn't bother us, the hustle and bustle enhanced our experience. Truly, we got the best of both worlds.  

Simple lines, friendly service, and solid food.  A16 delivered on it's promise to keep me and my belly happy. 


The cube started with my recent enemy, PORK. He began with the La Quercia tasting: Americano, Berkshire and acorn prosciutto.
We "shared" a Margherita Pizza, and decadent gnocchi; ironically, I think he ate most of it. He could have licked the plate. 
I ordered the Local ling cod, Manila clams and bay scallops in acqua pazza with basil.  I know, I know, I defaulted to seafood.  I can't help it, I love it. 

I scanned the dessert menu, and was not too impressed. Can you believe it, I didn't order anything sweet. Maybe because I was planning on getting lucky and heading to Bi-Rite.  Tragically, Pride week got in the way of my ice cream adventure :( I should have ordered something sweet. Oh well.  
I  made my reservation on open table and advised them it was my birthday.  At the end of the meal, I was greeted with our tab and a sorbet with a candle.  I was happy. Wine, good food, good company, and a great venue.  Great place, and I didn't have to fly thousands of miles to experience Italian Pizza Pie!
author: Flor D.

description:
This is based on Dine About Town last night. We went last night and there was no menu for Dine About Town. Granted I didn't make the reservations, but I thought that it was a bit odd that there was no mention of it.  Hmmmm. Am I am alone here? 

Anyway, dinner was great, we sat in back, I am glad as the front was way dark!  Had burrata, and the pizza of the day for a starter. I had the prosciutto sampler and polenta for dinner. Around the table there was the salumi as in sazitz , so good!!! Calciofi for the BF, which he was yipping about, I thought it was amazing and, squash blossom pasta and lamb. Had the pasta, and no lamb. Was dinner expensive, YES!!! But, was it good, for sure. Maybe returning, maybe not.
author: Nicole F.

description:
I used to love this restaurant, so it was at the top of my list for Easter/birthday dinner.  Unfortunately, we waited 20 minutes for the waiter to take our order, and he was clearly uninterested in providing any service.  My pasta was so salty that I could barely choke it down.  We had to ask repeatedly for bread to go with the terrine and were charged extra.  (Really? Charging for bread at an Italian restaurant?)   Oh, and they could not have been less polite about the fact that it was a birthday dinner.  Our espresso was cold (and brought over 10 minutes before dessert).

All around fail.  Oh wait.  The one positive was that the wine recommendation was great.
author: M D.

description:
The BEST lunch experience I have had in the city! My friend and I did squid ink pasta, Manila clam zouppa, sausage pizza, meatballs, prosciutto and burratta, and some other stuff that we knew we would never be able to fit. The food was flavorful, diverse, and colorful and the best part was our waitress and the GM who were enthusiastic about answering all our questions.

I think we had four kinds of wine. The entire vino experience was incredibly comforting. Started wtih a glass of pinot grigio, then after saying I didn't know jack about Italian wines the GM had us taste a rose and a white we had been eying which came in lovingly generous pours, a carafe of the spectacular white followed, and then a gift from the house of moscato for the two of us (I guess that can sometimes happen when you run up a $150 tab for two at lunch). Nice people man.

We couldn't decide on which dessert to get... so we did both. The rose water panna cotta tasted of prettiness and the chocolate was chocolate, though draped in olive oil, I love it when they mix savory and sweet, fun times.

The decor of this restaurant is one I particularly like. The main dining room has that industrial sheek look and the kitchen is exposed for all to see. Yet, there is also a back dining room behind floor to ceiling glass doors that resembles an Italian garden with natural sunlight, very beautiful. So both urban dining and country feelings are doable here. However, I recommend you dine at the chef's bar where we got to watch them prepare fresh pasta by hand and talk to them while they de-boned about 25 chickens, front row food network status (apparently at Wednesday lunch they do an entire pig).
author: Jordan Reis C.

description:
DO NOT GET ANYTHING BUT THE PIZZA!!!!!!!!!
The pizza is very good!!!!!! The other things are not. decent wine list but kinda expensive for bottles.
We had many dif things but nothing seemed to be good the pizza.
author: T.J. B.

description: I think the key to enjoying this restaurant is to have reservations and/or come on an off-time since it is very popular and hard to get into. I've been here a few times and the food has been excellent every time. They have a pretty extensive wine list, but I brought a bottle of wine and I thought the corkage fee was rather high - they really want you to order wine off the menu! Next time, I will leave the wine at home. It's casual dress, like most places in San Francisco. You could easily stop in after a day of touring the city and no one would bat an eye. Eating at the bar is good too - be sure to try a pizza among other things!
author: Cathy P.

description: Do Not go here...seriously people...what about their pizza is even good? I lived in SF for 2.5 years and any time we wanted to go there there was line and waiting so we had to go somewhere else just because we "had heard" it is good....finally since I don't live there anymore last week we finally got the chance to go there and all in the restaurant is packed, we got a nice seat in their little patio but ahhh the pizza is sooo bad...not only there is nothing on it but its not even delicious, I even missed California Pizza Kitchen over there....never again.
author: Sarrina S.

description:
Waited in the packed, tiny entrance area for thirty minutes past my reservation time. The hostess was fairly pleasant about everything and seemed really sorry, but it's hard to make up for waiting the same amount of time for your table as people coming in without reservations.

Ordered a pizza and a pasta dish. Both were okay but nothing spectacular. It's been a few months since my meal here and I can't remember anything about them. The place was packed (squishing past people the whole way to the table), loud, and seats were very close together.  The server wasn't particularly helpful or friendly.

Where is the hype coming from?  Don't bother.
author: Cristina S.

description:
Really delightful experience.  The food was amazing, and the service was spot-on.  

We had the yellowtail carpacio started which was to die for - I will definitely be going back for this one.  We also had the roasted and fresh fig starter with hazelnuts and saba.  Excellent fusion of interesting ingredients.  

For dinner we had the funghi pizza, sides of canneloni beans and squash.  Everything was delicately prepared and really nice.  We wanted to try the local wines from Campania and the sommalier was able to recommend wines by the glass that suited our styles very well.  I definitely recommend trying these wines - they are very different and a treat to experience.  

I deducted one star because 1) the restaurant was way too hot - they need to figure out a better circulation (the hostess even told us which sections of the area were less or more hot before we were seated). And 2) the only other thing that was not excellent was our greeting at the hostess station.  We told them the name our reservation was under and there were 3 people at the hostess stand staring at the screen for what seemed like 3 minutes trying to figure out where to seat us.  What was odd was that once we said our name none of them welcomed us or greeted us or even looked us in the eye.  They all stared at the screen trying to figure out what to do.  They could use a little better customer service training.

Other than that, great experience, we'll definitely be going back.
author: S. T.

description:
This is my one of my most favorite restaurants in San Francisco. Living in the bay area for several years, and sampling some of its many delicious restaurants, the simple approach to fresh ingredients at A 16 has won my taste buds over time and time again. The wine list is not intimidating, coupled with a staff happy to aid your selection, I usually go for the prosecco.

The burrata: creamy and tender, as old Italian cheese makers would have it be. The sea salt and fruity olive oil, all spread atop a crispy crostini make for the perfect start to the fantastic meal which awaits. 

The tuna conserva: light and flaky, paired with the fava beans and roasted peppers are like a little party of flavor in your mouth.

The beet salad: i didn't necessarily have a taste before beets before I tried this salad, but let's just say it won me over. 

The calamari: be nice to yourself and just order one. Each is spectacular in their own way.

The salumi: hand picked and delicious.

The pizza: i think I've tried them all, and none disappoint. However I am classicist, and always go for the Margherita. Closest to pizza to  Naples I have ever experienced in the US.

The squid ink cavatelli: one of my most favorite items on the menu. Perfectly made pasta, with the essence of ocean as only an ingredient such as squid ink can provide.  

The beef stufato: although the black cod is one of the best I've had, I love red meat, and the beef stufato is divine. Perfectly cooked, paired with the currents and the herb gremolata, a delicate balance achieved once again by the chiefs at A 16.

The cannellini beans: pair with any meal and the smooth puree will highlight any entree.
author: Aimee N.

description: Generally ok but too pricey for what you get. Pizza good. Clams ok. ricotta cheesecake more like a flan not the classic type. It was ok. Not likely to return.
author: Guy R.

description:
Every time I walked by here it was always crowded, so I of course had to see what all the fuss was about.  I'm still wondering....

I came on a Wednesday night and it was definitely crowded.  It's a larger restaurant than one would think having only seen its exterior.  You probably don't need a reservation, I'm guessing, because this place accommodates plenty.

The menu was so extensive, and it took us a while to peruse the entire list.  We ended up ordering the burrata with olive oil and the mushroom pizza.  Both were good, but nothing to write home about.  The burrata lacked a little flavor, as did the "pizza" which resembled flatbread more than anything.  

The dessert, however, was delicious.  I'm not usually a fan of Italian desserts, but the Amareno cherry tart with vanilla gelato is to die for!  Will return just for this.
author: Kira K.

description:
I'm sure its not often that a restaurant's customer has the restaurant's cook book before they've even stepped foot in the actual establishment.  However, I am the odd-ball here who did and whats worse is that the restaurant is less than two blocks walking distance from the apartment.  My first experience with A16's menu was one late night when we attempted to make the Monday Meatballs.  For someone who is not usually a meatball fan, I was blown away.  I enhaled more than I had an appetite for and was looking forward to visiting A16 when the time was right.  Apparently, this past weekend was that time.

We were those horrible people that showed up as one of the last tables.  The hostess tried to pretend everything was fine as I watched her scurry back to the manager on duty and confirm it was oki-doki to seat us.  When you walk into A16, the ceiling is low hanging and the bar is directly to the right.  You can't really see anything else beyond wood and some high bar tables.  As the hostess leads us through the bar and up a hallway, the restaurant suddenly opens up and its a completely different experience.  Ambiance alone, five stars for sure.  The ceilings were high and there was an experience of being in a secret room where only the 'cool kids with their pumped up kicks' go.  Instead of the bar to your right now, you will find the kitchen open to be viewed by diners and lined with bar seating.  I made sure not to sit there, otherwise I would have been talking to myself while the boyfriend drooled on the glass watching the cooks at work.

We were seated at a small two-top (not the best table in the house but whatever) and quickly greeted by our waitress.  This waitress (won't name names) was not horrible by any means, but she definitely was not oh so happy to see us.  And I'm sorry, but anytime you find yourself rationalizing that the waitress 'must have had a rough shift' or 'oh, its because we are her last table' - NO PASS!!!  First table is no different from the last table, the table who is buying appetizers and one cocktail should be treated with just as much enthusiasm as those buying the most expensive bottle of wine.  A16 has a reputation and it would behoove the wait staff to try to ensure their customers look forward to returning. (Sorry - had to get that out of my system.)

The boyfriend and I usually share everything because that was we are able to cover more of the menu.  To start, we had the cured salumi appetizer with pickles and grissini.  The salumi was really wonderful and paired delightfully with the pickles.  Each item had a fluffy texture to it, which was suprising to the heavy, chewiness I was expecting.  To follow, we shared the Funghi pizza and a tripe pasta.  The Funghi pizza was good, but it missed that final flavor note.  I can't say what it was specifically.  From New York to California, pizza is an experience that takes over the entire palette.  Somewhere towards the end of each bite I would find myself swallowing hard in search of something I would never find.  The tripe pasta was fantastic and a definite winner on A16's menu.  Tripe can be an intimidating ingredient because of its inherent texture.  This dish is no longer on the current A16 menu, but it was definitely a treat and the favorite dish of the night.  

We finished our meal with a sausage and pickled vegetable dish.  This literally left a sour taste in our mouths.  The sausage was house made and really lovely.  The pickled vegetables though were so overpowering and the strong, my tongue was sore the next day.  I didn't know what to make of this final experience at the restaurant.  I plan to return to A16 in the next few months after their menu has changed around with the seasons and hope to find more delights than let-downs.  For now, I can only give 3 stars.
author: Jessica C.

description:
The reviews are hit/miss, but I really liked it here.  I enjoyed the trendy atmosphere, and the service was superb--very helpful and efficient.  The pizza I would certainly come back for; it makes my Top Ten list.   

Outside of that, the rest of the meal was average.  The burrata app was good, but not something I would be dying to order again.  The cheese literally melts in your mouth.  It had the look and taste of egg white.  I'm a fan of burrata, but maybe not in such a naked fashion.  I'd much prefer it on pizza or in a sandwich. 

I was still riding on my high from the soft serve at Picco, so when I saw olive oil and sea salt on the dessert menu, I had to try it.  But the chocolate tart was a disappointment, very bland.  The vanilla semifreddo was the better of the two.  

The maccaronara pasta wasn't much to speak of, literally--I never really know what to think when they only serve you nine strands.  I was finished with my portion before I had a chance to form an opinion.  But I did notice that it was firmer than desired.  The wine was a good pick, per the server's recommendation, but it wasn't worth the $85 price tag.

A16 hits the mark if you're jonesing for pizza, and perhaps, a drink or two at the bar.  Reservations are recommended.  Like any place in the Marina, go early enough, and the crowd is tolerable.  But after a few drinks, you won't even care.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
One of the best Italian dining experiences I've had.

I loved the fierelli (sp?) peppers appetizer (a special), and we also had prosciutto and burratta  apps.  A fine way to start.

Three out of our four entrees were excellent.  The one failure was the squid ink pasta which was way too salty.  The flavors of the individual ingredients really shone through in all of our other entrees - the bucatini, gnocchi and pomodoro pizza.

Deserts were very yummy also - I'm not a chocolate lover, but the budino was a big hit with the rest of my party.  I had a melon desert, that had sorbet, fresh fruit, mint and gelatin - really refreshing, tasty and fun.  The meringue stars that topped my desert were unnecessary - although I love meringue.
author: Greg H.

description:
I can't think of a more favorable first impression than being greeted by Diana and bubbles!! Fresh!

We opted to sit at  the bar and boy was that a treat! 'Front Row Joe' for the kitchen performance! Liza rocked it, that woman can manage a kitchen! 

Dinner was superb, we ordered a few different options to sample, all of which were great! Our wine was paired nicely which of course added to the already positive experience. It had been eons since my last experience at A16 and I'm glad to see things are still just as good as I remember.
author: alexa c.

description: Great service, cool ambiance and very good food! The pizza was amazing and so was the sea bass.
author: Anabelle D.

description: I live in the neighborhood and now that I think about it, I just don't come here often enough.  Burrata delish!  Pizza excellent!  Wine selection impressive!  I just wish I could remember our server's name.  She was from Jalisco, super personable, and totally made our experience at A16!  I don't think you can go wrong with anything you order at this happening place.  My only advice to you, make a reservation.
author: Nicole W.

description: Great ambiance....always somewhat noisy....not too many options for vegetarians, but always a fun evening!
author: Carolyn B.

description: A good, not great experience at A16. Enjoyed the Pizza and Pasta, which were both good. However found the service to be stiff and not very welcoming. Atmosphere is ok, nothing good or great as well, unless you were seated at the back patio which feels pretty much like eating on a street corner. Really need to change that space to fit the decor of the restaurant. If you make a reservation, strongly suggest they do not seat you in that section. Nothing about the place makes me want to go back, but then again, not a lot to complain about the restaurant either. Too many better options in San Francisco.
author: Henry J.

description:
Major slippage here.

Had a reservation for five at 10pm on a Saturday evening.  Arrived 5 minutes early, but weren't seated till 10:30pm.  The burrata starter had a weird tang to it (I've had a lot of burrata and this my friends was on the verge of going bad).  Food in general was lackluster, pizza was served cold.  

Just a bad overall experience.
author: Sheetal S.

description:
The food gets two stars for average Italian inspired cuisine (Delfina, Oliveto and Pizzaiola do it better), but service gets a negative star for their handling of a sensitive situation, hence the one star.

I was having a business lunch with a new colleague and unfortunately, was having one of those days.  I forgot my wallet, only had a few dollars in my bag, and wasn't sure if the back up credit card I had was going to work.  (I am a big fan of redundancy-- I usually keep an extra credit card, an old license and some cash in my day planner, in case something like this happens, but clearly the fates were conspiring :-)

Given that I was splitting the lunch (cost of my share: $17) and I didn't want to be embarrassed by a "I'm sorry, but your credit card was just denied", I discreetly mentioned the situation to the server and asked her if the card was denied to "fake it" and I would take care of the bill after my colleague left.

Twenty minutes later (way too long), she finally returns our cards, and when my colleague asks why the delay, she mentioned that she had problems running the cards.   (I notice from the receipt that my card was declined and they didn't even include a pen in the folder for me to "sign".)

I say goodbye to my colleague and come back to talk to the server and the manager, and I explain the situation, and offer to hand over the few dollars I have and leave something as collateral, but they tell me that they can't let me leave the restaurant until I pay the bill.

I  offer to call American Express to see if they will take a charge over the phone, I deal with AmEx for 15 minutes, and unfortunately, AmEx can't help.   I offer to write a check to A16 and they won't take that.  I explain that I live in the East Bay, and I'm happy to go home, get my card and call back with my charge info.  They then inform me that they can't take charges over the phone (why they agreed that I should call AmEx initially is beyond me) and tell me again,  I can't leave the restaurant until I pay the bill.   

We continue to argue for ten minutes, and finally I hand over all of my money, which is $11, I give them my business card, they ask for my license!, I give them the old expired one, and I promise to come back with the $6 that afternoon.  Again, they explain if I don't,  they are going to charge my colleague.

So, an hour and half later, I come back with my $6 and tell them how disappointed I am with the way they handled the situation.

 I can understand how they might have problems with people that dine and dash, but I was professionally dressed and initially tried to calmly explain the situation.  Plus, I was only a few dollars short on a small bill.

Now, they have lost a customer based on $1.50 in food costs and an estimated potential profit of $3.  

Unbelievable how shortsighted they were.   I will NEVER go back.
author: bini b.

description: Great restaurant, I took my fiance there right after I proposed and it was great food, great service and they treated us very well, complimentary champagne for our special night, food was really good, and fun environment. I would recommend trying them out!
author: Rob P.

description:
I developed a real love for food sometime in my Freshman year of college.  Not talking about loving a Sourdough Jack w/ buttermilk sauce at Jack in the Box... talking about appreciating fresh products prepared well with thought and a real attention to flavor.

And ever since I was 18, I wanted to try A16.  It had always been on the top SF eats list.  Raves for their wood oven baked pizzas, homemade pastas, and Monday meatballs.  I don't know why but it took me 10 years to finally come here.  The wait was quite worth it.

A few flaws, but they could be overlooked.  There was a good 15+ min wait for our reservation and I can never adapt to a dining room where tables must be moved to squeeze in other patrons.  I call it the ass to elbow bump... both sides really doesn't need to be feeling that extra friendliness.  It really really irks me, but I have to keep reminding myself SF is sparse on real estate and every inch counts.  So on to the food...

For a light starter - Mozz burrata.  Definitely made the day of, because it was just oozing with freshness.  Good... perhaps needed a zip more seasoning.

The funghi pizza was wonderful... mushrooms were cooked well.  It can be so easy to cook it too much where the mushrooms become rubbery and gives you that squeak between your teeth.  Tomato sauce was spot on... how all pizzas should be adorned with.  Crust could have been crispier, but I enjoyed how thin it was and didn't go toward the dry cracker side.  A16 introduced me to chili oil on pizzas... yes genius.

Did not enjoy the squid ink pasta.  It seemed a bit too aldente and there was a strong fishy smell to the dish.  A real turn off... didn't eat half of it.

So after 3 courses we were getting pretty stuffed, but I booked this on a Monday and I wanted my meatballs, which they forgot to order for us.  Thought it would have came before the pizza.  It managed to come out in less than 5 minutes and despite our filled stomachs we trekked on.  And it was ah-mazing.  Great flavor... cheesy... and fluffy.  Can you describe a meatball that way?  Well, it definitely wasn't a dense mound.  

Overall a pleasant dining experience.  Love the ambiance and it's perfect for a cold day because the entire place is really warm with the wood oven.  Pretty noisy and always crowded.  Another one to check off my "foodie" list.
author: Chris T.

description: wonderful food and service every time i'm here for dinner. the bucatini and burrata are always solid.
author: Roujin M.

description:
Must have - the burratta.  As my friend said, it is basically cheese-flavored butter with sprinkles of salt and oil. OMG.  I was vetoed on the second order (particularly because I already had one at Bin 38 before then, which totally paled in comparison to A16s luscious dish).  But I was ready to have a third order of burratta on the night.

It is super packed.  My friend and I stalked a couple at the bar to get their seats when they got up.  No way to get a real table without a reservation, and it seemed like people were waiting anyway.  Eating at the bar was fantastic though, the bartenders are very knowledgable and fun, had some great wines (and probably too many since the names escape me now).

Not cheap but I can't remember the final bill either.  Fun splurge every once in a while, I'm coming back!
author: Aki N.

description:
A lot of great experiences with a lot of great people yesterday (you know who you are, take a bow) and A 16 was no exception... what a great day!

FAVA MAGIC
Roasted whole fava beans with chiles, anchovies and lemon - sweet mother of Hey_Zues.com  I could eat this stuff by the bucket load.  A bit of burn, a bit of bite, a whole lot of flavor.  

PIZZA
Their oven brings much joy... good pizza, great cooking.  

PASTA
House made sucker, and cooked right!

ICE CREAM
House made and the chocolate is fantastic.  The strawberry was one of the few that my wife actually gives the thumbs-up too!

OVERALL
Maybe this is an "any-given-Sunday" kind of place... don't know... but my experience was fantastic.  :)
author: Dan M.

description:
There are two kinds of gnocchi in the world. There is the gnocchi that people choke down 99.9% of the time: it is heavy, chewy, and hits your gut like so many lead weights. The kind of gnocchi that is so dense that only particles accelerated through a superconducting radio frequency cavity can penetrate (note: thanks for the constructive dialogue on particle acceleration, Ex C!). Sauce and spices have no chance. Then there is proper gnocchi, the kind of gnocchi that I have only experienced twice. It is light, airy, and virtually melts on your tongue. A16 has this kind of gnocchi. Heavenly.

So, why only 3 stars? Thinking back on the entire experience, a feeling of "whatever" comes over me. Sure, the gnocchi was ridiculous, but nothing else really blew my kilt up. The atmosphere was neither intimate nor friendly, it just was. The service was adequate and the rest of the food was (by City standards) also somewhat average.

Maybe A16 is a victim of more than a little hype. Like others, I think my expectations were set a little higher than A16 delivered. If this were my neighborhood eatery, I think I'd rave, but trekking halfway across town for it? Not so much.... unless, of course, I had a hankering for gnocchi.
author: Don B.

description:
Walked in for an impromptu lunch for four, and were seated immediately. Always a bonus.

As you can tell from their website and many of the reviews, this place is really about the wine. In fact , there was a lot of wine being consumed here during the middle of the day during the middle of the week.

Lucky blokes.

My group was strictly iced tea during the workday.

So my impression is that all of this food would be really good accompaniments, but I'm not sure it really held its own sans wine.

Conclusion: I want to go back and check out the wine.
author: Richard P.

description:
Loud, full of the worst kind of people, and food that's just ok. The fennel sausage pizza was good but nothing spectacular. The gnocchi was pretty uninspiring. Nothing else around the restaurant looked too appealing either. You can get better food elsewhere easily enough where you don't have to put up with the horrible atmosphere and horrible clientele. 

I don't want to turn this yelp into an I hate the marina crowd cause it's not A16's fault that marina people suck (even if they did open a restaurant in the marina). This d-bag party behind us was discussing the problem of parking and they came up with a solution. Here's a rough quote of the solution. "Bro, all you have to do is double-park, it doesn't matter if it's a hella busy street... just double park and disrupt the traffic... It's only a $25 fine." I hate that attitude. So if you want to have dinner listening to idiots like that who think they're better than everyone else go for it.
author: Jack M.

description:
I have been dying to try A 16 for a while.  I finally got the night off work and decided to come for dinner.  I made a same day reservation for 10:00 on Open Table since it was the only time left.  After seeing a movie across the street, we showed up about 20 minutes early thinking it would have died down by then.  Whoops.  We ended up waiting about 25 mins past our reservation time.  Luckily we were able to grab a glass of wine during the wait, although we had to stand.

The food:  The wine was impeccable and the beet salad was absolutely delicious.  I got the duck meatballs and they were overdone.  I liked the idea of them, but they just weren't that good.  I also got the almond crostada for dessert.  It was just okay.

The service:  Our server was very knowledgeable and was very sweet and professional.  We really liked her a lot and thought she was very helpful.

The atmosphere:  It was REALLY hot inside and I'm the type of person who's always cold.  The restaurant was a little crammed together.  Also, the crowd wasn't really my type.  A bit pretentious.  The table next to us was arguing over which sorority at Stanford was the best (although they were well into their 40's) and then gloated about how much money they made.  It was kinda lame.  It was more of a place for "well-to-do" men to go out and find a piece of ass while their boring wives stayed home.  I was getting eyeballed by two, much older, men for most of the night and it was just weird and uncomfortable since I was with my boyfriend.

Anyway, that's enough.  I could dog on the marina crowd all day if I could (not that it's the whole marina crowd) but that's not what this review is about.

I think overall, the experience was good.  I will definitely go back for some more wine and maybe try a pizza.  If the service hadn't been as good as it was, I probably wouldn't go back in the future.  I'm willing to give it another try though.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Have been here 2 or 3 times.  Last time was with a friend who hadn't been but anxious to experience.  We showed up without reservation on Sat at 5:30 and had  terrific kitchen bar seats in front of the fire oven. 
We split 4 very good  plates among them...
Erbette chard with pine nuts,...
Local albacore conserva with dried favas...

We both had very good wine from a great selection - it was cozy and nice all except for... the service.

Felt rushed by the waiter and while he was very knowledgeable of the menu and patient with questions, I felt myself trying to get him to warm up and be friendly.  Had one other gentleman serve with a smile, one young woman who clearly wished we weren't there and another who was icy in her engagement.  

Inattentiveness and even rudeness is unfortunately common I have experienced over the years, of wait staff with a party of women without a man in the midst. Yep, even in SF.  

So not sure I'll be back .  There are plenty of great cozy food houses in the City without being treated as if my patronage is a bother.
author: Jeanne S.

description:
Look, there are plenty of places to eat in SF and more coming up every time you look around. So, when a place is able to maintain our interest for as long as A16 has, it means something. Let's get the less important stuff out of the way first:

Service - 5. Attentive without being annoying, perfect timing. 
Decor - 4. It's nice but falls by the wayside compared to their food. 
Ambiance - 4.Yuppie central spanning all age groups. 

Now for the food..Yowza. It was fantastic. Here's what we ordered:

- Prosciutto (San Daniele) - Giant plate of perfectly salted meat. The carnivore in me went ape shit when I saw it. Like a dog that sees red, completely mad. When my friend reached for the meat I almost gnawed off her arm..by mistake of course.
- Lamb sausage with fennel - Not the prettiest looking dish (you'll understand when you see it) but what it lacks in presentation it more than makes up for in taste.
- Roasted beef tri-tip with salsa verde - Huge plate of food. While not a creative dish in terms of its originality, it is perfectly flavored. Would highly recommend ordering this and the lamb.

Overall, be prepared for their generous serving sizes and a fantastic meal.
author: Shreya C.

description:
What kind of Italian restaurant serves so-so pasta that is overpriced for the tiny portion?  What restaurant only has 5 entrees, and all of them are  red meat? What kind of high end restaurant seats adults with a reservation next to three tables of loud, screaming kids at 8pm at night? A 16, that's who. 

If we read the previous reviews, we should have skipped the pasta and just ordered Pizza.  (Or we wouldn't have bothered going, this place has BAD yelp reviews!!)

However, we ordered everything but the pizza: 2 full sized salads (Beet + Escarole, $11 each) , 3 Pastas ($18 each), two entrees (lamb chops, beef - $25 each), 2 desserts (Chocolate budino tart, Espresso panna cotta - $8.5 each)

TASTE: 2 stars
Pasta was just so so, and Olive Garden would have tasted better!! Desserts were so so, unless you love salt. 
Salad was kinda tasty

TINY PORTIONS. Pasta portions were tiny at $18. 

VERDICT: Totally overrated pasta, portions are tiny and overpriced, but if you want a pretentious atmosphere, A 16 is your place!
author: Lil I.

description:
I might not have ordered the correct dishes even after reading the reviews here, but my experience was average at best.

the pizza did not have any meat in it, in the literal sense. Eating the dough can be quite dry.
ordered the romana and bianca, nothing exciting.
the wine list was good, the ambience A ok for A 16, but sadly this place is not for me I think.

the service was average at best with the server disappearing for long periods of time.

the only good thing was even on a weekend when the place was choke-a-block, me and my friends were able to get a place to sit within 10 minutes.
author: Utsav M.

description:
After reading some of the reviews on Yelp, I was second guessing our decision to have dinner at A 16.  By the end of our meal, no more second guessing.

We were a table of four, and we ordered the pickled beet salad and the Burrata as our appetizers.  Both were excellent.
