Some of us wanted the short ribs, but alas they were out.  Instead, the waiter told us about an "off menu" item - braised beef cheeks.  Beef cheeks??  What the hell, we gave them a shot and WOW what a great dish.  Cooked to perfection and flavor oozing all over the place.

Also worth mentioning was the wine.  We gave our waiter some general guidelines (Max $60, Italian, red, medium body) and asked him to pick a wine for us.  He grabbed an obscure bottle from Sardinia and now I'm frantically trying to find where I can buy more for myself!

Only knock on this place is that it's filled with "beautiful people".  But honestly we were more focused on what was on our plate than who was in the restaurant.  

Can't wait to go back.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Nate Appleman just won the James Beard award... and a friend and I have been dying to come here to try it out. We had a late night ressie on a Friday night... 10:30 and it was still packed. WOW. 

It's a cute place. Nice vibe, cool people. Great corkage policy, bring a bottle, order a bottle and corkage is waived. NIce, so that is exactly what we did =)

We started with a nice dry white wine and ordred some starters. Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini, Napoletana, the house cured Salumi, and the classic Margherita pizza. All was delicious. 

on to entrees... we ordered the pasta special of the day, the maccaronara, the squid ink tornarelli, and lamb sausage with the side of roasted carrots. 

the pastas were good, but not what I was expecting, and the lamb was good... but those roasted carrots... i could have eaten just that as my entree. they were delicious. I wasn't extremely impressed with the entrees, I thought the starters were much tastier and the carrots were to die for. 

Now.... for dessert, you must have the chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil. I know it sounds weird... and olive oil with chocolate.. really? right... well, its amazing. and it works. We were going to order 2, but they ran out and we had the last one of the night. We were going at the plate... and it was delicious. 

I'll be back for more starters and dessert. next to try SPQR
author: Jennifer T.

description:
I am from Italy and I have to say that the pizza at A16 would have been one of my favorite pizzas even if this restaurant was in Italy!  My hubby and I shared the "Funghi", which at A16 is made without red sauce, but we asked to add a little red sauce and also a little regular mozzarella (to mix it with the smoked mozzarella and make it a more delicate taste): the pizza was phenomenal, perfect dough, delicious mushrooms, perfect amount of everything - stellar! I would highly recommend it with the changes we made, but even without, the dough and ingredients were so good that I can't imagine a bad pizza here. 

We immediately agreed that we would DEFINITELY GO BACK to have their pizza. Then, the main course arrived. We wanted to try multiple dishes. I got the Tuna Conserva without olives (can't stand olives) and he got the small portion of pasta Maccaronara with ragu napoletano e ricotta salata. Both were delicious, but the pasta was SO amazing that it tasted like a dish we had in a small osteria in Tuscany. It was so good that at this point neither me or my husband could decide if we liked the pizza or the pasta better.... never before.  

The service was attentive and the wine was good. The menu is not very large - which threw me off at the beginning - but I guess that the few items are so amazing that it does not matter. 

You definitely need to get there early and be ready to wait at least an hour.... I would recommend a reservation (well in advance, as they are always booked on same-week). With the reservation they seated us immediately.  They also have a back porch, which is covered and looks very European.

For dessert we had a one scoop of gelato each. Good.

I would definitely recommend A16 to any friend, just make sure you make a reservation in advance.
author: OcchiDiGatto S.

description:
Wow!!!!!!
Best Italian food I've had in a while. Please try the tripe. Any of the pizzas and fresh made pastas are amazing.
author: Javier L.

description:
mother of God, this place is GOOD!

FOOD:~you MUST have the mozzarella burrata...ohhhhh God. soooo good, soft, creamy, it's fresh mozzarella but they stop the process before it fully becomes mozzarella. they buy it from some company outside LA, although i would be more impressed if it was house-made like lulu. i could eat this every day!

~the fava beans were delicious & spicy. i had trouble finishing it, i'm more of a neutral-flavor person, & they serve them whole, so the shells became a little tough after a while. still, the flavoring was excellent, & i'd like the same seasoning applied to green beans or any other vegetable for that matter.

~pizza salsiccia with extra egg & pancetta ::snort snort:: yes, we are little piggies with our sausage pizza with extra bacon & egg! however, that egg is to die for. i don't usually like runny eggs, but it was poi-fect! i am going to crack an egg over every single pizza that i eat from now on.

~chocolate tart with olive oil & sea salt: i thought this was a great combo, but every time my friend tasted the salt, he made a yucky face. i know how he feels because i've felt that way about some chocolates with salt, but the way A16 did it made sense. i loved the olive oil on the chocolate tart! does olive oil taste good on everything?

i want to thank all the yelpers for helping me to make the right ordering choices!

& what's up with A16 vs A5's name? in my opinion, it was a little excessive.

SERVICE: excellent! very intelligent, warm, friendly, not pretentious at all! & it's in the marina!

DECOR: nice, warm, woody, kinda new york cuz the ceiling's not too high.

BATHROOM: great!

OVERALL: this is great for taking people who are looking for italian...i had trouble choosing between here & beretta, but my friend wanted napolitano food cuz he lived in naples for 3 years. response: A16! damn, san francisco is such a food mecca that u not only have to specify "italian," you have to specify which region. like whoa!
author: miss b.

description: Loved the squid ink pasta tossed with sea urchin and my husband said the pork belly was his fav! Great service!  Never an empty glass or a dirty dish. Can't wait to return. Worth every penny!
author: Debra S.

description:
I don't get it Yelpers...I just don't get how this place could get low reviews. 
The service, from the door to the table and back out, friendly, fast and efficient.
The food, delicious, reasonably priced for the quality and the amount.  The pizzas are cooked perfectly.  Thin and chewy crust, just the right amount of toppings and cheese. Not too salty, not too saucy, not too dry.
The roast chicken was juicy and so flavorful!
There are some great choices on the menu which we will have to try next time...lots of creativity in the way the staples are offered.
And a great wine list with lots of mid range wines that are delicious and perfect to sip in the afternoon. 
We celebrated mother's day here and everyone in the family was very happy (and drunk) after lunch.  
Loved it.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Simply overpriced and not much choice on the menu. Overall quality was good and could find a good wine (Negramaro)  from Southern Italy not too priced ...yet.
Unfortunately it looked like they were running out of "ragu" sauce and I would have appreciated if they simply told me instead of serving a "dry" sciatelli pasta dsh.
author: Enzo R.

description: Great italian with nice vibe.  The pizza is a highlight here.
author: Casey T.

description:
On a quest to complete 7x7's "Things to do in San Francisco Before You Die" check-list before year's end (I know, didn't we just begin?), we settled on A16 for dinner this past Saturday night. 

CONS: 

-You cannot call in your name for the list, and once you arrive the "hour" wait to be seated will easily turn out to be almost an hour and a half. 

-The waitress, though INCREDIBLY informative about ingredients and any difficult-to-decipher Italian names, wasn't very informative as to the size of the "small" dinner mains. One of our pasta dishes, though both small, had a fair amount more than the other. I would suggest asking about serving size, then consider getting one small dish and a second regular sized dish- that way you both eat enough, not too much, AND get to sample a couple items.

-The front room, for walk-ins and those who dont mind bar dining, is terribly noisy and dark. You may be tempted to post up here due to the wait, but I recommend sticking it out with some vino and getting cozy in the back.

PROS:
-Well...the FOOD. We started with Roasted Beet Salad (super fresh and sweet, it would make a great summer salad!) and their famous Bruschetta (the roasted Chanterelle mushrooms are heaven). For our mains, we had the Quattro formaggi Ravioli and a spinach gnocchi that had mushrooms and a spicy, red peper, oil sauce. Gnocchi is usually so heavy, I can'f finish half the plate. This gnocchi was light, packed with flavor, and the small portion size made it easy to finish. For dessert, I tried their newly debuted rosemary cake with caramelized apples and a thick, cold, creamy cheese (whose name escapes me) that sits as a block on top of the cake and tastes like a delicious cheesy gelato. INCREDIBLE. We also got a cherry crostata with lemon gelato- beautiful and delicious.

-The wine list is so extensive its difficult to choose a bottle- so I recommend sampling a few glasses, as the bartenders are more than happy to let you try a few different kinds before settling on your next glass.

-The ambiance in the back of the restaurant is better lit, more cozy, and thankfully quieter than the front. We had the pleasure of getting to sit up at the chef's bar, which is a real treat if you can manage it. Its nice to see all the food prep and be kept comfortable by the fire of the wood stove. 

Overall, the food and wine were stand-out, and the service was friendly and informative. Though the crowded waiting space and wait time were a bit annoying, I will definitely be going back!!.... just with a reservation 
:)
author: Raquel C.

description: We reserved a table one month ago for our annual family Christmas dinner and they seated us in the high top bar area - not even a regular dining table.  When I asked  if we could sit in the dining area, I was told in a very rude, abrupt fashion that it would be 20 minutes.  I replied that I reserved a month ago, but the answer was still a very rude 20 minutes.  It took 10 minutes for someone to acknowledge our presence at the table and it took 2 times to ask for water.  We ordered the Burrata and it came with only 5 thin pieces of bread.  We asked for more bread twice to finish the Burrata and finally received a basket with 3 small pieces and the waiter said that they were "out of bread."  Seriously??? What Italian restaurant on a major holiday weekend runs out of bread. Unacceptable.   The food was served in a timely fashion and the pasta was extremely salty.  Do not order the cookie plate.  Cookies were flavorless and not worth the $16 price tag...an icky rosemary cookie... terrible combo.  The waiter had to be reminded countless times for water refills and did not even ask if we wanted drink refills on wine & soda.  In all, a lackluster experience with service and reception that left so very much to be desired.   A disappointing family Christmas dinner.....A Bah Humbug restaurant.
author: Dina T.

description:
To the hostess when we arrive:

"Hi there, got a reservation for 8:30 for 4, but the other half of our party is going to be like 15-20 min late."

Hostess: "Well, do you want to wait at the bar?"

Me: "Noooo I think we'd rather sit at the table and get a drink there."

Hostess: "Well, we can only hold a table for 20 minutes"

Thinking to myself: "Yeah, that's the point of us sitting at it and ordering drinks you dumb !@#$%" What I actually said was, "wait I don't understand."

Then after whispering to the other employee she led us, laboriously, to our table. Look I know this restaurant is crazy busy at 8:30 on a friday, but still, the service could be a lot more inviting. In fact, the only nice person that served us was the guy who brought bread and filled up our water. I was ready to slap a smile on the faces of every other employee!

As for the food, it was definitely good, but not amazing. I tried the mozzarella buffata (which was the best app), the sardine bruschette, and the tuna conserva, all of which were just slightly better than average. The entrees were much better - my gnocchi verdi with wild mushrooms was fresh and light (not what I was expecting), and my favorite was the rabbit. But then again rabbit is my favorite meat - along with veal. Basically if you are a small, innocent, helpless animal, I want to eat you.

The only food that was absolutely out of this world was dessert, namely the lemon ricotta gelato. Now I know I said I had previously had the best ice cream flavor of my life at Bi-Rite, but I'm now stating for the record that the gelato I had at A16 was the best flavor I've ever tasted. That's a big statement, and I'm stickin by it. I told that to the waitress and she looked at me like I'm crazy, but everyone at my table agreed. 

The company and gelato almost pushed this to 4 stars, but honestly, my reviews have to come down to the overall impression of the food, which was only 3 stars, and the service was 2 at best. If I'm going to go to fun, modern Italian, I'm definitely sticking to Delfina.
author: Kelsey E.

description: Good pizza , pasta ok , not the best, service no comment
author: Mattia C.

description:
Do order:
- La Quercia tasting: Americano, Berkshire and acorn prosciutto
with
- Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini

The Squid ink tonnarelli with octopus, black olives, tomato, chiles and garlic had a interesting texture but the taste was mild and didn't really wow me.
author: Katie K.

description:
Wednesday evening, party of 4

On the positive:
+ Great service!  This guy knew his stuff.
+ Burrata = heavenly!! 
+ Celeb spotting...Mike Rowe 

Room for Improvement:
- no room to wait for your reservation
- slow to seat a reservation
- crowded!!!
- half the meal was a hit, half was a miss...which sucks when you pay that much and have to shell out the cab $ to get there!
author: Jules D.

description: This place has been packed since it opened and after tasting the food you will see why.  They have so many good things to choose from it can be hard to narrow it down.  I recommend coming with a group so you can sample more dishes.  But the salads and pizzas are my favorites.
author: Lisa V.

description:
We've being here many times over the years.

The food is great: the pizza among the best Neapolitan in Bay Area. Pastas are also great, meat and fish good.

The wine list is a different league compared to all the other restaurants (italian or otherwise) of this price range. Simply outstanding.
author: N K.

description:
Pizza was good but the bread that they served actually had MOLD on it.  We told the busboy who told the waitress who told the manager and the manager came by and explained that the chef looked at it and that what we saw was probably just burnt crust from the oven used to bake the bread.  

But we explained that it was GREEN and the manager said that it was our word against the chef's because at that point we realized that he didn't even look at the bread.  He gave us a few bite sized desserts to compensate us for our bad experience and brushed us off.

Anyway, wouldn't return.  Our advice if you go here: INSPECT THE BREAD BEFORE YOU EAT IT!
author: Geoff M.

description:
My dad took me here for dinner one night &I am forever grateful.

This place is just stunning. I fell in love with the interior right when I stepped in. The way the restaurant is set up is just beautiful.

As for the food... well... let's just say I ate an appetizer, a main course, part of my dad's pizza, AND dessert. I'm not sure what I ordered but i ate ALL of it &then some.


Ahhh if only I can find someone else besides my dad that can take me here again... (:
author: reiko o.

description:
Oh A16. Let me first say that we have been there before tonight. My boyfriend has actually been a couple of times without me. And he loves it. The one other time that I have been it was wonderful. I had the halibut with farro, lemon and cherry tomatoes. It was to die for. So tonight we had our usual date night, except that my boyfriend is moving in a week for a great job opportunity and we were excited to celebrate.  I digress.   We arrived for our reservation, on time, but waited 20-30 minutes because they didn't have a table. Alright we're over that. No biggie. 

Appetizer took another 25 minutes. It was a bruschetta. Granted it was good. But what takes 25 minutes?

My halibut-that I was so excited for: Epic fail A16. It looked awesome. As I cut into it though, I noticed pink juice came streaming out. Cooked halibut is bright white with clear juice. Cut in  just a but further, it was completely raw below the barely seared outside. I stuck my finger in to test the temperature and it was lukewarm. Not slightly pink and opaque. We're talking RAW. About an 1/8" sear and then pink, translucent, R-A-W all the way through. I was horrified.  We snagged a server who had brought it out but wasn't our original server and he was as horrified as I. He took it away quickly. My boyfriend continued eating his pizza and I my summer squash. Then our original server brought the fish back about 10 minutes later. Okay. Now I can eat, though I'm now terrified because I was once hospitalized by contaminated food. But anyway, our server comes back and asks, "How was your halibut, I know it came out late." Late? No, not late. In fact it appears that it was quite early as it was RAW. Don't get me wrong, she was absolutely lovely (And really knew her wine!). But I don't think they told her what happened. Not one person apologized. Nor did they offer any sort of anything--like some bread to go with my side, or just something to smooth it over. (though I am appreciative that the server that took it back didn't so much as bat an eye as I asked for new silverware since mine had touched the poor, raw fish.) No one was disrespectful. They were all quite pleasant actually. But it didn't seem that anyone was concerned that they had just served me my meal still swimming.

So 2 stars to be shared between the first time we went, our server and my boyfriend's pizza.  Maybe it was an off night. We had 3 different people come to our table for something, but it really seemed that the left hand didn't know what the right hand was doing tonight. 

The minus 3 is for the late seating, the wait for the appetizer and my seriously swimmy, probably stopped flipping on the way to the table halibut that no one apologized for. Oh A16, you'vegotsomesplainintodo!
author: Brie P.

description:
So, I try to never go to the Marina.  But, I had a friend in town who is my most Marina-ish pal, so I figured this would be a good place to take her, and honestly, I did really want to try A16.

We hit this place up on a Sunday night and, silly me, I thought it would be not so busy.  It was packed, good thing we had a reservation.  We were seated at a tiny table that was clearly added to the middle of two rows of tables just to bring in a few extra bucks.  It wasn't the most comfortable spot, but was doable. 

Our waiter was very friendly, but clearly had too many tables to attend to, as we hardly ever saw him.  When we did interact, he was great at suggesting wines and even brought me a new one when the first didn't do it for me.

I ordered the Burrata, which was amazing, as usual.  I really was craving a tasty pasta dish, but was disappointed to find that there were only a few pasta options and most of them had fish in them, which was not so appealing to me on this night.  So, I settled for a pizza.  The pizza was good and the hot chili oil that accompanied it made it even better.  My friend had the lamb, which was prepared very well. 

We, of course, had the chocolate, olive oil, and sea-salt tart.  It was as good as it sounds.  My friend thought it was too salty, but I disagreed.

Overall, a good experience.  But, for what I ordered in relation to what I paid, the rushed interactions with the server, and the crappy table, I won't be rushing back.  Nothing blatantly wrong, just not as amazing as it was hyped up to be.
author: Jessica L.

description:
This was my husband's and my first visit to A 16 and we will definitely go back!  

The restaurant is noisy and bustling, so it's great for a fun night out, but wouldn't be so good for an intimate, romantic dinner.  The building itself is long and narrow, creating a tight squeeze between the tables, but it didn't really bother us.

We ordered the burrata, which was delicious!  We also tried the prosciutto sampler, not knowing how much meat you get!  It would be suitable for a party of 4-6, but for the two of us it was just more than we could eat.  The trio of different meats was quite tasty, though!  For our entree, we split a pizza Margherita.  The sauce is light and flavorful, the basil was fresh and fragrant, and the slices of mozzarella on top were melty and delightful!  The highlight of this pizza had to be the crust.  Amazing flavor and texture is provided by the brick pizza oven which we could see from our table.

Our waiter was very attentive and really knew his wine.  He recommended a white and a red that both paired very well with our food.  The bussing staff was also very professional and friendly.  Our waters and wine glasses were full at all times!

We can't wait to visit A 16 again next time we are in the city.
author: Erin D.

description:
We came here on a Sunday night, the wait was long, one and a half hours. But that didn't deter us. We hopped around different bars in the area while waiting for our table. 

When we finally got our table, we started with a bottle of Black Kite 2006 pinot noir. An excellent choice for our meal: floral note, fruity palette, smooth finish, great balance, nice acidity. 

The zucchini and prosciutto were the first to arrive on the table. All I have to say is..WOW. What an excellent flavor combination. The light sweetness of the zucchini and the salty/savoriness of the prosciutto was a perfect flavor pairing. 

Next came the grilled peppers, calamari, and sausage pizza. The peppers were not what we expected...but still tasty and delicious none the less. It was simply a plateful of bite-size grilled green peppers. The calamari was decent. I enjoyed the toasted pinenuts more so than the calamari itself. And lastly, the pizza. Again...wow. The flavor and texture of the pizza was simply amazing. What made it even better was drizzling hot chili oil on it with a slice of prosciutto. Just imagine an explosion of flavor in your mouth. We were moaning with each bite, some of us more so than others. 

I think if we came here on any other night, it would have been a different experience. But the meal we had here was the perfect ending to an excellent weekend of fun and indulgence.
author: Jun W.

description:
This one has been on my list for 5 years.  We finally decided to go on the spur of the moment a few weeks ago.  

Of course the wine and food were undoubtedly 5 stars.  

Service - they were able to seat us at the bar without a reservation immediately.  Bonus to that was that we had a sommelier as our bartender.  Great!  Not only were we going to have a great wine and dinner, we would probably learn something.  Unfortunately, the bartender was kinda snobby.  He was not helpful and did not offer much insight to our pairings.  He doesn't seem very enthusiastic about what he has to offer as a sommelier.  

Because of the amazing food and extensive wine list, I was tempted to give it a 4 star, but the experience with the sommelier was the deciding factor.  I will be back for  a second shot and might change my mind.
author: J J.

description:
Great Italian food in a casual dining atmosphere. This place can get super crowded in the evening hours so head over here for lunch. But before doing so, make reservations. 

The appetizers here are delish! House-cured salumi - a platter full of goodness. I'm a cheese fanatic so of course I had to order the Mozzarella Burrata. So fresh, so good. Was advised by the waiter that its delivered fresh daily to the restaurant from up North.  

The Funghi pizza topped with their chilli sauce is off the hook! Would come here again.

Food=Excellent
Service=Ok 
Wait=Bad
Parking=Bad
author: Dee T.

description: A16's pizza is spectacular. The restaurant is a little cramped, I'd recommend reservations. Their Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini is one of my favorite things to get!
author: Hayley H.

description:
I had a res at 5:30 because I know this place gets crowded at night, and I like attention and service :)

Too bad the food was a little disappointing...I really liked the deconstructed calamari, but I've had better buratta at Scopa in Healdsburg, and my squid ink pasta with clams was waaay too salty.  The housemade gelato (cookies n cream and coffee) was yummy tho.  I'm glad I finally tried this place, but it's not a destination for me.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
With three starving ladies in tow, we set our sights on A16. It had been a long day and at 9:30pm with a 30 minute anticipated wait this pizza, pasta and everything in between better be as good as I've heard. Actually it better be freaking amazing! 

We started with drinks, as most good meals do. A glass of Italian red for me, and 2 Bellini's for the other ladies (which were great, nice and sparkly thanks to the prosecco). Bread and marinated olives helped us out until our first course. 

The farm fresh beet salad with arugula, goat cheese, and farro was perfect. Succulent in a tasty way, but not over done. The gnocchi verdi was garlic filled and delicious (the small portion is plenty for one). You must, and I mean must try the cannelloni bean side dish. It's like a paste and with the bread crumbs and garlic it  ='s out of this world. The chard with anchovies is a nice touch as well. 

Just when we thought we were finished they threw pumpkin cheesecake in our face (ok we picked it, but still). WOW! Sip with a glass of the 10 year tawny and I will totally forgive the 30min wait. 

Great food, will be back to try the pizza.
author: Theresa T.

description: A good dinner out needs a solid performance on three fronts: food, atmosphere, and service. A-16 had great food, a good atmosphere for our double date, but very disappointing service. The hostess didn't seem to happy to help find us a table and our waitress was even worse. For the food, recommend the Margarita pizza and pork shoulder app.
author: Lucas P.

description:
Things to order:
Mozzarella Burrata. If you like cheese, you'll love these bite size pieces of heaven. Burrata is basically a mozzarella inside a mozzarella. It's fluffy, light, and absolutely delicious

Salumi Sampler. Get a taste of Italy with a sample of their salumi.

Chocolate tart with olive oil and sea salt. It's amazing what salt can do to a dish. A little bit of salt serves to reinforce and accentuate the flavor. The sea salt brings out the sweetness and flavor. As one who doesn't have a sweet tooth, I was amazed how much I ate of the shared dessert. 

Detailed review:
Having recently learned that Nate Appleman won this year's James Beard Award for Rising Star Chef, I decided to visit a second time.  With an open kitchen and a remarkable staff, this is an ideal place for a date. 

To the restaurants credit, there are some lean-forward dishes--burrata, salumi, and chocolate tart.  With such great appetizers, I found that the main course had a hard time competing for my attention. I found myself looking forward to the beginning and ends of the meal.

Overall, A16 is a solid and dependable restaurant, but not a place that will blow your mind. My advice is to drop by for the bookends of your meal.
author: Vince H.

description: Saturday night dinner with my sister at A16 was very pleasant. Our reservation for 7pm was a great call because the restaurant was very busy and it looked like a long wait. We were seated immediately and service was very good.  The octopus appetizer was phenomenal. Hearty pieces of octopus combined with green olives, peas, crisp potatoes, parsley and a sweet sauce. The sautee clams were very good as well with a perfect broth and delicious rustic bread. The gnocchi was nothing extraordinary, but gnocchi in a light sauce with mushrooms. There was a seasoning or flavor lacking to the gnocchi. I could not decide between a pizza with sauce or without and we got the best of both worlds. A pizza with the sauce on the side. The dough was baked to perfection and the toppings were plentiful but not overwhelming. Definitely come for the appetizers and wine or a pizza, but the pasta left something in comparison to the perfect pizza. All in all a wonderful dinner experience. Also the sommelier had a nose ring and was super fine.
author: Christopher K.

description:
The epitome of cool.  Maybe too cool.  A friend and I decided to check out this place last Saturday night without a reservation.  As we expected, the wait was quite long, however the hostess tried very hard to accommodate us during our longer than anticipated wait.  So I would recommend having a reservation, especially over the weekend.  

The Memorable Parts:
- Friendly/Helpful Service (Wait staff recommended a nice wine that wasn't necessarily the highest price.)

- Tuna conserva with new potatoes, gaeta olives, bronze fennel and celery (Very interesting starter)

- Salsiccia - fennel sausage, roasted peppers, roasted onions, mozzarella, grana padano, garlic, chiles (Tasty. Do not underestimate the size of their pizza as I did.)

- Villa dora, gelsonero, lacryma christi del vesuvio, 2004  (Very smooth. I would recommend.)

I would like to try this place again.  But if you're going for the pizza alone, I think Pizzeria Delfina's pizza is better.
author: Brent S.

description:
A16 is a nice place with good food, but the price-performance ratio leaves a little to be desired.

Went on a Friday night, post Symphony, without reservations and were able to get seated immediately, which was nice.  Although the young hostess did seem concerned about putting 2 people at a table for 4.  Read the confusion in her eyes and suggested it would be fine -- she asked "How did you know?".  Ha, score one for me!

Our waiter was quite nice, appropriately humorous, attentive, and friendly, but A16 loses points for not enforcing a dress code on the wait staff.  At these prices, I'm not expecting my waiter to be wearing super tight skinny jeans and a well worn, ripped collar black t-shirt.  The sommelier was dressed nicely and was equivalently helpful.  She must have noticed me scouring the menu for my Italian fav, Valpolicella, which was unfortunately nowhere to be found.  She suggested a Montepulciano d'Abruzzo, which was my second choice in any case.  

The meal consisted of:

Asparagus
Roasted Fava Beans
Gnocchi with peas
Lamb chop
Polenta
Trio of Gelato (strawberry, rhubarb, and coffee/choco mix)

Of note, the Gnocchi was pillow soft and fluffy, which was both unexpected and delightful.  The Asparagus was quite flavorful.  But, I found the Fava Beans to be underwhelming -- just a wrong texture and mouth feel for me.  Others may like it just fine.  I think I swallowed the Lamb Chop whole.  

A16 is good, but there are several places in the city that I'd rather visit, including SPQR (same owners last I checked), Bar Bambino, and Delfina
author: Tom Y.

description: Overpriced,small portions, mediocre food,overpriced wines. I did not have the pizza, maybe that is better. Plus the service is intrusive at best.  The restaurant looks nice, but that's about it.  I would not go back for seconds.
author: Peter S.

description:
My favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Everytime that my girlfriend and i visit SF, we have dinner at A16. It is a great Italian place with excellent service and a nice wine list. 

I love Italian wines, but I am not a wine expert. The staff here is always helpful in selecting a wine that I will like. 

Besides the wine, the pizza is outstanding. I usually get the Pomodoro pizza and the calamari or burrata to start. 

The restaurant is small with a large open kitchen. The low ceilings make it feel cozy. Make a reservation and enjoy.
author: Tony D.

description:
We came here for dinner last Monday on President's Day. It was the perfect dinner to the perfect day (spent earlier at my favorite beach) ;)

We totally lucked out as we arrived to a packed restaurant, were told we'd have an hour wait, but since it was so sauna-like warm inside & so chilly outside, we decided to stay. Miraculously, a mere 5-10 minutes after we sat down to wait it out, we were seated! Splendid!

I had no idea what to do for my wine selection (admittedly I'm not as familiar with Italian wines), so I was grateful when the sommelier arrived. She recommended the most perfect wine for me, that totally hit the spot, and was exactly what I was looking for. 

I couldn't help myself but order the gnocchi (my favorite style of pasta), and it was just as delicious as I'd hoped it would be. 

Our dessert was incredible - a cherry-like tart/cobbler with lemon sorbet. (and this, coming from a chocolate-lover) ;)

Most of all, I loved the ambiance. Even though all the tables were crowded together, and jam packed with foodies and post-Valentine's day dates, we could still have an intimate conversation, didn't have to yell, and enjoyed ourselves very much. It is so refreshing to go to a packed restaurant that understands soundproofing (check out all the cork on the walls, etc.) Love.
author: Sally M.

description: The food and wine were great, but this place is overpriced and my server was condescending. I don't know much about wine, but wanted to try something nice. I didn't like the attitude he had. I'll go to Delphina instead, where they are knowledgeable AND helpful about their wine selection.
author: Milo D.

description:
Had a fantastic dinner w/my husband and son last night. 

-Escarole salad with watermelon radishes, egg, anchovies, breadcrumbs and black pepper - Good
-Prosciutto tasting: La Quercia Berkshire prosciutto and prosciutto di Parma - Good
-Roasted sardines (not listed on their online menu) - Very good
-Maccaronara with ragu napoletana and house-made ricotta salata - Very good
-Squid ink tonnarelli with Manila clams, capers, white wine and garlic - Good, but not enough clams
-Watson Farms lamb spiedino with ceci beans, fennel and olives - Excellent
Erbette chard with garlic, anchovy and lemon - Very good

Also love their corkage policy. We brought a bottle of pinot noir. Their fee is typically $30, but if you buy a bottle of theirs, they waive the fee for the bottle they bring. SO, we ordered a bottle of white for $35 and it went perfectly with our starters! And no, not at all embarrassed that we almost finished the two bottles between us. 

The service was great. Can't wait to go back!
author: Ali A.

description:
We went here last night for the first time and I absolutely loved it.  The lay out of the restaurant was great and I look forward to the next time we go and try to get a seat at the bar so we can watch the chef prepare the pizza and other dishes.  Instead of ordering more than one appetizer to start we decided to order two pastas and have them as small dishes before going with the margarita pizza.  All were delicious!  We had the canneloni pasta as well as the squid ink linguine with manila clams.  The next time I will have to have the burratta! 
Our waiter was wonderful, he was very knowledgeable of the food, wine and regions where the wine was coming from.  
Glad we could finally get a reservation here!
author: Emma A.

description: Great food, great wine.  Loved the neighborhood restaurant ambiance.  All the dishes we had, the salad, pizza, desserts were so simply but incredibly well balanced in flavor.  I would go here all the time if I lived up here.
author: Sana H.

description:
1. Reservation was on time.
2. Nice vibe to the room.
3. The food was excellent: Margarita pizza, burata, pork chop special, pasta w/crab,   special, budino.
4. The wine was fantastico - see next.
5. The service provided us with a rare dining experiences. The young lady who served us was a walking encyclopedia. I have never been served by anyone with such a in-depth knowledge of an extensive wine list. Our party of three decided on wines by the glass because we have very different tastes in wine. We each explained our wants and our server was able to offer choices for each of us that fell within the parameters we set.  She didn't just offer suggestions, she gave us full descriptions of the grape, vineyard and grower - amazing. When the wine arrived, we all agreed that our wines were precisely what we hoped for. My only regret is that I did not ask her name. The receipt said the server was Iris, but I believe we had to have been served by the sommelier. 
Grazie tante, A16.
author: Jim C.

description: Yep, it's good.  Eveerything we ordered was excellent, and the atmosphere was great.  There is a bit of a bar scene at the front which I always like - it makes me feel like there is some energy to the restaurant and that people are having fun.   We had a mix up with our reservation (I more than likely just didn't confirm it) but they were very nice and helpful about it and we ended up with a great table after about 45 minute's wait.  They were fully booked for the night so the fact that we got seated at all seemed a bit of a small miracle to me and I appreciated that they made that happen.
author: Danielle P.

description:
One of my very favorite restaurants.  The pizzas are so authentic (Italian, not NY;-), the pork meatballs are little nuggets from heaven and the desserts...well, save room. 

I recommend sharing a bunch of things.  Enjoy a few apps/sides, split a pizza, main dish and dessert.  

The wine selection is terrific.  If you're just in the mood for something sweet, come here for dessert, sit at the bar, have a glass of an Italian bold red and something with chocolate.

The service is really the best in the city.  Hip, yet very informed and helpful staff.
author: Michelle C.

description:
We have been to A16 over a half dozen of times in the past 5 years and never walked away fully satisfied by anything! I think we kept going back because of the hype. So, last night we happen to be in the area at 5:30pm, parking right in front, two available seats at the bar, so what the heck? ...And here's the final verdict:
Service=  'Ok', nothing special, think the people working there are a little jaded
Ambiance= kind of nice, nothing special
Food= small portions, pizza very dull, dry  & boring, pasta "bland" and truly Nothing Special! 
SF is a BIG city and I can name many restaurants who make a great fresh pizza & pastas!!! So, I am not sure who's giving these high ratings, maybe people who won't take a 10 minute cab ride to try something better/ new, or simply non savvy dinners? My husband and I eat out 6 nights a week, so I kind of know good food when I experience it and don't typical fall for hype.
author: H B.

description: The food and service was great.  We ordered the pork belly, burrata, bianca, and squid ink cavatelli.  My only critique was that the skin in the pork belly needed to be more crisp and it would be perfect.
author: Dax R.

description: Its good, over priced but good. The pizza here is some of the better in the city, the wine list is awesome. I'm not going to trek across the city just for A16 though so only 3 stars. I'll reserve 4 or more for places that its worth a $20 cab ride for. If you're in the area check it out, otherwise just stick to something in your hood at the same rating.
author: andrew f.

description:
Thoroughly enjoyed our dinner at A16!  

Dined early and couldn't believe how busy it was on a Monday evening.  It soon became evident why it was so crowded.  

Our dinner was fantastic.  Each started with an appetizer, beet salad, soup, arugula salad and bruschetta.  All super fresh, beautiful presentation and delicious.  We then shared a small portion of one of the pasta specials between the four of as a pasta.   Entrees were lovely, two pizzas, one pasta and the meatball special.  Dessert and coffee = fantastic!  One of the desserts that a member of our party ordered wasn't available so they took the liberty of bringing a pear tart which she didn't care for but graciously accepted.   In my opinion, I would have preferred to be told they were out of the cake and offered something else but it wasn't a big deal.  Blue bottle coffee, yum + they bring a big pot of it!  Great evening!  Would definitely go back and highly recommend!
author: Suzie L.

description:
A16 really just wasn't worth the prices. Ok granted that I'm not that big of a fan of Italian food (because I hate olives), I have had very very excellent Italian food -- just definitely not here.

Our waitress was a really cute, friendly girl who looked eerily similar to Michelle Monaghan. She is the only reason why I give this review 2 stars instead of 1. 

Anyways, the food was honestly mediocre Italian food that's just way overpriced. I got the roasted chicken (after reading a raving review from a Yelper) for $20, and it was honestly no better than chicken that you can get at El Pollo Loco. It came with a side of polenta that was so dry that it was like a ShamWow sucking the water out of my body. I told our waitress that the polenta was dry so I would like to have a small amount of marinara sauce -- bitch charged me $1.00 for that sauce. But she's still cute though and she looked like Michelle Monaghan so I forgive her.

I don't, however, forgive this mediocre restaurant for serving so-so Italian food at high prices just because they're in the Marina. By the way, if you order the $10-12 plate of pasta -- it's HONESTLY like 4 bites of pasta. That's about $3 per bite. For noodles. And tomato sauce. Yeah. Seriously.
author: Roy C.

description: Food is very good, service and atmosphere fantastic. The pizza is probably the best thing on the menu (had pizza Bianca).
author: Jules M.

description:
I went to A16 for my bday dinner and I was quite happy with the food and service.  We had a mushroom pizza to start and it was delicious.  We also had the sardine starter which didn't sound appetizing but it was absolutely tasty.  

The lady who helped us chose a wine was so helpful.  She had so much knowledge about the wine and probably could have sold us on anything. She picked a great wine for us that fit us and our meal so well. 

For dinner, we had two types of pasta.  We had the Maccaronara and the Squid Ink pasta.  They were both very good.  I think I enjoyed the starters a little more.  The Maccaronara is on the 7x7- 100 things to try before you die so I'm glad I got to try it.  The end a perfect night, we had a tasting of their gelato and wow...AMAZING! We had mint gelato made with creme fresh (I believe that's what she said) and it was soooooo good.  Melted in my mouth. 

Overall, great experience, great ambiance, and great service.  Thanks for making it a good bday!
author: Jaein L.

description:
One star for the Proscutto tasting. 
One star for the sea salt and olive oil chocolate deliciousness that showed up as dessert. 

The pizza was totally good. Not good enough to travel to the Marina for...
author: kristen l.

description:
I've decided A16 isn't the place to go for a nice, romantic meal.  It's way too loud for that.  But it's the perfect place for an amazing meal with a friend to catch up.
  
I dream about the burrata.  Seriously.  It's the best I've ever had.

I've found the entrees to be spotty, so I usually stick to pizzas, pasta and side dishes.  And the burrata.  Always the burrata.  Did I mention you have to try the burrata? Drool.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
I took my wife for our anniversary this past week and we really enjoyed it! 
We had reservations for 8 but showed up at 7, the bar was pretty crowded so we checked in with the hostess. We told her that we would be happy to take the next available table. She replied that the "Chef's Table" might be available so she went back to check. My wife and I have eaten at the Chef's Table in Miami at a nice restaurant and really enjoyed it. The Chef works with you directly as if he were your server, bringing out random things that he wants you to try. So she comes back and says "it is available, follow me" - so we follow her back and learn that the "Chef's Table" actually counter seating with about 12 seats available, overlooking the kitchen and hot wood fire oven. This is why they are getting 4 stars instead of 5, yes we could have said we'll wait for a table but it seemed fine - just not a "Chef's Table." Our server was very attentive and very helpful, she recommended wine, appetizers and entrees, everything was fantastic! 

If you do choose to sit at the counter, I don't recommend sitting right in front of the wood burning oven, it was really hot after about 10 minutes. So, they should ask folks if sitting in front of the wood burning oven is OK. They should also not call that area the "Chef's Table."
author: Phillip K.

description: Ate here with a friend this week, and I was very impressed by the professional service and friendly vibe.  The menu is varied (although the emphasis is on pizza and pasta) and clearly a lot of thought went into combining fresh, local ingredients with a South Italian flair.  We shared several appetizers (salad, clams, octopus, peppers) and found they made a satisfying meal. The prices, while not cheap, are quite reasonable for what one expects to spend in SF.   I especially appreciate the evident care that went into the wine list, as almost everything on it is new to me. We did get there early, and the place got a bit noisy as it filled up, but I'm afraid that's a problem everywhere.  Tasty food, great service, reasonable prices, and no wait for a table (at least before 6:00 pm) -- woohoo!
author: Andy G.

description:
Based on other reviews, I personally expected small plates, about little taste in the food, a loud location, and a really crappy experience.  Good, stay away folks cause really, this place is great and I would like to be able to get a reservation or table.  

Its in the Marina and most of these locations are loud and tight.  I don't know what was in the location prior to this but it has all the charm of a cow hollow/marina location with a nice old school brick oven.  

Everything we had at A16 was excellent.  From the burrata, to the prosciutto tasting, to the funghi pizza, and the berkshire pork chop.  I would come back here many times and wait, if I could, till the cows come home.  

The portions are not small but certainly not Cheesecake factory big.
author: Mark K.

description: Thin crust pizza like Delfinos. Fungi pizza had very fresh mushrooms. Amazing meatballs. Could add egg over easy over pizza. Good Italian wine. cool atmosphere. Not that impressive overall
author: Jenny Z.

description:
We ordered bean soup which was good. However, the meal went downhill from there. The wine Clos Mimi syrah was very "watery"  and mediocre. Nettle and Ricotta Gnocchi was salty to a point it was inedible. Ravioli with Lamb Ragu was also salty and plain. 
We did not know that Nate Appleman no longer is the chef at A16.  We were disappointed by our dining experience here and we will never  recommend this place to anyone we know .
author: T B.

description:
When I worked in Marin this place was a perfect midpoint at which to meet my wife for an early dinner.  Since I don't work up there anymore I haven't felt the pull to cross town.  It is easier to park here than in North Beach, but the food at a variety of places North Beach is a little better.

We first ate here on a Labor Day, ergo a Monday.  You know what that means?  Yep, Meatball Monday!  For my money, this is the sole reason to come here.  The rest of the menu offers up some reliable Southern Italian fare that is often inventive and typically very good, but the meatballs are the draw.

I suggest avoiding the pizza unless you're with a larger party and you treat them as communal appetizers.  Also the wine list is extremely well thought out.  Service is usually good, but when they fill to capacity it suffers.
author: Michael F.

description: I wish I could get a little more excited about a16 as it is only a few blocks from us and we constantly see the hoards of people going there. Starting with the positives, atmosphere is great. I really like the bar area,  Classy but casual and great for young professionals or just a casual weekend cocktail.  Dining room is nice as well. We had a pasta dish that was great as well but for 22$ a  reguar pasta dish it better be good. That was kind of the theme for everything, yes good food but not really up to expectations and not cheap (granted expectations were high). We also got a chicken dish that was pretty good. I will say the 2 bottles of wine we got were awesome and very reasonable. Service was good.  I think I'll give a16 another try but was hoping for a little more with all the attention this place gets.
author: Kate N.

description:
4.5.

If at possible, sit at the chef's table. It's like a reality TV cooking show, except it's actually real. You can watch the head chef yell at the line cook for not tasting his food before he sends it out.

For one, the olive oil they serve with the bread is the best olive oil I've ever had. Not surprisingly, they import it direct from Italy.

The pizzas are also great, while the toppings weren't the best ever, teh crust was perfect (big portion, too). The homemade gelato and sorbets were also as good as it gets, although the chocolate budino was a slight disappointment.

Nonetheless, you can tell that this is one of those places that places a  very high emphasis on only sourcing the best possible ingredients no matter what.
author: Mark A.

description:
Wine: awesome recommendations. Cold Heaven 'Vogelzang Vineyard', Viognier, Santa Barbara County 2006, a Californian Syrah, and a Rose, all were EXCELLENT, matched our descriptions so perfectly.

Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt, and crostini is the best dish we've had that night. The burrata was fresh, soft yet slightly chewy, very lightly seasoned with olive oil and sea salt, just perfect.

Beet salad with wheatberry, mint and ricotta salata is good, but to me the combination doesn't work. It's a bit greasy and dirty tasting, maybe because of the fried garlic. I would prefer my salad have a cleaner taste. My girl friend liked it, but we didn't love it. Good portion though.

Squid ink tornarelli with house-cured baccala, cherry tomatoes, green olive is delicious. Again, the combination isn't perfect, but it sorta works. The tornarelli is exellent, slightly chewy yet full of flavor. It doesn't even need a "squid ink sauce" to go with it. I like the fact that there's not much sauce so you get to taste the noodles which is fantastic. But there's just too much going on on 1 plate that the palette gets confused and feel muted.

The lamb leg, loin, sausage, and fennel, carrot raddish and herbs is SO HORRIBLE that we had to send it back. The lamb was almost flavorless and so stringy that it was impossible to cut, to chew and swallow. The veggies didn't have much flavor either. We talked to the waitress and she gladly took it back, saying " would you like to keep the sausage? no? are you sure? you're more than welcome to keep it!" So we did keep it, but later we were charged $12 dollars for the sausage!!!!???? We didn't even liked the sausage!

The roasted beef coulotte with salsa verde was good. At first we thought it's pretty blend, but the beef was so good that it tastes better with every bite. 

Overall...I felt disoriented. Some things are GREAT, but some SUCKED so bad, like being charged for the sausage which we were encouraged to keep. It seems that they are trying very hard, but it needs more time to mature. 

Will be back for the pizza and dessert.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
Great place, I had Burrata, the Bianca pizza & pork belly!!
Our server Joe was knowledgeable and warm!
good food + good service = great atmosphere
author: Pamela L.

description:
if you're over 40 and in a midlife crisis in the marina, i'd highly recommend coming here. the place is elbow to elbow with gray hairs and old hags who aspire to the "real housewives" mold. this mold consists of lowly people who try desperately to cling on to the "better days," & they believe acting with attitudes will make them appear even more attractive. oh, lord - how they are wrong. 

the hostess (terrible dyed hair with botox that is easily spotted and apparently not holding up) didn't even look our direction to seat us. i stood there apalled, wondering how old you could be and still say with comfort that you are a hostess at a restaurant. after a quick view of the pretentious scenery, it was definitely time to head out. 

one thing i would like to say to the normal clientele & staff here: 
GRAVITY ALWAYS WINS.
author: Jay S.

description: Best pasta EVER! Had the simple spaghetti with red sauce and it was beyond fantastic. Pizza was really good too and pretty cool it comes with pizza shears. Great service and friendly staff.
author: Elle S.

description: All I can say is, "Wow".  They have amazing brick oven pizza.  This place gets crowded that why I only wrote 4 stars.  However, the wait is worth the food and great wine selections.  I would suggest the pasta of the day, pizza, and redbeet salad.  The waitstaff is very friendly and super knowledgable.  It has a low light atmosphere which lends itself to a romatic evening.  Great date spot!
author: Angel L.

description: The restaurant is always pretty crowded and there isn't a good spot to wait (even in the bar which is really small) so reservations are a must unless you want to wait over an hour for dinner. The wine list is really good and I loved everything we ordered, especially the burratta and the funghi pizza. I went with a friend but it seems more like a date night spot and more of an NYC feel than SF. It's a little on the expensive side but I will definitely come back!
author: Gina C.

description:
Chic. Cheerful. Tasteful. 

A-16 is A-OK.  The pizza is deliciously light and the flavor of the grill resonates in your mouth throughout the meal.  Thin pizza, but not as thin as Delfina.  The beer selection pairs well with the pizzas they offer.

My main qualm is the lackadaisical service.  The place is bumpin, but the servers are sleepin.'  It took a while to order, my bf and I had hardly any interaction with our server, and before we knew it, the check was dropped and we were out the door.  Service is way better at sister store SPQR!

Maybe step up the service and the pizza will shine more!
author: Jane L.

description: I very much enjoyed the service and the meal. My pasta was great, beat salad was delicious, and the wine was excellent. The restaurant was packed. Make reservations.
author: Lyena S.

description:
3/4 *'s.
One of SF's most established restaurants.  Pricey and authentic Italian cuisine. Always packed.  Lots of "did you see me?" business folks.
But once I get seated and can enjoy my fellow dinner companions, it get transported to Italy and cannot get enough of it!
author: Damien J.

description:
And the winner of the James Beard award for worst service goes to...... 

After two years or haunting this establishment, I think it is time to write a review. I live around the corner and can never resist an amazing glass of vino for a reasonable $8, but the last trip was the inspiration for this review. I went with my girlfriends and we were ushered to their very cute patio in the back. I stopped counting the passing minutes before we had any sort of acknowledgement. When someone did appear, I got a table of water instead of a glass. The hasty busser poured it all over the table instead of into the glass- and then walked away without even noticing. Leaving the table, the brown paper and me soaking wet. Thanks! 

Resting upon their laurels, the service at this place has gone on a fast downward spiral. If you are 'lucky' enough to wait the two hours and snag a table, you might be serving the waiters instead of vice verse. I once walked out of this place after sitting at the chef's table for 20 minutes, never receiving anything- not even a nod of the head from anyone. 

Don't get me wrong, the food is great. A must is the mozzarella burrata and the la quercia tasting. But sometimes there is a point when the service overrides the food experience and leaves a sour taste. 

Due to William Werner's mastery of all things sweet, desserts have a lot to live up to in my book. While SPQR's panna cotta is wonderful, and the idea of chocolate and sea salt are amazing, I was disappointed in the ratio of salt and chocolate in this dish, it is showered in salt. I will say this is an excellent pre-marathon dessert. You will be able to intake enough water and never be depleted of your sodium during your race. 

The stars are for the decor, food (which is pretty dam good and I think reasonably priced for the quality), and the wine. The service just takes away from everything.
author: Megan M.

description:
The first time I ever at A16 was over a year ago. I was immediately won over by two dishes that I LOVED - the sweet roasted corn and the oven roasted peppers. Well, I don't know WHY, but they've chosen to take those items OFF the menu. I have never seen them come back. I've been back twice since then, hoping to be enamored by some other amazing dish, but so far...nothing has met my expectations. 

It's really unfortunate and which is why I'm conflicted in this review. I love the A16 of the PAST. The A16 at current, does not impress me. Last time I went, I had the Squid Ink Tonnarelli, which was basically pasta that had squid ink in it. YES, it's black. I think the idea is more exciting than the actual dish. It tasted good but still didn't bring back the nostalgic feelings of the corn and peppers of the past. 

Also, their pizzas, while good, really aren't anything special. 

I suppose the specialty of A16 is that they have wood-burning ovens. I've sat at the counter facing these ovens everytime I've been to A16 and there is something really cool about watching the chefs prepare the food and place it in the flames. 

But what I really want is those roasted peppers and the corn to come back. So until they do, I probably won't be frequenting A16 anytime soon.
author: Esther J.

description:
I guess there is a door to an alternate universe at the entrance to A16, where some of the reviewers on here walk into.  I would hate to visit the place that some have described on here.  Fortunately for me, everytime I have walked into A16, I walk through the door that keeps me firmly planted in our World, in the State of CA, in SF, in the Marina.

The food here is always fantastic.  That said, there is typically 1 dish we order that I am not so hot on, but there is always one that is so fantastic that I forget the mediocre one.  Our most recent trip, that was a home-made pasta, infused with squid ink so that it came out jet black.  The dish had just the right amount of spice and was absolutely fantastic.  I could eat their grilled corn by the truck load.  

I will admit I rarely order their pizza, because I am so intrigued by the other dishes (apps, home-made pastas, and house cured meats).  They make their own sausage as well that is delicious.

If you haven't been, go.  I just hope you stay firmly planted in this universe when you walk through!
author: Andrew M.

description:
'Packt Like Sardines in a Crushed Tin Box,' by Radiohead. 

I'm still getting accustomed to city living, including the myriad of shoebox dining experiences I've had. A16 is another notch in the belt, a challenging experience that left me wondering whether five stars would have been justified had I not felt like all of humanity's asses and elbows were being continually thrust in and upon my face. And to the loving couple seated next to us: no, dude, you need not lick her hand during your date--it really isn't necessary. 

'I'm a reasonable man. Get off my case.' 

I'm definitely a fan of the wine selection and applaud A16 for offering such a wide variety of Italians by the glass. Said glass is a bit tough to enjoy at the wine bar, however, when you are crammed into a corner, on guard that the humanity's whose ass is firmly lodged in your face does not inadvertently elbow your glass into the back of your throat. 

'I'm a reasonable man. Get off my case.' 

Our group of four shared a platter of salumi, which included two varieties of prosciutto and mortadella. My mortadella palate is a bit inexperienced, but was pleased nonetheless. The prosciutto were equally as pleasing, but did not leave anyone wanting for more. The platter screamed out for some type of accompaniment to offset the pork fest. 

'I'm a reasonable man. Get off my case.' 

Two of our group ordered pizzas and reported good reviews, yet not raving. A neutral review on the bucatini dish, which looked prettier than it tasted. 

I went for the Berkshire pork chop. It was a bit on the dry side inside (brining anyone?), but well seared with a house mustard on the outside. I didn't think it paired particularly well with the bitter greens on the plate, though. My side of baked polenta was reminiscent of corn bread, and not in a good, buttery way. 

'I'm a reasonable man. Get off my case.' 

Ostensibly stuffed from the apps and entrees, or perhaps truly unimpressed, we decided to pass on desserts. 

'After years of waiting, nothing came.' 

The service was adequate and attentive. Frankly, she outshone the food.  (That's an odd thing to say about someone.) 

We'll likely venture back to A16, but it will be on a weeknight and it will be for a pizza at the wine bar. And it will be my ass and elbow in yo' face. 

'I'm a reasonable man. Get off my case.'
author: Daryl E.

description:
Good food, underwhelming service, unfortunate artwork.

Had the quattro formaggi ravioli with a lamb ragu. It was delightful. Had the chard. It was very good. Had the pumpkin panna cotta. It was ok.

When we got there, there were plenty of tables. Yet, that sat us at the bar. Perhaps I am not old and white enough. Or perhaps the zillion open tables were reserved. Doubtful. I'll blame it on my youth.

The artwork that is currently up is......unfortunate. Can't think of a more appropriate word right now.

As for the service, I felt ignored. But maybe it was because I was young and sitting at the bar. Sure. That's it.

I think it's a fine enough establishment to go to if you aren't me. So, I'll give it 3 stars.
author: Patricia E.

description:
Chef Nate Appelman closely resembles one of my good friends.  They're both bald and from Ohio, but Nate is heavier-set, tattooed, and a much better cook.  It definitely shows in the popularity of his two restaurants, A16 and SPQR.  As a result, reservations during regular dining hours are hard to come by.  Fortunately, the restaurant has a walk-in policy for those without reservations who are willing to take a chance and wait for an open table.  I actually timed it perfectly by going there on a Friday night after catching an 8pm Joe Rogan show at Cobb's.  My reservations were for 10:30pm - we got there at 9:45 and had a table by 10pm.

Food:  4 stars.  For starters, we had the mozzarella burrata (way better than Perbacco's) and the margherita pizza (delicious, but too much dough in the crust).  Main courses were the maccaronara (fresh, but nothing special at all) and the braised beef short ribs genovese (heaven!) accompanied by the flavorful roasted potatoes.  The unfortunate thing about dining at 10pm became apparent when we ordered the dessert.  Three of the desserts were unavailable, including the highly-anticipated chocolate budino tart.  We settled for the honey panna cotta, which was....interesting.

Service:  4 stars.  Service here is good, but a tad slower than I would prefer.  Our server was really nice and gave us some good recommendations (except for the maccaronara).  Otherwise, no big complaints from me.

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  You could tell the restaurant is stretched for space, as the bar area in front is crowded, there are waits for the one-person restrooms and tables, and there is a small room in back that was converted into additional dining space (which is where we sat for the night).  Huge pluses for the hot Marina crowd.  Unfortunately for some reason, they seated us right next to the only old couple in the restaurant.  Even worse, the tables were practically connected (only separated by the glass dividing the small dining room from the large dining room).  It's a little off-putting to dine in plain view of liver spots (I kid!!!!).  On the plus side, the glass shielded us from having to engage in conversation with them (which ended up happening to the other table adjacent to them).    

Hits:   Mozzarella burrata, braised beef short ribs, hot crowd.

Misses:  Maccaronara, reservations, narrow space.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  SPQR, Delfina, Perbacco
author: Keith C.

description: Another amazing dinner out in one of my favorite neighborhoods in sf. Margarita pizza with arugula? Check. Delicious southern Italian vino check. Reservations? Not so bad!
author: Crystal K.

description:
Not quite sure what is wrong with me.  Am I prejudiced against a neighborhood?  Did I believe there could not have been a top notch restaurant in the Marina?  Try as I might, I can't think of why I hadn't been to A16 until now.

Sausage pizza - spectacular.   One of my dinner companions said she dreams about the pizza here.  It would not have been my first choice based on the menu description and ingredients, but it was a winner.  The crust was sublime.  Better than Ideale, which I had previously thought was the best pizza in SF.

Lasagnotte ragu pasta special - spectacular

Chicken meatballs -  ch ch ch check

"Crispelle" of lamb - very good

Sole - simply incredible

Service - very good

Romaine & Chicory side - a bit boring.

Dinning with two ladies, one said she was torn between the meatballs and the sole and asked the other two of us what we were having.  Simultaneously I said "sole" while my other friend said "meatballs".  Kinda funny.  So I let my other friend have the sole and I chose the lamb Crispelle.  The lamb was OK, but I am not a big fan of cannelloni and had I known that is what it was I probably would not have ordered it.  So that is more about my personal preference, just going by the quality of the dish and what they did with it, it was amazing.  We all kind of shared and the sole was out of this world.  Can't say enough about how perfectly married the flavors were and how well it was prepared.  Man, I can't wait to go back to this place!
author: craig F.

description:
Rachel's Raw Food Revolution (hereby forever known as RRR) is over.  

Why is it over?  

One word; Burrata.  Delcious, gooey, cheesy Burrata.  

That sexy forbidden cheese AND the fact that my hair is falling out from lack of protein and vitamins.  But the good news is that I think bald is beautiful... 

You don't?  Hmmmm.  Moving on:

A16 is the best place to stage a revolt against the Raw Food movement because basically their whole menu is an ode to cheese and bread, which goes against what most naturalist,  Tom's of Maine wearing vegan hippies believe in.

So in my mind this is how the conversation between the owners of A16 went: 

"I have an idea!!!  Let's end the RRR.  Ever since she stopped eating, the SF economy has taken a turn for the worse. Let's base the whole concept of our restaurant on the two things that put the most cellulite on people's asses!  Carbs AND Whole Milk Cheeses!  And then she is bound to come in."

"Brilliant!  We will be RICH!  With her spending alone, I will be able to finance that new Bentley." 

"It's almost too easy..."

And that's just what they did.  But, Oh. My. God.  It's worth it.  Every bite.  Every nook and cranny it adds to the voluptuousness of my curves is worth it.

And it doesn't really bother me since I can't see my own ass anyway.  I apologize in advance to you, though.
author: Rachel G.

description:
I think we* can all agree that there's no good pizza in San Francisco.  Mediocre pizza, yeah, on a good day maybe.  But New York good?  Napoli good?  Not on your life.

So I was reading this insane man's web page** (thanks yelp talk, thanks Keane L.!), and he said that the best pizza to be found in San Francisco is at A16.  Fair enough, reservations are made, and, in good time, pizza is consumed.  Minds aren't blown, but that may be because the minds in question have been east of the Mississippi.  This is, without question, the best pizza these particular minds have had in San Francisco.  Insane man was right about that.  It's even at the level of "pretty good" on the east coast.  In Italy it would earn a solid "eh".

Given the setting, a solid 4 stars for you, A16.  Elsewhere it'd be fewer, but with the dearth of options SF provides, take your stars and go.  Now I'm done talking about the restaurant--read on only if you're interested in pizza or veganism.

The original pizza, dating from the 16th century, is the pizza marinara.  Quite simply, this is a flatbread with tomatoes, oregano, garlic, and olive oil (with basil a technically illegal but common addition)***.  What does this list of ingredients mean?  Pizza, in its purest form, is vegan.  All those omnis who gawp at you with their moon faces and slack jaws and fingers up their noses to the third knuckle when you order a pizza senza formaggio are IN THE WRONG.  They are not only disrespectful, they are uneducated.  You are not only respecting your ethical framework, you are respecting the roots of 'za, and as an added bonus taking some bitches to school.

_______
*I
** http://slice.seriouseats.com/jvpizza/
*** for deliciously exhaustive details see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_pizza
author: Joel K.

description:
I always love the meatballs here .

The room is long and at times difficult to fit into but all was well .

It's hot, always will be !
author: Katherine N.

description:
Fake boobs, drunk cougs, good food, oh my!

This is a nice place to blow through your economic stimulus check. Reasons:

1. Gotta start with the food. It's excellent. I was with a decent-sized group and got to eat a little off of everyone's plate, and just about everything was off the hook! My entree was the yellowtail, and it was perfect.

2. Desserts. Dessert is food, I know, but it still deserves its own mention. I really have no idea what I was eating, but there was some strawberry cannoli thing that was just ridiculous. The cookies and cream gelato was also amazing. Our group absolutely ravaged those desserts even though everyone was full from dinner.

3. The help. Great wait staff and hostesses. Polite and formal, but still friendly and conversational.

4. The crowd. Definitely not my scene, but I can appreciate people-watching and listening in on some of the drunken Marina prose.
author: Trey C.

description:
I had low expectations. I know the story - Nate left, food not as good, blah blah blah. But it's been on my list for awhile and since Isa was closed for some strange reason on a random Wednesday night, we went in. 

Good stuff. We waited a bit given we were walk-ins but the place had a great vibe for a week night. Good wine list and friendly bartender. Menu was not too big or too small, had a varied amount of dishes for started, primis and secondis. Waiter had good recommendations and was patient with our indecision but we decided to go ahead with a salad, squid-ink pasta and pizza. 

Call it low expectations for SF (I tend to get disappointed often with my first love) but the food was solid. Pizza was thin and tasty, true Neapolitan style. Salad was well seasoned, pasta was al dente, and the cobbler was a nice finish to a pleasant meal. Everything paired nicely with the wines we had. I'll be back when I'm cruising by the Marina again.
author: Christina L.

description:
This place wasn't all i hoped it would be! The portions were small.. wayyy too small. We got the meatballs.. there was nothing else except the meatballs for $20 something dollars i was disappointed. We also got the salami tray to share which was good.
For a table of 4 with a reservation we waited 30 minutes! the only nice thing was they gave us wine for free while we waited.
not coming back here again.
author: Kate M.

description: Fiancé and I are obsessed with these type of restaurants (homemade pizza, Italian small plates), and have heard about A16 for months before we decided to give it a go. We called Saturday morning and luckily got reservations for 9PM, and although we got there a bit early - still had to wait 25 minutes before sitting down. Once seated, we waited about 15 minutes before the waitress came over to offer us something to drink (at this point, we were salivating over the thought of red wine). Overall - food was good. Bottle of wine was heavenly. Burrata was amazzzzzzing, pizza was good (had better at Delarosa) and pasta was very good. The winner of the entire meal? SUNCHOKES! Ridiculously good. The only thing that could have made the meal better was the service - it took us 20 minutes to try and order desert/coffee, and another 15 to check out!
author: Ashley L.

description:
I remember when this place was Zinzino.  Didn't this place used to be a laundromat at one time?

In all the years I've been coming here, I've never had a real sit-down dinner here as I prefer to hang for wine and appetizers at the bar.  If you choose to eat on the restaurant side, then YMMV (your mileage may vary) as I'm rating this as a wine bar with food.  My usual routine is to hit the bar for two or three nice glasses of wine and something simple and romantic to share or nibble on, usually pizza or a bit of pasta.    

The wines by the glass are always changing (nice selection!) and I always find something intriguing that I want to try.  Their Italian reds (and whites) by the glass are always fun for me since they always have something different and interesting that I am not familiar with, unlike California wines.  I love California wines, but trying something different makes me feel like a wine virgin, all over again.  I don't know who their wine steward is or if they even have one, but I've always taken delight in the selections I've sampled here.

I ordered their margherita pizza again as I believe it's the perfect accompaniment when you're sampling new wines.  Light, crispy, and trendy (not necessarily a compliment), it's been consistently good for me although outside of this environment, I'd probably want something far more substantial for $14.

Not sure if it's because of the bad economy or perhaps it's my imagination, but the pricepoints for their wines by the glass seemed lower this time than before with more wines priced at $11 per glass and lower.  A nice trend since you and a friend can enjoy more.  

Then again, by paying just another two or three dollars more you can get into some selections you often don't see elsewhere (especially not by the glass) and without commiting to the whole bottle.  I usually go this route.

Yes, the wine bar isn't too large and can get pretty loud at times.  I try to avoid going there when it's in full-packed madhouse mode, but when it's calmer, its a wonderful place to be, especially on a date or with someone special.  With the proximity of the waiting area and hostess desk right next to the bar, the people watching and networking opportunities abound as well.  

Wine Star is just down the street, but I prefer A16 as it has a slightly older, more sophisticated crowd.  Nice stemware too.  You can always tell the caliber of an establishment by it's stemware.

Every time I drive or pass by, I'm thinking...I wish I was in there right now.  That says a lot.
author: Roy N.

description: simply a 5 stars restuarant, hip, great service, wine and value
author: G T.

description: Ordinary and not worth any special effort to go to.  Ordinary salads, pizza.  Ordinary service.  Somewhat extraordinary setting as you may see large dead animals on the bar and the room may have the aroma of a slaughterhouse.  That was a first and last for me.  Good Flying Goat cappuccino and desserts.  Certainly overpriced for what you get.  Would not recommend.
author: Corry B.

description:
Why so good?  Damn it's SHO GEWD!  Even stuff I don't especially favor, like roasted corn, is so good.  Great wine selection, I've been told.  Desserts, panna cotta with quince and chocolate budino tart, sealed the deal.  Here's some other stuff I really liked:

olives (yup)
beet salad
escarole salad (for de bunnies)
Pizza Bianca (spicee)
Chestnut tagliolini

Damn i'm getting fat.
author: Joyhan S.

description: Good food, just doesn't blow me away like my other Italian favorites (Beretta, Star Belly, Flour + Water...).  Ambience doesn't compare either.  The burrata is delicious but teeny.
author: Anna V.

description: A16 is named after a highway in Campania, the region around Naples known for its mozzarella, spaghetti with tomato sauce, and pizza, but what you get here is so much more. Except for the pizza, which is too thin and crisp for my taste, everything I've had here has been outstanding, especially the perfectly al dente rigatoni, my favorite pasta, served with a mash of cauliflower, pancetta, and Pecorino cheese topped with breadcrumbs. Given the restaurant's Marina location and the quality of the food, it's comparatively inexpensive, with pasta priced at $8 and $13 and meat and seafood courses in the $17-22 range.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
Anyone with an affinity for delicious dairy must order the Burrata.  The other reviewers are spot-on when saying it is amazing.

Everything else is good also.  A nice update on traditional Italian fare.
author: Kyla B.

description:
Last night went back here (last time was Dec. 07) for brother's b-day, TOTALLY DISAPPOINTED.  Possibly one of the worst meals I have had at a so-called "high-end" SF restaurant.  Food was terribly salty through and through, almost every dish WAY TOO SALTY.

I have lived in Italy several times and know the country and cusine well, sorry folks this food was almost unedible.  My dad and my bro's gf got the "mixed roast" pork plate, AWFUL.  Way too much fat on the porchetta, in fact it was mostly fat.  Hugely substandard meal.  Desserts (we got three) were mostly blah, cinnamon-honey gelato was ok.  

Service was pretty good, we got a free refill on a spilled glass of wine and a good rec for a bottle of Lachyrma Christi red...but overall I would say NEVER AGAIN.  The food is much better at IDEALE in North Beach.  A16 seems to be packing them on name alone, very disappointing.  


Thankfully there is no shortage of good value, truly Italian dining here in SF.  It is pretty sad how "foodie" culture assumes any pork product with an Italian name is worth $25 a plate.
author: Michael G.

description:
