WOW. i've learned my lesson for drunk yelping. i reread the bunch of nonsense i wrote last night, and out of sheer embarrassment, i have deleted it and started over. i feel an apology is in order. sorry! here's my revised review:

2 friends, 2 bottles of melville chardonnay and a whole mess of food. the fresh buffalo mozzarella drizzled with olive oil and sea salt over toast was incredibly tasty for something so simple. i ordered the 20 year prosciutto and wasn't excited over a plate of slice ham. i wish it came with something else. maybe the chef could have decorated it or accompanied it with a little something else.

the anchovy pizza was nice. no cheese (yay!), and with plenty of hearty tomato sauce and whole kalamata olives. very tasty, and i don't even like pizza! the crust had a crunchy exterior from the oven. 

the pork shoulder was really tender, but something was missing from this dish as well. it could have used a little more spice to keep it from being forgettable.

last, but certainly not least, was a triple pistachio cannolli dessert. oh. my. god. i'm certainly paying for all of the heavy cream and cheese this morning, but it was damn well worth it. 

service could have been more attentive, but after our first few glasses of wine, we didn't really notice much although the two good-looking men at the next table over certainly noticed us.
author: May T.

description: Best wine and food pairing place I've ever been to. Michael and the other folks at the bar know an amazing amount about wines and pairing. The wait can be long, but the food and southern Italian wines are amazing! Don't be stupid...do it!
author: Greg H.

description:
Have you ever had that experience where you do something or go to a restaurant with people you always agree with (usually) and for some reason all of the like something and you just don't get it? And then you feel like you are from mars or something all of a sudden?

That was basically my experience eat A16. This place had great reviews from everyone i know (people whose taste i almost always agree with) and I went with my girlfriend (we don't agree on anything, but we almost always agree on food) and she loved it, and I thought it was expensive, way too yuppie (and i can take a fair amount of yuppie)  and overall just not that good. if the food had been as good as everyone was saying I could have forgiven everything else, but it really just wasn't. 

Then on top of that, I had the only wine ever that i wanted to send back (my girlfriend wouldn't let me). It tasted like dirt. I actually called the sommelier over and asked him to taste it and tell me if it was bad. he refused and then tried to explain to me why this wine was SUPPOSED to taste like dirt. And I am not talking "earthy overtones" here, it actually tasted like dirt and he wanted to tell me that was a good quality in the wine. I couldn't freaking believe it!

This city has so many amazing restaurants - i will never go back here
author: Adam W.

description:
Boy, we had a great time over here. And it was packed on Tuesday.

We had 
Marinated castelvetrano and san remo olives,
Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini, 
La Quercia tasting: Americano, Berkshire and speck prosciutto, 
Margherita pizza - tomato, mozzarella, grana padano, basil, olive oil,
Bucatini with walnut, meyer lemon and anchovy pesto
Maccaronara with ragu napoletana and house-made ricotta salata 

and to finish

Chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil 

oh yea 2 bottles of wine, i cant remember what the white and the red was. I wish i did.

Meal was great!, Service was great, The sommelier was awesome!

Atmosphere was great, next time i think we will be at the seats next to the chefs! That looks like a great experience because you can see them make all those pizzas!

Great place gotta go there again!
author: Roy K.

description:
A-16 had a lot of hype to live up to due to lots of people  telling me how great it was. Here is why I ended up liking this place and decided to toss four stars its way:

a) Loved the look of this place (inside and out...esp. out)
2). Had one of the BEST DRINKS OF MY LIFE here:I think it was called the Blushing Angel (it was pink)
d). fast service
7). Prosciutto sampler combined with Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini.

I had the meatballs with the cannelloni beans. The meatballs were pretty good but I think  they would have been better had they not been flying solo on the plate. Note: DO NOT ORDER the plain yogurt for dessert. It was not a good way to end the meal. The crowd here is definitely on the yup side.

I would come here again but I would stick to the pizza because I tasted/heard that's what they do best and of course  their blushing angels.
author: Jackie M.

description:
Took my date to A16 a few weeks ago, looking for a nice spot in Cow Hollow.

Got there early and got my  name on a list to get a table.  My date shows up and we sit at the bar for a while to enjoy a glass of wine.  Good wines and not too overpriced.

Table is ready and the hostess asks us to close our tab.  She waited patiently while I did this and then showed us to our table.

Food was smelling great.  We surveyed the menu and decided to split a pizza, plus she ordered a salad and I ordered some gnocchi.

The pizza came and is outstanding.  We ordered the Salsiccia - fennel sausage, roasted spring onions, mozzarella, grana padano, garlic, chiles.  It's wood-fired It was huge, so our additional choices really weren't necessary.

The gnocchi was green with roasted wild mushrooms green garlic and pecorino.  Outstanding, but I was getting stuffed.

We both enjoyed another glass of wine with dinner.  We passed on dessert.

Prices were a little high, but I'm finding this to be about on-par with prices I'm seeing in San Francisco.  So I guess I just need to get used to it.

Overall a good time.  Will go back soon.
author: Todd M.

description:
This is one of my favorite spots in the city.

The wine, pizza, pasta, meats, and entrees are all delicious.  

If you order right, it isn't even that expensive.

The only reason the rating is as low is because people love to HATE on the Marina.  Yes, I agree in some regards, but A16 stands is in a league of its own in this neighborhood of mediocre/yuppy restaurants.
author: Peter G.

description:
I had a lovely, lovely time at A16. Excellent food, superb service, fabulous wines -- just perfect. 

I got there early and had a glass of brut rose at the bar: bartenders were super friendly and happy to give recommendations.

Let's get to the meat of this review: The Food!

Apps: We had the tuna conserva (surprisingly delish!), the burrata (mmm, melt-in-your-mouth) and the frisee salad with medjool dates (perfectly balanced).

Entrees: Fungi pizza (crispy, chewy crust that had that perfect wood-fired oven smokiness) and the lamb sausage (I'm not a huge sausage fan, but even I enjoyed this dish).

Wines: Phenomenal wine list and the waiters are all really knowledgeable about wine -- just let them know what you like and they'll give you something that will be utterly quaffable.
author: Michelle K.

description:
I have had a change of heart. Initially I gave A16 5 stars and a detailed review of the food and wine. What I have come to realize is that great, exceptional service and okay food ,mixed with too much wine may make some one feel as though the food was better than it was. 

The food at A16 is good but not 5 star good it is more like 3-4 star good. The service and the sommelier, Shelly are 5 star plus good. The wine list is 5 star good. 
The gnocchh with peas and calabrian chile, a  primi was the most memorabal dish. 
The service created a night to remember...Thanks Shelly and A16 support staff.
author: Ellis D.

description:
I don't even know where to start......We decided to go to A16 because the Chronicle had listed it as one of the 10 best restaurants in the Bay  Area. So much for their recommendations.....
It disappointed early on, and it only got worse.
I was annoyed that the menu they had on the website didn't match the one outside. I understand places change dishes around, but seriously, how hard is it to put "sample menu" on the web menu? I found it even more odd that the menu posted outside was different from both the web menu, and the actual menu.
They had one fish choice, which also seemed out of place for an Italian restaurant.
We decided to share the mozzarella burrata, (another mistake.) It was a lump of runny, tasteless cheese served with 4 tiny crostini. It was ridiculous that they served only four with such a big lump of cheese. Big ripoff, and it wasn't even good. 
My BF was really excited to try their "house-cured salumi", it was in a word- GROSS! It was basically tasteless fat. 
I forgot to mention it took way too long to get our drinks, we actually got our appetizers a few minutes before. 
Our waitress apparently thought she was better  than she was. She took our orders with no pen and paper. i understand there are servers that can do this. but I'm not impressed if you can't get it right. Which of course she didn't.
She couldn't even remember what appetizers we ordered. I was waiting for her to mess up the dinner order too. This was the only thing that wasn't a disappointment there. (Yep, she screwed that up too!)
So, we waited for our food with hope of it being much better than the appetizers. 
Again, big mistake.
I  got the white prawns which were nasty. They had an awful odor, and an even worse taste. Frankly, i was a little surprised anyone would serve them. The presentation was also lacking. I can do better at home. The same can be said of the roasted potatoes. They were bland, and boring. I generally like things a lot more bland than most people, so if i think somethings bland, it has to be really bad.
I also should mention, we had to ask for refills on our waters. The guy we asked never came back, but finally our server graced us with her presence, and we were lucky she gave us a refill. 
The prices are completely ridiculous, and the food is some of the worst I've had, 
Without a doubt, this is the worst experience I've had at a restaurant in the city.
I'm pretty pissed we wasted the time, and money we did there. Hopefully, others will stop making the same mistake!
author: Amanda G.

description:
Sit at the Chef's counter.
Ignore the crowd around you.
And order the mozzarella burrata.  A pizza.  the squid ink pasta.  
And ask the knowledgeable staff for a great Southern Italian wine to pair with it.  
Everything here is delicious.  The olive oil is drinkable.
A16's chef was a James Beard nominee for Rising Star Chef, and it is very clear why after my 2 experiences at A16.
author: Kelli R.

description:
This review is for the wine bar only.

This place has a very generous selection of wines by the glass, even larger than The Wine Room in Palo Alto (http://www.yelp.com/biz/the-wine-room-palo-alto).  They seem to specialize in Italian wines, with some Napa and Sonoma added in for variety.  Prices are okay, ranging from $8 to $15 on average (with some outliers higher than that).  The bar was packed at 10pm on a Saturday night but we were able to sit down along the far wall (away from the bar).  All of the bartenders were very accommodating, even though we weren't sitting at the bar itself.

Overall, a cozy place to hang out with good company on a cold evening.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Alphabet Soup- A dinner

Incredible wine list (obviously) and sommelier was probably the most helpful of any sommelier I've talked to anywhere, yet the wines seemed ridiculously overpriced.

food was good... pizza was great, but not worth the price unless it came topped with a small studio apt.

Overall- good food and service, but not worth the prices.  I'm no cheapskate and frequently pay a pretty penny for good food, yet this meal was definitely lacking the substance that makes me not regret spending so much when I get up from the table.
author: Geri-Ayn G.

description:
It's much more than hype.

The marinara pizza is outstanding.  The service with 5pm reservations was friendly and helpful.  The olives, sourdough bread, and chocolate tart with olive oil and sea salt, delicious.  

The dough has depth and flavor.  Lots of char and air pockets from the intense heat.  My husband will continue to perfect his dough making skills at home and we'll revisit A 16 for more pizza perfection!  

Better than Delfina if the above Neapolitan crust is your preference.  Close in line with Pizzeria Picco  in Larkspur.
author: Colleen C.

description: Went to A 16 on the recommendation of the bartender at Nectar (also a fun place for wine tasting).  A great find!  It was a busy Wed. night and we were seated at the "bar" in front of the wood ovens where all the food is prepared.  Very entertaining.  We shared a pizza, margharita with fennel sausage, excellent pizza, thin crispy crust and the sausage was very tasty.  Also had the fresh spring pea salad, very good, I could have eaten two, I love fresh peas!  Nice wine selection; we would love to go back and try some of the other entrees; the rabbit and the chicken and the chickpea dish looked really good too.  As for the "yuppie Marina" thing that other reviews speak of, that is what makes it fun.  Great people watching.
author: Laylee D.

description: Pretty good but not fantastic.  Perhaps the name keeps this place packed.  Unless I'm in the area and can get a table during happy hour or the first wave I probably won't seek this place out.  There's just a lot better Italian places in SF with better pricing than A16
author: Michelle M.

description:
So I went here on a Sunday night, as I had heard so many bad things about going on the weekends. I have to say I was very happy. Even though it was a Sunday, the place was very full. Good mix of people and the bar was packed. We had a nice table towards the back, seating is pretty tight.
For food we had the Mozzarella Burrata, Ricotta Gnocchi, and the Margherita Pizze. All were very good and extremely fresh. There was just two of us and this was plenty of food.  Would have liked to have a dessert, but I was just too full.
Wine list is huge and very interesting. The staff was very helpful and extremely attentive. I am looking forward to my next visit!
author: Lisa A.

description:
Wow, I don't know if my expectations were too high but I was not impressed with A16. Having just come back from Italy where I ate some of the most amazing Italian fare in the world, A16 left me feeling jipped and unsatisfied. 

I started with the beet salad which to be honest, tasted like some weird version of a homemade potato salad - something you would bring to a picnic. It tasted of mustard and was smothered in crumbled almonds. For whatever reason, it just didn't work for me. The gnocchi we ordered was probably the highlight of the evening for me - completely tender and filled with ricotta cheese. The pizza was just eh. I'm a big fan of thin crust pizza but this lacked something...it wasn't crispy enough and the pizza itself, even with prosciutto on it, seemed to lack flavor. 

The dessert was by far the worst part of the evening. We ordered the chocolate tart and for whatever reason, it was jam packed full of rock salt. Every bite tasted like I had just consumed 3 days worth of sodium. I kept on eating thinking that I would eventually get why they would serve this to humans (seemed more suitable to place in front of a cow as a salt lick) but had to stop because I could feel my stomach bloat from water retention.

Service was good and the wine that I ordered was enjoyable. I had no idea the restaurant itself was so large! It seemed to go back for miles.  This is definitely a lively spot and would consider coming back  again to try something else...maybe we missed the mark as far as dishes-to-order but for now, 2.5 Stars...3 at best.
author: Julia N.

description:
I've been to A16 a handful of times but decided to Yelp about it after being taken there last week on a date. First of all, kudos to homeslice for the restaurant selection...gentlemen, write this one down.

Once you get over the fact that you're in the Marina (ugh), the restaurant is really incredibly romantic. Every girl likes candle light and cozy Italian ambiance. They have a great wine selection, I adore the prosciutto platter and you can't go wrong with any of their pizza selections.

It's true, their service is a little slow, but if you read more of my reviews you will see that I kind of like that. I like being left alone to get lost in my conversation with someone...just keep my wine glass full and I'm good.

A16...check it out. I actually feel guilty for living in North Beach and recommending a Marina spot for Italian. Eh...fuhgeddaboutit
author: Lynsey C.

description: Very hit or miss menu that can be delicious or a source of regret. Very annoying Marina clientele heavy on the douchebags. Too inconsistent and crowded to be worth the money.
author: Jacqueline A.

description:
This is a neighborhood gem. It's not uncommon to find me at the bar enjoying a Traviso pizza, a half-dish of fresh squid ink pasta, a plate of house made ciccoli, or braised meatballs. While the whole menu is tempting, it's hard for me to break away from my favorites. I truly love to cook, but A-16 gives me a number of great reasons to stay out of my kitchen. 
The bartenders always have great wine recommendations and seem to love watching everyone enjoy the delicious food. This is everything a neighborhood restaurant should be. If you don't call the Marina or PacHeights home, this restaurant is well worth the trip to a different part of the city and the hassle of finding parking.
author: Pamela B.

description:
I've been dying to try A16 ever since it opened, what, 5 years ago? For whatever reason, I've never made it down the hill for a try until last week when I had a business lunch here.

Granted, it was one of the really, really hot days in the city and there was neither air conditioning or a fan in the restaurant so it was unbearably hot and its possible this tainted to my review  a bit.

The good:

The wine list. Great selection. I had a couple glasses (yes, I said this was a business lunch) and they were both great. Granted, I was gulping them down trying to escape the heat, but they were good.

The Service was great. Our waitress was very sweet, knowledgeable and on the ball. I felt bad for her running around in the heat but I never saw her sweat!

The not so good:

The bathroom. There is only one for girls and one for boys and they are in the main hallway so you have to wait for a while and you feel sort of stupid in the hallway while waiting and dodging the waiters bustling by and you feel even stupider when you come out of the bathroom and there is a line of people standing RIGHT outside the door hoping that you would hurry the hell up. Its just strange.

The menu. There was nothing on it! I seriously struggled to figure out what to eat for lunch. There were no pasta dishes to speak of. There were no lunch salads. There were a couple of pizzas, a sausage entree and some sparse salads. In the end, I ordered the meatballs. Just meatballs and sauce...that was it. They were very good, but it was really a boring meal. My dining partners each had pizzas which were way too big for a single/lunch serving. Neither pizza was very exciting.

The heat! It was stifling. I had to go home afterward and take a shower. I realize its way too much to expect restaurants to have A/C here, but a few fans would have gone a very long way.

I doubt I would be back, unless it was just to enjoy some wine at the bar.
author: Megan L.

description:
A 16 is one of my favorite go-to places in San Fran.  I love it!!  The foods fresh and light Italian.  The wine menu is insane -- I love any of the wines grown in the volcanic regions as they have such rich complex flavors.  I recommend the Barata cheese appetizer that comes drizzled with olive oil and sea salt.  Me and one of my good girlfriends insists on each getting our own as we can't bare to share.  Also tasty, the mushroom gnocchi comes in a light and flavorful clear broth.  I highly recommend. 

Also, I don't think the service is as bad as people make it out to be.  Our server was always around when we needed her.  The one downside I have to say is the tables are a bit tight and for whatever reason, some people just don't seem to get the concept of personal space.  Maybe all the good wine makes them feel a bit more friendly towards me than I would like.  And this coming from a girl use to NY crowds ...
author: Catherine S.

description: Tried it twice now. After hearing such great things , thought the first time was a fluke. Nothing was BAD, but I felt like I could have made better pasta at home. Everything was just mediocre. The pasta was just so so, the soup was the best part, the chicken was good, but nothing extraordinary. Must save, service was bad. Almost did two stars bad. Will not be going back, too many good restaurants to try. Now flour and Water ...THATS italian food.
author: Jen B.

description: A 16 is a near-perfect dining experience-delicious but not pretentious, reasonably priced, and incredible service.  Order the burrata, and you really can't go wrong from there.
author: Jen T.

description:
came here for lunch and a16 was a-ok.

we shared the prosciutto and i was surprised it didn't come with anything else. just sliced ham. no fruit, no bread... after i tasted it, i realized, hey it didn't need anything. it was delicious just as is.

i then had the home-made Cavatelli with cherry tomatoes, summer squash flowers, basil, chiles and pecorino and it was so good. pasta cooked to perfection. fresh sweet cherry tomatoes that popped in my mouth and sweet summer squash for some crunch. its the best when your dish isn't drenched with sauce. bravo on this dish!

my bf had the Salsiccia Pizza with fennel sausage, roasted peppers, mozzarella, grana padano, garlic, chiles. This pizza was okay. I thought it was just spicy. the crust was a little soggy in the middle, but my bf ate the whole thing and wanted more.

thumbs up: friendly service, home-made pasta, no wait, warm olive oil with rustic bread.
thumbs down: we were seated in the very corner, a very tight space where a larger gentleman was occupying a lot of room... i had to slide into my chair, sideways, and couldn't scoot back. my boyfriend had to pull the table closer to him on the booth side. i didn't understand why they couldn't seat us somewhere else.
author: Lauren Y.

description: This place is so cute!  Very nice and trendy atmosphere and decor.  Make sure to make reservations or you'll be waiting a while.  The food was pretty good but I wouldn't say AMAZING.  They have this semi-outdoor back patio that's really nice =)
author: Josephine C.

description:
If you are looking for Italian food I would not go to A16.  There are so many other places in SF that are much better.  This place is so over hyped. 

I would suggest trying it once and forming your own opinion.
author: Chris L.

description:
Took my mom from out of town here, and was disappointed with:

- the front desk service.  It was fine, but did not meet the expectations of the place.  Example - we were told by the front desk that we could sit sooner than our reservation if we took a table at the bar surrounding the kitchen, which we decided to do.  We sat there at the same time as the reservation, without so much as a mention as to why it was delayed from the offer 25 minutes earlier.
- the food.  Preparation and plating was gorgeous, and my mom's pasta was great, but my pork shoulder was not great - too large a portion (yep), and all the ingredients just didn't gel.  Also, isn't Budino supposed to be thick?  Ours was a mousse.  Flour and Water's kills this one.

2 appetizers, 2 entrees, 2 glasses of wine, and one dessert totaled about $108, which is expected for this kind of place, but I'd rather spend that money at Delfina, Aperto, or Flour and Water going forward.  Disappointed.
author: Rob P.

description: This is great pizza and i love the toppings.    Close to Giovanni's in Sacramento except Giovanni's crust is tastier and a little more crispier.
author: Alexander C.

description: I went to A 16 with a friend on a Thursday a couple of weeks ago and had a great experience. There was about a 45 minute wait if you didn't have any reservations. Luckily it took us forever to park but by the time we did they had called my cell to tell me the table was ready. To start we had the Mozzarella Burrata then we ordered a bottle of chardonnay ($52) and finished up with their cheese pizza, we made the good call of adding prosciutto to the pizza and they literally cover the pie with a thin layer of the stuff. We definitely return...
author: Michael C.

description:
This is one of the better pizzas I have had in the US (definitely top 5).  I have ONLY eaten their pizzas, since I am such a pizza fanatic.

The Margherita is the real deal and holds its crisp even better than those found in Naples, Italy.  Their sausage is very tasty and goes on the pie fresh (as it should).  

It is a bit pricey, but what the heck it is a lot cheaper than flying to Italy.  I recommend going early in the evening to avoid the wait for a seat.
author: Brad K.

description: Really cute place but I have been there 4 times and EVERY time horrible service. Food is ok, not great. Meh.
author: Andrea C.

description:
something about this place didn't hit a fuzzy spot in my heart.

Granted, I'm not the biggest fan of said Italian fare, this place def was the greatest either.  Where shall we begin... as my followers know, I'm a fan of the "tapas" style dining- more food to devour.  I started the the burrata- nearly perfect. It could stand alone, the sign of a great dish.  The crackers it was served with must've been the same ones Jesus broke bread with because dear sweet Lord.. I nearly lost a filling!  

Next off- zuchini something or other. A medium sized plate of thinly sliced zucchini with olive oil, parm, and olives. I could have made this piece at home and saved myself (or my date hehe) 12 bucks.  Too light to actually sustain anyone. You'd be tired of the taste before you were near satiated.  The pumpkin gnocci wasn't as dense as I'm accustomed to, but the texture was pleasant. It either came out cold or wasn't fully warm to begin with.  Next time I'd prob just convince someone else to order it and steal off their plate (works every time).
author: Kai P.

description:
I am revising my A16 review a bit.  I did not care for the restaurant the first time I went.  It was too crowded very noisy and the food was just okay.  I went for a second time almost a year later.  It was Halloween and the restaurant was not very crowded.  I could actually hear what the people in my group were saying this time!  

My husband and I have been searching for authentic Italian pizza ever since we got back from our honeymoon in Italy.  A16 totally nailed it.  Their desserts are still really lacking.  I have never had a good dessert here and I have now tasted 4 of the options.  I got a carmel gelato, how can you go wrong?  Well they did.  It tasted like very burnt sugar.  Well I will go back for the pizza!
author: Diane R.

description:
On a Monday night whim, the beau and I decided to venture to the Marina for dinner. After much menu reading along Chestnut, the beau decides that A16 would be his #1 preference. I personally would have chosen a different place, but couldn't refuse after seeing how excited he got over the A16 offerings. 

The place was packed, but we were still able to get 2 table choices--a  regular one or one that sits alongside the kitchen. Being the total kitchen enthusiast that he is, of course the beau immediately chooses the latter option. At this point, I was not too happy. Whenever we sit in those type of seats (and we often do, thanks to the beau), I always return home smelling like the aromas of the kitchen for days. However,  it turned out to be an excellent choice. Not only was it very well ventilated but in this kitchen, the cooks are facing you (vs. the usual restaurants where you are staring at their backs & butts). Being able to see the action was quite fun! 

Our meal consisted of the following:

-grilled sardines: The appetizer should never be overlooked in terms of importance because it sets the tone for the meal. This was a perfect balance of flavors and textures. Definitely gave us much to look forward to.

-funghi pizza: super fresh with top quality ingredients (enormous in size too). Everything is made in-house. Thin crust with just the right amount of cheese, sauce, and other toppings. I'm not even a huge fan of pizza, but I'd be willing to eat this any time it's offered. 

-lamb w/ a side of carrots: Oh my gosh, so good. Even after I was feeling stuffed, I was still trying to get as much of it as possible into my mouth. And it really doesn't do justice to call the carrots a "side." That makes it sound so trivial. Trust me, it is anything but that. Those carrots could definitely hold its own ground.

-Yogurt panna cotta: if you've read any of my previous reviews, you'd know that we always go for the panna cotta. It's the beau's favorite dessert--and we're even willing to forego the bread pudding special (that just means left over bread from the weekends, anyway). HEAVY panna cotta with shortbread & citrus. Nice pairing. Very filling.

-Meatball (to go): Hey, it was Meatball Monday! And sitting by the kitchen, we saw those plated meatballs fly out every other minute. A crowd favorite, obviously. Miss out on something this good? Not us. You always gotta plan for tomorrow's lunch!

5 stars without a hint of a doubt. So memorable that we will be talking about this dinner for months to come.

And oh, listen to your beau (or mine) and sit by the kitchen.
author: Rona J.

description: Loved the service, the environment, and especially the WINE list.  However, the options for lunch were minimal, and a bit on the gourmet side.  The pizza was large, but the sauce and cheese smaller portions.  Loved the pasta dish, and bread with olive oil.  Server was both professional and friendly, took his time to explain the menu to us  I would try dinner next visit.
author: Neice K.

description:
I made a reservation at A 16 for my birthday. I heard and read amazing reviews of the pizza and was really looking forward to the experience. Let me break it down: 

Food - Pizza was good. I would give it 3.5 stars on it's own. But, compared to other pizza places in San Francisco, I think it deserves only three stars. I prefer Delfina and Pizzetta 211 for thin-crust pizza. If you are opening the playing field to include the east bay, Gather in Berkeley and Pizzaiolo in Oakland are the way to go! 

Service - Two stars. I was a server for many years in many restaurants from super casual to high end...and I always give service the benefit of the doubt because I know how difficult it can be. The table was not ready on time - ummm, ok, not the end of the world. But after waiting a good 10-15 min beyond the reservation time, I would expect the server to be attentive. Not so. Our server did not show up to the table for another 5-10 min after we were seated. Our drinks came after our appetizer (I have gotten chewed out by former bosses when this happens). She was perfectly friendly, but the overall service was not what I would expect from such a highly rated establishment. 

Overall, I'm glad I went. However, I don't think I'll be returning any time soon - or recommending it to friends. There are way too many GREAT pizza places to try!
author: Robyn G.

description:
This is my home away from home. Only girlfriends and family can come to my nest with me.  Sorry, no Daddys allowed.  

I call it No Man's Land, because no man will come between me and my A16  crew:  Andrew, Benito, Tim and Kevin. 

The pizza is addictive, with a perfectly charred crust, balanced out with a nice sauce featuring fresh and locally grown ingredients. For an extra kick, if you've got the spine, order the chili oil, then pour a hefty drizzle on.   

This is also a friendly, non-snobby wine bar. Just step right up and tell the excellent sommeliers what kind of wine you're looking for. Don't even bother looking at the wine menu. It's always fun to sample various flavors without a big commitment. Hmmm, now I'm sounding like my brothers.   

The fine and amenable staff will keep bringing you choices you until you're happy. Just like the shoe department at Nordstrom.  

I also love the beef short ribs, the stewed green beans, the arugula with peaches and olives.  And the desserts are all very good, sweet and yummy... unlike me. 

Overall: Truly, I consider this my little slice of heaven. No matter what  mood I walk in with, the crew, the food and the wine combine to put a big happy smile in this girl's heart when I walk back home.
author: CharliesAngel L.

description: HORRIBLE FOOD......The menu looks extremely appetizing, but it was awful..Three of my friends and I went and we all felt the same way...So not worth the money..
author: L B.

description:
This place made me believe in pizza again. Before I had dinner here, pizza for me had become a poor caricature of itself: gooey, doughy, a vomitorium of toppings. But then I tried the Salsiccia, which has fennel sausage, spring onions, grana padano, fresh mozzarella, garlic, and chiles. No drippy sauce (no tomato sauce at all in fact), no gummy crust, no lava flow of mozzarella, no garbage dump of toppings. Just a light thin crust of perfectly cooked dough supporting a cast of savory ingredients that perfectly harmonize into one delicious eating experience.

The atmosphere here is pretty trendy and noisy, and it seems to be a popular place for groups. The service, as a result, seems a bit harried and distracted, but they are for the most part friendly and helpful.

They also have a pretty interesting selection of wines from Southern Italy, which I know nothing about. So before ordering that glass, ask the server to pour you a tiny sip (if s/he has the time) so you can test it out. I made the mistake of ordering a full glass upon the recommendation of our server, but I ended up not liking it -- or rather, I did not think it went well with my oh so glorious slices of heaven.

Great food. Fun place. See for yourself.
author: Paul L.

description:
pizza's and wine lists get five stars,   only two for the pastas and other dishes.  I absolutely love that you can get one scoop of gelato or sorbeto for dessert as after stuffing my face with the pizza it's all I can do to roll down the street to wherever we managed to hide the miata.

update on 2.6.07   I think that this place has great service.  My husband and I are in our early sixties and we are always treated nicely and with a smile.  We like to sit at the counter and watch them make the pizza.
I love the Romano  one   anchovies, olives,hot peppers no cheese,
really really a great pizza.
author: Susanne C.

description:
Molto bene!  The food is very authentic Italian.  It reminded me of what I ate when I studied abroad in Florence many years ago.  The mozzarella appetizer is out of this world.  I seriously want to call A16 to find out where they buy it, because I've never tasted anything so good.  The wine selection is also top notch.  

I had to give this four stars because it's so crowded and loud in the restaurant, which was a buzz kill.  But, the friendly staff goes out of their way to make you feel welcome.  I will be going back again for sure.
author: Emily S.

description:
I experienced A 16 for the first time tonight and was slightly disappointed. I have heard many positive remarks, but the restaurant did not live up to the expectations.

The atmosphere was great offering a snappy casual / metro feel. The pizzas are great, but the sole my mother ordered tasted too fishy and lacked seasoning. I also found it interesting that they do not serve diet coke or any diet soft drinks. Funny.

This restaurant would be a great place to grab a drink or a quick appetizer, but for dinner the entrees lacked spark and the appeal that draws eagerness back. 

You will be happy to experience the restaurant, but I doubt you will rush back seeing as there are other more impressive Italian restaurants in the Bay area. The hype didn't live up to the expectations except if you want a gormé pizza.
author: Leslie C.

description: This place is tough for me.  It gets a lot of hype, but compared to other hot SF spots, it's the pits.  The gnocchi was watered down and was so bad that I didn't finish it and ended up eating somewhere else after we left.
author: Dan N.

description: Always come to eat at a16 and i am always very satisfied! The people at the bar are soo helpful and they never gave up on us when we wanted a specific wine and couldn't remember the name, the gentleman at the bar helped us and never gave up, he also found the wine...our server Christina was soo awesome! She went above any normal server and asked the kitchen if they could put onions on my pizza (when it wasnt an option) the staff was beyond great and i will b coming back..and spreading the word!
author: Angelica O.

description: The food at A16 is amazing. But, I have never had good service in probably the six times I have dined at A16. We went for my birthday and the wine didn't come out until after we had finished our appetizers. The waitress kept saying they couldn't find the wine we ordered and someone was going to come by our table to help us choose something comparable. But that someone didn't show up until we had finished all of our appetizers. It would have been more appropriate to hold the appetizers until we had chosen a different wine. Instead of comping something we had ordered, they added in a dessert  at the end as a peace offering for the wine fiasco. Better than not acknowledge the poor service at the beginning of the meal I suppose. Best service is when sitting at the bar.
author: Adrienne P.

description:
This is my first restaurant review out of 4 restaurants on my trip to san francisco. Thanks to Chef Roy, whom i worked with the last year, i got the VIP treatment from the chef de cuisine that night. Chef Appleman (James Beard nominee 2007 best new chef) went to school with Chef Roy at the CIA. however, he was in italy so chef roy told me to introduce myself to the chef de cuisine, Chef Liza. things only got better from there. 

Being from LA, i never expect a restaurant to be busy on a monday night. holy crap, never in my life have i seen so many people packed into a restaurant at 9pm on a monday night. so to start off with i ordered the roasted calamari and meatballs. man those meatballs were out of this world. its not on the menu because they only serve these porky/beefy morsels of goodness on monday. actually i would not have ordered them until chef liza told me about them. the calamari was cooked perfectly tender with a tangy pickled chili salad. then a complimentary plate of house cured lonza came out. yum. i love anything that is cured and made of pork. good balance b/w fat and meat. 

then the pizza came out. as i mentioned in my earlier reviews, antica pizzeria  was/is my favorite pizza place because they are one of the few places that are certified by the italian gov't. once our funghi pizza came out and i took the first bite, i knew this was certified by the italians. man was it good. the crust was chewy and charred. man was it good with their homemade chili oil. i could literally put that stuff on anything. 

then was our pasta course(s). i ordered the tonnarelli (fresh spaghettia pasta) with pork, tomatoes, and corona beans. the beans were whole and mashed and it gave the sauce a creamy velvety texture. very flavorful. then the complimentary anson mills polenta came out. little pieces of guanciale (cured porked jowl) and fava beans topped it off. perfect. by this time i couldnt move out of my chair. 

ordered a meyer lemon sorbetto and a machiatto and called it a night. talked to the chef for a little bit (only because it was 11:30 and the customers finally died down) and went on my way. great way to start of the week in the bay city.
author: Daniel K.

description:
My Mom's fave food is Italian and when she comes into town, I frantically try to find an Italian place to impress her with. 

Let's just say that my track record isn't so good. 

In comes A16. First off, I should have known that my Mom would love it. It's in the Marina, where she repeats over and over that she would live here if she lived in SF (like mother, NOT like daughter), it's charmingly cozy, and the menu has local specials depending on the season and the day. We had the fava bean appetizer, which changed my outlook on those green, flavorless beans (they do have flavor!), the prosciutto sampler platter (and it is BIG), the pizza romano (we're suckers for anchovies) and a half bottle of a beautiful southern Italian red wine that has too many apostrophes in the name to remember. The waiters were very friendly and patient while we decided and asked repeatedly about wines and what they like, etc.... The prices were not too shabby either! I could go with my bf, my girlfriends or hell, the next time my mom is in town.

[Me grinning] Success!
author: Defne A.

description:
Although the hostess said the wait would be about an hour, we got a call saying our table was ready in about 20-30 minutes.  From the hostess station, the restaurant appears not to be very big.  However, this impression would be wrong.  A larger dining room with an open kitchen is set behind the bar area and there is another dining area after that one.  

Having read about Nate Appleman's departure from San Francisco and his impending NYC pizzeria, I wanted to sample some of the goods that made him famous.  I ordered the funghi pizza with pancetta and egg.  I'm not sure the egg added anything, but the pancetta and mushrooms were great.   I didn't even notice the lack of tomato sauce on the pizza.  

The size of the pizza is also pretty good.  I think two people could easily share a pizza and a small pasta or a pizza and two appetizers.  

Also, make sure you order the burrata, which was recommended by the waitress, as an appetizer.  This was my first time experiencing burrata, but if Mr. Appleman brings this burrata to NYC, I'll be seeing him in the Bowery
author: Larry L.

description:
Yay.  I can finally write a review for this joint and not just say 'the pizza rocks!".  

Mind you, the pizza DOES rock.  I have dined there 3 times now.  Here's what I have ordered and the ratings:

-Margarita Pizza:  To me, this is a wow.  Very very similar to the ones I have had in Italy.  Super thin bottom crust, a nice thick outer crust, light mild tangy tomato sauce, random placed pieces of mozzarella, and strips of fresh basil.  YUM.
-Cold cut meat plate:  Nothing super fantastic, but it did come with a variety of cuts that were so-so.  Good if you were looking to eat that, but otherwise, probably pass the next time.  Good selection, however.
-Tuna conserva - Eh, again, not my cup of tea, but my two friends were all over it.  The tuna was warm - not a fan.  It was tossed in red cabbage and other mix greens.
-Beef short ribs genovese:  OMG.  Like the ox-tail grandma used to make when you were little.  Sweet, layers of reduction and char, and the ribs were tender like marshmallows.  This rib-less concoction definitely made me forget all the other par apps.

I really cant wait to dig deeper.  Will update more.

As far as the wine list, if you not Italian-oriented, you will be overwhelmed.  I wasn't sure to just go with the prices or really dig into the meat of the 20 some odd paged wine list.  We opted for a couple glasses the bartender suggested, but they were crappy.  However, there seemed to be quite a selection and if I had the time, I would of requested a sommelier to help pair our food.

The ambiance is great.  RIGHT in between upscale and casual.  The really made the place work - feels very New Yorkish with very detailed yet soft decor.  Lots of nice lines, fun marble counter tops (chef's table), a wood burning oven (very fun to watch the cooks manage that thing), and nice low-set lighting.  Fun for dates, close friends, and entertaining guests.  Might be bad for a large crowd, but you could try.

One HUGE takeway - make reservations.  It definitely is a hit or miss with walk-ins, but be aware, you possibly can get stiffed with a 2 hour wait.

http://www.a16sf.com/Menu.html
author: Isaac L.

description:
I've been to A16 a few times now and here is what you should get:
-halibut cheeks. so good and coated in almonds. texture sort of like crab, and although it is "cheeks" it is still halibut so you don't feel like you are eating something gross.
-mushroom pizza. delish.
-any salad with beets in it. i like beets, they are mm-mmm. 
-the gnocci. so good and the portions are small enough that you don't eat so much you feel like a fat ass. (gnocci can be like that. i asked my roommate if she liked gnocci once and she said, "i haven't had gnocci since i was fat"). 

here's what you should not get:
-the tripe. for obvious reasons i guess. thought we'd try being adventurous. bad idea. if you like warm smelly dog food go for the tripe. 
-chicory salad. boring. lame.

I'm still giving a16 5 stars because it's not their fault we ordered the cow intestines and a lame side dish. Such a great ambiance though, and we loved sitting at the chef's counter and watching the chefs cook.  Don't bitch about the wait either, because Delaneys is like 5 stores down the street and never crowded, so get a drink there while waiting.
author: Jamie G.

description: Had a good dinner with friends on a Saturday night. We ordered the Fungi pizza and another that I can't remember now. All told it was a good dinner, but nothing particularly notable.
author: Angela P.

description:
Has the world gone mad?  Perhaps the 'oh-so-exotic' tripe and salumi have passed along a little mad cow disease to my fellow foodies.

Now, I must admit I had high expectations.  After all, every time I pass A16 it is certainly bustling and the reviews have been so generous.  Yet, even if I had anticipated mediocrity I still would have been disappointed.

Though our reservations were for Sunday evening at 9:30, we were still forced to wait in the crowded bar area.  The hostess was like many a busy hostess--indifferent and impersonal--who can blame her with such a terrible scheduling system!?

The decor itself is beautiful and cozy.  The open kitchen fills the main room with flavorful smells and warmth.  Lots of warmth.  If it gets any hotter in there we'll all come with a choice of side dish.

Luckily we were seated in the back room--a sort of enclosed patio.  While it was significantly cooler and quieter, the sparse decor and partition make you feel entirely removed from the restaurant itself.

Our waitress was extremely nice, though a bit befuddled when pressed for wine suggestions.  (The shiraz we ended up with was miserable.)  Though nice, I must mention that we only saw her once after taking our order--when she dropped off the bill.  Nor did she seem to remember, or care, that a member of our party was celebrating her sixtieth birthday: neither a candle nor a cake was to be seen.

Following our blah appetizers we were hoping for the best when it came to the main courses--the bucatini, lamb, and a pizza.  

With the exception of the lamb we were extremely disappointed.  The pizza was bland and the bucatini--which was also bland--was further sullied by the overabundance of breadcrumbs.  Breadcrumbs, breadcrumbs everywhere!  Hansel and Gretel would get a kick out of A16--breadcrumbs appear like insidious guests in way too many appetizers and entrees (even when not listed on the menu).  

All in all, the experience was a waste of time and money.  We didn't enjoy our food, we didn't enjoy our service, and we didn't enjoy the tab for all this mediocrity.  Surely, this passion for A16 is like a boy band--raging for a minute and gone the next?  We can only hope for the best.
author: Kat P.

description:
The+'s:
Loved everything we had ordered for two!!!
+ sardines with fried breadcrumbs & currants ($12)
+ romaine & chicory side salad dressed with olive oil and lemon ($6)
+ margherita pizza with 2 eggs ($14 + $4). GQ Magazine had rated A16's pizza as top 20 in nation. After trying Delfina (#3) we had to see how A16 stacked up. It did. Though I prefer the pillow dough from Delfina, I would not hesitate to return to A16 for their version since the sauce is better than Delfina's. Liquid hot sauce was perfect optional condiment.
+ squid ink pasta ($18) divine with chiles and garlic
+ alas dessert was a fig raspberry crostata dressed with ricotta ice cream and pistachio bits ($8)
+ 3 bottles of sparkling water ($5 each) drove our total to $88.
+ Service attentive and not doting
+ Plates cleared constantly to start afresh for next entree--maybe not necessary for environmental reasons.
+ A16, named after highway that runs from Naples to Canosa, Puglia, was a great trip without having to book a ticket on Alitalia

The -'s:
- Must book reservation. Not into waiting.
- Street parking is painful.
author: Yiven C.

description:
Got Gilt ripped off.  Urg.  $160 + tax + tip and all I can say is this:

Pro's (ish) 

-They didn't have our reservation.  Hostess more than made up for this mistake, and got us our table a bit latish, but still really - blame Gilt?  I have used Gilt before as a business owner - and you know what they are marketing your product as, at what price, and what the discount to you as the owner is. 

-Waitress was great, super nice and informative.

-On Gilt it was worded as 4 shared meals and 4 glasses of half wine splits.  We got the first 2 meals at once with one wine, and the "2nd" and "3rd" meals and wines afterwards. 

-There is difference between a shared menu and a tasting menu. For the price, we got a VERY expensive tasting menu.  

-Gilt - don't use the word "pasta" if you are talking about fregula.  It's not the same unless you are being spot on specific.  Its like saying you serve claim chowder, and then being surprised when you serve Manhattan and the guest was expecting New England.  

-At the end, we left not feeling full, were not offered a main menu, but had our wine at the bar comped for the inconvenience.  The waitress said they had received lots of complaints and apologized.  Again she was great! 

-I wish I had spent my $200 on the Gilt dinner and gotten $200 worth of the food that everyone else around us was being served.
author: Joseph L.

description: My husband and a had a wonderful experience for dinner. The service, the wine selections and the food were exceptional. We had the two tuna appetizers, the crudo and the tuna conserva panzanella, followed by two pasta dishes--the scialatielli:and the paccheri:, both most unusual and complex creations. The olive oil served with the bread was outstanding (from Puglia).. The dessert, the chocolate budino, was also delicious and again a complex dish of three parts. We were fortunate to have a skillful waiter (Andi) who guided us thorugh the menu and the wine list . The service isn't speedy but we had 3 full courses in one and one half hours and felt the timing was just right. The noise level is a bit high but only because the restaurant was full and everyone seemed to be having a good time.
author: Mary G.

description:
recent sf trip with family.
brought the kids.
thoroughly enjoyed the meal.
kids love their pasta and fish entree.
excellent and attentive service
author: Jerry L.

description:
This place is 5 stars.   How do I know this?  Because my stomach told me (gurgle, gurgle, rumble) that their pizza is the cleanest and best in San Fran.  

For lunch on a sunny Wednesday, Thursday or Friday, try to reserve the back patio.
author: Tim G.

description:
It's a shame that people go there just to eat pizza...or don't get past the pizza on the menu.  The best dish (and the reason why I'm not a vegetarian) is short ribs stracotto.  The meat comes right off the bone.  I haven't had ribs like this since I've left Texas.  The halibut cheeks is another highlight.

My other favs are  the mozzarella burrata (it's dairy crack- can't get enough of it) and the ricotta gnocchi with squash blossoms is delish.  All the desserts were divine.  Chocolate tart with sea salt and olive oil was a great combination.

The wine selection is superb.  This has got to be one of my best meals in SF.   The wait staff was really cool and no attitude.  Wait a minute...was I in the Marina?
author: Julia H.

description:
You know, we had a really great meal here on a Saturday nght.  True, it's very marina-ish (um, it IS in the Marina), but that's fine.  We stopped by without a reservation, and we only had to wait about 20 mins before we were seated.  Enjoyed some so-so Syrah while we waited.

The mozzarella appetizer was just downright excellent--it's a real must-have.  Trust me.  The pizza was delicious (I think we had the salsiccia--sausage).  After the pizza, per our waiter's recommendation (to eat in this sequence, that is), we had some of their house-cured solumi (oh YUM--melt-in-your-mouth-yum), the chard salad and some pasta.  The pasta was okay, nothing fantabulous, but it was just the right amount.

The sommelier gets special kudos--in complete contrast to the wine we drank while waiting for our table, she really did a bang-up job of recommending a fantastic wine in our price range that went with our food and fit our tastes.  And she did that with class and without making us feel foolish at all.  She made the meal that much more enjoyable.

We're going back.
author: Jason L.

description:
Whenever out of towners ask me where to go for a great meal in the Marina (or anywhere in the city, for that matter), I point them in the direction of A16.

A16 is a terrific restaurant. Packed almost always, it's both a typical Marina scene, a family restaurant, or a great date spot. It's hard to go wrong with the menu--the pizzas are really good but my personal favorite is the tuna and a side of mini corn...amazing!
Definitely do NOT skip on the desserts. For $6 you can get two scoops of gelato or sorbet. The huckleberry sorbet and chocolate gelato are hands down the best sorbet/gelato I've ever had. Truly delicious. Their wine list is tremendous.

The ambiance at A16 is really lovely. There is a patio in the back of the restaurant and a dim, dark wine bar in front. The restaurant is long and narrow, but the main dining room is somewhat sunny and overall very pleasant. 

You really can't go wrong with A16, it always impresses.
author: Sophie D.

description: Great food but a really long wait. Make sure to get reservations because I waited for over an hour on a Friday night. It was worth it though! The waiters were very knowledgable, the food very good and loved the extensive wine list. I'd definitely go back!
author: Karin Z.

description: You have to get a reservation here , the food is really good, great pizza and pasta, and great wine selection
author: P E.

description:
After all the ranting and raving about how amazing and delicious this place was, I finally made it over there after reservations were less difficult to come by. The space is nice, good amience -
But after all the hype, I was less than impressed. The entrees were mediorce   - we got the lamb and the shortribs - both which were overly fatty and had some pretty boring sauces.. the salad that accompanied it was nothing special.
The best part of the meal was the prosciutto appetizer.
I would definitely stick with the house cured meats and the pizzas at this place. For all the hype, San Francisco definitely has better options then this.
author: Melissa W.

description:
had a wonderful dinner with friends here.  love the design of the restaurant and overall atmosphere.  would be a great place for a romantic dinner date.

we ordered:
burrata - good, but not incredibly impressive.
canneloni type dish with swordfish - very flavorful and unique.
maccaronara - not your standard ragout.  very flavorful as well.  would definitely recommend or order again.

i'm dying to try the roasted pumpkin bruschetta when i come back!
author: Lindsay Z.

description:
A16 - what were you thinking?  You kept us waiting for 50 minutes for a 7:30 Sunday reservation with out-of-town guests.  You didn't offer us a glass of anything while we waited, and you pretended to be captivated by your reservations screen rather than address the unhappy customers you were ignoring.  

Once our table was ready, you assured us the manager would stop by our table to apologize.  That never happened.  Once we sat down, you moved us to a larger table (thank you) which took an additional 15 minutes to set-up for some reason (no thanks).  Our server was friendly enough, but slower than molasses.  She got the order wrong twice, and we were left thirsty for most of the meal.  

After the ordeal you like to call "dinner" was over and we stated our complaints to your "manager" (who, as it turned out, was only the sommelier), she didn't do even the smallest thing to make it better - she wouldn't say "sorry."  If you had ONLY said that, we might have come back another time.  But you couldn't even muster that.  So, instead of giving you repeat business, I will now take pleasure in trashing your name to anyone who asks.  You can take your Marina attitude and shove it very far up your conceited ass.

BTW - your food was so so.  And over-priced.  You pretty much suck all around.
author: Preston B.

description:
Celebrated a friend's birthday here last night and the food was spot on. The wine was flowing and well paired and the pizza was close to perfect (this is a WOP from Brooklyn talkin so, know that the pizza compliments are far and few between) 

Our waitress was knowledgeable and fun and cute as was the manager, Kelly, who is a super star! She  knows how to make a party feel comfy and special. Plus, that chick knows her wines! 

I was with a big group of good eaters and we tried most everything on the menu. i was pleasantly surprised to discover that the dish I kept going back to was goat. Er, yeah. But so fuckin good. 

Whatever, I'm into goat now. So?

I was too hammered by the time dessert arrived to make a comment but I heard that I liked the sweet ricotta and shortbread. 

One warning: The pizza ovens make the place rather warm so don't wear a turtle neck or wool or anything. Actually, never wear a turtleneck.

Oh, and the crowd can be weird, but who cares?!? Go with the people you like, get drunk, eat a lot, and dress scantily!
author: cynthia p.

description:
Margherita pizza - good flavor, except a little too burnt on the crusts for my liking. I like my food less carcinogenic. 

Funghi pizza - served as a white pizza. If you like yours with tomato sauce, be sure to ask for it. Didn't care too much for the flavor although it would have been enhanced by a little oil whether it be truffle or olive oil. It too was a bit too burnt on the crust which gave it a bitter taste.

Meat balls - sauce was nice but the texture of the meatballs was not so great...like they added to many breadcrumbs and it just didn't hold together.

Cavatelli pasta - nice and toothsome pasta. Funky looking...a little like larvae, but had a nice texture and was a homemade pasta. Good flavor of pork ragu.

Bread - I loved their bread. It was fresh and obviously homemade.

Service - waitress was aloof and didn't seem to really care to be serving us and didn't say g'bye or thank us although looked right at us, when the rest of the staff thanked us for coming and and told us happy new year as we walked past. 

Neither the service nor the meal (even tho the bread was fabulous) was good enough to draw us back although our experience was for lunch. Maybe they jazz it up for dinner?
author: Lola Z.

description:
It seems to be a trendy place with chef counter seating. I sat at the counter and followed the chef's performance all the time.  But I still didn't see how my food was prepared. The Escarole salad was simple but good. Squid ink cavatelli was scaring and I felt like eating a plate of worms. But the pasta itself was good. 

Too full so we only ordered the house made ice cream. The ice cream had good texture (smooth and milky) and good flavor too (for the tea type we ordered). 

May go back just for its ice cream.
author: Ile F.

description:
Not that this 612th review of A16 will matter much in the grand scheme of things, but since it was my 3rd time in there (2nd to eat and once just for drinks) I figure I should share my experiences...

Anyhow we went for a late dinner with my friends Lara, Maryann and Dave and ran into other friends making it feel very small town as SF often does.  Although I felt like a wuss drinking a 'blushing angel' it was a nice light cocktail to start off the evening.

When we sat down we ended up doing everything family style and every thing we had was fantastic from the wine to the mozzarella (OMG!), and of course their signature pizzas.  We were craving the pumpkin gnocchi but had let our eyes outdo our stomachs so held back.  

The meatballs were nice and balanced with some spice but not overly heavy.  We also saved room for dessert and although I can't recall what the items were officially called - we called it Apple and Chocolate since those were the primary elements of each dessert - both proving to be very satisfying finishes to a great meal shared with friends (this I would say is the preferred way to dine at A16).
author: Gene X.

description: I waited a LONG time to try this place. I tried grabbing lunch here on multiple occasions, but it was always closed. I finally took the time to make a reservation and went here last week for lunch. Yes, it was good, but was it worth driving from Soma to the Marina for? No. Delfina or Flour+Water beats it for pizza no question, and Zero Zero is stiff competition. I had the chard as an appetizer and it was delicious as was the soup, but I was honestly a little disappointed with the pizza. Yes, it was good, but I'm surprised it's consistently been on the list of the Chronicle's Top 100 Bay Area Restaurants. I'd try it again if I were in the Marina, but don't think I'll ever go out of my way to go here again.
author: Kathryn M.

description: We enjoyed the restaurant very much. My boyfriend and I went there with his cousin and her husband who love the restaurant and have been many times. My boyfriend was especially excited to go, since they feature the type of food from the region of Italy that their family is from, and we will be visiting in the fall for a wedding. The food was amazing, we let our cousins husband take control and order many different dishes, so we all ate family style and were able to try more things than we normally would have. The wines that were ordered were very good, they have a huge wine list mostly of imported Italian wines and a few from California as well. Our waitress was an absolute joy, she was just so sweet and bubbly, very helpful and just a lot of fun. It's obvious that A16 is the place to be, the restaurant was full of people the entire time and I can see why. The only criticism I have was for the front of the house. My boyfriend and I had our table reserved for 6pm knowing that his cousin and her husband would be running a few minutes later than us. When we got there, the hostess told us that we could wait for them at the tiny stool area right at the front by the door across from the bar which was full. We ordered a couple of glasses of wine from the bar, but felt very in the way right there in the front. The 2 girls were standing behind the podium right next to us & talking to each other about all kinds of things, and we finally asked if we could go to our table. One of them replied that they prefer we wait until the rest of our party comes because it throws off the flow of the restaurant. Being in the restaurant business ourselves, we have never heard of such a thing and were kind of shocked! A few minutes later, my boyfriend got one of the girls' attention to give them our credit card (we wanted to make sure that we paid for dinner since we invited them) Well, shortly after that she got our attention and took us to our table even though the rest of our party hadn't arrived. I guess since A16 is the hottest restaurant in town they don't have to have their customer service skills as polished as their recipes. But our server made up for it all, she was great! So needless to say, after the slightly rough beginning, our time at the restaurant was very nice. And we look forward to coming back nest time we visit the Bay Area.
author: Helen L.

description:
We had reservations, so we were seated promptly despite the mob-scene at the door. That was the last good thing that happened all night. 

The menu was brief enough that we both had a hard time finding more than one thing that appealed to us. We split an order of roasted red peppers to start. The fresh sardines garnish was good, but the peppers themselves weren't peeled (possibly intentional?) or seeded...very unappetizing. 

My husband ordered the pizza margherita -- it was decent, but not actively good. The crust was too thin in the center, not crisp, and too thick at the edges.  I ordered the pizza verde... what a train wreck. Crust was sprinkled with red chile flakes (good), a little bit of olive oil (not enough), 4 or 5 small slices of cheese (good, perhaps not quite enough), and something like 2 cups of sliced sweet italian peppers (also not skinned or seeded). Even for an american style pie, this overdose of topping would have been unappetizing... for an Italian-style pizza one, it was a disgrace. There was literally 3/4 of an inch of solid peppers burying the crust. 

Service was sloppy: We were done with our appetizer before our wine flights came, and the waiter dropped scraped-up food from another table onto ours when clearing our plates... eww. 

For as difficult as it was to get a reservation here, I certainly expected better. I can't believe this is supposed to be one of the Top 50 restaurants in SF!
author: anita c.

description:
Chocolate tart with salt is the best!!!

Great food, good quality, super small spaces between tables. It is pretty tiny, we were enjoying dessert when my husband had to move a bit to get away from the table next to us who were eating sardines...Don't really want to smell sardines while going goo goo gaa gaa over chocolate!

Appetizer was tasty (burrata, really really tasty), the pasta and pizza were super delicious!

Will come back with a larger party, not exactly a quiet spot.
author: Alissa T.

description:
A16 has some reputation.  That is a tough thing to live up to so many expectations.  I had no reservation about going there and had correctly balanced my expectations.  I had an expertly prepared black cod.  Perfectly cooked not a bit under cooked nor overcooked.  It was a delight.   The service was approachable, engaging, respectful, and were so unassuming.  Often restaurant staff can get a bit snooty because of their employers reputation but not here.  The best chocolate tart I have ever had is here--there is a perfect balance of sweet and savory.  They add a smart amount of sea salt and I was delighted to see that it had the freshest olive oil.  I will spend many a night trying to recreate this phenomenon.  

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
Came here last night for the second time (first time I would have given it four stars...not now, eh)...

We got:

-A nice bottle of Chardonnay
-meatball appetizer
-unpasteurized cheese appetizer (brata, or something like that,  I forget!!)
-mushroom pizza
-Bianca pizza
-Margarita pizza
-chocolate tart

Everything was good, but I don't really see a reason to go back.  I had tried one of their meat entrees two years ago, and that was good, enough to warrant a return trip, I just don't make it down to the marina all that much.   The pizzas were pretty standard, I only liked the Bianca (with olives and basil...) the others I could have made at home.  The meatballs were fantastic though, and the soft cheese appetizer, eh, it gave me a stomach ache I think (possibly my fault).

The ambiance wasn't fun for me.  It seemed like everyone was really full of themselves. But the waitstaff I must say was extremely accommodating and very friendly.  Spot on!

The chocolate tart was interesting as well.  It had three very random things you usually don't see on dessert: salt, pepper and olive oil.  It sounds funky, but it was delicious and strangely complimentary.  

A16 gets golf claps from me.
author: Kristin E.

description:
A16 definitely feels "very marina" -- and this was especially true of our waitress. When asked what she recommended, she listed at minimum 4 items for each sub-category (i.e. 4 from appetizers, 5 from entrees, 4  from desserts, etc.). By the time she was done imparting her knowledge she had listed the better part of the menu for us. 

Regardless, once we ordered some food we didn't have to deal with her much more, which was a bit of a godsend. As Lauren G. has pointed out -- the table was a bit long and made it difficult at times to hear her above the din of the room. 

The food was tasty though, and had a nice fresh taste about it. 

I'm a Marina noob, but this was a nice way to start.
author: Mike S.

description:
Went to this restaurant last week when I was in SF to see my friend.
This restaurant has pretty good review in a lot of site. Of course I will try it out. 
Overall architecture, service and atmosphere, this place is ok, pretty cozy, not bad, The service is very good, our waiter actually very good looking and he is very nice.
Everyone in the restaurant including the bartender, manager and even the cook are very friendly and helpful.

Food is not as good as what I expect. We order a pizza, pasta, couple appetizers to share. The pizza is too dry could use a little bit more sauce and cheese. 
The cavatelli pasta is just ok. The tuna is the best amount our 4 dishes.

On the other hand, the dessert is very good. We have Budino Tart and pear crostata, they all very delicious.

Overall, this place is worth to try it out.
author: Francis L.

description:
My girl and I love this place. The food is always amazing, the wine list is great, and the ambiance and service is fabulous.

A few recommendations:

Reservations are almost a necessity. If you're driving, leave yourself at least 20 minutes to find a spot (damn Marina). The funghi pizza is orgasmic and the prosciutto sampler is our favorite starter. Just smile and nod when the server describes each to you, wait 'till they leave to say "which one was which?', then laugh and enjoy!
author: Kate P.

description:
Holy fvck Batman, we dropped $118 pp there and what a frickin' waste especially in these times where we are all trying to save $.
Got cajoled into meeting up with some friends who were visiting and they chose the place, they're all wine aficionados so you can see where this is going.
A16 has a rule, a party of 10 has a minimum of $65 pp, that already sucks.
The normal prices of food are a bit on the high side, but coupled with $14 a glass wine, things add up quickly
The ambiance and service was good, place is hip, and the foods are also good, but if were going to piss away that much dough on 1 meal, we'd better get a happy ending (or a few).

I hate expensive restaurants (we could have had a 4 or 5 nice Thai dinners for the same price) or a few month's worth of pizza.

The only upside was the company was good.

We wont be going back.
author: G K.

description: My good friend visiting from Japan treated me to a dinner at A-16 in North Beach. She says there is one in Japan and wanted to try it here. My brother recommended it for "good food". I would agree with my brother but the prices were over the top. Yes, my pork chop was delicious! ...and $28...for that price, I can go to my local butcher shop and buy two organic farm friendly thick cut bone-in pork chop, stick it in the oven, and get the same results. I get it. It's expensive to have a business in SF, especially North Beach. Between rent, taxes and insurance, I know why a $10 cut of meat costs my friend $28. It's strictly business economies of scale. I would probably opt for the pizza next time. They seemed more reasonably priced. For the rest of the features, it was a crowded Sunday night, we were seated a bit earlier than our reservations which was nice, the server was friendly and attentive, the place was dark lit (mixed feelings about dark restaurants with dark furniture), it smelled delicious inside, and it was warm on one of the 'freeze warning' nights we've had. The ambiance was okay but tight. I wouldn't make this my go to spot but I may stop in again at an earlier hour to try a pizza and avoid the evening crowd.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
Best pasta I've had since Italy!!!!!!

Very cute restaurant...ask to sit on the "outdoor" patio.

The pizza (Margherita) was delicious, did not have too much cheese on it and had great tomato sauce!

The Maccaronara pasta was DELICIOUS...it tasted home-made and was simple, yet perfect.

The Ricotta gnocchi was awesome and tasted like matzo ball soup, which is weird, but amazing at the same time.

The wine list is long and they have a great selection.

Our whole meal was only $90 for 3 of us and wine (although we didn't order dessert)!

I've been craving the pasta and pizza since I ate there...I want to go back ASAP!
author: Elaine S.

description:
During my recent visit, I ordered the:

Bianca - mozzarella, grana padano, chiles, garlic, green olives, basil, olive oil 

So delicious! The green olives were cooked to perfection and the pizza encompassed that savory and spiciness that is so difficult to achieve with pizza!  We paired our pizzas with a wonderful Riesling recommended by the waitress.   I'm still drooling thinking about the green olives on this pizza!
author: Minna A.

description:
Do Not Plan An Event Here!! Rudest People EVER!

I used to love this place - the food was great, location convenient, fabulous wine. So, naturally, I wanted to plan a special event here.  You would think that any restaurant would welcome the opportunity for a large party that plans to spend an exorbitant amount of money, right?

So not the case. First of all, they claim that they have a "long standing policy" of not taking reservations for parties larger than 6 on Friday and Saturday nights. Stupid policy for any popular dining place to have. So I decided to talk to the manager to see if any sort of exception could be made (a deposit, minimum order etc, I was willing to be as flexible as possible).

Instead of being put on hold forever by some receptionist, I decided to go in person. I walked in 15 minuted after they opened and was greeted by 5 girls who worked there, all standing around and chatting. There were no customers anywhere in sight. I asked very nicely to speak to the manager. 

You might have thought by their reaction that I asked for a private audience with the Queen of England. They all started exchanging looks with each other, I was asked if I had an appointment, I said no and asked to make one. The snotty receptionists reply was that "it wasn't really her job." I even told them that it was nothing bad, I just wanted to speak to someone in charge! Their reply was that they were about to start serving (to who?? there was no one there!) and he was met possibly busy. I didn't know the manager was needed to start food service...

After several more awkward looks being exchanged and thrown at me, I was ushered out of there with the managers name (given with rolled eyes and a reluctant pen so I could write it down) and directions to call an automated phone tree that the management team may or may not check.

Even after all of this, I called and left a message for the manager. 

I never got a reply.

I've worked in customer service. This is NEVER how a potential client should be treated. Shame on all of them for thinking that they can brush off a patron to their restaurant. Their food was good, but not good enough to excuse this kind of treatment. 

There are plenty of other amazing places to eat and throw parties in San Francisco. I strongly encourage everyone out there reading this to take their money elsewhere.
author: Jade N.

description:
My friend and I had the best dinner at A16 last night. I did a reservation through open table and we were seated right away. The staff was friendly and helpful in picking out an appropriate wine...the wine list was amazing! I had the roasted beef coulots with cannelini beans that was so tender and deliscious. My friend had the black cod with chickory salad which was cooked to perfection.

I was also impressed that, despite it being a Saturday night, we never felt rushed. It was packed, of course...but we had an amazing meal with good conversation. We sat in the very back alcove-type area...I highly recommend it as it was not as noisy.

I live in the neighborhood and have always been turned off by the crowds, but I'm glad we braved them. We will be back!
author: Angela C.

description: looking forward to A16 opening on College Ave in Oakland in Rockridge......welcome to the neighborhood!
author: Jeff M.

description:
3.5 to 4 stars.

Decided to give A16 another shot after a previous unmemorable expereince. Our initial plan to grab a snack turned into full on feast. I guess that's what happens when you order wine and sit at the bar. Italian wines are always foreign to me and it was nice to have a bartender that let us taste a lot of the wines. 

I browsed the menu and the first thing I noticed was the expansive and creative use of fresh ingredients. Not a new concept to SF, but when you intercept locally seasoned ingredients with rustic italian food, the result is something very beautiful.  First up was the Funghi pizza with smoked mozzarella. The crisp dandelion greens on the pizza  provided a nice complement to the mushrooms. The pumpkin gnocci with keel was one of the highlights of the meal. I enjoyed this pasta because rather then being the typical heavy gnocci dish doused with tomato sauce, it was light, ingredient focused, and completely flavorful. This was the perfect dish at the perfect place in the middle of a cold and rainy November SF night. Next up was the Bucatini with Sicilian almond and dried san marzano pesto, mint and pecorino. I enjoyed this dish the least as I did not feel the ingredients in the sauce were strong enough to support the thick bucatini pasta. The Romana pizza is SO delicious. It's not the best pizza in the city (Pizza Napoletana gets my vote) but the anchovies, chillis, and tomato make a great combination (no anchovies at Pizza Napoletana). This pizza came out pippin hot and it was delicious!

One great thing about A16 is the quality of the chilli sauce they put on the side for you to add to your pizza or pasta.  It's a delicious chilli oil with flakes. Probably the best restaurant in the Marina and one of the good Italian restaurants in the city.
author: Annie Y.

description:
If you are pretentious and love the Gavin type crowd, it's for you.

Boring and typical Marina. Crowd is worth a laugh every now and then.

Yawn.  What a pity they want to build one in the Dogpatch, I hope it never happens, however the Bayview is pretty close so should scare the bimbos away hopefully.
author: E C.
