description: The hostess were super friendly. Our waitress was also great. The food was excellent, the pizza was crisp and very flavorful, the pizza shears were fun. The grilled asparagus was great. Squid ink cavatelli was super tasty.
author: Drew H.

description:
The GF and i hit A16 again last night before going to see the Nutcracker at the SF ballet. We got stuck in traffic and got to the restaurant later than we wanted. It was also cold and raining so i dropped the GF off at the door so that she could order while i went to find parking. She told our waiter that we were in a bit of a rush, but the folks at A16 came through for us and the food arrived as i walked in the door only partially soaked.

We ordered the Gnocchi and the margherita pizza, both of which were fabulous. The gnocchi was light and delicious. I still can't get over how great their pizzas are either. Service was so good that we ended up having time for dessert. The chocolate tort with sea salt was also great.

Not only was the food and the service fantastic, but we got out for under $40 total. Quite a bit different from the multi-course gut busting meal with wine blowing past the $100 mark that we had last time. I love when a restaurant is that versatile. 

A16 got us in and out in about 30 minutes, all while serving us terrific food at a reasonable price. They turned what could have been a disastrous night (suits and ties, rain, and san francisco don't mix) into a wonderful one. For that, i will be eternally grateful. Thanks A16.
author: Travis D.

description:
OH. MY. GOD. This place just might be my new favorite restaurant. I ended up going there at the last minute on a Friday night with no reservations, so we had to wait for a bit, but it was definitely worth it. We were initially seated at the counter overlooking the kitchen and after about 10 minutes decided we really wanted a table. I was kind of embarrassed to ask our server since we'd already been sitting there for awhile, but he and the hostess were both super accommodating. 

And the food, oh the food! Everything I put in my mouth was absolutely delicious. I started off with a salad that had the freshest, most delicious nectarines in it and then my date and I shared a thin crust pizza with ricotta cheese and cherry tomatoes that was seriously unreal. I don't remember what desserts we had since I was already stuffed and fairly tipsy at that point, but I know they were just as amazing as the rest of the meal.

I highly recommend this place: everything from the music they played to the decor to the wine selection was spot on. The service was particularly good - our waiter was very knowledgeable and friendly and really took the time to give us recommendations. I can't wait to go back.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
This was one of the other restaurants that usually had a line out the door. I can see why- the vibe, the food, the drinks. It's a nice place to socialize and relax after work, or hang out on the weekends. But it's nothing unique. I thought I was in Mario Batali's pizzeria in LA, just with a name and wallpaper change. 
What I remembered about the night- 

appetizers- the mozzarella one and the calamari. these were outstanding. the mozzarella was really good quality.

pizza- yuck. i would choose Pizza Hut's pizza over A 16. The toppings were okay, but the crust is horrible! A pizza with bad crust is a bad pizza.

pasta- the only one worth mentioning is the gnocchi. It was soft, moist, and flavorful. A must get entree here.
author: Jeanie C.

description: We've lived in the city just 8 months. When out of town guests come to town, almost all of them mention wanting to go to A16? I've thought wow, their PR is a lot better than their food.  I've been there twice, and I'm under impressed. I gather from reading other reviews that it's past it's prime. I won't be going back - too many other much better places to eat in the city.
author: Linda H.

description:
Honestly, I just wasn't that impressed with this place. Really didn't live up to the hype for me.

I loved the atmosphere - reminded me of small crowded intimate restaurants in NY. And the wine menu was to die for - so many selections and at reasonable prices.

My friend got the mozzarella burrata as an app and that was delish. Definitely a big thumbs up there. I should also say the service was AWESOME - our waitress was excellent. 

But from there, nothing else really impressed. I got the lamb which came with a side (I chose potatoes). The portions were small and it was kind of overcooked. The potatoes were good but reminded me of breakfast potatoes which threw me off since it was dinner. Other orders at my table included pizzas and pastas which looked delicious but I didn't try them. Maybe I should have stuck with the pasta since it's an Italian place.

Anyway, let's just say I'm not going to jump at the chance to go here again.
author: Ana H.

description: Bad service. It took many hours to go through the meal because the service was so slow, sans explanation from the not-to-be-seen staff. Plus, the pizza edges were burnt with black flecks coming off onto the plate. The fish was overcooked. Entree portions were oddly tiny and placed on large white plates (to show off the insufficient portions?). And it was super pricey to boot.
author: Catt G.

description:
Had lunch here and it was great!  Started out with a salumi plate which consisted of all housemade goodies.  The Lonza stood out.  looks like prosciutto but it melts in the mouth.  The fat reminded me of taleggio cheese.  Then we had the creamy flavored burrata which was fantastic with just a bit of sea salt and olive oil.  The tripe was next and it was off the hook.  Tender ,slightly chewy and completely satisfying.
Next was a margherita pizza which had great sauce and the perfect crunch and chewy texture.  Lastly, desserts were phenomenal!  Persimmon cake and pudding and quince granita with panna cotta.  These were a couple of the best desserts i've had in sometime.  I had a great experience and would definitely go back.
author: goldberg d.

description: Officially my favorite restaurant in SF. Food was amazing, staff was friendly but my only complain is the steep corkage fee of $30. Can't wait to try their sister restaurant!
author: Amanda T.

description:
I took my boyfriend to A16 for a special dinner and it was very special indeed. To start out, their wine list is amazing. Nothing like a big Italian red with pasta and pizza. And this is not your average pasta and pizza, but a super tasty, swanktastic version of the things you know and love.

Since the menu changes often, I'll just say that anything with meatballs is good and the prosciutto is the bomb...

Love it!
author: Julie C.

description:
First off, turning left onto Chestnut Avenue from Scott St. is a pain in the ass. The pedestrians, literally, walk all over you. They seem to think that there are no automobiles roaming the streets and just walk freely across the crosswalk--what.the.hell. So annoying.

Luckily, I drove my mini cooper, so finding parking wasn't too much of a problem as I was able to fit into a tiny spot that no regular sized automobile couldn't. Hah, Don't hate! 

The place was jam packed with uber chic people just waiting for their names to be called. Luckily, we made reservations ahead of time and was seated fairly quickly once we arrived. I like that kind of service. Don't you hate it when you do make reservations and you end up waiting still for a good amount of time? Don't you? 

We ordered the pomodoro pizza, beef coulette and a side of grilled polenta. Weird how the pizza was better tasting then the beef coulette and polenta. I found the beef lacking in flavor and the polenta sorta burnt. Although, our appetizers were another story. We ordered the tuna conserva with flatbread. Oh my. I could eat this dish everyday. The tomatoes were so sweet and the dish itself had such a great kick to it. Hubby ordered the beet and pototo salad that was good, but not as good as the tuna appetizer. 

For dessert, we ordered the apple puff pastry. It sure didn't taste like what I thought an apple puff pastry would taste like. The apples seemed like they were pureed, hence the mushy texture. The side of lemon sorbet was good. 

I'd return to this restaurant, but I wouldn't necessarily crave anything from here. The next time I do return, I definitely want to try out their pasta dishes.
author: stacy k.

description:
I've eaten here again and I still enjoy the restaurant, but I don't ever feel like I've been enlightened having had the experience.  The pizza is usually excellent, but I think I chose un-wisely for my taste this time (tomato sauce - I didn't read the sauce part of the menu - with 6 black olives and the same number of anchovies).  The wine was good, but even though I KNOW they're pouring a full 5.5 oz -or whatever - into those big wine glasses of theirs (and I do love those big glasses when served a bottle of wine) I still can't help feeling irked by what appears to be a tenth of a glass of wine.  I understand that this is my failing as a consumer, but I thought I would note it in case anyone wanted to set up a support group (I'm in!).

Service was enthusiastic and friendly.  But, what is good service anyway?  The server was nice enough, knowledgeable and brought us what we ordered.  How is she to know that I was trying to warm up my cranky friend (who was still pissed off about some previous transgression that I still haven't figured out) and that her bouncy introduction and breathless specials reciting didn't quite fit into the moment.  Anyway, no one was hurt so that's pretty good, right?

Nice design and decor.  Kudos for the cork (fully recyclable) flooring.  Thank you for having faith in us that we would enjoy the large wine glasses (I swear I'm trying!).
author: Keith R.

description:
This is the only restaurant I've been to where I'll remember the service.  My friend, who knows the pastry chef here, and I shared an appetizer, two entrees, and a dessert and the busboy replaced the plates and the silverware before each dish.  I've never experienced this and it made me feel like a king.  Not just that, but the waitress waited on us just the right amount and had our leftover food ready for us in a bag when we were ready to leave.

They're apparently known for their cheeses and wines, but I think they should be known for their meatballs and bread pudding with green apple sorbet.  The only downsides are the parking and the noise, which takes away from the romantic decor, but these are a small price to pay for the food and service.
author: Stephen G.

description: "In San Francisco the audience is easy. You put tripe in a bowl and tell them it's from a humanely raised cow and they're going to eat it." PWNED!  I eat it all biatch.   Thank god the pizza and squid ink pasta were cage free.  Free range only for my fatty ass.
author: Fatty A.

description:
The boyfriend and I recently had an 8PM reservation.   We arrived a few minutes early and were promptly seated on time. We were seated in the atrium section of the restaurant, and while I did not request this seating, it always has been my preferred location: it's quieter/more intimate and more comfortable temperature-wise, as you avoid the heat of the wood burning ovens. This was my boyfriend's first visit; I, however, have been quite fortunate to have a bit of an insider advantage as a colleague is involved with the restaurant. This, however, was the first time I've gone whereas I've not been there with coworkers - I was curious to see if there would be any glitches sans the colleague.

We split all of our dishes:

- Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini
First time the boyfriend had had burrata. Their traditional, simple presentation makes for as good of an introduction as any.

- Salsiccia - rapini, grana padano, mozzarella, fennel sausage, garlic, chiles
A16 pizzas are regularly debated - some do not care for the doughier center that is traditional to Neapolitan pizzas. For all of you wishing for a crispier crust, our pizza last night would have been perfect for you: the crust was crisp throughout. I, on the other hand, wished it had been a bit underdone. The boyfriend agreed. Still better than most of what you'll find in the Bay Area.

- Ricotta gnocchi in brodo with pork meatballs, wild nettles and chiles
Definitely the best dish of the night. We only split a small and were immediately wishing we'd gotten the larger portion. The gnocchi were that perfect "pillowly" light texture. The meatballs were very flavorful and light in their own right. Just the right amount of spice to the dish. One of the best pasta dishes I've had at A16, hands down.

- Berkshire pork loin with pinenuts and (some variety of) berries
Excellent flavor. The boyfriend thought it was a bit salty, however I thought it was perfectly acceptable (I tend to like saltier foods anyhow). Very simple presentation allowing the pork to shine. I think the pork was just a BIT overdone, though it was still moist and fork tender.

- Roasted potatoes, cauliflower and brussels sprouts (side dish)
Not an entirely exciting side, but paired suitably with the pork. I did like the textural contrast between the crisp potatoes, the slight crunch to the cauliflower, and the buttery sprouts.

- Chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil
I love chocolate. I love salt. I love EVOO (sorry, all your Rachel Ray haters!). The tart was a bit drier than normal (are we sensing a commonality for the evening?), but was still tasty. I've had this dessert numerous times, and while I think this was probably the weakest I've had, it was still better than probably 75% of the desserts I've had in Bay Area restaurants.

- Honey gelato with figs and buckwheat cookies (there was another component - I think it was a crme anglaise).
Probably the weakest of the dishes for the evening. The gelato was a bit weakly flavored: it was good, but could have been better with more intensity. The buckwheat cookies by themselves were fairly blah, though they did work better when fully integrated with the gelato, etc. The figs were left behind - didn't feel like they meshed well actually. Or perhaps I just wasn't in a fig mood.

I unfortunately do not remember the specifics of the wine we had. It was a medium bodied red, which was more befitting to my boyfriend's tastes - fruity, but fairly dry. It opened up quite nicely and paired well with all of our dishes (we let is breath a bit through the burrata). I'm more familiar with CA and French wines: my knowledge of Italians is limited to mainly Nebbiolos and Barberas. This was a nice departure from my norm - we relied purely on the advice of the wine staff. Good pick.

I'll also say that I think that A16's service is, for its mid-range categorization, is quite top notch: plates and utensils removed after each course, our pasta dish was held in the kitchen so that it would not get cold when the waitress noticed I had excused myself to the bathroom (my napkin was folded upon my return), courses perfectly timed, etc. Highly efficient and friendly... but it still holds true to its more casual roots and isn't overly fussy.

Total (including tax and tip) was about $160.

It's hard to believe that A16 has been around for 3 years already. While I've had certain dishes that have been stronger on previous occasions, the food was of a very high quality. The faults I found were fairly minimal and stem from the fact that I personally have many visits under my belt for contrast. The boyfriend felt it was one of the strongest meals we've shared together. It was great to see that I wasn't just privy to special service because of a work connection. A16 definitely stays on the repeat visit and recommendation list.
author: Jesse H.

description:
I haven't ventured to the Marina for dinner in a long time.  But I had heard some good things about A16 and that along with my love of Italian food and I was able to secure a last minute 8:00 reservation was enough to get me to give it a try. 

The evening didn't start off that great as the hostess had a real attitude.  You know the one, "our shit don't stink and everyone wants two scoops" kinda attitude.  I really got the feeling that they expected the customer to be happy just with the fact that they were allowed to come in to have dinner.

The space was nice, bar dining in the front and a blend of modern/rustic dining in the back with an open kitchen the focal point of the dining area.  One problem was it was kinda cramped and noisy and difficult to manuveur in and out of the restaurant, or to and from the bathroom.  You always felt like you were in someone's way.

Now all of this could have been overlooked if the food would have just lived up to expectations.

We started with a couple of half portion pastas.  We had the gnocchi with pork meatballs, and a fusilli in a chicken stock with mushrooms.  The fusilli was the better of the two dishes.  The fusilli pasta was properly cooked al dente and the flavors were very nice.

The gnocchi was disappointing.  The gnocchi was meh, and neither the pork meatballs or sauce had a lot of flavor.  It kinda reminded me of a weak version of Italian wedding soup with gnocchi instead of orzo pasta and overall not as much flavor.

Next up was a funghi pizza.  Again, I had high hopes but again this disappointed.  There were way, way too many mushrooms.  A combination of enoki and button mushrooms was so overpowering and resulted in a soggy middle to the crust.  Sometimes less is more and this pizza could have done with less mushrooms.  A real let down.

Finally the halibut with fennel and tomato agrodolce.  This was the best dish of the meal.  The halibut was perfectly cooked and the tomato agrodolce really provided a little sweetness, acidity, and color  to the dish.

For dessert we had the hazelnut cannoli.  Another bummer, it was not a typical cannoli shell with a ricotta filling.  Instead it was some kind of flakey puff pastry filled with hazelnut cream and there were three of them on a plate.  Another case where they should have followed the rule "less is more".  There was no need for three of them and the plating was kind of messy and uninteresting/unappetizing.  I would not order this again at all.

As a final comment, I will say the wine list is very nice with a good selection of wines by the glass.  Let me just say you will need to down a few glasses of wine to help overlook all the missteps on the menu.

Food:  2.5 stars
Service:  2.5 stars
Atmosphere:  3 stars

I would really like to give this place 2.5 stars but will begrudgingly round up for the wine list.
author: Geoff H.

description:
I had a GREAT experience here!  First, it was me and my girls heading out for some wine and conversation.  Sadly, when we arrived, there was no seating available and the place was jam packed.  We were only there for some wine and to start our evening of debauchery.  

The wine was FANTASTIC!  Indeed!  After about fifteen minutes, the hostess came up and offered us a table because the reservations didn't show up.  Very thoughtful and she saved my feet, as I was wearing a sweet set of stilettos!  

The place did have a little bit of noise, but nothing out of control.  The lighting is nice.  Not to dark and definitely not to well lit either.  The bartenders and servers were both very knowledgeable about the wines this place carries.  I've heard fantastic things about their pizza, but didn't get the chance to try it this time around.  But I will definitely be back.  In my opinion, it's a nice place to go with friends to enjoy nice, tasty wine and relax.  But keep in mind, they're behind 3 weeks on reservations someone told us last night!  Or, you can always "risk it" and wait for a "lucky table" to open up like it did for us.  It might take an hour or longer though.
author: Kat M.

description:
I came here a couple months ago for dinner and it was a pleasant experience all-around. We ordered the mozzarella burrata, a margherita pizza, and the pasta made with squid ink. The mozzarella burrata was pretty amazing. The cheese was soft and creamy and the olive oil topped it off perfectly. The margherita pizza was quite delicious as well. The pasta made with squid ink, however, was just okay. It was a bit dry and lacked taste, in my opinion.

We sat in sort of a hallway area which was a bit cramped because of foot traffic. It was a bit on the dark side as well. Despite the gripes, this is definitely a place to check out!
author: David M.

description:
Disappointing.  I came here last night with the boyfriend after we'd heard good things about it.  Granted most of this was before Nate Appleman left, but we definitely had high hopes that they would maintain a similar caliber.

The evening actually started out really well.  We had the salumi plate and the prosciutto plate.  Delicious.  But I'm not so sure that it was house cured?  Then came the tuna appetizer, which was pretty good but nothing to write home about.  Then we waited about 20 minutes after our appetizer was cleared before our main course came out.  The boyfriend had a funghi pizza, he said it was just decent but he'd definitely had better.  I ordered the roasted chicken.  The chicken was fine, although not spectacular.  The broccolini that came with my chicken, however, was horrible.  It was so salty that I drank 2 glasses of water (mine and his) to make it better.  The waiter then came by and only filled up my water and left the boyfriend's glass completely empty.  Weird.  We were done for over 15 minutes before the waiter finally came back to us to give us our check.  He never checked in on us, never talked to us and only filled our water once.  It was ridiculous.

To top it off, the place is really crowded...and I heard all about our neighboring table's birthday plans that included dancing with her friends and also the other table's horrible boyfriend problems (did you ask him to stop playing his video game rather than just start yelling at him that you hoped he failed in life?  I dunno, just saying, usually I just tell the boyfriend that we have reservations and he'll stop his game).  Fine, I can sort of handle that if it was just that lone complaint, but on top of that you add horrible and slow service and overly salty food (taste the food, if they had tasted the food, they wouldn't have sent it out!)...it's unacceptable.
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
A16 is solid.  I stopped in with lunch with a friend last week and the place left me thinking about my meal for the next 2 days. 

We started off with the Romaine Chicory Salad and an order of the House-Cured Fennel Salami.  The salami was off the charts and a great snack to go with a rather simple yet tasty salad.  

Then came the real highlight which was the pasta.  House made and the ragu was simply off the charts.  I can't remember the precise name of the dish and it looks like the menu changed a bit.  I am sure you can't lose with any of the past dishes.

We also order the Romano pizza.  No cheese on this one which is great for the non-dairy lovers out there.  It was great, tasty but I just can't get all that worked up about pizza.  

On a side note, I had a lemonade, and it was one of the best lemonades I had in a long time.  I know not many people are going to get a lemonade - but hey its lunch right.  Its cool that even on something like lemonade - A16 makes the effort to do it right - not super sweet like a soda but a bit tart with a bite of lemon.

The space is nice.  You walk into the bar area with ample bar seating.  The main space is open and inviting.  The smells of the food are intense and welcoming.  We sat outside in a covered patio area which was nice for lunch time. 

The service was excellent but they did seem a bit short staffed at lunch.  Things could have ran a tad more smoothly.  Parking is metered outside and easy during the day and free and should be easy on a weeknight.  On a weekend night, you probably don't want to drive or just pay for parking because the area can get jammed up.  

Love this place, will definitely be back for dinner and to try the wine.
author: Moe J.

description:
Visited this restaurant several years ago and were unimpressed-we finally ventured back last night. Will be our last visit. Do not understand why we waited three weeks for a Friday night reservation?

We had the burrata, which was fine, but poorly presented. Bread and cheese on a plate. The bruschetta was overly salty- apparently it was universally disliked as our server was not surprised that we did not eat it and took it off the bill.  I had the pizza with proscuitto and arugula (one of my favorites) and ate less than a quarter of it dispute being famished. The pizza was not cut and the crust was so tough it was work to cut through.  Not worth the effort. My husbands filet of sole was small and overly salty. 

Our server was great and the wine recommendation was fantastic and reasonably priced. However neither of these things can overcome the poor food. We will not return.
author: Sandra W.

description:
This was one of the worst meals I've ever had.

The "bruschetta" was some canned  beans on burnt toast.  My filet of sole was two ounces of meat boiled in salty water.  My wife's pizza was so undercooked it was inedible.

However, the service was good.  Although it's more than just a little disingenuous to serve offal with a smile.
author: Paul W.

description: Trendy place with nice atmosphere, but it wasn't somewhere I would want to go back again.  Sure, main dishes are relatively inexpensive, but it was small!  I could have ate twice that much.  Wine was good, but I felt it was over priced.  Parking was at a premium in this busy location, so I had to pay for valet parking.  If I pay for "valet" parking, shouldn't I drop my car in front of the restaurant?  Instead, I had to walk around the block in rain.  Ranked by SF Magazine as 2005 top 50 Eats.
author: トモ T.

description:
I dined at the chef's counter, and must admit that the food is better than most other Italian eateries.

There is a dimension of traditional cooking combined with some innovative ideas, mostly executed at a reasonably high standard.

One thing you won't normally find in other places is the double wood-fired brick oven,one for pizzas, the other for meats and vegetables.

I had an olives and bresaola antipast, followed by a cod "all'acqua pazza" and  finished with some traditional cheese and honey: all of them were executed beautyfully. Only exception was my side of cannellini beans: mushy and flavorless.

The wine selection is quite amable, but service a bit slow. Overall you can expect good food although a bit overpriced (not too much, though)!
author: Pier F.

description:
Last summer, I discovered the existance of burrata. It was supposed to be deliciously fresh mozzarella injected with cream, incredibly milky, and fantastic on crostini. I was hooked. Where could I find this delectable concoction? Does anyone in the Bay Area make such creamy heaven? (my forays into Bay Area Italian food have encountered mediocre fare, at best) I discovered a review (I can't find it again) that praised the burrata at A16, imported fresh every Wednesday (or Thursday). Thus, my hopes for A16 were incredibly high. I didn't manage to get here last summer, so I went for a late birthday dinner a few weeks ago. A summary follows.

Finding parking is kind of annoying; there's only street parking as far as I know, and it took us about 15 to 20 minutes to find any sort of parking spot. Thankfully, we'd tried to arrive early, so we got there just on time for our 8pm reservation. The lovely hostesses were happy to bring us straight to our table in the back near the kitchen. A16, like many fine restaurants, is a dim sort of place which provides a nice ambiance for intimate dining. The tables are closely packed, however, so the intimacy is mostly lost by rubbing elbows with your neighbors.

A16 has several sommeliers on hand, and after a reasonable wait for a Wednesday dinner, she came over and helped us pick out some delicious wines. She was spot on with my wine, and we had mostly hits with our group's other glasses. And then we ordered the burrata. With some prosciutto on the side. And maybe olives. But the burrata.

(Z). Oh. My. God. It was just as lovely as I had dreamed. You maybe thinking now, "Why did this strange person give A16 two stars if she orgasmed over the burrata so much?" To you, gentle reader, I say "Yes, quite strange. Keep reading." The prosciutto was acceptable but a bit dry, and paled next to the mindblowing awesomeness of the burrata. The olives were quite tasty as well.

Unfortunately, everything else was meh. We ordered pizzas, which were supposed to be fantastic; they were okay. I'll admit I misordered and got prosciutto on a pizza. I adore prosciutto, but the cuts they had were very salty when heated. My bad. The crust was incredibly doughy and for the most part the pizzas, while okay, felt like they could have been had for half the price at a mediocre pizza joint. I'd looked up A16 on Yelp just prior to heading up and ordered the chocolate budini tart drizzled with olive oil on the advice of one of my fellow reviewers. It was, alas, not for me. The saltiness overwhelmed the chocolate, and the olive oil just tasted out of place.

To recap: the service was good taking into account the size of the crowd, the food felt overly expensive for the quality, and honestly it's just too tight to really relax inside the restaurant. Next time I will go back just for the burrata and a glass of wine, and save my stomach for dinner elsewhere.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Set aside the amazing experience dining in, the simple yet pleasing interior, and move right into the kitchen.

The food is usually on point. As any restaurant as busy as this (and isn't a once a year treat) they can be hit and miss when it comes to the entree's. It is always good but more times than not, it really is great!

Serve me on a paper plate and A16 is still the best all around of the loud, hip, frequented Marina dining spots. 

The pizza is how it should be: simple, fresh and light. And to the owner(s) - Could you please open up an A16 Pizza and Cannoli spot?
author: Paul R.

description:
I'll have to say this, I was won back by A16. So in general I'm not a big fan of the "higher-end" Italian restaurants in SF, I think they disappoint 9 times out of 10. And although I'd been to A16 once before, this time I went back with a more positive mindset, and guess what, it was pretty good! I had a Margherita pizza to start (good sauce, but crust wasn't quite up to Pizzeria Delfina standards), then followed that up with a gnocchi special they had that night, as well as a side of Cannellini beans with garlic and oregano and an appetizer portion of their beef and ham meatballs. Only 3 meatballs came with the dish, which turned out to be more than enough. 

Minus one star because they forgot to bring my beer for the first 20 minutes of the meal, but once they brought it they comped it!
author: Keyvan R.

description:
I finally made it to A16 for a festive pre-holiday meal. I admit that I've probably read oh, about 200 reviews raving about the burrata, pizzas, charcuterie, and pastas, but I was still worried that it might be over-rated. I'm seldom on that side of town, but decided to make the trek and was well rewarded for doing so.

Holidays=gluttony in America, yes? I've been on a hiatus from dining adventures as of late due to busy work and a cold, but now I'm back. To really appreciate my return to nice meals, we started with the cloud-like burrata and the prosciutto tasting. After tasting the 14 month and the 20 month prosciutto, the verdict is that we liked both and couldn't discern between the two. It takes a mighty cheese to steal my attentions away from the most velvety marbled salt-cured ham, but the burrata succeeded. We both paused to admire its simplicity, elastomer and creamy pillowiness, and to ponder how a pedestrian "Precious" brand mozzarella ball at Safeway could even be distantly related to a cheese so indulgent.

The wine list is quite lengthy and full of mysterious Italian varietals that I know nothing of. Our menu selections were all over the place, but the sommelier was able to point us in the direction of a Casavecchia when we told her we were looking for something "interesting" and easy drinking. 

At this point we were relaxed and in good spirits. I was afraid that we had ordered too much food, so we opted for the small serving of bucatini with Dungeness crab, cherry tomatoes, basil, gigante beans, and some lovely toasty bread crumbs. The beans were strangely absent but completely unnecessary. The pasta was one of our favorites for the evening, simple but incredibly delicious with plentiful chunks of sweet crab. Even though the small portion allowed us to order dessert later, we both wished we had ordered the large. 

I was a little let down by our entree selection, but I think it was just a case of mis-ordering. The manfriend was happy with the coils of house-made lamb sausage, but I wasn't so taken by the accompanying giardiniera. I love all things pickled, but the mixture tasted a bit off to me. The lamb sausages themselves were tasty, but overall the plating was careless and I felt like the dish was lacking something. 

In a rare showing of self-restraint, we had asked for the remainder of the prosciutto to be boxed up. I foresaw a cheese plate in my future, but the manfriend could not resist the panna cotta with pomegranate seeds and almonds, two of his favorite things. I'm not one for jiggly, creamy, or custardy finales, so I went with the naughty and wildly rich chocolate budino tart, deliciously topped with sea salt and olive oil for an ultimate sweet savory combination. This little pudding tart can best be described as adult, yum.

Service was attractive and polished, very easy to deal with and not at all in our faces. Sommelier was friendly and informative, but didn't make it over until our appetizers were arriving which was a little awkward. The room itself is more pleasant with warmer lighting than the low-ceilinged bar seating. I duly noted the toasty wood burning oven and the cute covered patio. I can't wait to get back to try the pizzas and some more burrata.
author: Candice L.

description:
So, here goes.  I've done my due diligence, but I still can't figure out what "A16" means.  So far, my guesses are:

* Italian Scrabble tile, where A is worth 16 points.  (Sounds like the game I could win, although I don't speak Italian).
* Italian highway number.  (Take the A16 down to Palermo, then take Exit 6).
* Something heard while playing Battleship in Italy.  (A16?  You sank my battleship!)
* Italian steak sauce which is 16 times better than our A-1 sauce.  (I would never even try A-4, let alone A-1!)

Any ideas?

The place itself feels very European.  When you walk in, the restaurant looks very small and kind of narrow, but it's really not.  My friend who had been to A16 a few times before requested a table on the patio, which is all the way in the back.  We walked past some bar tables, the actual bar, an open kitchen, a LOUD dining area and finally arrived at the patio.  It's a small, quiet covered area with 4 tables.  The serenity of the patio was worth the 4-minute walk.  (It wasn't really THAT long of a walk, but you know me, I like to exaggerate and complain).

Our waitress was upbeat and efficient, although she kind of disappeared for a while and forgot to refill my iced tea.  They brought us bread before the meal, but for some reason did not bring us the bread plates.  I guess it's their M.O. in Italy, because no one had them.  The tablecloth, the butcher paper and the menu were beige in color, which contributed to a nice, relaxed atmosphere.

I had the arugula salad with nectarines, ricotta and walnuts as an appetizer.  The salad was very good--nectarines and arugula are a great combination--although the dressing was a bit too lemony for my taste.  For my entree I ordered the cavatelli pasta with squash blossoms.  Cavatelli are small pasta shells that are more dense and chewy than other pasta.  I'd say it was like undercooked al dente pasta.  Nonetheless, it was delicious and very filling.  The squash blossoms gave the dish a unique taste, and the chiles added the much needed spice.  I also tried a slice of my friend's Margherita pizza.  I loved the thin crust, although pizza without meat is like a crystal chandelier without light bulbs: it's beautiful to look at, but what's the point?

Overall, I felt very European dining here.  When we walked out, I wanted to hop on my Vespa and ride it to my palazzo, but I remembered that I lived in America, and my 6-cylinder sedan was parked 6 blocks away.  Back to reality!

P.S.  I was just informed that A 16 is indeed one of the main highways in Italy.  Go figure.
author: Yan G.

description:
Just awesome!!!

So, we'd been trying to go to this place for a while, after passing by on other occasions and seeing how crowded it was, along with seeing the great reviews on Yelp and in the Chronicle.

We finally got reservations here (although we had to book about 10 days in advance, to get them at a prime time).

We walk in and the bar is extremely crowded.  I'm thinking, "great, another stuff, pretentious, loud Marina joint".  This was compounded by the fact that our table wasn't ready until almost 30 minutes past our reservations time.  Still, I give it the benefit of the doubt.  To my surprise, the place is quite extensive in the back.  It has a nice and modern look to it.  In the back, we sat in the patio, which was tranquil and provided a nice respite from the Marina meat market of the bar.

We ordered a plethora of dishes amongst the 4 of us:

Appetizers:

Burrata crostini - Yum, yum, yum.  This is the tastiest, most interesting textured mozzarella I've ever had.  Couple that with the olive oil and I couldn't get enough.
Prosciutto sampler - Loved it, from the mild, to the very strong (bacon like taste).  I'm not usually a huge prosciutto fan, but they definitely know how to cure the meat properly here
Beat salad - With the combination of flavors and the almonds, it was absolutely delicious.  

For the main course, I tried the pizza salsiccia.  It came to my table and was enormous.  From the way it was wood fired, to the delicious ricotta, to the fennel sausage, every bite was sensational.  I had to bring some home and I'll be happily having the rest for my lunch today.

I hadn't been overly impressed with the other Italian places I've tried in the Marina before (E'angelo, Emporio Rulli - although they do have great desserts), but I think I now found a gem.  I have a new favorite Italian restaurant in the city and I'm definitely coming back (provided that I can get reservations again).
author: Aaron M.

description:
I walked in with no reservation on a busy Saturday night.  The hostess at the front said the wait was at least an hour, which seemed right considering that I'd had to push my way through people to even get in the door and across the three feet of space to where she was standing.  I told her I'd need to ask the rest of my group and started to turn around, but she stopped me and said that if we stayed "right there", the wait would be 15-20 minutes, tops.

Strange, but we were seated within 20 minutes (well ahead of some people who had been waiting when we arrived).  We spent the rest of dinner trying to figure out what sense it made to seat us right away.  

The food was good, but not outstanding.  Everything was very salty, but I've never been a huge fan of my food tasting like a salt-lick--my partner, who loves salt, would have probably enjoyed it.   They do have a great wine selection and made solid recommendations.

Overall a 3.5 more than a straight 3.
author: Katie S.

description:
I can't believe it's taken me over a year to write a review for A16. Was brought here by a lovely fellow for our date. We began our evening with their little gems and roasted beets with walnuts and pecorino which was fabulous. We ordered two pizzas, the Margherita and Funghi, both amazing, they're quite large for one person but we shared and ended up finishing them off in the car on the way home. Their wines are amazing, I wish I could have remembered the name of the white we shared ugh so good!

For dessert we shared a Strawberry crostata and topped that off with some Rose mmmm 

I love the feel of A16, the staff very friendly and knowledgeable not only about the food but the roots of the restaurant. I'd definitely go back in a heart beat. Beautiful beautiful food! But I must say the company was even sweeter :)
author: Penelope B.

description:
One of my new favorites in the city.  I guarantee you that I will be coming back here again and again.

Simple, rustic Italian food, fantastic wood-fired pizzas, and a lively atmosphere.  And prices are fantastically reasonable!

Downsides:
It's pretty busy, and as others have said, fairly loud inside.
Parking in the neighborhood is not easy, in fact, it's horrible.
There's a whole 'lotta "Marina people" walkin' around, nuff said.

Upsides:
Great food.
Cheap!
author: Gracie-C Y.

description:
I have to admit, I was a little disappointed by the whole experience. I think because I have heard such wonderful things about this place and it started out fantastic - but it got worse and worse...

The decor and atmosphere were amazing. It's cozy, yet chic - and very modern italiano. 

The burrata with olive oil is a must have - 5 stars for that. 
The zuppa was  pretty good and very hearty, even though it was a bit salty. 

The wine was fabulous - and I would go back for the wine and a couple apps. 

The pizza was a little heavy, but overall good. We had the 

The gnocchi with peas was ok - the peas were overdone. 

Now it goes down: 

I'm a very adventurous eater, but the squid ink pasta was awful. No one at our table could eat it. It was briney. Salty, fishy - egh. Not what I am looking for in a seafood dish. To top it off, our waitress even saw that the table didn't touch it except to taste, and didn't ask how we liked it or offer to get us something else. Negative points on that. 

Since we didn't have that final pasta dish, we decided to try some desserts. The special fig and walnut gelato was too tart and sweet - and the olive oil chocolate torte was heavy too. 

My overall impression is that the chef must be a smoker and thus over salts and over seasons to compensate for burnt taste buds. Italian food is incredibly delicious and simple on it's own, when you use good ingredients. There's no reason to complicate it with too many ingredients or too much salt. That to me just sends a message that you're not using the best ingredients. 

Overall, a 2.75  - the wine, the decor, and that special burrata make it worth the trip.
author: Erin M.

description:
At long last, I finally had dinner at A16 a few weeks ago.  My experience pretty much confirmed most of the things I'd heard or read about the place:

1) The pizza is very, very good (we had the margherita; the crust was perfect and the ingredients were fresh and delicious).  

2) The wine program is excellent.  One of the assistant sommeliers picked out some great selections for us, which was no easy task given that we were trying to pair with a pizza, a prosciutto plate, a gnocchi dish (with lamb, I think?) and a salad with ricotta.  I was thoroughly impressed.

3) It is very, very crowded.  But this is okay, because you can have a glass of wine at the very crowded bar before hand.  This was really my only complaint, as there was no place to stand near the bar where I didn't feel like I was getting in the way of the wait staff or the hostess, who were constantly moving back and forth from the bar area to the tables.  Just a minor issue, really, but for a place that's so popular, it would be nice if there was a better setup for those who have to wait.

The rest of the Italian menu looked terrific; next time, if I go back with a larger group, I should be able to sample more of it.  I'm pretty sure I'll end up adding a fifth star then.
author: Andrew E.

description:
I have been searching since I moved here for an awesome authentic Italy-like Italian restaurant here in SF.  I have been meaning ot go to A-16 for a while and it was amazing.  Their pizza is so delicious, I got one with black olives, anchovies, and added prosciutto on top. Joe declared it the best pizza he has had in SF.  We went with a group and ended up sharing and eating everyone's food cause everything was great.  I also loved the pork saltamboca that was pounded thin and wrapped in a crepe with ricotta and sauce.  The asparagus and walcut sauce appie was also great it melts in your mouth.  

Serious wine list of great Italian and CA wines, we had two awesome bottles of crazy good Italian reds that didn't break the bank.  Also excellent service, two wine glasses brought for each person with our two bottles so we could taste both at the same time if we wanted.  I had to minus one star though cause I asked the bus boy to box up the rest of my pizza to go and he did not.  Will def be back here often with the lofty goal of trying all the Italian reds and everything on the menu :)
author: Katie M.

description:
Fantastic pizza, made in a very authentic Italian manner. Nice and thin, with just the right amount of cheese (not piled on like most restaurants around here) and very little grease. Affordable too, since most pizzas are around $15 or less.

The layout of the restaurant is kind of odd- you walk in where the main bar is, pass through a narrow hallway (where they have tables also) and then it widens again into a bigger dining room. My friends and I sat in the narrow hallway part of it, and it gets slightly bothersome to be in such a high traffic area. Enjoyable lighting and setting otherwise. 

We were originally told it would be a 2 hour wait for 3 people (at 6:30 pm on a Saturday night) but got seated much faster than that due to a cancellation. 

Next time I plan on trying one of their entrees, and definitely the dessert!
author: lindsay w.

description:
Excellent Sunday Dinner!!!

Showed up with 3 people at 6:00pm, we had no reservations, the place was packed, and we got seated in 30 minutes instead of the 45-60 minutes the hostess had estimated... Boom-Bop....1 star just for that....

The food was off the chain....  

The pizza, especially the Margherita, has no comparison. Its the closest thing to authentic Italian pizza you can get here in the United States, trust me. We tried the other pizzas (Salsiccia and Pizza Bianca) they were pretty good but if you have to order one... the Margherita is the ticket. Don't get mesmerized by all the other silly toppings. Pomodoro, Mozzarella, and Basil is the BEST on Pizza... 

Now if you really want to taste a dish from the region around A16, especially just south of the highway about halfway from Napoli to Bari, it is the Maccaronara with tomato ragu and ricotta salata. Wow...really close to how my mamma makes it. I was impressed. Perfectly cooked and made right...

Can't wait to go back to try the wine and some other dishes...
author: Tony R.

description:
So after a lot of reading, thinking, pondering, questioning my decisions, going back to the drawing board, making another decision, etc. I finally decided I would celebrate my bday at A16. I was a little hesitant about my decisions given what I read about being noisy and crowded -- but the menu and wine selection made it sound like my kind of place.

I have to say that I had mixed reactions to different courses:
Excellent
- Beet and little gem salad with potatoes, house-made mustard and toasted almonds
- Coppa Salumi 
- Salsiccia - fennel sausage, cherry tomatoes, ricotta, grana padano, garlic, basil, chiles 
- Roasted potatoes side
** Wine selection!
** Service!

Average 
- Maccaronara with tomato ragu and house-made ricotta salata 
- Watson Farms lamb                                                                                                                                                                                          - Cannellini beans with garlic and oregano 


So, I would love to eat here again. It may not have lived up to expectations for a place to celebrate my bday -- but I would be very happy with their wine list, a salad and a pizza for a nice evening.
author: Tom D.

description: Great wines. Massive wine list. Food....not so good. Uninspired dishes. We started with octopus, which was ok. This was the best course, sadly. The pork belly came next. What can I say? If paying 25 bucks for 2 pieces of bacon with some spiced apples on top is your thing, go for it. Not my idea of dinner. It tasted like bacon, cut like bacon and made me sad. I've had good pork belly. Good pork belly has a dense fatty texture and the fat cuts almost like meat when prepared properly. What A 16 served us.....was bacon. THEN came the pasta. Since when is pasta the last course? New to me but, hey,  I'm no expert, I just know what I like and what I've become accustomed to when going to an Italian restaurant. I cut into the pasta with my fork and it was hard and dry. Not pleasant. Told the server. He said it's supposed to be like that and if he takes it back to the chef, that's what he'll say. Really? Huh. I guess I've never had "authentic" Italian food before. The server was very gracious and accommodating though and offered another "softer" pasta as an alternate. Sigh. I expected so much more from A 16. Sorry,  the food we got just plain sucked!
author: Pro S.

description: I love it.  I have yet to find a better pizza.  After I go to Delphina pizzeria I'll make sure to decide which i like better.   The Bianca pizza was incredible.  I was full but I did not want to waste it.  The raw and grilled fig salad was delicious as well.  They sold out of the pork belly which just means i have to go back.  Our waitress was really friendly and had awesome wine by the glass suggestions.
author: Lada M.

description:
A16....mmmm...delicious. I just went for the first time, and it definitely won't be the last.

The place is upscale but definitely comfortable. It's reasonably priced, but they've got a fantastic wine list and a sommelier. We ordered the 14-month proscuitto appetizer, and the sommelier suggested a great pairing with our pizzas. The wine was fabulous (if pricy, but that was our call), and our $12 pizzas were terrific. Just as good, or better, than a restaurant at twice the prices.

I'm definitely heading back.
author: Evan G.

description:
Named after a main route in Northern Italy, this cozy Italian restaurant is one of my favorite places. It's mainly neighborhood folks, but it definitely gets draws a crowd. Reservations are key, but you may not get in exactly on time. The place is oh-so popular. But don't be discouraged, the food is spectacular and authentic-tasting. Fresh ingredients are noted. I usually leave the wine recommendations to the waiters and/or sommolier. They've never let me down.

I've seen other reviews frustrated by the wait and wait staff - but I'm usually friendly to them, so, in turn, they're nice to me. Remember, these hard-working people have been on their feet for hours kissing our butts. They've always been great when I go. You can always head to their sister restaurant in Fillmore, SPQR. It's just as spectacular, if not better. But no reservations can be made. Get there early and wait in the line - or time it for the second round of seating (which is about 7pm). 

I know -- a little too much but it's all worth it. It's SF, people.
author: Tracy O.

description:
I was going to finish looking over that ridiculous 272 page voter info "pamphlet" and sample ballot before the BIG election day that everyone is all abuzz about.  Some folks in the East Bay have gone to vote at their registrar's by absentee ballot because they couldn't wait until Nov. 4th.  Like having urge incontinence.  How can you call that a "pamphlet" when it's almost 300 pages?  Isn't "mini-dictionary" more appropriate?  

Oops.  How did I get on that subject when I'm suppose to talk about A16?   I was throwing out some old receipts and found the A16 receipt from a year ago this month.  I couldn't believe how much we paid for 12 sm. plates, a bottle of red wine and 1 cup of coffee, almost $200!  Given the current "recession" we're in, I wouldn't spend that kind of $$ today for the food we had.  The bottle of wine was very good but accounted for 1/4 of the bill. 

My BFF loves this place & brought all of us there.  We sat in the rear secluded room which reminded me of someone's porch converted into an additional room.  The large table of 12-14 next to us was so loud that it made dinner distracting.  I like eating in surroundings with not so much acoustic vibrato such that I'm unable to give my undivided attention to the food and company of friends.  

Most of the plates ran over $10.  The meat ones were $14 to over $20, for small portions.  We had the luganica and small salumi and the slices of meat were good.  They're known for curing their own meats.  The salsiccia pizza was OK, reminded me of a less flattering version of the flatbreat at  NOPA.  The roast lamb was not memorable.  The chicken meatballs and beef were OK, not great.  A large order of Maccheronara (pasta) at $28, was equivalent to a serving for one person, really highway robbery.   The gelato was fair.  It's a hip place to be at but not worth my hard earned money to make a return visit.  I'm tossing out that receipt now.  Ciao, Bella.
author: Ry T.

description:
Actually, I want to give it 3 1/2 stars but anyway.. (why can't you do 1/2 star ratings?).

After reading different message boards and reviews from others, I expected the place to be quite snooty. However, all of the staff (servers, hostess, even the chefs/cooks) were gregarious and warm. If they faked it, they did a good job.

I was seated at the chef's counter so that I could watch them prepare the food. The appetizer I had was a special and not on the menu. Pork something...I don't remember. So no review of that.

I ordered the Margherita pizza. The crust was nice and thin and all the ingredients tasted fresh. But, they didn't seem to meld together. Rather, it was as if I was tasting all the ingredients individually on a foundation of a pizza. Anyway, it was still tasty.

I had a glass of  Taurasi during the meal. It complimented the pizza nicely and was enjoyable on its own as well.

A 16 is worth a visit but I would not be frantically dialing reservations trying to get in. I don't think I would ever be craving A 16 but I will go back sometime.
author: Shawn T.

description:
Good Italian Fusion,

Nice but mechanical wait staff.

split layout, Front house / Back house deal.

Usually more crowded than a Japanese Subway, it's mostly populated with drunk blond bimbos and or their Newsome look-alike boy toys.
author: Mark B.

description:
I recently dined there with my husband and some friends of ours. It was absolutely fantastic! While we waited for our guests to arrive we had a lovely sparkling rose at the bar and once we were seated the great sommelier assisted us with our wine selections and kept us well within our budget while selecting fantastic wines. Our server was extremely helpful, fun and professional and the food was out of this world. We had (just to name a few) the octopus and potatoes, beet salad, bianca pizza, gnocchi... all was great. We ordered too much but, found a place for it. 

I will definitely return.
author: J B.

description:
One of the first places I tried when I moved to the city. This is the essence of pizza. Pizza, invented in Campania, Italy, is made at A16 in the traditional fashion. Fired in brick ovens...cracker-thin with just-the-right-amount of chewiness. If you've never had pizza in Italy, you might not understand.

If you have, this is the real deal. Not only that, they have an amazingly obscure wine list with a ridiculous amount of southern Italian wines. Restaurants that make the effort to challenge your concepts of fine food and drink get high marks in my book.

Yeah, and try the Burrata Mozzarella. Not only is it delicious, it's fun to say as well.

This is one of those I'm-so-rich-and-cool-and-I-live-in-the-Marina places, so you might want to wear your Italian shoes and blazer when you come here.
author: Berg W.

description:
With all the hype that A 16 was getting (still am) I have been dying to try it so finally my friend and I went there last Sunday for dinner.   We were seated about 10 mins. after checking in and taken to the back room - place looks lot smaller when you first walk in but it's decent size.  

We started with a plate of prosciutto - that was a nice big potion size.  I did have to ask for more bread to go with the prosciutto three times before I got it.  That was annoying.  The wine recommendation was great - sommelier came out to help us!  I ordered the Roasted beef tri-tip with cherry tomatoes, wild arugula and grana padano and my friend had the Mixed roast of Watson Farm lamb with fennel, carrots and herbs.  I really liked the lamb - extremely juicy and full of flavor but the cold/warm fennel was not (in our opinion) a good combination with the lamb.  My tri-tip was alright - nothing to make me "ohh ahh" or dream of having more of.  

Overall it was an ok experience but sadly had higher hopes based on the review.  I will say next time I'm going to sit at the bar for drinks and appetizers only!
author: Lily W.

description:
Our server looked like Linda Hamilton (you know, from Terminator) and sort of acted like it as well.  She had a bitchy attitude and was pretty inattentive to boot.  

The food was good, albeit somewhat inconsistent.  Meatballs were flavorful but on the mushy side.  Gramigna nera was kind of creepy-looking but admittedly delicious.  The gnocchi looked like chunks of honeydew, but was very good, especially with the spicy kick added by the chiles.  The yogurt panna cotta was perfect - light, creamy, and beautifully complemented by honeydew, pistachios, and perilla.  

All in all, I'm sure I would have enjoyed the experience had I been assisted by a more personable server.  I may give the place another try, but definitely not in the near future.
author: Annabel C.

description:
Good, but not great.  One of the restaurants that polarizes people - perhaps it is the hype, but it has always underdelivered relative to expectations.  

Pizzas? Good.  Pastas? Good.  Burratta? Very good.  

I guess I just don't see what the fuss is about.
author: Sean C.

description: This was a place I WANTED to like...but it was SOOOO damn salty. Every single item was drowning in salt. It SHOULD have been good, but it just wasn't.
author: Josh B.

description: A16 is a horrible restaurant with a horrible manger. Our food was ice cold so we asked them to heat it up and we were told that the kitchen was too busy. The manager was sent over and she was incredibly rude and ruined our entire evening. She thinks she is lena dunham. I will never step foot in a16 again.
author: Gil M.

description:
Being a "homemade" pizza enthusiast I usually don't have high hopes but the pizza at A16 was good. The service was OK and there was an inviting character about the place. A trendy spot for sure. 

One observation, and it may have been just a vendor issue that day, is that when attending a business lunch at this restaurant is that there was only one choice of salad. Lunch = salad in many circles so it was a bit strange to here our table of six order the arugula salad six times. 

That said, I will give it another try. Any place that will add an egg to their pizza, in true European style, is worth a redo.
author: Alona G.

description:
Ate here today for lunch.  Enjoyed the entire experience.  We sat at the Chef's Bar, watched Nate Applemen and his crew hack an entire pig (yummy), and ate.  Housemade spicy salame, meatballs, calamari pizza.  Spicy salame and meatballs were delicious.  Calamari pizza was a more mature taste for my pallete.  I finished with a housemade chocolate gelato and the BF had an Italian Moscato.

Come on Wednesdays for lunch to enjoy the chefs in action with their butchery skills.

We will have to come back for some dinner action.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
I had some friends visiting from Colorado who had heard about this place from a friend back home.  They HAD to eat here during their stay with me.   I made a 10pm res, but we still had to wait for 20 minutes for a table, even though there were plenty of empties available.  Whateva...we had some cocktails while we waited.  The hostess finally sat us waaaaaaay in the back where it was uncomfortably cold.  We politely asked to be reseated in another, warmer place, and they grudgingly complied with our request.  

We settled in nicely and waited another 15 minutes for our server to drop in.  Service was incredibly slow, but, being in the biz myself, I understood that the staff was probably winding down for the night.  Our server was super nice, and once the ball was rolling, everything was pretty good.   Except for everything I ordered.  The pinot noir blows, and the tri tip was tasteless slices of beef atop a mound of arugula.  Pass the salt, please.  Some sort of sauce would have been nice.  My dinner companions were gracious enough to share their entrees with me so I wouldn't starve.  I gotta say, tho, the lamb chops were awesome. 

To sum it all up: kinda pricey and nothing to write home about.
author: Shauna H.

description:
Went here last night, and had a fantastic dinner.

Arrived a little late for my reservation, and was seated in about 10 minutes.  Our waitress was prompt and attentive without being over bearing --  a difficult balancing act in a place as crowded and bustling as A16.  

For starters we ordered the Mozzarella burrata and the Meatballs.  I love the burrata -- get it every time I come -- and the Meatballs are amazing.  They are reason enough alone to only come here on Monday nights (the only night the meatballs are served).

For the mains we got the Ricotta Gnocchi and the Crespelle of Lamb.  The Lamb was sublime, while we both felt the Gnocchi needed a sauce with a little more body and/or flavor to stand up to the dumplings.

Dessert was the Blackberry Panzanella, where, as fresh as the blackberrys were,  the the honey panna cotta and the basil oil stole the show.  They should make that a dessert all on it's own.

For the wine, the sommelier did a great job of steering us towards something that complemented both of our mains really well, was very flavorful on it's own, was something completely different from anything I've had before, or would have even considered (the strongest aroma in the bouquet was rose petals!?), and was shockingly affordable (I think it was around $40).  The bottle was taken home so that it can be hunted down for future consumption :-)

I wish I could give 5 stars, but the Gnocchi didn't quite cut it.

When you go, definitely ask for the sommelier's recommendation -- if for no other reason to try something really good, and completely different!
author: Maneesh B.

description: Took my wife and daughter here last Sat. We have been here a couple of times before. I would say always consistant, fun, friendly. Daughter had the Margherita pizza(looked delicious), Robyn had the Fregula--must admit I am not a fan of fava beans, but these were so tender. Very tasty mixed with the white corn. I had the lucky dog ranch beef. Perfectly med-rare and sliced thin. The wine selection is amazing. High recommend. Book way in advance as reservations are hard to get last minute. Or, take a chance and sit at the "chef's bar" and watch the action.
author: Mark W.

description:
I last came to A16 three years ago, and had a pretty lackluster meal. Usually that means no revisit, but had a sudden urge to try it again last night. Being a true creature of impulse, off we went. 
And I'm glad we did. Every bite was delicious. The signature burrata didn't disappoint, but the real starter star was the roasted sunchokes and cipollini onions. The pasta with sundried tomato and almond pesto was hearty and intense flavored, but the bianca pizza (with a fried egg perched on top) was even better. The wine choices were spot on, and the sommelier super friendly.
I've heard that dessert is not the memorable part of an evening here, but we really enjoyed our almond cake and mascarpone mousse. Could have been the heady wine talking. But then, that just means they're playing their cards right.
author: Purnima M.

description: I went here on a first date last week and it was the perfect spot! Definitely make a reservation before you go, as it is a pretty small venue. We were originally sat at the "chef's table" which is a bar stool seated area right in front of the kitchen. It sounds greater than it really is, as the heat from the pizza oven was scorching hot! Once we moved, we were delighted by the wait we'd knowledge of the menu and his recommendations. We had the bruschetta, duck, and chicken sausage with a carafe of wine. We finished off the meal with a couple of ports (very delicious). Definitely recommend for any occasion!
author: Kristina C.

description: We sat at Chef's table and got to watch all the action! Stop in here by chance and so glad we did, pizza was YUMMY! Service was pretty good and friendly.
author: snails s.

description: Terrible service. Food mediocre. Charged us for a $250 bottle of wine but we drank a $50 bottle. I am not first to report this.
author: Ana E.

description:
My gf and I just dined there last night and was really underwhelmed by one person's service...  Here's my email that I sent to the info@a16sf.com mail address.  

To Whom it May Concern --

I'm writing this email to you in order to express feedback on our dining
experience last night.  Normally I wouldn't take the time to write negative
feedback if I don't want/expect consideration in return, and in this case, we
don't think we'll be going back.  But I am writing because I think it's unfair
that one person's attitude/service fixes a negative impression and diminishes
the quality of work of the rest of your staff.

[... rest of email deleted by author ...=

We eat out about 8-10 times a month at restaurants such as TarTare, Aqua, La Suite, Slanted Door, etc.  We normally don't try hang out in the Marina as most of the crowd there "tries too hard."  Given the overall negative experience at A16, there's probably less of a reason to go there than there was before.  Too bad.  We were following a great host from TarTare there, and though we like the host, will not risk suffering another negative experience.  Food was reasonably priced and good, though.
author: Mike P.

description:
I came to this place with pretty high expectations...having listened to all of the good reviews. Unfortunately A16 did not live up.  After waiting an hour to be seated, which was fine because we didn't have a reservation, we were seated with only one menu even though there were two of us. After asking for a second menu, the waitress and hostess both acted like they were listening and then completely ignored us. Next after mulling over what to order and being completely convinced by my waitress that I should get the fantastic albacore, she comes back to report that, oops, they are out of that one.

On to the appetizer...we ordered burrata which came with what was supposed to be some crostini, and which unfortunately looked like a burn victim.

My chicken dish was fare but certainly not worth the rude service and expensive prices. 

I really prefer not to be treated like I am in a cheap burger joint when I am paying over 20 dollars an entree and 10 or more for a glass of wine!
author: Lauren H.

description:
My boyfriend and I sat in the back room, which I guess is supposed to evoke sitting in an ivy-clad patio? It was a bit drafty, a little bare, incongruous with the rest of the restaurant. After being led past the open kitchen, the cured meats, the wood oven, the intimate dining room, it was a little hard to settle for the back room, with a view of a blank wall, sandwiched between a man showing off about social networking and internet marketing (why is it always my luck to get seated next to the peacock guy?) and the table dominated by the asian girl showing off her foodie prowess (odds are good she has a really boring job like accounting)...but no matter...onto the food!

The bruschette with roasted sardines, minted english peas, and pickled onions. It was good at first bite, and the sardines well prepared. But the flavors - minted peas, pickled onions, sardines - didn't seem to meld together. Individually, the components tasted pretty good, but it didn't pack the punch I expected.

I loved the Napoletana. A house-cured salami with pepper is welcome in my house any time.

Pizza verde definitely surprised me. Chewy, dense, airy, flavor of a wood oven, the dough was delicious. The prosciutto on top was mouth-wateringly good. The asparagus crunchy and amazingly not overcooked the way it often is. Arugula plentiful, though I wish it had more of a peppery bite. So good.

Our server recommended a good medium-ranged Italian red which we enjoyed.

Good service, great food, positive experience. Will be back!
author: Sarah W.

description: Went for a work lunch. Sat in the patio and it was perfect. Shared a salad and the funghi pizza and the taste and portion size was just right.
author: Lulu d.

description:
Be careful when the table is being cleared!  My wineglass was knocked over, and my clothes, and my husband's clothes were soaked with red wine.  I am sorry...

Not even a phone call from the restaurant.

Thanks to Lindsay...accidents happen.  My faith in customer service is restored. They covered the cleaning costs.
author: Maven G.

description:
Overall food was good but not wow. We did a walk in cuz we were too late to make reservations. Our wait was an hour an a half but it passed by fast. Don't let their small entrance food you. This place is not only packed but quite huge. It took us a good long journey with the company of our hostess to finally seat us down at the end of the restaurant. We were in the back room.. felt like we were outside but the top was covered.  

Things that stood out for me was: the burrata with pruscuitto ,margherita pizza, and their bread with the olive oil.

Ambiance: hip, crowded, loud...not a date spot but great for big groups
Service was excellent!
author: stephanie n.

description:
Why?  So... I banned this place from my list a few years back after I called to make a reservation and the conversation went like this:

A 16: Hello
Me:  I'd like to make a reservation.
A 16:  (hugh audible sigh) ...  for when.  (in a sarcastic tone)
Me: For..get it.  Thanks...  (hung up)

I was shocked at the attitude on the phone and chalked it up to being a hip new restaurant and why do they need to be nice if they're booked solid every night.  

Then I kept hearing how it was one of my friends favorites in the city... read all the Best of reviews.  So... 3 years after the disappointing phone call I decided to try the place for my Husband's Birthday. 

I must have had the same hostess as I got on the phone 3 years earlier since she was very rude when we walked in.  Blonde girl...didn't get her name.  Then we waiting about 20 minutes past our reservation time, which is ok... kind of, but come on.... We make ressos for a certain time.  At least seat us in 10 minutes max.  

I had the pork which was pretty tasteless and boring.  I actually forget what my husband had since it wasn't spectacular either. 

What's the hype???  I don't get it.  A couple hundred dollars later... so wish we went somewhere else. 

Oh and the atmosphere... think cougars and balding men.
author: Kerry L.

description:
In the restaurant business for 25 years so some cache is present. I don't like to slam businesses but when they charge a lot, are packed and cruise on their laurels it's time to get Ghengis Khan or maybe even Gordon Ramsey. I've been meaning to go to this place for some time-don't live in the city anymore so it's a chore to drive 45 minutes, park, wait, etc. The last time I tried to get in had no luck and ended up in Acquerello, in hindsight, thank God.
On the phone, after I mentioned a special occasion, and after I was quoted the obligatory 5 and 9 rap, she called me back and had me in at 7pm. She was very nice and in fact, everyone I came in contact was very nice. The waitress was technically proficient and personable enough. The bussers were helpful. The hostess smiling. The crowd was toe to toe, table to table. It looked like a foodie slave ship...sorry about that one.
Something has happened here, and I say that because the reviews and accolades I have read on this place do not jive with the food that I ate that night, or my wife ate or even my teenage children. I mean it was marginal/mediocre. Can't think of any other "m" words.
1) the burrata was ok
2) the salad was allright
3)the pizza was wimpy (try Pane e Vino).
4) the pastas were wierd (NOT Italian).
5) the dining room was claustrophobic (not even French Bistros pack tables like that, try Florio).
6) My wife's fish, the black cod was silly bad
7) The wine list is the only thing, in my humble opinion, that really speaks of Campania.

The biggest difference that I see between restaurants here and, say in Europe is the following: Here, the chefs travel around from job to job trying to pad their resume. It's all about positioning and where you've "worked". In Europe, chefs dig themselves in for the long run because it is truly an honor and privilage to practice your passion and grow and mature doing ONE THING. Here, they want their resume to say:
Danko's
Boulevard
Slanted Door
Etc.
Etc.
Etc.
I think something is missing here. I think someone left and they haven't recovered. I ain't going back until they do. 
Bye.
author: alex f.

description: Their wine selection is superb and the pizza is amazing! I personally loved the Sauvignon blanc from napa. The staff was friendly and the bartenders provided GREAT service
author: Tauna S.

description:
At the risk of repeating myself, about which I just cannot care, A16 in San Francisco is my nirvana of restaurants.

A young man serving at a wine bar we went to earlier said the bubbly labeled #1 on the wine list was really good. On arriving at the restaurant, we discovered it was a Prosecco and ordered it. The kid was
right, so points to him!

With great difficulty because everything on the menu is totally intriguing
and you want to try it all, we ordered:
--Monterey sardine bruschetta with minted peas and pickled onions
--Trippa napoletana with onions, tomato, white wine and breadcrumbs
for our appetizers. It was G&J's first time eating tripe, and only my
second, and while its texture takes a bit of getting used to, it was
perfectly cooked, soft, and pleasant, and the sauce was just to die for. We had to order a basket of bread because that sauce needed sopping up, every drop of it. Thesardines on toast, which we probably should have eaten first, were very delicate flavors, and the fish was quite fishy-briny tasting. The mint was very restrained so that the flavors of the peas and the pickled onions could complement the sardine. And even the durned toast was just perfectly cooked. I can never talk highly enough of the simple perfection of the cooking in this place.

Next, we had the Capricciosa pizza (aka, let the pizza chef have his way with us and put whatever he liked on it). It came with smoked cheese, bitter greens, tiny pieces of pancetta, and was stupendous. They get their crust so thin and perfect, and with marvelous flavor to
it.

We ordered just one entree with two side dishes, hoping to save room for dessert. I got to choose and went for the black cod with a crust of olives, capers and a sauce of chilis, tomato and herbs. I adore black cod and this was prime (and of course, perfectly cooked, I just can't say that enough!). There was no need to even CHEWit; the fish just melted in the mouth. Our sides were cannellini beans with garlic and oregano, and roasted polenta squares (which were great with the sauce from the fish). Even the humble, simple beans at this place are a joyous pleasure in the mouth.

We ordered two desserts:
--Almond cake with roasted nectarines, florentine syrup, and sage semifreddo
--Cheese plate with mild bleu cheese, walnut toast, dark thin slices of date nut bread, and Marshall Farms honey
I think I'm going to dream about the sage semifreddo for weeks, and the
honey on that cheese plate was insanely good.

We were in pleasurable, over-filled pain for the rest of the night.
author: TL V.

description:
this place really sucks for lunch, i hear that dinner has more variety, but i'm not going to try & find out.
italy has the best pizza i've ever tasted. and A16 has about the worse. the crust is hard & the center is soggy. if you order the pork meatballs, that's all you get. 3 or 5 small meatballs. no soup, no salad , no bread.
we had wine for 3 which came in a carafe 1/2 the size of the glass. 
the service was good, the menu was meager, the price was high & the food was awful.
DO NOT go for lunch !!!
author: jane s.

description:
Sigh. 

I had very high hopes for A16, as I have only heard good things from my friends.... So dissapointed.

I had the fish which was topped with a mixture of toasted almonds and parsley.  I couldnt taste anything but the parsley, the idea seemed great but the parsley overwhelmed the tasteless fish.

My boyfiend had the porkchop, which was a poor cut of meat, made worse only by being overcooked.

Lets talk about the sides.  I had the cannellini beans, which were well.. my meal, as they far outshined my entree.  My boyfriend had the roasted corn which in a food magazine would have been perfect for the summer bbq spread, however, to eat - ridiculous.  Lets talk more on the corn.  Roasted corn sliced into 1/2 inch coins served in a small bowl.  To eat you must either a. try to cut the corn off the cob on your plate to render only 1/4 of a teaspoon of kernels or b. pick them up and eat them as mini corn cobs, making you look like you are at a mini-tea party for your 3 year old neice.

Saving grace was the wine.  Great variety and definitely made the meal.  Our server was also very attentive, and great- only wish the food had matched!

The couple one table over had the pizza, and the smell of that blew me away.  If I come back it will be for the wine and pizza -- which when I am planning to eat like that, I'd rather hit up pizza orgazmica for a slice then head home for a cold one.
author: Sara Ann S.

description:
SO F-ING GOOD!!

All I can say is that my experience was so great!  Started off with sharing a burrata appetizer.  I love burrata and I normally buy it at the store because I like my burrata creamy and most restaurants don't serve burrata my way.  But this was out of this world!  I highly recommended this appetizer.

Moving on to the pizza, so good.  One of the best pizza's I have had outside of Naples.  It is almost hard to even compare to Napoli style pizza because it is so good there, but this comes pretty close.  The crust was super chewy and the ingredients super fresh.  The pizza was big, so it can defiantly be used for leftovers or to share.  Yet, I must say the leftovers were pretty tasty too.  Either way wouldn't hurt.
