Anyway, if you are looking for a fabulous pizza with great wine, head over here!
author: Cara D.

description:
If you like real, original Italian food, you'll love A16's. What you won't love is that they take poor SF service to new heights (or lows depending on how you look at it). 

The hostesses are incredibly unfriendly. Perhaps it's due to the never-ending throng of people trying to get a table or maybe they're simply food elitists. 

Typically if you don't make reservations two weeks in advance you'll have to grab a drink at the bar for 30 minutes to 4 hours, depending on the night. The bartenders are knowledgeable but also don't understand customer service. When you want a drink, they avert their eyes and continue doing whatever it is they are doing, instead of giving you that reassuring nod that says "I see you and I'll be right over." This can be somewhat embarrassing if on a date to a nice restaurant. 

The upside is they have great wine. Much better wines overall and by the glass for price...especially when compared with the California Wine Merchant just down Chestnut. If only they could swap the customer service at California Wine Merchant for the staff behind the bar at A16... 

The wait staff takes forever to bring you food, remove dirty plates, ask if you want another glass of wine, and bring more bread...all things that you expect from a fine restaurant. 

However, if you can avoid getting an ulcer from the annoying service that abounds at every turn, you'll fall in love with the amazing food. I recommend a seat at the chef's table, a marble counter in back that goes along the open kitchen, providing a meal's worth of insight into food preparation that might only be rivaled by taking a culinary class. 

Conversely, if in Boulder, CO, I'd recommend you try Frasca Food and Wine, a much better and friendlier version of A16, which specializes on the northern region of Friuli. This restaurant might be what A16 used to be when it began. The meals are equally priced, but the food is about 50% better and the service about 90% better. 

So, in summary, great food but really horrible service. ...But this is San Francisco and no one has quite figured out how to do food in this city that encompasses great service, food, and price. Maybe that's a good thing because that just means there's room for more gastronomic entrepreneurship.
author: Jake V.

description: Great date spot. Definitely ask for a table in the back garden area with the twinkle lights. The extensive wine list and variety of options and portions on the menu made this place a stand out for me.
author: Samantha S.

description: I just had dinner at A16 last night - they do serve a nice pizza but the rest was rather unimpressive. For the crowd that this restaurant attracts, I am not sure what the draw is (maybe the ambiance?). The server all but laughed when I told her I do not eat meat and basically told me there were not many options for me. She did however, return to the table and make an additional suggestion. I went with the sqiud ink pasta, which was just okay. Of all the Italian places in town, I am not in a rush to return here - maybe for a glass of wine, but not for the food or service.
author: Holly K.

description:
This was my second visit at A16...I wanted to give it a second chance before I wrote a review. I have to admit, I just don't understand the hype. I agree, the mozzarella burrata was absolutely delicious, but the rest of the food left something to be desired. Our pizza was so spicy, I could barely eat it, and I had some rockin' heartburn afterwards. Ouch. Service was quite good, however, and the sommolier really knew her stuff. Not bad, but not great either.
*3 1/2 stars*
author: Brianne K.

description:
Oh my gosh the mozzarella burrata is outstanding. I would go just for that. Although everything else I've ever had is just as fantastic. My other fave is the maccaronata...nice and simple - just pasta with tomato sauce - but it's so good. 

It can get a little loud in the main area of the restaurant but great atmosphere. Cool counter seats too so you can watch the chefs do their thing. If you're on a date, try to get a table in the back on the covered patio area...it's a little quieter and oh-so-cozy...
author: Kate S.

description:
Made Resers online,  arrived early, waited for friend.  Parking its tough. Cute girl beyond the bar but I digress.  Moretti on tap!  Impressive. Seated near the back, ask for patio if you can get it.  Tables along wall are tightly packed so quiet conversation not possible.

Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostin to begin.!  This is cows milk mozzerella but it's also made with cream so that's why the consistency is so smooth.  Fat content times 100 but it's so good going down.  If you'll pardon the expression! . A must order item!  Followed up with House cured Ciccioli.  Fatty but goes really well with Syrah or Cab. I brought a '99 Novy Syrah.  Incredible but long gone now.

Should have stopped here or orderd a pizza but we went with main courses.  Did Watson Farms lamb., she went with Gramigna nera with octopus, borlotti beans, tomato, garlic and basil.  Nera means black!  Be prepared or know what you're ordering.  Very strong taste of Octopus which did not go with wine.  She liked it but not what she expected.

Dessert:  Honey semifreddo with cornmeal croccante and blueberries.   Nice experience, staff was great, Yep, I'm a fan but both of us felt no need to hurry back.  About that Mozzerella burruta though.....
author: Steven R.

description: Smells great, which is ALWAYS a good sign.  A little on the Marina side but the food was great, and Charley Brinton paid for it.  What a guy!
author: Jack M.

description: Excellent dinning experience, delicious food and fantastic service. Always wish the portions could be a little larger but it's worth the high quality ingredients used.
author: Meghan P.

description:
Another restaurant checked off the list. 

Came here for a Sunday dinner. Reservations on opentable were convenient, and there was only had to wait a few minutes for our table to open up. Service was friendly and helpful. The place is quite energetic and the ambiance fits the mood. Somewhat subdued lighting, with an almost gastropub-like feel. They also have quite a wine list. 

Food:
1) Burrata w/ crostini - Nice. The olive oil balanced the saltiness of the cheese well. 
2) Beet salad - Love roasted beets, and the beets in this salad were bursting with beety flavor. 
3) Gnocchi with guinea hen ragu - gnocchi were pillowy soft and delicious. The guinea hen ragu was interesting. 
4) Squid ink pasta - very good, the noodles were chewy
5) Lamb chops - Outstanding, some of the best lamb I've had in a long time
6) Fennel sausage pizza - Loved the crust, you could really taste the fennel seeds in the sausage, which kind of reminds me of the sausage you get on a frozen pizza, but the pizza was very good. I'd have to do a side-by-side with Delfina to really make the comparison
7) Meyer lemon panna cotta - excellent, with the lemon flavor really coming out and the olive oil shortbread a nice accompaniment
8) Chocolate budino with sea salt - has this sea salt on dessert thing been around forever? Rich and chocolatey, drizzled with olive oil, which adds an interesting flavor element to the taste. 

Thank goodness for the Blackboard Eats discount code we had when we came to A16 for dinner, though, cuz we ran up quite a bill! 

Still on Michael Bauer's top 100 restaurants in the bay area, so will have to keep working my way through that.
author: Saunders C.

description:
went for lunch.  Great little place on Chestnut with beautiful, warm interior.  Looks are deceiving, actually quite large (deep restaurant).

Bartender was fantastic - friendly, knowledgeable and efficient.

Ordered Coppa di testa - Pig head cheese.  yes, head cheese.  Had no idea that this was going to turn out like a terrine.  Was expecting a sort of dried meet a la salami, sopprasata.  It was like a terrine - mind you, I am not a big fan of terrines so I am not good judge.

Read in a recent Cucina di Italia magazine that A16 has one of the few authentic Neapolitan pizza places in the country.  Having been many times to Sally and Pepe's in New Haven, I came in with great anticipation and high expectation.  

Ordered the margherita - meh.  The dough was fine though a bit soggy in the middle.  The sauce tasted like San Marzano and nothing else (good tomato-y but didn't grab me), probably not enough either.  The mozarella was fresh but didn't really add much.  Net net, good pizza but not stupendous.  have had better, even in SF.
author: Madison W.

description:
I wasn't too thrilled about heading to the Marina to eat at some Italian Restaurant called A16 - yuppified name didn't help none to much in terms of lending credibility to some good guido fare. 

I have to admit that I was more than pleased from the moment we sat down. The space was great. It had a really good feel... sorta like Bar Bambino but a whole lot bigger. And, I didn't realize prior that the food/wine was southern Italian. That really appealled to me since my family is a quarter Sicilian. From the wine recommended to the starters - coppa, olives, beet salad; to the entrees - pork roast, pork chop, tri tip; to the desserts - lemon granita w/zabalione, apple tart, chocolate gelato... let's just say we were quite HAPPY after dinner.

Thanks for doin' right by our familigia!
author: JB B.

description:
The pizza is fabulous. The crust is perfect, the sauce and cheese (if present) are in proper balance. 
The meatballs are awesome. Any of their ragu's that I've tried have been great too. 
Nice wine list. The flights are fun and a decent value.
I like the slant on specific regional cooking and they do it very well! It is true to the tastes and styles of Campania.
I also love the name - A16 is the Autostrade in Napoli. Brilliant!
author: Rick R.

description:
I visited A16 on a Friday night as a birthday treat from my partner - the restaurant Zinzino that used to be here was where we had our first date many moon ago and we had some great pizza back then.  An Italian friend of mine had said Zinzino was one of only two places in the City with authentic pizza that she would eat (the other is Pazzia which still has great pizza).  Unfortunately for us A16 didn't live up to our memories of Zinzino (okay, there really is no reason it should since it was a different restaurant) or expectations based on Yelp reviews.  

We started out arriving about 15 minutes early and since the place was crowded we knew there was little chance of getting seated early.  The hostess told us we were told we would be seated at the time of our reservation.  We luckily got a couple of seats at the wine bar within minutes and a very helpful and knowledgeable wine waiter helped us pick out wine.  We were enjoying sitting there but just as our bottle arrived we were told our table was ready.  

Our table was right at the back in an outdoor section behind a window which would have been bad since it was cold but fortunately there was a heater very close to us so it was okay but we did feel a bit left out of from the ambiance of the place.  Given the noise level in the restaurant that might have been an advantage though.  Our waitress was also helpful including pointing out that the salumi dish my partner had ordered was actually head cheese.  A substitution was suggested and gratefully ordered.  The food came out pretty quickly - no complaints there.

My husband stopper bean zuppa was actually very good - probably the highlight of the evening gastronomically.  But afterwards it was downhill.  The pork salumi my partner got was very fatty and reminded her of spam and so we put some bean soup on it to liven it up.  

My main was lamb with radishes and another bean based side dish - both were big disappointments.  The lamb was over cooked and dry - maybe it is the authentic Italian style for lamb and I'm just too used to medium-rare lamb in this country, but these well-done casserole sized nuggets of lamb just didn't do it for me, and the radish accompaniment added nothing to the dish.   I took two bites of the bean side and it was bland and very bready - my partner thought the same.  After the great bean soup we were both let down.  Some cheese or spices would have really helped.  For over $20 of food my main was a big disappointment.

My partner's main was the sausage pizza and it came with a pot of chili oil but there was already a substantial amount of that on the pizza.  In my mind too much and I like spicy and hot food.  If the chili oil is delivered on the side then I think the cook should really go sparingly or just leave it off altogether.  The crust was thicker, softer and doughier than I expected, altogether not much to write home about, maybe we just chose one of their less interesting pizzas and got a heavy handed serving of chili oil.

For dessert I had a fruit dish in a little pastry case that was unmemorable except for the honey ice cream which was tasty and very sweet.

Overall it felt like A16 had many elements to be a great place - perhaps it has been a victim of its own popularity that has lead to less that great food.  Or maybe a late seating on a Friday night is the wrong time to be eating there.  I can imagine that if you can walk in, sit at the bar, enjoy a nice wine and a pizza then you'll love the place.  If you looking for more gastronomically it was hard to imagine from our experience that you'll get it.  Clearly with all the other fantastic reviews we felt let down but it is unlikely that we'd ever trek across the Bay and across town to give it a second chance.
author: Simon W.

description:
After multiple visits I raise my rating to 5 stars. I just can't imagine not loving this place. The more dishes I try, the more I love.

Still believe: Make a reservation. Waiting for a table can be painful.

Still love: Order pizza or salumi plate.
author: Gina L.

description:
Wow. 

Seriously. Maybe I caught them on a good night but I have to admit, this was one of the best meals I have had in the city, and I have been to a few places.

We sat down at 9:15 after catching a movie across the street. Sunday night, no wait for two. I like that. Perhaps an hour earlier or on a different night it might (def?) have been different, but to sit immediately was such a relief. 

The server was a young girl who was very nice and quite helpful about answering questions. I like to poll the audience and find out what the server likes, dislikes, recommends and she was very forthcoming. 

The wine we picked was a Barbera blend that was very good, kinda chilled. Not sure of the name unfortunately.

We started with two apps, the escarole salad (new on the menu that night) with green apples and I believe pecorino cheese/fried almond bits, and it was very good. I thought it might be kinda plain, but the mixture of the apples and cheese was perfect, great compliments of each other. I also forgot how much I love escarole, it has a unique texture which reminds me of bok choy (am i crazy?). 

We also got the octopus zuppa, which was AMAZING, and also new on the menu. Chickpeas, sliced tentacles and wilted escarole in a deliciously spicy broth. Really, this was kind of mind blowing. I wanted to stop eating it but it was difficult. It was almost as if they new what kind of things I like b/c the spiciness was just what the doctor ordered, like they read my mind.

Next we shared a pizza, the Bianca. I love white pizzas and this did not even come close to disappointing. I remember I turned to my gf and said, "better than Delfina" and even today, I think I meant it. We got pancetta added and it was well received. Again reading my mind, they brought out this chili oil which you apply to the pizzas and it was so good. I thought there was only a select few of us who really like to spicy-up their pizzas, and so seeing that oil was very nice. 

We skipped the dessert. Too stuffed, so nothing to report there. But damn, this place was good.
author: Jeff G.

description:
Friends and I went to A16 last week.  Pizza was just OK, and the burrata (as other people have pointed out) was incredible, but we had a terrible waitress--just really terrible.  I don't typically berate wait staff, but please humor me and my crazy-lady rant.

The woman watched us 4 girls order two appetizers, two GIANT pizzas, and two pastas, reminding us the pastas could be ordered large.  If you follow my math, this adds up to WAY TOO MUCH FOOD.  When my friends and I realized our eyes were infinitely larger than our stomachs, we asked the waitress to cancel the pastas, and she made no effort to pretend she wasn't incredibly annoyed.

Any competent waitress should know her menu well enough to see when too much is too much, and any waitress who knowingly lets her customers over-order, and isn't gracious about customers changing their minds, is just a BAD waitress.  

Lame.  Will probably never go back.
author: Tiffinie M.

description:
All I can say is excellent food for a place that's been in business for 5 years. I happened to show up alone on a night when the owner's grandmother was in town - she was in the kitchen making pasta. Insanely great.

Outstanding wine selection as well.

I felt like I was back in Italy.
author: Victor Z.

description:
I definitely won't be returning. Utterly unremarkable meal. The sardine bruschetta (with mint, peas and red onions) was pretty interesting and tasty, if a little dry. The service was great, but, man, did the entrees suck. I had the pork plate, which consisted of three pork riblets -- too dry and very fatty (I know, how is that possible?). There was also pork jowl (I think?) which was about 90% fat. And not in a "damn that's a nice slab of bacon" sort of way. It was greasy and just sorta slid down my throat and felt like it would soon be leaving me. The side of chard was overcooked and bathed in oil. My friend didn't have much better luck with his steak entree. 

It's a cute space, but the culinary experience is severely lacking.
author: Chris O.

description: The food was very average at best.   The pasta did not blow my mind and my dad ordered the pork chop and it was a piece of fat.  The waiter explained that it was fatty because of the type of pork chop it is... well, I think he should have mentioned this prior to our order.  It was quite disgusting.  I watched my dad cut away chunks and chunks of fat and had to return it back to the kitchen.  The pizza margherita was a solid A.  With all the great restaurants in the area, I would probably skip this one and go to another.
author: Agatha H.

description:
There are several reasons why A16 is the best restaurant in the city.

1) You can always eat there, even without a reservation.  The hostesses really do have the mostesses and take care of everyone, from Marina trash to scrubby jean hipsters.  They might make you wait for a table but you can ALWAYS get one if you decide to wait, unlike some restaurants (ahem, Delfina).

2) Fantastic wine selection.  I recommend tasting the Women Wine Makers trio.

3) You can eat here for such a reasonable price if you order smart: an appetizer, a salad and a pizza for two.  Extra cash to splurge on a bottle of red.

4) Speaking of pizza!  They have authentic ovens and a simple selection that includes upgrades with prosciutto and arugula.  Mmmm!
author: Mz M.

description:
Just visited again on Sunday.  We mixed it up a little this time and ordered entrees as well as pizzas.  I'm seeing burrata on a lot of Italian menus these days, and I really like A16's take on it.  I had an incredible plum hazelnut crostata for dessert.  As always, I enjoy digging into their unique wine list.

Try all the pizzas.  It's a little tight in there and it gets warm by the ovens (especially if you've been indulging in their impressive wine selection), but it is outstanding stuff.  I could just sit there and eat olives.  Wonder why they chose Chestnut Street for the location?
author: Bridget T.

description:
All I really have to say is, Eh...

My brother had hyped this place up, claiming it as his favorite restaurant in San Fran. So, I had high hopes. But everything tasted the same and kind of bland. Plus, it was a bit on the pricey side for what they bring you (size-wise and taste-wise).

The wine was just okay, nothing to write home about. But, the desert was actually good.

It also doesn't help that I woke up in the middle of the night with the "I ate something I shouldn't have... I've got a deep down not-so-good feeling."
author: Golmar M.

description:
A co-worker recommended this place saying it was great and not too touristy. We didn't have reservations but managed to get one of the last tall tables. 

The food came out quickly and it was good but felt like I left a little hungry!

Definitely a good place for a date.
author: Susie M.

description:
A 16 is my absolute favorite place to go out for dinner in San Francisco, period!  I've been going here ever since the first month that they opened and visit quite frequently.  The service is always perfect, ALWAYS.  The food has NEVER once let me down.  The appetizers, main course, pizza, everything is well thought-out and very well executed.  I could probably go on and on and on about this place!  And $10-15 for the size and quality of the pizza!  Forget about it!  I was just in Italy about a month ago, in Rio Maggiore among other places, and let me tell you; THEY GET IT RIGHT AT A 16!

Another thing that's great is that if you love wine as I do, the servers are extremely knowledgeable so don't hesitate to ask; if you're lucky you'll catch Andrew for a wine question.  

The only set back is that it's ALWAYS crowded, but that's fantastic because the owners deserve all the business, I hope that it STAYS crowded.  Plan ahead to enjoy a special night at A 16!
author: Dustin T.

description:
I was really excited to go to A16 as I had read so many great reviews.  My wife and I were quite disappointed with our experience.

We sat in the back of the restaurant; it looks like it was once an outdoor space that is now covered.  There was a floor drain and my chair was sliding down toward it, so we moved tables.  The overhead outdoor lights had a problem as they continually got dimmer and then brighter again.  It was surprisingly annoying and brought on a slight touch of nausea.

We ordered our food and selected only a main course and wine since we had lunch at Boulevard in downtown SF and weren't really that hungry.  Our lamb dishes were brought out before the bread and olive oil, which we had to ask for.  The lamb was very good, well prepared and tasty.  The accompanying side salad was fresh, but chopped up Romaine lettuce with a vinaigrette dressing was much too unimaginative and too large (quite disappointing).

During dinner, a three top was seated at our 1st sloping table.  They seemed to have quite the time with the musical chairs as they too had difficulty getting comfortable on the decline (it was a small table for 2, let alone 3).  They ordered wine and the sommelier spend a solid 5 minutes trying to open a bottle of red, all the while having her rear end uncomfortably close to my wife's head.  Quite unprofessional on the sommeliers part (no spatial awareness even though the table next to her was empty).

Everyone seemed to be in a hurry especially the waitress and the food runner.

Then the waitress dropped of the dessert menus, literally.  Sort of tossing them to us.  She was in a hurry to attend to her other duties/guests.  We declined.  The check finally came, we paid and on the way out we addressed our concerns to the floor manager.  

She was quite apologetic and seemed to have an excuse for everything that happened, although, she did ask us to give A16 another try.  She even said that the sloping table, the one in the very back right by the door was the favorite of some of A16's guests.  Hard to imagine.  And no thanks, there are so many great restaurants in SF there is no need to settle for second rate one especially if the best they can do is "Sorry, but give us another try".  Maybe their staff should eat at Boulevard and see how it's done.  Only 10% of dissatisfied customers say something, the rest just don't come back.

We were quite disappointed especially after all the great reviews.  It was not a great way to cap of our anniversary.
author: Kai T.

description: LOVE LOVE LOVE the food. the Wine selection is AMAZING! The wait staff is always on the ball and it is a beautiful decor. Beware of the double-popped collar douches that frequent this place on a Saturday night, but that is not A16's fault. Also, Saturday night they might be running late on your reservations, but will likely buy you a drink for your trouble.
author: Emily P.

description:
The wine list is perfect, expand your horizons and look at it online before you go eat so you know what to order.  This is a wine list for people who give f'uck.  Learn your shit and then order something good.

The food is impeccable and you don't need to order pizza to have a good meal.  The pork shoulder is the sweetest hog I have ever suckled.  It is the best piece of pork I have ever eaten.  We are lucky to have this dish in our city.

Go here. Relax when your table is not ready.  Then order something people would have known how to cook 1000 years ago.  You will leave satisfied.

This place is in the heart of the Marina so be prepared to deal with that, if you are the food is worth the company you keep.  Once you get a table if you bring someone you like to eat with you will be fine.
author: Glenn P.

description:
I have been wanting to hit this place for about a year and for some reason never got around to it. Let me tell you. As an Italian lover (both in food and men) - this place was great. But not for a family style 'stuff your face with pasta and bruchetta' kind of place. The pizza was fab - I recommend the margarita with arugula. And the wine list is off the hook.  The pastas tried a bit too hard and missed for me. Next time I will go back and just sit at the bar - get myself a fabulous glass of wine and a pizza. Oh, and try the salumi selection. They cure their own meets people!

Oh, and our waiter was fabulous. Darling Darling Darling. Super helpful and fun.
author: Sarah P.

description:
A16 is our all time favorite authentice Italian restaurant. We just love the atmosphere and the design of the dishes there. We keep going back there. The place is fun and trendy, although casual and comfortable and kids-friendly.  My favorites there are Mozerrella burrata and salumi, pasta (you got to try differnt pasta dishes according to the season).. BTW, I love it that they give you just enough. I do hate it when some America Italian restaurant give you a hugh dish of pasta all soaked in spaghetti sauce..
Well, the pizza is very authentic - thin, crispy and simple!
We also had the pork chop last weekend and it's amazing. It's so tender, juicy and tasty.
No even mentioning the dessert and coffee. You can always count on them to surprise you with some really creatic while simple desert to delight you! Coffee is good and reasonable priced!
author: Fion S.

description:
I live right around the corner and always see a crowd of people here, so I thought there must be something to this... 

My hubby and I decided to give it a try tonight and boy was it a disappointment!  Besides the Funghi pizza, which was all right, the whole experience was less than I expected.  We ordered the Coulotte (a thin sliced beef dish) for $24. There were maybe six little greasy, rubbery pieces of meat. The ends were so hard to chew that I actually couldn't swallow it and had to put the half-chewed piece into my napkin. The middle was full of fatty pieces and the taste was bland. 

In the middle of eating the chard (just so-so tasting greens), I found a piece of something hard, and even asking the waitress, we couldn't figure it out. I hope it wasn't someone's fingernail! They replaced the bowl of chard, but that further ruined my appetite.

The service was also substandard. The waitress kept forgetting things (my water, my lemon, to fill the water) and when I asked her for these things, her attitude seemed to say: "Just hold your horses! I was just about to get to you!" I felt like I shouldn't have asked or something.

I'm not sure why so many people keep coming to this restaurant. Maybe it's because of the hype and the perception that it's a "Hip" happening place, but atmosphere alone can't get me to come back. The food and service are just a little bit important to me too. I felt like I was ripped off after spending so much and getting so little satisfaction in return.
author: Jade C.

description:
Fun time; lots of energy; packed spot; tight quarters; very sceney. But the spot was a little too hip for its own good. Not a TON of different options. Pizzas were very interesting. Getting the egg on top sounds cooler than it is. It seems the common way to go is to each get a pizza and mix-and-match slices. But don't count on finishing - the pies are pretty substantial. 

I would have been inclined to have given it a 4 if the bill hadn't ended up being so unexpectedly steep. 

And do note: it's beer and wine only - nothing hard!

And if you're a diet coke junkie - their substitute hardly suffices.
author: Patrick H.

description:
Hit and Miss. First experience not so great. 2nd experience was much better. Pizzas are good, but not That great
I really want to like it....but it's inconsistent
i'd say it's just OK...but definitely overrated
author: Jocelyn L.

description:
Excellent pizza!  yum!  We had ricotta and cherry tomatoes and sausage, onion and fennel. We loved, loved, loved the zucchini salad, quite possibly the best use of zucchini ever. The beet salad was good, but the flavor in the zucc salad with the green olives and pecorino was truly outstanding. And...the chocolate bundino tart, OMG its soooooo good with the EVOO (sorry to sound like Rachel Ray) and the sea salt sprinkled over the creamy super chocolatey tart with the yummy chocolate tart crust. YUM!  I think about that dessert on almost a daily basis...I must go back to SF ASAP to have it again.

It was a little loud but we went early and I'm sure it could've been worse.  Our service was amazing.
author: Foodie M.

description: Probably the closest you will get to true Southern Italian food with out having to get on a plane. I've been there now a dozen times and can say the meals and service have never let me down. Like everyone else the pizza is great, and the wine list is excellent. The staff is knowledgable and on their game 7 days a week.
author: john g.

description:
These guys make an ok margherita pizza.  I'd call it Margherita Povera since the sauce tastes something like what you might get out of a can of Spaghetteos.  Now before the owners of the establishment get all hot and bothered about that reference it is kind of a positive since it works strangely well with the Mozarella, Basil and thin crust.  It's good in a way that it reminds me of coming home from school as a teen and making me a "pizza" in my toaster oven with some middle eastern pocket bread, tomater sauce from the jar and american cheese.  Mmmmm.  

Anyway despite that walk down memory lane it does not beat the more gold standard thin crust pizzAHHHss in town.  It is on par or a notch below Delfina though.

The location is Cow Hollow Marina so the crowd is solidly Marina types and is as crowded as any bar might be on a southern california dock bar or yacht club.  I wouldn't call it fun but it is a scene.  meh.
author: Chango M.

description:
I've been to this place probably 10 times now, and I order the same thing every time: Bianca pizza with an egg.  It's incredible.  It is the perfect pizza - salty Castelvetrano olives, cheese, basil, egg.  Heaven.  That being said, the service is not stellar.  They're pretty slow - we've waited over an hour for our food before (noting that other people seemed to be getting their food in a timely manner).  They don't like to refill your water glasses.  Last time, I was choking - CHOKING! (watch out for the red-hot pepper flakes in the Bianca) - and the waitress walked by several times without refilling my empty glass.  Also, they do this crazy thing where they take away your food to box up but then never bring it back to you unless you ask.  Every. Single. Time.  It's super annoying because I've forgotten to ask before and that pizza is not something you want to leave behind.  Also, skip the bread.  I've never had such bland, dry bread in my life - you're an Italian restaurant, for god's sake!!!

So I guess I really give this restaurant a one, but I give that Bianca pizza three fives, so it evens out.
author: Liz V.

description: Great spot for dinner.  Had a wonderful time, with excellent service and outstanding food.  Try this place if you have not already!
author: Michael J.

description:
I thought Delfina was my fave restaurant in SF...until now!  Everything was delicious...especially the Fava Beans perfectly grilled and spiced with mouthwatering chillies.  

I'm giving 5 stars for two reasons:
1.  I felt like I was having a meal in Italy instead of the Marina because we weren't hassled by wait staff asking us a million times "how is everything"  or "are you guys doing alright?"  We had a long, leisurely meal full of killer pastas and the Monday night meatballs.  Often times at nice restaurants you feel like they are rushing you out the door to turn over the table.  Not so here.  My boyfriend and I had a great time drinking wine and celebrating his birthday.

2.  The meatballs.  Lets just say I'm a vegetarian and I downed those meatballs in 5 minutes flat.
author: Alora D.

description:
The soup & pizza was amazing!  

We had even come from a party where we had been munching on appetizers, so were not too hungry...AND IT WAS STILL sooooo tasty.

I couldn't wait to dig into the pizza the next morning and it was fun sitting at the bar watching them make the food.  We will definitely be back.
author: eliza k.

description:
Came here to try their famous maccaronara with tomato ragu and house-made ricotta salata since it was on their 7x7 list for 2012, but left a little disappointed.

Food:
- Buratta- cheese was not proportional to the amount of bread provided--I guess it's good that there was leftover buratta but I wish they gave you a slice or two more of bread so I wouldn't have to eat the cheese by itself? Overall, the dish was lackng seasoning...it would've been great if they had sprinkled some salt before serving. 
- Margherita pizza- solid dish. Great flavors, decent serving--good for an app for four or more. The cheese was melting and the dough was thin. Yum! 
- Maccaronara- to be honest, it was the most lack luster dish we ordered. Pasta was thick and doughy, but I didn't care for it all. Flavors seemed lacking--I could taste was a light tomato sauce and I was not impressed at all. 7x7, you let me down once again! 
- Squid ink cavatelli with calamari- Definitely better than the maccaronara! Had a definite seafood flavor, but the combination of calamari + squid ink + seasoning went well together and tasted a lot different/better than the other squid ink pasta I've tried in the city. Pasta is a little bit on the heavier/thicker side, so I would recommend the smaller portion if you were having it to yourself.

The large portions of pasta are definitely good for two. We ordered the buratta, margherita, cavatelli (large) and maccaronara (large) to split between four and it was a good amount of good! 

Wine list is expansive and atmosphere is great! The place fills up quickly--we had a reservation for 6pm and the restaurant was filled to capacity by 7. Definitely make a reservation if you go, and arrive early because parking is a beez in the area.
author: Stefi C.

description:
My experience at A16 was so horrible it inspired me write a haiku:

The hostesses suck.
The food is mediocre.
Do not waste your time.

My boyfriend and I went to A16 last night expecting a peaceful and romantic evening filled with good wine, delicious Italian food and accommodating service. We were disappointed on all fronts. 

We waited 30 minutes for our 8PM reservation, all the while dealing with the snotty hostesses who did not once apologize for our wait. If I'm going to be given attitude, I'd rather get it from models hostessing at the newest hot spot in NYC, not SFU undergrads wearing their finest Banana Republic working the door at a douchey restaurant in the Marina.

The rest of the evening was simply "blah." The food was uninspired and very overpriced. We shared the beet salad, bucatini with almond pesto, verde pizza and the chocolate tart. All were fine, but far from excellent. The bucatini was particularly bland. The restaurant itself is also a pretty boring space, and the fact that it is perpetually crowded and noisy doesn't help. AND to add insult to injury, the flaky waitress never gave us our left overs! (not that they were that good to begin with..)

Do NOT give this restaurant your money and time. There are thousands of better places to go in SF and in the Marina (Maverick, Terzo, Umami, Bar Bambino, the list goes on...). where you will not have to put up with rudeness and mediocrity.
author: Jennifer S.

description: I went to A16 for a work dinner back in late May. Overall, it was great! The menu was a little small, and not many vegetatrian options, but the food we ordered was outstanding. Great beers, nice wine selection.
author: Maggi B.

description: Had dinner at A-16 while visiting San Francisco. The place was excellent, the pizza they made us is 99% perfect, authentic Neapolitan pizza. On top of that, they have some healthy devotion to fresh, local ingredients and a good wine list. My appetizer were some delicious oven-roasted porcini from northern CA covered with razor thin cured lard (and I'm not a fan of lard, whether it's on people or on my plate!)
author: Gabriele D.

description: For as much hype as this place has gotten, my experience here was terrible!!  The pizza was raw, the pasta was uncooked, and the service was just terrible.  My experience may be one off, but I truly don't plan on eating here again.
author: Sonia M.

description:
We had a date night last Saturday, very impromtu, but very appreciated.  A surprise to the city, but into the mouth of the Marina, oh well.  Surprisingly, it was civil, not too crazy, and even though we didn't have reservations, we lucked into a table.(probably because we ate so early and needed to get home)

Anyway, loved the wines from Campagina, especially the Falenghina and the Aglianico.  Burrato was good, the salumi good (love fennel) and tripes!  Where do you see tripes that often, and we ordered a second to have with the pizza margherita.  Yum, but it did get busy with the beautiful marina crowd fast, and it got loud.  Next time I will go with my mominlaw for a late lunch
author: Caitlyn L.

description:
Two words.
Meatball Mondays.

3 commands.
go, eat, enjoy.
author: Audra E.

description: I really don't know what all the fuss is about A16 and why it is so popular.  I find it over priced, poor selection and extremely noisy.
author: Julie D.

description:
Sadly, this didn't hit the spot.  I've been on a losing streak lately in SF, so maybe we can blame the stars or something.  
Awkward crowding around the host desk upon arrival, though... It's more of a design flaw.  Seated relatively promptly, though a good 10 minutes after our 8:30 reservation.  The long, narrow restaurant opens gracefully into a quaint dining room with exposed kitchen and a little almost "outdoor" nook.. Presumably for private dining etc...
Ambiance aside, the food really lacked.  The squash bruschetta was delicious, however the crostini it was spread upon was dry and clashed with the silky and sumptuous topping.
The house made salumi was nice overall, though heavy on the salt and not fully cured.  It was paired with extremely astringent pickled vegetables that acted against the more delicate flavors of the charcuterie.  
My companion and I shared the Maccaronara and the steak.  Both were mediocre at best.  The pasta was undercooked to a point that it was sticking to our teeth.  All the flavors were there, though it wasn't enjoyable to eat.  The steak was a mess.  Our waitress never asked the preferred temperature and I realized it too late.  It came literally every temperature.  Each piece was either way over cooked or under.. Except for one perfectly cooked sliver that unfortunately couldn't make up for the dish.  Accompanying the dish were fingerling potatoes and a bit of arugula.. Severely in need of a binding sauce to bring it all together.  I chose the polenta as my side and it was also over cooked, in fact burnt... Only the very center hinted at what it should have tasted like.
Our wine was delicious however and our server was very knowledgable and chose an outstanding pairing. 
We were set on trying to enjoy our meal to it's fullest, so we opted for the chocolate mousse tart.  Again, the tart was so over cooked it was almost chalky.  Each bite disintegrated into a weird mush that just didn't mesh with the rich quenelle of mousse. I've never not finished a desert, but this was the first.
A 16 is a beautiful restaurant with a very talented team of food minded individuals, that much is clear.  Tonight just wasn't our night it seems.
author: Nathan K.

description:
An old friend came to town on April 6th and I am just getting around to writing my review. Still dreaming about some of the food though!
Our reservations were for 8:30; we were actually seated almost right away. They had two options for us: chef counter or a table, and of course we chose to sit at the counter.
Classic app: went for the burrata. You just can't go wrong with fresh cream-filled cheese! I also asked if you could get just one of the prosciuttos from the tasting since I am a huge fan of La Quercia (made in the USA!), and they surprisingly obliged. I did want a few more crostini, but knew I had to leave room for the delights to come.
We ordered an interesting white blend from Italy that went well with the salty meat and also the pastas that followed.
Next up: pastas. We shared the small portions of the squid ink tonnarelli and the gnocchi. The tonnarelli was black as night and twirled with spicy Calabrian chilies and tender little clams. My friend had never had squid-ink pasta before and delcared it delicious! I actually liked the gnocchi prep better - it was pillowy little gnocchi that were lightly sauced with braised guinea hen and pea tendrils, with an interesting cheese called pecorino canestrato on top.
We ordered an Italian red (their last bottle) to go with our entree; one of the best red wines I have ever tried, and my friend was in love with it as well. I wish I had taken a picture of the label or written it down but I was in a gnocchi-induced stupor. So we shared the lamb sausage entree with spinach and pickled currants. It was a perfect little coil of spiced lamb sausage, and the accompaniment was good too - we ordered the roasted sunchokes which had a great roasty flavor plus a little heat from the chilies. What's funny is that since we were at the chef counter, I was watching all these coils of sausage going in the oven and they looked so good - I didn't realize there was *another* sausage dish on the menu that was combined with porchetta!!! Super sad I missed out on that one, will just have to return to try it.
Just when we thought there was no more room, we went ahead and ordered the chocolate budino for dessert. Amazing! The soft creamy chocolate is slicked with extra-virgin olive oil and a few flecks of sea salt. It was hard to leave some on the plate but we had to! We also had an amazing dessert wine with this called Moscato di Noto that I will be on the look-out for. 
We ended up chatting with our servers and Chef Nigel for a while and pretty much closed the place down. All in all, a really great experience - thanks team A16! I was just glad that my friend was paying because with 2 bottles of wine and all those shared plates, the bill got pretty steep.

I really want to come back to try the trippa napoletana, but I'm still a little scared of it - maybe another bottle of wine would have given me some liquid courage!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
True confession - yes I used to live in the Marina. Yes - I love A16. One of the few reasons for me to visit this part of town. The other reasons are the Apple store and Janie and Jack for our little one. And let me not forget Bin 38. 

Anyway - love their meatballs, pizza and anti pasti. Great service, well paced and consistently great wine recommendations.
author: Ranjan R.

description:
At nearly 700 reviews, I think it's clear that A16 is great and its an open secret. Does anything more need to be said? Well yes. 

Lots of folks visit A16. Sometimes it rocks their world, sometimes not, depending on what they eat. So why visit A16 versus any other good mid-priced food in the city? 

Simply put, because of the food+wine pairing.If you simply get food here without a couple of wine pairings, you've gotten 25% of the experience. Instead of just a good funghi pizza or just a good glass of Aglianico, have them together and there's 5x more deliciousness. A16 does what they do well. and that is Southern Italian food + Southern Italian wine. 

Recommended dishes/wine:
tuna conserva + Statti Mantonico 
castelvetrano olives + Clelia Romano Fiano di Avellino
funghi pizza + Basilim Aglianico
some frizzante, sweet aperitif + house-cured meat
gramigna nera pasta + Librandi Ciro Rosso 
chocolate budino is just something you have to try. One of the best things in SF. 

did i mention the wine guys and gals are super knowledgeable and great folks?
author: Steph P.

description:
Get a reservation and show up early to experience the best regional italian cuisine in the Marina for sure, possibly the city. 

Cozy neighborhood joint with unpretentious cork finishes. Tall tables in the front, larger tables in the back with views of the open kitchen. Dim lighting adds to the quaint atmosphere. 

I can't promote one item because each one is prepared gracefully with depth and soul. The pasta, the pizzas, the meat, the anti-pasta momma mia!

I would eat here once a week if we were not in recession. 

Don't come rushed...enjoy yourself, your wine, your conversation.
author: Johnny H.

description:
I had a wonderful meal here with my wife and two of our friends.  The restaurant is small, but it can seat a fair amount of people, which means that you sit very close to other patrons.  The kitchen is open so you can watch all of the chefs hard at work.  
When I went, we ordered two appetizers, we all ordered one dish a piece and shared and we all ordered our own desserts (which we also shared).  A bottle of Presseco with the dinner was great and four cups of Blue Bottle Coffee ended the meal perfectly. The bill was reasonable for that amount of food.
Make a point to eat here.  Make a reservation!
author: Christopher D.

description: 2nd best pizza spot in San Francisco! So tasty and the wine is always AMAZING! Great service! 5 shiny stars :)
author: Katrina H.

description:
This place is incredible.  My buddy and I came here because I told him I wanted incredible Italian- and that's what I got!  We started with the Mozzarella burrata- a wonderful soft cheese with the perfect amount of flavor.  We also had the Tuna Conserva Panzanella, a tuna/artichoke/bread salad.  Absolutely incredible.  My friend ordered the meatballs (the special) and gobbled them up in about five minutes.  I had the Chicken.  

I don't normally order chicken from restaurants because my mother makes an incredible chicken, and no restaurant can compare.  While this chicken was not better than mom's, it was incredibly juicy which a nice amount of spices on the skin.  The side dish I ordered was Roasted carrots and turnips with green garlic, mint and chiles- the waitress recommended it, and was right on.  I would have bet money I hated turnips, but this totally changed my mind.  These were perfect.  

And then the dessert- one of the greatest desserts I have ever had, The Chocolate tart with sea salt and olive oil.  I never would have guessed that olive oil, sea salt, and a rich chocolate tart would go together, but this was absolutely top notch.  

The restaurant blew away my expectations, would go back in a heartbeat.
author: Will B.

description:
I begrudgingly give this Marina spot four stars. Not that it has anything to do with the restaurant, but that I claim not to be a fan of the Marina and A16 makes me feel like a liar. 

Stopped in on a Monday night over the fourth of July holiday.  Although it was busy and we didn't have a reservation, I greatly appreciate that they will call your cell phone when the table is ready. Our table for 2 took about 40 minutes, but we grabbed a cocktail down the street while we waited. 

I ordered a glass of the Montepulciano, simply because I have fond memories of driving through the town. And, I'm happy to report that this little Tuscan wine didn't disappoint. We weren't starving and didn't order starters. I had the Ricotta Gnocchi -- and loved it. Very light flavoring, delicate gnocchi and the squash blossoms were wonderful. 

So, all in all, thanks to A16 for a lovely dinner and making me reconsider my obnoxious opinion about the Marina.
author: Erin M.

description:
I'm a pretty spontaneous person, but perhaps I was a little ambitious with the Wild Boar Scallopine. Yes, I love meat, and perhaps it's the nature of wild piggly wiggly himself, but I felt that it was too tough.

But since people on Yelp just keep talking about the pizza pizza pizza at A16, I will put in my 2 cents worth: My dinner party informed me that the pizza chef had the official "Naples Stamp" to make these "authentic" pizzas. This could be bunch of hogwash, but the pizza itself is indeed good... but nothing orgasmic where I'd be conditioned to start salivating whenever I hear "A16 Pizza."

Thirdly, this place is in the Marina... which means pashminas, sweater vests, and trendy cowgirl hats (these are still in fashion? Give it to Brokeback); A16 is a trend. Good... not great. Eat here once, and I'm on my way.

Lastly, like many yelpers have mentioned, some dishes have too much salt. Lots of salt = high blood pressure. Plus it's pretty noisy and hot. Maybe it's because I'm a sexy bitch... or just a bitch.
author: I Love Beef C.

description:
Only 2 stars...and after ALL the hype!! The pizza's and champagne were about the only thing here that kept me interested. Besides being way too crowded and over-priced, the food was not at all up-to-par with similar restaurants. The pasta I had was over salted and lacked flavor.  Service was good - not too intrusive, but unfortunately, our waiter didn't know a lot about the wines (the list was extensive).
I want to give it a 2nd chance, because of all the rave reviews. For now, I think it could be a nice place to meet a friend or co-worker for drinks & appetizers - assuming you can find a seat & hear each other over all the noise.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
OooverRaaated. Come on people, the pizza is good but it's still pizza and it's just not THAT good.  

I had to try it after all the hype.  We went last night.  Don't get me wrong, the pizza is very good.  The mozzeralla was fabulous.  Our server selected a wonderful well priced bottle of red for us.  But...  well, if it wasn't for these factors I probably would have given A16 only 2 stars.

First of all, our reservation for 2 was at 9:30 and we were not seated until 10 pm.  Come on.  How hard is it to squeeze two people in on time.  And the hostess was completely indifferent.  We had to keep bugging her about our table.  Basically, we were ignored.  When we got seated it was not a great table.  It was squeezed in behind a huge party.  Our server was pleasant but rushed.  He neither detracted nor added to the experience.  All this I might have overlooked if it was truly the best pizza I had ever had.  It was not.  Sorry.  Pasty Grimaldi's (located in NY and Scottdale) is better.  If I had never had Grimaldi's, I might have though this was the best pizza ever.  A16 doesn't even come close.  Soooo...  my ultimate analysis?  I would come here midweek for pizza if I could walk right in and get a table.  But it is not worth a special trip or a long wait.
author: sarah k.

description:
A friend was visiting from out of town for the holidays and wanted to try out this trendy Italian restaurant in the Marina.   It took us about 30 minutes before finding a parking spot. When we finally got seated in the restaurant , we were starving!  It's just the two of us but we seem of ordered from every section in the menu!  We ordered the tuna conserva, margarita pizza, Bucatini with Dungeness crab, gigante beans, cherry tomatoes and basil pasta, Beef ribeye tagliata , Cannellini beans with garlic and oregano, half a bottle of red and half of white and pomengrate (sp?) gelato.  

Everything mentioned above was just okay... but the tuna conserva and margarita pizza were awesome!  Of course the wines were good too!  I would definately go back for the pizza, tuna conserva and some good wine.  I thought the Beef ribeye was a little over cooked and I didnt really taste any crab in the pasta.
author: Anna L.

description:
I love A16. If it weren't for the crowds, lines, wait, and price, I'd hit up this place daily!

After circling the block for 20 mins, waiting for another hour (but hey, it was a Friday night), we finally were seated in the patio. Very dark and romantic (which was good because it was a double date). I was a bit hesitate but eventually went with the Maccaronara. My boyfriend had the Margarita pizza (daring isn't he?) and our friends had the gnocchi and tri-tips. Everything was absolutely delicious. Since we didn't try anything too out of the ordinary, it seemed like a familiar meal with a updated twist. 

Word of advice, try A16 during the weekdays to avoid a wait.
author: Emily F.

description:
A16 seems to have very erratic reviews and maybe they truly are inconsistent but having been here only once I can't comment on that.

I was there for about 6-7 months ago and sat at the 'bar' where you can see the kitchen staff working - which I must admit I often enjoy doing. I remember having an excellent sausage dish and my dining partnet had something that I can't remember what it exactly was - but I can remember we both enjoyed our dishes a lot.

The crowd is your semi-annyoing Marina crowd but it's fairly easy to block them and pretend that you're surrounded by intelligent life.

I did see the pizzas coming out and they looked terrific. If or when I go back I think I will have to try one of those...
author: Rich S.

description:
This was a Chronicle top 100 restaurant in 2006 so I was eager to try it. We went on a "Meatball Monday" and were seated immediately for our 7PM reservation (we were about 7 minutes late). The place was crazy busy and loud. 

The table we were give was right next to the open kitchen, which was quite warm. Nice on a cool winter day, but in warmer weather this might be a problem. Also, the row of tables by the kitchen are on a busy row with servers and patrons dancing around each other to get through the narrow row. I had my chair hit several times during the evening. 

We started with the mozzarella appetizer. Interesting texture, but I didn't think it tasted like much. I thought it'd be better with something rather than on its own. 

The Fabriano salame was too fatty (more so than other of it's type I've seen) and not very flavorful. 

I opted for what I thought was a small serving of the Maccaronara with tomato ragu and ricotta salata and a small serving of the meatballs. The Maccaronara was OK, but nothing special, the same with the meatballs. After I paid the bill and thought about it, I realized I'd actaully been served (or at least charged) for the full portion of Maccaronara. 

The service was below average, the food average at best. 

What a waste of an evening.
author: Chuck K.

description:
When we arrived for a 6pm dinner on a Friday evening we were seated right away. At that point being led to the back dining room from the front bar area somehow felt like they were stashing us away where we wouldn't bother anyone. From reading other reviews I can see that at some point during dinnertime it switches. The food was very good, not terribly authentic and not really worth the buzz, but very tasty. Our waitress was very nice and took great care of us, she really anticipated our needs. Unfortunately the people sitting next to us were so incredibly loud it almost ruined the experience completely. Seriously lady, you can quiet down instead of trying to impress us with tales of getting your garden landscaped! We were thisclose to asking for a new table they were so loud, and no, it wasn't loud in the dining room yet. 

We enjoyed the bresaola and arugula on crostini as well as our Carciofi (artichoke) Pizza. On a slight step down was the Cavatelli with fava beans, guanciale, pecorino and black pepper. It was good but it was drenched in butter and reminded the hubs of Pasta Roni... we had been hoping it would be more like a carbonara. Dessert was amazing, we had the chocolate tart with olive oil and sea salt. I have the softest of all soft spots for desserts that involve olive oil! Yummy. I was embarrassed to say the name but the cocktail I had was also quite good, it was called a Blushing Angel though. Hard to get past a bad name like that!

So yes, over all we had good food and a decent time. But it had too many strong down points to really be a winner.
author: Melissa W.

description:
I ate here last night with my co-workers & bosses.  I enjoyed the meal very much.

We started with a few appetizers, including the mozzarella burrata, tuna conserva, roasted fava beans, and tripe napoletana.  All were very good, but stand-outs were the roasted fava beans and the tripe.  The fava beans were tender and flavorful, and the tripe was awesome-- perfectly cooked and drenched in a very rich sauce.

Next we had a pizza course with the Margherita and the Salsiccia.  I only tried the Margherita.  It was good but perhaps not remarkable.  

For entrees I tried the roasted young chicken with radishes & salsa verde.  The chicken was very nicely done, with crispy and well-spiced skin, and moist, juicy flesh.  The radishes were tasty, but a bit heavy on the salt.  I also tried the halibut cheeks with almonds, parsley, and lemon.  They were very good, properly cooked, but a bit stringy in texture (which I don't remember from other times I've had halibut cheeks).  

Desserts were shared across the table.  We ordered a trio of the house made sorbets, the chocolate budino tart with sea salt and olive oil, and the strawberry zuppa inglese.  All were good.  The stand out for me was the chocolate budino tart w/ sea salt & olive oil.  The flavors were so nicely complimentary.  The rich pudding of the tart stood up well to the flavors of olive and sea salt.  

I didn't have any wine, but the sommelier seems very knowledgeable and it was fun to hear him describe the wines.  Everyone enjoyed his recommendations.
author: Bruce S.

description:
This was a really nice wine bar.  My friends and I were just looking for a place to relax after dinner to chat, and instead of going to a super loud lounge like Matrix Fillmore, we headed down to Chestnut and found A16.

The hostess was very nice, but unfortunately it was so small that we couldn't sit at a table and have desert and wine.  Instead we had to cram into the corner near the bar, but at least we were next to the windows.

The restaurant wasn't loud, medium, and lots of friendly smiles all around.  The wine list was pretty good too.

Nice environment to hang out and drink some wine.  The bar tender wasn't all that engaging but I was with plenty of company so that was ok.

I'd recommend it when the bar isn't too crowded.
author: Art C.

description:
The pizzas are a generous size and very authentic italian- meaning nice and thin without too many toppings.  
You must try the Burrata appetizer, the creamy fresh mozzerella is to die for. 
Great wine selection and friendly service.
author: sara b.

description:
Very slow service, even on a Sunday night. We arrived on time and it took thirty minutes to seat us, and much longer before the protracted and inattentive service began. The ambiance was sub-par: it was hot and crowded, and the dining experience itself was not nearly exceptional enough to warrant such uncomfortable environs.

As for the food, the appetizers were pretty awful. Stay away from the tuna in particular, it was a huge disappointment, and tasted like something out of a can. Likewise for the gnocchi - there was something gnarly going on with the guinea hen and the gnocchi itself was bland and overdone. 

The only saving graces were the above-average if unoriginal pizza offerings my two companions ordered. However, trying them I feel that there are many equivalent/better pizza options in the city, and pizza alone does not warrant a visit.

Surprising since I had heard good things, but I would not return.
author: Dennis M.

description: Big raspberry.  8:00 reservation. Arrived at 8:10. Seated at 8:45 next to the bathroom with the third chair sticking out into the walkway. Silly hostesses who kept saying our table was being set, but we kept waiting. A blob of buratta for our inconvenience.  The rest of the food was MEH. dry pizza with sparse veggies, tuna conserva not bad, dry halibut, steamed plain cafeteria chard (please, you can do better).  Desserts were the only saving grace, but you wont see me here again.  Too bad, this place rocked in its day.
author: Lisa P.

description:
A-M-A-Z-I-N-G!!!!!

Our food was sublime.  The mushroom (funghi) pizza appetizer was outstanding.  Our entrees were all fabu too.  The shortribs...I almost passed out they were so good.

The service was flawless.  Friendly but very professional.  We ordered a magnum of the Serpico which was truly a sublime ferret in my underpants.  INCREDIBLE!!!

and the desserts...I can't go on...too good!!!!
author: Luis O.

description:
Have you ever heard of restaurants that have types? Well this restaurant has a type and its type is flirtatious gold-diggers and douchy guys who all feel they are the hottest most desirable people on Earth. 
 
This is the type of place where people look you up and down from head to toe in that annoying way of the pretentious and privileged. So just know what you're getting into. 

We got the Bianca pizza which was good but very hard to consume as we were provided knives that could not effectively cut the pizza (this seems like an issue that shouldn't exist). Also our salt shaker didn't work, so it had to be replaced (nit picky?), and we were seated at the most undesirable table in the house after waiting for 30 minutes and having a couple who arrived after us be seated at the more desirable table ahead of us... make reservations. 

We were only checked on once by our waiter who seemed to be checking in to guarantee his tip, and he asked me what I would be drinking in a leading way... I just want water, get off my back. 

Overall the pizza was good, it is thin crust and can be shared and treated as a first course instead of a main if you are hungry.The carrot and snap pea side was nearly flavorless, don't try it. I don't think I can stomach another visit to a place where everyone in the restaurant rubs me the wrong way.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
SPQR is much better.  Between the five people at my party we ordered over 10 dishes, and all were uniformly "meh."  I was super disappointed, as I love SPQR and my roommate owns Nate Appleman's cookbook and the dishes in that thing are uniformly delicious.

Service was not rude, but verging on it.  Obviously it was packed, noisy, and actually quite hot inside.  Don't bother
author: Anthony L.

description: After a mid afternoon pub crawl that involved a few drinks and a couple of appetizers a few of us decided to stop off at A16 for some pizza. While I'd imagine most people come in here to have a complete meal, our waitress seemed somewhat uncomfortable about serving 4 people 2 pizzas. First she mentioned that she could eat one herself, a few minutes later came back by to ask if we would like to order anything else, then came back for the second time asking if we had changed our minds about ordering drinks. I understand her tip is proportionate to the tab, but enough already. The pizza was great and it was served in about 20 mins so that was awesome! Definitely look forward to going there the next time on an empty stomach to enjoy the complete experience.
author: Vivek N.

description: When I saw that a16 chef was featured on one of the food network shows,  then seeing this restaurant again on the best of San Francisco or something like that I had to try it..... On a way back from Tahoe one weekend my husband and I stopped by this place..... My mushroom pizza had barely any mushrooms but nevertheless the pizza still tasted ok...since my friends and I search for new and fun places around sf, I doubt that I will end up going to A16 again....
author: Zayka Z.

description:
Outside of the wait (always try and get a rezzie), this place is awesome. The ambience is great, as is the wine list. I like the fact that I had to have the waiter explain to me what all the wines actually were since I don't speak Italian. How often do you go to an Italian place and see your standard Chiantis and Cabs--from California. 9 times out of ten. You won't find an exclusive collection of California wines here. 
I had the almond crusted halibut which was AWESOME. And the cannelli beans with garlic and oregano as a side were seriously addicting. Was a little bitter about the bread guy not delivering. Not all of us are the anti-carb type--and I just wanted some of that damn bread.
All in all, good service, great food and wine. I will be back.
author: Kristin B.

description:
So I call this place up and see if they might deign to put said uber-pie in a box. A Cardboard box. Doesn't have to be Chef Boy-ar-Dee's caricature on the box with the pencil moustache, just a box. Ask politely.   


Some little blonde creature with a Generations old Valley Girl Accent, the kind who says "amaaazing" when she means "good" takes my call. "We don't offer pizza to go". She says this with some coldness incompatable with the pizzeria culture. Strike Uno.

This is the first time in recorded human history that a place that makes pizza would not put it in a box. Not this pizzeria. It's special. Strike Due.

Then we get into the whole inside pizza gossip world with its own official mumbo jumbo, as discussed by some guy who types in a dark room with four computer screens live ["A16 is certified and uses OO flour - Park Chow tries to cut costs by not using OO and is flavorless. In fact, although the owner wanted to use OO flour his exec chef chose to ignore this request and utilize non OO flour]. 

Pal, I don't care if they use flour that came over on the Mayflower and is the size of birdshot if  tastes good. I don't care about celebrity chefs or the inner workings of the Wizard of Oz oven. Strike Due and one-half.

Its just warm bread with cheese and sauce, and maybe a few pounds of processed meats. Its not a religious icon given to man to enjoy in a state of religious rhapsody. Pizza - remember? 

So I go to this shrine of everything crappy that San Francisco has become , and i finally order the super pie. With the certification. With the 00 flour, whatever that means. Verdict: it stunk. The dough was both burned and soggy, the rest of this pie nothing to write home about.

Why is it that some fat guy in Brooklyn who never heard of 00 flour or certification, and is only too happy to put his pie in the box makes real pie, while this object of gourmet veneration has nothing? 

I realize that all the recent transplants to the Bay Area got their Merit Badges in  Restaurant Reviewing,  and that you are supposed to like this place because every insufferable moron does, but seriously - it's hard to park, expensive, the servers are all vying to be on Reality TV, and if they served you the same pizza at Domino's you'd start going to Papa Johns.
author: john d.

description: Enjoyed a Friday night at A16 with The Joy for dinner. The place was packed (no surprise) with a nice mix of the beautiful people and families. Started with Burrata as a starter, Salsiccia Pizza, and a Fregula pasta with a side of Chard. All the dishes were very good. Preparation and presentation were steller. The service was spot on which is a plus considering the crowds. The pizza was my favorite. The corkage is high at $30. A16 has an extensive wine list and wants to drive you to their wines. I look forward to a return visit on my next visit to the Marina. Lot's of fun, and a hot spot!
author: Gerry C.

description:
Such a horrible meal I was compelled to finally stop being a yelping moocher and actually contribute to the yelpers community.  Created an account and here we go.  

The ambiance was great, we showed up at 7 on a friday and enjoyed a glass of wine while we waited for the table.  Hostess was friendly and exactly what a hostess should be.  The server (short almost buzzed head) was awesome, attentive and managed to sneak in and fill the wine glasses without interrupting.  Our wine was nice and not that out there price wise.......so from this point you can see that we were getting excited and hoping the hype was going to stand up the restaurant....sadly, it definitely was  a huge letdown.

My date ordered the roasted chicken with a side of polenta, while i ordered the gnocchi.  My dates chicken was good but honestly very reminiscent of a Safeway precooked chicken.  My gnocchi, which by the way i ordered the large dish, came out with im guessing maybe 10 peices, it was green and surrounded by the mushrooms.  One bite and it was all downhill.  Tasted like green play-doe with an earthworm surround and the sauce was EXTREMELY bland.  

I sat their wondering how I had heard about this restaurant, and why it was packed.....my only guess is that we ordered entrees rather than pizza (i know right, what jackasses we ordered the more expensive items) and that the pizza must be where its at.  

I will be back at some point in the future to give this place another try.....but I will definitly only be ordereing off the pizza menu and wine list only.   Hope you redeem yourself a16!  Hope it was an off night

Oh yeah, and why im so bitter,   I walked out the door and my wallet was 140 bucks lighter, granted a good portion of that was drank! lol

only reason it wasn't 1 star.......my date felt bad that I was so distraught about taking her to a bad restaurant, that she made sure my night ended well!
author: Dillon G.

description:
Sooooo good. Organic produce, meats and the delicious wines. Did I mention that it has a foosball table!

Its in the Marina but you can't blame them for that, its still good.
author: Shalin A.

description: Second time visiting A 16, a word of advice, get there early to find parking. it gets busy and very crowded and loud. Great salads and appetizers to start, they are decent portion. True Italian flavor, not you American Italian style. The trick to save money here is to go with two appetizers to share, a pizza from the wood fired Brick oven, then just one appetizer. The main show piece was the Italian wine collection, strongly recommend the Raina rosso, from MonteFalco, well balanvced and memorable. Till next time.
author: Bob W.

description:
Preface: I literally searched for A16's name again because I could not believe it didn't have a five-star rating. That being said...

I keep reading how Nate Appleman is a rising chef, and I'm excited to see just how far he can go -- because in my opinion, he's gone at least five stars. 

As a Cow Hollow neighbor, I'm all-to-lucky to have this hidden gem restaurant in close proximity. While tables are limited and the crowd keeps flowing in, I'm happy to wait my turn and savor the goodness. 

Last time I went was Meatball Monday. If you haven't been, you should. Definitely book in advance if you want a prime time (7-9) or come in earlier for a more lax atmosphere and no-wait line. Regardless of the time, my server has always been knowledgeable, friendly and prompt. 

I love the fresh ingredients, creative pairings and seasoning. I'd recommend their mozzarella or ricotta (they receive from a place in southern california that is to-die-for and if you want to purchase elsewhere, I'd go to Bristol Farms downtown). The asparagus pizza with prosciutto was lush and my favorite, brioche toast topped with pancetta, pea-puree and egg (with a hint of chile oil). 

If you haven't been, go. If you've been and had a non-five star experience, go again. And buy the cookbook, it's really an investment if you're into cooking and expanding your culinary experiences.
author: Sara W.

description:
was okay. Maybe I need to go back there, because I keep here fantastic things about this restaurant. I thought the pasta was okay, wine list was a little bland and I'm sorry to say the pizza didn't really blow my mind...don't hate me.

In fairness, we were with a big group, so maybe that's why the food was so-so. The atmosphere was cute, great central location for the bars in the Marina. Parking can be a little tough.

Good date place!
author: A.L. S.

description: Quoted a 30 minute wait but waited an hour and a half. When we were at the hour mark and I asked the hostess how much longer to see if we should go on another walk around the neighborhood she snapped at me and told me the 30 minutes was just an estimate and wouldn't give an estimate as to how much longer. Don't know who peed in her wheaties that morning. Once seated the waitress didn't even give us 2 minutes before expecting to take our order and she was also short with us. Mostly Italian wines which we did not recognize any on the menu so asked for suggestions to which the waitress replied she knew nothing about wine. Could you get someone then? Oh well we ordered a standard CA wine since no one could help. We were there for a friends birthday and told the waitress that but instead of saying "Happy Birthday" she asked her if she was of age to have wine, my friend told her her age and the waitress left to get the wine we ordered. Upon her return with the wine she then decided to ID my friend, which was fine but odd that it was after the fact and with the attitude we had already recieved. We ordered a salad and 2 pizzas. The salad was very good and the only reason this place gets 3 stars. The pizza was just ok. I prefer Gialina's on Diamond which not only has better pizza but a nice staff that isn't pretentious like that of A-16.
author: Christina F.

description:
One of the best meals of my life...
I was lucky enough to dine at A 16 with a friend over the weekend and sit at the chefs counter. The entire experience at A 16 was amazing and I think we may have had the majority of the menu. To start we had the calamari appetizer, which was the special for the day and the bruschetta, both amazing. The bruschetta was to die for and I could have eaten multiple pieces of that amazing bread. Then came the pasta course....the quattro formaggi ravioli was delicious and the gnocchi just perfect. Then came a very simple pizza, just sauce and olives, but it was made right in front of us by the amazing pizza chef and just perfect. Next...a pork chop from god with some kind of amazing apple sauce and a white bean side (the only thing that was not so hot). And finally just when I though I was going to explode came desert. The chocolate tart with sea salt and evoo would definitely be on the menu for my final meal. It was by far the most unique and delicious thing I have ever put in my mouth.

My experience at A16 was great. The entire line at the chefs table was very friendly, checked up on our food between every course and created a very entertaining experience for my friend and I.
author: Kathleen E.

description:
Enjoyed a fabulous dinner here the other night. It was nice to have Shelley pick our champagne, wine and dessert wine for us. We ended up eating family style ordering a bunch of different plates and just about everything was top notch.

I loved the fact that their pizza came with very little cheese if any at all (which is a favorite italian way to eat pizza). The spaghetti was tasty and perfectly al dente. Also I absolutely hate any poultry related meat substitutes such as turkey/chicken meatloaf, but their chicken meatballs were awesome. 

My only disappointment was with the pumpkin and ricotta gnocchi with kale. The flavor was all right there and it was ready to be my favorite part of the meal, but sadly I think the gnocchi was slightly over cooked. But again I could see this being a favorite dish on another night. Will have to try again soon.
author: Alexis G.

description:
I'm extremely disappointed with this place because I had a much higher expectations based on all the positive comments I've heard from people who have eaten here.  The price was a bit pricey, but it comes with the neighborhood, so I figure I'd give it a try.  I don't mind spending a bit more money than usual on food if it's good, but all the dishes my ex and I ordered were highly disappointing.  The wine was not what I expected...I'm no wine connoisseur, but I know what I like and don't like, which I've told the server before getting her recommendation.  My ex ordered a soup and a calamari appetizer while I ordered the lamb chops with some vegetable dish along with the wine I didn't care for.  The soup deserves a -1 star, the lamb chops were full of fat...the whatever meat there actually was (1/2 a star since it at least had a little meat? Heck, I'll even be nice and give it an extra star because the seasoning wasn't bad), I had shared with my ex since I felt bad that he didn't even touch his soup.  The vegetables were blah (1 star), and the calamari appetizer gets a solid 3 stars!

All in all, I think the food gets 1.5-2 stars, and the service gets 4 stars.  I'll never go there again.  The bright side of that whole experience was that my ex had to pay for the poor meal, not me, and his company wasn't unbearable!
author: My Loan J.

description:
I like it here. Some of my friends get it, some of them don't. The wine list is great and the waitstaff I have had is mostly good. The tables are cramped and I hate to try and shove my butt by someone else every time I need to get up. Frightens me that I may knock something off of someones table with my butt. With all that being said, I love the mushroom pizza, salads and I have to say my favorite dish is the sunchoke. I am not sure how they make them so great, but they do. Burrata and the Salumi are top rate always.   

No I do not live in the Marina.  I am not one of those chicks.  I do not follow fads.  I normally avoid this area at night like the plague.  I like the wine, food and sometimes service. 

More bum space please. My butt is pretty small and it freaks me out.
author: Doreen D.

description: Finally - A16.  Got seating at the chef's bar quite promptly.  Liked the open and brighter feeling marble countertop area more than the narrow table near the entry that was initially offered to us.
