Decided to get the pizza romana, the halibut with squid and fennel, and a side of sunchokes.  Scoop of rhubarb sorbet and an order of delicious caramelized almond semi freddo.  One star off for the servers recommendation that we try arugula on the pizza - not only did it detract from the pizza but we were charged extra!  2 bucks, not a big deal but I thought she should have clarified that it was extra.
author: Ash A.

description: The food was incredible!  We ordered a number of pasta dishes to split and each one was better than the last.  Then came the Salsiccia pizza.  The fennel sausage was amazing.  The thin crust had the perfect balance of crispness and tender dough.  Add a bottle (or two heehee!) of Jelly Jar Zinfandel and the meal was phenomenal.  My only complaint about this gem is that it can get rather hot in there.  Otherwise, dress lightly and prepare to have a wonderful meal!
author: Dana E.

description:
If I was stranded on a desert island, and I could have one food to take with me, the fare of choice would have to be spaghetti and meatballs.  And fresh mozzarella.  (It's not one food, but I digress).

My palate is Italian through and through.

So when Food&Wine first ran an article on Shelley Lindgren's new spot at A16, I made note and put in on my mental Go-To list.  I've traveled to SF twice in the last few months, and both times, hit this hotspot.  

The first time was for my wedding anniversary.  We made a reservation, and showed up in our best duds.  (I was giddy when not one, not two, but three people mistook me for the maitre d'.  Yeah, I'm a dork, so what!)  It was a Friday night, and we had to wait, I don't know, maybe twenty minutes.  So I read the cookbook, and made sure diners were happy.  

We were squeezed into the banquette in the bustling dining room, next to a loudmouth former frat boy and his poor date, but things turned magical when the food arrived.  Grilled fava beans with garlic and crushed red pepper, an assortment of salumi that melted in the mouth, and we shared a wood-fired oven pizza with sausage and mushrooms.  It was six months ago, and I still remember it, that's how good it was.

Next stop was just last week, on a Monday, after a full day of site seeing.  We were sweaty and dirty, and wearing our best "We Are Tourists" outfits.  No, they weren't matching.  

We couldn't get in through Open Table on this trip, and when we passed by the restaurant we crossed our fingers and decided to take a look-see.  And what do you know, they were starting to get busy, but they had a place for us.  This time, we sat at the bar, watched the kitchen and asked questions, all of which the garde mange chef seemed more than happy to answer.  

Our server, who sported a "Doin it" tattoo on her wrist because as she said, she was doin it, livin the life, suggested a Campanian wine to go with our pastas, Bucatini with Monterey Sardines and Squid Ink Tonnarelli with Shrimp.  We were supposed to share, but... it's not like it was a special occasion, though that didn't stop us from scarfing down the Chocolate Budino Tart with sea salt and olive oil.  I say we, but really that bad boy was mine, all mine.

I promise next time we're in SF, we'll try something new.  Maybe.
author: Paula S.

description: Enter the lively hallway to great Neapolitan pizzas and southern Italian cuisine in the Marina.  Some guys are satisfied by chilling out front with the hostesses until they are seated by the friendly staff.
author: Jenny L.

description: After my internship at the Exploratorium ended, my bosses and the chief of staff took me here for lunch as a token of thanks. Talk about a nice sendoff! I had the chickpea, chestnut & dandelion zuppa with pork meatballs, one and a half margherita pizzas (they're sized for one person each), and some dessert with coffee and chocolate in it - divine! SOOOO GOOD! Of course, part of my enthusiasm probably lies in the fact that I didn't have to pay for any of it, but now that I've been a working stiff for the past four months, I can come back here and find out for sure... maybe with a date this time? puahahahahah
author: Aivy C.

description: Getting a table at A16 can be difficult, even on a Monday.  But the effort is well-rewarded with some simple, fresh and flavorful food.  The Burata is simply served with a little olive oil, but very good.  We also tried the salumi assortment, which is on the more rustic side (i.e. don't expect perfectly formed salami) but very flavorful.  A16 is know for it's brick oven  pizza and doesn't disappoint.  The pasta dish, however, was a bit of a disappointment (cavatini with meat sauce).  Another plus is the wine list, and A16 had one of the best selections of wiones from Southern Italy and Sicily.  We had a bottle of nero'd'avola from Sagana, which was outstanding and alone is worth a visit.  The place gets packed and noisy so come here for the food, but have your conversation elsewhere.
author: Peter L.

description: We were late for our reservation but they were still able to accommodate us - the hostess was very polite and thanked us for being patient.  As we were shown to our table it seemed like the restaurant never ended...we kept walking and walking until we were seated just inside of the small outdoor patio area.  I only tried one of the Compania wines which I liked very much.  However the waiter ended up pouring sparkling water into my wine glass and took way too long to replace it.  Then towards the end of the meal, another waitress poured tap water into my sparkling water.  Oh well.  Our entrees were so-so...nothing mind blowing.  I'd say check it out for the wine bar and the atmosphere, not for the good food.
author: Emi N.

description: I really wanna like this restaurant. The restaurant itself has nice lay-out including a long bar area and a nice bright patio in the back. The wait staff are super attentive and knowledgeable at their menu. The wait time between each course was just perfectly timed. Food has nice presentations and fresh ingredients. Burrata with oliva oil and prosciutto was beyond average; Funghi pizza was a disappointment, the greens on the pizza were bitter; Squid Ink tonnarelli with sea urchin was creative but didn't meet my expection; Ricotta gnocchi with hen and pancetta sugo was cremey and a bit salty. Drinks were fine but nothing ordinary. Did I set the bar too high? Possibly! Not every course met my expectation but I will go back to try out other things on the menu given the great service and fresh ingredients.
author: Stef L.

description:
I have to say we really enjoyed our time here.  I happened to run by it mid-afternoon, poked my head in to see if they had any openings that night and, as luck would have it, they had a 6:30 open. We showed up, snuck past all the people that didn't evidently have the same luck, and got seated exactly at 6:30. No wait.  Big points there.  

Our server was awesome (wishing I remembered her name, blond, short hair), super attentive and was really capable of answering some ingredient questions that stymied me, going so far as to bringing out samples of the peppers in question.

We had the bruschetta, salad, Lamb chop, pork shop, polenta (side), and lastly the sunchoke (side). Everything was exceptional. Would LOVE to go back next time we're in town.
author: daniel s.

description:
We were trying to figure out a place for a quick bite in the marina, and embarassingly enough, I couldn't think of anything. I really do live in this city - my brain just went blank and don't have a Yelp app yet to guide me around!
So we ended up at A16 and were pleasantly surprised. We had a few glasses of a great red wine that the bartender recommended, and then moved to a table where we split a perfect little salad (get it - it's the one with walnuts and persimmon, which I had never had before... YUM!). Decided to split a pizza margherita and had them add sausage. I'm not usually a pizza person, or a sausage person either, but it hit the spot. Thin crust, light, perfect. Apparently A16's regional fare from Southern Italy is lighter, juxtapositioned with it's sister restaurant SPQR that is supposedly much heavier.

Can't wait to go back to check out their entrees and more of their menu.

The ambiance is great too. I always love high tables - maybe because it makes me feel like a kid again sitting on a high chair! 

And DEFINITELY props for the service. Jason was by far the best food runner I have ever had (OK I may be a bit biased - he IS dating my cousin). All in all good service, although our waitress was a bit pushy with the wine/dessert recommendations.
author: Alex H.

description:
We were looking for a pre-show dinner spot, and A16 came to mind.  (Go early, because it books up and the wait is long.)  For our purposes it was perfect.  Close to the venue, no wait to walk in at 6:15pm, good food and wine.  

Service was good, in a Marina sort of way.  Our waitress was efficient but had a little too much of that Barbie-style fake-cheerfulness going on.  I was looking for a tad more sincere and down to earth for some reason.  The busboys and food-bearers (do waitresses not carry the food out any more??) were cute and charming and pleasant.  

Food was good, wine was good, but neither was anything to write home about.  My wood-fired pizza got a little close to the fire and good portions weren't just infused with that great smokiness, they were ... black.  Before I even tried it, the busboy offered me chili oil, and I have to admit it was a bit bland.  (I was hoping to review the leftover-pizza-as-breakfast, too, but alas, the busboy never returned with my to-go box before we left.  Shame.)  Salads were good.  The octopus was great ... not too rubbery.  In general, dishes seemed a little over-sauced, but when I saw the LIBERAL use of olive oil on almost every dish, I figured out why there was a always a puddle at the bottom of the plates.  

All in all, nice.  I'd go again.  Nice warm, congenial atmosphere, best suited for a group of  4 or so.  I.e. not cozy-romantic, but not crazy-big-party either.
author: jill j.

description: Amazing food, weird space, decent service. Dont sit across from the kitchen. WAY too narrow space and my chair kept getting bumped into by staff and patrons. I was in fear that food would soon splatter on my head. That being said, the food was very good. The kitchen was accommodating for our non-meat eating friend, and substituted a different sauce for the gnocchi dish. The pizza was spectacular--VERY spicy tomato sauce with black olives and anchovy. Yum.
author: brewgirl b.

description:
Had some friends in town and this was such a great place to take them too. We tried a little bit of everything and it was all so amazing... the only down fall was when we were charged $160 for a bottle of wine which they insisted was the one we ordered.

The bartender was very nice and realized it was his mistake and took care of it :)

I definitely recommend this place... really great atmosphere!
author: Stephanie S.

description: I must say that this is by far the best Italian restaurant I have eaten at, outside of our family's restaurant and home. This is a restaurant that only someone from Italy, especially southern Italy could really appreciate.
author: Nantas S.

description: Get a reservation in advance, be prepared to wait for your table in a small space with a ton of other people, but then make sure to talk to the bartenders in the front while you wait, and tell them what type of wine you like and ask them to recommend something. We said we liked Pinot Grigio, they gave us an amazing wine called Falanghina, which we continued to order in carafes at the table. Once you sit down, get excited--the food is incredible. Burrata is absurdly good, salumi platter comes with incredible meat and paté on crostini, pizza is unbelievable, squid ink pasta and the more simple thick spaghetti with tomato and ricotta are both perfect. Only downside was that the desserts were slightly less than perfect; date cake was dry, chocolate torte was a little too greasy with olive oil. But it didn't even matter at that point. Love this place.
author: Sabbies B.

description:
I was worried that this was going to be typical terrible Marina fare (I'm not a Marina-hater, I'm just sayin').  But I was pleasantly surprised and it's actually quite good Italian food for the area.

The atmosphere is a little loud and I didn't think the pizza was worth the accolades I've heard, but I was very impressed with the wine list and the service.  I'm not quite sure why it's so hard to get into this place.
author: Geoff K.

description:
A16 might just have the best southern Italian food in San Francisco - certainly the best I've had since leaving Europe. For a place smack in the heart of the Marina that's filled with striped-shirt wearers, it's remarkably without pretension and attitude, the service is efficient and the staff is personable and witty. The challenge is getting seated...

Tonight was our second trip to A16, and the food just gets better. We started with perfect meatballs - light and almost fluffy made with pork, proscuitto and ricotta cheese which was quickly followed by the mozzarella burata (handmade partially formed mozzarella) with crostini and a fried cheese dish - amazingly crispy and chewy with a radiccio and arugula salad on top.

We all had pizza next - and my rapini (broccoli rabe) pizza with pancetta and chili oil was amazing. I've always been a fan of broccoli rabe, and the preparation was spot-on: garlicy and spicy with a little fat and salt lent to it by the melt-in-your-mouth pancetta. The crust was perfectly charred and had a fresh dough flavor.

The point doesn't come off for the food, which is a clear five stars. A half point is lost due to the physical layout of the entrance/bar area - it's way too crowded, making it almost impossible to physically get up to the bar to actually order a drink. Because the restaurant is so popular (read: prone to crowds) and they offer food service at the bar, the turnover up front is very slow making it an uncomfortable place to park yourself while waiting for your table. Still, once you make it to the restaurant area, it's quite relaxed, with enough space around each table so that you don't feel like you're listening in on your neighbor's conversation.

The second half point is due to the 45 minute delay we incurred waiting for our table. Even though we had to wait, the maitre 'd did a very good job keeping us informed about the delay (a table wasn't clearing out fast enough) and arranged with the owner, who stopped in to check on us, to comp us a significant amount off of the bill for the delay. For the record, I do expect that a restaurant open for more than 3 months should know their turnover rates and arrange for their seatings appropriately. I know we were not the only table waiting to be seated this night.

Still, when we had our first bite of the food, the four of us unanimously agreed that it's practically impossible to be angry, because the food completely lived up to our expectation.

Highly recommended if you miss the bold flavors of Southern Italian food.
author: Avery G.

description:
With 76 reviews of A16 I'm not sure what to add ....

Except this is the BEST Dinner spot in the City!!

Always great everything! Can't go wrong...

Get a reservation at least a week in advanced!!
author: Kristina A.

description:
Our first time here we loved the vino, pizza, et al, but since then we've found it very difficult to brave the crowds. Later, like 10:30 at night, works well because you miss the main rush. But bottom line, there is absolutely nothing better on earth than the Burrata. NOTHING.

Update - went again last night for the first time in years. Our company was lovely and that made the night. The food was also great - we got the burrata, a margherita pizza, lasagna special, short ribs, white beans, potatoes and brussel sprouts, and a nice white wine. One thing we did notice is that the service is off - our waitress would ask us a question and then leave without listening to the answer. But the food is still good!
author: Sarah R.

description:
I really want to like this place after hearing so many great things. I think it's lost it's touch. The pizzas are good but fall short a bit. I really like a crispy crust and it didn't really deliver.

It's a long and narrow restaurant - it's very 'cozy' though not only with your dining companions but also with the other tables around you.
author: Ling L.

description:
Generally been a fan of this place since they opened...but after my last experience, i'm over it.  

The service was terribly slow (even on a moderately busy Wednesday night) and the menu hasn't changed one bit (that I could tell) from the day they opened years ago....nothing new, creative, interesting...just the same old, same old. There are many other restaurants that invest the time to train their staff and mix up their menu periodically for my business....
author: Greg A.

description:
My parents were in town, so what better way to kick off their stay than lunch at A16. I couldn't get a reservation for Saturday lunch, so Friday it was. It pays to plan ahead; otherwise you can bet your burrata that you'll have to wait.

Here's what we had; I would highly recommend all of it:

Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini  -- an amazing standard, smooth, fresh, and creamy cheese

Salumi plate -- from the prosciutto to the coppa di testa, lots of tasty pig goodness

Zuchinni salad with mint, pecorino cheese, and green olives -- a refreshing summer treat

Monday meatballs -- always for lunch and always good (perhaps a bit salty)

Margherita pizza with tomato, mozzarella, grana padano, basil, pancetta, egg -- thin pizza perfection 

Pleasant service, a little noisy, but who needs to talk?
author: Peng A.

description:
Booo, me thinks NOT.  What's with all the hype?  I don't get it.  Yes, I have had a very few tasty things here.  Yes, they have a great wine list.  however, I have had some really crap food too.  And the specialty is thin crust pizza - for which there are too few options to choose from.

Sorry, not down.
author: david s.

description: Had  dinner here with my family. Food was tasty, atmosphere was lovely, great wine list, but ended up very disappointed by our waitress. We were greeted by a warm staff--the hostess and our initial server, but our server changed after about 10 minutes of being there. While the food was all very flavorful and well prepared, there's something extremely disappointing about poor service. I have to acknowledge the support staff who thankfully remained attentive and accommodating throughout our meal. But our waitress came across arrogant and uninterested. At any rate, we enjoyed the burrata and peppers to start off our meal, and we had the pork and the halibut entrees and also delicious sides of corn and the incredible arugula salad.  The pasta which my daughter ordered was somewhat bland but everything else I'd call exceptional. What ended our experience on the unpleasant side was again our waitress...who assumed (and charged us for) a large pasta order despite ordering a kid-sized portion. When we were curious about the charge and inquired about the bill, she gave us complete attitude. How she handled the whole exchange was rude and unprofessional. For me, there's little that's worse than when trying to enjoy an otherwise wonderful meal and environment, while having a server that seems to exude unpleasantness. Perhaps she was having an off night--who knows--but perhaps she could have simply recognized that we were patrons to her restaurant where she's employed to be knowledgeable and helpful about the menu, and provide good service.
author: Kristen J.

description:
This place is great... with friends, a date, or visitors from out of town.  It's popular, so reservations are probably a good idea for any group of more than 3 people. We sat at the 'chef bar' where we got to watch them make all the food, which was fun.

I got the sole and scallops with a side of sunchokes - definitely recommend! What are sunchokes? We were wondering the same thing. The waitress was pretty bad at describing them, but we decided to try it out - delicious! They have a potato consistency. 

My friends got the margherita pizza and pumpkin gnocchi, with another side of sunchokes and we were all very happy with our choices.
author: Caitlin B.

description:
The marinara pizza (no cheese) with arugula is delicious.  Give a pizza with no cheese a chance.  It will surprise you.  You can add proscuito too.  

The fresh mozarella is imported on a regular basis.  This is over the top delicicious.

Warning: Very loud and crowded.  I always sit at the bar because I enjoy bar seating but sometimes there are people breathing down your neck waiting for a table.  SICK!
author: Wakako U.

description:
Call me naive, but I had no idea this was an italian restaurant until I sat down and looked at the menu.  And I had no idea it was such a big restaurant until I walked to the back!

I'm not a fan of italian food (I know, shocking. And surprisingly inconvenient).  So when I scanned the menu, I was not excited.  The only thing even remotely appealing to me was the shellfish, which I ordered with a side of butternut squash.   My hot date ordered the minestra maritata and duck.

The minestra maritata was INCREDIBLE.   It was an amazing, authentic-tasting version of italian wedding soup.  Except with more flavor and less broth-- and the perfect balance of saltiness.  The following dishes didn't get the same reaction, although they were also good.  

We really enjoyed the charming sommelier, who brought interesting, enthusiastic stories with each bottle.
author: Zuzzi E.

description:
A16? You sunk my battleship!

A16 is actually an Italian restaurant that melds a trendy atmosphere, pricey menu, and good food.  This is a place to get together with friends that you don't mind speaking loudly to.  A16's is noisy!  You might want to bring the ear muffs.  Good thing the delicate thin crust pizza is tasty.
author: Michael H.

description:
I took a course from a Master Sommelier this week up in Napa.  When we got to Italy, he commented on A16, and how he always looks to A16 for innovative Italian selections.  In fact, he commented on how HE is continually educated by A16's list.  Probably the best compliment you can pay a restaurant, as one of 92 MS's in the U.S. takes off his hat.  Well done A16!

As for the food and service?  I went there a few years ago, and it was solid but I wasn't blown away.  I didn't try the pizza however, which seems to be all the rage.
author: Nate H.

description:
alright a16....time for a 1-star upgrade to five stars yahoo!!!

I won't dedicate this ENTIRE review to Kevin but I have to say that, once again, his paisley shirt didn't disappoint!  We specifically asked for him to come over and say hi because we enjoyed his Williams Selyem wine recommendation so much on our previous visit and ended up ordering the same bottle last night.  When we went to order a 2nd bottle they were out of the specific vintage we were looking for but Kevin's recommendation of a different wine was spot-on.  He's got a great personality, super funny....and love the shirts.

last night had dinner with 3 others and had another fantastical dining experience. Our waitress, Jame (ja-MAY) was super friendly and was there when we needed her, not bothering us when we didnt.  The four of us split a salsiccia pizza with fennel sausage, chiles,basil, mozz and onions maybe? It was delicious- no wonder this place is known for their pizzas.  I also had an escarole salad with apples, pecorino and hazelnuts.  It was the perfect balance of crisp, crunch, sweet and salty - i actually could hae had it for my entree.  And lucky for me, two others ordered the buttery, delicious, ridiculous-good burrata appetizer.

My entree was the seasonal ricotta/pumpkin gnocci with greens.  it was light and fluffy with a fabulous, light yet super savory pan-sauce.

Another person ordered the chicken meatballs and they were fantastic aas well.  The service here is always impeccable and friendly - the ambience welcoming and i think the restaurant is the perfect size.  A16 is a not-to-miss when visiting SF or if you're looking for a solid italian spot!
author: Brooke M.

description:
Not sure what the hype is about.. the marina crowd seems very pumped up on this place. But then again they are into their wine, if you're not into the wine don't go for the food. 

Strange menu... a combination of why the **** would you put that together and pizza.  (and not great pizza, just so-so)
 
On a positive note, Mozarella app very good, prosciutto app also very good Also,the staff were nice, and very friendly unlike the rest of the San Francisco pretentious crowd that seem to dine here. 

FYI  not a good date place if you actually want to talk, it is loud and crowded
author: Amanda S.

description:
Excellent Service. I decided to try this place at the last minute.  I did a late dinner.  I only waited 30 minutes and was seated at the Chef's Bar.  The appetizers, Salame, and Pizza were amazing.  The pizza is the thin, wood fire type.   I sat right by the wood fire pizza oven so I got  to see all the different types of pizzas made.  They all look delish. The sauce they use for the pizza is very good. I really think that makes the pizza.

Also, they have some reasonably priced wines and they are generous with the pours.

Update - I have been back a few times since my original review - still just as good - make sure to request that you're not seated in the back part of the restaurant (its sort of outside but still covered).  You feel too closed off from the rest of the restaurant and it is a little chilly.  The Meatballs and the asparagus are both exceptionally delicious.  Try them!
author: Angie C.

description:
I love the wine list here.  The food is great.  Really really great.  The gnocchi is a miss, but it's really the only thing i can possibly find fault with.

Aside from the service, that is.  The Som is awesome, but the server really didn't seem to feel like paying attention.  Still, make a reservation and go- it's worth it.
author: Alison R.

description:
The food was ok.  The spiced corn side was really good, but I thought the pizza was a little too doughy, and the fish was gross.  The Ink linguini was ok but I've had better.  It was really hot in there and it seemed to have a happening bar scene, but very crowded.

It's not a place i would recommend or go back to.
author: C A.

description: Bad pizza, even worse service. Ambience is good and the hostess was great (got us a table in 15 minutes - and called us back while we were walking outside), but our server (I think his name was David), was terrible. We definitely will not return or recommend. Save yourself the agony of a bad experience all round.  I can't understand how people commenting on this place say the pizza is good - they must enjoy bland food - because I sure don't!
author: Vinny L.

description: Crazy crowded on a Sat. night, but well worth it.  Had the funghi pizza, a couple amazing bottles of vino, some tasty pasta, good night.
author: Brian H.

description: Under the "Pizza Capricciosa" item in the menu, it does not list ingredients, but rather, it says "Trust the Chef."   Cocky, very cocky.  Nevertheless, I expected and looked forward to a spin on prosciutto and artichoke toppings, but what I got - or rather, didn't get - was a pizza capricciosa.  Instead, I got a pizza with anchovies, capers, and olives.....  Learn your pizzas, guys.  Otherwise, list the damn ingredients, as I no longer "trust your chef."
author: Ellen R.

description:
So let me start off by saying I am not a very big fan of the Marina so it took a good friend raving about this place to get me to go... After finding parking we were welcomed by  a large crowd busing out the door, I guess this place is a hot spot right now or perhaps has been for a while. Our friend already had a table waiting for us so that was nice to not have to wait in the over crowded lounge / doorway. We were given and extra chair in a narrow area which was stuck right in the walkway, however it was much better than waiting. 

Our waitstaff was very good, the sommelier was very knowledgeable and friendly and the wine she helped us pick out was very good. We had the mozzarella appetizer which was decent and had a pizza which to me wasn't that great, however I think it might of had to do with my taste and what my friend ordered. I didn't walk away from this blown away, yet there wasn't anything that stuck out in my mind to make it terrible. It looked like the back area of the restaurant might be cool with a kind of outdoor area and more room, I believe there is a reservation area that is probably worth making the reservation for. 

My experience was A-OK, I am not sure you will get me to the Marina for this place anytime in the future though.
author: Bobby B.

description: We always make sure to visit A16 when we are in town. The pork chop entree was perfectly cooked and very tasty. We have never been disappointed by a meal.
author: Julia R.

description:
Usually excellent. Jammed every night. Avoid the back patio. 
Very Marina, but that's not (necessarily) a bad thing...  Great 
wine list, but no Thunderbird.
author: Mick G.

description: Great wine and wood-fired pizza!  Didn't cost me an arm or leg either.  Good place for a date in the Marina.
author: Tron D.

description: I think this place is highly overated!  Four of us went and no one left impressed with service or food or ambiance, unless you call sitting on top of each other fun.  The menu is not very innovative, except for the wine menu which is great!  The sommelier is what saved the day.  But the pizza was the driest, most boring i have ever eaten.  The roasted chicken was fine but uninteresting, the meat platter unimaginative and pasta just OK. A neighborhood kind of place---you go because it is convenient but certainly not special occasion.
author: Maggie D.

description:
A 16.  Best meal I've had in ages.  The salad was arugula in a Meyers lemon vinaigrette:  finely chopped walnuts, tangerine, a few pieces of green olive, ribbons of finely shaved fennel and a salty, chewy smattering of goat cheese.  

We inhaled the salad along with dense, yeasty, thickly cut peasant bread accompanied by fresh green olive oil.  Excellent companions washed down with Alois wine - no idea the varietal - something Italian.  

All precursors to the stars of the evening show:  roasted chicken meatballs with pesto fennel strips and a pizza adorned by mushrooms just plucked from a dense woody glen before being scarified on a crispy thin pizza crust.   Mama mia.  Fungi is fine.
 
Thanks, A 16, your salad, meatballs and service more than make up for the pretension of not having an actual name.  We will be back.
author: Erin C.

description:
Yes yes yes! Pizza! A16, Napoli-Canosa!

UPDATE: I can't forgive them for removing the foosball table. More than that.....I can't forgive them for changing the chef.....now pizza is soggy. Still, a good trustworthy Italian restaurant.
author: Dario B.

description:
Its still one of my faves in SF.  Went there on a first date with my bf of 2.4 years now, and it was lovely.  Went back a few more times recently, and its still good.  Love the casually elegant ambiance.  The food is interesting and tasty.  The wine never disappoints.

Went there for lunch one day with a friend, and we sat in the little terrace.  At the end of our meal, we noticed they had a decanter of red wine that the employees were tasting from.  We jokingly said to the waitress that we'd also love to try some.  She then said no problem and poured us 2 tastings!  It was awesome.
author: janice l.

description:
Loved the Wine. Loved the bread and olive oil. Loved the Olives (they reminded me of the ones at Garibaldi's). The house cured salami was divine! My greatest surprise was the complimentary Grapefruit Sorbet (Not normally free, the waitress wanted us to experience it!). It was simply OFF THE RICHTER! I would have given them 5 stars but my entree was too salty (Lamb). Aside from that, it was a wonderful luncheon experience!

UPDATE: Ok. I really wanted to adore this place. I went back Easter Sunday for Brunch. I wanted my son to experience the Grapefruit Sorbet/Gelato. No dice. It was not served that day. *Big* disappointement since that is what my son was craving and I bragged about this place. Next. 

Ok. So, on to the House Cured Salumi. No dice. It wasn't served that day. Seems the chef couldn't operate the slicer for brunch. Now they're Oh-for-two (0-2). 

I ordered the tomatoe garlic mushroom pizza. The best description of the taste is ... BRINE. A real salt lick. (0-3). I drank as much water as I could and called it a day. Thoroughly disappointing.

They got 2 stars because of the Anti-pasti plate. The tatoo'd waitress couldn't have been more un-accomodating. I won't be going back. 

The prices are too high for a hit and miss this wide. And the "guess what we're having" menu style reeks if you've a taste for what you had the last time you were there. It also makes you look really bad when you've bragged on a place and it tanks. I mean TRULY.  The experience was a deck chair on the Titanic...
author: Now V.

description:
Confounded by the traffic we recently had to forgo a reservation in the North Bay - so we headed to Chestnut Street. My wife, in-laws and 5 month old baby were accommodated at a high table. Though the seating was not ideal we were fitted in and served promptly. The wait staff were extremely friendly. 

I had a nice glass of reasonably priced New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc, with chicken meatballs. to close off I have the chocolate, hazelnut cannoli washed down with a double espresso.  

A lovely meal in a family friendly restaurant. I will certainly go again.
author: Tony H.

description:
I avoided trying A16 for years because it was in the Marina... But I gave in and I'm glad I did.  There's a NY feel to A16.  The pasta and pizza are simple and delicious -- and the service is suprisingly good.  

Icing on the cake was chatting with Nate the chef while in line for the loos... He was sooo very nice -- and sent his favorite dessert over to our table.  Best panna cotta dessert I've had.
author: Tina T.

description:
I recommend this place for wine and an appetizer -- one appetizer in particular -- Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini... best in the city, hands down.

It gets four stars because the restaurant is a bit hot (bc it has an open kitchen) and so it's not super comfortable to be there all through dinner.  You can have wine/appetizers at the front of the restaurant, which is away from the kitchen, so it's better.  Plus, I thought the food was good... but the appetizer stole the show!  Now I just go back for the appetizer and some wine.  Yum!
author: Angela B.

description:
Good mozzarella cheese and appetizers. Good wine selection. I licked my plates clean. Not the best place for Italian entrees but the experience and atmosphere make it a 4 star!

Will see Jack Osborne look-alike waiter. A16 is very Marina like.
author: Stefanie Y.

description:
Overpriced, fine dining experience.
If you are rich I guess its worthwhile.
Not one plate stood out as something I would ever want to eat again for the price.
They need to be a little less pretentious too.
author: Josepe M.

description:
Cons: A little crowded and tables close together (but not too bad at all) and generally have to wait a while even w/ reservation.

Pros: Food is awesome and once you're seated service is excellent.

Had a prosecco (Italian sparkling wine) before dinner. Delicious and refreshing.

Unfortunately, had to wait about 30 minutes for our table, which was annoying. However, the hostess was quite apologetic and nice. Also, multiple very cute chicks working there.

Starters (for 4): Mozzarella burrata (mozz w/ creamy center, wow so great), proscuitto plate (YUM), pork liver terrine (WOW, this was really exceptional), margherita pizza w/ arugula & proscuitto.

Excellent sommelier recommended a reasonably priced Sardinian wine that was like a fruity Syrah/Zin blend w/ a nice hint of earthiness and oak.

First three apps came out, delicious. Slight mis-step then when the guy brought out the pizza. I noticed they screwed up the order and it was proscuitto + mushrooms instead of arugula, but it looked really good so decided not to bother w/ correcting them and ate it. A few minutes later guy came back and apologized for bringing us the wrong pizza. He was super apologetic but I told him it was awesome and not to worry about it.

Got two pastas and two entrees. Maccaronara - simple thick spaghetti type pasta w/ homemade tomato ragu. Simple and delicious. Ricotta gnocchi - fluffy, perfect. Braised beef short ribs - tender and tasty. Sausage and pork plate - hearty and super good. Sides of butternut squash (WOW!) and chard (yum). Basically, everything was great.

At this point we were pretty stuffed, but it was a friend's bday dinner, so we got dessert.

Sformatino di zucca with honeycomb candy and bitter chocolate and Chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil. Excellent.

So, once again (3rd time in a row) there was a little bit of a hitch up front, but nothing extreme, and once we were seated everything was excellent. The bill ($230 incl tax/tip) was a little cheaper than normal, so I think a couple of apps were comped to make up for the delay, which is always appreciated. It's a bit of a scene rather than a relaxed dinner environment, but if you're in the mood for a nice dinner in a somewhat bustling setting, I definitely recommend it. The staff and food are top notch.
author: Deva H.

description:
I went here for Dine About Town and they only offered a lunch option to me and my girlfriend went last week! This restaurant might have been overhyped for me but I was not impressed. The Dine About Town menu offered the following:

- Beat Salad = YUMMY esp if you like beets!

- Pizza option or meat balls = Here I was not impressed. It was pizza. I have had better... granted it was a medium sized pizza for one person to eat, but I have definitely had better. My friend ordered the meat balls a la carte and they were okay. Again, not the best meatballs out there. 

- Dessert: cookies or sorbet = Good.

- Side note: My friend ordered the bruschetta as her appetizer and we have never seen bruschetta like this. The bread was burnt to the point where it overwhelmed the flavor of the toppings, and the toppings consisted of ricotta cheese and peas? I've never had peas on a bruschetta before and don't choose to ever again.

I don't think this was worth the Dine About Town price. I don't think it offered the best of the what the restaurant could give because I have been given rave reviews about this place. And I would think a restaurant would realize that this may be a first impression it gives to newbies. The service was okay. I think that they could have done better. My water was not filled all the time and they only came to drop off food but not check on us. I don't know if I'll come back again.
author: Jess D.

description:
I heard good things and I guess it used to be the new hip place in the Marina... so it definitely didn't meet my expectations. We came on a random Wednesday night without reservations so were seated at the cook's table (which is just bar seating right by the open kitchen). I ordered the special (meatballs) on top of the maccaronara. The portion is tiny and tastes just o.k. Because the food wasn't great, we decided to skip dessert. 

Eh, just 3 stars.
author: Han C.

description:
A very crowded, popular restaurant in the Marina district.
I absolutely loved their Ciccioli (salami)!  Their pizza was my favorite type - thin & crispy Italian style.

Their wines were a bit pricey, but their mostly-Italian selections paired very well with their food.  The staff was very knowledgeable about the wines, too.
author: Durif M.

description:
A16 is amazing. I a great place with an amazing staff that continues to deliver year after year.

Their authentic, southern dishes are just solid Italian comfort foods. Their wines are pretty much unmatched for quality and value, and the burrata cheese is simply wrong.

Nice to see great food come to the Marina and it couldn't happen to a cooler group.
author: Lucky L.

description:
A16 is constantly on top 10 lists for SF - for good reason.  The food is tasty beyond description, stays true to the Italian cuisine, Italian wine list is extensive, service is excellent, and the ambiance is fun and hip.

We came here with a small group to celebrate daughter's high school graduation.  Everything - I mean EVERYTHING - was excellent.  And they bring out a little tiny pot of tasty hot pepper paste (not just pepper flakes).  If, like me, you love food that is spicy, this is a huge plus.

I'd list every item we ordered in minute detail and rate each one, but I'll just take the shortcut and say it was all fantastic.  All 7 people in our group (and trust me, a few of them are ultra finicky) agreed.

A16 has been one of my favorite SF restaurants for a couple of years, and I can say after dining here last night, it still is.
author: Blue L.

description: Two of us ordered the gnocchi, they were somewhat terrible, almost couldn't eat them -- like really pillowy but not in a good way, more like mush and I am somewhat obsessed with good gnocchi (I've lived in Italy).  Pizza, however, was good, although nothing special considering what is offered in the same neighborhood.  A group of us girls (ages 25) went with one of our moms and were talked down to by the server a bit which we thought was kinda weird.  Ambience was OK but not incredible.  All in all, I probably wouldn't go back, but I'm glad I tried it.   Just didn't really stand out for me.
author: sophie h.

description: What a terrible disappointment.  We were seated next to a table of over a dozen adults and children and it was so noisy we could barely hear each other.  Our service was unsatisfactory:  no one took our order for quite a while, and even then, our server forgot our pizza.
author: diane R.

description: Anyone who gives A16 a negative review just doesn't know a thing about food...And since I do, I will tell you that A16 served me the BEST pizza I've ever had other than that fabulous little restaurant I went to when I was  in Capri, Italy...Just writing about it makes me wish I was there right now ordering another Pizza Margharita! At A16...not the one in Capri!!! Now, I guess I should mention that I stumbled into this delightful little joint after a fun filled day of shopping on Union Street...The Fleet Street Blue Angels had just completed their Manuvers and we were able to grab a couple of Seats at the Bar...And so glad I did! Aidan, the Bartender, is Amazing! After asking me a couple of questions, he was able to select the PERFECT wine for me...Yummy, so delicious. Great Wine List.  Perfect Menu for either Light Nosh or Full on dinner...Very Cool, interesting, upscale crowd...You know I'll definitely be back...
author: Elayne L.

description: Burrata , Maccaronara (with chili oil), and Syrah! great combo and at the end of my block! My favorite Sunday night spot.
author: Sarah A.

description: The atmosphere is great and so is the food. The pizzas are terrific.
author: David H.

description:
I felt like giving A 16 three stars but after thinking about all of the dishes my girlfriend and I had, I had to move it up to four stars.

We started with the mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini. Simple yet damn good.

My girlfriend loved her bianca pizza and the few bites I had were satisfying. The pizza was flavorful and light. I especially liked the use of chiles and green olives to complement the mozzarella and grana padano cheeses.

My short ribs were excellent and, as I understand it, are a signature dish at A 16. Juicy and succulent, these are well worth a try.

Having spent time in a seaside village on the Lazio/Campania border a few years back, I'm definitely impressed with the authenticity and care taken with the wine list. I cannot recall the wine we had but I believe it was  a Campania red from Taurasi or Paestum.    

For dessert we split gelato. Always a good way to finish a meal, A 16's  house made gelato was refreshing.

A 16 lives up to the hype.
author: Adam L.

description:
On a recent trip to San Francisco, A16 was the one and only place he really wanted to have dinner while out there.  Out of all the amazing dining options in San Francisco, I think that's a huge endorsement for A16.

Things I liked:
 - Our waiter was funny, engaging, and attentive.  He also had great hair.
 - The burrata appetizer.  Why, oh why can we not get burrata on the east coast???
 - Our pizza (margherita) was quite tasty and is maybe in my personal Top 5 pizza ranking.  
 - the wine.  We chatted with one of the owners while waiting for a table and she recommended an Italian white (called 'titolo', I think) that was awesome.  
 - the pasta comes in half orders, which is a perfect size if you just want a little taste.  
 
Downsides:
 - found my pasta a bit salty.  I got the buccatini with almond pesto.  I think the saltiness came from the pecorino it was topped with.
 - waiting.  we had a reservation, but even so had to wait a bit.  The bar area is also fairly small, so it was quite cramped on a weekend night.
author: Lauren M.

description: Great pizza, great wine, good desserts.  I was not as wowed as I had hoped to be based on the hype, but the margarita pizza was wonderful and so was the wine.  Downsides are that the place feels cramped and the bill was a little more than what I felt my experience warranted.  Will go back to try additional items and sit outside (looked charming and less cramped).
author: Andrea D.

description:
Really, 3.5 stars. 

I have been to A16 twice and, after the first try, I felt that maybe it was too early to judge.  After all, maybe I just ordered the more lack luster plates.  But, during our last trip to A16 we ordered almost everything on the menu.  I have to say that it is good.  The food is your standard delicious California-inspired Italian cuisine.  Solid effort.  If only A16 wasn't in a city like San Francisco, where sooo many places do what they do well also.  So A16 gets lost in my memory, mixed in with other expensive, solid, and yet forgettable places like Conduit, Farina, and Range.  As with these other places, they are great restaurants for dates, to bring baby boomer aged parents, and provide a gracious atmosphere and service for a lovely long dinner.  Still, you are more likely to remember your conversation with friends than the food.  Which could be a good thing.

The gnocchi was the best dish.  The desserts were ok.  I almost liked the chocolate tart.
author: Caricia C.

description:
Starters where just OK
Pizza very disappointing soggy and sub par to any good pizza place!.....go to little star !!!!
Pasta is good!
Main courses where insulting no love in preparation or presentation.  Not properly seasoned!  for what you are being served really not worth the money!!!!!  Left feeling really ripped off with the main courses and the side dishes where really sub standard.
All food served on ice cold plates!!! WTF?
Service just ok really not great.  Waitress kept filling my husbands glass from husbands and never topped mine off so with out him even knowing it he drank 90% of our bottle!
Wont go back will keep going to Quince paying a bit more but getting f a first class meal and service!!
author: Aubrey P.

description:
I didn't go to school, but was reading the WSJ at school so, i made a reservation with opentable which i recommend.
The place is well located in the Marina, the outside stands out with all the restaurants, and shops close by. The layout  creates a bottle nose effect where there is small room in the front, but a lot in the back. As you walk in to your left is the hostess on the wall is the list of wines, the right is about a 10 seat bar, and as you walk back you see the exposed kitchen with wood fired pizza ovens, and the dinning area. Even though the place is small it can fit a great deal of people. My table was next to a window looking into an atrium with more seating, but was very well lit, and pleasant. 
The server came quickly, and was a joy to have i kinda wanted to have her sit, and eat lunch with us. I got a simple pizza to share, and a simple salad for my friend. The pizza was thin (type of style), and crispy with everything melted, and warm. The menu has a limited range of items for lunch, but pizza is mostly the main course. After we finished, we then ordered the 3 flavor ice cream, and accidently got two espresso which was nice to have with the coffee.
This place is a Marina restaurant, the pizza is good, the staff is kind, and was an enjoyable, and a repeatable experience for sure.
author: Nathan M.

description:
Terrific food and wine! Ambience befitting of typical marina with 'beautiful people' but don't let the good looking people distract you from the fantastic epicurian delights that await. 

Their pizza (esp. the Funghi [mushroom]) is simply fantastic-- the mixed grill I had as well was pheonmenal. The staff is friendly and approachable. The bartender, Kevin, paired a terrific itialian white wine with our meal and even gave us a sparkling Muscat on the house top off what was already a great meal.

If you're in the MARINA definitely worth it. BTW waiting for a table I hear is painful, but full menu is availible at the bar and it's less stuffy (the inside restaurant can get a bit warm)
author: A K.

description:
I love to sit at A16 for a glass of wine and quick bite before seeing a movie across the street.  (Support your local small theaters!)  I especially enjoyed the white bean appetizer.

But...
The last few times I have been here the bar was WAY too crowded for anything but screaming at your compatriots about how quickly to make your way back out the door (screaming only because it's the only way to be heard, natch).
And the one time I had dinner it was pretty unimpressive. The pizza at Amici's on Lombard has a much nicer crust.
author: Jess S.

description:
Best pizza around!  The food here is really great.  The standard Margherita is fantastic with Arugula and the hot pepper oil and don't miss the Salume.  Mmm... tasty.  We usually just sit at the bar, which has a pretty high turnover, as an alternative to waiting for a table.  This place gets crowded, so don't complain about having to wait a little while, even with a reservation.

Steve
author: Stephen H.

description:
A16 always has good Italian food -

I personally think it's fun to sit on the barstools right across from the chefs, so you can watch them as they prepare your dinner.  I would recommend most of the dinner entrees, but for dessert, the chocolate tart with olive oil is pretty amazing!
author: Rose W.

description: Right before I left San Francisco to move back to Atlanta, this adorable Italian spot opened and people are still singing its praises with good reason. If you are looking for simple Italian fare (made with mostly local ingredients) served up in a warm enviornment with an amazing wine list full of obscure Italian and California wines, this is the place to go. Reservations can be tough to get, but walk-in tables are always available. We went simple and got a few plates to share. Everything was perfect. The salad with Jerusalem artichokes, fried almonds, pecorino and escarole was just sick. And the burrata with mini toasts was gorgeous.
author: Blissful G.

description:
Not very happy

We had reservations at 8:30 - we didn't get seated until 9:15.  So I wasnt too happy about the length of time to wait.  We were offered though some champagne towards the ned of the wait so that was good and it was good champagne.  We were seated in the back - it was very dark and it was hard to see the food.  I ordered the pork chop and it was good - but TONS of FAT, TONS AND TONS and I had to work at my food to cut around it in the dark.  They also made the wrong thing for my friend twice and got it right the third time - that was annoying because it was his BDAY Dinner.

The last time I was at this place - I really enjoyed my meal.  I am a big Salumi fan and they have some great selections and the atmosphere is nice if you dont sit in the outside area. I was there a year ago and it seems as thought the quality and service has declined and I am disappointed.
author: Rod S.

description:
I've been wanting to try A-16 since I moved to the city about two years ago.  Every time I had tried to get a reservation they were always booked but I was able to have an early dinner with my mom who was passing through SF on the way to Sac for a business trip.  

My first impression was a hostess who although was competent and tried to muster up a smile was a bit rude.  Our server was excellent and very attentive and seemed to be enthusiastic about both the resturant and the food.  I had the tri tip which was a bit salty but still very good, I had a bite of my mom's yellow tail which was also good but a bit bland.  

A-16 is probably not worth all the hype but is a good resturant none the less.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
Finally I could make a reservartion for A16!!

I liked the amibrance, feeling great energy. 
Service is very good, and foods and wine are great.
But I am wondering why it is so difficult to make a reservation for this restaurant. There are a lot same or even better quality restaurants  Mission or other place in SF. 

Well, I may go back there someday.
author: Miho O.

description: I hit up this joint once a week for the pizza.  The Bianca is my fav.  Don't forget the hot chili oil.  Sit at the Chef Counter and watch them create!  Very friendly staff!
author: Billy M.

description: Read it on a GQ issue but recently tried out it pizza and it lives up to the hype.  But found the squid ink tonnarelli is even better.
author: Meo M.

description:
We went there for New Years and found the experience vastly, vastly overrated.

Most of the food was merely adequate, which is not what I'm paying for at those prices.  The one standout was the octopus carpaccio for which, if nothing else, I can appreciate the skill that went into its preparation.

Given that New Years is one of those days when a restaurant should be putting its best foot forward, I can't help but to wonder what the food must be like on regular days, nor shall I be making a return visit to find out.
author: Andrew L.

description: Food was good, but not extraordinary like I had hoped.  Clams were solid, and the leg of lamb was good.  I have never been more baffled by a wine list... and the Somm picked out an obscure bottle that was pretty disappointing.  Overall good restaurant, but did not live up to my grand expectations.
author: Bob M.

description: Great service and solid food.  Had a nice meal this evening.  The service was awesome and the wine was great.  Overall, I felt the pasta I had was just OK.  Nothing special.  The burrata was very good.
author: Mark G.

description: We have recently moved into the neighbourhood. Always busy, so thought it must be A plus. In brief, food is no better than on offer in other restaurants in the area, service is at best ambivalent, at worst they couldn't care less. On entry we were told that they would not seat our group until the third member of the party arrived (he was parking the car). Not the warm welcome you might expect! We had to get up and chase waiters down to order, get the bill etc. No smiles or interaction whatsoever. I don't know the secret to their success, but quite frankly they are so consistently busy that they really don't seem to have to care.  People come regardless. Wont rush back.
author: Danielle M.

description:
fun, loud, and casual.

i came here for a friend's bday dinner and with 9pm rezzies, this place was hopping on a thurs night.

the roasted peppers and the mozzarella burrata were both amazing!

the funghi pizza was a tried and true staple order.

we tried the much yelped about ricotta gnocchi and it was good but it's pretty heavy.  so do think of sharing and trying other things like the chicken which was very tasty and falling off the bone good.

with no cheese selection in sight, (the bday girl is not much of a dessert person) but the goat cheese crepes were a fun and light way to end the evening.

the service was really top notch.  super friendly and they even came with extra toast for the burrata without us even asking!  now that's impressive.
author: Anh V.

description: The space is nice, I like their wine wall and the decor but their service isn't that great considering the price.  The pizzas were yummy enough but it took FOREVER to get them.  Now I don't mind a long wait but they weren't very attentive.  I had to ask for my iced tea and water refill and they never really came to check up on us.  Maybe this is being super critical since the night before I ate at NOPA's and it was the COMPLETE opposite!
author: Eric G.

description:
I give A16 3.5 stars. Modern and cute inside with dim lighting makes this place a nice intimate setting, though it's fairly packed with people. At first we ordered a pasta with chile in it and it came out literally looking like pasta with sriracha hot sauce drizzled on top and tasted like it too. Upon trying it, I could tell the pasta had great texture but couldn't even taste it because the spicyness of the sauce overpowered the entire dish. What a shame, I kept thinking. When we sent the dish back (I usually never do this) the server was so sweet and wonderful about it, she allowed us to choose something else in place. This time we tried the MACCARONARA with ragu napoletana and house-made ricotta salata, which our server said was her favorite. Let me tell you, this pasta was so fantastic that I can daydream about it! The pasta noodles were freshly made, thick and CHEWY. The sauce was excellent as well and, overall, I think the simplicity of the dish is what made it so great. It's like eating the best spaghetti you will ever have. 
We also had the margherita pizza and added arugula. B was slightly disappointed that it didn't come with baby arugula. This probably would have been a better option for them to use because the large arugula leaves dressed over the pizza made it a little difficult to eat. The pizza was good, nonetheless. I must admit, I would come here for the maccaronara pasta alone and leave the margherita pizza up to Flour and Water!
author: Justine C.

description:
cuddly warmth in the "i'm-too-cool-for-school" that is the Marina, A16 serves light, refreshing versions of italian favorites.

(note: i was on a no-carb or alcohol diet when i went, and still enjoyed yummies! rating subject to change when this madness is over)

A16's strikes a great balance between a chic bustly energy and affectionate ambiance. our hostess was quick to know we were coming, and with reservations, we were swooped into our cozy corner table in no time. walking through the restaurant, dark wood benches line the matching wall, and laissez-faire stools line the open kitchen bar. i loved the outdoor patio - note to self - great place for a larger party to dine under the stars!

service by our server and bus boys was to-the-point, but considerate. specials and wine favorites were quickly provided, and food was on our table very promptly, a pleasant surprise given how crowded the restaurant was.

the menu had a delicious spread of starters, pizza, pasta, and sides -- and plenty that were carb friendly! we ordered a zucchini crudo, which was bursting with the green life of shaved zucchini, mint, parsley, green olives, and a lemon olive dressing. we also had their chanterelle mushroom starter with kale, which may have been slightly overdressed with salt, but nonetheless delicious and pure.

we continued to indulge with the maccaronara with ricotta and a rock cod, mussels, and bay scallops stew. yes, i did sneak a bite of the maccaronara (how could i not!), and it was homemade al dente perfection. it's a common theme with this review - but it was warmly cool. haha! my seafood stew was flavorful and seasoned perfectly to let all of its ingredients shine.

dessert? next time, i'm afraid. (though they had so many mouth-watering options)

overall, a modern italian dining experience that is traditional enough that i will bring my pops and mom to try it!
author: Diana L.

description:
so my friends hubby was waiting 2years to make it out to cali and try A16. he left a very happy man. my friend noticed first how 'cramped' the tables seemed to be in there. wasn't too loud. everyone working had a smile on and really friendly. since we all are 'foodies' we did 4 courses and i have never felt so full after a meal. the little bites really add up..(blushing angel cocktail=delightful)
starters: 
Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini- amazing, creamy, salty
La Quercia tasting: Americano, Berkshire and speck prosciutto, fun comparing the differences, favorite on plate- berkshire, loved the sweetness of it
Cannellini beans with garlic and oregano- full flavored
second course:
Pomodoro pizza- tons of little roasted cherry tomatoes, ricotta, garlic crust was fantastic
Ricotta gnocchi in brodo with cherry tomatoes, garlic and basil- cooked perfectly but i personally thought it could have used something more to bring out the flavor.. didn't really have a 'garlic basil' taste. it was good, but not exciting.
Squid ink tonnarelli with shrimp, zucchini, garlic, mint, anchovies and chiles- some nice spice to it, again, good, but not exciting. not something i would want to order again. 
Lamb meatball special- awesome. melted in your mouth deliciousness. i enjoy finding a well made meatball :)
third course:
Roasted beef tri-tip with salsa verde and fried Senise peppers- bf got this one, delicious. 
Breaded pork shoulder special- friend's hubby got this (my personal favorite entree) crisp outside, juicy mouth watering center)
Local rock cod in acqua pazza with basil- lots of seafood, tasty, i found it good, and again not exciting.
Roasted stuffed quail with pork belly spiedino and mosto- my dish. the pork belly was the prized piece on this plate. the quail seemed stuffed with.. i dont know what, but it was eh. 
Side dishes:
Roasted potatoes with pickled onions, capers and chiles- plain jane
Erbette chard with pine nuts, currants, garlic and lemon- tasty!
fourth course (and the show stopper)
Chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil - at first i was questioning if i really wanted that fantastic olive oil paired with the chocolate. first bite it was strange, but then you dig deeper and the salt mixed in is truly incredible. it made the ending absolutely worth the wait. 
Ps- if you didn't notice, the chef here LOVEs pork :)
author: Abigail W.

description: This place is a winebar / Pizza joint gone upscale.   We came here for late night dinner and it was great.  Good veggie options, wine list is wonderful, staff is very good.  We didn't tried the Deconcillis Aglianic red and it was nice.
author: H D.

description:
Popped up to chestnut street for a bite after a long day at the museums. We decided on A 16 after peeking at their menu on the door. We walked in (about 10 till 5 30, which we never come this early but museum business is rough) and put our names in, and she told us to wait. When clearly the restaurant was empty. 
We side tracked to the Olive Oil boutique place a few stores down. We came back and was seated. 
We ordered the wine, and decided to split a pizza--the Bianco Pizza. The magic pot of chile olive oil is lovely, its like Winnie the Pooh's jar of honey. Delightful. Drizzle that all over yo pizza and you ll love it all. 
I was not thrilled with the service. It was awkward where we were sitting, b/c the kitchen staff kept starring at us--dumb. Go make your pizza's! Ale! 
Our pizza arrived, and it was plenty for the two. Heads up. The crust is not where I wanted it to be, but decent and served its purpose as the handle to hold the pizza.
author: Brittany B.

description: decent italian food, i had the proscuito sampler, there were only two samples, an italian (di parma) and US one, the italian was too dry to what I would be used to. The pizza (funghi) was superb. The roasted chicken with brocolli di ciccio was good, vegartables overseasoned. Busy place, competent staff. I would go back for the pizza.
author: Jef C.

description: This restaurant introduced me to burrata cheese. I loved every taste of it paired with the prosciutto tasting. However, my main course was not too appealing to me. I ordered a cold dish pasta with black noodles. A bit dry for me, but I would love to try this place again- with another dish..
author: Monica C.

description: Had the tripe for lunch last time.  Nom nom.  Don't think about it, just try it.  You'll like it!
author: Tim L.

description:
I have friends that will shake their heads at the 2 star rating, but being true to myself and my dining companions, our meal was below average... and not even just for the price.

The ambiance is fun, a little crowded and a little older crowd than most places I normally go in the city, but that didn't bother me at all.  I am usually a little confused at butcher paper on a "nicer" restaurant, but I can go with it.  Our server was nice, our wine was good, but that's about all the good things I have to say.  

For our table of 3, we ordered multiple plates to share.  Our first app was the Tuna conserva, which was relatively flavorless.  I was able to pick out a few artichoke pieces which were tasty, but the flavors really didn't seem to fit together.  We also had a Funghi pizza, which was average at best.  It was flimsy, the toppings all slid off as we picked up each piece, it lacked in cheese, and it was just boring.  As a huge gnocchi fan, I was really looking forward to the Gnocchi verde but was beyond disappointed.  It was gritty with a strange flavor.  It was in a flavorless, clear broth.  My city pal and I were entertaining a friend from the Midwest so we didn't really talk about it, but we didn't even finish half of it.  We had a side order of polenta which was good, but its pretty hard to screw up polenta.

That's it.  We decided to skip dessert and paid the bill.  I don't mind paying the price for a good meal but I was surprised, especially on the high recommendation of friends, that our meal was such a disappointment.
author: Erin H.

description:
Very creative concept named after a freeway in Italy, with great wines and a nice atmosphere.  The guys behind the bar are super knowledgeable about wines and very friendly.  That said, as great as the wine list may be, it's too much --  I'm lost.  

Also, twice, now, my pizza has been pretty mediocre, and given the price tag, I was a little annoyed.  The food is good but certainly there are better places to eat.
author: marie m.

description:
Endlessly hyped by the masses and often debated by my friends, A 16 had a lot riding on this meal. 

Before I even opened the menu, I ate some of their bread and olive oil. The olive oil had such a pure taste that I couldn't stop mopping it up. This was a good sign. Bread is such an important indicator of a restaurant's attention to detail.

Salads, cured meats, olives, and cheese were passed around, all delightful. The house cured meats were particularly exciting, as their personal touches shook the salames and pates out of the expectations I'd built up after plenty of grocery store foraging over the years. 

As we grazed on the array of snacks we'd ordered, it hit me by surprise. The aroma of fresh crust, tomato sauce, and cheese wafted my way. Luckily we'd ordered a bunch of pizzas to try, as after catching a whiff of the pizza scent floating out of their kitchen, there was nothing that could have prevented me from eating one. The thin, tasty, cracked crust provides an unrivaled foundation. As I ate it, I tried to think of pizza in Italy that compared, but I couldn't. This was better, though I never made it south of Rome. 

My entree came along and was fine. The gnocchi was beyond delicate, melting seconds after putting it in my mouth. My complaint was that they didn't do enough with the chantrelles. There must be some way to illuminate their flavor more and spread them throughout the dish.

After dessert I was so full it was painful. The bottom line here is that the food is good and the pizza is excellent. I know that I get cravings for mindblowing pizza pretty regularly, and I'll definitely think about A 16 the next time one rolls in.
author: Dibital N.

description:
Tasty, somewhat authentic Italian food in a very loud restaurant.  The standouts are the pizzas, homemade buratta and, of course, the wine list, which is full of obscure, regional Italians.  I know nothing about these, but the wait staff is very helpful.  At a recent dinner party, our server suggested one $40 dollar bottle after another; each was delicious.  The salumis, also made in-house, are tasty too but lack the gaminess of made-in-Italy sausages.

Monday is meatball night.

Or so I've been told.  Due to San Francisco's discriminatory and unfair health codes, I am not permitted to enter this restaurant.
author: spot d.

description:
When my friend arrived at A16 to put his name in, he was told there was a 2 hour wait. Which was good, since my other friend and I hadn't even made it to the Marina yet and parking was a pain in the ass due to some beer festival. We finally parked right in front of the Palace of Fine Arts and met our friend at the Grove where he was enjoying a beer. 5 minutes later the A16 hostess called to say there was a cancellation and we could be seated after all. SWEET!

I'm always confused by restaurants that put out only olive oil with their bread. No herbed oil, no balsamic vinegar, just straight olive oil. It's a little strange. A16 should invest in some balsamic or at the very least, rosemary and garlic.

The pizza I had was delcious, and you get a really nice sized pie for the money. I could only eat half of it. Yay for leftovers! I wish they had a more reasonably priced side salad, to balance out the carb heavy pizza.

Our service was good, when the waiter was around, but he disappeared for long stretches. We were having good conversation and the place was a little busy, so we didn't mind. Plus he didn't act like he was too busy to deal with our requests. The bus boys filled the water regularly (always a good thing). 

If you don't like sitting on top of everyone else, I wouldn't recommend A16. They jam the tables together and you have to weave in between them like you're in a maze. Otherwise, it's a pretty reasonably priced, delicious meal.
author: Jessica B.

description:
Unfortunately I don't eat pork but everything from the different types of ham, meatballs and pizzas looked deliciously appetizing. 
The gelato and various desserts were also good but the cannoli was a bit too modern for my taste. My favorite cannolis are from Ferrara Bakery & Cafe in NYC.

Parking is a pain in the ass. I suggest walking if you can or taking a cab.
author: Tu R.

description:
I went on meatball night (Monday).  I thought I was going for meatballs but ended up enjoying much more.  The burrata was insane, creamy, milky goodness.  Then my friend and I split the 5 meatballs and the Maccaronara and had a side of chard.  It was gone in about 5 seconds.  This wasn't because of small portions, but because it was so good we couldn't stop eating.
I can't wait to go back.  Our waiter was so great...reco on the wine was spot on.
author: cristina t.

description:
Being that I am a pseudo vegetarian this might not have been the place for me, since their specialty is in house made salami and prosciutto, but my experience was extremely enjoyable.  The wine selection is outstanding and I was able to have gnocchi with a slight modification made to it.  The food was wonderful and reasonably priced.  They actually serve great portion sizes (not big) and the opportunity to get half orders of all their pastas is great!!!  

Great place to go with another couple/with a significant other!!!
author: matt g.

description:
This seems to be one of those places that is divisive.  It is perhaps our favorite place to go when my wife and I get the rare chance to dine out in San Francisco - above Boulevard.  Above Aqua.  Above Quince.

We've found the wait staff to be impressively informed on esoteric Italian wines, and all of the four rotating sommeliers to be impressively well-trained on the wines of Italy.  Their study time is evident.

But you have to enjoy the esoteric foods of Italy, including a smattering of offal-based cuisine, to really appreciate A-16.  Those who complain of high volume, high heat (they do have a 700-degree, wood-fired pizza oven) and high crowds are absolutely right.  I definitely recommend going early.

Tip - Go Early!
Tip #2 - if alone or with a group of 2 or 3, opt to sit at the bar.  You'll get an amazing education and, depending on who's cheffing that night, some great conversation.

Cheers!
Dave Chambers, Wine Merchant
Dave@SidewaysWineClub.com
author: Dave C.

description:
Service= great. I never had to ask for anything, food came out at the right time, and everyone was nice, but not super friendly. 

Food= hit and miss. The pizza was awesome. Perfectly cooked, and really good crust. We had the octopus with cucumber and tomato appitizer. It was the weakest part of the dinner. It tasted like a tuna salad without the mayo. I like tuna, but this just wasnt clicking for me. The roasted eggplant appitizer was also just ok, the eggplant skins were tough and plasticy. The highlight though was the marinated olives. YUM! i usually have to be in the mood for olives, but not these, i could eat hundreds of them! Then we got dessert. Tried the homemade chocolate gelato, very good. But i dont think i have had a desert as good as there chocolate tart with sea salt and olive oil in along time. it was AMAZING!

On to the drinks. Im sure they have a great wine selection, but their wine list isnt very user friendly. My date is very expirenced with italian wines and we were still very intimidated by the whole thing. We could have asked for help, but saw trumner pils on tap, so we just went with that.

I'll go back for sure, there was alot of other things on the menu that looked interesting enough to try. The place is very Marina though. You know what that means, not that there is anything wrong with that, but this place fits in well with its surroundings.
author: clint e.

description:
As everyone says, you MUST have reservations here if you want to get a table. I live right down the street from this place, and can honestly say that it is always busy. The bar area is relatively small and the overflow is forced onto the street. However, the wine selection is great - mostly Italian wines - so that will definitely hold you over until your meal. 

The service here was great, the food was very good, and the sommelier was very knowledgeable. Towards the end of the night we ended up with a great wine from Lazio - it definitely capped off our experience at A16. I'll definitely be back!
author: Jonathan D.

description:
Salty, salty, salty.  Everything was so damn salty.  I was very disappointed in this place, and here's why (Some of this is nit-picky, but at $80 a person, valid all the same):

Table of ten ordered apps to share (salumi, pizzas and Mozzarella).  Most also ordered salads when they ordered their entrees.  The obvious option would be to course it out.  But they brought out all the salads and family style apps at the same time.  Which means to me that they only booked the table for an hour and 1/2 or 2 hours.  Come on, a ten top?  Give us 2 1/2 hours at least.  Especially since it was a Tuesday.  At 6 o'clock

Got the salumi, but no one would/could tell us what was what

SALTY.  I mentioned it at the beginning and I'll mention it again.  The food was way too salty.  and the pizza was BURNT.  I'm talking black bubbles on the crust.  Since there were so many of us, I got to try most of the menu.  The salads were salty, the pastas were salty, the minestra was WAY salty.  Two things I did like - the short ribs and the side of potatoes.

I would definitely not go back and I would definitely not recommend this place.
author: Gabrielle G.

description:
I have been told to skip the sit down dinner and head to bar, order a pie and a bottle of wine.  That is what we did and thoroughly enjoyed it.   
The bartender was fabulous - very helpful with the wine  - however, the hostess was a bit rude - go figure.  This place is a stones throw from my house - I will be back....maybe tonight.
author: Catherine B.

description:
I went to A16 with two friends last night. The ambiance is great, the staff is very friendly and the food is almost great. We started with the Mozzarella burrata which was fantastic. It was Meatball Monday so we had to order some meatballs which were also really good. Then things went a bit downhill, the Marinara pizza was just ok, and the Chestnut tonnarelli was rather dry and bland. 

I will definitely be going back but haven't quite found the perfect order yet. . .
author: Alexis J.

description:
I've been to A16 dozens of time and this is my advice:
Go to A16 for what they do well....pizza and Italian wine, and you won't be disappointed.  
Their pizza bianca with olives and basil is spot on.  A16 is  one of the only restaurants in SF with a permit for a wood oven, which sets their pizza apart.  Even from (dare I say it), Pizzeria Delfina. 
The wine list is incredible and their sommeliers are knowledgeable and accommodating. They have a great selection of small vineyard and limited production wines-- they certainly do their leg-work. 

My experience with the rest of their menu is that the food is solid, authentic and quality but the "wow" factor is hit or miss. Great appetizers and salads though!
author: Kiira M.

description:
Crowded?  Always.  Great wine recommendations?  Always.  So does it really matter if the wait is forever when you've got a tasty glass of red vino to take the edge off? 

I like this place on Sundays, when it's a little more tolerable of a wait, the prospect of cooking seems overwhelming, and the smell of pizza dough and wine coupled with the warmth of the ovens and beautiful bodies make the impending workweek seem more tolerable.

Recommendations?  Everything, really.  I do have a strong preference for two of the sides:  the white beans and the kale.  The BF wants the Saliccia Pizza every time, but I'm still waiting to try the mushroom which looks delicious also.  The beet salad appetizer is worth a try if you can handle a big plate o' beets.  I'm raising a glass of Italian Red to many more Sundays at A16!
author: Marina Maven C.

description:
First off three stars for not having a full bar.
Moving past this 
I really liked the wine list - we only stopped in to have wine.
Good full bodied reds. Lots of flavors. Seemed like a great selection and from the quick browse of the wine list focused only on Italy, which is honestly different that the norm. It's nice to see something different.
Food - I don't know how it tastes - from what it looked like the dishes had really nice presentation and they looked tasty.
