I liked how the space is small that's a nice plus and the staff is really friendly - which is very important.
author: melissa h.

description:
Someone help me understand the fascination with this place.  Why does everyone say - "You live in the Marina?  Have you been to A16?!".  And why would Reese Witherspoon and Jack Gyllenhal visit A16 two nights in a row then they were recently in town?  Especially with the money they have to throw around.
A16 is, at best, average.  The food is good, but not spectacular.  It is way too hard to get a reservation.  The service is fair.  Really, I don't get it.  It doesn't even seem like that hip of an atmosphere, especially if you are unfortunate enough to be seated in what I call "the stairwell" - an area in the back behind the restaurant that feels like a NYC apartment building stairwell to me.
For the money, you can do SO much better.  Enough is enough about A16.
author: Bette K.

description:
Went to dinner here with 2 friends and we were able to get in without a reservation which was a surprise (a pleasant one!)
We decided to sit at the little bar area facing the kitchen which was really neat - the smells were amazing! We ordered a pizza, gnocchi and the burrata and shared a bottle of wine. The server was VERY knowledgeable about wine and helped us pick an inexpensive bottle ($35) that was delicious. We were all impressed by the wine knowledge and their ability to explain Italian wines so that we understood how they compared to California wines ...very cool! Food was fabulous and we are excited to go back. Little pricey but oh so good. If you like burrata it's the best in the city (in my humble opinion!)
author: Kelly C.

description:
Fabulous Place.  Been here twice now and have been impressed both times.  

Its a great place - so guess what people - there are gonna be a lot of people in there and it might get a little loud at times.  Relax and enjoy.  You want privacy and intimacy go get a room in a hotel and order room service!!!

Pizzas are definitely on point and adding an egg was great.  The tripe is out of this world.  Best I've ever tasted and cooked to perfection.  If you've never tried tripe before this would be the place to do it for your first time.

YOU MUST TRY THE ITALIAN BEER - Nora.  Hints of white pepper and very clean and refreshing.  Went great with the Italian food.  Where do they sell this stuff?  I am on a mission to hunt it down.
author: Omnivore's D.

description:
The wine list is exceptional.
The contorni and salads are excellent.
The pasta is good.
The Pizza was my favorite (Picco is better).
I would give it 5 stars, but Picco is better (sorry :( )
Oh, and the staff are beautiful ( hmmm, I guess I should give them 5 stars. )
author: Roop D.

description:
Took my wife here for her first time.  Service was awesome and the hostess was very nice to us.  We ordered two salads and a pizza (wife's pregnant so she's eating for two).  She had the romaine something and she thought it was too sour.  I ordered the arugola and I thought it was pretty good, but the nectarines didn't quite fit into the picture.

Pizza was awesome which made up for it.

The worst part was finding parking....
author: David C.

description:
So I realize that I often give restaurants 5 stars...I think it's because I'm only compelled to write a review if I LOVED a place.  Well, I loved A 16.

I was craving pizza and I heard A 16 was the place to go.  We were seated immediately without a reservation, and our waitress was delightful.  We were waited on almost immediately.  We had a lovely bottle of Prosecco and shared two pizzas.  The pizzas were UH-MAY-ZING.  We shared the Salsiccia and the Margarita...highly recommend the Salsiccia.  Our waitress gave us chili oil to put on the pizza, which I have never done and will now always do.  Delicious!  The crust on the pizza is totally soft and perfect.  Yum yum yum.

I can't speak to the non-pizza dishes, and we were too full for dessert.  But I am a BIG fan of A 16's pizza.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Meghan P.

description: Ate hear shortly before Nate Appleman started getting his accolades from Food and Wine magazine and the James Beard folks. I can understand the praise being showered upon him. Truly amazing comfort italian food. Bring a friend, share some wine, split a pizza and a pasta dish to get the best of both worlds. The gnocchi were simply to die for and a pizza with prosciutto on top is also divine. I'll definitely be back again.
author: Jason T.

description:
Third time eating here an I have to say it was outstanding!!!!

Went with my girlfriend and we went to town.  Started with the salumi tasting- pork in all its deliciousness.  There was at least five different applications of pork on the board, each with their own distinct flavors and textures.  Thumbs up.

Next on to tuna conserva panzanella-crisp bread, thinly sliced celery, big beefy black olives, all tossed with tjust the right amount of olive oil and  
vinegar.

I can go on forever here, but I won't.  We had at least 5 other things and they all sang.  Can't forget to mention the superb wine pairings that were made by the wine steward.  1/2 glasses of everything, as to not break the bank and to bring out the best of each dish.

Bravo A16!!  I shall return.
author: frizzle-fry e.

description:
Ran by this place while walking by after dinner at Mamacita's, which by the way I loved great ambiance, scrumptious food and good service. We decided to make a reservation and hit this spot on a friday night with a couple of our friends.

I would rate the food a 4 star, the pizzas are really good we tried the funghi and the Salsiccia. They also have an impressive wine collection. The review gets a 3 star for the service. it absolutely sucked! The waitresses seem stuck up and act like they are manufactured in Italy. They were little help with the menu, did not serve with a smile and corrected any wrong pronunciations of the the italian words. Not a very warm feeling and we even left them a real low tip as we were disgusted with the service.
author: Ash O.

description: Delish. Love their wood-fired pizzas. Pricey, but reasonable for a really nice date night.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Went here for dinner Friday night.  Awesome staff - seated us in five minutes.  (We got there around 8:30pm).   Had two salads, both were delicious (a panzanella with roasted calamari, and a Roasted mushroom and snap pea salad with radishes, nepitella and pecorino).  We had the Salsiccia  pizza - was a little spicier then I generally like, but good.  Waitress was great, and made a great wine suggestion.  Would return on my next trip.
author: Haley S.

description:
I really wanted to like A16.  I have heard so many good things about this place but I just didn't like the food or the service.  

We tried three different pizzas and not one of them did it for me.  In addition, the waitress had forgotten to put our order in so we ended up waiting a very long time for our pizzas.

On top of that, we brought a bottle of wine and they charged a $30 corkage fee!  I realize that they have a huge wine list of their own, but we had come straight from wine tasting and had it with us and we definitely didn't expect to pay so much.  

If you want good pizza I would definitely recommend Little Star or Pauline's in the Mission over A16.
author: Maura B.

description:
We went here on a Sunday night during Natural Wine Week.  We knew it would probably be crowded and tried to make a reservation earlier in the week, but unfortunately they were all full.  The lady I spoke to on the phone, however, was very accommodating and nice to talk to.  She told me that they reserve 1/3 of the restaurant for walk-ins so we could still come in if we wanted, we would just need to wait a bit for a table.  We tried that and went around 5:45.  We left my name and cell phone number and they said the wait would be a little over an hour and they would call us to let us know when a table was available.  Well I guess we lucked out because we got a call about 15 minutes later saying that they had a cancellation and could get us in.

The food was pretty good.  We had the appetizer special which was some small grilled peppers.  They were good, but I like the shisito peppers at The Alembic bar better.  We drank lots of Brown wine as that was the featured winery for the night.  Great wine, but I'm used to paying winery prices for the bottles rather than restaurant prices, so I was in a bit of price shock (although I understand that bottle prices are typically 2 to 3 times what you pay retail for).  Most of our party had pizzas and I had the pasta.  They gave us some house made chili oil that went great over everything.  I felt a little rushed by the staff between the appetizers and the entrees and they must have checked with me 2-3 different times to ask if they could clear my unfinished plate before I finally finished and allowed them to clear it.  Our waitress was very nice, but all in all I'm not sure if I will go back any time soon...  I appreciate the hostess, nice waitress, and overall hospitality, but there are so many great restaurants in the city, and this one just didn't really stand out to me as one I will be raving about.
author: Jen F.

description: Great place for some Italian.  Had the Salsiccia pizza which was delicious. Staff gave some good recommendations for appetizers and wines. I'll be going back again!
author: Matt F.

description:
I hate to give bad reviews, but I was VERY disappointed in A16.  I went there a few years back with a friend and had a bad meal.  But, we thought we'd try it again, seeing as every time I walk past there, the place is packed.  I figured it had to be good.  Bad assumption.  

The pizza was subpar - burnt crust, which was also completely soggy (go figure), mediocre toppings and generic tomato sauce.

The pasta was obviously made there and fresh, but it was overcooked to the point of mush and the sauce tasted like it came out of a jar. My friend and I had our first bites, looked at each other and said "Ragu!" Unbelievably bad.  

We both sat there thinking, why didn't we go to Rose's?  The pizza there is great, the pasta is delicious and everything on the menu looks amazing.

I will NOT be going back to A16.
author: Jennifer Marie J.

description:
Pretty good. I went here expecting to be really impressed but it was ok. Went for dinner. Started with the burrata which was good. Pizza (2 kinds) green olive and also sausage. Good, but not fabulous.
 Nice wine selection and staff knowledgeable about the list. Pretty loud and just ok service, prices not bad. Overall nice night but I guess I might have to go back to see what all of the hype is about. It is what I expected from a wood oven pizza place, just not fantastic!
If you don't want to wait as long and want a tasty meal go down the block and eat at Mamacita which is really delicious.
author: julie q.

description:
Fantastic Italian restaurant in the Marina. The previous reviewer is right: the mozzarella is simply amazing - best I've ever had. The margherita pizza is simple but excellent, and the gnocchi is decent. Service was very attentive and we loved the wine our waitress suggested. And the atmosphere is perfect: energetic without cramming you in.

Just don't try parking in the neighborhood; it's near-impossible on a crowded Saturday night. Take a cab.
author: Brian G.

description: Had pizza for lunch.  It was positively delicious.  Great wine selection I would visit again and would probably have dinner next time.  I have the cookbook and I'm going to start using it! Especially to make a pizza sauce...
author: Eydie H.

description:
The cookbook from this restaurant is called simply "A16: Food + Wine". That is exactly what you get: simple yet imaginative Italian food inspired by Campania and surrounding regions and excellent wines from Southern Italy. I'd been hearing about A16 for a while from my friend Brien W., whose sister Anna helped start the restaurant and worked with the Nate Appleman (the former exec chef) and Liza Shaw (the present one). Since then I visited A16 a few times and had my birthday dinner there this year. Throughout the time I've sampled a variety of items off the menu and the whole range has been really good, but A16 is especially known for a few things: its mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt, and crostini; the tuna conserva with dried favas and roasted peppers; the house-cured salumis; and, of course, the Neapolitan-style pizzas. The latter are my favorites and compete with Pizzeria Delfina for the best pizza in the city. I also really enjoy their wines and the sommelier, Shelley Lindgren, is excellent and always ready to listen to you and recommend a good option.

The service is generally good, but can be hit-and-miss sometimes. A16 is not a quiet place by any means, so don't count on having a nice romantic dinner because it is always infused with energy and tends to get pretty loud. I would almost say it's better with a group of people since you can order a variety of dishes to share then. It is usually busy, even on weekdays, so reservations are a good idea. Although, if you are not hurting for time, just come in, finagle a seat at the front bar, and have a glass of wine while you wait for the table and the delicious pizza.
author: Andrei Z.

description:
Had not visited this place in over 2 years.  And you know what , it gets a 5 star for the food.  I love it, awesome, amazing fantastic - in particular the fresh Mozarella (borrata, berrata or somat like that!).

Unfortunately they sat us near the brick ovens, which are great if you are a thin crust pizza, but not if you are wearing a wool sweater and jeans.  I walked out feeling like I had just played a game of tennis!  Oh and the server charged my friends card twice, instead of half and half.  It is a good job he knows where to find me to get half the money.... damn it :-)
author: Dazza M.

description:
My husband and I went here for my birthday. And this year it happened to fall on a Friday. And as everyone knows Friday night is one the busiest nights for a restaurant. Well, we got there pretty early. It was about 6:00 when we sat down. We didn't have reservations either. A good recommendation would to be make reservations because when we left the place was packed and people waiting in the front to be seated. 

We sat down, I order a Bellini to drink. I would say it was OK. Not the greatest but it wasn't bad. As an appetizer we order Mozzarella on Crostini. Good. Very crunchy and delicious. 

For dinner I had their Maccaronara. Which is a thick spaghetti type noodle. It was good. The portions are OK. Very dainty. My husband had their Margherita Pizza with Pancetta. It was delicious. I loved it. 

For dessert we had Hazelnut Semifreddo with Hazelnut Brittle and Chocolate Cake. It was good. Especially with a latte. 

Overall the food was good. The service we received was ok. The waitstaff was very nice and friendly. We never waited too long for anything. They were a delight. 

But the restaurant is a little pricy and over hyped. So it's a matter of taste. I would come here again but maybe early in the day and maybe just for after work drinks.
author: Jessica L.

description:
A16, let me count the ways. I love this place. I understand native San Franciscans may not understand good pizza, so I'll let any bad reviews slide. This is by far the best pizza I've had outside of that boot-shaped country called Italy. It's a perfect thickness, the ingredients are fresh and delicious and it's cooked to perfection in a true bad ass wood burning oven. 
My fiance and I have eaten here more than any other place in the city. The food is always inventive and incredible. We've also only had great service here. 
Another BIG bonus to A16 is the wine list. We can find rare Sicilian wines on their list that we can't even find in Europe. AND the sommelier is always great. We give them a budget and some ideas and they always pick an amazing bottle.
My advice would be to go here with a group of four or more and share everything. You won't be sorry!
author: Lee T.

description:
Believe the hype! Granted, we go at the grandfatherly hour of 5:30, but this place is one fantastic trip for your tastebuds.  

Formula for oozy perfection:

Bottle of Red.  We like the Primitivos. 
Burrata appetizer.  Oh. My. God!!! so tasty. (I know you can get it at the cowgirl creamery but what they do to it here with the slight seasoning and the crostini is to die for.) My eyes closed over and over while eating.
We like to share a pasta appetizer portion.
Split two pizzas. The funghi is the best. 
Chocolate gelato and biscotti for dessert.
Cab home.  Watch DVD in stupor. Sleep.
author: Ashley S.

description:
If I had pets, I'd name them Burrata and Salumi, 'nuff said.

Fantastic wine list.  It is hard *not* to experiment here, especially if you are new to southern Italian wines.

Tip:  If you don't like the Marina crowd, wear earplugs and take them out only when your waiter is at your table. They're not so bad when you can't hear them talking!
author: Dave K.

description:
For making the top 100 in the Chronicle, this place really does deserve a 4 or 5.  However, let me plead my case as to why it only gets a 3...

For one, getting a reservation here is a serious ordeal.  You should be booking at least 2 weeks in advance - expect a poor time, be happy if  you get what you asked for.  Secondly, it's like a zoo in there.  The place is jam packed all the time, with nowhere to wait.  Don't expect to find relief when you sit down, because the tables are just as 'cozy'.

Now, why would I go back?  The food is pretty damn tasty...even looking past the stereotypical marina crowd.  If I recall correctly, I sampled the proscuitto plate, a squid ink pasta, pizza dish, and an olive plate.  All were better than expected. 

Service was good with the staff knowledgable about the wine and dishes.  Kudos to the management for training them properly!

I think I'll come back to A16 when the opportune time comes, but for now they have slipped from glory.
author: Simon Y.

description:
I just made our reservations for New Year's Eve and in anticipation of that meal I thought it appropriate to leave a review for what is fast becoming one of my favorite restaurants in The City.

We've dined at A16 half a dozen times and have never failed to have a great experience. Two real standouts - the atmosphere and the hospitality. Sadly, both are increasingly in short supply these days. A16 benefits from having one of the more unique settings, but they've filled the space with warmth and a terrific staff.

Two other constants in our visits are the pizza Margherita and the salumi. There are some wonderful pizza joints in The City but I'd stack A16's Margherita against any of them, as well as many east coast pizzerias. As for the salumi, you can't go wrong with any selection but the prosciutto tasting is consistently excellent.

Among pastas the gnocchi is truly outstanding. It's really the only pasta I'd substitute for one of their entrees, in part because I've become a white bean fiend in the past year and A16's take is pure bliss.

The dining room can get a little loud, particularly on the weekends, which is a shame because during a lull you'll turn to your dining companions and ask, "Is this Talib Kweli they're playing?" Too good.

Some detractors will lament that A16 "isn't very Italian." Having never been to Italy I can't vouch for the cuisine's authenticity, but what I think those people mean is that A16 "doesn't fit my definition of an Italian restaurant" e.g. no Chianti bottles with dripping candles. Isn't that what those tourist traps in North Beach are for?
author: Trip T.

description:
We hit up A 16 based on recommendations from a number of friends. We  tried to make a reservation for a party of 7 only one day early, and it clearly wasn't going to happen. The maitre d' suggested we show up at 5pm as they hold (two) tables for walk ins. They sat us at the first table that's designed to really seat a max of 6, so it was cozy, but not horrible. We were a motley crew of friends and family catching up after almost 2 years, so we were too engrossed in our company and conversation to worry too much about our seating location. There's a separate corridor for walking down to the back of the restaurant so we weren't bothered much by staff and guests walking past to get to the rest of the restaurant.

The food was great, not excellent, but great.  We shared an appetizer of mozzarella spun with cream, served with EVOO and a brown bread crostini. My dairy sensitive tummy told me no, but my tongue told me yes yes yes! The salumi plate was great, although they factored in a lot of sweetbreads/offal/pate style food, all of which I'm not a fan of, but it was enjoyed by everyone else.

The wine list was great, very heavy on the Italian wines with a reasonable but limited selection of Californian wines. The range of prices was broad, $30 to $400. You could make it an expensive meal or keep it more affordable based on your wine choices.

Most of us had a proper entree, one had pasta and I had a pizza. I wouldn't rush back for the pizza, but the lamb and beef dishes were delicious, as was the quail. Not sure about the pasta, but the ingredients suggested it should be good. Being able to choose your side dish was great, the potatoes with the salsa verde were cooked and seasoned to perfection. I also liked the way they were served separately in a small bowl- good for sharing and easy for the kitchen staff to prepare :)

Nothing on the dessert menu tickled anyone's fancy so no one had anything. There were a lot of savoury-esque items and not a smidge of chocolate to be seen (call me simple, but at least one thing on a dessert menu should have chocolate in it). 

Unlike other reviewers, we found the service pleasant and informative. We had a large enough party that we had a few people tending on us at times, which is always fun. The ladies at the table always had their wine glasses filled first -I'm a sucker for classic service like that so thumbs up in that department for me :) We're also a bunch who like to hang about and talk after the meal is done rather than be rushed out and I felt that because we were walk-ins they weren't too concerned about rushing us out because the table was needed for the next reservation. 

So, all in all, a good experience. Crowded and busy, yes, but it's that kind of a place. Will definitely go back, would definitely recommend it and will also be trying SPQR.
author: Emily T.

description:
One of my FAVORITE restaurants in SF!!! I actually wish I lived in the Marina just so I can eat here more. In fact, I'm actually pouting at home right this minute because my husband "does not feel like going there tonight" 

I LOVE everything about this place....super cozy atmosphere, I always love a good wine bar, but when you combine it with good food, then you got a killer spot in my opinion. Pizza's here are amazing, salads here amazing, entrees I've had alll super yummy. Only thing I'm sad about is that they seemed to not have my favorite spinach pizza anymore :(

Oh, did I mention that if you like hotness in your food, please remember to put some spicy chili oil on your pizzas...it's killer! 

If I did not mention enough already, I love this place, and I would urge you to go but I'm afraid that would mean less space for me when I make my way over there again. :) In fact, I think I'm gonna grab my coat and head on over there right now!
author: Susan K.

description: I love neapolitan style pizza and would rate A16 as the best in San Francisco. I can see why it's always crowded and it's well worth the wait.
author: Jack R.

description:
Finally ate here for the first time for lunch.  Had been hearing a lot of hype, so was keeping my expectations in check.  The food WAS delicious (had margherita pizza, meatballs, and beet & potato salad), but the service was a bit awkward.  They served two of our appetizers before they brought out the bottle of wine we ordered (and it felt like the apps were brought out about a minute after placing our order.) Then, following the apps, we waited FOREVER for our entree. The waiter had also taken our bottle of wine away to keep chilled, but was inconsistent in refilling us, so at the end of the meal we still had more than a 1/3 of the bottle left and no time to finish it.

Will go back, but hoping the odd service was a one-time thing.
author: Lynn B.

description:
If you are just craving for pizza, this might not be the best place to kill your hunger.
I happened to be around Chestnut St when looking for a pizza bite and found this place. Nice ambient and service but the pizza wasn't that attractive: very little sauce and toppings, specially when you consider the prices.
My experience with pizza places is that usually these very chi-chi restaurants tend to serve quite boring pizzas. If you share the same opinion, maybe A 16 is just not for you. At least not for pizzas.
author: Camila E.

description: This restaurant was GREAT - we tried the pizza margherita with egg, the pasta maccaronara, the burrata and the pickled beets.  Everything was delicious, and the service was fantastic!  Fun night out in SF!!
author: Andrea D.

description: My first time here and I fell in love with the Buratta!!!  OOOOHHHHH SOOOOOO good!!!  The pizza is also awesome too!  Definitely going back for more!
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Interesting, fun menu. Great wine list with some reasonably priced offerings. Unbeatable location in a very cool part of town. What is there not to like?  We waited about 20 min for a table. We were able to stroll around and they called us on my cell when the table was ready. Great choice for a enjoyable evening. 

We did not have kids with us, but there were many families and they seemed to be haing as much fun as the couples on dates.
author: Stu U.

description: Delicious but a bit too expensive. Order a few smaller dishes to try pizza and pasta!
author: Philipp W.

description: Five stars for atmosphere. Four stars for service. Four stars for food. I thought (for the price) that this place was pretty dang good. Unfortunately, I never made it here when Nate Appleman was running the kitchen so I can't really tell if it's dropped off or not. (My co-diner said that it had.) The duck meatballs were not very good and I really like duck so I wanted to like the dish. The pizza was very nice. The polenta was sublime.
author: Jason Y.

description:
Note: Ate here in May 2010, and raiting is more 3.75 than 4 stars.

Some of the best pizza I have had in a long time.  

If you are in a group of four I would recommend ordering at least 3 pizza's and two appetizers.  

Some of the pizza selections are more rich than others, but you should try as many as possible if presented the opportunity.

It was very loud in the place and service is back and forth.  So if you are expecting like Michelin quality service you are in the wrong place, but if you want a damn good slice of pizze you are in the right spot!
author: naeem a.

description:
Dinner started out with arriving 10 minutes before 5pm. The restaurant opens at 5. There was a line waiting outside to enter. (my opinion, these day's and times , if you are lucky enough to have people waiting to spend their money. I would open the doors 10 minutes early and allow them to purchase a $10.00 glass of wine) I had made reservations so we thought we would have a table to sit at, but were shown the bar area in front of the kitchen to sit for dinner. There were tables available so we said we would like a table, after some discussion we were given a table.
Next came ordering our meal.  I asked our server if I could have the chef make my pasta dish a little spicy, and to my surprise she said no! The chef would not accommodate my request. I then responded with my comment that when going to a less snooty / she she place the chef/cook typically will always fulfill the customers request. I also commented that the chef at A16 was pretentious and could not understand why a simple request could not be made. Next, we placed our order's. Wife and friend had the app portion of pasta while I ordered the dinner size. When the plates were served. I commented that my order must be a mistake and that it was the same size as the small order.  The server's comment was that my pasta is weighed and because it is heavier they cut the portion size down. ???????? We are talkin pasta for god's sake, not Gold!!!!!!! The experience went down hill from there. Save your money and try Perbacco, Tiramisu or anyone of hundreds of other fine italian restaurants in the city.
author: earle s.

description: Def no less than 4 stars. The restaurant itself is really cool and the food did not disappoint. Highly recommend the oven roasted fava beans and proscuitto for appetizers. Maccoronara was pretty good, nothing amazing. Salsiccia pizza was Real good. Great amount of different flavors and the pizza's are a great size. Ya it was a little soggy towards the middle, but the flavor made up for it. Good spot!
author: Thomas D.

description: My friends took me here for my birthday and we had a great time!  The food was pretty delicious (the sunchokes and chard were a stand out for me) but the best part about it was the atmosphere and the great looking crowd!  The only thing I wasn't thrilled about was that the salumi plate came with tongue and head without any warning - I wouldn't have ordered that if I had know.
author: Katherine K.

description: Came to this place because it was across the street from the movie theatre on Chestnut Street. We weren't staying for very long, so we ordered one mushroom pizza, which was absolutely delicious, and two glasses of wine. The server recommended an Italian I had never had which accompanied the pie very well. The server seemed like someone I would want to be friends with. Very warm and knowledgable. Definitely will come back here to have a full course meal.
author: Ryan C.

description: A little loud upfront for a date, but the back room was great and the food / wine were outstanding.
author: Robin B.

description: Once cutting edge offerings, now pedestrian. Noisy,with indifferent and rushed staff. Good, but pricey wine list. Frisco has better alternatives now.
author: Roy F.

description:
One of our top 5 places to go in SF.  The pizza can be a little inconsistent, but it always at least really good and when it's on, it's really amazing.  The maconara pasta has incredible consistency and is like the pasta you get in Italy.  To me, the chocolate tart with balsamic and sea salt is the best dessert dish in SF.

Place is loud and a bit frantic, but it's always fun.  Always had good service.
author: Pete's Za Z.

description:
Often very good pizza, but inconsistent (depending on pizza maker)
This is a common problem for neapolitan pizza- the devil is in the details and there are a ton of variables.
It requires a lot of experience to get it right consistently.
author: jeff k.

description:
Is this a good restaurant?  I can't tell anymore.  I've been here several times with long intervals between visits and each time I return I feel disappointed.  

I had dinner there last week, and although we were seated quickly, we were mostly ignored by the servers and staff.  This was particularly noticeable as we were at one of the small tables between the bar and the main dining area (all the staff has to walk by to get to the kitchen and bar).  

The appetizers were good, but our entrees were bland.  The pasta with crab was especially disappointing.  One item of note is that the portions were large.   Usually I complain about small portions, but this is one case where I'd rather have a small plate of good food.

It will be a long time before I go back.
author: T H.

description:
Had a fabulous meal at A16 on a Saturday night.  The bar area was ridiculously crowded and we had to wait 15 mins past our 8:30 reservation.  Once we sat down, all was good.

We ordered the burrata, funghi pizza w/ egg, and the tonnarelli.  All were excellent.  I would highly recommend adding the egg to your pie.  Beware of the chili oil - it was tasty but I'm going to be hurtin' tomorrow.  The burrata was light and satisfying.  The tonnarelli was cooked to al dente perfection and the beans were unbelievably creamy.  No room for dessert for us.

We don't know anything about wine so we asked our server for a carafe recommendation.  She brought us a sangiovese that was perfect.  

It's definitely a scene here but it didn't get in the way of our dinner.  We've been here a few times before and it was a 4 star experience then but the food was hitting on all cylinders tonight.
author: Ben K.

description:
This is the first review that I have ever written, first off.

Usually I do not see the point  in (or atleast have time too) writing a review on a place unless it was really good or really bad.

Mine is the latter.  As I have noticed in other reviews, I believe that there should be one more classification to warn people not to try a place, and this is the place!

My fiance was taken in by the decor and the lively atmosphere (I refuse to apply the word "ambiance" to A16!), so we figured that there was a reason for all the people and since it is a restaurant . . . well.

after a drink, we were sat.  The wine was good.

We shared one of the salads, and it was totally unremarkable!  It looked good, and the discription in the menu sounded good, but IT was not!

For dinner, I decided on the lamb.  It was three small portions of lamb which did not add up to more than an appetizer with an arugulla (please forgive my Midwest/Engineer Spelling) salad in the middle.  Well, the pieces of lamb were marinaded in a quite pungent concoction (SP?).  Three different pungent concoctions for, what I believe to be, several weeks!

My fiance had the macaroni in tomato sauce (not really the name but . . .).  It reminded me of my childhood when my mom was to busy and served us just that.  I really shouldn't talk about my mother that way!

For the side we shared the abbreviated corn cobs, which was very deliteful!

That's it.  The wine (which we all can buy for much less) and the abbreviated corn cobs.

All this for $90.00!
author: David M.

description: One last update. My friends and I went back and had a great experience. Our waiter Nico was fabulous. The sommelier and hostess were incredibly sweet and helpful. The food was delicious and we had a really wonderful evening. Thank you for inviting us back A 16!
author: Stacy R.

description: A16 is part of a growing list of restaurants that have great food,  good (or great, but this time just good) service,and yet...  As good as it all was, and even with the relaxed/negligent service I just don't think it was worth the money.  And it cost $200 for two people to have a great dinner with a bottle of wine here.  When I hit the +$175 range I need to really feel the value for the money, and I didn't.  The best example I know of a restaurant in that price range is Acquerello. A16 kept me waiting 15 minutes for my reservation. Not a big deal except in that price range. A16's service was slow at the beginning of the evening. Partially sloppy service is not always a big deal...except in that price range. So liked the food, but won't be back.
author: J.D. W.

description:
I love the atmosphere at A16 - lively, cozy, convivial .. we took a seat at the bar rather than wait 45 minutes for a table and it was a very comfortable environment. The bartender was extremely friendly and knowledgable of the wine menu.

Most of the food was great! We started with a random choice for an appetizer - pig ears! (My dog likes pig ear treats ... the can't be that bad right!?)  It was a bold move - one that didnt really pan out. The texture of the pig ears were ... um ... tendon-like ... not a ton of taste .. just kinda tasted like cartlidge w a dash of olive oil and sea salt. 

For entrees we got one of their pizzas which was delicious - added proscuitto which made it amazing. We also had a half order of the gnocchi - absolute perfection.

I will definitely go back, avoid the cartlilidge, and may even give it 5 stars next time.
author: Jana M.

description:
fun spot, trendy, almost annoying-ly because you do wait for a while, but its great if your planning on spending a lot of time catching up with someone over a very yummy meal. 

homemade pumpkin gnocchi with kale...to die

pizza was light, wonderful and huge so its great to split

waiters were cute

wine was pricey, but they have a great selection, even from Abruzzo where my family resides, so you know, i had to go and be patriotic

it was fun and definitely delicious but i wouldn't go here on a regular basis, too trendy and hectic
author: Tina D.

description: This is one of my favorite places in all of SF. First, the food is top notch and consistent.  It's a once a week spot and I've never had an off meal.  The wine list is interesting and spectacular. The best way to order (unless you are big time wine geek) is give a description and try the adventure in a glass.  Service is always nice, warm, and efficient.  You can see why it's a neighborhood favorite and a destination spot.  Funghi pizza #1!
author: Len W.

description:
Reason for 3 stars: service, not just our server, but in total. 
The FOOD was 4 or 41/2 stars. 


When we walked in 10minutes before our reservation time, the host told us she could not find our name and tried to kick us out. When we glanced at the micros screen, our name was at the 8:30 mark instead of the 8:00. Wtf?  She could have easily scrolled down to check our name! And why 30 minutes later? No Idea. We told her who we had made the reservation with, and she said that there was no "Kelly" that worked there. I don't understand what happened. 

Anyways, we were shown to our table 30min later.

The interior is beautiful. I love the layout of the restaurant, except that they cramp too many tables in there. 

Busy busy night. I understand, but someone should at least have greeted us in the first 15minues. Server OR Manager. Teamwork people!!

We had decided on every dish by the time the server had come to the table. She was very sweet, but swamped with all the other tables in her section. We only saw her about 3 times during our 21/2 hour meal. 

The food was delicious. 
We ordered:

Escarole salad-nice portion, great starter to share. Only complaint. This item came LAST. Its a starter! please bring it first!
Funghi Pizza- yummy yummy. Maybe more mushrooms, or a few more varieties of mushrooms? 
Squid ink cavatelli- delish, but not as flavorful as I had expected.
Cod and clam entree- good, but not great. For the price, the size was minimal. 
Special sausage entree. Very flavorful and meaty. But again, that was not an entree portion. 

The runner who brought our food was obviously in a hurry. He slammed a few dishes down, didn't explain the dishes, and didn't take our empty plates away.

All our food came almost simultaneously.  Not enough space! 
I really wished the server or expediter had coursed or timed our dishes out more, so we could start with the salad and end w/ the entree but not get EVERYTHING at once.  

We ordered a bottle of the prosecco in the beginning, thinking that we would finish by the time the entrees came, but they were so slow in taking the bev. order and then too fast in bringing the entree that it wasn't as enjoyable as it should have been. 

For our entrees, we tried to order a bottle of the montepulciano d abruzzo, but the manager? lady brought out a different bottle.
She showed me the bottle without explanation first, and when I asked why it wasn't  what I had ordered, she explained the situation.  I enjoyed the wine, but I wasn't happy with the way she handled the situation. 

I would have loved to speak to the server first about the change, so I might look at the wine list and see if there was a different option that I could choose from.  Also an explanation and apology FIRST would have been nice.

For dessert, we had the chocolate pepper? and the caramel ice cream. Also the Caramel custard.

The chocolate pepper was interesting but very intense, but too much pepper. I had to chug some water after a bite. 

Two bottles of wine, five dishes plus dessert for 5 people, the $200 bill was a great price.  

I would go back for the delicious food, but I'd look for improvement on staffing and a little change in attitude.
author: Sam P.

description:
I wasn't blown away by A 16 having eaten the day before at Pizzeria Delfina.  I've heard some mixed reviews but ultimately don't think that A 16 is that special.  We ordered a lot of items to share so we had a good portion of the menu.  The thing I most enjoyed was that they butcher and make everything in house.  We had a close up view of one of the butchers chopping into a pig's head.  Good stuff. 
Meatballs were the best item of the day if not a bit salty.  The red sauce was good, bright and fresh. 
Sausage was pretty expensive at $18 for 2 medium sized rounds.  The sausage needed some more punch, it lacked something even after squeezing a nice helping of lemon.
Salami plate was interesting.  They gave us some salami, proscuitto, pate and head cheese.  I assume everything was made in house.  It was enjoyable but nothing that memorable which was a shame given all of the effort they put into making their own cured meats.
The pizzas were a bit of a disappointment considering this is what they are known for.  All of the pizzas were a bit soggy and didn't have the same crunch/texture you'd expect from a wood burning oven.  My guess is that either the temperature was not high enough or our pizzas were sitting out for a few minutes.  Compared to Delfina these pies were not in the same class.  The margherita was the best of them all because of the good red sauce and nice amount of fresh basil.  The mushroom pizza has an overwhelming earthy woody flavor from the mushrooms.  I think it was over powering all of the other ingredients and disappointing.  The bianca pizza which had proscuitto added was generally just ok.  I wasn't able to discern the flavors of the different cheeses.  The chili oil is super hot and delicious.  I overdid the chili oil to try and compensate for some of the missing elements I usually love in pizza.  Oh well.
author: Jerrold S.

description: Believe the hype! I had a memorable birthday meal here a few weeks ago. It consisted of the following fatty things: pork terrine, burrata, squid ink pasta, pizza with riccotta/asparagus/prosciutto/egg, porchetta with pork ribs and polenta, chocolate budino with sea salt and olive oil, and a grapefruit gelatina with mascarpone and prosecco granita--OH MY! Although the waitress broke a beer glass on our table and forgot to put the egg on my pizza, I had a fabulous time! Since I don't know much about wine but still wanted to try something, she asked me what i normally like to drink (riesling) and she found something really light and fantastic. The waitress was so nice and the food was so good that I didn't mind anything at all for the rest of the evening. On top of that, I didn't think the prices were too bad. I will definitely be back.
author: Tin-Tin E.

description:
Desert here sucks except for the panna cotta (which is small, but excellent!) .I didnt try the pizza.. The salt budino tart was so poorly prepared, I had it sent back. I even had my wine sent back because I felt it was from an old bottle. I didn't even bother to try anything but an appetizer. It is way too costly, and poorly prepared. This is too busy of a Italian Joint to prepare good food. 

We spent like 40 bucks for a few pieces of bread and poorly created dessert
author: A N.

description: I had been to A16 several years ago when in San Francisco so wanted to take my husband there this time.  We had a great time at the chef's counter and enjoyed watching all the food preparation and had a great meal.  I would recommend this restaurant to anyone!
author: Mary H.

description:
Good pizza.  I like pizzeria delfina better.  But it was good.  So hard to get into that I don't go there very often (not to mention the location is out of my way and also, annoying).

I only had pizza and apps, no entrees!
author: Emily d.

description:
Food: Simply delicious - pizza, pastas, salumi, oh my. Sides can be disappointing - avoid the swamp-like chard.

Mood: Busy, but inviting. Reservations are hard to get. Bar area gets very crowded. Noisy. But lighting and lush-colored interior makes the space comforting. Just don't sit at the high tables near the front - they're not.

Loot: Reasonable...for what it is. Pastas and pizzas are good value. 

Staff: Friendly and attentive. Sommelier and bar folks are top notch.

Bonus: Suspense. A woman waiting for a table burst into flames when we were there last...literally. She was standing too close to some candles and her coat lit up. A Superman ran in from the streets, having spied her through the window, tore off her coat and stomped out the fire. There was screaming. The hostesses never did move those candles. So we blew them out.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Amazing wine list I must say. Blew my mind. 

Now, the food was great but not amazing. Perhaps it was the hour I went, I was the last table sat and the very patient kitchen staff had started packing up the kitchen when I placed my order. 

The pizza was not to be messed with. I thought it was one of the best I had here in San Francisco. With that said, not one of the best I've had all around.  My girlfriends had the squid ink pasta with clams which was delicious but the tuna, on the other hand, lacked excitement on the palate. 

Another highlight! The octopus salad was fresh-tasting and had a clean finish. I'm a fan. A true fan.
author: Catsu H.

description:
Great wine selection, happening hip spot, read many reviews before I came here.  
Went for their Meatball Mondays.  Sitting at the bar watching those in action, and watching what went around me this seemed to me like it was going to be fabulous!  

My other reviews i state that I really appreciate the simplicity with food and ingredients, as long as the flavors are present.  Here they are not.  A16 concentrates on a particular region of Italy, its light and simple dishes just didnt cut it.  However, the housemade sausage was well....nice, portions were tiny and prices high and those in the kitchen didn't seem very excited to be working. Ricotta gnocci in a light broth with small niblets of housemade sausage, roasted vegetables as a side, 3 tiny meatballs in a very bland marinara I left thinking..."whats with the hype"
Complaint: its an overrated Marina spot.  Simple food, nothing seemed too overwhelming or caught my attention.  I'll go again and try their pizza...which looked like naan.  Hey I'm all about second chances.
author: Tina d.

description:
Ok, let me start from here:
I was raised eating Italian food because my father is native Italian.  I've also lived in Italy twice, once in the north and once in the south, for extended periods of time. I rarely agree to eat out at an Italian restaurant because too often the food is not authentic (and more often than not, tastes as though it came out of a can) and therefore, very disappointing. Most restaurants slap high prices onto their meals just because they can, but rarely does it mean it's good.

Last night I went to A16 rather hesitantly and left happier than I've ever left any restaurant in San Francisco. The food was incredible and just about everything I ordered was just how I remembered it while abroad. 
I highly recommend the Burrata cheese with some salame or prosciutto to start. The pasta was simple but perfectly made and the entrees, though I don't know where the recipes originate from, were absolutely mouthwatering delicious.
On top of that, the service was outstanding. Ryan was our waiter and topped off the night with his wit and charm.

I would recommend this place to anyone looking for a hearty, delicious meal -- if you can afford it!
author: audrey b.

description:
What?  Can you say that louder?

This was how A16 went the other night.  A group of 10 of us, and the only person you could talk to was the person sitting to your side.  The person across the table was too far away BECAUSE THE PLACE IS SO LOUD (that was me screaming)!!

Food was really good though.  I got the pork chop and I thought it was one of the better ones I've had.  Service was mediocre, and brings it down a star.  Wine list was average.

Decent place, I just wish it was a little quieter and that the service was better.
author: Full S.

description: Good. But not worth the hype. Better quality when it opened initially. Good pizza but hit or miss. Sometimes comes out soggy or burnt. Nice wine selection fun to try things you would never think of. Watch out for the corkage fee 30 or 35 is a lot to go with a pie and some tripe! Fun as long as no one sees you on Chestnut. :)
author: Tom W.

description: Go on Monday meatball night, They are soft little pillows of wonderful meaty goodness in a nice tomato sauce -and their pizzas are wonderfullt authentic by a pizza master!
author: Gina G.

description: A16 is one of my favorite San Francisco restaurants. A16 has an amazing neighborhood feel and is a place with great energy. I have had my fair share of "okay" dinners here but have had some amazing ones that keep me coming back. It is 3 blocks from my apartment and I find that the prices are very reasonable for a nice San Francisco dinner. We tend to stick to very moderate priced wines that the sommelier has recommended and that keeps the bill very reasonable. My favorite appetizer is the mozzerella burrata- it is amazing! You also can't go wrong with the margherita pizza! Always a winner!
author: Kimberly M.

description: Very friendly staff, especially the chef prepping the tripe that night.  The cuisine, while being slightly inventive... Just didn't do it for me.  Had the bruchetta, tripe special, gnocci, some sort of black pasta (yes, it takes a lot for me to forget a dish... And I forgot what was in this one)... And something else... Tripe and gnocci are recommended.  Great ambiance and misleading street face... This place is actually pretty large!
author: Shannon S.

description: This is my fiance and I's go to restaurant!  Simply the best food/wine and atmosphere in SF. Although we live a couple blocks away I would still travel far and wide to eat here. Not to mention the staff is incredible!  I have to say Benito has served me some of the best Italian wine I have ever had!!  LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this spot!.
author: Courtney B.

description: great ambiance - classy, romantic, excellent service. great wine selection. food was a little too earthy for my taste.
author: Sam C.

description:
I am only rating the pizza, but it is absolutely delicious. Sit at the pizza counter and order the Capriciosa; we've found that it is always worth the risk--the chef decides what she wants to give you and you try something new. Watching the cooking process is fun, and the chef is good at what she does.

Reservations usually need to be made well in advance, but I've found it more fun to walk in and sit at the pizza counter (it's usually a 15-30 minute wait, so if you time it right you can get a nice walk). It's a slightly stuffy crowd, but if you focus on the food it's a great experience.
author: Mark T.

description:
I was born and raised in Italy, have eaten at A16 more times than I can count on my fingers, and have sent many out of town visitors and friends there without hesitation. It has been at the top of my SF restaurant favorites since it opened. I had a great meal there in August 2008 (with two visitors from Italy), and then went back last night after a two-year hiatus. 

Sadly, last night's meal was less than stellar. The calamari panzanella was the best thing we had. All else was a disappointment: the beloved, usually infallible burrata tasted like it was one day past its prime, the fish was bland, the pork zampone was heavy and mediocre in flavor, and the romaine and chicory salad was crazy salty. I thought that perhaps they were just having a bad night so I decided  to console myself with the best dessert ever, the chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil, but to my horror this dessert is no longer what it used to be. The former hazelnut-infused chocolate awesomeness drizzled with olive oil is now an overly crispy tart (without hazelnuts) topped with a lump of less than remarkable chocolate pudding. The salt and olive oil seemed to be in, rather than on top of, the tart, so the flavors were overly blended, rather than ready to blend on the palate. Oh, and the wines were more expensive and less unique than they used to be. Shelley Lindgren, whose passion and knowledge for Italian wines was always infectious, was not there and was greatly missed. The food was overall less authentic in flavor than it used to be.  

I hope that last night's meal was an exception, so I'll be back again, but I need to have another great meal there before I can recommend it again.
author: Viola T.

description:
Only one visit to this restaurant, motivated by a promo coupon that a friend sent me. This restaurant isn't bad, and it isn't super-good, either. It's uneven. I ate the bruschetta with roast squash and ricotta (excellent), and the salsiccia pizza (very good). For dessert I ordered a scoop of the persimmon sorbet and the fig marsala gelato. The persimmon sorbet was sweet but flavorless (where's the persimmon?), and the fig marsala gelato tasted cinnamon-y, no hint at all of fig or marsala. Since cinnamon gelato was the third gelato available that day--the flavor I DIDN'T order--I queried the wait staff. The waiter shrugged & said the pastry chef scooped it out herself, so there couldn't be any mistake, unless it had been mislabelled. Then the waiter removed the dessert plate with the half-eaten ice creams on it, and that was that. At $3 a scoop for fancy frozen dessert, I would expect better quality, and frankly, a little more concern. 

Which brings me to the service. Like the food, it was uneven. At least 4 different servers showed up at my table at various intervals to do this and that. There was a long wait for the bruschetta starter and nobody bothered to talk to me about the delay (although when the starter finally came the wait staff apologized). Ironically, when you're served by that many wait staff, you don't feel like you're being waited on at all. I was there for lunch, the restaurant was about half-full, and I was dining alone. I can't say that any of these factors may have made a difference. But I've had a much better experience dining alone for lunch or dinner in other restaurants.
author: Liz B.

description:
A16 is our go to provincial Italian joint in SF. 

After going here since it's opened, I'm still happy to report that this is one of my favorites.  I can't understand the wine list, but they always help select delicious and reasonably priced wines (or not if you prefer).  Don't be fooled by the great pizza's, definitely order an entree from the grill.  You won't be disappointed.  Still a great spot that has stood the test of time.
author: R D.

description:
hmmmmm let's just say I had not such a great day and did a little mini stroll to a16 not knowing anything about it, I felt like this restaurant should have belonged in a quaint alley way in England :) 
-very beautiful-

The receptionist was magnificently breathtakingly beautiful and of course nice had given me the option to either sit at the bar top or dine at a table. I of course choose the bar top, and with a nice glass of wine since I felt rude ordering anything else but wine at a wine based restaurant I chose a nice Riesling since I love the sweeter side and order myself a pizza. I know a pizza but damn it was good. And I am a type of person that loves a good wood fire pizza. The service was amazing, and the bill wasn't too painful either. 

Next time I go I will be in a better mood and I'll order maybe a little bit from every each portion of the menu, and maybe see what the famous popular chef has to offer me :)
author: Nina M.

description:
I took my boyfriend here for his birthday. Food was really good and our server was great. She paired up every course with a wine and she was very attentive.

My only complaint would be that we were seated at a small table for two and were so close to the people sitting next to us I could join their conversation.
author: K j.

description:
For my first review on Yelp, I'm reviewing the famed A 16 -- a place that more or less accurately represents some of the better (some might say 'standard') aspects of "upper mid-range" (or is it "lower upper-range") San Franciso dining. 

The equation for this sort of SF establishment (at least, as I understand it) is: delightful atmosphere + overall good New American or Cal-Ital or  Asian Fusion or Italian food (with two-to-four outstanding dishes) + entrees priced in the twenties + a good wine list. If that's the left side of the equation, then A 16 could very much be on the latter side of the equals sign.

A 16 -- located on Chestnut Street in the Marina District -- features Italian food from the Campania region. The menu includes several solid appetizers, a nice selection of pizzas, pastas, and a small collection of entrees. 

Mozzarella burrata with olive oil appetizer was solid, but not spectacular.  Ricotta gnocchi was enjoyable, with a nice and balanced taste of basil. The Bianca pizza was a highlight. The crust out of the wood-fired oven was crisp, but not too crisp -- just right, in fact. Gelato for desert provided a nice finish, with 2 flavors for $6. Overall, dinner is quite solid, but not of the highest-rank. (Food only: 4/5).

As others have noted, the wine selection is strong and interesting. Appealing ambiance, and the lighting is well-executed. Our most recent server was direct, efficient; not exactly 'warm,' but I had no doubt in her ability to get things done. Service is general seems fine. 

This is a place than any SF diner will eventually make her or his way to (if only because of the buzz inertia that A 16 still has from its well-received opening several years ago). The food is unlikely to disappoint, and the prices are reasonable for a restaurant with this much attention. Overall, A 16 really is a good example of this sort of SF dining -- a place that out-of-towners might think to be a rare gem, while you in fact know that it's one of many truly strong restaurants.
author: Matti L.

description:
Had been looking forward to trying out this place for awhile.  Been there, done that, don't need to go back.  We battled Friday night traffic to get into the city and head to the Marina.  I dock points from places that are difficult to get to, park near, and don't have valet.

It might be a good neighborhood spot if you are fortunate enough to live in the area.  But the highlight of my meal was the burrata mozzarella (that they purchase).  The pastas left much to be desired.  Had the gramigna nera and maccaronara with tomato ragu.  The former was served with beans.  I did not enjoy the contrasting texture of dense and chewy with soft and mushy in the same bite; so like a kid, I picked out the beans.  I liked the flavors of the squid ink pasta and it had an al dente texture, but the presentation was kind of funky (2" long black thick strands and brown beans).  The ragu one was just way off - neither liked the texture (not as firm as the other) nor the taste (ragu was lacking in flavor).

With that said, Husband enjoyed every one of his courses.  But even he agreed that it was not worth the effort to get there.
author: Manic Beagle M.

description: Great margherita pizza, but I didn't give them more stars because it tends to get soggy in the center. It's an art to make these pizza's that are super thin, but still crispy, and half the time I don't get that here.
author: Kelly L.

description:
Cons: service wasn't what we expected based on some of the previous reviews we read.  our waitress was taking care of the other tables around us and we sort of got left out - everyone around us got their wine in a timely manner but we didn't get ours until our second course.  We also didn't get the house-made chili oil for dipping/drizzling that our waitress offered and raved to us about it.  Overall, the food was ok but next time we want great pizza and wine, we'll head to Delarosa for much better service.  

Pros: vibe was great, we sat towards the back of the restaurant by the brick oven (smelled wonderful!), there was a heated outdoor dining spot that really looked nice, would likely have requested outside seating had we known.
author: N H.

description: Maybe i ordered the wrong dish...ordered pizza which was kind of dumb since pizza is whatever...should have ordered something else; however, doubt I will go back.
author: Cassie L.

description: We weren't seated until thirty minutes past our reservation.  They served us cheese and olives as an apology treat but what they should've done was offer my group complimentary glasses of wine whilst we were waiting.  My friends enjoyed their pizzas.  I ordered the pork chop -- overcooked and flavorless.  Enjoyed the energetic atmosphere, though.
author: S W.

description: 465 reviews for A16? Here's number 466: Reasonably good pizzas, pasta and salads with an inventive Italian-centric wine selection. So what's wrong with A16? It's always crowded, always noisy and the hubris of success and popularity, I think, has gone to their head. It's a small place that feels even smaller once you get a handful of people at the bar. I do like A16 but it's too much of a scene to deal with the crowd, wait and at times rushed service.
author: John B.

description:
What is considered a long time when waiting for a table at a restaurant on a Saturday night? 1 hour....2 hours...3 hours?!? Well, for a hungry petite Asian girl who had been saving her appetite all day to try out A16 for the first time, 2 1/2 hours is a loooong time. Good thing I was with awesome company or I may have lost it.

So on a crazy Saturday night, a friend and I go to A16 after planning and looking forward to it all week. Did the OpenTable thing, did the calling thing--no reservation because they were having a function. Oh well. The restaurant looks small on the outside, but it's actually fairly decent sized--full bar, dining rooms and chef counters. By the way, there were a lot of "cougars" at A16 on this particular Saturday--I thought my friend was going to get devoured before we got a table.

Most of the staff were really nice--one host was a cutie, our server was extremely cool and nice, and one of the other hostesses, I wasn't crazy about--a little snooty, a little attitudey. She's lucky we weren't rude. 

As for the food, there was nothing that we didn't order that wasn't good. We were starving and were going to get a pizza as an appetizer and then separate entrees, but decided to get the arugula salad with nectarines, aged prosciutto, and the Cavatelli pasta as appetizers and then the mixed lamb roast and roasted beef as entrees. Yes, we were definitely hungry. We got a bottle of the 2004 Contesa, Montepulciano to wash everything down and we couldn't have asked for anything better--we finished it off with ease. Now for the dessert. We got a raspberry crostata  and it was really tasty. It was the topping on a very delicious Italian dinner. The raspberry crostata was on a small plate with what looked like vanilla ice cream, but it was ricotta cheese. It was different and kind of threw off our equilibrium--we were expecting ice cream! But it was good. It was like a raspberry/cheese danish but yummier with crunchy carmelized goodness and more expensive than a danish. 

I recommend A16 to anyone. I would definitely go back even if I had to wait. It was definitely worth it, but next time I might just bring a snack with me while I'm waiting...
author: Maureen B.

description:
We went to A16 for my birthday.  Although the food is great, because the service was so terrible, the food was ruined.  We ordered an antipasto, a pizza, a pasta and an entrree.  The antipasto came first..all good.  Then all the other dishes arrived.  The table wasn't big enough to hold the plates.  When we complained, the serve said, "you asked for it that way".  That was a TOTAL LIE.  The manager came over and "apologized" profusely, but still seemed to support the server's side of the story which was just ridiculous.  A competent server, if we had asked for everything at once, would have told us that would be a BIG MISTAKE.

As a result, all food got cold, was just plain ruined.  When I contacted A 16 the next day by email, I was called back by the same manager who said I should just eat at other restaurants!!!

Great way to build clientele.  I will never go back and continue to speak poorly of A16.
author: Harriette U.

description: We LOVE this restaurant for many reasons, not the least of which is their incredible, friendly and efficient staff.  Everyone we encountered was so helpful, and had smiles on their faces in spite of the busy crowd they had to serve.  We started off with the salumi plate and delicious, creamy burrata.  Oh, and the best margherita pizza we've tasted!  The wine list is extensive and the staff very knowledgeable about the different varieties.  Our bottle of white wine was amazing, and a 2nd one followed quickly.  (of course my mind is now blank about which one it was!! guess i'll have to go back for more).  Everyone at our table of  6 ordered a different meal, and no one had a single complaint.  My dish was the pasta with swordfish......heaven!  This isn't a huge restaurant (which is a plus in our book), but they really handle their guests well, and clearly have quite the following.  It's a beautiful spot and the ambiance is very pleasant and comfortable.  Not stuffy!  We sat in the mid section near the huge wine storage -  great location.  We would go back in a second.
author: J H.

description: Ugh. Here are some descriptors: pretentious, sub-par, loud, inauthentic, marina-maxima, sloppy service, WAY over-priced, snooty patooty (and for WHAT? I ask!), annoying to infinity, crappy. Oh, and someone wrote: "Don't bring pretentious NYers here". I would add to that: "Don't bring anyone Italian, or  anyone who knows anyone Italian, or anyone who has ever been to Italy or eaten Italian food" to this restaurant because they are all puffed up over themselves and the food is at best mediocre.  come dire, "molto fumo, poco arrosto".
author: T O.

description: Ah, A16 what happened to you?  Did you slack off based upon your neighborhood appeal?  Did a long reservation list of newcomers change your ability to create a tasty dish?   What's going on?  You & I are 0-3 tonight for the courses I ordered.  First off, the calamari was bland and the pumpkin gnocci was lifeless.  Thank God I brought my own wine until I saw on my bill your corckage was $30!!  Serious?  $30 for corkage?  Fuck me.  Next time at least give me some good food to ease the pain.  I was hesitant to order a main, so my GF & I split a pizza.  Wow, I should have brought some waterslide/miniture golf pizza to compare to what you served me. Watery sauce, overly anchovie'd salty mess.  Arrgh!  Praise the solitary scoop of hazelnut gelato that cleaned my palate.  FYI- head over to Pasta Pomodoro on Union St. or Il Fornaio on Battery for a lesson in great Italian cooking.
author: Informed C.

description:
I know a lot of people seem to love this place but I had a terrible experience some time last year.  We ordered flights of wine and my date and I sat there for fifteen minutes (literally) with no results.  When I asked our server about the wine, she told us the bar was really busy and backed up.  Meanwhile she proceeded to hang out at various tables in her section, not once heading off to check on our drinks.  So after twenty minutes or more we still had nothing but water.  I finally decided to investigate and walked up to where the bar was.  I half expected to see a scene akin to the evacuation of Saigon, with people hanging out of helicopters clutching wine bottles, but the bartender was not even especially busy.  I asked a guy walking by if he worked there and he said yes, he was the manager.  I told him what was up and he immediately got us our wine, and even a little extra taste of something.  

Now this guy rocked, and did kind of make up for the brain dead server, who must have got an earful from him because she then decided to get back at us by ignoring us completely.  Our food was brought by other people and she spent time at every table but ours.  

At one point she was at the next table exuding charm and hospitality, when to be a smart ass I said to her, "oh, everything's great thanks!"  She then turned to me with a confused look and proceeded to try to salvage her tip by kissing our asses.  Really weird shit.  

Then there was the food, which sucked.  All I can remember was the main course, some pork dish that was actually pretty disgusting.  The place was also hot as a sauna, and so loud we couldn't hear each other talk.  All in all, a fantastic dinner.  I do give the manager credit for being helpful and attentive.  I have a feeling this was maybe not a typical experience, but it was bad enough to prevent me from going back to find out.
author: George C.

description:
First off, I had never brought a bottle of wine to a restaurant, so this was going to be a "first".  I called ahead and they confirmed a $25 corkage fee.  What they neglected to mention is that they will:
a. whisk your bottle away to decant it
b. leave you wondering where it is for 15-20 minutes
c. take 1/4-1/3 cup of wine as a "taste" for themselves

Yup, it's true.  I know this because I went to the restroom, and as I walked by, the sommelier was opening our bottle.  By the time I came out and walked by, the bottle had been partially poured into the decanter.  Then, to my horror, the sommelier was chatting it up with two other co-workers and she was swirling a LARGE amount of (my) wine in a glass, urging them to smell it and taste it.  In shock, I slowly walked by and glared at the sommelier.

When the sommelier did come to the table to bring our wine, she said nothing to us.  As in zero words.  No greeting, no 'how was the white wine?' we had ordered while waiting.  Nothing.  After she sloppily poured our glasses, she curtly said, "I'll come by to top off your glasses later" and took off with the decanter.  Okay, fine, no problem, if that's the way they did it, but the odd part was that we were the only ones in the restaurant to NOT have the bottle or decanter at our table... 

To top it off, the food was good, but not great.  The wine glasses had some lint in it, which is especially disappointing for a place that has a 'wine bar'.  

Because of the wine fiasco, the meal was ruined.  True, I take some responsibility in the disastrous experience, in that I was too dismayed to complain right there, on the spot.  So my bad.  But the feelings of distrust and suspicion had already ruined the evening, and complaining to the manager wouldn't have made me feel better.  

P.S. In case you are wondering, we did not bring a crap bottle of wine to piss the sommelier off.
author: M S.

description:
For the most part, I'm a happy little vegan, glad to be living a healthy lifestyle that is in line with my morals, but once in a while I go to a restaurant where the server is just painfully ignorant of what a vegan is and makes it extremely clear to me and whoever I am eating with that I might as well have green skin and little antennas sticking out of my head (ahem Turkish resto in Folsom where the server kept telling me, but there is just a little bit of milk in this, but there is just a little bit of butter in that). Anyway, I was in a bit of a slump before going to A16, and they totally renewed my happy vegan attitude. 

When my friend suggested that we go there, I had hesitations. Trendy Italian restos with home-made pasta (read egg) and lots of fancy cheeses are not usu so vegan friendly, but the server at A16 was an ex-vegan herself, and knew all of the stuff on the menu we could eat (which was a surprisingly long list) and was sensitive even to the pizza dough and pasta egg content question. We ended up getting a beat salad that was pretty good (although the beats could have been a bit fresher, it seemed like they may have sat around a bit), a marinara pizza (this is actually already on the menu woohoo). We added mushrooms ($5!), but they were nice chewy earthy mushrooms. The pizza sauce was sooo good with lots of flavor. They also had one type of pasta that was vegan, and it was fabulous. They were little folded over ear pastas (forgive me, but I forget the name!) with a nice red sauce and white beans (yes we even got protein). They seem to really know their red sauces, which so often end up bland and in need of salt. They even had a vegan dessert (sorbet), but we skipped it, since we were stuffed. 

We also had a really nice wine that was on the cheaper end of the wine menu. It was a Pinot Noir from Copain Winery. It was nice and full of black cherry and blueberry flavors that were light and food friendly. Perfect summer red.

The only thing that bugged me about the experience was the server felt the need to tell me that she was vegan until...dun dun dun... she got pregnant, and everything changed! Personally, I plan to stay vegan for the rest of my life, and believe me it's possible to do so without killing your baby or having them turn green and grow antennae (actually that might be cool). She was very nice, though, and I did appreciate her knowledge of veganism, so overall I'm a happy little vegan camper and can recommend a trip to A16 for other vegan kiddies looking for a nice dinner and willing to brave the Marina.
author: Jeani H.

description:
I am so fed up with the reservation system at A16.  This past Thursday, I tried to make a reservation around 5 pm for 8pm that night for four people.  However, the earliest they had available was 9:30 pm.  They have the front section of tables set up just for walk-ins and the back is for reservations.  

My friends wanted to eat at 8 pm and we were going to meet for drinks at 7 pm.  I figured I would put my name in at A16 and go to Bin38 for a drink while we waited.   The hostess told me that this could not be done and that I would have to wait at the restaurant to put my name down.  I find it so unbelievably obnoxious when restaurants do this - if way trendier places in NYC can do it, A16 should do it.  But the place did not seem too busy so I figured we'd still go to Bin38 for a glass or two of wine and then head over to A16.  

Well, when we got there I put my name down and the hostess told me it should be about 15 minutes.... 50 minutes later (almost 9pm) we were seated.  While waiting, we were forced to stand huddled along the wall and we couldn't face each other to talk.  If you're going to require people to stay at the restaurant  to put a name down, then accommodate! 

We started off with the buratta (my fav), it was delicious as usual.  They had a pork liver brushetta on special and it was just average.  One of my friends is a vegetarian, so we ordered the Margherita and the Bianca.  This was definitely a little too boring for me, but I typically like white pizza so I thought it would be okay. The Bianca had green olives on it but it was still really bland and nothing special. The Margherita was okay, but how hard is it to do that?  I would come back again for the pizza but would have to get something more interesting. 

Also, I still think the wine list is ridiculous.  They need to have more reasonably priced bottles if they're going to serve $15 pizzas.  We only ordered one as a table.  It's unfortunate, b/c I would come more often if I could get a bottle of wine for a bit cheaper.  I'd end up spending the same amount of money but would have 2 bottles instead of one!
author: Katie S.

description:
Made the giant mistake of showing up with a table of four without making a reservation. Put our names on a list, left for an hour, then came back and waited for two and a half hours, in a no-space-to-breathe bar. Finally, we didn't even get a table--we had to sit at the chef's bar.

So make a reservation.

Both the food and the wine are excellent. Try the tripe and the fava beans (roasted whole in their shells in 900 degree oven). The pizza also is very good. Prices are very reasonable.
author: David P.

description:
fantastic service! excellent pizza and wine list.

the front bar area is very crowded and cramped, but the restaurant itself goes on and on. there are several different sections you could be seated in, all different. i personally like sitting at the marble counter towards the back where you can see the chefs and watch the black smoke cloud in the pizza oven. seeing that smoke cloud makes me taste it /complexity of the crust - good!

the friendly staff really stands out, and that includes everyone, chefs, sommelier, wait staff and hosts.
author: Sophia L.

description: My excitement has waned.  I will still recommend the appetizers, but the rest of our food was less than stellar.  The one exception was the Macaronarra pasta.  The dungeness crab pasta was destroyed with the addition of a gritty fava bean sauce.  Why oh why do that to such sweet crab?  Not only but also, the waitress was obviously told to push some heavy sicilian red wine with our delicate crab pasta.  We were on to them.
author: Amme P.

description: Wow, I just had a bad meal at A16. I have not been here in a few years and it used to be great. Now, I feel slightly ill from eating overly salty pizza, bland pasta and flavorless appetizers. I am not some angry yelp'er who wants to post a bad review but really, the food was bad, the place was loud and the service was lack luster. Is it the new chef? Is it the over-popularity in the neighborhood, is it the hype? Who knows. All I know is that it is hard to make bad pizza.
author: Janell H.

description: Still good but has lost its edge.  Or perhaps we are Now so used to thin crust pizza that the thrill has passed?  Still very good. Very noisy though and tables crammed together so not much privacy. Dining room  can get quite warm due to pizza oven     Burrata to die for. Friendly service.  Yummy desserts. Great location !!
author: Henry H.

description:
I like it, I like it, I LIKE IT!!
 
Off the bat, let me say that A16 is not a 5-star kind of place.  It's just not.  The bar is really cool, and the seating is also quite nice - - the ambience is all good, and so forth, but this is just not Acquerello, French Laundry, etc. type of 5-stars.
 
Life took a strange turn one weekend - - and I was trying to get back on my feet from that blow.  Sh*t happens, and when it does, you either get back up or you stay down.  I always get back up - - but good food and lots of alcohol always helps.
So, I get taken to A16..... for dinner.  It's to cheer me up.... or perhaps it was bribery.  I don't know.
 
Parking is seriously an issue here!!!!!!!!!!!!  Meters are crazy expensive, too, or so I am  told.  I was dropped off at the restaurant but ended up waiting on my own for a good 20 minutes while the car was parked.
 
First - - let's just touch on the service.  Service here is sketchy.  It's not horrible, nowhere near that.  But it's not great - - nowhere near that either.
