It's hit or miss, and then kind of mediocre even when it hits.  The hostesses.... I'm not sure if they were just bimbos or if they were unfriendly - - but it seemed that they either took 4 minutes to register one sentence, or just didn't care to react to whatever was being said.  Was it that they assmed I was speaking in a foreign language?  Can they not hear me, though I can hear them?  Anyone home?  Helloooo--oooo?  (insert echo) 
Now I don't expect much from a hostess - - I expect efficiency, and a smile.  Neither is offered here.  Hmm.  OK....
But once we got seated (after a 30 minute wait or so, which is great, considering it was a full house and we did not have reservations), the waitstaff was better.  Our guy was nice enough - not very quick on the uptake or very attentive, but really nice enough and if asked twice, he got everything done.  Our busboy was better, actually.  And the sommelier we got - - she was friendlier, but I am not so certain regarding how good of a sommelier she is.  Perhaps I know too many people who know good wine...
 
Now, the food.
Well - - I have to say that THE OCTOPUS AND ARUGULA SALAD SERVED HERE IS THE BEST IN THE WHOLE WIDE WORLD.  Wow.  Amazing.  Now I tend to order this alot at various places - - and the closest to this that I ever got was Acquerello in SF, which was also terrific, but even they could not hold a candle to how good this was at A16.  DELICIOUS.  5 stars!
We also had their house-made fresh Mozzarella with the works - -  super fresh ingredients with outstanding tomatoes..... I loved it, especially with the wine we had. 4.5 stars!
They are well-known for their pizzas so we had to try that, too.  So we ordered the Funghi pizza - - mushrooms, mozzarella, etc.  REALLY GOOD, strong 4-stars.  I recommend this particular pizza... and this means alot as I am not big on pizza, at all.
Lastly - - the main entree.
After much thought - we settled on the halibut based on our not particularly craving meat that night - AND the server's recommendation.  This was pretty bad.  Bad, bland, boring.  I could boil a halibut to be tastier than this.  I mean, halibut is not a hard fish to cook - meaty, with enough fat in it, and tasty on its own.  It's hard to go wrong and yet, they somehow did.  REAL disappointment.  1 star.
 
So.... combining the mediocre service with the awful halibut to the outstanding appetizers and pizza - - - I settle on a good 4 stars for A16.


FYI - this restaurant gets WARM.  At some point, it felt like a steam room.  Full house, no ventllation and bottles of wine  - - -not a good thing.  Dress in layers.... and be ready to peel them off one by one!

***********************

Edit on 6/6/08 to add:
Bartenders here are terrific.
And try the salumi samplers -  some head cheese type of meat, pork belly concoctions, excellent prosciutto, etc.  Their homemade burrata cheese was quite good, too, but I'd prefer it unheated.
Also had the pizza.... great crust, quite tasty.  At A16, I suggest you skip any and all entrees - - just pig out on appetizers and their pasta.  Their basic ragu sauce with homemade THICK pasta noodles was nothing short of EXCELLENT.
author: Grace K.

description: I went for the pizza and was very satisfied, but I was blown away by the grilled fava bean starter.   Who knew you could eat the whole bean, pod and all?  Such a revelation.  Life changing. Life affirming.
author: L W.

description: A+ everything!  My fiance took me to A-16 for my birthday this year, and boy was it a birthday meal.  The service was phenomenal, and the food?  To die for delicious!  We were there for Meatball Monday and just had to get the pasta along with it.  INCREDIBLE!  Oh yeah, and their pizzas are delicious too!  I've been admiring this place for the last year, and am so glad we finally had a chance to enjoy it!  We will definitely be back!
author: Katherine L.

description:
Always great!  This is one of our favorite Italien restaurants in the neighborhood.  I love the squid ink pasta and the pizzas.  The service is usually excellent as well.  Be sure and make reservations, as this place is packed even on Tuesdays!

I wish I could leave 1/2 stars as I would give this place a 4 and 1/2.
author: Debbie M.

description: Warm. Cozy. Delicious. Great selection of Italian wines which is hard to find in this town. Fantastic selection of Italian staples like pizza margherita with some surprise dishes from the southern Italy featuring sardines and cauliflower.  As I sat at the chef's table last night I wondered why I don't make this place one of my regular spots and planned what I was going to have on my next visit.  The staff is very friendly and responsive even though the place is packed pretty much every night.
author: Angela N.

description: One of my favorite places to dine in my neighborhood, especially with their service and wine selection.  Our server recommended what was easily one of the best red dessert wines I've ever tasted, after I inquired about a dessert wine that wasn't cloyingly sweet.  Haunted by the wine's flavor and impression, I returned a week later to buy a bottle, only to discover that it had been their last bottle with little possibility of acquiring more.  I'd name the grape and vintage, but it's apparently rare and I'd prefer to do without the competition.  Simply excellent.
author: Pipoca C.

description: Decided to dine here prior to our drinking rampage in the Marina.  First off, pleasantly surprised by the meat market selection, and I'm not talking about the prosciutto or the beef ribs if you know what I am saying.  Anyways for a week night in the Marina, it's a hopping place.  We only tried the pizzas, but they were quite filling and delicous and definitely some of the best that I have had in the city.  My only complaint with the restaraunt is the wine list.  The good thing about it is that there is a lot of variety for every price point; however we were dependent on the server to translate the options and we relied on her reccommendations, which were good.  I mean I am sure I am not the only person to come here who is not knowledgable about Italian wines so that's my beef.  If you want to dine, I would reccommend making a reservation unless you are lucky all the time.
author: Amy Z.

description:
I've been twice before they changed chefs. Memorable and very good THOSE times. This time, not so much. Big mistake loosing that previous chef. Coincidentally, I was SPQR last week and that was even more noticeably different. 

The new chef, I'm sure good in their own way, just doesn't hold up compared to the previous. Not bold, very bland and common flavors, nothing stood out. 

The Burrata was good, but over salted. The Sardines should have been a little more cooked, a little crunch, and accompanied with a different textured bread and spread, the cod flavors were very mismatched, and the pasta with squash blossoms was buried in heavy cream flavors completely unnecessary to the the dish.

Not sure if you're trying too hard, but something is off. Maybe try simpler. Likes beach walk grill in a small town. In Italy. Not New York.
author: Michelle M.

description: If you are a Yuppie and you drink, this is your place. If you were Asian and a first timer, beware. After we had our entrees, we noticed the newly seated people had bread on the table quite immediately. We felt a bit cheated. Italian restaurant without bread and olive oil must not be an Italian restaurant. We asked the wait staff and they said that they didn't get their bread delivered and people only got bread if they asked. I must have missed that sign. They made up for it with complimentary 5 cookies at the end. Thank you. The dimly lit backroom was very romantic, but for the vision impaired, you can't read the darn menu. The small and large pasta portion: small means a handful of macaronara ragu pasta is like a hand full of noodles. Come with a full stomach. The chocolate tart with sea salt and olive oil: loved the chocolate mousse on top, but the tart was really dry. The Margherita pizza was soggy after 1/2 hour, so eat fast. This is not a place for wheelchairs or a bit robust person. The waitress was nice, but she over poured the water and I realized water was dripping from my glass.
author: Helen L.

description: We ordered the Bucatini pasta and the Funghi pizza. For dessert, we had a light cake covered with creme anglaise (Coffee and hazelnut zuppa inglese a la napoletana) which, I'm sad to say, was the best part of the meal.  The place was packed for a Wed night and there were lots of people waiting to get seated so I was glad I had reservations. The decor is modern and simple and the ambiance somewhat romantic, although quite noisy. I'm not a huge fan of italian cuisine but I think I've had better elsewhere.
author: Trinh T.

description: Four stars alone for the burrata -- which, if you didn't know, is soft, oozy fresh buffalo milk mozzarella stuffed with cream.  Here it's sprinkled with salt, pepper, a touch of olive oil, and served with some crostini for spreading.  Fan-diddly-tastic.
author: Nat K.

description: We really love A16.  Ever since it opened we've been coming here to sit at the bar and enjoy the ambience over great pizza/pasta and good wine.  The bar staff are very friendly and knowledgeable with the food and wine suggestions.  Also fun is the 'chefs counter' in the rear of the restaurant which is much easier to get a reservation especially if you are booking fairly close in advance.  Nice to be able to have a great meal/wine and get in and out for under $120!
author: eva j.

description:
I am glad this place exists, because if it didn't I would have to feign illness every time one of my friends wanted to do dinner in the Marina.  

Yes, A16 is the only real restaurant in the Marina - as in, it offers menu choices not geared toward base frat boy palates (wait, do frat boys even have palates?).   Sure, you can get a margherita pizza (and an excellent, blistered-crust one at that).  But there are also things like housemade buffalo sausage.  And interesting appetizers, the best section of the menu.   And the quality of ingredients is high, and they stick to their Southern Italy schtick quite nicely, as opposed to throwing whatever vaguely Italian trendy food item of the moment on the menu.  They do concede to trendiness in the form of burrata, which people love (and rightly so, because it is delicious) but which totally pisses me off.  Why?  Because I used to buy an entire tub of the EXACT same cheese that A16 flies up from Long Beach at Bristol Farms in LA, and it cost $10 and was fresher.  A16 charges that much for a wimpy sliver!  (gnashing teeth in fury...).

Regardless, because the goodness of A16 is no secret, reservations are a pain.  Solution: go on an off night or early weekend and grab a seat at the bar.  Then you can have cute Kevin the bartender take you the otherwise confusing wine list (who's ever heard of, let alone tasted, those random Italian varietals?).   Please do not follow in my high-maintenance footsteps of tasting 6 reds before committing, though he will humor you if you do.

Two more words of advice: order at least one dessert, as they are off-the-path in the best way possible - no standard panna cotta here.  Also, it's hotter than f**k in this place (due to the wood-burning oven that makes said pizzas, I assume), so layers are good.   I mean, it's the Marina, you can get away with showing some skin...
author: Melissa B.

description: Italian food that's worth the trip from the Castro to the Marina. I haven't had the pizza yet, but all the pastas I tried were excellent. Go during the week to avoid the crowds.
author: Michael R.

description: It is wonderful to have a restaurant of this class on Chestnut Street. The Marina has come a long way. It is fun to mix and match several starters. If you are not familiar with Mozzarella burrata, this is the place to try it. You can't beat the Pizza unless you fly off to Naples. Top all this with a beautiful staff, fun ambiance, and an interesting wine list. You won't be disappointed unless you let your pocketbook influence your judgment.
author: David C.

description: I love love love this place. Came here last night and had the special pizza which was a margherita with red onions and beef and it was so so so good. We shared the peppers as appetizers which sound weird, but they are the little green peppers and it's like crack. You eat one and can't stop, I'm serious!! Apparently it had anchovies, but I wasn't aware. For my main, I just settled on pasta and I ordered the macarronara (sorry I probably butchered that) which had tomato ragu. The noodles were thick, uneven and totally chewy and cooked to perfection. The sauce was unbelievable. I am a big big tomato based sauce fan and apparently it was cooked with pork, but the pork was strained, but you had the pork juice mixed in with the sauce. Lemme tell you, it was so freaking good. Just writing this review makes me hungry and I kinda wanna just run down the street and get some more!
author: Natalie S.

description:
Went here last night for a late dinner following a late run in the park.  I was starving!  We got seated instantly which was hard to understand at first because there seemed to be tons of people waiting up front.  The host said that we were a good size party (of two) which helped us get a table quickly.  We weren't seated in the back which looked to have a nicer atmosphere and I felt somewhat too far from my date.  I have noticed a trend of longer skinnier tables lately which means that restaurants can seat more people without interfering with circulation space but it also means that tables are rather awkwardly shaped.  
We ordered a starter of an assortment of olives, the Margherita pizza and the romaine and chicory salad with lemon and olive oil.  I scarfed down the pizza slices, found the olives interesting but too salty and the lettuce too acidic with all of the lemon juice on it.
A sommelier came by and kindly helped us choose a great Californian red.  I admit that I am somewhat intimidated by a wine list with a table of contents.  This nice man helped us without being the slightest bit patronizing.
All in all, I had a great time.
author: Lauren S.

description: I wouldn't rush here on a busy night, but hitting it before the dinner rush proved to be just right.  I have heard so much about the meatballs. I mean really, so much...from Daily Candy to the Chronicle to the movie of the same name.  I was disappointed to learn that they are served on Mondays only.  I ordered the pizza and after one bite forgot all about the 'balls.  I still want to try them.  Minus one star for the standoffish service.
author: T-Bone L.

description: A16 has a special place in our hearts.  It was the first time that we realized that nearly any skirmish can be instantly forgotten by putting a menu  or a wine list in our hands and letting us go to work.  The service has been average at best, but the food....wow.  The menu changes nightly, but there's always a fresh variations on a few staple dishes.  The gnocchi, prepared a different way nightly is amazing, as is the rabbit, the duck and anything else we've eaten there.  Also enjoyed a great bottle of Librandi that we haven't been able to find anywhere else, but you can buy it retail at the bar.  Yes, you need a reservation and yes, you need to allow time to park - if not, good luck with both.  Either way - it's worth it!
author: P J.

description:
The food was above average: I shared the Maccaronara with ricotta salad and the chef's choice pizza. The maccaronara was tiny, but good. The chef's choice pizza ended up being ricotta with arugula, which was just so-so. I tried my friend's margarita pizza and it was ten times better. 

I deducted two stars because of the appauling terrible service. If you get the tatted up brunette waitress, move to a different section. Only positive about the waitress was she was a complete idiot and forgot to include our wine on the bill.
author: Jackie S.

description:
I was very looking forward coming to this restaurant.   
Made reservation, got table close to the back of the restaurant, where it was nice and quiet - good start.   Waitress came, took our drink order.  Came back w/o drinks, okay, but we placed an order.  We saw waitress hanging around and chatting with regulars, 10-15 min. later, still no drinks.  Appetizer came, no drink, waitress still chatting with someone.
If she was very busy with doing what she was supposed to, I would not be upset....  Bottom line, bring drinks!
author: Tomo S.

description: The attitude and food at A16 have changed. The food is not bad, it's just not amazing. I can make it better at home with the recipes from my A16 cookbook. Perhaps Nate Appleman's departure has caused the change ( he has left San  Francisco behind for New York and is no longer at A16 or SPQR), or maybe I just feel that the food here is not worth the hype it once deserved. You be the judge, but if you are in the mood for the flavors you remember from the old A16, go buy the book and make it at home yourself. You'll get the same amazing food without the new rude attitude.
author: Abby Z.

description: REALLY liked this place. The burrata cheese appetizer, the farro salad, the pizza, the dessert, the wine ... the only reason it's not getting 5 stars is because the pasta we ordered was not so great. I wanna go back though. Good memories ... we went for my hubby's 30th bday :-)
author: Antara B.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for the longest time, and finally got a taste of it.  We came here on a spur of the moment and found seats at the bar.  The bartender was friendly, as were our fellow diners.   We split a margherita pizza with arugula and it was really good -- can't wait to come back and have a full meal here.
author: DD B.

description: Having had the chance to sample real Italian pizza, I can safely say that A16 passes muster.  The margherita pie brought back memories of my trip.  Thin and not too crispy with just the right balance of ingredients.   I can't understand why it costs more over here for something so simple. The atmosphere and decor was fitting for the Marina locale.  Had it not been the bug that crawled out of my friend's salad, I might have given them 4 stars.  Staff barely flinched when we complained.
author: JeFF T.

description: I used to really love this restaurant, but after a visit in June, I wouldn't come back.  The owners are over extending themselves and have clearly lost focus on their food.  The Neapolitan pizzas here put this restaurant on the map, but on my last meal here, both pizzas we ordered were over saturated, soggy and under cook.  It was disgusting.  Nothing but the burrata (which is hard to mess up) stood out.  All of our other entrees and appetizers were mediocre at best.
author: beverly l.

description: The only bad thing about this place is having to squeeze your way through the people in front at the bar. Its a small place but a very cool atmosphere. The food is amazing and the service has always been great!
author: amy r.

description:
Had reservations at A16 last night. It was my 2nd time here. 1st time, sat at the bar. I recommend making reservations at the back bar in front of the kitchen if you are a fan of Top Chef, you will like the action. Anyhow, we had a 4 top near the back patio. The place is cozy, decent decibel level (good music, allows for conversation) and good food. The service is my only problem. Although the girl at the front was friendly, real and full of great advice, our server was "removed" - and borderline fake. I don't think she was happy to be there. As far as the food: 
- Beet Salad - awesome. enough for 4 to share a few bites. Great starter. 
- Mozzarella Burata - a MUST. Get one or two. The best mozzarella you will have tasted. Served w/crunchy toasts. 
- Side of roasted butternut squash. a MUST. So damn good. crunch and smooth. Get one order for two or even two for 4 people. 
- Sardine Bruchetta - I love sardines. But I was not in love with the way it was served on what tasted like hummus. It was heavy. I prefer sardines drenched in olive oil and lemmon, served simply on a plate alone. 
- Fabriano Salumi - a plate of cured salami, very very god. 
- Pizza - good but not the best. 
Our table started w/champagne (pink) then two of us continued w/a bottle of white and two others - the guys, chose to go the Chimay route. To sum it up, this place is great for shared plates of cured meats, interesting apps, wine selection and warm cozy festive (stylish holiday decor) - love the black wood atmosphere. Great entrance good place to bring another couple and share a tasty southern style italian meal. Service desperately needs improvement. Seems to be an ongoing issue.
author: Amy E.

description:
With a 7:00 reservation, I thought I would be set. The people before was told over an hour wait for a seat. If you decide to come here, I would make reservations before heading out. 

This was our 1 year anniversary so we wanted some place special. I received 2 recommendations from Jim Stewart and my boss.  They both raved about this place so I thought it would be the perfect experience... 

We got to the restaurant and they took us back to our table. As we approach the back of the restaurant, the hostess turns around and apologizes that they did not have a table. It's not the end of the world but it was a foreshadowing of things to come. After waiting about 15 min, we finally get our table. It looks like they just threw a table in the back. I couldn't even move my seat back more than an inch or else I would hit the chair behind me. The table was horrible! It wobbled like a rocking chair. It almost felt like it was gonna fall over. After bringing this to the attention of our waiter Nico, he pushed the table against the wall and said he was going to get a wedge for the table. About 10 minutes later, he mentioned that he forgot the wedge and came back to fix the table. 

Nico seemed like a very nice and knowledgeable guy, the few seconds we actually got to talk to him. It felt like he was running around like a chicken with his head cut off. Every time he came to our table, we felt like we were an after thought. 

We started with the Margherita pizza. This was the best dish of the night. The crust was crispy, the cheese was gooey and the herbs were fresh and flavorful. We probably should have just stuck to the pizza. We then ordered the Bucatini with Monterey sardines, dried san marzanos, capers, green olives, garlic and chiles and squid ink tonnarelli with shrimp, zucchini, garlic, mint, anchovies and chiles. The squid ink pasta was very flavorful and actually pretty good. The Bucatini with sardines was extremely fishy and not our cup of tea. I took one bite and didn't touch it again. For our main course, we ended up splitting the local rock cod in acqua pazza with basil. I thought the bay scallops and muscles with this dish was cooked to perfection. My gf said the fish was really fishy even compared to the sardine bucatini. The sauce they use tasted similar to Chinese satay sauce. The side dish of roasted potatoes with pickled onions, capers and chiles was delicious and the best part of our main course. 

I really wanted to like this place but I'm sad it was not as good as I had hoped.
author: Ken W.

description:
eh. it was tasty and trendy and affordable but not at all the fantastic-ness that i was expecting due to the hype (hence the 3 stars). 

don't get me wrong, the food was good and the wine we had was also very good, but i'd rather go to pizzetta 211 for great thin crust pizza instead of good thin crust pizza. 

one thing must be said however - it's a good place to go if you're looking for an affordable place to eat in the marina since most of the other marina joints are much more expensive.
author: lisa w.

description:
The new chef here is great!  better than Nate in my opinion. 

Has changed from a redundant one trick pony, to more of a fresh, rustic, authentic, loca-vore kind of menu.

maybe its just me, but I like the pizza more now to- and I don't know if they've even changed anything.  Its a fun place to go to style it out big, or just grab some good pizza and a glass of wine.
author: Nick H.

description: Not worth the hype but very marina! Love the ambiance, the crowd, the super helpful bartender, but the food is just so-so.  We had two pizzas, gnocchi, and a bunch of appetizers.  Not thrilled with any of the dishes but love the wine selection.  I'd go back there for finger food and wine for sure, but would not recommend for dinner.
author: Cathy Y.

description: I'm impressed!  We ducked in here at 5:30pm just as it started to rain.  No reservation, but we got to sit at the bar over the kitchen.  It was fun watching the cooks coordinate, timing the orders so that everything would show up hot at the same time.  The pizza oven was heated to 760 F, and pizzas went through it in about 5 minutes.  We ordered full dinners, watched the order go through, and loved the food.  The servings looked small, served California-style on big white plates with lots of space around each item, but after the dinner was over we felt there was more than enough food.  The crew was fast and polite, pouring the sparkling mineral water for us just as we finished off each glass.  All in all, it was a good night, a very satisfying experience.  It was a little more expensive than I expected, but it was worth it to me.
author: David D.

description:
this used to be one of my favorite 'hip' italian eateries.  i've had many good meals here, a favorite - the funghi pizza.

but what happened?

service was less then stellar with a cool (as ice) host and slightly sloppy waitress (who seemed cranky and lacked the grace of a good waitress).

the funghi pizza was also lacking....in funghi!  the first time i tried this pizza, it was light on sauce, moderate on cheese, and abundant in mushrooms.  this time, the mushroom sprinkles were sparce as if tapped out of a can, and so much tomato sauce, i almost burned my lip biting into it.  my gnocchi with meatballs was good, but again with the portions??  3 meatballs!  i understand it was a side order, but the meatballs were the size of a quarters!

the only saving grace is the wine list, and the sommelier, i think her name is sherry, is always pleasant and sweet.

i think i'll only come here on meatball mondays going forward.
author: Josie M.

description: A16's the ONLY reason to go to Chestnut Street. Especially when there's room at the bar.
author: Tiffinie T.

description: Even with a reservation, this place makes you wait forever. I guess you have to know someone to be seated on time. Too bad I will never go back. This past weekend was the third time they made me wait over an hour for a table I reserved two months prior. And a very rude hostess to boot.
author: Amanda C.

description:
great starters:
tripe.....i was impressed, delicious
squid ink pasta with octopus ragout....very fishy, but good

after that I had the lamb, it was ok, but not as impressive as the starters.  minus one star for the lamb.

staff/service: friendly, knowledgeable, courteous.  they called my cell as shopped near by to tell me that a space had opened up.
author: H C.

description:
Ok, so I've just started Yelping but here goes nothing.

I've been to A 16 twice, both on a special occasion w/ my g/f.  I must say that the food would have been a lot better if it would get to me hot.  Both times I've been there when the food got to the table and I took my first bite it was warm.  For someone like myself that's very disappointing.  Service there could be a lot better for the prices you're paying and most of all the food should come out hot!  This is not a place for cheap asses and people who are not willing to spend money.

I can say that the reason I'm not going back there anymore is due to the lack of service.  If you're down for good food accompanied by some mediocre service feel free to hit them up.
author: Anthony T.

description:
Went here for my birthday with my parents and girlfriend. 

The pizza was awesome! 5 Stars really...and I'm a huge pizza fanatic. 

The rest of the food wasn't as exciting, but still decent. For the price, I wish it could have been a little more memorable. 

I can't remember what dishes we had specifically, so I'll have to go back and review again.
author: Josh M.

description: Obviously, I'm a big fan of Italian food, and in this city you have a lot to choose from, but this place is at the top of their game.  I always feel so well taken care of when I go here.  The food always tastes so fresh like it came straight from the farmer's market.  I recommend any of their pizzas, especially the one with mushrooms, grab a glass of Aglianico and sit at the counter and admire the artisan work of the pizzaiolo.
author: J. F.

description: The best thing you can say about this place is that the location, if you happen to have seen a movie at the Presidio Movie Theater, is perfect.  Other than that, this place is completely and totally "eh".  Maybe, I'll give you a maybe, this place would be more than "eh" if the service was greater than "lame" but until that time, it's a big "eh".  The owners must have a fabulous PR crew that puts them in the national travel rags, because it's not because of the food and it's certainly not because of the service.
author: amanda g.

description: Great pizza, great small plates, meatballs are fabulous and the wine list is great! The burrata (soft mozzarella cheese) and prosciutto are sooo yummy. I always go with my wine distributor friend who knows what to order. The only con is it's in the Marina.....parking sucks and it's always packed. Best to get there on the early side with only 1 friend and grab a seat at the bar.
author: lani P.

description: Fun authentic Italian in vibrant spot. Owner Shelly is very visible and friendly with great wine advice. Everything we had was excellent...burrata, pizzas, pastas, apple dessert.
author: Peter H.

description: I after hearing of all the hype, we decided to head down to the Marina to try the food. If you want atmosphere, the energy, great selection of wines, and good/attentive/knowledgeable staff, then this is the place for you. But for the price, I would have expected better quality food. Sardine starter was the best thing that we had and the food quality went down from there. The lamb was ok but it wasn't anything special and the squid ink pasta was so salty that is was difficult to finish. The desserts were good but nothing to write home about. But our waiter chose great wine for us and we had great service throughout the meal. I hear the pizzas are good but didn't order it and not sure that I would go back for it anyway. Overall an underwhelming experience for us. Not matter how good the ambience, the restaurant should always be about the FOOD!
author: InHo K.

description:
Went to A16 with a small group sans reservation, which I would NOT recommend.  We probably waited for over an hour for a small table top against the wall, which was simply too small for three people with wine and food.  The atmosphere is ok, very trendy with that 'place to be' feel.  

We ordered the mozzarella burrata based on all the recommendations and while the burrata was very fresh and creamy, it did not have a whole lot of flavor.  I found the burrata at Bottega Louie in LA with pesto much better.  The La Quercia tasting salumi plate was delicious and a must have for any meat lover.  We also ordered two very thin crusted pizzas, the 16 Salsiccia and funghi - both were perfectly cooked and very flavorful.  The fennel sausage on the Salsiccia was particularly delicious.  

The only thing really lacking was their by the glass wine selection.  Will definitely be back to try their entrees and wine by the bottle.
author: Deborah H.

description: Uhhh.... ok.  Went twice and yes, great wine selection and there was one pasta dish that was dreamy, tomatoes, meat, perfectly cooked pasta.  But, the rest of the dishes were over priced and not all that great.  The cured meats were nice, but lacked in presentation.
author: Cosmolicious L.

description: Delicious food, incredible wine list and decently priced. I've been here with everyone from my best friend to my grandma and had a wonderful time. The burrata is fantastic and the pizzas are definitely big enough to split. Highly recommend making a reservation otherwise expect a long wait. Sitting outside can be good for large groups otherwise try to get a seat inside.
author: Kelly F.

description: Basically, I will never return here.  Our waitress (aka: ice queen) could not have been more rude or unknowledgable about the wine list and what would pair best with our food selection.  The food looked and tasted like it was just unwrapped from plastic, cold, and I passed to wait until I got home for my meal.  Paid a lot of money for a place that was too crowded, and their ego filled most of the room.
author: Lulu B.

description: Pizza was great. Salame great. Beet salad great. But loud as hell. Gave up on trying to hear dinner companions sitting accross from me after about  20 minutes.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I dream about the pizza Margherita con Prosciutto at A16. As much as I try, I have never found another restaurant that can compare with their perfection.  They have a great assortment of Italian wines by the glass and the bartenders/sommeliers will let you taste until you find just the right one.
author: Kristine K.

description:
This was the worst meal I have had in San Francisco hands down!  I paid like $40 for two glasses of wine while waiting in the cramped entry way for an hour after the host said it was going to be twenty minutes.  Then the wine bar is actually not part of the restaurant so they can't put it on one bill, all this after trying to get the bartenders attention for 15 minutes!  Then we sat down.  We had a good seat which was a surprise.  We ordered a salad.  It tasted so bad I didn't understand why it was called a salad and why it was on the menu.  some sort of beet salad w/ onion ehhh!  
I had been told by a friend that the place was great.  My girlfriend and I looked at the menu and figured why get pizza when we can get it anywhere in SF and pay half the price for it.  So I ordered a Pork Chop and she ordered a pasta dish.  After a long time it came out.  It was not cooked at all.  The thing was rubber and in-edible, and the side was clearly not fresh and flat aout tasted bad.  How hard is it to cook a pork chop and some potatoes.  I can do it easily.  My girlfriends pasta looked terribe and tasted even worse.  I never have had a bad dinner like this in my life!  I seriously can't ever remember sending a dish back to be cooked.  So ten minutes later it came back.  The pork chop was just disgusting covered in fat and no meat.  The pasta was terrible and my girlfriend couldn't eat it.  
When we left we went down the street and ate some pizza because we were still hungry.  I spent $100 and got garbage in return.  
If you want high priced, crapy pizza and overpriced wine then go there.  Don't bother getting any of the entres.  I have worked in the restaurant industry since I was a kid,  I have done everything from waiting table to cooking.   I know what should and shouldnt happen at restaurants.  This was the worst experience at any restaurant I have ever been to.
author: Pete L.

description:
i've just had my second eating experience at A16, and while i had thoroughly enjoyed the first, this time really impressed me.

first of all, if you can, i recommend sitting at the chef's counter.  granted, it's more casual, but it's very interesting to watch all the chefs cooking...and everything smells SO good.  but, a forewarning...because everything smells wonderful, you might be apt to order it all!

my friend and i were well-behaved.  she recommended we order this app...mozzarella burrata with sea salt, olive oil, and crostini...O.M.G., wow.  that's really all i can say about it.  it is heavenly...creamy, salty...just plain yummy-ness!!!  i actually dream about eating this now.  HIGHLY recommend ordering this.

for our entree, we shared the funghi pizza with smoked mozzarella & wild argula.  again, along with the mozzarella burrata, this was fabulous.  while we both should've stopped at the over-sized first slice, we couldn't bear to waste the rest of the pizza, so finished it off (probably, foolishly), and waddled out of the restaurant.  extremely full, but definitely beyond satisfied.

my friend and i shared the app & entree, so the price is pretty moderate...where else can you get such fabulous food for under $25-30 per person??

i cannot wait for my next visit...yes, i'm dreaming about that mozzarella burrata already...
author: Kelly T.

description:
for a regional italian restaurant, i thought it was pretty good.  came in without high expectations and enjoyed a very reasonable tasty meal
this place is very loud though!
mozzarella burrata was as great as everyone says -- soft and simple, with a drizzle of olive oil and sea salt.
ricotta gnocchi was nice, corn broth quite scrumptious
had it with a side of broccoli, bacon bits, and chili
salsiccia pizza -- flavorful, spicy, great crust, but not so special that i would come here just for that.
i think this place holds its own against oliveto.
as for parking, pierce garage is usually full, so check out lombard street garage.
author: Rob C.

description: Hmmm been there a few times.. perhaps the weather was somewhat warm, but it was kind of steamy... good food. small bar. good people watching.... I feel like I am preying on a sit when I am there by myself. Sexy place
author: Jonathan C.

description: we were a walk-in at 5:15, and had to wait for a table for an hour and a half. The apps we ordered at the bar never came. I guess they only have two tables for walk-ins (way to support the home team, folks!) both of which are jammed into the M-80 decibel level bar. The food is good, but certainly not worth waiting that long for.
author: Kathy P.

description: I know that the chef has left to probably start his own thing, but we returned anyway.  The only thing that we noticed different was the absence of any specials.  The staff seems to be continuing on with the same great menu.  We enjoyed our meal and the waitress recommended a wonderful wine.  I will continue to return.
author: Jeff W.

description: I'm really surprised that this place is considered one of the "best" Italian restaurants in SF, considering how many stellar restaurants there are in the city. I had lunch with friends here last week and was not that impressed by the food - it was good, but not great. The ambiance was nice though, and they had some interesting choices for wines by the glass. We were seated in the cozy back patio, which was nice and warm despite the cold/wet weather at the time. I had the bruschetta, which featured bread that was sliced way too thick. The pizza was good, but sort of bland and definitely not memorable. I wish I had tried the burrata after reading the reviews on here, but I don't think I'll be rushing back there anytime soon to try it.
author: Laura P.

description: A16 is touted as one of the best in SF, and their food is certainly amazing.  but my review is going to be more about the bar than the restaurant...you have to jockey for a seat on most evenings, but the wine list is superb and the staff...especially behind the bar...are amazing.  let them choose for you and "climb the ladder" and sample the best they have.  you will not be disappointed.
author: A E.

description: I saw a segment about A 16 on youtube for slow food.    My husband and I had to check out this famous resturant.  So hard to get reservation but we  finally got it on a Saturday.  We were expecting fabulous food.   Great pizza   and got one free glass of wine b/c of customer wrong order.  Other dishes are like california cusine with healthy (slow food) concept.    This is the place to be if you want to dine in Marina, SF.
author: Nicole C.

description: After reading so many reviews on here about A16 (both good and not so good), I'm glad I can finally write one myself. A friend suggested this place for lunch so we gathered here one day for a ladies' luncheon. The menu was very small and half of it was pizza. We agreed on the funghi pizza and two others: zucchini salad with green olives and parmesan; and I ordered the burrata which was so highly recommended here. Now, the pizza was absolutely fantastic! The crust was thin and the mushrooms were just extremely flavorful. The zucchini salad was good, however, the burrata served with proscuitto was really disappointing. Both my lunch companions are seasoned travelers, one of who has been in the 5-star hotel industry and the other, a lifestyles magazine editor for many years. The consensus on the burrata was that it was so-so, nothing to write home about. Having said that, we did enjoy our meal, the service was good, nothing exceptional. I must say the iced tea was really one of the best I've had and I'm an iced tea afficionado. We split a dessert which was recommended by our server... the Gravenstein apple crostata with caramel gelato and cherry coulis. The dessert was very good and not overly rich or sweet. Would definitely return again, but I don't think I would drive into SF specifically to eat at this place.
author: Anita L.

description: I've been here a couple of times, and every time it was packed.    While you can order individually, I've particularly enjoyed being able to order "family style" here.     The food is really good, the pizza is so much better than many places.  They do a nice job with charcuterie and I'm completely in love with their polenta.  Polenta?  yes,  it's a simple dish, but not everybody gets it right.   My only gripe this last visit, one of our pasta dishes was waaay to salty. Much saltier than other visits.  Since we were eating family style, most of the dish was served by the time we all tasted.  We told the server we were done, (not quite sending it back).  I heard the server tell the line that we had a comment about the heavy hand with the salt, but beyond that it wasn't addressed to our table.  Given everything else we had (rabbit, sea bass, etc) was so good, one down dish won't prevent me from returning on my next visit to the city.
author: Christie V.

description: I wish I had more of an appetite to sample some of the other dishes but the brick oven pizza was pretty darn good.  We ordered the mushroom pizza (funghi) and was later clued in by a chef to add pancetta next time... of course!  Well, I guess this place deserves a repeat visit then for the pizza and then some.  My only complaint is they don't do take out (who doesn't love good food on the couch).
author: Aileen L.

description:
cool atmosphere. 

felt like i was in a comedic drama movie. 

wine was good and i'd go back. 

bar could be bigger. 

hostess was the mostest. va va voom
author: Bobby B.

description:
My cousin and I were in SF for an appointment and decided to stay for dinner... now the problem - where to?  We called one of her friends, who highly recommended that we try A16 - so we did.  We started our meal with an amazing glass of wine - recommended to us by the Sommelier from the restaurant - and an amazing mozzarella appetizer that was the best thing I have ever had... For dinner, we had the meatball special (consisted of 5 good sized meatballs in a white wine sauce covered in olive oil and shredded Parmesan) along with one of their fresh pizza's.  Just when we thought we couldn't eat another thing... we ordered more wine and dessert - a chocolate torte with olive oil and sea salt along with a scoop of caramel gelato. I know it sounds weird - but trust me - you must try this dessert... it is a true slice of heaven and one of a kind.  

Outside of the food - the service was attentive and all around amazing. I cannot say enough about this place - in fact, I am already planning my next visit.
author: Remaining U.

description: I love italian food, but not typically the italian food they serve in the U.S. A16, though, they give italian food in the States justice. I love so many of the dishes at this restaurant, but I always order the tripe. Yes, its not for everyone, but you don't know what you are missing out. This is the best tripe I have had. In addition, you can't go wrong with the pastas, which are made to the perfect al dente texture, and the pizzas. Plus, the sommelier always suggests great and affordable bottles of wine. The service can be a bit spotty at times, but the great food and wine at reasonable prices make up for it. I've been to this restaurant multiple times. Amazing...
author: Karen C.

description:
First visit to A16:

Pizza: Excellent
Entrees:  eh?
Side Dishes: eh?
Wine: Good
Hype: Not getting it.
author: Hung T.

description: yea, still a solid 4 stars.  I don't know about some of the other reviews I tried the burrata which was  very good - anything you can order that's cooked in the wood fire oven is the way to go IMHO.  Although it is crowded and without reservations you will have to wait - it's all worth it!  Love this place.....
author: Grover G.

description:
Great food, great waitstaff. The pizza was first class. The pasta and gnocchi were excellent. The first bottle of wine was mildly corked - the waiter removed the bottle without question. The wine he recommended (once a good bottle was opened!) was excellent, as were his food recommendations. 

We were running late, but the hostess was able to accomodate us without problems (we called ahead to inform them we were running late, which always help). Our wait once we got there was no more than 10 min.

Great restaurant.
author: daniel p.

description:
Our absolute favorite.  Not often you find such a top-notch spot as your neighborhood restaurant.  Nate and his folks are consistently excellent in their menu choices, preparation, wine list and service.

If you're in the Marina and looking for a great pizza or southern Italian meal, do not miss A16.
author: Reed G.

description: I love this place.  I think its great food and they have an extensive wine list.  Its kind of small and the ceiling is kinda low and it gets pretty crowded in the bar area, but it's all worth it cause the food is so good.  The proscuito plater was awesome, the crab pasta was great and the salads are amazing as well.  Nothing to complain about the service.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Lauren M.

description:
we really enjoyed our meal here.  we came in w/ no reservations and put ourselves on the walk in list and we got seated in less than 10 minutes.  before we got seated we got a drink at the bar and that was pretty much chaos.  the bartender working was running around a lot and trying his best to get to everyone but didn't quite give everyone enough attention.  we ordered some wine there but the pinot noir recommendation i had was quite bad.

anyways, we were finally seated in what i assume was the seating area for walk-ins.  it was very cool w/ high tables and chairs and all.  we could see the reservation seating area and that seemed a tad bit more shee-shee.  in any case, we were greeted by our waiter and we were off to ordering.

to start we had gotten the mozzarella burrata and crostini.  this was very good as the mozzarella was almost spreadable.  the crostini was the approved vessel to bring the cheese to the mouth and it proved to be a worthy one.

for our main entrees, the wife got the ricotta gnocchi.  this was a very nice and light gnocchi not the startchy variety.  very good and cheesy.  one of my wife's best friends had the roast chicken with peperonata which in turn was very good.  i had the braised lamb w/ chickpeas and this was almost like a chole in indian food but w/ a beautifully braised lamb.  excellent though a bit too hot when it came out.  for the entrees, you can get sides and the roasted potatoes and butternut squash were ordered.  though they were good, they failed to make a huge impact at all.

for dessert, i had the parfait of lemon granita which started off super tart but then an nice sweetness finished it off.  the two of them shared the apple crostata which they enjoyed and i liked the bite that i had.

this was a nice find in the marina for sure.  though the crown might be your typical yuppie crowd, don't let that fool you.  there are good eats to be had!
author: Swarup B.

description:
I've got to tell you, I'm tired of hearing the age old debate about GIalina vs. A16 on pizza. I'll weigh in here - although granted that Gialina has more authentic tastes, I think that A16 actually had better quality overall pizza. I'm talking about attention to detail with to the crust (just the right amount of thickness), great quality ingredients that makes for a great pizza.

Why I gave this 4 stars instead of 5, is because of the fact that I think the other food here is actually not very good. The 3 times that I have been here, I have ordered different items (the last time I think i got a pork chop) and it has honestly been sub-par. Stick with pizza and wine though and you wont regret it at all!
author: Vijay S.

description: Great dining room and even the walk-in seating by the bar where it's dark and cozy was cool but avoid the weird tiny back patio room where there's zero ambiance and you're separated from the fun of being around everyone else. All dishes are really good and so fresh including the much raved about pizza though i don't find them as mind-blowing as I've read.  Love the offer of pasta dishes in either app or entree sizes.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
I have been coming to A 16 for a couple of years. It is my husbands favorite place. Why? 
The food is excellent - not frou frou, but delicious, fresh, seasonal, and well prepared.  The meatballs are fabulous - tender and tasty. Love the pizza - simple ingredients with the chili oil. 
The prices are reasonable. You can order just salad and pizza. Unfortunately, it is very difficult for us to do this. We have been known to order one item from each section - just for the two of us. Of course we cannot finish it all, but it is always so good. 
The service has always been excellent for us, whether or not we had reservations. The wait staff is well informed of the menu and ingredients and attentive. 
But most importantly, the wine selection from Southern Italy and the help we get from Shelley. We love trying new wines that match perfectly with our food selections. 
Yes, parking in this neighborhood is challenging, but the food, service, price and wine all makes it difficult to go anywhere else.
author: Terrie R.

description:
A friend brought me to A16 for lunch on a Wednesday (April '09)... on purpose.  A16 gets their pork on Wednesdays--a hog and a half, typically.  And they chop the (drained and quartered, so not at all icky) sucker up right there.  Nothin' but a 10-inch high and few mms thick strip of glass between my midday meal and some strangers' to-be-dinners... 

I dug everything about it.

The employees had surely seen our curiosity before...  I was one of a group of five, and a couple of us were taking photos.  Not an issue.  The staff answered our frequent questions with patience and sincerity.  The food was good and appropriately priced.

My companion and I tend to dig big reds, and we (typically) neither drink in the afternoon nor waste time on anything white.  Scott, our server, recommended the perfect red... 

I imagine that dinner at A16 is a different experience altogether.  But, if you're headed in for lunch, order a pizza and talk to Scott about wine.  And go on a Wednesday if you're up for the whole hog show (worth it, I'd say).
author: Jessica H.

description: Went to dinner at A16 last night and there wasn't an outrageous wait time. The food was delicious, especially the side of sunchokes (a recommendation from our server). Dana was our server and she was really pleasant, as well as knowledgeable. Definitely a great experience! I recommend this place.
author: Lisa C.

description:
i seriously dream about the mozzerella burrata.  

...mmmm....
author: Natalie H.

description: This is one of the first restaurants I ate at when I first moved to San Francisco 4 years ago, and even though I've eaten at hundreds of places since then, that first visit to A-16 remains one of the most vivid dining experiences I've ever had.  They serve the type of unpretentious, stripped down Italian food that I could eat every day.   I had my first taste of burrata mozzarella that night, served with sea salt crostini.  We had mushroom pizza, with prosciutto on the side.  Rosemary crusted hangar steak with olive oil and balsalmic.  Local sole in almond sauce.  White beans casserole.  Orange semifreddo.  If I lived in the Marina I would eat here once a season.  It's hard not to feel comfortable in a restaurant where you will find the executive chef in a button-up dishwasher shirt focused entirely on slinging pizza into a wood-burning oven all night.
author: Kevin G.

description: This place is always so packed and it's hard to get a seat, but if you get there early, it's a great spot to meet before a movie.  Otherwise, if you simply must have unusual Italian wines with a yummy crisp pizza (or two -- the extra thin crust will have you wanting more), patience is a virtue!
author: Lorraine F.

description: Such a cool place.  It just really has that relaxed, "we know we're awesome but we're keeping it on the down-low" vibe.  Pizza - yum!
author: Jenn K.

description: I really did want to like this place, after all the excitement and talk. But I have to say I won't be going back. And it has nothing to do with the marina crowd (i will put up with them for a great meal). This was my second visit, the first time I went my pizza was burnt and raw at the same time. This time we sent it back when it arrived burnt and raw, our waitres was great, super attentive and tried very hard. But I just can't get past the fact that on the third time the pizza still tasted like crap. If you want pizza in this style go to Pizzeta's in the avenues, if you can make there before they run out of dough!
author: Kai H.

description:
I came to A 16 after wanting to try it for a while, for lunch with my dad (so, he paid--which allowed us to sample a few wines). The food actually was moderately priced for lunch, but the wine is where they get ya. But anyway, we were seated in the back patio, with heat lamps because even on a sunny day it's cold. It was much quieter back there and we enjoyed the sense of privacy, though sometimes it seemed like our waiter had forgotten about us...
We each had their chicory salad with a delightfully light & flavorful lemon and olive oil dressing, and then we shared a pizza with scrumptious artichoke hearts that had been cooked to perfection. Had we not had wine, that fabulous lunch would've only cost us about 30 bucks.
But we tried several of the obscure Italian whites from Southern Italy, and they were all pretty excellent.
I'm not sure I'd be eager to go  back for dinner though, because I could tell that it would easily fill with snobby people who were blessedly few because it was a weekday late lunch hour....I can take pleasure in gay snobs, but straight snobs ruin my digestion.
author: Renu C.

description:
Maybe it's just my bad luck with hyped up restaurants or maybe my expectations were set too high. That being said, I expected better from A16. After hearing rave reviews from friends I was really excited about coming to dinner here. 

The first thing that went wrong was the reservation. I had made a reservation early that morning for 3 people for 9:30, a reasonably late reservation. At around 6 we extended that reservation for 4. When we got there at 9:30, the hostess tells us that we are going to be seated in the bar section in the front. I was a little perturbed to say the least. I asked her why there was an issue sitting us in the dining room and she said it's because we extended our reservation. What I don't understand is that a table for 3 is basically a table for 4 right? So they sat us at the front, we ordered some appetizers and we were later moved to the dining room. The one bonus is that they must have felt sorry for messing up, so our table did receive comped prossecco, but that still doesn't make up for the fact that they screwed up our reservations. The next thing that went wrong was when we were seated in the dining room my silverware settings were dirty! 

So now onto the food.. I've definitely had better Italian before, especially for that price. The house-cured bresaola was definitely my favorite appetizer, along with the arugula salad with nectarines, fennel, walnuts, green olives and ricotta salata. For dinner I had the maccaronara with tomato ragu and house-made ricotta salata and it was just mediocre.. The wine selection was wonderful, I can't remember the name of the wine, but it was so good! It was a dark red with a full body but it was so smooth at the same time. 

I guess I'll just wait a little while and try back some other time to see if my experience improves. At least long enough to forget about this shitty one, but that won't be for a long time...
author: Sarah T.

description: This place has peaked and is on the road downhill.  Obnoxious hostess, crowded, noisy, and food has lost some of the magic (did they change chefs?).  The locals have tapered off so you are left with tourists (working off a guide book 2 years old) and an older pick-up scene at the bar / front of restaurant.  Best bet would be to order a pizza to go, but I forgot - they don't allow that.
author: Craig F.

description:
Let's throw another opinion onto the pile shall we?

I went on a Saturday evening, without a reservation... it was early, proabably quarter to 6ish.  They were totally accomodating and gave us a lovely table, not in the bar or out back.  Our server was a delight and knew the wine list well, she suggested a Vicari Rosso Piceno that was fantastic.

Starters included the Burrata and the Tuna Conserva.  The Burrata was good, can't really go wrong with a lump of high quality cheese.  The Tuna was interesting and good.

My dining partner (who suggested the place) and I shared half orders of Maccaronara with tomato ragu that was absolutely fantastic and the pumpkin/ricotta gnocci with kale, red onions and pancettea, equally fantastic and a unique take on gnocci.  We had sides of cannelini beans and a chard with lemon and anchovy.  There was nothing left on any plates.  We had a house cured beef salami as an after dinner savory before dessert.

The chocolate bundito with olive oil and sea salt was sublime, but the suggested wine pairing with it should be mandatory!  It took the dessert to a new level.  We also had the canoli with the wine pairing, decadent.  

Needless to say, we left happy and enjoyed the food coma that ensued.
author: T. R.

description: OMG, I finally tried this restaurant everyone I know raved about!  I tried to have dinner here a few times but it's always at least 2 hour wait.  Finally I went with a friend for their dine about town lunch menu.  The beet salad with fennel was delicious and the choice of ingredients is interesting.  Pizza was main course for lunch, any type of pizza from their lunch pizza menu.  That was a bit disappointing.  Not the pizza, but I was disappointed that I wasn't given the choice of other main course items other than pizza.  We ordered Salsiccia and Margherita pizzas.  Salsiccia is more unique, but they both are very good.  I still want to go back to try their dinner menu.
author: Gina W.

description: a friend who is a regular brought us and did all the ordering, i have no idea what all we ate but it was all fantastic and the wine pairing that the sommelier recommended was perfect! my boyfriend has been talking about the salumi plate since we have been together and when i finally made it in he was right! we shared a pizza and a pasta along with an assortment of appetizers, all outstanding.. and i am one to scope out plates passing by, they all looked great.
author: Barbara C.

description:
The pizza is 5 stars -- our favorite in the bay area. The other food is great too -- the gnocci is to die for -- but the pizza is so good, we almost always order that. Plus, it's a great value. 

It's fun to sit at the bar in the back and watch them make the food! 

Only problem is that it's nearly impossible to eat here. Every time we call for a reservation, unless you're weeks ahead, 10pm is the only time they have open. We started just stopping by instead and planning to wait. That seems to work better (but don't tell!).
author: suz q.

description: This place ROCKS! Been here a few times and its been phenomenal each time. Started off at the bar one night, which can get really crowded but were able to snatch 2 bar seats. But then got seated in about 20 minutes which wasn't bad. The buffalo mozzarella with crostini is excellent, however, found out its not served every night?The fennel sausage pizza is delish, and the beet salad very good. Plus the waiters are all very friendly and helpful, no attitudes here. The only downside is that its located in the Marina and the restaurant is ALWAYS packed.
author: Carol B.

description: Over-Hyped beyond belief!  Service is horrible, food is Basic meatballs and pizza...this is a LA style restaurant in the marina aka "little LA".  How non-san francisco!
author: Sir Paul L.

description: This was one of the better dining experiences I've had in SF.  Originally walking in I thought service would be pushy and uptight.  It turned out that it was anything but that.  Service was friendly, the extensive wine selection awesome, and the food pretty outstanding.  The one item that stood out in my mind was the fungi (mushroom) pizza.  Love the flavors from the wood burning stove and the variety of roasted mushrooms.  The shock of the night was when I saw Charles Phan, owner of Slanted Door, and his family sitting at a table behind my g-friend and I.  I love A16 more so than S.D. and that's a fact!  Sorry Chef Phan.
author: Hiro A.

description: Oh the hype.  It was destined to disappoint after the expectations had been built up.  Sure enough, I left wondering just what I'd missed that had led so many people to tell me that I HAD to try this place.  My gf and I went on a Thursday night not long ago.  But apparently, long enough ago that I can't even remember what we ordered.  Either my memory is failing me or the meal just wasn't memorable at all.  I'm going with the latter.  If I'm going to spend that kind of money for dinner, I'd rather be some place that really delivers---Delfina, Circa, Bix, or any number of other better-quality places for the same price.
author: Bess K.

description: I have been to A16 on two different occasions and can now say that this is my favorite fine dining restaurant in San Francisco. I guess Tanuki was looking over me both times because I never made reservations and never had to wait. The Marina isn't my type of neighborhood but that didn't affect my dining experience. The meals were flawless and the service was attentive. All of these factors plus the excellent cost to quality ratio really makes A16 amazing.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
Don't believe the hype.  First off, if I had to choose between A16 and its sister resto, SPQR, it's the latter all the way.

A16 is just an irritating scene to begin with.  The layout is borderline dysfunctional and the noise is nearly unbearable.  The burrata, on the other hand, is AMAZING.  Pizzas are niceish, but I'd still prefer Oakland's Pizzaiolo and Boot and Shoe Service any day of the week, a million times over.
author: Alice T.

description: I really enjoyed my time at A 16. The waiter was excellent. He was attentive but not overly so, and well versed with the menu. He was also quite friendly and accommodating. The food was pretty good. I shared 3 pizzas with my group and they were all quite good. The only thing I wasn't too keen on at this establishment was the menu. I didn't think the appetizers were particularly appitizing and all the pizzas were fairly similar. Bottom line: a really nice spot with good food and great service.
author: Erik S.

description: I used to live in Italy. This pizza is on par with some pies you'll get over there. The service is very good. The vibe is ok for the Marina, it's a bit older than the crowd usually skews. The other menu items, other than Pizza are just ok. But worth a trip for a bottle of wine and a pie.
author: Sir M.

description: This is one of my favorite Italian spots in the city. Reservations for last minute dinners are tough and sometimes we just wait it out (cramped into tight spaces yes) with a glass of wine. BUT i think it is so worth it. This is what we order. Burrata with the homemade crostinis AND the proscuitto. Both the best I have had anywhere. Then the margherita pizza and the maccaronara. so so so yum! And we usually just share all this yummy stuff. The bread and olive oil are some of my favorite too:) i am happy just thinking about all this yummy stuff.
author: Lisa O.

description: Great experience, aside from ok service.
author: C. L. B.

description: A16 is a restaurant I would return to time and again if only it were a bit easier to get a table.  Food was great, wine was excellent.  Defintely a place that's worth the hype
author: Heather C.

description: yummy!!! I love this place. It is the only restaurant that I would order something as simple as spaghetti with red sauce and it is amazing!!!  The sometimes hours wait is totally worth it! And everything is good!
author: Rachel P.

description: Good Lord have mercy on me for that Mozzarella appetizer! I don't think I will EVER be the same again.......................
author: Yelper A.

description:
I really, really wanted to like this place.  I don't live too far, and have heard raves about it for months.  And hey, if Reese Witherspoon and Jake Gyllenhall ate here 2x in 24 hours, then it just must be fabulous, right?
WRONG. 
I came here w/ a good friend on the spur of the moment. It was rainy so we thought we'd have luck with a walk in.  
Here's how the night went.
Hostess: "hiiiiiiii (rudely), can we helpppp you??
Me (thinking): of course you can help me you shit, what do you think i want, to sell you girl scout cookies?! I want dinner!!
PS- the place is empty because of the rain
Hostess: "ummm. let me check to see if we have anything available...."
Me and Friend exchange "are you kidding me?" glances

We are escorted to the back of the restaurant.... 15 minutes passes. The server finally shows up....she tries to take our drink order but since we've been ignored for 15 minutes we already know what we want, so we just tell her everything at once, which I think kinda pisses her off.
So now 30 minutes has passed, and we get our meatball appetizer BEFORE our wine that we ordered!! wtf?! 
Hence the extra star- the meatballs were DAMN good, so fine.
Our pizza comes, and to be quite honest....blaaaaaaaaaaaa.
I was expecting to have an orgasm on first bite and was SO SO SO disappointed. The prosciutto I added just didn't go w/ the rest of the pizza.
We want dessert, but instead our server just hands us our check.
We tell her we each want a dessert, and she acts flustered. again, wtf?!  If the weather had been better, we seriously would've left and gone somewhere else for dessert, but we were lazy.
Dessert was fantastic, I had a semifreddo w/ huckleberries and walnut? amazing yum yum.

To top it off, we each had our pizzas boxed up to go, and they bring both of them in 1 bag. We do not live together, why couldn't they have given us each our own bag? I paid enough for that shitty pizza that it deserves its own bag!!  
We ask our server which is which, to which she replies "Um, that I do not know" and walks away!! OH MY GOD!

So to sum it up, our best service came from the damn busboy who was so attentive at refilling our water, and other than that, it was such a shitty experience. I will NEVER go here again, would NEVER bring my parents here, would NEVER go on a date here! too bad..
author: Lauren G.

description: I was not in love with this place. we waited over an hour to sit down, which was fine.  we sat at the bar and chatted with the very knowledgeable  bartender regarding various wines on the menu. i was annoyed after asking the hostess if maybe we should just order at the bar she said no your table is almost ready and then has us walk to sit at the bar at the back of the resturant! The mozzarella app was great, the pizza and the pasta were good but i think that there might be a little too much hype about this place. will definitely go back to the bar not so sure about dinner though.
author: Jenifer B.

description: Sorry, but this place is very overrated.  Fortunately you can't get a reservation there anyway and its always an hour+ wait if you walk in.  One trick to try is that there are bar seats in the back -- if the front bar is full try walking to the back and seeing if you can sit there.
author: Michael E.

description:
what a perfect place to take my g-bff 4eva to ring in his 30th birthday - mind you, this is a very important day that he has waited 30 years for so that he can finally gain all the full grown man power that is rightfully his.

we arrived 5 minutes prior to our reservation time, 7pm on a thursday night, and were seated promptly for the most delicious meal ever.

to start we had the mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt, and crostini, and the octopus salad with cucumbers, cherry tomatoes, wild arugula and breadcrumbs.

these were the kind of appetizers that really make you bounce with anticipation and excitement over the meal to come.  as confirmed by all the other reviews, the mozzarella burrata was melt in your mouth delicious... though i must say that i could not stop eating the octopus salad.  the octopus, bite size pieces of a large tenacle, was coated in breadcrumbs which added a really nice crispy crunch to the different crunch of the raw octopus.  i think this is my most favorite salad of anywhere at the moment.  or maybe ever.

somewhere along our conversation about our respective guy problems, work, and life, our pizza came.  now, g-bff is the one that turned me into a pizza snob by the way of pizzetta 211.  it is our faaaaavorite.  i think that was the place where i decided to make him my official g-bff.  anyway, so as good as our funghi pizza was, we still thought pizzetta 211 was a little better with its slightly thinner and blistered crust.

the wine flowed as easily as our conversation, and before we knew it, our entrees were here - the pacing of our courses were spot on.  he had the roasted tri tip with chiles, meyer lemon, basil and mint, and i had the squid ink tonnarelli.  the pasta had a really briney taste to it, which i LOVE... it tasted like the ocean.  i didnt try his but he assured me it was excellent.

as stuffed as we were, we couldn't pass up dessert.  i mean, of course not!  its me and sam!  we looked at the menu and wanted to order everything, but settled on the chocolate budino tart and the plum and hazelnut praline crostata.

oh. my. god.

the chocolate budino tart, doused with evoo and sprinkled with sea salt, was the most amazing thing i have ever put into my mouth.  it was sinful.  it satisfied all my wants and needs, and then more.  sweet, salty, creamy, decadent... all at the same time.  it was f-ing orgasmic.  i honestly think g-bff would gladly relinquish all the full grown man power that he just gained for the recipe.

all in all, a most perfect birthday dinner for a most favorite friend!
author: Helen L.

description: This was a great place for dinner. We had reservations and still had to wait about 20 minutes but in the end it was a good experience. The waiter was very helpful, the food was delicious, and I will definitely be going back again
author: Miguel V.

description: I think I'm being generous for giving it 3 stars, as this was not a memorable meal in any way. The dining area is beautiful, but then it fills with the "Marina-crowd" - in fact the staff as well seem to have a bit of an attitude, too, like you're lucky you got to eat there or something. The food is not bad, but nothing memorable. The pizza was probably the best thing we had, but still, I've had better italian pizza elsewhere. The overhyped Monday meatballs were not worth the hype and the gnocchi were rather bland even though they sounded great from the description (leeks, mint and pancetta). We also tried some wine which was good. Generally, the food was nothing special, the atmosphere was stuffy - probably the best part of the meal was the 100 points I got on opentable for my reservation!
author: Chris D.

description:
I've been here twice; we had an elongated multi-course dinner for Valentines Day and have also been back for pizza and a dessert at the counter tables.

Pizza at the chef's Counter:

The sausage pizza was great, although I would never add arugula to a pizza again here. While other places scatter a handful of beautiful wild arugula over your pizza at A16 they unceremoniously dump a pile an inch high, completely blocking the pizza from view. We also opted for the chocolate tart with olive oil and sea salt which was very nice. Even at the counter service was great, and having tried pizzas around the Bay I would say that overall A16 tops even Delfina and Pizzaiolo.

Dinner:

We sat at the back Patio which was very romantic and intimate, although the constantly changing heat lamp made it hard to get totally comfy. While they had a set V-Day menu, we selected our dinner from the regular menu. We started with a salad course; the tuna conserva salad was totally delicious. Next was a Pasta course, Abby had the squid ink pasta which was pretty good, but I had the Bucantini with roasted tomato and almond pesto and it was pretty pathetic. I totally understand a small sized pasta portion, but this was literally a single fork-twist of pasta. On top of that it was dry and totally boring (at $11 this is not ok). However, the fish entree we shared was really nice and came with some great sides. They also do a fantastic espresso and are more than capable of matching wines for any of your dinner selections. For a multi course meal that included wine and dessert the final price tag of $150 was very acceptable.

Whether you want an intimate meal or a quick bite A16 is a great place to go. Plan ahead, they fill up quick every night of the week.
author: Alex D.

description: Delicious food, outstanding service. Some of the best pizza I have had, and the staff is super attentive and helpful. Pricing is very reasonable given the outstanding quality. What more can I ask for?
author: new s.

description: Just finished a fantastic dinner - we ate at one of the tables in the bar area. Our waitor was super knowledgeable/helpful, which was great because I know nothing about Italian wine. He hooked me up with a great white that was fruity without being syrupy-sweet. We split a pizza and then I had the pasta dish that the past starts with scial... it's like spaghetti, but it may have ruined me from store-bought pasta forever. I loved the casual atmosphere of a wine bar, but real food. I'm looking forward to going back again!
author: Heidi L.

description:
A16 is A-OK!

The husband and I went out last night for our first anniversary and chose A16.  After learning that chefs come in on Mondays, we decided to try it out.  The wine list is very good, and the bartender was extrememly knowledgeable.  Hubby had the pork and pronounced it delicious.  I had the pizza, and though the reviews talked about how great it is, I didn't care for it.  There was little taste to the sauce, and any good italian knows that the success of any pizza depends on the flavor of the sauce.  Also the center was undercooked, so it was a soggy mess.  The dessert was ok.  We had the gelato and it was served in this weird tiny, plasticy, cheap-looking cup: completely opposite of how it would served in Italy. The waitress rushed us: hey, it wasn't our fault that we had a late reservation! It was all that was available.  I saw some of the characters from the Real World: Miami there, and the chef had a mohawk.  The conversation noise was loud but not obnoxiously so, and the hostess kept us updated on when we could be seated.
author: Tova S.

description: The mozzarella burrata really is amazing, the funghi pizza was solid, and the gnocchi was surprisingly flavorful.  The downside is that we were eating great food in air so thick with sweat and general human body heat, we were alternating wiping condensaation off our glasses and our faces. Anyone still hungry? Yeah, didn't think so. The place was so overpacked and bottlenecked by the front that unless you could score a table in the back of the restaurant, you were pretty much guaranteed to melt. In a bigger location with better "flow" management, the place could be worth the hype. Pity.
author: S T.

description: I went to A16 with two old college friends.  Wow, am i old enough to say "old college friends"?  Anyhoo, when you walk in you wonder if you will be able to hear people sitting next to you since the front of the restaurant is so loud.  You also wonder if you care about not being able to hear because all of the girls at the bar are really good looking.  Towards the back of the restaurant where they seat you is quieter.  Its a date place, a fancy date place.  The calamari was good but small, the pizza was good and huge.  Cost wise its not bad for the Marina, I would come back.
author: Marc M.

description: Was the food good? Sure. Was the service competent? Yes. Was it worth having to make a Monday night reservation a week in advance and driving across town? Not really. Was it unlike other Italian food I've already had or could make at home? No.
author: Amy E.

description: From what I hear, you're lucky to get a table hours later. In my case, I was extremely lucky as I was able to get a table only 15 minutes later. I tried various items on the menu but didn't get a chance to try their pizzas which I hear is the best. Unfortunately, I only heard this after I saw a delicious looking pizza float by. I loved their beet salad but I am a beet fanatic, the sand dabs were cooked to perfection, seafood pasta was delish, and almond cake was devine. Definitely worth swinging by to try for a table when in the Marina or making reservations in advance, but not worth waiting an hour for unless you're not hungry yet=:)
author: Sabi M.

description:
A16 is great.  From Chestnut Street, it appears to be nothing more than a small restaurant of no more than a few tables, but it is much longer than it is wide.  

We walked in here around 9pm on a Thursday night and managed to get a table within 15 minutes.  I had already had 2 glasses of wine, so I didn't exactly need another.  I skipped right to dinner and I ordered the flank steak, which was a little on the rare side, but very good.  Their entrees come with a side dish, so I selected the the romaine and chicory salad.  Not wowed by this.

For dessert, I had a bit of dolce-de-leche gelatto, which was a nice refreshing end to a good dinner.  I still need to try the pizza here because I've heard many amazing things about it.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
