I recently moved to the Marina and had heard great things about A16.  The first time I tried to go (without reservations) I was told there would be a 3 hour wait.  Fast forward two months later and I was able to walk in, at a peak hour, without reservations.  Telling??

Started with the Mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini - definitely enjoyable.  The meal was off to a great start - but that's about where it ended.

Next - Funghi Pizza with roasted mushrooms, smoked mozzarella, grana padano, garlic, oregano, wild arugula, olive oil.  

It was dry and under-seasoned.  Lacked taste.  We asked for a side of tomato sauce - hoping that would possibly improve the taste of this pizza (it was a white pizza - but very dry).  The service was slow - the tomato sauce arrived about 10 minutes later, at which point it was no longer even desired.  

Their wine menu was pretty extensive - but the prices were steep for the serving size.  

Next time I'm hoping for a fun pizza place in the Marina - I'll head to Delarosa.
author: Nicole H.

description: I love the pizza here! The crust is delicious and the chili oil they bring with the pizza is great, gives it a nice kick. The atmosphere is so fun and it is a great place to bring friends. Some people complain that it is too loud, but I find it festive. The olive oil that is served with the bread before the meal is the best around - it is grassy and peppery at the end. I always try not to eat too much bread so I have room for my dinner, but that olive oil always gets me. I personally find the food here better in the spring/summer because I enjoy the seasonal offerings more (the fire roasted corn with black pepper is wonderful). If you are not able to get a reservation, you can always come right when they open. I have found that the hostesses are very accommodating and will squeeze you in if you ask nicely.
author: Dana H.

description: I finally ate here and had a delicious pizza and a nice glass of white.  I'd go back to have an early dinner at the bar.  Pretty good!
author: Chris P.

description: I once ate with Carlo Petrini, founder of Slow Food, at A 16 and he said it was the best Italian meal he'd had in the US. But that was nearly 6 years ago, maybe more. This restaurant has been through a lot in the last few years, losing the two chefs who took it to the top of the list of America's great Italian restaurants. In late 2010 I had a couple of so-so meals there, but last month ago I stopped in on a whim and was very pleased to see they were back on their game. The salumi was great. The two pasta dishes we ordered were perfect as were the salads. The waiter was ace. He helped us pick excellent wines by the glass. I love the wine list there. One of the very best I have seen in the city for Italian wines, all from the southern regions, and the staff knows the wines well. It is pricey, loud, and often a very long wait if you don't make a reservation. But when they are on, it is well worth these little frustrations. I am hopeful A 16 is back!
author: Michael D.

description: Yes, I was in the Marina.  Not once, not twice, but many many times (gasp!) to eat at this wonderful restaurant.  The salumi is made with love and the burra mozzarella sends shivers down my spine.
author: Julie H.

description: I think one of the most over-rated restaurants in the City.  It is mediocre Italian food with a nice bar and a great PR person.  Good location and lively crowd are one of the few pluses of A16, how this restaurant has made it on so many of the "best of" lists is beyond me.  I have tried it several times each ordering different plates and was not wowed by any of them.
author: Katie P.

description:
I don't know why I love A16 so darn much.  

Maybe it's the foosball table that does it for me.  Or the cozy atmosphere, or the pretty people, or the wood-fired funghi pizza.  Maybe it's because I'm a sentimental sap, and once spent a idyllic evening here, or maybe it's because everyone else seems to love it so much.  

No matter.
author: Hannah J.

description: My benchmark for pizza (and I am an italian-raised pizza freak)  is margeherita. A16 gets 5 stars. The closest to my absolute favorite, Neapolitan pizza. Not that this means it is an absolute best, but it is incredibly close to the real stuff and it IS good!. I haven't checked the rest but the menu seems very appealing and so is the wine list (donnafugata was my choice and I did like it). So far the best margherita I have ever had in my 6 years in California. Nice atmosphere - I was there for lunch on a Friday - and good service. I'd like to check it out more thoroughly, looks very promising.  One of the few Italian restaurants I liked so far. I cannot rate  the place 5 stars because I reserve it only for absolutely memorable experiences.
author: Donato M.

description:
The food is wonderful, but the restaurant is chaotic and stressful.  Mind you, I did go there on a Friday night, but there was no rhyme or reason to anything.  We had to wait almost 45 minutes for our table, and we had reservations (that I had made a month prior).  We decided to wait outside since it was so congested inside.  The host could visibly see us, but failed to come and let us know when the table was ready. We had to continually check back with her until we were finally seated.  It was a little easier to relax once we were at the table, but things still felt a little rushed.  The service was mediocre as the waitress did not have a strong grasp of the menu, and the menu itself was a little difficult to decipher.  The placement of the items and the food descriptions did not do the food justice. 
The tomato sauce on my fresh maccheronara pasta was amazing.  Simple and flavorful just like you'd find in Italy, and the fresh gnocchi that my friend ordered was equally lovely.  The portion sizes were perfect and you felt completely satisfied at the end of the meal-not too full.  
I probably won't come back though-too much work!
author: Angela N.

description:
I've eaten here twice; once, a year and a half ago, and i had a good meal, though was seated along a tight busy corridor. went there again last night with family, and its unfortunate to say, but we won't be going back. the service was not in sync. started off on a bad foot with our waitress that didn't introduce herself or tell us the specials. was redeemed by the friendly sommelier who picked us out a wonderful white from marche. then, while we had already started eatting and our wine was poured, the lady from the front desk that sat us wanted us to get up and move to a different table across the room. what?! the restaurant wasn't busy yet because we were the first seating, and we said no. none of us had ever had that happen, and i never witnessed that when i worked at bacar. last night, i even asked friends that are career waiters if they had ever done that, and they said never if someone is already eatting. 

we finished our appetizers, and then the waitress tells us of their only special which is a starter. i thought that was strange to mention while the bus boy was removing our first plates. i actually enjoyed the irony of that.

the pizza was excellent. the gnocchi was NOT gnocchi. it was mashed potatoes. my ziti dish was salty. tripe was supposively just okay. dessert, cannoli tasted fine, though it wasn't authentic. basically, the cenus was the meal wasn't true italian - which is a v.big deal to other italians, but probably not so important to the general population.
author: Alexia P.

description: Great!  We were just there, on a Monday night, on a holiday, and late (arrived just before 10pm).  We sat at the bar, and had a pizza, the salumi plate, several different wines, and a couple desserts that were paired with some superb dessert wines.  We'd had dinner earlier, so can't vouch for the full dinner experience, but I'd go back and sit at the bar and eat and drink any time.  Tim the bartender poured us some excellent wines and treated us right.  Loved it, and a perfect end to our day.
author: Chris B.

description:
My friends and I didn't have a reservation but we were able to get a table because we got there around 5:30 p.m. half an hour after opening time.   We ordered bruschetta with porcini, beet salad, pizza margherita, porcini pasta and panna cotta for dessert.  The meal was phenomenal.  This was the first time I have ever tasted fresh porcini mushrooms and wow!    The chef cooked it just right.  The pizza margherita was the best I've ever had.  And the panna cotta was heavenly, the perfect ending for a perfect meal.  The only complaint is that they really undercook their pasta.  I love my pasta al dente but theirs was almost raw!  

Update: This weekend I went there with the same group of friends.  The place was humming with customers.at 5:30 p.m.  Porcinis were not the menu this time so we ordered the beet and arugula salads, a prosciutto taster, a tripe appetizer and a pasta with rod cod.  Most everything was as expected.  The salads were very tasty and seasoned just right.  We all loved the beet salad.  The most memorable part of the meal for me were the prociutto and the pizza margherita.  I never knew prosciutto could be so tasty.  It wasn't salty and chewy like some other types I've had which proved that those were probably low in quality.  The pizza crust was thin and chewy and cooked perfectly with just the right amount of burnt spots.  The perfect amount of tomato sauce kept the crust from becoming soggy.  Then came the pasta.  I thought the pasta I had last time was just a fluke but the pasta was raw again.  Even our waiter agreed that the pasta was raw.  Pasta should not be crunchy.  Unfortunately, even though the pasta was cooked right the second time, the dish was too fishy for our taste.  To end the meal, we had blue bottle coffee and yogurt panna cotta.  The yogurt panna cotta was not as good as the ones they made with cream so I was a little disappointed.  But it was still good.  I have to come back to try the porcini mushrooms again!
author: Allysam C.

description: I had a terrible experience here. We had a reservation, arrived right on time, then waited for an hour before we were led to our table. The hostesses were extremely dismissive, and the service from our actual waiter was pretty mediocre. We had heard great things about the food, and so we were hoping the wait would be worth it. Unfortunately, this was not the case. The food was pretty uninteresting and some of it was overcooked. I think this restaurant is very popular because it is "cool" and  is part of the Marina "scene", so if you base your dining decisions on image, this is the place for you. If you want some good Italian food, decent service, and a nice atmosphere, look elsewhere.
author: Marina M.

description: Convinced some friends to come to my 'hood since im usually at theirs to watch football/bbq on sundays because they have the direct tv sports package and we're all in the same fantasy football league.  anyways,we went to A16..the wine selection was excellent, but the pizzas came out soggy.  I've been here a few times before and the pizza was much better when they originally opened.  The buffalo mozarella (burrata) is still good as an appetizer and a great starter with a nice bottle of vino.  The rest was okay, but not memorable.. sad since the ambience is so nice and inviting.
author: Frank K.

description:
(Lunch review).  To be fair, I wanted to come here despite the lackluster reviews so was hoping to be thrilled.  However, I walked away disappointed by poor service and very mediocre food.

Overview
Highlights
+ Walnut gelato.  They get half a star just for this.  The walnuts were chunked up and were candied which gave a crackly sugar texture to the gelato.  Fantastic.
+ Olive oil served with the bread had a nice and subtle taste.

Drawbacks
- FOOD:  The mushroom pizza was AWFUL.  To be fair, the margherita did look better, as did the meatballs.  My major complaint was that the bread was simultaneously too soggy and thick.  The pizza kept sagging but was rather doughy as well.
- SERVICE:  Had to ask for bread; waitress kept on trying to take my check even while I was still having dessert; basic requests were barely met.
- DECOR: Very average.  No charm.  Back patio looks like a converted shanty town.
- MINOR PREJUDICE: I saw that the two single-occupancy bathrooms were gender-specific, which seems ridiculous in this social climate.  Seems overly biased against transgendered individuals.  (I'm not transgendered, but things like this give the Marina the vibe it has).  This is admittedly nitty, but I just wanted to raise the issue.
- UNRESPONSIVE FOH: I think the service was bad from the get-go.  The maitre'd was chit-chatting with her friend for 5 minutes.  When I checked in, she told me they were setting my table. Her chit-chat continued and 5 minutes later, only when she saw that I was still waiting there, did she seat me.

Don't think I will return any time soon.
author: Jeff A.

description:
What a fun restaurant! Plus great service and great food! We had a reservation at 8:30 on a Wednesday and the place was still slammed!! But for as busy as it was the service was exceptional! Our server, I believe his name was Nicco, was very nice and attentive. 

The Villa Dora wine was delicious...got the recommendation from a yelp review of this restaurant...so thanks!

Definitely check this place out!
But word to the wise...make a reservation!
author: Christi B.

description:
Eeeeh. I didnt like this place so much for several reasons

Pros:
1. Got a seat at the chef's counter and it was cool watching them do their thing
2. Nice ambiance
3. Friendly waiters and staff

Cons:
1. Extremely over-priced food. Like a lot. I mean, $11 for small pieces of burnt toast and  cheese? Not so much...
2. I really had no fucking clue what I was eating. A friend ordered on behalf of our party and they came out with some weird potato thing, some other weird mashed up fish thing, and said burnt toast. 
3. I know they were busy, but they took HELLA long to get around to getting our orders.
4. Sitting at the chef's counter with a party of more than 2 is a hassle b/c the seating ended up being awkward and not good for conversation. It's hard to talk down a line of people. 
5. We got the pizza (the last one on the menu) and it was highly unimpressive and over-priced
6. I got a Bellini and for someone who never drinks (this is my 3rd drink in my entire life) it tasted like champagne...
7. I felt really really young there and extremely out of place. Everyone there seriously looked 35+ and they were drinking wine and the place ONLY offered wine. It was obviously catering to a certain crowd, which is fine, but I dont think our party really knew that going in...so we all kind of felt out of place

So yeah. I probably would not be going back until Im like mid-40s or something...oh and if I have $$$
author: Dustin H.

description: When you can get in this place is decent and the ambiance is good, however, I have tried time and time again to make reservations at this place and the only time that is ever offered is 5:30, 9 or 10 PM. It never fails, size of the reservation doesn't matter either. Make an effort to visit but their hostess service is lacking...
author: Brandi b.

description: Well, this is one of the best things that has happened to the Marina in years.  The food is simple, but very thought out and extremely tasty.  One of my favorite dishes is the Baratta fresh Mozzarella.  Once you've had it, it is hard not to order it every time you go.  Also, the Pizza is traditional thin crust and the Romana w/o cheese might be my favorite. And the wine list is a work of art from southern Italy and reasonable.  But my favorite thing about A16 is the people that work there!
author: Steven S.

description: Atmosphere was nice- very cozy and a fun bar/ restaurant-- but the service was less than expected. The waitress was unfriendly and unapologetic. Food was good- it's cool that you can see the chefs servin' it up in an open kitchen.
author: Monica N.

description:
I really, really like A16. The only reason they don't get 5 stars is because it is always a bit too warm inside, which can be uncomfortable.

A16 is consistent in everything - service, food quality, atmosphere, etc. I have yet to eat anything that I didn't like - except for the octopus salad, but I don't like octopus anyway.

The tuna appetizer is one my favorites and all of the pizzas are great. For entrees I tend to get the halibut or whatever the special is that day. Let your server pick wine to go with your dishes and be sure to order dessert. The gelati is heavenly.

You need to make reservations to get a table here. If you can get there between 5:30 - 6 on a weekend night, you won't have to wait more than 20 minutes for a table. Otherwise, you are looking at a long wait. 

Note: If you check out the menu for Perbacco, you will notice that there are a lot of the same items as on A16's. Since A16 has been around longer, I have to argue that Perbacco copied A16. Too bad they weren't able to copy A16's service and delicious dishes!
author: Rachelle P.

description: It pains me to give A16 only 3 starts, because all in all I had a great time here.  The service was very friendly, the atmosphere was warm and energetic... but the food didn't leave me wanting more.  I had the maccaronara and we split the corn, the pepper/tuna app, and a salad.  All were well-flavored and fresh, but I haven't really craved any of it since.  I do recommended A16 for groups or dates, however  - definitely a nice atmosphere.
author: seema s.

description: I love, love, love this place.  Great atmosphere and the food is amazing.  Be sure to try the corn (when in season) and the pizzas - cheap, delicious and just like what you would expect to get in Europe!  Just as a side note - this place gets really hot, so don't wear a heavy sweater!
author: Margaret C.

description:
this place is amazing!! everything we ordered (2 appetizers, pizza, wine and dessert) was excellent. light on textures and rich in flavor. pizza was the best i have ever tried and their desserts are truly exceptional.

you can get a table right away without a reservation if you come early enough, right when they open. the back part of the restaurant is actually very spacious and relaxing.
author: alisa o.

description:
I cannot describe the amazing evening my boyfriend and I shared here!  There are no words!  If you want to be surrounded by staff that knows EXACTLY what they are doing at all the right moments - Go to A16!
We went to celebrate New Year's eve - and couldn't have been surrounded by more wonderful people.  Every member of the staff - ever efficient, warm and friendly.  It was like celebrating with honors!
The food was unbelieveable, - the pasta dish SHINED in our 5 course meal.  Props to the pasta guy ; )
The wines selected for us were decadent and unforgettable with each dish.  The all house toast at midnight brought tears to my eyes promising a better new year for all.

Thank YOU to ALL at A16 for the stellar evening!  We will be back soon!
author: A W.

description: A 16 had been on my list of places to try ever since I saw it on Iron Chef America. Anyway, I finally made my way to A 16 (without reservations) a couple of weeks ago. I arrived around 8 on a Friday night and was told there would be a 45 minute wait, but was pleasantly surprised after being seated 15 minutes later.  The atmosphere inside the restaurant is great, its pretty loud, and very crowded... maybe not the place for a romantic meal, but a great spot for a trendy night out. Originally I had my mind set on pizza, because I had heard so many great things, but after looking at the menu, my eye was drawn to the pasta's... the only real solution was to forgo appetizers, split a margherita pizza and order a couple of pasta's. The margherita pizza came out first (and very quickly) and it was very good, but I have to admit, Pizzeria Delfina has them beat here. However, the homemade pasta is heavenly and it will bring me back to this restaurant in the near future. Also of note, they have an Italian lager-style beer which is great and a must try ($5). Overall, A 16 is "win" in my book, good service, great food, and a lively atmosphere... if you can snag a reservation, there is little left to be desired.
author: Nick C.

description: This is a favorite of mine. Consistently good food and friendly service. The pizzas are always good. The entrees change frequently, but you can always count on a few very tasty options being on the menu. Try the burrata for a real treat. And let them pick the wine. You will not be disappointed!
author: Sarah L.

description:
Heres the drill:

- sit at the bar

- order a glass of wine

- share a few of the dishes that are cooked in the wood burning ovens...

you'll leave fat and happy!
author: Mak F.

description: We visited A 16 on a Friday night with a friend from San Francisco. He suggested it so we let him order. He sold us on the tripe starter. I agreed, but after eating it I wished we would have tried something else. It was just a little chewy for me. Next he ordered the Salsiccia pizza. He went off the menu a little with this one and asked for an egg to be on top of the pizza. It was an interesting addition and very good. After the pizza we had the Maccaronara pasta. We actually ordered two of this dish because it was so good. It was seriously one of the best pasta dishes I have ever had! Finally, we had the Chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil which was very tasty and unlike any other chocolate tart I've ever had. If I make it back I would stay away from the tripe, but everything else was great!
author: Michael P.

description: This place is so overrated! The pizza is fine, but I think A16 has been built up a bit too much. Make sure you have reservations or the wait is ridiculous. Oh and god forbid you ever have a large party and sit in the back room. You will be treated like lepers and you will be hustled out. Sorry, I just don't get all the fuss...
author: Jen L.

description:
I so wanted to like this place.... sigh...

Ambiance :  A.  Great vibe, lots of energy, cool bar, brick walls.

Food:  So hit and miss.  

Bruschetta with eggplants :  A-M-A-Z-I-N-G.  If Ieft after this dish I would've given 5 stars.  Huge slab of egglplant (we're talking an inch thick), huge slab of heirloom tomato, and delicious home-made cheese.  Generous portion size.  My only complaint was that with such generous toppings the bread got weighed down and soggy and wasn't able to hold up.  

Mushrooms with Kale:  Good, nothing amazing.  Needed a little salt.  Hard to mess up mushrooms.

Pizza Romana and Margherita:  Toppings aside, my hubby and I had the same complaint - the crust was a little soggy and had lost all it's crispness.  The dough itself was also kind of bland.  I found myself pouring on the chii oil or trying to dip in salt just to give it some flavor.  After trying Pizzeria Delfina the week before, A16 just couldn't come close to measuring up.  Sad, b/c I had heard good things about their pizza.

If I go back, I'll avoid the pizza, stick to more appetizers, and maybe split the meatballs - heard those were good.  Do I need to go back?  No.  Not worth the $$$.
author: Casey M.

description: Filled with obnoxiously loud Marina-types. Service was slow and disinterested (as noted by many others). Food was mediocre at best. Wine selection is woeful. Went once; never need to go again
author: Tom F.

description:
From the moment I walked into A16 I was greeted with very friendly people who saw to everything I needed. I was seated promptly (with a reservation) and given water and bread right away. We had a table close to the kitchen and it was great to watch them at work. We ordered a pizza for an appetizer which was excellent (I love the sauce) and several other items on the varied menu. One person in our party was unhappy with the dish he ordered and they very graciously brought him something else without any fuss. The waitstaff were wonderful and the food was delicious and very interesting. 
I will be back.
author: melinda g.

description: Absolutely Fantastic!  The ambiance is a crowd pleaser!  The price moderate, and the food and service fantastic.  Amazing how simple food can be so tasty.  I love the different array of meats on the salumi plate, the earthy rustic pizzas, the amazing texture of the spagetti, and the chewy tomato-based tripe.  Great choice of Italian wines.
author: Ruthie K.

description: Great pizza and apps... but the service was just terrible.  The server was surly and their wine expert was downright nasty and not helpful (we work for a winery so we were not clueless).    Its too bad because its cozy and local but there are too many good food places in San Francisco with great service to deal with this.  Unfortunately, I would like to just say this was an off night for them but this has happened the last few times that I have brought friends and clients there.  I wouldn't go back or recommend.
author: devorah d.

description: It's my go-to place.  The burrata and margarita pizza are a must everytime.
author: pablo e.

description: Probably the closest you will get to true Southern Italian food with out having to get on a plane. I've been there now a dozen times and can say the meals and service have never let me down. Like everyone else the pizza is great, "Meatball" Mondays are a must, and a great wine list. The staff is knowledgable and on their game 7 days a week.
author: Ryan P.

description: I brought my 82 year old Italian father there... he cried it was so good.  Unaffected, fresh food.  Great staff - very welcoming.
author: Mark A.

description: The best Pizza, the whole meal was amazing, the wine pairings were top notch. Service was over the top. Had a reservation and were seated on time. The deserts were amazing. Can't wait to come and visit it again soon.
author: neil l.

description:
I've never written a review on here before- so that should tell you how disappointed I was after my meal at A16 last night.  
Complaint #1-  Escarole and sunchoke salad- had no escarole, but what appeared to be iceberg lettuce.
#2- On the menu given to us- the pork entree said it included 3 pork items- porchetta, sausage and ribs.  What came to the table were 2 small spirals of sausage on top of arugula.  When my husband asked where the rest of it was- the server told us- oh, it's only sausage tonight.  My husband then said, "what happened to the other 2 things?".  She said, "well- there's only supposed to be one other item, they must have run out".  She did not offer a substitute or even apologize.   
#3- Then dessert menus come out.  We ask the server (a different one now) the flavors of gelato.  She says, "milk chocolate, and caramel".  She says that she absolutely LOVES the caramel flavor.  So- we order it.  What she failed to tell us- is that it's SALTED caramel.  That's a pretty big thing to leave out of a description.  
This was my second time eating there.  The first time I went was not long after it opened.  I thought it was over rated then, and feel the same way now.  I will never go back, and will never recommend this restaurant to anyone.
author: jo k.

description: I had heard for some time that I had to check out this place. Kind of out of the way for me, but I figured I would give it a go. I have to say it was dissappointing. The food seemed overcooked and the presentation was lacking, especially for the prices. The server did not know the answers to several questions we had and did not know anything about the wine. The plus side, the atmosphere is cozy and warm, the dessert was very good. Honestly, I probably will not go back.
author: Alicia A.

description:
I headed to A16 with my husband to celebrate our anniversary with high hopes on all of the hype I heard about this restaurant. I was very disappointed. First, the service was so impersonal. I felt the lady serving us our dinner really didn't want to be there. I do have to say that the Italian wine selection was very good and I was happy with my selection. However, my glass was just a little more than a taste at $14. 

Both of our entrees were very simple and my seafood was just that with a very thin sauce and nothing else. I feel I should have more to offer on this place but I didn't come away with anything else. I can think of 20 other restaurants (including Salt House or Piperade) that I should have chose for our special night. Never felt welcome and won't be back.
author: Christine G.

description:
I came here with a friend on a Thursday night and was told the wait was an hour and 15 minutes....low and behold, it only took 45 min to get a table.  That was a pleasant surprise, since there isn't much waiting room within the restaurant.

The food was delicious, but the service was a bit slow.  I highly recommend the mozzarella burrata.  The flat bread pizza is also yummy.  Overall we had a good dining experience and will definitely be visiting again!
author: Kelly G.

description: Ok. Just if you don't expect an Italian restaurant.
author: Francesca C.

description: Warning - this is a mixed review! First time I went to A16 shortly after they opened I thought the food was incredible. Everything from the burrata (my favorite item on the menu) to the pizza was delicious - and the wine list is incredible and well-focused on Southern Italy (a much overlooked wine area up until that point). On subsequent visits, however, the service was lacking, and the pizza was way too thin - and I lived in Italy for 5 years and ate pizza like drinking water - and A16 was too thin and basically collapsed on the plate. All the flavors were good, but it just didn't stand up like before. The burrata thank god is still good but there's a bit too much attitude and resting on laurels right now. They've done wonders for Southern Italian wines and that I applaud, but what's going to bring me to the Nut if I've got Delfina Pizzeria now? Tell me.
author: Mariangela S.

description: Perhaps I'm missing something.  I just don't quite understand all the fawning over A16.  I love their pizza, but other items on the menu--pasta and entrees in particular--are not very impressive.  And while the service is pretty good, I find the staff to be quite pretentious.  My last dinner at A16 just made me miss Delfina.  Thankfully, I've got reservations there for next weekend.
author: Sharyn F.

description:
The service is good (I sit at the bar) and the gal bartender always has a smile.  Food is good, not great but better than the other pizza in the Marina.  But the people who are regulars truly believe their perspiration smells like a fine red wine.  In other words, the regulars are just a bunch of arrogant wannabes.  

But do not let the regulars stop you from stopping in.  Positives far outweigh the negatives.
author: Allan B.

description:
i took my italian family from nyc here. they picked this place out, otherwise they would never let me live this one down. embarrassing to call this an italian restaurant. service was ok. food, horrid---apps to dessert. literally, everything was terrible. pastas were overcooked, undersauced. two different apps (tuna conserva and the pork liver) both tasted suspiciously the same----like cat food. 

another reason to stay away from the bland cookie cutter marina district. get better italian at arinelli pizza. man, i %$#@ miss nyc.
author: kristin p.

description:
A16 is one of my very favorite restaurants. I have 4 favorite restaurants, and they're all in the same category of haute Italian dining: Pizzeria Ortica down south, Osteria Mozza in LA, and Perbacco and A16 in San Francisco. Pizzas and pasta that are in a different category than your Italian-American, Buca de Beppo tomato fests. The flavors they feature are the bitterness of greens, the tang of olive oil, and the zing of calabrian chilies.

Don't miss A16 if you love food.
author: Tim H.

description:
Good food and wine.

Started with the calamari, quite tasty. They had a good wine list, from which we had nice bottle of Zinfandel. For my main course, I had the scallops, cod and mussels -  good, although the scallops were very small. My girlfriend had the arugula salad and zucchini which were also very good. The cannellini beans side dish was amazing - highlight of the night. Dessert wine and service were good - overall nice dinner.
author: Adam C.

description:
Had a few wrinkles here...but I really liked my food so I'll give it 4 stars.  

I made reservations over a week in advance. When we arrived, we were told it would be 'a few minutes.' To make a long story short, 30 minutes later we were finally seated. By the way this was on a Thursday, not even a weekend night. What made the unnecessary wait in the small. cramped front bearable was the fact the hostess was extremely accommodating. She updated us frequently on the status of the table and even gave us free glasses of the house sparkling. I was impressed with her level of service. 
We sat in the back...tables are very close together and it is very noisy. That was expected on my part so I didn't mind. I ordered a special, which were lamb crepes in sauce, they were really delicious. My aunt got a pizza which was good from the bite I had. She only likes plain things so it was just Margherita...nothing special to me but still good. Loved the grilled polenta and the walnut honey dessert. I would definitely go there again and give them a second chance. Hopefully the waiting thing was just a fluke...
author: Jamie G.

description: I love this place, but then, I'm friends with them, it makes me a little biased. Still, some of the best pizza in the city and my absolute favorite wine list - Update- the fungi pizza has had a makeover and is even closer to perfection than before, tiny mushrooms of every form, oyster, trumpet, shitake and cremini all earth and musk. It's fragrant with garlic and drizzled with peppery new seasons olive oil. It is a must order, as is the fresh buffalo mozzarella baratta, all white purity and a  heart of cream.
author: Stellah D.

description:
food was ok but the service was absolutely terrible.  we had sarah as a server and she was so rude!!  the table next to us felt the exact same way -- as soon as she would leave their table they would half-laughing exclaim about how "curt" she was.  we chimed in that we felt the exact same way.  while ordering, she walked away in the middle of one of our questions about the menu. before we finished out meal, she came in and abruptly took away our salt/pepper shakers.  normally this would be ok, but it would be nice if she would say, "excuse me" i just need to grab this.  instead she just comes in during the middle of our conversation and dashes off with them.  nothing ruins a supposedly nice meal more when the topic of conversation is mainly focused on how rude your server is.

as for the food, let's just say there is better out there.  we ordered 4 dishes and only margherita pizza made an impression.  it was a little burnt so this made parts of it inedible.  we won't be going back again, there are just too many other places to go to.
author: Brian I.

description: I frequently wind up meeting business friends here, but I like Terzo a little better.
author: Anna G.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco! The quality of the food and wine list is top notch and I love the decor and back patio. Truly delicious assortment of great Italian foods.
author: Sara W.

description: First of all, let me preface this with the fact that I love, love, love A16. I've been eating there for months (for lunches and dinner) and think Nate Appleman was a genius and well deserving of the James Beard award he won.  Plus the fact that they've continued to be incredible even without him makes me love this place even more. In fact, I've loved dining there on Wednesdays when they typically do their weekly pork butchering in view of all to see as the kitchen is wide open and there's a great counter where you can really get up close and personal with their techniques. One day, however went a little too far. I was sitting in a booth (at a business lunch) facing the counter/kitchen and all of a sudden the person sitting next to me says, "oh my God". I look up towards the kitchen/counter and see a pig snout still attached to its head with a hand saw stuck in the middle of the snout. Wow. A little intense but no big deal. Then, one of the chefs begins sawing and sawing and splits the head right down the middle (through the snout) and the sound was horrible - something out of a horror movie. Not only that but when he grabbed either side of the head and pulled the two halves apart I could have vomited. The sound was something akin to a melon being separated and this along with the visual was a little much. I was unable to even really touch the pasta dish I ordered which came out right when this was happening. It had pig trotters in it and while it was technically the other end of the pig, I just couldn't do it. Thank God I had the amazing and wonderful fresh ricotta bruschetta w/ grilled asparagus before and the chocolate budino afterwards. I think I may have to skip Wednesday lunches and go on Thursdays and Fridays instead.
author: Erin H.

description: Had a quick bite to eat here before a long night of drinks. A friend and I were lucky enough to walk in and get a table for 2 within 15-20 minutes at 8:30 on a Saturday night. The wine was incredible and the staff knows their stuff. The mozzarella burrata was unreal, I could have eaten an entire plate myself. The lamb sausage with a side of fried potatoes were excellent. This is definitely a date spot or where you go to have a nice long relaxing dinner to catch up with friends.
author: melissa g.

description: This place is spunky and loud, so don't plan on convincing anyone of anything over dinner - they won't be able to hear you.  The meatballs are worth the dodging and weaving (tables are close together and it gets CROWDED).  No distractions or heavy sauces to mask the ball itself, just tender, flavorful ball of meat that made a superb appetizer for the table.  Pizza toppings were innovative, blending just right.  We spent the extra money on the pancetta.  I was dubious about adding more meat to the sausage pizza, but it made the topping combo soar.  Gnocchi was just ok.  I would certainly return for the pizzas - take your friends and share a few.
author: Lauren S.

description:
My wife and I were excited to try A16 - we had walked by it several times and loved the ambiance, and had heard some good things about the pizza as well.

And I must say, the ambiance is the only thing that did not disappoint.

Quick summary of our grades:

Host stand: D
Food: C-
Wait staff: b+
Ambiance: A-
Value: C-

Food summary (each suggested by our server):

Arugula salad with nectarines - bravo for the idea, boo on the execution.  The fruit was absolutely lost in a sea of over-dressed greens and ricotta.

Chicken - was juicy but terribly over-salted to the point where you really couldn't tell if it had any other flavor beside salt.  And yes, I know, who orders chicken out?  It was by our waitresses insistence that we gave it a try - she claimed it was really one of their best dishes.

Margherita Pizza - last thing to come out, and we were really excited for it, the reason we came.  My first bit in and immediately the first thing I thought of was Enzio's frozen pizza which my mother used to buy when I was a kid.  Except Enzio's crust was crispy.  This crust was flat and soggy from an over abundance of bland tomato sauce.  The mozzarella was sparse and unimpressive, and the basil just a token 2 leaves.

If you want to read about our hostess experience, read on.  Otherwise, you get the drift. 

It is a shame because the place does have great ambiance.  But food and friendliness wise, there is really no reason to go.

Hostess experience:

We walked in and were met with a very chilly reception from the hostesses, who upon further observation seemed like they were either:
-not wanting to be there
-felt like they were too good to work there

The job of the host stand is generally to make you feel welcomed and comfortable - they were indifferent and aloof.  (Note - and its not like we came in wearing shorts - we were both dressed to go to a nice place).

We did not have a reservation (it was Monday), so they said it would be @45 minutes but they would take our phone number and call us if we wanted to walk around (the bar was packed).  No problem.  But 50+ minutes later and no call (we had gone somewhere else for a drink) and I suggested we try back, only to find a few open tables.  Guess they had not gotten around to calling.  Or didn't care.  But at this point it was 9pm on a Monday, so it would have been nice to get a call when they saw a few tables opening up.
author: michael d.

description: Went last night and they were slammed. Good but not great food, surly service from a woman who would not smile. This evening could have been so much better with just a little effort.
author: Jim C.

description: A neighborhood gem!  Went with some friends who are local and had a wonderful dinner.  The food was fresh, simply prepared and excellent.  The service was wonderful.  Worth going out of your way for a simple, elegant dinner in great setting away from the tourists!
author: Brian S.

description:
I've heard really nice things about this restaurant and I've been wanting to dine here for quite a while. When I read all the so-so reviews I thought, "What's up with that? Lighten up, people!" And then we ate there. And now I understand. 
I have to say this was the poorest quality meal I've had in years. That's including the taco trucks and Chinatown. 
I'm not even going to waste my time with telling you what we ate. The food was unseasoned, oily, poorly presented and overcooked beyond belief. I was thinking maybe if we had ordered pizza we might have been okay. Then I looked at the table next to us and they had this poor little white anemic, bendy thing that I guess was supposed to be pizza. When we were served one of our appetizers, I thought of this line we used to use in a kitchen I worked in, "What'd you do, slice that with a hammer?!"
So disappointing. I wanted to purge and go back to my neck of the woods and have dinner somewhere decent.
author: Pam O.

description: The food here is commendable and the restaurant is elegant. The one thing that went wrong was that our server sniffed our bottle of wine after she opened it. That was rude and bizarre. That one act almost ruined our whole dinner experience.
author: Kelly L.

description: I cannot write a full review as I only stopped in here to see the restaurant and sit at the bar for a bit with a couple glasses of wine however, it is a beautiful place.  Our bartender was kind and kept our glasses full even attending to many other people on a crowded Friday evening.  I am looking for ward to having dinner here very soon.
author: Steven K.

description:
What is all the hype about?  Our experience last night was under whelming, from the time we walked into the door until we paid our bill.

1.  we had to wait 35 minutes past over reservation to be seated.

2.  super crowded, loud and tables are on top of each other. hard to hear the person sitting across from you.

3.  food was over seasoned and below average.  i don't like a cup of salt on my food, the "over hyped pizza" was disappointing and pasta was flat.

only props is the extensive wine list.

I won't  be visiting this spot again given all the other better options out there.
author: Tracy Y.

description: Best Italian in the city for me! Pizza pizza pizza and all that good vino!  Try the octopus pasta if they ever decide to put it back on the menu, it is delish and don't forget meatball Mondays!
author: Torres F.

description:
An update to my previous review, which is below: the service is improving a little, so I raised my grade from 3 to 4. However, I lowered it back to 3 because the bread totally sucks - it's flavorless and dry with a mediocre crust. Why can't they use Acme, Thorough Bread, or Tartine? It probably costs jus a little more and would make a world of difference. Better yet, bake some bread in the wood oven!

The food here is good, but the service is just okay and the hostesses are usually frantic and have a snotty attitude. If the front of the house were run as well as the kitchen, this would be a fantastic restaurant.

Another frustration: no takeout.
author: Look and C.

description: So I had the Margarita Pizza, the Mozzarella cheese plater, and the meatballs. They were all good but not great. The issue I had with all dishes, Too SALTY! If they put less salt I think the dishes would be real good. The meatballs were sooo moist and the cheese was good. The famous Pizza was ok.
author: Karen T.

description: Liked this place...fun interior, yummy food and great wine.  Ditto to _Not M_ about the mozzarella starter...ridiculously tasty.  A lil' noisy but that's to be expected in this trendy marina hot spot.
author: Allison K.

description: Wow, I was really surprised because the place and the people look really good, but unfortunately, the pizza doesn't even come close to being good.  Try Rose's or Pizzetta for some good pie's.  And yes, I'm originally from NY so we call it PIE's, the cool way.  Anyways, if you think you're hip and trendy and are a typical American snob, this is the place for you.  I give it 2 stars because of the people watching.
author: Mitch A.

description: Food was okay, nothing spectacular.  I believe my recent trip to italy did spoil my taste buds and wallet though.  The pizza we happened to get was "pretty good' but that's about it.  The service was good, but menu was quite short.
author: Emiko M.

description:
Grilled calamari with fresh favas, ramps, garlic and potatoes $11
Margherita Pizze - tomato, mozzarella, basil, olive oil $12
Funghi Pizze- mushrooms, grana padano, garlic, oregano, parsley, olive oil $15
Maccaronara with tomato ragu and ricotta salata $8
House-made pork sausage with Chioggia radicchio w/roasted potatoes $20

I've been waiting over a year to visit A16 and although the food was delicious when we were there, I think it probably bore on the company moreso than the cusine. No complaints on the calamari, but nothing else stood out. The funghi pizze was okay, although I prefer my pizzas with sauce. Although it was loaded with mushrooms, I didn't feel as though the earthy flavor was brought out in the preparation. The margherita was exotic with a drippy sauce, visible pools of olive oil, as well as sparse slices of cheese. Upon first examination, I thought it gave the pizza a very homemade feel, which tends to be a good thing with me. I then realized that it didn't add much to the flavor, and was less thrilled with the super thin floppy crust [although it was probably supposed to be like that]. The maccaronara was good, but nothing special. The pork sausage did nothing for me and the radicchio's bitterness didn't really do much to bring out the flavor in the sausage. The potatoes were one of the highlights of the meal. When it comes down to it, I'd rather get my pizzas from Dopo, pastas from Oliveto, and sausage from Top Dog.
author: Monica T.

description: Started with the mozzerella burruta  and then the house cured salumi. Both were delicious and a must try. Then we went on to the classic Pizza Margherita.  The service was wonderful and we got seated pretty quick. Can't wait to come back.
author: Juliane N.

description: I've been here twice and I'm sure I'll be back again. Good pizza (sausage), appetizers, dessert and service. Their main courses are good but not exceptional. I brought the family here the second time around and our waitress was very patient with my cranky elderly grandmother...a tough feat for most us.
author: Raya K.

description: Cute little spot.  The Pie was great.  We ordered the Margherita.  It was delicious.  The sauce was perfectly seasoned and the crust was thin and crisp.
author: Delilah B.

description: I had a great lunch here on a recent trip to SF We started with some simple dressed greens, then shared the braised meatballs, I had pasta with tomatoes, squash blossoms and ricotta salata and my friend had the eggplant bruschetta.  We finished with the yogurt panna cotta and I had a cappucino.  This is regional Italian cuisine done very well, perfectly prepared, simple ingredients that let the flavors shine through.  Reminds me of Al Forno here at home.  I liked the neighborhood vibe of the place and the way they gave a to-go container of water to a pug who was waiting outside for her mommies.  I'd go back for dinner.
author: Heather B.

description: This was some of the best Italian food that I had in a long time.  The pizza and chicken meatballs were delicious, and I even tried some lamb from my friend's plate which was also devine.  We got to sit at the Chef's counter which ws very cool since you can watch all the behind the scene action, although I will say that it got a bit hot sitting in front of the wood-burning stoves.  The wait can be very long if you do not have a reservation, and for a Wednesday night, the restaurant was packed.  But everyone there was in good spirits and having a great time.  Service was attentive and good, with our waiter offering good suggestions for food and wine.  I would like to try to go back when it is a little less crowded, but that may be quite a feat since the restaurant is excellent.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
No, no, no... I do not understand the hype about this place besides the cute ambiance, nor how they have loyal following of patrons.

I was extremely excited to dine at A16 since it is so "highly regarded" in San Francisco. The food was BLAND! It really fell flat and lacked flavor in every dish... nothing to savor, no ohhs and ahhs, absolutely nothing lit us up with excitement... just flat, boring, bland

We had the calamari; everyone recommends it, no flavor, good concept, but no flavor.
Then the lamb meat balls... ehhh I have much better ones before and the pickled vegetable salad in the middle was all wrong and no good.
We had the gnocchi as well and yes the texture is PERFECT but the flavor is NON-EXISTANT, I was dying for more kick like kalamata olive or red pepper... something to savor.... I wish the sauce had been better or stronger...

I really don't understand why this place is rated as such.... I was terribly disappointed.... and we really felt robbed by the bill at the end of it all... I DO NOT RECOMMEND A16.... and if you have never been before, I do not suggest you bring guests for your first experience if you do decide to check it out.
author: Beebe J.

description: Waaay overrated, so sorry to say, because the staff is really nice. I went three different times just to make sure, and I won't be going back, despite the fantastic wine list. The food wasn't that interesting, and it's very loud & echo-y, especially if you're seated on the patio next to a loud group with high pitched voices, which has that fingernails on chalkboard effect.
author: N B.

description: Nice, very drinkable selection of largely Italian wines by the glass, priced a bit high, but all the wines I sampled were not only drinkable, but in nearly all cases very good. Pizza is wonderful in a very Italian sort of way, with suprisingly acidic tomato sauce. The Wild Boar Salami is a must. In fact, all the food was very good, and the seats in back on the counter along the kitchen are great fun, allowing you to watch the chefs work their magic. Get a reservation though - its often crowded.
author: Don H.

description:
3.5 Stars..
We finally went to A16 last nite and because of all of the mixed reviews on here, we  were hoping to just judge for ourselves..
Well, it turns out that most of the folks were pretty dead on.. 
Here' the breakdown:
-Started with the Mozzerella Burrata that everyone raved about and let me just say that I completely AGREE.  It was to die for and not to be missed...  Who knew that something so simple could be SO flippin' good?
-Then we had the Funghi Pizza with Pancetta, which D thought the crust was the best crust that he had ever had..  LOVE Pancetta!  i would totally marry it if I could.. We both thought that although it was good, it would have been better if we had gotten the Margherita with the Pancetta..
-Next we had the Scialatielli with local calamari, zucchini, basil, chiles and pinenuts which we thought was just alright...  We shoulda had the Maccaronara as everyone suggested..
-We ended with the Roast Lamb Loin and the Cannellini Beans for our side which were both nothing to write home about..  Honestly, we could've done with out this part of the meal..

The service was good, as was the wine..  We are both no connoisseurs when it comes to wine and we did not recognize much on the wine list, but the bartender and servers were very knowledgeable and helped us choose..  As far as the loudness, we sat in the very back room which was great, because it wasn't so loud back there and we could actually hear one another..  
All in all, a 3.5 experience..  the 1st half of the meal was great, could've done with out the 2nd half..
author: Rose C R.

description: My first meal was over two years ago,and it was good. Subsequent visits were not as good. If you're nearby, getting brows/nails/waxing/massage done, just stop by to drink the wines on their wonderful non-California heavy list, perhaps a nosh to slow the buzz, because unless you live in that 'hood, it's not worth the trip for just meatballs.
author: Rene D.

description:
When we moved to SF, this was the first place we went.  It also just happens to be down the street from my place.  No reservation?  Expect to wait at least 2 hours.  The restaurant is long and the back exposes the entire kitchen so every seat feels like the chef's table or close to it.  Not a great spot for big groups but would recommend for a date or small group.  

Wine list is long and impressive and if you don't know anything about Italian wines just ask because they are able to point you in the right direction.

We will need to go back for meatball night!
author: elizabeth s.

description: I've only been to this spot once and it was terrific. I had the marinara pizza and the beef short ribs. Good thing I convinced my friend to order the short ribs!! He didn't to, but I was dead set on them! They were sooooo good. It was just the meat off the bone, so tender and tasty. I have dreams about that dish (I'm not kidding) and I will definitely go back to have some more!! I just wish the place wasn't so crowded!
author: Angela T.

description:
I have had an unusual experience with this place. I don't know what happened but I have been here about 5 times before my more recent visits this month. I always thought it was good, but nothing truly extraordinary. I honestly don't know what happened,  but I have been converted, I have seen the light. Call it education of the pallate, but I am now a believer.
My lovely wife and I, after waiting a very long time (still won't take the rating down because the food is so amazing) were seated at the chef's table, that is, the table that faces the chefs where you observe in awe the chefs working their magic while you enjoy your company and your meal. This possibly could be what changed my mind about this place. After observing how everything is prepared, it became evident that this is no ordinary pizzeria. I knew that this is one of few places certified by some Italian pizza agency (forgive my ignorance, I don't know all the details) .When I observed the art of how the pizzas are made here I understood what a far cry they are from anything else you'll find in this city. The ingredients are of course fresh. The key though is the wood burning oven. The pizza is first gently topped with sauce and a light sprinkling of mozarella (again, so different from "our" pizza) and then topped with whatever you order. The magic happens in the oven, where wood is tossed in to keep ambient temperature. The pizza maker then hoists the pizza towards the top of the oven in its final stages so that it absorbs some of the smoke from the fire. This adds a very nice smoky, earthy flavor to the pizza. It is then topped off (after removing from the oven) with final ingredients like prosciutto that do better melting into the pie than being baked to a crisp in the oven. Sprinkled with some pepper oil, you have a truly amazing pie, even for those of us who are traditional West Coast pie lovers.
So last night I was very hungry and decided to have a pizza as an appetizer and the beef short ribs for my entree. I again watched this all being prepared, which is entertainment by itself and was once again amazed by how good the food was. Absolutely delish. The side potatoes that came with the beef were absolutely to die for. Just perfectly seasoned. The real treat in this whole experience, as I've mentioned above but will say it again here, is watching the chefs. I also learned that the main entrees are also cooked in a woodburning stove. They put the dish in a frying pan and slide it into the stove where it bakes to perfection. This is truly a unique way of cooking. The guy who runs that station is simply unbelievable. By himself (with occasional help with the olive oil or small toppings) he manages to prepare dish after dish, knowing exactly when to remove each from the wood burning oven, visibly scalding himself just a little bit each time. Think about this for a second: he single handedly prepares almost every dish that leaves that kitchen in a restaurant packed with 100 or so people at all hours of the night starting in the early evening. This is not to say he is the master chef, as he is not. It is a humbling act to watch though, this guy has got it going on in a big way. When things slowed down just enough for him to take a swig of water I could not resist the temptation to yell to him (had to yell as unfortunately it is very loud in there) my compliments, of which he was very modest and grateful. It's worth noting that all of the chefs in there clearly know what they are doing and seem to enjoy what they do, even when it seems like that would be impossible, being as busy as they are in a hot kitchen under all that pressure. Wow. That's money well spent.
author: Matt H.

description: Food's great -- had the mozzarella burrata referenced by other reviewers and they are right -- it's delectable.  So soft and flavorful, literally melts in your mouth.  Our service was great, very attentive woman with a huge tattoo on her forearm.  Contrary to other service comments, she didn't rush us even tho the place was packed.  Had the lamb -- awesome and the side of cannellini beans, really incredible.  The only downside: the banquet along the wall opposite the open air ovens/kitchen made us feel like we were IN the oven.  WAY too warm.  If you go, ask for a table in the back so you don't roast...
author: Ryan D.

description: Every time my boyfriend and I come to town we make a point to make a reservation here. By far one of our favorite spots in town. We love the atmosphere and the food is just as amazing! Awesome wine selection, we love the half order option for pasta and the pizza is fantastic. You have to start with the buratta cheese starter, it melts in your mouth and tastes divine. Always a great night out, great service, great food, book in advance and still be prepared to enjoy some wine while you wait!
author: Erin P.

description: A16 is a hot restaurant in this seaside neighborhood. The restaurant is named for the motorway that goes through the Italian region of Campania in Naples. The setting is dark enough to obscure the cover-up on your zit but light enough so that folks can see the colorful food.   Read more: http://www.ballyhoo.us/restaurants/review.cfm?review=96
author: Baochi N.

description: Good wine selections if your in the mood. The food isn't as good as people make it out to be. There are much better Italian choices out there. Very busy even on a Tuesday night, make reservations.
author: Jen J.

description: After reading all the reviews below I'm just not sure what the hype is about.  The food was okay, with decent portion sizes and tasty enough.  I like that you can order an entree for an appetizer.  The service, though friendly, was very slow.  We had regular entrees, so maybe we missed out on the pizza.  I'd say at best it was an average restaurant experience, but not someplace to go for a special occasion.
author: kerry l.

description: Oh. My. God.  I love this place.  The pizza and tripe are fantastic, and I almost died over the burrata.  The only thing I was disappointed about was their red wine flight - I should have stuck with what I know and like.  Mmmmm.
author: Serena Y.

description: I've been here twice so far, and if it was closer to home (I'd live in the south part of the city), I'd go more often. Yeah, I don't like the Marina vibe, but that's fairly easy to overlook once you get past the crowded front bar area. Pizzas are tasty and large, yum. My major complaint about the food is that when I ordered a small version of one of the pasta dishes, it contained about five noodles -- skimpy. Service is attentive, though, and the setting is pleasant, if a bit crowded.
author: Tara M.

description: 3 1/2 more likely, but given how the ambiance is and the comfort level, I'll give 4 to boost its ratings.  The pizza was great.  A must try.  It's thin w/ a layer of cheese and toppings.  Very well done, I must say.  I also had the pork and beef meat balls and they were these small 4 meatballs, which wasn't very fulfilling as an entree itself, but nevertheless good.  IT was marinated in this tomato sauce w/ cheese on top.  Hey, put anything w/ cheese and I'm game.  Dip some of the bread w/ the sauce and it's heaven.  Like the ice tea, very fragrant and sweet w/ out adding sugar which I like.  There's a back patio, which was bright during lunch time and it's just a relaxing place to be in.
author: AhLin C.

description: I like the setup here. Nice dark setting with cool high rise tables and chairs. (I've never sat in the back). The wine list is comprehensive and the food, especially the Roasted butternut squash, is good. It seems like the wait will take forever but I've always gotten a table within 30 minutes. I usually leave my cell # and walk around Chestnut until my table is ready.
author: Deepak J.

description: Apparently you can't get a table here, so I didn't.  I went to the bar and sat down and had a delicious meal.  I got the braised beef and my lady friend got the pizza and something else.  Braised anything is pretty awesome, and everything else pleased me, if you know what I saying and I think you do.
author: Julian M.

description: This is a 3.5 star review....i'm going with 3 stars instead of 4 since it's so hard to find parking in the marina. The food is pretty solid, but not spectacular. The noodles are well-made, the ingredients are fresh...but nothing especially memorable.
author: j d.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. While occasionally the service is sub par, the food here is second to none and the wine list is reasonably priced with outstanding selection. 

My wife and I frequent the restaurant weekend evenings. While actually getting a reservation is nearly impossible, waits for a party of two rarely actually exceed an hour if you arrive before 7pm. 

We typically get one or two appetizers and then split a pizza (best in the city) and a pasta, followed up with the chocolate budino tart (best desert in the city). The meatballs on Monday are also excellent. 

For the quality of the food, I think the price here is unbeatable, i.e. $10 appetizers and $20 entrees.
author: Mike S.

description: A16 is only a block away from my house and is my favorite pizza place in the city and has a great ambiance.  They make perfect super-thin Italian pizza, which is hard to find done right.  I suggest adding arugala to your pizza, it is fabulous!  Great wine selection as well, with really helpful servers and bartenders for wine suggestions.
author: Britt M.

description: I normally really like A16 and their pizza's.   Last night, the food was good but the service was horrible.  We were served our wine AFTER our dinner.  I think the waitress would have forgotten about the wine alltogether but we asked the gentleman who brought our food about it.  Overall-  a very poor experience.
author: Lisa P.

description: We come here for dinner every so often and always have a pleasant meal. The salumi platters and pizza are always great to start with and I'm a huge fan of the pastas-- with the squid ink cavatelli being a favorite. I've had the flounder a couple of times and wasn't disappointed. And the service is attentive and the prices fair.
author: Jennifer S.

description: If there was a 3.5, I would give it to them because it is GREAT pizza and friendly service.  However, the hype that has surrounded this new marina spot may be slightly over the top.  I've eaten there 3 times, all good, but nothing spectacular.  The pizza and wine are always the highlight! I know it's not escape from New York, but the Pizza is UNBELIEVABLE!
author: Sarah D.

description: Pizza is good, I just have to steel myself to make it past the scene atmosphere.  Hopefully, everyone will find someplace else soon.  Until then, it's still worth a trip across the city every once in a while.
author: Beth V.

description: There is no great pizza in San Francisco.  The hunt continues.
author: Jean C.

description: A16 has great food! The new Chef here is doing some great things. If you're interested in some great new takes on Italian check A16 out. It's really a pain to get a reservation here - so, make sure you plan early. The wine and service is top notch. Aim for the pizzas here - they're probably the best thing on their menu. I was disappointed with the Lamb Dish - it was okay, but a little less tender than lamb should be.
author: Dan M.

description:
a little noisy and hard to get a table [the bar is good for walk-ins, however], but the pizza and wine are delicious

this isn't your average pizza either, it's authentic with just a little char, fresh ingredients and flavors you wont find anywhere else

[having driven and eaten along the A16 a few years ago, i would know]

just be prepared for the difficult parking and all the banana republicans in the marina- otherwise, enjoy yourself
author: Charles C.

description: Yum, yum, yum.  I always start with the gooey fresh mozzarella and some of their house-cured meats, which are so good I tend to be delirious by the time the mains roll around.
author: Alison C.

description: Maybe it's me or maybe I was simply comparing it to the hype.  But this restaurant just didn't do it for me.  The food was good, not great like I had heard.  The wine was ok.  The ambiance nothing special.  Maybe I will try and go again to give it another shot.
author: Amanda P.

description: Excellent service, superb wine selection, and tasty food! Definitely try the Gnocchi, it's the best I've had!
author: Amit V.

description:
THIS IS 3.5 STARS

my lady and i went for a celebratory meal, and i was pleasantly surprised because  #1 - we are not into the marina scene, #2 - i hadn't heard of the place.

this is what we found: 
1.  very gracious hostesses (giving us prosecco when we had to wait for our table), 
2.  an excellent manager - blonde small woman who chatted us up about wines and life, 
3.  great wine - although our server rushed us and didn't take the time to tell us about the wines - 
4.  which brings me to her... the server - a tall thin woman with awkward mannorisms, unfriendly and annoying (but we noticed that everyone else's server seemed great, the busers and runners were also great - so no hard feelings),
5.  the food ranged from good to great:  good were the beet + potato salad and the veal meatballs, very good was the blob of cheese on crostini, great were the squid ink pasta and the ALMOND TORTINO... maybe the BEST DESERT I'VE HAD IN THE WHOLE BAY AREA.  almond warm cake, bitter almond gelato - not too sweet and a little tart, with some fresh nectarines.
6. the atmosphere was TOO loud (and i usually never care about this) but cozy
7. lastly i'd go back, maybe sit at the bar or inside for a late or early meal... or just coffee/wine and ALMOND TORTINO
author: Erika Y.

description:
the crowd is a bit older (i'm late 20's and i felt like a kid).  the temperature is way too high, let's invest in some A/C?  i was sweating the entire time. there's no music, but there's also no need since the chatter level is at a 10.

the waiter was very unpretentious, the wine was real good. the pasta was mediocre at best, the pizza was delicious, and the experience was something you had to have.

i took elsie here for her bday and we had a great time. i like the glasses that the beer comes in, it felt like a large graduated cylinder.
author: Ameer N.

description: I admit that I had certain assumptions about this place based on the fact that it is on Chestnut Street -- need I say more? -- but I was pleasantly surprised by the crowd.  The service was just a teeny bit slow considering that we got there earlier in the evening, but not enough to put a damper on things.  Wine by the glass, pizza and a side of butternut squash was delicious.  But, I had to wait forever to get my leftovers wrapped to-go.  The most memorable thing I had: the olive oil.
author: Tamara M.

description: Although I typically 100% agree with my good friend Helen Y (who happens to be the dang most popular yelper I know), and despite this place being filled with super-Marina types, I do like this place. Mushroom pizza is good, roasted butternut squash with toasty bits of garlic and pine nuts that melt in your mouth are delicious. It can definitely be overrated, but the bar is a good place to sit, and I heard reece witherspoon ate here two nights in a row. and if she likes it, it must be good.
author: Jenny R.

description: Their pizza is so light and delicious, not too much salt in the tomato sauce. I could eat it for breakfast lunch and dinner.
author: Carson H.

description:
I caught it on off night, I hope.  
Warning: this is gonna be whine-y.  
It was a tuesday, usually an easy night... yet our table was not ready, the server took 10+ minutes to stop by, her comments were not really suggestions so much as dismissive, condescending rebuttals to our questions.  
As Rachel G. said, I was enamored with the mozzarella Burrata.  Luckily I dont worry about cellulite.  Hooray for being a man!
As everyone, including their olfactorally-deficient cousin has said, I ordered the fennel sausage pizza and it looked, smelled, tasted...well tasty.  But I wouldn't put it far above pauline's or tommasso's necessarily.  
The meal really took a turn with the maccarona Ragu.   The pasta was fresh and well made, but the sauce tasted like chef boy-ar-dee.  So, maybe chef boyardee just isn't getting his due credit? and he is really cooking and canning authentic Campanian cuisine?  Is that what people will think of Wolfgang Puck in 30 years: he's just some hack making canned soup, ...oh wait, i ALREADY think that.

Maybe Campbell's was a great eatery and we just forgot?  I wonder if there is some family in England who reminisces about the days when critics fawned for their tomato soup.
Well, I did some research, it's not the case.  According to wikipedia, "a gifted chemist with degrees from MIT and Gttingen University, Germany, developed a commercially viable method for condensing soup by halving the quantity of its heaviest ingredient: water."  So really wolfgang is the only lame guy since boyardee.

The bottom line: GF's Birthday+bad service+chef boy-ar-dee+$100 tab for sour experience+bad table in middle of room= not so happy couple, especially the birthday girl.  

we should put that server on a bus and send her back to Naples on the A 16.
author: Christian W.

description: We had an enjoyable dining experience here last night. The beet and arugula salads were delicious and the bianca pizza was excellent.I especially loved the crust. The service was friendly and helpful.
author: Barry G.

description: Dinner with the girls at A16? A fun and upbeat restaurant. The wait was quite long, but after a couple of drinks and my delicious pasta, I was a happy girl.
author: Lisa C.

description:
received a gift cert from a friend. very excited and reserved this 2 weeks ahead.

arrived there, staff was cold, not friendly at all. I don't know if it is because we only ordered 2 glasses of wine instead of bottles. I don't look that young, felt I was treated like either too young to come to this place, or just because we are Asian. (we were the only 2 Asian ppl that entire night probably)

Starter was good, octopus too salty. Pizza was good, veggies on the pizza was way too salty. Squid ink pasta was just ok, was hoping for the ink in the pasta, not the ink in the pasta sauce. Pasta was under cooked.

Ordered meat balls ... $ 22 for 5 meat balls ... what the ... :-P it must be good right? not really..... don't even want to look at the desert either .. just wanna leave after all the salty dishes... and with their cold faces, I did not dare to send any dishes back.

Over all, very nice place to sit in. Food is just ok ... and too $$$.... lastly .. why are the staff more friendly to those who ordered bottles of wine ?

We were disappointed.
author: Joe H.

description: Ok, this is one of my favorite restaurants in town.  Yeah, it's in the Marina, but I can contently deal with that issue once I walk through the the front door.  The dining area has an open kitchen so you can watch all of the talent going throughout your dinner.  One of my favorite parts about this place is the service.  What we normally do is order to eat family style.  We also order each course as we go.  They have amazing italian wine, so ask your server to pair each course.  You can order by carafe or 1/2 carafe vs by bottle if you are into trying a different wine with differerent courses.  Everything on the menu is delicious, so try it all.  Do make sure you order the homemade buratta and a pizza of your choice. Bon Appetite!
author: Erin B.

description:
I found A16 to be good, but not great. The food was good and efficient but certainly not spectacular - as a matter of fact, that could be said of the entire experience, food, decor, service. 

Also, I will note that the night we were there, the place was very crowded and the ambient temperature in the dining room must have been well over 80 degrees - not a pleasant experience while trying to enjoy dinner. Perhaps they could invest in some sort of air circulation gizmo (fans?, A/C?) - Lord knows from the crowds and the prices, they could afford it.
author: Jason W.

description:
DO NOT BUY GIFT CERTIFICATES HERE!! We were given a $200 Gift Certificate for this restaurant. We had a nice dinner, with a total bill of about $150.00. We presented the $200 gift certificate and were told we could not use it for tip or gratuity?!?!?! Who does this??? The whole point of a gift certificate is that it is a gift to someone else to have a nice night out and not spend ANY money??? Only after compaining to the Manager did they agree to use it for tip. Ridiculous!

I think the food was ok, apps and pizza, are very good, the remainer were ok. We had a very long wait 45 min between finishing main course and getting dessert, way too long. I know the chef is good and it is a trendy place, but not sure we will return.
author: Donald S.

description: I was very disappointed in A 16.  I admit that I am older than the average customer that frequents this restaurant.  I knew that it is a trendy spot but, I didn't expect to not be able to hear my dinner partner.  So loud!  More importantly, the food was a huge disappointment. The appetizers were fair but the Margarita Pizza tasted like cardboard.  The best part of the evening was the bartender who suggested a very good Italian wine for me after I described to him what I like to drink.
author: Nancy R.

description: I just don't get it.  The food is okay the space is fine, service is good...but nothing exceptional.  Place is always packed so clearly I am missing something.  Make reservations in advance bar area gets filled within the first 15 min they are open.
author: frank m.

description: If you enjoy classic italian food and a great wine list you must go here. Reservations are a little hard but you can always show up at the bar and eat there. The neopolitan pizza has the best crust of any pizza i have ever had(i lived in nyc for a while so i have some experience with good za). The mozzarella appetizer is to die for and the macaronara pasta dish is just plain awesome.
author: Not M.

description: This is a really fun spot, especially if you like good light pizza,  good wine (the co-owner/wine guide iw friendly and really knows her stuff), and a bustling atmosphere. We opted to sit at on the chef's line (a few seats that basically overlook the kitchen) and spent the entire time marveling and the goodies they were concocting in the back. Definitely a fun way to go if you're out with a friend!
author: Lindsey B.

description:
The pizza is pretty good and authentic with the super duper thin crust, but the service is horrid. We had such horrible service that my boyfriend just wanted to leave without getting his change back because he didn't want to deal with our flighty waitress. The place is very crowded and loud. If you have to eat in the Marina, this is probably one of the better places. Just be prepared to be extremely patient and ask to be seated out on the heated patio.

***UPDATE 6/14
This place has the funniest people watching. Did I miss the "first Match.com dates only" memo?
author: Mama L.

description: Best pizza in the City by far. If you are searching for pizza like they make in the Old Country, then you will love A16's pizza. The crust is perfectly balanced between doughy and crispy and the toppings are super fresh. The marinara with pancetta and arugula is a must have along with a glass of Casavecchia. Don't let the long list of Italian wines intimidate you. The staff is so knowledgable and eager to make suggestions to help navigate their wine list.  I'll be back!
author: Joslyn D.

description:
One of my friends brought me to this restaurant this past Tuesday (around 7PM). Although I'm not a huge fan of Italian food and saucey dishes, we decided to give this place a whirl anyways. We were proptly seated at the bar in the main room (no wait) in front of the brick oven and prep line. At first glance, the restaurant is on the smaller side, long, with rustic decor, nice outside patio and 'family-style' seating.  Everyone was primarily dressed in the 'Marina-uniform' but hell, so was I for the night.  

The wine list was VERY impressive and can not gush enough over how HUGE of a fan I am of the 1/2 bottle carafes they have to offer.  The sommelier was even nice enough to come over and explain to us his favorites and how the list is formatted. '...the complexity that some of the Italian wines carry with them are unparallel to most California wines....' How true how ture... 

Our waitress was also very friendly and even swapped out our side plates before every course...service points.
