My friend had been here a few times before so I let her order a few small plates, a pizza, and a pasta dish to share (Prosciutto and beet salad, tripe, mozzarella burrata, garlic/anchovy pizza, and mushroom pasta.) I rarely go to a restaurant and truly enjoy every dish; the tripe was my least favorite and I don't even like tripe! The fresh ingredients are highlighted in every plate and are unmasked by heavy sauces and butter. If you're a fan of Olive Garden Style pasta swimming in their signature butter/cream/tablewine slurry, I'm unsure whether to recommend this restaurant to you. I've never been to Italy therefore can not preach to you if this is an 'authentic' Italian restaurant, however I think their approach to food is uncompromising and refreshing. The only thing I was slighty dissapointed about was their pizza; the one we had ordered had a thin crust (+++) but had no cheese on it. (--).  Delicious, but felt it was lacking.  For a restaurant that boasts a certified pizzaiolo chef, have had better a better pie in town (DELFINA!!).  Nonetheless, I can't wait to go back!
author: William R.

description: OK... 2nd visit not as good as the first.  First trip was probably worthy of five stars; killer service, creative -- yet soulful, romanesque grub.  Second visit, service was team-oriented, never knew who to ask for what, and the wine steward was aloof.  Food was every bit as good as the first, but due to a lack of attention on our servers part, there was no delivery, no timing... dished showed up haphazardly by the hands of a runner with no sense of time.  Hope the new place on Nob Hill fares better long-term -- I really do like their food!
author: Don N.

description: Amazing.  The best gnocci I have ever tasted, and the ziti with sardines is unbelievable.  If you like meat, this is your place.  Try the devil's gulch porchetta and the bresaola.
author: Bill B.

description: Went there last week. The service was most excellent and I found it to be very reasonably priced. We had an $80 bottle of Italian bubbly and the whole meal for four was $250 including tip. Granted we didn't have appetizers but we did split deserts. I wasn't blown away with the food but overall it was a good experience.
author: Nathaniel R.

description:
All of my recent reviews have been glowing and gushy and I don't want people to get the wrong idea about me. You know, that I'm all giggles and easy to impress. I'm actually one of the most obnoxiously picky people I know :) and very proud to be so. Having that said that, I felt it was time for me to write a review that wasn't so scrumtrillecent. 
 I haven't been to A16 in a while but they were the first place that popped into my head when I thought "Which restaurant in recent memory would I not give 4 or 5 stars to?" The last time I tried to go there I was with my entire family and was told by the hostess on the phone that they did not take reservations for a party of 8 but if we came in soon after they opened we might have an chance at being seated. After dropping off the kiddies with the babysitter we rushed to make it over to A16 before 5:30. We were told the wait would be 2 hours. Thanks, informative hostess person. I'm glad I stubbed my toes running down my apartment stairs in order to toss myself in the back of my brothers Suburban to hear I would have to wait 2 hrs for a table. No thanks.
 The time before that, my husband and I went out for a nice dinner date and waited only 15 minutes at the bar. We had a nice glass of wine at the bar while we waited. Somehow, in this 15 minutes we got into the first and biggest argument of our relationship about what, I don't remember. All I remember is sitting down at our table and becoming that annoying bitter fighting couple who is having a horrible night and glaring at the waitress as if it were her fault we're having a bad time. I'm sure she and the other wait staff whispered about us back at the POS. Not entirely A16's fault but it's all I remember from that experience. I think it's ruined for me now. To our servers credit, she did not charge us a corkage fee for the wine we brought in and was always sweet and attentive during the lulls in the argument where we just sat back to glare at each other. So I can't be too hard on them. I think the food I had was good. Again, I don't remember. 
 And you'll all be happy to know, my boy and I made up the next day and have never had another argument in a restaurant again. I love you baby :)
author: Nuvia C.

description: I love this place.   They do authentic umbrian food, and the wine list is fantastic (and a good value too).   It's kind of a shame the place has gotten so popular . . . waits can be quite long even if you do have a reservation.  And yes, the gnocchi will rock your world
author: Stephen G.

description: A16 must be a code for overrated , in Italian. I am shocked at the throngs people that line up for bad service , overpriced wine , and so so food. We had some bresaola that tasted like leather and some overcooked pasta that took 45 minutes to arrive. Frankly I liked the place much better in its previous incarnation. The only reason that i gave it two stars is that the crowd in fun. Go for the scene , not for the food.
author: Brad S.

description: Good decent wine list, nice substainal food and a good hopping atmosphere.  We had reservations and after 2 hours were asked to leave....that was not cool.  But it was an indication of how well loved the place is by the locals on a Monday night.
author: Kim N.

description: We had dinner there last night. Food was good, though the almond/caper/parsley/lemon topping on my swordfish was WAY too salty. Vibe was pretty good (if you like an army of Marina striped shirts & flared jeans). Hostess not so much. Just not welcoming at all, and told us our wait would be 30 minutes, but then maybe 15 minutes later found us a spot at the "chef's table". The bar that looks onto the open kitchen. VERY fun to watch, but she didn't really give us an option, and I wondered if we weren't cool enough to get a proper table, so got dropped at the bar. Overall I like A 16 a lot. Can't wait to try SPQR.
author: Tony S.

description:
Yep. Overhyped. Service was very friendly and pretty efficient, but the food was...eh. Went with my man and split 4 courses.
Got the mozzarella burrata starter, nothing special. 
Sausage+fennel pizza with an egg was really good, never had an egg on pizza before...
The lamb entree was bad and just really bland. It tasted like nothing. It was rubbery. I expected maybe the lamb sausage would be better, but it wasn't. The side of potatoes was INCREDIBLY SALTY. Mayhaps the kitchen should start tasting food before sending it out with nonexistant/overzealous seasoning, eh? We each took a couple bites, winced, and left the plate 3/4 full.
The gelato was almond+stone fruit swirl, and choco-pepperoncini [sp?], and the sorbetto was grapefruit. All were mediocre, and I didn't particularly appreciate the burning sensation in my throat after swallowing the choco-pepperoncini gelato.
I spose the pizza was good, but nothing we'd go back for.
author: Skye L.

description: Just had our second visit to A16. Since they were in this months Wine Spectator for their Pizza AND recommeded for their pizza from a friend, we HAD to try it. Walked over and had the Cecamariti "husband-blinder" zuppa of peas, gigante and ceci beans, lentils, pancetta, chiles and pecori, - was absolutely amazing!!!  and the Romaine and chicory salad with lemon and olive oil - very tasty! Salsiccia - fennel sausage, spring onions, mozzarella, grana padano, garlic, chiles Pizza - soooooooooo good, great crust!!! Also, a bottle of the Neal Family Cab - SUPER! An amazing meal - again. Will return. Friendly staff, somewhat loud - but aren't they all? We did not get dessert. We stopped by the new icecream/gelato shop Tuttimelon instead.
author: Barbara N.

description:
not sure what the hype is over this place.  what's the big deal?  the food is ok.  the wine selection is pretty amazing.  tons of options by the glass.  but the pizza, which is supposed to be awesome, isn't that great.  we ordered the margherita.  it was pretty soggy, not really memorable.  i've had thin crust, crunchy, cracker-like wood oven pizza, and this just doesn't match up.  
if you're interested in a scene in one of the most generic neighborhoods in san francisco, go to a16.  if you're interested in some kick ass gourmet pizza, cross the bridge and head over to pizzaiolo or head down to sleazy north beach and indulge in some delicious tomossos.  3 stars for the wine menu and the good service.
author: kris m.

description:
I didn't have plans to stop and eat dinner on my early evening stroll last night, but when I passed A16 and inhaled the pleasing aromas of house made pizza and the wonderful fragrances that only a wood-burning oven can produce, my stomach literally growled and suddenly I was famished.  

A16 - named after the Autostrada Sedici (Highway Sixteen) in Italy that runs across the bootstrap from Naples to the ankle known as Canosa di Puglia - focuses on southern cuisine from the Campania region of Italy.  The city of Naples is the capital of Campania as well as the birthplace of pizza.  In fact, Neapolitans were among the first Europeans to use tomatoes as food, which were purely ornamental before someone discovered their many uses in cooking.  

Situated on the quiet end of Chestnut Street in Pacific Heights, this warm and inviting restaurant lulled me into a peaceful state.  Although I have heard the restaurant can be quite loud, the evening I visited was calm and subdued.  I took a table in the covered patio in the far end of the restaurant and sipped a glass of Prosecco di Valdobbiadene while I perused the menu.  I was craving hearty pasta and desperately needed to replace the memory of my last Italian meal (at a less revered establishment) when a lasagna Bolognese arrived with an unwelcome "ingredient" that was so revolting I had to send the dish back and leave immediately.  Moving on from that memory, I sat and thought about my new life in San Francisco - I daydreamed about growing herbs in the courtyard outside my new apartment, imagined riding my Cruiser bicycle through the city, and pictured myself sipping wine with my boyfriend as the sun sets over the bay.    

I'm not sure how long I sat there, lost in my own thought, but I was only shaken from my fantasy when the main course arrived; a simple and yet wholly satisfying dish of Maccaronara with tomato ragu and house-made ricotta salata.  Maccaronara is a hand made pasta that is long like spaghetti, however much thicker.  When cooked properly, it is chewy but not firm and easily wraps around a fork or spoon without splattering on one's crisp, white blouse.  After the pasta was gone, I sopped the remaining ragu with bread and left no trace that the bowl had ever come in contact with food.  

Not wanting the feeling of elation to end, I opted to slow down my usually brisk New York pace by ordering a cappuccino and the chocolate budino tart.  Drizzled with extra virgin olive oil and a sprinkle of sea salt, the bitterness of the chocolate tart reacted perfectly with the salt and sent me off into daydreams about whipping up a batch of my homemade dark chocolate turtles with fleur de sel.  

I hope to visit SPQR soon, which is A16's Roman counterpart in Pacific Heights, where I hear the food is lovingly created by the same chef, Nate Appleman. Named after the Latin phrase Sentus Populusque Rmnus, which translates to The Senate and the People of Rome, I look forward to exploring more of Nate Appleman's food and, of course, more opportunities to slow down and let myself be inspired to daydream.
author: T. L.

description: this is probably my favorite restaurant in SF, besides delfina, for pizza, yummy wine and a great ambiance. i always ask to sit at the chef's table, so we can watch them cook. the food is awesome and the chocolate budino tart is a must- have.
author: Jacin F.

description:
the 2 stars speaks for itself. i've had better.  i was excited to come here being that i've heard wonderful things about this place and the head chef nate appleman.  let's just say that this place was so "meh" that i couldn't bring myself to finish half of my food.  i don't even think i made it to a quarter. 

the pumpkin and ricotta gnocchi was surprisingly tough.  it was dense and not light and fluffy at all.  i had ordered it w/o pancetta but of course our server didn't feel the need to write it down because he insisted he can remember orders of parties of 12 and more and that jotting down a party of 2 was a piece of cake.  that lame nut not only forgot the pancetta but he forgot our wine... twice.  TWICE! 

my date's short ribs were on the rubbery and a bit on the salty side.  the best part of his dish were the cannellini beans w/garlic and oregano.  yum!

by the time our server came with the dessert menu, we had already paid and were ready to leave.  he had pulled the disappearing act on us that we had to flag down another server to serve us while he was missing.

i'm on the fence whether to come back here and give it another whirl.  i guess i just need to let this experience pass and see.
author: ann.ie k.

description:
If I had reviewed A16 based on my first experience, I would have given it 5 stars.  I had an amazing meal there my first time.  The second time I went back, the pizza was not how I remembered it.  It was soggy and burnt because the pizza was cooked too quickly, at too high of a heat.  

When I complained, I was told they could cook me another, and if it turned out the same, no problem, they would just take care of it.  Typically that means they take it off the bill.   When I got the check, the pizza was still on there and they looked at me like I was insane when I asked why.

Well the 2nd pizza showed up pretty much in the same shape, and the table next to us complained about the same issue with the pizza- the burnt and soggy combo.  Apparently they've eaten there many times and the pizza is hit or miss - it depends on who's cooking the pizza that night.

At the caliber of restaurant, I would really expect much better.

3 stars because I did have that amazing first meal, and the chicken meatballs were very tasty.  Oh and for providing a total Melrose Place moment - Daphne Zuniga was dining there with the mayor and his TVstar wifey.  Daphne has held up nicely.
author: Julie C.

description: I am sorry but I just don't get this place.  The wait staff seem to go out of their way to be rude and the food is spotty at best.  Yet it still stays packed and people fawn over it.  I have been three times and three strikes.  A16 you're out!
author: David L.

description: and it keeps getting better. The staff has introduced me to some of my new favorite italian wines.
author: Jason N.

description:
SICK OILY PASTA. Overpriced. 3 hour wait. Beware! Read this.

I went to this place last night with some friends. It was the worst eating experience of my life. In a nutshell: 3 hour wait for a tiny portion of disgusting oozing- with-oil Gnocci thats waaay overpriced. Now the details...

We called at 7:30 to reserve a table and were told that the wait would be for an hour. We arrived at 8:00, expecting to wait for a half hour and decided to hang out at the bar until we got our table.

Little did we know then that we wouldn't get our table until an astounding 10:30. Yes, 3 hours for a damn table. 

" Well, why then didn't you up and leave and go elsewhere"?? you may ask...
Because every half an hour when asked on the status of our table, we were told "oh, just a half hour more"... and this game went on until 10:30. I can understand they're busy that night, but in that case, shouldn't the staff give folks a more accurate estimate of the time involved. There's a huge difference between waiting an hour and waiting 3 hours. 

As a side note - this place has the worst acoustics. Maybe its something about the cork type walls, but everything is really loud in there even though its not that big. Its like you're in a dive bar, screaming to the person next to you to be heard.

And now for our main event. The pasta fiasco.

I ordered the large portion of the Gnocci (all their pasta dishes come in two sizes). To be fair, my friends who recommended the place, said to try the pizza, which was what they ordered. But c'mon, I've driven all the way from the south bay to the snooty SF Marina District,  I gotta have something other than PIZZA - and so i went with the Gnocchi which sounded really appetizing on the menu. Another person in our group also got seduced into the Gnocci. Forget about ordering the steak or the main entrees cos that stuff is really expensive. 
So anyways, my wife, myself, and two other people in our group went with pasta type dishes.

Boy do they sucker you at this ripoff joint. 

The portion size - SMALL. And i mean REALLY small for what you're paying. 

The quality of the food- Disgusting. Dripping with oil and salt and no flavor. One of the guys at our table who was also seduced into ordering this dish didn't even finish it and proclaimed halfway through that he'd lost his appetite. It really was that bad.

So you're thinking, maybe its just the Gnocci. Well....... no. My wife had ordered another kind of pasta and a girl at the table ordered yet another type. All the pastas were sad and less than mediocre testing. Like someone dumped a couple of spoonfuls of Ragu sauce over spaghetti. 

Everyone gets hit with a bad restaurant now and then and I've had a few as well. But this is the first time, where I came away from a meal feeling robbed and hungry - after waiting for 3 hours to sit at the table. 

You've been warned.

One extra star for the Pizza - my friends who ordered it did get a beautiful and unique looking pizza. To be really, er, tasteful about it, everything else about this place just sucks.
author: Dinesh G.

description: Love this restaurant. The service is excellent even amidst hectic crowds. The wine list is fantastic. And the server knew her wines! She recommended one that wasn't on the menu but was in the same family and price range we were looking for...it's always a thrill to find a perfect inexpensive bottle of wine, the way it used to be with Joseph Phelps! The alaskan cod was heavenly. Friday marked my second visit and this weekend will no doubt start of with another amazing dinner at A16!
author: Monika S.

description: Has a fun atmosphere, great wine list and is in a good location.  The pizza, as everyone agrees, is really wonderful.  However, I went here three times and had an ok, not memorable meal.  Then I went back with a friend who knew how to order and loved it.  Stick with the pizza, the fresh mozzerella appetizer, and the macarona pasta... veer off this list and you are taking a chance that usually ends up not so good.
author: Mary S.

description:
This place is saturated with conservatively dressed Anglo-Saxon yupppies.

Great thin-crust Neapolitan pizza. The rest of the food struck me as being pretty bland, although supposedly this is "authentic". The sole with almonds was quite literally that -- a chunk of seared sole with piece of orange  and  sprinkled with a few almonds -- not very flavorful. Excellent food-friendly wine list.

I'd come back here, but only for the Pizza.
author: Peter B.

description:
if yelp did half stars, i would give this place a 2.5.  there is a lot of rave reviews out there in the foodie world about a16, and many from people whom i really respect when it comes to opinions of the palate.  i have been to a16 twice and ii wanted to love the place as so many others have, but the food just fell short of my expectations.  

if you're just going for the wine bar and to be where the older but still beautiful "in-the-know" demographic are, then this is the place to be.  if you don't mind the occasional draft coming from the bar and don't want to deal with the long wait on the weekends, bar service is the way to go.  i've always done bar service here, so can't comment on the servers, but andrew who has worked the wine bar the times i have gone on the weekends is great at helping you pick out the perfect wine from an already great selection of italian wines.  plus, his wife comes and eats at the bar, which i find adorable.

now the food . . . i tried sampling the fully array of their offerings.  the good: i did love the olives and the mozzarella burrata (staples on their menu).  the olives were everything olives are supposed to be.  the mozzarella is incredibly creamy and is great as a filling for the salume they offer on their menu.  the pizza, however, which they are known for was an utter disappointment.  i ordered the funghi pizza on my last visit.  they do the thin crust thing but after having lived in italy, this pizza did not evoke any memories of the wonderful pizze i enjoyed there.  i also tried the octopus and ceci bean zuppa because i always love to try something unique and different.  it lacked the punch that i was looking for unfortunately, and i found the octopus to be overpowering in the dish.  

is this a place i would go back to?  yes, because all restaurants have off nights.  however, there is a lot of hype around those amazing pizzas.  you will have to judge for yourslf.
author: Jessica D.

description: This is some of the best italian food in the city. Focusing on the appetizers and wood-oven pizzas, everything is fantastic. It's a great opportunity to try new things also - the salumis, the tripe, the burrata. The only things I would say are less than great are the main dishes - they are absolutely good, but not as great as the apps, pizzas and pastas. Also, this has one of the best italian wine lists I've seen, organized by region. It's a must-go!
author: Franco R.

description: It still takes too long to get a table, but damn the pizzas are amazing.
author: Mike P.

description: Overrated. The wine list is great and I've discovered some gems but I have never been impressed with the food (outside of the pizza which is really good), the atmosphere noisy, and the wait (even with reservations) too long. Kept going back to check it out, always walking away with the same impression. Best bet is to sit at the bar and sample the wines with a Margherita pizza.
author: Michelle M.

description: I've been hearing great things about this restaurant so my husband and I went last night. It was better than anticipated. The gnocci was the best I've ever had. The wine list is to die for and there is a nice guy who is what I'm assuming is the restaurant expert. He helped us pick out a great Italian wine. Reservations are tough to make and the seating is a little close, but the food is great! Other Yelpers didn't have the best service experiences, but our waiter was fantastic. Definitely one of my favorites in the city.
author: Sarah K.

description:
Wow...AMAZING!  
First of all, you HAVE to try the Mozzarella Burrata appetizer.  It is out of this world.  The creamiest, smoothest mozzarella I have ever had...it was like butta'.  Seriously.
Aside from the deliciousness that makes me drool as I write this...I thought we had all-around fantastic experience.  The hostesses were SO friendly....our table was waiting and sooo romantic (okay, I have to admit it: it was an anniversary dinner)...the sommelier came over and was incredibly helpful in adapting my French palate toward the Southern Italian varietals...our server let us take our time and linger...
And, everything was sooo flavorful.  We had a pizza with pancetta and shared two small plates of pasta, a gnocchi, and another square-spaghetti that had been slow-roasted in pork and chicken broths.  (Forgive my lack of knowledge on pasta!)
The pizza was AWESOME (and I was resisting it)...thin crust, great ratio of real mozz cheese and fresh sauce, the gnocchi was okay (maybe a little hard?) and the spaghetti-type dish was out of this world--sooo tasty.  Meat flavored pasta without any large pieces of meat in the dish?  Probably a man's dream.  But I loved it too!
And, the wine...awesome.  As I said earlier, the sommelier was fantastic (Kevin) and he suggested we split a glass of prosecco to start as we looked over the wine list...so smart!  And they waive a corkage fee if you buy one of their bottles...so yes, we had two.
Regardless, overall, warmth and lighting were great, noise level a pleasant hum but no problem hearing across the table...laid-back atmosphere...
I highly recommend you check it out.  But don't go while on a diet...the food is just too good!
author: Emma H.

description:
I've been trying to go to this place for about 6 months - but can never get a reservation and the walk-in wait is always over an hour.

Last night, though, we had luck on our side. 

First, BF found parking within a block on the first lap.

Hostess quotes an hour wait, but we decided to stick it out. Were seated within 15 minutes at the cooks counter - which was great b/c i love to watch food prep.

Our waitress was great - really sweet and knowledgeable. She recomended a great wine.

Food- amazing!!!! We split the funghi pizza and the beef short ribs with squash as the side. every bite was amazing! I was very pleased and didn't feel like we were being overcharged given the quality.
author: Kay T.

description:
the food was salty and yummy.  between the 3 of us, we shared the runny mozzarella on toast (the name escapes me at the moment.  something like "burrata", i think), the noodle-y pasta with tomato sauce, the mushroom pizza, the meat dish, and the dessert with salt sprinkles.  all of the dishes were superb but i will say that the flavor and tenderness of the meat pleasantly surprised me the most.  it was better than l.a.'s lucques' version.

bf + friend had to roll me out but i'd gladly do it all again.  it was excellent.
author: Adela K.

description: Been there three times and every time has been awesome!  I like that you can go to A-16 for a big fancy meal or you can grab a pizza and wine for more of a low key evening.  Either way, the food is amazing and the atmosphere is great.  If you have a chance, sit at the bar that overlooks the oven and enjoy all the amazing dishes that go by.  The only down side of this is that you'll want to order everything.  So be prepared to go back again and again if you can't fit the entire menu in your belly on the first try.  ;-)
author: Will H.

description:
My god, is this place overrated.  Pizzeria Delfina wipes its ass with A16's menu.

The salad I had was probably the worst salad in a restaurant i've ever had, outside of maybe some diner in nebraska - lifeless, half-dead arugala (yes, much of it was yellow and pale) with lifeless but decent mushrooms and sad looking onions.

The Waitress was very knowledgeable about the thorough wine list, tho.  Recommended a decent dry fruity white, although not as good as Delfina's Muscato.  She was pretty good, i'll give her that.

The pizzas were basically lahore karahi's excellent garlic cheese naan bread, (not necessarily a bad thing) which isn't on the menu btw, whose toppings reminded me mostly of thai food (likely basil chicken even tho we had salsiccia) on top of said naan bread.  I feel I could have bought the two and put them together and had a better meal.

The pasta (that they have apparently had on the menu since they opened and was recommended) was a cross between a slightly fresher (and thicker) version of chef boyardee spaghetti and canned tomato sauce.  For $9.  For a half size.  As in the size of the palm of your hand.

Dessert?  Jello putting with sea salt and olive oil.  Wow.  Salt and oil on top of mediocre cheap tasting chocolate mouse.  You go gurl.  I want to rake all of my patrons over the coals and somehow make a business of it like this place.  Well, actually I don't but nice work if you can get it I suppose if that's your thing.  Want to know how they made the strawberry "gelato"?  Ground fruit roll-ups (with an extra teaspoon of organic white sugar for sophistication) and original capri-sun, flash frozen for your pleasure.  That will be $9, thank you.  Thank god we were there on an expense account.

This place takes "I could make this at home!" to a whole 'nother level, because, well, I actually could, which for the average San Francisco restaurant (which this place clearly is not) is saying alot.

The people who go here and think it's soooo amazing have obviously never been through the mission or other parts of town outside of the marina -- and by the looks of most of the clientele there, they obviously wouldn't be caught dead with restaurant staff with actual personality and the decor to match.
author: Ben H.

description: I love the FOOD at A16.  Nothing disappoints.  The pizza was so good, I didn't want to share any of mine with my boyfriend.  The tuna conserva salad was perfect, and I LOVED the chocolate dessert with the sea salt and olive oil!  Delicioso!  BUT . . . I don't know, maybe it's just me, but I found the clientele to be . . . rich. Like not my kind of people.  Totally nice, and cheery, and maybe I was the one feeling insecure about my monetary status, but I did feel a bit weird.  That aside, I can't wait to go back.
author: Annie F.

description: Tasty food, especially the funghi pizza. The service was also prompt and courteous. The server made a great suggestion on our wine pairing. This place loses two stars for being more expensive than it was worth considering its smaller portion sizes and non-intimate setting where you need to shout to be heard. I don't think I would revisit unless someone else was paying.
author: Julie Z.

description: With over 700 review, I don't know what I could possibly say that would add anything new. But I wholeheartedly believe that it deserves more like overall 4 stars and not 3.5.
author: Carla Y.

description: I have heard about this place for a while and just made it there last week. Becides the amazing atmosphere the food was incredible! The menu is completely authentic and the food was very well prepared and fresh. Pizzas are a must, along with the procuitto platter for appetizers. Definitly #1 spot for italian food and wine in the city hands down.
author: Chris S.

description: worst experience in a long time. every single dish was aweful, it felt like eating at a canteen.nothing had a good point from presentation to taste(way too salty and otherwise flavorless), the pizza was burned outside and flabby inside. the pomodorro tasted like salsa and the pasta- you can have better opening a can....this place(once my favorate) has become a low quality rip off.
author: Barbara S.

description:
Really 3.5 stars. Overall quite good.  Excellent tripe and burrata for starters.
Pizza is very good, out of the beautiful wood burning oven, with a nice charred crust.  But overall, I prefer the crispness of the pizzas at Gialina more than here...perhaps just stylistic differences, though.
Standard Marina parking headaches.
author: Scott S.

description: My husband surprised me by making a lunchtime reservation for the two of us one Friday. We were warmly greeted and shown to our table immediately. I was delighted by the menu offerings and selected the cavatelli with cannellini beans. It was delicious and the portion was more than generous. My husband had a pizza and very much enjoyed it and the wine suggested by the waitress. The only downside is the tables are so close together that you hear your neighbor's conversation, whether you want to or not. I don't know if they offer take out but I sure hope so.
author: Nan C.

description: KIller food in this little marina spot.  Home made salami and mozzeralla as apertizers were out of this world and reasonably priced.  The service was outstanding, and Som is was of best I've delt with in the city, not to mention very friendly wine list with great selections from California and Italy.
author: brian m.

description:
My wife, myself, and another couple went to A 16 last night (9/8/05). It was one of the better restaurant experiences I have ever had. Our friends were late, really late, 45 minutes late. The hostess was wonderful and was very accomodating. She even offered to seat us without the other couple. They finally arrived and we started with two house cured meats; fennel salami and ciccioli. We also had the mozzarella burrate. All were very delicious. We then ordered a pizza to share...the Margherita pizza plus arugula. It was perfectly done and great. The mains were chicken meatballs (2), the pork shoulder and the orecchiette with octopus. All were terrific except for the orecchiette. It was fishy and had very little octopus.
We had two bottles of wine suggested by the server. Both were excellent and were moderately priced. 
As other reviews have pointed out, the sound level is pretty high (even with cork walls). 
Overall, it was a great experience.
author: Rich S.

description:
The food didnt cut it for me.  The pizza is ok, the fish we ordered was really rough and it's over-priced.  I'd go to Delfina Pizzeria over A16.

They have an awesome wine list.
author: amy l.

description: Despite the ridiculous lines and wait for A16, this small italian joint is probably one of the best Italian restaurants in the city.  With a ridiculously nice array of wine choices, authentic light pizzas and some of the best hand made pastas in town, you cannot go wrong here if you are looking for some genuine italian food.
author: Charles C.

description: I have been here twice and enjoyed it both times. I see a lot of people review the restarurant based on pizza, which I would say is only one componenet of the package. Go for the salumi. They cure their own meats and they have fantastic tasting meats. Order them all!!! I would go here more for a flight of wine and a selection of salumis than the pizza.
author: Scott J.

description:
So I must say I've heard a boatload about this place. The buzz when it first opened was crazy. I was excited to finally try it for myself last night. My man and I where just across the street at the movies when we decided to check it out. The place was hoppn' for sure. The lady who greeted us made eye contact with me immediately and was quite upbeat when I asked what are chances were. I thought for sure we would need a reservation but to my surprise she said it would only be 20 to 30 minutes.  So we headed to the bar and started scrutinizing the wine list. Now here is where I must take a star off. The pages and pages of wine selections required some researched. I by no means consider myself an expert but I can usually feel quite comfortable getting through a list in almost any restaurant. This list was so esoteric and contained so many obscure wines I couldn't make heads or tails out of it. 
After selecting something safe (Draft beer) we were taken to our table. Again the lady who sat us gave us an option of a romantic table or two kitchen-side counter seats to watch the chefs. We selected the table but I though it was super nice to give us the option.
The menu had lots of options, which is always a plus. The octopus salad with cucumbers, cherry tomatoes and breadcrumbs was a little disappointing. The breadcrumb gave the dish a funny consistency and didn't add any flavor. The salsiccia pizza with fennel sausage, roasted peppers and red onions was fantastic. The crust was amazing. Finally the Chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil was out of this world. I could not stop talking about how perfect the savory/sweet combo was. 
The service is the other star deduction. Personality was completely lacking. The service was somewhat attentive but I really don't know who got the tip. One person took the order, another brought our drinks, and another brought one course, yet another bought the second course. I believe in teamwork but it really made the experience sterile and impersonal. When I was figuring out the gratuity I thought to myself I hope this house 'pulls tips'.
author: Gina C.

description:
super hot, super crowded, super marina people.

super worth it.

the wine list is awesome and the bartenders are very knowledgeable.  the pizza is some of the best i have had outside of italy, as is the pasta.  we tried 3 different deserts and they were all wonderful.  

i can't wait to go back.  maybe then we can get a reservation before 9 and be seated before 9:30.
author: Tony A.

description:
A16 is a great place to get some good Italian food.  Cozy inside and has a great patio in the back.  Fun to go and sit at the bar by the cooks and watch them make all the food as you eat.  

They make their won mozzarella, which is amazing, so if it is on/in any item....yummy!  Pizzas are great and unique...good to share.  Love their cannellini bean side dish.

Only downside is it can be hard to get a reservation on the weekends.  With 2 or 3, usually don't have problems at least sitting at the counter.
author: Elena L.

description:
I am writing this more as a question to fellow Yelpers than a 'review'.

I had heard amazing things about the pizza at A16, so with a great deal of excitement I went this week for the first time.

I will describe below what I was given, I am interested to hear back in this forum from other Yelpers whether my description is typical of the pizza there, or whether I could have been there on an 'off night' and should go back to try it again. It would help if you can give me some details on the sauce, crust, cheese that you encountered when you went there.

The Pizza: Margherita

1. Cheese - quite bland and tasteless. Not much of it.
2. Sauce - Bright red, spread very thin on the pizza crust. Ok flavour, but needed more of it.
3. Pizza crust (ie the entire round pizza base) - Closer to a pita bread than any pizza that I had tasted before. Most of it was paper thin, maybe 2mm thick. Not crispy at all, and when I picked up each slice, it hung down completely flaccid (sorry for the innuendo), and all of the toppings slid off onto the plate. The only way to eat it by hand was to roll it up like a mini burrito.  Significant parts of the rim and the underside of the crust were burnt. The dough didn't have much taste.

Overall, I left feeling confused. Is this the great A16 pizza that everyone raves about or was I there on an unlucky night? Maybe I just don't like that style of pizza? What does everyone think?
author: John S.

description: To be honest I've always had god meals here, but never been blown out of the water like so many people claim to be. In actuality, the pizza really is great, but not angelic, as is all their food, which is to say I've never had a bad meal here, just maybe never had that euphonious moment of food zen at A16 like I have at NOPA, Town Hall or Myth. Still, the wine list is competent, and the som has always been super friendly and excited about the wines. I like to saddle up the bar if possible early on a weekday night and share a bottle and a pizza, and I'm sure I will again, but still think as far as the Marina goes, Isa is my favorite, but A16 is certainly worth a couple of chances, maybe you'll have that divine moment I've been missing!
author: Steve l.

description: I thought the food was great. Pizza was unreal, probably among the best I've ever had. I had the special seafood pasta, which was great. Service was good and staff was friendly. We had reservations but waited an extra 30 minutes (not sure what that was about) so the hostess gave us a round of champagne. Not bad I guess. I wish the entrance was larger though, people from the bar and people waiting for tables can really quickly crowd up the place.
author: Mike C.

description:
Since I've eaten here about 50 times, I guess I owe this place a review. I'm an impulse eater. If a restaurant requires me to make a reservation weeks or months in advance, then forget about it. And I would forget about it. 
Fortunately, the bar area at A16 is on a first come first serve basis, so thats where I usually end up eating, although once they realized I was a local and a regular, I would occasionaly get a table.
My favorite pizza this side of Long Branch New Jersey. Crisp crust!!
The small portions are perfect for sharing a lot of dishs with your freinds. The sausages are always a winner. The beans as a side are great.
And the wine!! What a fantastic collection of wine from every region in Italy. The bartenders here know their stuff, and I've gotten drunk here a few times just in the course of testing to deside which one to order. Did I say I like sitting at the bar? Also, a lot of the gals in the hostessing and waiting department are sporting some great tattoos. This always gets an extra 5% tip out of me.
author: jeff b.

description: A bit overrated but one of the better offerings in the neighborhood.  The highlight is their solid pizzas from their brick oven using high quality flour.   Their pasta selection is also decent, although during my last visit the pasta was a bit too firm and undercooked.   The best place to sit is the chef's bar to view the pizza making process.  A minus is the large crowds and a bit of inattentiveness by the hostesses, although the wait staff is efficient and friendly.
author: Yoonity A.

description: My favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Casual and delicious! Order the burratta to start and then follow it up with a brick oven pizza... Awesome wine list as well - mostly Italian but a great small selection of NW and CA wines as well!
author: Katherine E.

description: I am not sure if A16 is better sans Nate Appleman, but it is certainly much more consistent. Since his departure I have been back 3-4 times for just solid food, good pizza and refined service. Before you could get a burned or soggy pizza one time and a stellar one the next, but it now seems that the kitchen has worked out its kinks. Wonderful wine service as usual. The bar is always a great place to sit and the guys who work behind the bar never lose their cool, no matter how busy the place gets!
author: B.M. B.

description: Had dinner there the first time last weekend.  The food is spectacular and I love the fresh pasta and the clean taste.   I would go back.
author: yum y.

description: YUM! The burrata here is INCREDIBLE!! So good that me and my girlfriend ordered two orders of it. HAHA! The pizza is also very good here, I haven't really tried their entrees. I love this place because of their wine selection - it's very unique because all of their wine comes from Southern Italy. I tried a few of their wines which were all very good and very reasonably priced. Also the bartenders are very helpful with familarizing you with the wine list. I will be back for some more burrata and some yummy Italian wine :)
author: Vanessa G.

description: After all the hype, and now having gone, all I can say is "You've gotta be kidding." Really, across the board for all 3 of us, disappointing food. Okay. Well, I did find my sardine appetizer delicious, but the special pasta of the day wasn't even blah, I actually didn't like it and didn't finish it. My two companions got cod and, well, blah. Really blah. Plus, it's a very white, Marina crowd. And NOISY.
author: Grace H.

description:
delish food--- hated the ambience!
reasonably priced for the high quality  =0 )
author: Roxanne M.

description: The Pizza was not that good, seems overrated. Bland sauce, soggy crust, hardly any Mozzarella. I heard such good things, maybe ill give it another shot. The decor is nice.
author: Jason L.

description: A16 is a trendy restaurant (sat next to Gavin Newsom and his crew last time I was there) in the Marina with some pretty good italian food.  The Pork breast is extremely tender, and the house cured Salumi dishes were very good.  The pizza and other pasta dishes were just ok.  The place gets loud, mostly because its pretty trendy and I believe on Monday or Wednesday night there are quite a few people there drinking at bar late.  Good for groups, but prob not if you want to have a quite conversation!
author: David C.

description:
A16 has become a staple in the Marina. Not only because the area lacks a lot of really good places to eat, but also because A16 is really a great Italian restaurant.
It's authentic and they really did receive the official Neopolitan-style pizza making approval (a big deal in Italy), and their tripe (for those who eat it) is as authentic as you'll find west of NY or Boston. But they have pulled together an amazing wine list, an incredible staff, and some of the best appetizers in the city (try the burrata mozzarella cheese - it's crazy).
While perhaps not perfect (you're always waiting for a table, the mains are not as good as the apps or pizza, etc.), it's a pretty special place and you can tell they really care about what their doing from top to bottom.
author: Lucky L.

description:
I could have written this review 5 years later and would still give this place a 5 star , if nothing else, just for the Mozarella and Bresaola I had the other night. It is hard to forget. My European friends attested for the authenticity of the cheese. For me, I have never had Mozarella at the perfect boundary of being soft and yet firm .  The salad was also very good, with the blend of almond, tangerine which is however not that unusual. But the Bresaola was completely out of ordinary and very creative.  We also had Funghi-Pizza which  was quite ordinary and a bit too salty. 

Service can be slow, but then again what you expect when it is packed on a Sunday night at 10pm!

Inspite of the not-so-impressive Pizza I would give them 5 for the decor, ambience and ofcourse the creativity and originality!!
author: Kingshuk g.

description: I've been here twice and loved the food the first time, liked it the second.
author: L C.

description: A16 is so yummy.  I love to sit at the bar and drink way to much wine and eat way to much food.  Pure Indulgence.  The staff is so knowledgable.  Some of my favorite wines have been discovered here: Falanghina and Ridge.  Mmm...
author: Jennifer H.

description: The meatballs are fabulous, but everything else was so-so.  I got the penne with lentils, but am not sure why because lentils are typically quite bland - and they were.  But the service was friendly, the food came quickly, and the ambiance was nice, if a little noisy for a business dinner.
author: Alison P.

description: If you are looking for genuine pizza Marguerita and fresh delicious Italian cuisine - this is for you. The best pizza I've had outside of Naples (although Pazzia is a close second). Also, their other menu items are a delight. Fresh, flavorful and delightful. A-16 never disappoints, ever.
author: laura p.

description:
I went to A16 with my honey for a little post-birthday-woo-hoo-I-got-a-gift-certificate dinner!  It was a place we had both wanted to try, but was a little out of our price range.  Made a reservation for a 9pm Sunday night meal and we were off and running.  
If you don't want to wait around for your table, I recommend the late Sunday night res, because we were seated immediately.  Since we had the extra money, we splurged on a really nice bottle of wine.  I wish I could remember what it was called- I do remember that it was tasty.
We shared a salad that was a nice, basic salad.  I had the pizza Margherita and it was tasty and crisp.  My honey had the gnocchi with sausage and it was pretty darn amazing.
We split something gooey and decadent for dessert and it was all around a great experience.  The place was busy, but our server was attentive and it wasn't too loud.  We were even seated next to a family with younger aged children (normally the off-duty teacher's worst nightmare) and they were very pleasant. 
I would love to go back again!
author: Tracy R.

description: Everything is drizzled in olive oil ... which is fine by me.  I love going to this place during the week as I ALWAYS manage to get a single seat at the counter and occasionally there are neighborhood regulars who will say 'hi.'   Since the counter overlooks the kitchen, it's also a great cooking lesson.  The pizzas, of course, are the best anywhere.  I timed them a few days ago, since I was sitting at the counter and saw my ricotta cheese pizza go in the wood burning oven.  1 minute and 50 second was all it took to emerge perfect.
author: Peter F.

description:
I've had better... way better.  I see where they are trying to go with this place with their somewhat creative spin on Italian, but it doesn't deserve the accolades that I've heard about it.  

The wine is decent.
author: T D.

description: Very good food; exceptional sausages; great place to go before seeing a show at the Palace of Fine Arts.
author: Valerie H.

description:
Entrees were a disaster.  Waitress recommended pizza & pasta.  Told her I was allergic to wheat .  She asked, "What happens if you eat wheat?". Inappropriate.  

- Ordered chicken and got a pork.  We had been waiting forever, so tried to eat it. Well took one bite.  Awful.

- Pizza undercooked and inedible.  Doughy, and floury.  The pork on top looked pink.    We tell the waitress who responds "That is the way it is supposed to be."

- Forgave A16 till they brought a complimentary brownie, soaked in olive oil.  This is gross. Not to mention I had a conversation with the waitress that I am allergic to wheat.

Comically bad dining experience.  They felt guilty and comp'd the pizza and olive oil/ brownie .  Place is a "glorified wine bar".  I stole that quote from somone else description of this place. Good appetizers - asparagus and shrimp.  Great bottle of Sagrantino.
author: chris w.

description:
A16 rocks. I live several blocks from there, and it is convenient, tasty, and clean. Even my dad likes it.

Furthermore, sometimes I get off work late on Mondays, and the place is already crowded. You know its rocking when it is crowded on a Monday evening.
author: Dom C.

description: Meh. Overpriced, overrated, and underwhelmed. The service, atmosphere, and food left a lot to be desired. I thought the prices were way too high given the quality of the food (the pizza was soggy and uninspired and the entrees my table ordered were boring). As far as atmosphere goes, the servers were running around the place like a TGI Friday's - it seemed chaotic, loud and disorganized for what is supposed to be a high-end restaurant. What's even odder, is the pretension that the hostesses demonstrate in the front of the house. Normally that sort of thing doesn't bother me if the food and experience is worth it, but given the lack of quality and innovation here it's almost laughable. This restaurant would be sooo out of business in Manhattan (or any other major East Coast city I can think of) in a heartbeat. I wouldn't go back. Perbacco has better food, better service, and a better atmosphere.
author: Britt M.

description:
Just know this:

Always good food.
Fantastic wines. Don't even look at the list. Their sommeliers know the list better than anyplace in town. They are MASTERS.
Great service.

This has to be one of the most consistent places in town. Three years into it I've never had a disappointing meal. I love knowing I can pop in here and have a top notch experience. It's great to grab a seat at the bar in the back in front of the pizza oven to watch the action. Or up front to talk wine with the bartenders.

I went on New Year's Eve with a group of friends and had a killer meal. Some salumi, crab dumplings in brodo, truffle lasagna, scallops, and a killer chocolate semifreddo. And all paired with heavenly wines.

Why can't every place be this good?? Why??
author: jane m.

description: Hmmm mozzarella and olive oil. It was just too good to be true. Salumi was good too. We had a reservation but still had to wait a while to be seated. Otherwise, service was excellent, food was great and we enjoyed ourselves. Def will go back again. Can be a little noisy but it's all good.
author: Eva L.

description:
Southern Italian cuisine at its best! Our lunch on a busy December afternoon was good. The only problem was the hostess who needed "to check" if the kitchen was open when we came in at 2.35 for our 2.3o reservation. She had a sour face, no smile but I was happy that  she did not represent the waiters in the restaurant. Most waiting staff seemed pleasant, although not too experienced. Witnessed one pressing down too hard on a french press and splashing the coffee all over the table and a customer. The scene which is hard to forget. You really must have no idea how a french press works!

The food is pretty good, pizzas are crusty and flavorful, salads are mouth-watering.
author: lilzeppelin y.

description: This is the best pizza in the city, as far as I've been able to tell. I don't think SF pizza is very good on the whole, so only a few places make the cut: A16, Pizzetta 211, and Delfina (Little Star is second tier due to lack of thin crust options). A16 is expensive but great because the achitecture of the interior is beautiful, the food is fresh and authentic, and the kitchen-side seating (the bar in back--ask for it) is fun and makes the experience more laid-back. It's cozy to see the fire and entertaining to watch the chef do his thing. The service and wine are also top-notch. Bonus: the chocolate budino with seasalt. If you've fouind a better dessert in this city, let me know.
author: alison m.

description:
food quality overall is pretty good, a little bit tilted towards the heavier side on taste. 

very reasonably priced as well (imo).


Went for early dinner on a non-weekend, and it was LOUD. Got louder as the night progressed, to a rather irritating level. Decor is also irritating and distracting - the layout being a 3 part (long bar entrance, aux and main seating areas, rear "greenhouse" room seating area). Sharing a 2 person table in the main room, it was straining to hear and converse.  Layout is rather distracting visually, and doesn't even match- it feels like you walked into 3 coffeeshops glued togeather in a unique way.


I enjoyed my dinner and would eat their food again; however i'd like it to be delivered to Alegias for me to eat (in peace).
author: Haoming C.

description: Once again, A16 - unbelievable! After a show at Davies 9/14, we went to Jardiniere for dinner.  (And I am not even going to discuss  the bill.) We ordered gnocchi and short ribs.  Let me tell you, the gnocchi were not even close to A16's lighter than air, delicious, best I've ever tasted ricotta gnocchi (when it is on the menu). It seems I have a new habit of comparing every where I eat to A16 and you know what? A16 usually wins! Seriously , still one of the best restaurants in SF. If not the best. I shouldn't even post this since you can barely squeeze in the door as it is, but again, there is a reason for that!
author: Lucy B.

description: A16 is fabulous - great atmosphere, great wine, great food. You can order a couple starters and pizzas and everyone at the table will leave a satisfied. For parties of 4 or more, make sure to make a reservation a day or two in advance so that they can accomodate. Highly recommended.
author: Allie G.

description: went there for the first time since nate appleman left and its just not the same.  I should correct.  Some things are just as good---such as the romano pizza.  But the escarole salad with watermelon radish was truly pathetic--limp and barely dressed.   And the two pasta dishes were ok but not ethereal like they used to be.  Dessert--pumpkin panna cotta--was also a disappointment.   If you want to know how panna cotta should be, go to Pizzaolo.  Of course, the place was packed--but everyone looked just too damn perfect.
author: David T.

description:
Had lunch here recently, mostly a very positive experience.

Food:  That may be the best funghi (mushroom) pizza I've ever had, period.  Abosolutely fabulous, from the mushrooms to the cheese to the crust.   To me that's at least 80% of the experience, hence the high grade.

Service: Average.  Hostess who seated us was very considerate.  Friendly service, but I think our primary server believes her real career is in modeling and that when we all see her on magazine covers then our relative stations in life will become more apparent.  She may just have had a bad day and I may have misread how she dealt with it as 'tude when it was not.

Drink: This was a business lunch, so no alcohol.  I ordered a Diet Coke or Pepsi and was told they serve a different brand.  It was weak sauce and awful.  

Noice level: Once the place was full for lunch (which it was) we had to work at hearing each other talk.

Ambiance:  Pleasant little place, the front feels like you're in Europe.
author: Annie S.

description:
some people call the 2000s the decade that everyone wants to forget.  yes, we had the worst president through most of the 2000s and the nation went downhill farther than anyone alive can remember.  however, i have to admit that my personal life wasn't all that bad throughout the aughties: i got together with the woman who would become my wife.  we got married, and some six years later we had a kid.  our son, our first and only so far, is now six weeks old and then some.  this past weekend was my wife's and my first valentine's day with him around.  what were we going to do? *shrug*  that sure as heck was not an easy question.  my wife has always wanted to be taken out for a glitzy night on the town.  however, she's adamant about raising our boy as natural as possible, which means as much breastfeeding as possible.  those two things don't really mix; but you know... a husband's got to learn how to force water to mix with oil in this post.post.modern world, you know?  at times, my wife talked about having me find a place where we could bring our baby.  i tried to convince her to let my mom take care of him, while we enjoyed a romantic dinner.  however, yeah... there was the breastfeeding issue... so... well, in the end my mom told me to leave our son with her because i already needed to meet up with a client for my dj business in san francisco; so i explained that to my wife, and she was fine with the idea of going for a nice dinner.  still, i wasn't sure if she was going to back out of it, so i didn't make any actual reservation anywhere.  when i looked up romantic san francisco restaurants, i felt so out of it.  ten years ago, when we lived in berkeley and hung out in sf, i knew all the phreshest, phattest joints.  nowadays, whoa... everything was different.  where to go? *shrug* i was pretty screwed.

well, i feel so indebted to a16 because we stumbled upon on it.  the mobile opentable site was totally screwed up on that saturday because of all the guys who were frantically making last minute reservations, so i could only trust my animal instinct and head towards  the marina.  i knew i had seen a few french restaurants of interest out there.  anyway, we found a nice parking spot, and my wife had us start walking in the opposite direction of where i personally thought we should've been headed, but we walked right up to a16.  she looked at the menu and approved.  the only drawback at that point was the quoted, one.hour wait.  we ended up strolling around the chestnut street mall and browsing through baby clothes.

well, when we were finally seated, i discovered this place was worth the wait.  my wife started with a very creative salad.  good salads aren't as plentiful on menus in the winter months, even here in sunny california.  i started out with the tripe dish.  we loved both.  the tripe was nice and tender.  i suppose the tomatoes provided some acidity or something.  the dish was not overly complicated and, with the spice of the chili oil, actually reminded me a bit of chinese food... i guess it was in a "good food is good food regardless of origin" way.  my wife's salad was very creative, with these watermelon radishes.  these slices really looked like little watermelon slices.

for our entrees, my wife ordered a squid ink cavatelli with bacala, and i ordered a pizza with salsiccia and egg because 1) i saw many other people ordering pizzas, and 2) i wanted to have egg on pizza just as i had in one nice pizza place in d.c. a long time ago.  yeah, the pizza was delicious.  i like sausage pizza.  the rapini on there reminded me of kong ching chai (water celery) that you get at taiwanese restaurants.  what's with me and comparing italian food to asian food, eh? *shrug*  gee, well, i'm going to continue and say that my wife's cavatelli looked like buhndeigi and tasted like joraengi dduhk.  it was delicious.  man, i was thoroughly impressed with the creativeness of the menu.  also; wow, i don't remember san francisco portions ever being _this_ generous!  since i was stuffed, i let my wife pick the dessert on her own, and she chose this pumpkin hazelnut panna cotta dessert.  it was really delicious.

the decor and ambience of the place was very classy and hip.  it reminded us of a gastropub that my cousin showed us in manhattan.  the service _really_ stood out.  everyone was so polite and out to do a sincere good job.  i feel like i haven't experienced service as good as this recently at other restaurants of similar levels of  "fanciness."  i don't know; maybe this place is just seriously out to impress or something.  i really liked how our waitress could pick out good wines for each of our dishes.  she was so on top of things even though the restaurant was so busy on this valentine's day eve saturday night.  wow.

yeah, so i really feel that a 16 was the perfect venue for this now married.with.child couple to try to relive their "carefree" days back in the aughties; but that statement doesn't do them justice.
author: beno h.

description:
Good pizza with an snotty attitude. Every time I visit SF, 4-5 times a year, I try and book a reservation at A-16, their pizza IS very good; if you know, and enjoy Italian pizza (forget the whole Neapolitan thing and VPN, all pizza in Italian  is similar). BTW very few pizzerias in Italy do the VPN thing....very fake, and only a method to promote southern Neapolitan food producers. The hostess' at A-16 always cop an attitude and act like such snots that I don't even want to eat there, even when I am lucky enough to get a reservation 3-4 days in advance. 
I think their pizza choices are too limited, forcing a Cali-cuisine flavor on an italian "VPN" ( http://www.verapizzanapoletana.org/ )pizza
Margherita (with grana padana?) would never happen in Italy, and if you are going to use aged cheese, at least use Parmegiano Reggiano for god's sake.
Dandelion Greens-Pretentious at best and this says it all, why not add broccoli rabe, and some mustard greens to top it off? I know a goat that would love this pizza.
Extravagant Upcharges- $4 for prosciutto di Parma / $4 for house-cured pancetta / $3 for arugula / $2 for an egg
If they are sooooo "VPN" where the hell is a Prosciutto di Parma pizza, how about Prosciutto-Fungi
Technically speaking, their wood oven is not at optimum temperature for "VPN" pizza. Technically, according to the VPN,  the pizza should cook in 90-120 seconds Check the time that a pizza cooks in their oven, 3-4 minutes is typical because their pizzaiola's are lazy, it takes a lot of effort to manage a hot oven.

What are the basic VPN Guidelines?
They really are pretty simple.
1. A Wood-Burning Oven: Pizza Napoletana must be cooked in a wood-fired dome oven operating at roughly 800ºF.
2. Proper Ingredients: Tipo 00 flour, San Marzano tomatoes, all natural Fior di Latte or Bufala mozzarella, fresh basil, salt and yeast -- only fresh, all-natural, non-processed ingredients.
3. Proper Technique: Your pizza dough must be kneaded either by hand, or with a low speed mixer. No mechanical dough shaping is allowed, such as a dough press or rolling pin, and proper pizza preparation. Pizza baking time should not exceed 90 seconds.
http://www.fornobravo.com/vera_pizza_napoletana/VPN_faq.html

There are a half dozen wood ovens in SF, try any of them before you are dissed at A-16
author: B P.

description:
Lordy, being fat ain't easy in this city of skinnies, and A16 is not only way too damn popular for the northies, but it defies the laws of physics--and the firecode--in squeezing in maximum people in minimum space.  Thank Yahweh that my foodie partner in crime had nailed us a reservation and got the maitre d' to act on it with a helpful dose of Southern charm and unrelenting chipperness. I was wiggling in sideway through tables, and my flat large butt was still giving a few backs an unwanted rub on the way into our humid little corner table beneath the pseudo sunlit alcove. We were headed to Smuin Ballet afterwards, but we kept getting forgotten in the heat--and I mean that in every literal and figurative sense...it was a freaking furnace of hot mouth air in there. It was peak period, so I guess that's an excuse for  substandard service.  But hey, they named their restaurant after some stretch of Italian highway, so who am I to question their methods?

The food? We ordered some speciial that ended up being--I'm not exaggerating--charred hot peppers of some sort.  A couple bites and my companion sent it back opting instead for roasted potatoes (hey you can't jack up spuds...can you?) that were rosemaried into oblivion.

I had a pumpkin and ricotta gnocchi that was decent, if not as savory as I tend to need to activate my timeworn buds, so I'd not recommend it. 

Kept waiting for a waiter to come back and refill our initial glass of water, but after 15 minutes--an eternity in restaurant time--we gave up, asked for the check and bolted, a little worse for the wear, but every place deserves a try.  I've had southern and northern Italian food on Chicago's south side ("Hey Capone!"), St Louis on the Hill, and San Diego in Little Italy. A16, my friends, was none of those. But i'm loathe to judge on one experience. May your driveby be a better experience than mine.
author: Chaz S.

description: On a recommendation from my brother-in-law, my girlfriend and I came here to celebrate our anniversary. We arrived 25 minutes before our reservation and were sat shortly thereafter in the rear dining room where you can watch the chefs go to work on their woodfired masterpieces. The wine list is ample with lots of eclectic blends as well as local vintages. We ordered the salumi plate to start, which all of the meats are made in-house, and were not disappointed. We went on to order gnochi and a chef's choice pizza to continue (they chose the Napolitana); both had good flavor and were not overly filling. We opted to keep drinking in lieu of ordering more food (why not, right?) and when offered a complimentary dessert (I think I put it on the reservation form but don't remember...I know, I drink too much) we were full enough to pass. Our server however indulged us with a glass of dessert wine which was a perfect end to a wonderful dinner. Service was great, ambiance was fun, and I would recommend this to anyone looking for the same.
author: Nick A.

description: I went to A16 last time I was visiting San Francisco and thought it was fantastic.  This time I was very pleased as well.  The gnocci was out of this world as was the argula salad.  The pizza was good but I have had better fennel sausage elsewhere.  Although many say the desserts are spotty, the almond cake I shared was quite good.  With all that said, if 4.5 stars were an option I would rate them accordingly.
author: Ila L.

description: 4th time dining here. Hostesses are always warm and calm even on the busiest of nights. This place is NEVER quiet... had a glass of wine at the bar during our wait and the bar service is always professional and quick! Well done! Had the burrata app. everyone raves about, but wasn't that impressed. I've had a couple salads before that have definitely stolen the show. Entrees consisted of the buccatini with crab. Solid! Pastas are always a strong  here! I like the fact that you can do half orders as well. Another great meal at A16.......
author: Brent A.

description: So I am new to Yelp,  but I've been to A16 so many times. Shelley, Shelley, Shelley, the fungi pizza, wine, and Shelley. Just go if you have never been. My point is likely moot at this point, but I wanted to go on the record. I'll be taking my parents there again when they are in from Maine next week....
author: BP N.

description:
We thought the food was fantastic however the service was terrible.  Our waitress Hannah not only had an attitude and screwed up our order she also screwed up the order of the table next to us.  
So if you decide to go to A16 make sure you ask that you get any waitress EXCEPT Hannah. Sky  knows her wine -- Andrea is an excellent manager-
author: gabrielle o.

description:
This is a really nice place. The food is the best and what I like about 
it best is the service. Also the place is huge!! I will always remember 
this place and the service

                             Service: Perfect
                             Food: Great
                             Restruant meaning clean: Nice
                             Restrooms:Clean
author: Pavlos P.

description: Atrociously bad service and chalk full of attitude. If you have kids, avoid at all costs.  When we came is with a toddler, we were treated by the hostess like we had the black death. Food was fairly decent...
author: Florence R.

description:
I choose this restaurant based on searching Zagat.com for top rated Italian restaurants in SF.  But I have to say I was disapointed with my experience.  I arrived about 15 min early for my reservation and was told that it would take 10' for my table...no problem.  However after 3 parties arrived after me and were seated I started to wonder what was going on. I checked in at the desk again and was told 'oh, we didn't realize you were here, we thought you were late and were about to cancel your reservation'.    

So we're seated and we wait, and wait, and wait...before we get to order wine.  Meanwhile the couple who were seated next to us (and were one of those couples who arrived after us) were already finishing their appetizer.  

Our drinks arrive, we order food and all is right in the world.  Our appetizer arrived (another rave for the roasted asparagus with walnut crema...and we also ordered proscuttio).  The proscuttio is a dream...melt in your mouth....but our enjoyment of it was slightly impaired by the fact that the staff kept wanting to take away our dishes. We had about a third of a plate of the proscuttio left...and we had our utensils in hand so I'm unclear why we looked like we were finished.

For my main entree I ordered the marinara pizza, which is described as having tomato sauce, olive oil, garlic and basil. I didn't expect the pizza to have 1 piece of basil (one leaf) in the middle of the pizza.  However the pizza was good. The sauce was tasty, the bread fresh and chewy/crispy at the same time.    My friends enjoyed their entrees.

But again, we were rushed with our plates.  Our table was large enough for us and our plates so I'm unsure why there was such a rush for clearing the table.

For dessert we ordered the 3 flavors of gelato.  I loved the pistachio and the strawberry swirl but the lemon flavour was a little too tart and salty for me....but perhaps others would really like it.  

All in all I'm not sure I would rush back to this restaurant. 
Drawbacks:
Small, crowded and very very loud.  We were sitting near the oven and it got really hot later in the night.  
Service was spotty...from the whole disconnect on the reservation, then waiting and waiting to order, and having to defend the food against premature removal.

The pluses:
The quality of the food was excellent and I thought the menu had items that I hadn't seen on many American menus.
author: Sarah A.

description:
Absolutely outstanding! Quality and size of the portion are very good.
I am always a little leery when I go to the Marina/Cow Hollow for dinner because I have found that people are there more for the show than the food. With A16, you get both.
My favorite dish is probably the pizza romana. Simple but yet delicious. The thin crust is perfect. Highly recommended.
author: Samuel M.

description:
Like Christine, my sweetie and I were also celebrating our anniversary yesterday and picked A16 for the special night. Having heard such great things, we left sorely disappointed. Our reservation was late, the bartender ignored us for far too long as we tried to pass the time with a good drink, the decor itself lacked imagination and was underwhelming. 

While it is nice to linger over a long romantic meal, we were not looking for a nearly three-hour commitment. The pace was painfully, unnecessarily slow. The pizza was a definite highlight - just delicious - as were the wines. Portion size notwithstanding, we were offered delicious selections that paired well with the food. But the beans were mushy and seemed overcooked, the pork chop dry (even if it was flavorful), and by the time we got to dessert, we stopped caring. 

We had a spur of the moment meal at Delfina last week, and it blew our expectations out the water. Sorry A16, we won't be driving across town for a meal here anytime soon.
author: Lena B.

description: A16 is amazing!! The thin crust pizza baked in the wood burning oven is to die for!! Pasta is really good too, and the homemade ice cream topped it all off.
author: sati l.

description: Went w/ 5 other folks, expected A LOT from this place and was really disappointed.  Pizza was very soggy and the taste was really sub-par.  I'm still in search of the perfect pizza...We ordered family style -- 5 different appetizers and 5 entrees -- so we hit all the recommendations from the waitress.  Everything left something to be desired.  Parking was tough...really tough, as I'd also expected.  Ended up pulling into the lot of a nearby hotel, front desk manager was kind enough to let me park there =)  I wouldn't recommend this place for the food, but the energy was great.
author: Cali G.

description: A16 is one of my favorite places in the city. They support local farmers! The fava beans, carrots and chard were delicious. Your salumi is so tasty. The Havens Hudson vineyard Syrah is superb.
author: Katie N.

description:
I don't understand what all the hype is about. There was such a long wait for this place and the only thing i can rave about is their wine selection ~ but what is amazing wine when you can't enjoy it was amazing food? The olive oil tasted bitter- the mozzarella appetizer was good, the pizza was nothing special in fact it was soggy in the middle and the dessert was small and average tasting.

ahhh if you're looking to try this place- i wouldn't waste your time, there are such better places in the Marina.
author: Ashley N.

description: Less than stellar pizza, great apps (mozzarella burrata!), a very helpful sommelier, and nice desserts.  Can't escape the well-heeled marina crowd here but a welcoming and genuinely friendly staff makes the place feel authentic.
author: Ben M.

description: So the GF and I finally had a chance to check out A16. While not reviewing alot on here we do get around to the SF food scene so of course have always known about their reputation, accolades, and focus on Campania and specifically pizza. Well last Sat after spending the morning at the Walt Disney Family Museum (which is great by the way), we were looking for a place to go and ended up here. We sat at the bar so never got to see the main dining area. So hearing so much about how the chef had studied in Italy to master the "art" of just making the dough, we had to go with at least one pizza, the funghi. Let me preface the rest of the review by saying that I love any pizza even the grease laden pizza at Sbarros at my local mall. That being said when it came out to our table I could immediately smell a hint of wood and freshly baked dough. I've always been more of a thick crust kind of guy but never shy away from thin.  So I was a little skeptical before even eating here. Well, while it looked very simple, the flavors were perfect with the most incredible crust. From texture to flavor, it spot on. The crusty bottom with the blackened blisters with their nice crunch, to the soft steamy inner core, has just the right touch of woodsy smoky flavor. We were told that it comes from the 800 degree oven that cooks the pizza in less then two minutes creating that perfect harmony of textures. I'm thinking that you throw any old topping on that and you'd have a great pizza. On top of the heavenly crust was the topping of roasted mushrooms, smoked mozzarella and arugala for a nice spicy punch, simple but just really nice flavors. Oh and did I mention the crust was the bomb? We also had the braised greens with spicy pork meatballs..uh,ok. nothing special but did have good hearty broth,  meatballs were a little bland for my taste.  Service was good sitting at the bar. All in all would definitely would come back for the pizza and certainly try other things off their menu.
author: David C.

description: We came with no reservations on Presidents day weekend on Valentine's day and were seated right away at the bar which was still a decent seating arrangement considering the conditions.  The food was excellent.  Squid ink cavatalli was lovely and the beet salad was very tasty.  The wine suggestion was perfect.  Overall we had an excellent dinner, lovely atmosphere, and tolerable price for a spontaneous night out for Valentine's day.
author: Natalie B.

description: Just came back here again with my sis because I thought the food was good last time despite the horrible service. The guy at the front this time was nicer and we were sat down immediately. First they put me behind this brat that was WAILING! So I asked to be moved and moved as far away as possible, but you can still hear the kid... oh well. The cold cuts were still good. We got the assortment and the meats were still very good. I think this was the best thing of the night. We also decided to try the Salsiccia pizza with fennel sausage. The sausages had a very interesting texture and taste that reminded me of duck. Overall the pizza was actually pretty tasty and good but a little too salty. Which would be the theme for the entire night... For pasta we got the Tonnarelli with Ink Squid... this dish was a disappointment in my opinion... it was just salty and flavorless... too 1-dimensional for my taste. The noodles were cooked nicely but it wasn't anything memorable. I really like the pasta last time and this time I was hugely disappointed. We got their Meatballs and it's almost the EXACT same one I had 4 months ago. Kind of uninventive and this time it was gross. The meatball was plain and boring. It was just super super salty! I was not pleased with the flavor nor the sauce because it was just salty and flavorless. As I am writing this review I keep wavering btwn 2 or 3 stars... I told my sister I don't want to come back here anymore so I am going to have to lower it to 2 stars. It's about 2.5 stars because the Salumi platter and Pizza were good, but I detested the main courses... Maybe after some recovery time I will wonder back to this place... MAYBE =P
author: Kat L.

description: Ok...I don't know if y'all read my review for A-16 yesterday.  I was in an angry, caustic, and very negative frame of mind.  I woke up this morning and realized there was probably a little too much vitriol in my review.  Today, being Friday, and I being in a much better mood will still give A-16 one star due to the poor service, but will remove the harsher elements of my review.
