My girlfriend took me there for my birthday this last Wednesday.  After 20 minutes of being totally ignored (and sitting through an earthquake), we decided that we must be invisible.  The table next to us, which was closer to us than we were to one another due to the cramped seating layout, was served before us by our waitress.  The table on the other side was being fussed over by our waitress like a favorite child.  One of the chefs from Lark Creek Inn was seated at the table behind us after we were seated and was served before us.  Then there was the guy at the bar she was flirting with instead of acknowledging our presence.  Finally, a random wine steward took pity on us and decided to take our order for a bottle of wine.  We finally got bread and water (after we got wine) and were a bit concerned that might be all we get for dinner.  Our waitress randomly approached us, didn't even say hi, but did say, "Oh, I totally love that wine.  We used to serve it by the glass, but don't anymore.  Are you ready to order."  Huh? I worked in the restaurant business for over 10 years.  When you have totally ignored a table for 20+ minutes, you don't walk up and make small talk.  You walk up and beg forgiveness.  Maybe treat the table to an appetizer.  In my not so humble opinion, a restaurant experiences its greatest success when you are made to feel like the guest of honor.  A-16 failed.
author: Curtis H.

description: overrated for the price, just found it wasn't worth the hassle of getting to the place, NASCAR racing for the next open parking spot on Lombard, then paying way too much for some overly salted meatball with overly salty sauce ...tryed to rehydrate because of the  thirstiness for water the whole NEXT day...so-so frou frou chi chi ka ka.(Garden State film suburb depression expression)..somewhat akin to drinking a cup of Salt Lake City Lake.
author: miriam b.

description: We had dinner there and sat towards the back.  I liked the relative quietness there.  The front was the livelier part of the restaurant. The service was excellent.  The salumi plate and prosciutto tasting were awesome.  One person in our party had the chicken meatballs.  They were outstanding.  I had the beef and pork meatballs and they were great, too.  But the chicken meatballs were better.  My husband ordered a pizza and liked it a lot.  He would have liked it more if the server had remembered to give him the half pizza that was supposed to be wrapped to go. We didn't miss it until it was too late. The strawberry sorbeto was delicious.
author: Andrea P.

description: I went to A16 Thursday night with a couple of other yelpers.  We recognized the bartender from a previous yelp outing and got the royal treatment: wine, appetizer, dessert on the house.  The mozzarella appetizer is mind-blowing.  I didn't know it could taste so good!  The octopus salad was well done; the octopus was tender and tasty.  They sent us over a free tuna salad and while my two yelper friends loved it, I thought it was really fishy.  I had a basil pasta with rock shrimp and a little kick that was totally unmemorable (I think I made this for dinner last weekend).  However, the other entrees were delicious: early girl tomato pizza with prosciutto and ricotta gnocchi.  The gnocchi were very unique and nothing like I'd ever tasted before.  Unfortunately, dessert was uneven as well.  The gelato was all right but tasted more like ice cream.  I ordered the panna cotta with figs and zucchini bread.  The panna cotta tasted sour and weird and the figs were too sweet.  I guess they were supposed to go together but I think elements of a dessert plated separately should hold up independently.  The zucchini bread was all right but my coworker's is better . . .  I would normally give this place three stars but our waiter and the sommelier were spectacular and the ambiance was stellar.  It's not as consistently spectacular as Angelini Osteria in LA, but good. . .  Just make sure you order the right thing!
author: Elena S.

description: We ate here four years ago and thought that we'd return with our friends for a treat.  I was thoroughly disappointed.  First off, the corkage fee was $30!  That mean two things to me: a) you're bringing in a $100+ bottle, or, b) you're forced to buy their wine.  Not a good start.  We ordered the calamari/squid ink pasta and a couple pizzas.  The pasta had absolutely no taste, had the texture of hard processed cheese and we mentioned this to our waitress.  Her response was to offer two thimble-sized cups of gelato at desert, to appease us.  They were so small that we couldn't use our spoons.  The pizzas had great crust but the toppings were what you would find in the frozen section of Safeway.  Seriously!  The bill came and it was $169 for four of us, which included a $38 bottle of wine that we felt forced to buy from them.  I have no idea why this restaurant exists, especially given the fierce competition amongst good to great eateries.  All four of us agreed:  Never Again!
author: Jeremy L.

description:
visited a couple weeks ago:

food-generally good and interesting.  really liked the pizza bianca and the squid ink pasta.  as others have said, the burrata is quite good.  the polenta side dish was NOT--dry, stiff, and hard to eat, pretty tasteless too

service-fast but rude and our server did not want to answer any questions, etc.

temperature--be careful where you sit!!  we were seated near the pizza ovens and it was HOT, even though the weather outside was cold.  it was incredibly unpleasant to eat a meal while my shirt was stuck to my back from perspiration

price--seems rather overpriced for what it is.
author: momoftwobear s.

description: My friend and I have been trying forever to get reservations here because he's been dying to eat here.  We finally got reservations last night (of course, we had to plan this outing two weeks in advance).  You know how some restaurants (even though you have a reservation), still make you wait for your table?  This was not one of those restaurants.  It was PACKED for a Sunday night, but it IS a holiday weekend.  Service was a little slow, but we didn't mind because we got in a lot of conversation.  Our appetizer (I can't for the life of me remember what we ordered, but it was the special - not on the menu) was to die for.  YUMMY!!  I ordered the pork shoulder for my entree and it was absolutely delicious.  I saw a lot of people had ordered the pizza and if I ever go back, I'm definitely going to order the pizza next.  I wasn't as impressed with my dessert.  I had the pear, apple and quince terrine on puffy pastry with spiced gelato.  The dessert didn't do much for me, but the rest of the dinner was well worth it.
author: Kris L.

description: Don't believe the hype, well at least not about the pizza. A16 is a trendy and pretty darn cool looking space in the Marina. It seems to be constantly filled with Marina files and "Yipsters". That's right. You heard it here first, Yipsters. A cross between a Yuppie and a Hipster.   A16 did hit a few high marks. The house cured meats for example. The Ciccioli (cured pork belly with fennel and olive oil) had a wonderful blend of savory and floral notes to it. In addition, the asparagus with pancetta, hazelnuts and pecorino was simple, elegant and delicious.  Another highlight was Shelley Lindgren's wine list. I was amazed by the amount of great Italian wines she had chosen to serve by the glass. It seemed as if almost every region and varietal of Italy was represented.  Probably the most disappointing part of the meal was the pizza. I had been excited to try Christophe Hille a certified pizzaiolo, rendition of the Campania pizza. I had the Romana pizza, actually I tried it twice in the same night. I ordered it with the addition of pancetta a wise choice I thought, it would accent the tomato, anchovies and calabrian chilies wonderfully. Unfortunately I was mistaken. When the pizza came it had huge chunks of pancetta lardons that were barley warmed by the specially made oven. In addition, the crust was burnt and soggy at the same time, now how does that happen? Don't get me wrong, I appreciate a well charred crust and I am even willing to eat half cooked pancetta, but I could not get over the soggy dough and the overly sweet sauce of the pizza. When asked by my server I told her my thoughts and she was extremely accommodating. She insisted that the pizza be taken back and re-fired. It was a gracious gesture and that alone helped make up for the sub-par pizza, but unfortunately the second pizza was just as bad.  So if you want good pizza try some other joint, but if you want to eat a few appetizers and drink some great wine A16 is a good spot for it.
author: Matthew R.

description: Brought my parents here and amazingly we were seated immediately upon entering. We were confused on who exactly was our server, our actual server who introduced herself, or the sommelier who was helping bus the tables? Random. The food was 4-5 stars. The meatball special was delicious, however, we never did figure out how the hell to get some pasta, major confusion over the menu and the actual communication from the sommerlier / slash / waitress who was snarling her lips at us when my father and I ordered beer as opposed to the $300 bottle of wine she was shoving down our throat. We were seated next to the back door / slash / trailer trash backporch with cold air breezin across our table, and load slurping Marina asswipes outtalking each other on who has a more fabulous hairdo, pedicure, and gas-guzzling SUV than the other. We were surely packed in there like sardines, all the Marina stares, the obnoxious glares, the au-pairs, get me out of here! I truly thought the restaurant with the southern Italian fare would do fairly well in my book. However, even my parents, who are red-state Conservative, noticed how "Oh my God Becky" obnoxious both the wait staff and the diners were that cold evening. Yummy dessert, semifreddo with huckleberry and walnut, and orgasmic sugar swirls. Oh my! Again, great food, but bad interior, decoration, service, and attitudes all around.
author: Braden B.

description: Not as amazing as I remember from 2 years ago. The food was just OK. The restaurant itself and the service are still great, but I'm not sure it's worth the 5 week wait for a Saturday night table.
author: Joe C.

description: this place has really good food.  i had this lamb meatball gnocchi....so good.  the space is really long and narrow...larger than i expected.  and, they have an outdoor patio thing in the back...i dont believe its smoke friendly , however.  the chef at the restaurant i work at loves this place, so thats gotta say something, right?
author: Genevieve M.

description: saw this in the Chron so decided to stop by.  sat at bar back by ovens.  most cooking is done with ovens.  We have been to restaurants like this in ITaly. they put olive oil on it before it goes in oven and after it come out.  Ordered the Margharita and fungh pizza's. these are amongst the best ever.  reminded me of real Italian pizzas!.  the Campagnai red wines are light.  not my fav but the Italian red's and whites we ordered were very good and complimentary to the pizza's.  Most of all, we will return
author: Kent W.

description: Did someone say "food was not memorable"?! what did you eat, just the breadsticks?!  My husband and I had dinner there the night we were engaged.  I'm sure our experience was a little elevated just because we were so deliriously happy with our new status, but it is still our favorite restaurant ever.  I had to shake some sense into my husband when he wanted to take a cab from the airport  just to go the restaurant when we were in San Francisco again for a layover.  Anyways, nuff about emotional attachments and our mushy feelings about this place.  We had the lamb in ricotta crispelle, braised short ribs, fabulously yummy roasted potatoes tossed in lemon juice that we continue to try and recreate at home, and butternut squash, followed by gelato !yummy!  I can still remember how the food tasted almost 2 years later, it was amazing.  That along with a great est waiter that found us the greatest wine ever, perfect service.  Kisses to A16.  And I will say that the restaurant was terribly crowded when we arrived and had a long wait at 7pm on a Friday, we were able to sit right away at the "chef's table" which is basically the counter.  We had a great show watching him fix the food and thought we had the best seat in the restaurant.
author: Melissa M.

description: generally stunning food, if a bit "wild."  staff can be rushed and icy and not groomed for the level of establishment. still, i am excited to experience the extreme dishes and chef's vision. though i will say all the red meats i've had there have been very braised - i.e. over cooked. oh, and they have a veeery shy pour on the wine. VERY.
author: I. V.

description: OVERPRICED salty food served by disinterested wait staff. I will be avoiding this place in the future.
author: Michael H.

description: Five years ago, I had my first date with my husband in this restaurant - so it will always hold a special place in my heart.  But, even from an objective standpoint, the food melts in your mouth in the best way!  If you remotely enjoy fresh moz, the burrata is not to be missed.  The pizzas and pastas are excellent too.  I've never strayed into the meats, I simply justify the carb-fest and delight and indulge my palate.  Yum!
author: Katie M.

description: J says: Stopped by for lunch, no need for reservations since it was half empty, nice.  The salsiccia pizza was one of the best pizzas I've had in the city, the crust was crispy and wasn't overly thin so it could hold in the toppings nicely.  The mozarella on the pizza was to die for, and the combo of grilled spring onions and luganega sausage, garlic, chiles was absolutely delish.  Of course being the huge carnivore that I am, the sausage alone wasn't enough for me and I ordered an extra topping of house cured pancetta, yeah.  The smoky flavor added an extra kick.  One of my lunch pals got the pork meatballs which were so fluffy and accompanied by just the right amount of tangy tomato sauce.  My other friend got the tagliolini with short rib ragu and pecorino which he said was cooked perfectly al dente.  Didn't have room for dessert at lunchtime but the sweet stuff on the menu looked very enticing.  Love this place!  Just remember to book way ahead if you're coming for dins.
author: Jen Ken H.

description: Good service, nice wine/drink list, fun atmosphere, bland food, pretentious hostess.
author: Matt G.

description: I only ate some appetizers at the bar and was impressed at how nice the bartenders and servers were. They let you do a taste of wines and are nice enough to ensure you find the one that you like so you aren't pressured to have more than just 1 or 2 taste. The appetizers were really good, with the exception of the bread. I figure a restaurant like this would offer warm bread, but they didn't. Oh well...obviously you don't come to such a restaurant for bread. I give it four thumbs up.
author: Chanli S.

description: Very disappointed with the food here. 2 in our group had pizza - 2 had pasta.  Pasta was very dry.  Pizza was a little better.  Will not return to this restaurant.
author: Sandy D.

description: did you know that mozzarella burrata is basically cheese wrapped cream?? Mmmmm. All my points are for the burrata.  Minus a point for the starchy, gummy pasta we sent back.  Minus another point for the cheeky waiter who told us that was what fresh pasta was supposed to taste like.
author: Fallon C.

description: I thought it was OK but the bar area is wayyyy too crowded. You can't even feel comfortable sitting at the bar because there are people literally breathing down your neck. Other than that, the place has a good atmosphere and the food is good. My favorite meal there is the beef shortribs.  Another note: This is the only place my parents request whenever they are in the city - they are very "hip" parents and are definite food snobs - so I don't know what that means to others but to me, it means this place must be good.  Make sure to make a reservation!
author: Katie G.

description: Had a friend from HKG come through here and he wanted to try this place.  I've walked by many times and seen the bar crowded and heard some good to fair things about the place.  We standby for a 8pm res.  The place is a little cramped but it's deep and has a dining room in the back, we sat on high chairs next to the bar. We first split a mix green salad, standard nothing to write home about.  The soup was good, pork meatballs and chard with little soup.  We both commented it tasted like chinese lions head meatballs and typical chinese soup vegtables, not too salty yet savory, which is good.  Next we split a pasta, squid ink pasta, like lo mein, (we started comparing everything to chinese ) with shrimp, it was tasty and again not too salty. Finally came the entree, I had the duck meatballs and he had the pesto black cod.  Too salty, now here it comes, the black cod was a bit slimey and the pesto spread on top, too salty.  My duck meatballs were dry and partially burnt and again too salty.  I think we should of ordered their pizza, they looked better at the tables next to us.  Overall for the price they charge,  I would give it 2 stars, pricy and salty. Next time I crave lions head and shrimp lo mein, I'll go to a chinese restaurant. Maybe I'll go back just to try the pizza but forget dinner, not a repeat.
author: Michael D.

description: Came here for post xmas dinner with my two BFFs. Made reservations a month ago and only got 8pm on friday night? Why the high profile A16? Anyways...after tasting their food..kinda understand why. Firstly, server was great and his recommendations were spot on! Here's what we got (we shared everything since we're a bunch of girls)...Sunchokes appetizer (average..skip it), pizza bianco + fried egg on top (definitely not even in the same league as mozza but still good), pumpkin nochi (not too heavy and very seasonal), tri-tip steak (highlight!!!! just drooled a little thinking about it), sides of white beans (yum) and chard (okay), chocolate budino (dry and a waste of salt on top), and some type of pumpkin rolled desert (pretty yummy)...oh and wine recommendation by the server was great too! All in all very condusive to having a super yummy and satisfying dinner with good peeps.
author: Emily W.

description: the roast chicken, pizza and wine selection are all amazing. loved it and will go back, even though it was super crowded. it really depends on what you order, but order the right dishes, and you will be a fan.
author: Yaz J.

description: It does not get better than this... Italian food at its best... I went twice in 2 days during my last visit in San Francisco... Make sure that you try one of the pizza ( mushroom or margherita ), the tripes are divine and so are the pasta.. The wine list is fun and reasonably priced. The staff was super friendly and helpful... If this place was in San Diego, I would be a regular.
author: Chris A.

description: pretty decent italian/californian cuisine.  good italian wine menu, although if you are not used to ordering italian wine then you will be utterly confounded.  only downside is that it suffers from the prototypical marina/cow hollow vapid honkification, a restaurant that you would expect patrick batemen to eat at had he been on the west coast.
author: christopher a.

description: Favorite italian cuisine in SF.  Pasta is unbelievable and great selection of Southern Italian wines.  Margharita Pizza is amazing too.
author: Joshua R.

description: a perfect place for a fun, casual, light dining and great selections of wine.
author: Joanne H.

description: I don't hang out in the Marina much, so it's not terribly surprising that I've managed to avoid this spot for so long. Ok, so the place has a charming exterior, and it's unusual name refers to an Italian motorway. 2 for 2 so far. I won't dwell on the fact that this place is louder than a Hazmat suit, because it's been mentioned innumerable times before. But the house prosecco was bitter (inexcusable). And the pizza was just bland and uninspired. The waitress said something about a pungent goat and it tasted more like cottage cheese. The ricotta gnocchi lacked the usual delicacy that you might find in the same dish at Zuni Cafe. And the prosciutto tasting plate was so unadorned and indiscernible that I almost laughed when she started pointing out each selection (if there's one thing I know, it's pig). There are too many great Italian flavors in San Francisco (Quince, Delfina, Acquerello) to suffer this place. I would consider giving it another chance, but mostly just to save you the time.
author: Lawrence S.

description: except for the fact that it is always crowded here, this place makes my day better because of the helpful bartenders, great italian wine selection, burn-my-mouth-hot margherita pizza, and chocolate tart with olive oil and sea salt.  the burrata and tripe napoletana are added bonuses.
author: jane d.

description: Admittedly, the first time I came here I was pretty bombed.  Something to do with a free bottle of champagne before dinner...yeah, that will do it.  So while I knew I enjoyed the food, I couldn't remember much of my meal.  Damn you bubbly!  And I looked forward to trying it again.  So I ate here tonight with the visiting parents, best friend, and her boyfriend.  Couldn't get a reservation, so we walked in early at 5:30  (my parents are very early folk), and were seated immediately.  But not in the main dining room, apparently you definitely need a reservation for that.  Started off with a little taste of an italian red and then we drank 2 bottles of another italian red.  I will never remember the names, especially since my dad ordered.  In fact, he did most of the ordering!  Appetizers for the table were mozzarella burrata with olive oil, sea salt and crostini (delicious and creamy, though I preferred the house bread to the crostini), roasted friarelli peppers with anchovies, Calabrian chiles, lemon and fried breadcrumbs (fantastic!  spicy, salty and delicious), zuppa of fresh butter beans, summer vegetables and spicy pork meatballs with basil and pecorino (loved, especially the meatballs), and a margherita pizza (yum, wood-oven baked).  Whew, after all that, can you believe we ordered mains!?!  My mom and I split (and my best friend ordered) the cavatelli with squash blossoms, zucchini, chiles, basil and grana padano.  This was very yummy, and not super heavy.  My dad ordered an appetizer size of the maccaronara with tomato ragu and house-made ricotta salata, which was good, but not memorable.  And my friend's boyfriend had the duroc pork chop with sausage, with a side of cannellini beans (yum!).  The sausage was DELICIOUS!  One of the best things I tried tonight.  Lastly, there was dessert.  Naturally.  5 people, that meant 4 desserts, each of which was equally yummy: yogurt panna cotta with buckwheat cookie, apples, and candied fennel, plum and hazelnut cake with hazelnut brittle and plum gelato, raspberry crostata di marmellata with figs, pistachios, and ricotta, and chocolate budino tart with sea salt and extra virgin olive oil.  I mean seriously, I felt like we ate the whole menu, and every thing was good.  However, I am only giving this restaurant 4 stars.  Why, you ask?  Because they were a little overly attentive.  You might be thinking, why is this a bad thing?  Because you don't want a server clearing your plates while someone else is still eating.  It makes the people who are finished feel like fatties, and the people who are still eating uncomfortable and rushed.  Poor form A16.  Let the people savor their food!  Other than that, it was pretty great.  I look forward to dining again at A16.
author: Rebecca R.

description: A16 is fine dining without the fuss, and the only place like that in the Marina. The pizzas here are the main attraction for me. I love the Napolitano and the Blanco. The dough is nice and a little chewy, but not super thin crust like in many other "designer" pizzarias. The pastas are solid and the side dishes are straightforward but surprisingly good. As for the famous meatballs, I prefer the appetizer version in a nice rich broth to the giant ones in red sauce.
author: Jenny C.

description: I really wanted to hate this place because of the long lines and "hype"  but I just couldn't ....have been here 5 times now.....reliable and delicious....but I did hear the chef just left?
author: Kaley T.

description: This review is for the Neopolitan Pizza, Salumi, Burrata, wine and service.   They are all 5 stars.  The Pizza is the best, hands down.  Better than Delfina?  Yes.  No contest.  I love the loud cozy confines as well.   Always a pleasure.
author: Robert B.

description: The two stars are for the waitress, Mary. She was extremely attentive, cordial and knowledgeable. She timed our dinner perfectly. I'm surprised she's not working at some 5 star place. Anyway, so we walk in a few minutes early for a 10pm reservation, (we tried 9 but they were booked up). We got seated some 15 minutes after 10. While we waited on some barstools behind the hostess stand, we noticed the diverse selection of wines. I guess this place seems to be a meeting place, too. The bar was packed. The hostess saw that I was wearing a short skirt and sat us a a very tiny and cumbersome table smack in the center of the room with no privacy below the table top (girls, you know what I mean). I felt so awkward and exposed. Wishing to be moved I tried to get someone's attention as people whizzed by us and around us, over and over. I guess I wouldn't have minded it  if we were in a small pizza place and I was out for a casual slice in my jeans, but this was our big night out . And suddenly there she was, our wonderful waitress who didn't need much of an explanation to realize I wanted to move and she grabbed a busboy to set us up along the back wall (yeah!).Now to the food, I ordered a very nice citrus salad that was very good, my husband's octopus was very good, too. The main dishes were another story, however. They lacked taste, flavor and creativity. My Main dish of Rabbit was ok, It was cooked on wooden skewers and given a mediocre rubbing with some cheap herbs. I could've done better myself and that's not saying much. With all the hype about this place I expected better. My husband had a fish that was breaded. It was just that and no more. There was no interesting flavor or anything to justify the price...and the wait. We had a nice bottle of Vermentino and the check came out to just under 200$ with the tip. I don't mind paying for a nice dinner but this was just average. More hype than anything , I guess. It's a place to go so you can say you've been there, that's all. I won't be going back.
author: rosanna m.

description:
started with a prosciutto sampler and the calamari with cannelli beans. couple of glasses of a good italian red.
then the star, the special of the day, black cod with scallops and muscles in a wine caper sauce, simple but one of the best prepped fish dishes ive ever had.

Just glad I wasnt paying for the meal.
author: Jeff E.

description: twas amazing.  i can't believe I waited so long to come here.  the wines were delicious.  seriously everything I ate was wonderful.  the most memorable was the house cured salumi.  the pasta and pizza were great as well.  i was pretty sad that the famous meatballs are only available on mondays but i guess i'll just have to come back.  darn!
author: a g.

description: For as far in advance as I had to book this place to get a descent Friday night reservation, I expected a lot more.  The food was good, but nothing memorable.  The rolled skirt steak was just ok.  I enjoyed the prosciutto much more.  The worst part for me was the service.  It took 30 minutes from the time we sat down to get a glass of wine.  That's just not right.  From what I had heard, my expectations were high.  But even if they hadn't been, I don't think A16 is anything more than average.
author: Todd J.

description: We were on our way to one of our favorite places in the city... another small Italian restaurant but on the way we decide - what the heck, let's try something new.  So stopped in and got seated immediately.  Atmosphere was fine - we sat at the chef's counter.  But the food...could not have been more uninspiring.  What a huge disappointment.  I had the pasta with cod.  The cod was microscopic and the flavor in general very bland.  My husband had the pasta with red sauce and it too was very bland.  My recommendation would be to keep walking down the street... there are many other places FAR better than this!
author: Dena P.

description: I went here with my parents for my birthday dinner. I was not dissapointed at all. We got a pizza as an appetizer and then shared three different entrees. The wine, atmosphere and our waiter was superb. I will be back soon!
author: Sarah R.

description: This place still rocks even thought it's been in business for some time now.  The food and wine is soooo tasty and the wait staff super friendly, upbeat, knowledgeable, and professional.  I've had dinner here twice in the last two months and was waited on directly by the owner during one occasion.  The only downside is that it's been discovered by tourists and the bridge and tunnel crowd, so the scene isn't quite what it used to be.
author: Tim Z.

description: Really great environment, but the food was not amazing like we heard it would be.  Waitstaff took over 15 minutes to ask if we wanted a glass of wine or drinks.  Took us 30 minutes to sit when we had reservations for over a month ahead of time.  The attention to details was lacking.  Especially since we had a special occasion and they knew it.
author: Jackson F.

description:
it's apparent that yelpers, even those who supposedly know about food, can be clueless. first of all, "vb", you should learn how to write before attempting to craft a seemingly scathing review. get your verb tenses right, for chrissakes. and you're wrong - you meant to say: "this place never ceases to amaze". perbacco is crap compared to l'autostrada. those of you who order pizza in Italian restaurants in the US (and complement it) are automatically dismissed and are therefore one of the following:
a) too young to understand real food
b) brought up poorly, with bad food
c) never been to italy and had real pizza
i pity those of you. one does not go to an italian restaurant (of this caliber) in the US and order pizza. be that as it may, let's not be concerned about americanized bastardizations of dough and tomato sauce, parking, wait-time, ancestry of the staff, or anything other than what really matters: primi and secondi piatti!! the wine list is superb - it's fitting for the cuisine and it creates a suitable foundation for the menu. shelley, sky and andrew rule, as well. as a side note, I think yelp should filter their reviewers after administering a battery of exams, before allowing the hoi polloi to run free and willy-nilly with their loose tongues.
author: ultra p.

description: My wife's favorite,  I think its Great.  Sneak in at opening time and sit at the bar if you don't have reservations.  Otherwise don't bother without reservations.  Really like sitting at Chefs counter.  Noisy, but love the pizza and the Prosciutto San Daniele.  Talk to them about wine, tell them what you like and they can pick something out for you.  Big Fan
author: Paul M.

description: Please note this review is aged, and I can't remember the details. For some reason I forgot to write about this eatery until I saw it mentioned in Gourmet magazine. So I figured I'd throw in my two cents. We decided to get some food at A16 since it was cold out, we were hungry, and I had seen A16 in the eating San Francisco ad magazine for ages. We were seated relatively promptly in the back. Much to our misfortune, it was way in the back, by the exit and there was a splendid wind that made us very cold. The place was packed full of Marina blowhards and San Francisco elites. It wasn't my favorite crowd, but the food was wonderful. We each had a pasta dish that was original and well plated. The waiter had a great knowledge of wines, and spoke to us about some central coast favorites. Since I grew up on the central coast, this pleased me. All in all, the service was good, the food was great and the drinks were also wonderful. I have to say the fact we froze our asses off was unfortunate. The entire place should be the same temperature in my opinion. But I'm a nerd, not a doctor...er architect.
author: Erik U.

description: Went here for my birthday with a party of 6.  They sat us in back on the covered patio, which was nice and semi-private.  We had reservations for 9 and they didn't seat us until 9:30, but that's how long it took the bf to find parking anyway.  I was worried there would be a strong Marina vibe, but there turned out to be all sorts of people there and we had a great time.  Our server was AWESOME--recommended some good wines (though he didn't warn us the first needed like 15 minutes to open up, and we needed some wine PRONTO), was really patient with our slow decision making, and was friendly and informative.  And my friend brought a cake, and A16 handled it perfectly--they refrigerated it for us while we had dinner, then cut and served it for us, washed the serving dish we had brought, and boxed up the leftovers.  We split a couple orders of the amazing burrata, a couple people had the meatballs, a couple had a pizza, I had a pasta, and the bf had pork, and I think we all really enjoyed our dishes and had a fun dinner overall.  They didn't rush us out even though we stayed until midnight chatting.  Now my parents can't wait to go, and I hope they bring me with them!
author: Gina K.

description: why do people love this place?it is really pricey for a place that is just ok.good but not out of this world.tiny portions and too overly simplified.extremely dark and drafty too.we ordered the meatballs that my sister could cook better.the pizza was burnt and lacked pizzaz.the dessert was good but they gave us the wrong thing.overall,just ok
author: Sophia C.

description: This place has a great vibe for groups. Came here with a bunch of girls for the start of my girls night out since the fiancee is out of town for his bachelor party. If I could only write one sentence reviews my review would say ORDER THE BURRATA. Seriously, it's heaven. It was creamy and fresh and tasted like butter in the best way possible, do not miss this dish. It was amazing. We also had the prosciutto and it was also delicious, ordered with the burrata, the two complemented each other quite well. I am a fan of simple pastas so I got the maccaronara with tomato ragu and homemade ricotta salata that was really good, the pasta itself was cooked perfectly al dente and my only minor complaint was that the dish seemed a little oversalted. I had a taste of my friend's gnocchi which was really good, the gnocchi were really plump and soft and had a really good finish to them. We got the semifredo for dessert on the waiter's recommendation and while good it was not particularly special. Overall I had a really enjoyable experience here for dinner and can't wait to come back.
author: Cathy T.

description: Outstanding food!  Very busy restaurant.  Loud and great for a fun meal with friends. The open kitchen and aromas are amazing.
author: Gus L.

description: I was excited to go to A 16, simply because I had heard it mentioned among many people in the industry. The service was excellent, but the food....not so much. It's one of those places where you have to order the "right" dish. The pizzas are the right dishes, the gnocchi....not so much. We started out with the mozzarrella burata, which was delcious- the cheese was SO fresh and the sea salt/olive oil was a nice touch. My salsiccia pizza was huge- could have shared it with 1 other person. The fennel sausage added nice spice to it- my dish was the best on the table. My two friends both ordered gnocchi- it had no flavor and was not melt-in-your mouth, the way gnochhi could be.The semifreddo dessert was fine- nothing spectacular. The sommelier was very helpful in picking out a bottle of wine and our server was great. It fits in with the Marina vibe....very trendy, a little overpriced for the quality of food you are getting.
author: Laura D.

description: i've been here a number of times and just got back from another great meal so here's the review.  my staples include the canalloni white beans and the macarenerra fresh pasta.  i have to get these every time.  you can't go wrong with any wine you get, even the $30-somethings are stellar, which is the great part.  tonight we had a seasonal side of squash with pancetta, phenominal.  the pizzas looked good but we didn't get one this time.  always look forward to the next time while i'm there.
author: e w.

description: I think this is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco. Although I have suffered through horrible, long waits (even with a reservation booked months in advance) I still find it hard not to go back. Their mozzarella appetizer is orgasmic and their pizza is probably the most authentic Italian pizza I have tasted in the city with the thin crust, fresh tomato sauce and small portions of fresh mozarella. Best of all, unlike many SF restaurants they change their menu often and always seem to have new and exciting dishes. While it is very hard to get an 8pm rez on a Friday night, it is worth going for a 9 pm dinner on a Tuesday.
author: Sammy D.

description: I am sorry but I don't see what everyone's talking about when it comes to this place.  Everything is covered in olive oil, sea salt, and black pepper, and they don't change things upon request.  If you want to come here, make sure you have a reservation.  The chocolate tart with sea salt & olive oil literally made me gag.  A lot of people like it though!  It just tasted like a mouth full of salt to me, and I couldn't taste anything else.  It's a pretty expensive place, and if you're in the city, there are a million other places you could go that'd be much better.
author: Jessica J.

description:
it takes a lot for me to trek all the way to the marina - especially for a restaurant- there are just too many good options near me. my geographical tendencies aside, a16 was fantastic. we were immediately ushered to our table and waited on lovingly by a wonderful server. i may have been biased by the fact that he insisted on getting me a new glass of wine when i told him that the one he originally suggested wasn't my favorite. (maybe i'm more of a diva than i think? hmm.) we started with the arugula salad- delightful though a touch salty. i happen to adore salt, so it didn't bother me at all, but if you are salt sensitive, you might want to choose another option. we also had the prosciutto tasting- oh.my.god. if you like prosciutto, even just a little, you have to try this. the only downside of the tasting was that the american prosciutto (similar to what you get in most stores) was so clearly inferior to the italian version, i may be ruined forever. le sigh. 
on to our entrees- we tried a pizza- delightful thin crust- and the lamb crespelle (crepes). outstanding. seriously. i had to remind myself to relax and enjoy the meal, and not continue to shove it in my mouth as fast as possible. to borrow the favorite phrase of a certain loud-mouthed food network host - yum-o. a16 was absolutely worth the trek to the marina- and that's a huge compliment in my book.
author: oona m.

description: eh...i was expecting great things from this place considering there is a line out the door every night.  i must say that the pizza here is really good...nice thin, chewy crust.  everything else is so-so.  there is a great wine list, tho!
author: Helen T.

description: Very good Italian food.  On the pricey side, but worth it.  I don't like the wait time for this place, but you can usually get a place at the bar more quickly.  It's a bit of a scene, but it's easy to ignore this.  Also, the chocolate cake with salt is awesome!
author: Lisa K.

description: A16's appetizers keep me coming back for more, Their creamy mozzerella buratta with sea salt, cracked black pepper and a healthy drizzle of extra virgin olive oil makes my mouth water. Served with ciabatta toast this dish is simple yet satisfying appetizer. The eggplant parm has a great element of freshness that combines the texture of the eggplant with sweetness of the earl girl tomatoes and the salty smokeyness of proscuitto. Moving on, the main courses aren't as consistent. The Maccaronara is pretty standard. i.e a fancy name for a dish that is very  comparable to spaghetti. The Bucatini with clams was slighly disspointing as my noodles were a little more than al dente, which is fine if you like it still crunchy in the middle. What really stands out are the beef short ribs and the polenta when they offer it. The ribs are tender and posess a rich tomato flavor. The broth is thick and full of flavor that has been imparted by the slow cooking process. The side dishes of roasted corn and cannlini beans are yummy, but overall its the starters that make this place a hit - that said - a better value would be Isa.
author: Stacy T.

description: So, maybe this place is better than a 3, not sure, but its really hard to decide since the hype parade was in my head!  This place is great and there should be more places like it since you have to wait a month to get a decent reservation.  It is a reasonable price point for dinner which does not really exist here.  Sometimes you just want an easy night out, and this concept could be it.  The dishes are good and reasonable.  The wine list is a bit overpriced, but extensive.  I thought everything I had was good, but not wait a month for a reservation good.  The eggplant app was my favorite, but all in all, they make very good pastas and the pizzas are pretty tasty too.  Either SF on the whole needs to create more places like this, or people need to find somewhere else to hype about so that I can get in here a lot easier.  I would eat here again, but I am probably not going to go out of my way to be looking to reserve a table a month out.
author: Jaime C.

description: I'm still suffering from food coma, but I guess that's what happens when it's 1:30am and you had dinner at 10pm.  Due to poor planning, we made reservations day of instead of in advance and ended up with 10:30pm reservations, but luckily they were able to seat us early.  At 10pm, they were at full house.  Now I understand why it's so hard to get in!  Although I usually hate eating dinner this late, I couldn't resist trying a little bit of everything off the menu.  We asked the waitress for suggestions and luckily she picked out all the ones we were eyeing.  We started with the Margherita pizza and mozzarella burrata.  The fresh mozzarella was very delicious, I would recommend it to anyone.  The Margherita pizza was also just as good, although the crust was a tad thick for a "thin crust pizza".  We also shared the Maccaronara and the Braised Beef short rib.  As soon as they served the two dishes on our table, you can detect the fragrant aroma of the dishes.  I just wanted to sit there and smell the dishes, taking in all of it.  Oh wait, I did do that!  The waitress even came back and asked if everything was alright.  Of course everything was alright, it all smelled so good!  The Maccaronara was kind of average, but you definitely appreciate the fresh flavors.  The Braised Beef short rib aroma brought back memories of one of my favorite dishes that mom used to make.  And equally to my delight, it was just as scrumptious.  We ended the night initially a tad disappointed that they had sold out of three of the desserts.  However, the honey panna cotta satisfied our sweet tooth. I love eating family style.  I was very happy with the selections we shared.  I'd go back again, anytime!
author: Irene C.

description: Excellent pizzas and pastas, I really enjoy Nate's cooking.  The crowd is very Marina, the only real drawback.
author: Grace R.

description: If they only had their burrata and delicious thin crust pizzas they would get 5 stairs.  Their entire menu, however, is equally delicious. Staff is always pleasant but parts of the restaurant can be extremely loud.  If you're looking for something quieter ask about sitting in the back room which is closed off.  Reservations strongly encouraged.
author: B B.

description:
A little disappointed tonight.
A16 has long been our favorite restaurant in SF.  We live in the neighborhood and eat here every 3-4 weeks (and, for better or worse, compare all other restaurants to A16 in terms of food, service and value).  
Tonight, however, we had our first disappointing experience in years.  The food and wine were excellent.  Our favorite bartender was there and gave us wonderful wine recommendations while we waited.  The wait for an up front table was only ~20 minutes, but once seated the service was lackluster.  Our first few dishes arrived promptly but then it took a full hour (yes, 60 minutes) before our main course (and wine) arrived.  All around us other tables were being seated, served and bill settled while we waited.  Our server was nowhere to be found and then swept by and offered a complimentary half glass of wine to compensate for the wait.  That would have been lovely except that, when the check arrived, we had been charged for it.  It was eventually rectified, but we shouldn't have had to point that out.

We're such huge fans and we don't want to see this restaurant go downhill - so please take another look at your service.
author: Maggie L.

description: Fun, cool atmosphere, good food and great for a place to go after work where it isn't too much of the extreme. The service was good and the pizza--yum!  It isn't too Marina-esque.  I guess the hype has perhaps died down a bit.
author: Misti L.

description: my favorite italian restaurant in sf. the pizzas are just like (not quite as thin) northern italian pizza from milan and bologna. great mix of toppings like arugula and the all coveted prosciutto di san daniele (arguably the best in the world.) their appetizers are also very tasty. i tend to stay away from the entrees to keep the bill low, but the few i've had were delicious. it's nice to watch the open air pizza and salad kitchen and cork walls and floor add a nice touch to the atmosphere. the also have a nice selection of wines and beers.
author: Alex L.

description: I've never actually walked around the marina (ick), but I've taken every out of town guest i've had for the last year to A16.  Make a reservation and just be patient if you have to wait another 20 minutes.  Enjoy a glass from their amazing Southern Italian wine list.  The bar staff is super-knowledgeable and can guide you to a wine that might make your new favorites list.  The ingredients here are all fresh, mostly prepared in-house, and the purity of the dishes shows A16's devotion to old-world techniques.  The menu is a seasonally-changing delight every time I go.  Most recently, I had a fresh Sardine appetizer that I can't stop thinking about.  So simple, light and full of flavor.  The burrata mozzarella melts in your mouth and tastes of creamy freshness.  The Napolitan style pizzas are the real deal, like I ate all along the Amalfi coast, with few ingredients, purposefully chosen and perfectly baked in their wood oven.  The homemade gnocchi are bites of heavenly bliss.  I've had them in a few different preparations - all wonderful.  My meat-eating guests always rave about the house-cured salumis and the pork chops.  Don't be shy - if you don't know what something is (much of the menu includes Italian names for things), just ask.  The servers love to share their wealth of information and help you select items you will truly enjoy.  I can't forget to mention desert.  Last time, I had a persimmon bread pudding and a glass of white dessert wine, recommended by my server, that were a perfect tasting pair and the perfect ending to an amazing meal.
author: Michelina M.

description: really a 2  1/2 Uhh...am i missing something here? So I came in here with 2 of my buddies. Upon entering, we were seated right away since we had reservations. BTW the hostess was frikkin beautiful with a huge...ahem.. anyways, the place we sat at was too warm but bearable. the waitress was funny and attentive and the ambiance was loud. Onto the food. Overall, this place is hit and miss. The tuna appetizer was awesome,full of flavors. The fish was marinated in some sort of vinegar marinade and garnished with capers...simple, flavorful, just how I like it. Also their house cured meats were also delicious. We tried the prosciutto...thinly sliced and goes extremely well with bread. For entrees, we ordered a pizza dish...for a long time, I heard this place make the best pizzas...meh....out pizza was burnt and tasted bitter...funny thing was the couple next to us.their pizza was also burnt...i'm all about thin pizza being slightly toasty, but this just tasted bitter and greasy....the lamb was good, nothing special really about it, and the gnochi(sp?) was bland in some sort of broth...the dessert however was good...we ordered this lemon shaved ice which was refreshing and cleaned the pallate very well after eating burnt pizza...overall...i may want to try this reataurant again...i may have caught  it on a bad day...then again...i heard they just changed head chefs which may have to do with the disappointing pizza and entree...if you want good brick over pizza...go to tomasso's...better yet...if youy dig chicago style pizza, go to Zachary's in berkely
author: Joel V.

description: I'm not going to reinvent the wheel here with a detailed description of this classic spot.  I will say that the pizza romana with arugula added is wonderful and is my favorite thin crust pizza in SF (disclaimer: I have yet to make it to Pizzeria Delfina). The tomato sauce is nice and tangy and the anchovies and arugula give it a nice kick.  It's the perfect starter to split. The pastas are quite good but not always amazing.  Most recently I had the casarecchia with baccala (pasta with what I believe was tiny chunks of salt cod) .  It was good enough but found the breadcrumbs detracted from the dish.  It definitely didn't live up to other pasta dish I've had here, a pasta with squid that used to be on the menu, which was one of the best pastas I've had in SF.
author: Mel X.

description: The most official Napoli style pizza I've found in SF. Wood burning ovens and everything. Pizza was great. The pork chop was big and juicy and well crusted, very tasty. But the nuts on top were unnecessary. The chard as a side was great. We had the custard dessert, which was just OK.
author: Jacob K.

description: Seated before the real crunch of people and expected (hoped) for well paced service but ...not on the same "schedule as the server" ... who   sought to inquire no more than three times in the first 5 minutes of my being seated for my full order.  I guess a glass of wine and appetizer after requesting time to relax is not "ok".  Ordered a dish available in small and large portions.  I neglected to specify -  care to guess which size dish arrived????  Small things but the net effect -- so so dining experience.  Great location and ambiance.  Other places nearby to explore.  Won't return quickly.
author: t h.

description: Love their pizzas!  I've had their sausage and Margarita pizzas, and the flavors were very full and lip-smacking, with nice crispy, yeasty, wood-fired crusts. But a word of advice:  make a reservation.  They have only a couple of tables for walk-ins, and they fill up immediately.
author: Mary C.

description: Walked in as soon as it opened for dinner last Friday night w/o reservations, and sat at the chef's viewing area-- Highly Recommend If: 1. You like watching FooNetwork and/or 2. You're with someone kind of boring, and need conversation starters/awkward silence fillers. I sat here bc my boyfriend and I had just watched the rerun of Iron Chef where Nate Applewood (exec chef) battled and won! The TV said he was known for his pizza, so that's what we started with- the Margherita, and it was great. So fresh, just the right amount of everything. Then I had the gnocchi- best gnocchi I've ever had! It had so much flavor, absolutely recommend it to anyone, seriously just anyone. Finished off a very entertaining and delicious dinner with housemade chocolate gelato- really delicious! Probably the best part about all of this- it's all really reasonably priced! So summary of my 5 star rating- Fabulous/friendly service, awesome kitchen-viewing seats available (recommend you do that!), perfect pizzas, heavenly pastas, and scrumptious desserts!
author: Olivia F.

description: My first experience here was great! A friend and I shared all three pastas and loved each one. The ricotta wrapped in swiss chard was delicious (involtini). The service was wonderful, though the late night crowd can be a tad loud.  My second experience was a let down. I went for lunch and ordered pizza. The waitress was not polite and we were not impressed.  I would still go back for dinner because there is a longer more detailed, and changing menu.
author: Lisa J.

description: When you are the last man standing (and the last man starving!), head over to A-16 for a late night supper.  Last night, I witnessed a grown man, (a friend of mine) have a temper tantrum because we got turned away from several rests. in the Marina because the kitchen was closed and there was no food but Pizza Orgasmica to be found.  He refused to resort to that and would rather feed on beers until I suggested heading over to A-16.  At first we were told that they had stopped serving food, (it was around 10:30ish at this point) but there was a very kind man behind the bar who realized that my friend was about to pass out from hunger.  He got us a table right away and even told us to relax and take our time with ordering our food. The service was exceptional, (they never rushed us at any point in the night and even let us drink our wine at the 11th hour while they were closing). The food was really good and even though we made some additions to our order, (like extra mushrooms on the side), the kitchen did not mess it up.  The vino (I don't know my Italian wines like I know my Italian men) are really impressive there.  So, when your stomach starts growling late into the night, head over to A-16 for some delicious food and a cool wait staff as well.
author: Stacia F.

description: Finally went here last Sat-my clients rave about it but I can't plan 5 weeks in advance...I got out the calendar...the atmosphere was lively-dates, foodies, friends, girls-night-out.  We got the mozzerella app (WOW) with a pizza and pasta to share.  I liked the wine list-great prices and I liked the small pitcher/half bottle thing.  We got seated right away and our waiter was nice.  The price was OK and the whole experience was better than expected from these Yelp reviews-I take them very casually now because Yelpers like to trash places for fun...
author: Shannon J.

description: I've been to A16 on several occasions, but am finally getting around to writing a review.  My hubby and I have had dinner there several times at the bar and it was fun and casual.  There's nothing better than splitting the burratta, a salad and a pizza!  Well, we finally made reservations in advance and got a real table.  It was just ok.  The food was fine - we had the burrata, sardines, pork sausage and a pasta dish with baccala.  The service was rushed and we left without them packing up all of our yummy leftovers.  Needless to say my husband was sad when he realized they dumped our food.  I don't think we'll be back.
author: Charlotte C.

description: great place for a bottle of wine and a pizzia and when you sit in the back in the restraunt it feels like your not in san francisco anymore but like your some where in europe i really love the feel of this place
author: patrick o.

description: a-ok is what that star thing above this post reads, and that is fitting.  Quintessential Marina, both good and bad.  food just wasn't fitting for a place that requires reservations?  was that a bit harsh?  sorry, it must be past my bedtime.
author: Benson J.

description: Went for meatball Monday with some friends and was only regretting not getting the full servig for my meal after we tried them for the appetizer. Chef, servers ad front of house staff all really warm. Had an amazing glass of a white blend that was a pretty rare find and delicious. Gnocchi entrée was good gnocchi but a little on the flavorless side otherwise. Fennel sausage pizza that I tried was awesome. Overall worth the wait and a great, cozy spot on a rainy night.
author: Chris S.

description: my wife and i dined at A16 on valentines day...as opposed to some negative comments we had ready service was very good.  Food was excellent.  Extensive wine list. A tad noisy but we find thats the case for us most of the time anyways. Overall a fine experience and we would not hesitate to go again.
author: Joseph B.

description: The wines are amazing.  The pizza is delicious.  Everything else after that. . . not so much.  Bistro Aix down the street has far better fare.
author: Laura C.

description: Nice restaurant with good food. Service was efficient and the staff are very friendly and the waiter made a good recommendation of wine which fit the description of what I like. I would go back.
author: Joe C.

description: We went there on a Sunday and it was pretty busy. We had an appetizer, a pizza, and 2 entrees. Between the pizza and the 2 entrees, we waited for half an hour. The waitress made some excuse after 25 minutes that my dry pasta took a long time to make,  which I don't believe and which they didn't warn me from the beginning,  Overall, the food is very average. The staff isn't friendly (other than the hostess).
author: Helen L.

description: Totally uninspring.  I actually hated the atmosphere and felt it to be cold and unromantic.  The front room with the bar is beautiful and dark, but the back room was bright with tables crammed together.  Our food, for the most part, was fine, even good.  It just didn't live up to expectations as one of the premier restaurants in the city.  We got the mozzarella appetizer, which was good, the asparagus which was fine but overcooked, a pizza with sausage, which was good but I can get the same thing at Gialina's or Pauline's without a reservation, and a simple pasta dish, which was bad and tasted like Chef Boyardee.  Meal was $100 with wine and we were anxious to leave because the atmosphere was so claustsrophic.  Nothing was terrible, just disappointing.
author: Kristi S.

description: My favorite restaurant!!! It's expensive but rly rly rly good :D. They have the best spaghetti and bread ;)
author: Paulina A.

description: This is one of the few places in the states where I had pasta with a light red sauce that resembles the kind of sauce my grandmother makes.  Ate at the bar and had a pleasant dining experience.
author: Barbara K.

description: you will have to wait, no matter what you do.  we had reservations and still had to wait a good 45 minutes or more. what are all these people doing here at 9:30 on a Tuesday night??  the free champagne was nice, however.  but the service and food was what made this place top notch.  the wine recommendations were solid and the maccaronara was unbeatable - I  imagine this is what chef boyardi pasta tastes like if it underwent an extreme reality show makeover.  kind of a  "pimp my ride" version of canned pasta
author: K N.

description: This place was a nice little surprise for dinner in the marina. We had no idea it was so big until we walked to the back area. The ambiance is pretty cool - modern but cozy feel, wine was good, and pizzas were great! Not too oily, interesting varieties and combinations of ingredients - really yummy crust - very good overall. I'd definitely come back here for the pizza. The only thing lacking was the dessert. We got this chocolate tart situation - which had olive oil and sea salt on top .... who does that to chocolate honestly. Totally ruined the taste of the tart - we thought it might be an interesting combination initially and the waiter highly recommended it - but it was so weird! Definitely not an enjoyable way to end the meal. We also got another dessert which was kind of tiramisu-ish which was pretty good though - so I'm thinking this chocolate salt tart business might have just been a bad call on the part of the chef. Overall - really cute place, and they let us hang out there til like 130 am which was nice too. I'd come back again.
author: Anjali M.

description: This place isn't that bad. The food was really salty though. even the salad was salty. And the pizza was burnt. And when I ordered a drink instead of telling me they didn't have it they gave us a different drink and didn't tell us until we almost finished it. It wasn't that bad but it wasn't really that good.
author: Max H.

description: Love this place. Pastas, salumi and the thin pizzas are incredible. And I always order the roasted sardines when they are on the menu. Guys at the bar really know their wine and always recommend something interesting.
author: AJ R.

description: Great food.  It can be crowded so don't expect a quiet scene. I hosted my husband's birthday dinner here last year and the service was also fantastic. The sommelier is nice and great at what she does too. Make reservations . . . you'll need them.
author: Laly J.

description: I went last night and was blown away at how amazingly good the food was.  I had the pork loin with whole grain mustard and fresh black pepper and can't recall a dish I had with more intense flavors in it.   My date had the lamb meatballs which were good, but I felt I won on the main course.  We split a plate of the house-cured spicy lamb salami and the mozzarella Burrata to start.  I've never had salami that I wanted to let melt in my mouth like that.  The Southern Italian wine flight was a little hit or miss, but that's expected and forgiveable.   I'd like to wait a month or two and go again, as neither of us tried the pizzas, and I understand they're a high point.
author: Lamont L.

description: The decor is great and food is o.k. always a scene.  Great place for a glass a wine before dinner or if you want to be seen.
author: Maria R.

description: Excellent pizza, good pasta, good appetizers.  This place is a bit too crowded and busy during the weekends, but I've haven't been disappointed on weekdays.  I usually end up paying $30-45/person for wine/appetizer/entree/dessert.  I will definitely come back.
author: sei l.

description: My friends and I had all been told (on separate occasions) to check out A1 for the delicious wood fired oven pizza and "down home" Italian "cucina povera."  Alas, while the salads, appetizers and pizza were terrific (and tasted just like home -- all three diners were native Italians) our dining experience was ruined by the "ice queen" (as another reviewer noted -- I had a much more grafic depiction of her involving a wooden pole) hired as the wine steward.  She was at best snooty and at her worse she talked down to us, even after I explained that we were from the Old Country and that I was in the gourmet food business. And all because she did not really know what an Insalata Treviso was.  FYI Treviso is not another word for radicchio, "You know a salad green" as she put it BUT a potato and radiccio salad originally from Treviso. The wait staff was decidedly better but the whole experience left a disappointing taste in my mouth.  It made me either wanna go back just to mess with the staff or contact the owners to give them a piece of my mind! BLAH!
author: Mia C.

description: Went there last week and now understand why so hard to get a reservation.  I think their pizza dough was quite close to the ones i had in Italy and their pasta was very aromatic, fresh and with creative yet simply delicious ingredient. The salad was amazing too, it reminds me a plate i had in a neighbor hood restaurant near piazza republic in Rome.    I will go back as soon as i get another reservation.  Love it.  Just order tomato, mozzarella, basil and prosciutto pizza  you won't go wrong with that!
author: Josephine J.

description: My husband and I had dinner here after just walking in off the street. It was busy and I can understand why it does get the comments it does. It's not very authentic. We were in for more of a snack. We each had a salad and pizza and just a beer. My husband had the marinara pizza which he loved and I had the margherita pizza which was also very good. I would have to eat here again to really see if it's so great. It reminds me of a lot of other restaurants that have that new, swanky, young business professional feel to it. I do recommend that you have dinner here. It was crowded and be dressed as if you are out for the night. It's not as casual as I thought. It did have a warm atmosphere with dark wood tables and cork on the walls. It's worth trying. It may not be a restaurant for everyone....but you won't know until you try.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
food = 5 stars
location = negative 5 stars

a16 lives up to the rep for excellent food & wine.  everything we ordered from appetizer to dessert was fabulous.  the service we had was also excellent - our waiter had a great sense of humor and he was patient with us as a16 virgins.  too bad the location sucks!  the only negative i can give this place is due to the crowd that frequents it - they are jackasses.  i'm sure there were some non jackasses like us in there but unfortunately they weren't sitting in our area.  i should have known going in but i thought i'd give the marina a chance - silly me!  for what it's worth, i probably would gladly go back since the food is THAT good.
author: Shelley N.

description: The food is good, but it isn't worth waiting for... My last two visits, I waited 45 minutes each time to be seated, even though we had a reservation. One was a Saturday night, the other was a Monday night. I think this is incredibly inconsiderate.
author: Michael S.

description: This was the best pizza I've had in SF, just eclipsing my previous favorite at pizzeria delfina. The thin crust mushroom pizza was scorched on the edges like it should be, and it also managed to stay deliciously chewy, the amount of sauce and cheese was perfect, but there were a few too many enoki mushrooms for my liking. The pizza was surprisingly good value, unlike the wine - a glass sets you back more than a whole pizza. I tried four different Italian wines between $12 and $16 per glass and although they were not awful, they should have cost that per bottle.  I'll go back for the pizza, but next time I'm drinking beer - if they have any.
author: Matchak R.

description: For non rushed service in a non frat boy Marina eatery I would have to say that A16 is probably one of the better almost white table cloth restaurants in San Francisco. With a quintessential California/Italian Fusion cuisine A16 is definitely reminiscent to Zinzino, which actually occupied the same location during the mid to late 90's. Genuine wood fired pizza along with hand made pasta makes A16 a very sought after spot; precisely why I can only give four out of five stars. A16 is very difficult to get a table at, perhaps its reputation, perhaps it has to do with lack of space, nothing you can do about that, or maybe it has to do with the fact that the wait staff is far more interested in the guests having a good time then in moving people from appetizer, to entree, to dessert in record time, whatever the reason is, it is in fact very hard to get a table and often if you just sort of "show up" you may have to wait as long as an hour and a half for an open table... That being said all of those things have far less to do with whats being done wrong and are in fact a result of whats being done right.
author: Salvatore R.

description: Love it! Love it! Great wine and good. Although you do have to deal with the Marina, the food is wonderful and the vibe is worth it.
author: brandi w.

description: I've been to A16 on a regular night and have to say I had good food with great wine (as stated on most of their reviews).  But, feel compelled to comment on their NYE pre-set dinner.  It did not include any of their signature dishes (i.e. pizzas).  Instead, they tried to be more sophisticated than they are and serve things like crab meatballs and lasagna with unmelted cheese with some random cardboard-like truffles.  Plus, it was $120/person for the food and an additional $75 for the wine pairing. Our group of ten brought some of our favorite wines to serve with dinner, but were told we could only open three of our five bottles (after we called three separate times to make sure we could bring our own wine).
author: Andi B.

description: Overrated.  I think the pizzas are fine, but the rest of the food that I've had in my three visits has been just fair.  The wait is way too long for food that average.  Would not recommend this place to friends and choose other more friendly, cheaper solutions in the neighborhood and elsewhere.
author: Brian L.

description: Serving fantastic italian style thin crust pizza, this chic marina restraurant is a real treat for true pizza lovers. They mozzarella is also one of the best I've ever had.
author: Srinivas N.

description: This is one of the coolest places in San Francisco. It has atmosphere, great service and a fabulous wine selection. The food is Campania (think Naples) style and authentic (I have been there). I have taken a lot of people there, young and older, sophisticated and newbies to the restaurant scene or to San Francisco and have never been disappointed. I also organized my girlfriend's birthday party there last year and A16 came through magnificently. Admitedly, the place is crowded and difficult to get into at peak times but that is the flip side of success.
author: Jean-Louis F.

description: No longer for locals, every Mid- West business traveler on an expense account has found this place. The wine list is comprised of any bottle they can buy for $5.00 with no other distribution in the Bay Area  and sell to us for $16 a glass. They don't even buy from local distributors. Their Meatball Mondays was a success until they figured they were not making enough money on the "local bar crowd" and decided to cancel until all we locals complained and they started it up again.  Definitely not a cool place anymore.
author: Doc M.

description:
I had been wanting to try A16 since I first heard about it several years ago. I had very high expectations as the reviews have been good and it's been rated one of SF's top 100 restaurants...and I think the anticipation got me a little too.
The ambiance is romantic and cozy...we sat at the "chef's bar" toward the back and watched the cook's do their thing over the wood burning ovens. It was a warm night so it was a bit warm at our seats, but no unbearable.
I like the idea that they do things simply...not too many different flavors in one dish and no flavors that overpower the main ingredient(s) which a lot of restaurants try to do. And, of course, I love the idea that they have their own organic garden for much of their produce. 
Overall, however, my boyfriend and I were not blown away by the food. My grilled pork (kebob style) was a little too chewy and gristly and my boyfriend's chicken was nothing out of the ordinary. 
The service was great...our waitress had wonderfully reasonable suggestions for wine. And the wine list is good. 
I think to stay a  top restaurant in a city where good food is not hard to find, they'll have to be a little more inventive in complimenting the good, quality produce and meats to step up the flavor.
author: Jennifer R.

description: the food is excellent.  the service was good.  this place has mellowed a bit... like a good wine, I think it needed to breathe for a while.  a little more down-to-earth.. i love to sit at the chef's counter for a spontaneous bite.
author: Claire U.

description: After several attempts I finally got in at A-16.  Things did not start off as well as I would have liked due to a hostess with TOO much attitude.  Our server was very good and knowledgeable about the menu.  Started out with the tuna with favas, dandelions, etc. - the dish was just okay (tuna tasted fishy). Roasted sardines were excellent.  Funhi pizza had great flavor but the crust was so tender it was mushy. Ricotta gnocchi were very good, the mushroom just jumped out at you with flavor.  Butternut nut squash with pine nuts and currents were excellent.  Chocolate tart with olive oil and sea salt was nice with a very flaky chocolate crust but TOO MUCH salt.  Once I got home I must have drank a 1/2 gallon of water due to the over salting of the foods ( I haven't had this happen to me in years).  Overall we enjoyed our meal with the exception of the hostess, very small portions and saltiness of the food.  Will probably give it one more try before writing A-16 off.
author: chris a.

description: This place was amazing! The maccaronara pasta and the bianca pizza were FANTASTIC!!!! The wine was excellent! I don't care that this place is crowded, don't care that there's a long wait, the food is WORTH IT! And that's all I have to say about that.
author: esther Q.

description: The food here is horrible. I don't understand what all the hype is. I can't believe this place is still in business.
author: Sarah E.

description: Absolutely amazing restaurant.  Would recommend it to everyone and anyone. Service is great, food is exquisite. Pizza does remind me of Naples and the wine is great. The only downside to this great restaurant is that is can get pretty pricey. Other than that its a must see.
author: Wayne B.

description:
-1 for the impatient server ... she was getting rather impatient with my parents and i, when ordering... i promise you, we didn't even take THAT LONG. mind me, it WAS my first time there, but jeez louise ... 

for $55, late lunch // dinner was 5 stars, but like i said, the server ruined the experience...we weren't hungry so mind us in having a quick bite.

thanks to a friend who suggested this over Amici, it was well worth it!

-Margherita Pizza:  This was a wow.  Not your everyday deepdish, Chicago pie... Thin bottom crust, with a slight mild tangy tomato sauce, random pieces of cheese and basil throughout. ($12) With 3 people, you can easily kill it with 2 slices each. 5 stars
-Maccaronara w/ tomato ragu and house made ricotta salata ($8 for half size portion and $14 whole) 5 stars for taste, 1 star for portion. if you're a hungry hippo, then, i suggest the whole, i kid you not, you literally will eat this thing in seconds, you could prolly coil your pasta with a fork once or even twice, and then, it's gone. im not kidding!
-for a Monday night special, they had meatballs for $18, you get 6 huge bite sizes, and again, w/ 3 people, you get 2 pieces each, and it was fab. YUM!!! 5 stars. With this special, you were able to get any one of their 5 side dishes, and so we ordered the Cannellini beans w/garlic and oregano. I'm personally not fond of beans but this wasn't that bad at all, i'd prolly give it a 3.5 stars.

Great place for a date, or what not, or even for get togethers...The ambiance is great.  Make sure to make reservations, or i swear, you'll be waiting for almost an hour or two... My parents and I walked from A16, to the Marina 2x and we still had to wait 15 minutes...

Stay tuned for another 3 tomorrow:)
author: Jennifer S.

description: Clearly this place is resting on its laurels.  After the SF Chronicle Magazine listed it as one of the Top 100 Restaurants in the Bay Area, I agreed to go to dinner here with a group of girlfriends.  Bad idea.  Two of the people in our party of four showed up on time, but were told that our reservation would be cancelled if the rest of us were not there within 15 minutes of the reservation time.  Even though we were on our way.  I understand the need for people to be on time, but if you don't have valet parking, you should give a little lee-way - and be willing to seat the people who are there and willing to pay for your overpriced food.  Tables were way too close together - making it difficult to have a conversation, or make it to the restroom without a waiter rudely hitting you with their serving trays.  We ordered some artichoke/tuna appetizer (I think that's what it was) which was not edible as far as I was concerned.  Their famed pizza arrived at our table greasy and basically cold.  Gnocchi was decent, but nothing memorable.  The chocolate desserts were pretty good.  The service , however, was HORRIBLE.  The person who sat us had a strange staring problem, and the person clearing the table tried no less than four times to take away my plate while I was still eating from it.  The only excellent parts of the evening were my fellow eating companions, and the nice bottle of champagne we ordered.  Given the number of amazing restaurants in SF, I am absolutely shocked that this restaurant is ever recommended as a good place to go.  I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.  Except maybe an ex-boyfriend who I hoped wasn't going to score on his first date.
author: Anne H.

description: Me and my friend came in to A16 at 7:30 pm on a Thursday night and it was pretty packed. We were excited and the atmosphere was happening but yo can still talk without the loud background noise. We proceed to order roasted squid, mushroom pizza with prosciutto and squid ink pizza. Service was really slow as we were not offered any bread like what the rest of the patron are offered. The squid came and its good, crunchy with simple flavor. The mushroom pizza was normal,i had better in Beretta or Tommaso Ristorante, the crust is thicker and chewy compare to those two restaurant making it hard to bite or cut. The squid pasta was normal with more to the dry side. We order the chocolate tart for dessert and its very chocolate and taste pretty normal. I've been to better place and saw a lot other crowded restaurant around chestnut street and will visit other place. I would have given more star if they have a faster service!!
author: fourevindo h.

description: the wine selection is crazy there, and most of the food seems to complement the wine than vice versa. mostly i dig the pastas and starters at this italian joint.
author: John L.

description: Wow.  Rarely have I seen so much hype so little justified.  This place is pure attitude, zero substance.  Boring menu.  Mediocre cooking techniques.  Indifferent service.  I had a side of carrots, and they came out greasy, unevenly cooked, dismal.  I had a plate of four lamb cuts; the saddle had a breading that was soggy and flavorless. The other three cuts were ok, but nothing other than a chunk of meat on a plate.  That's it.  Four chunks of lamb and some soggy breading.  Appetizer was a very narrow notch above, with at least some reasonably well cooked asparagus.  To make our evening perfect, they kicked out the lady dining alone at the table next to us, trying to entice her to the bar with a free glass of champagne.  Real class act guys.
